original: aṅgasaṅkantito, ārammaṇasaṅkantito, aṅgārammaṇasaṅkantito, aṅgavavatthāpanato, ārammaṇavavatthāpanatoti.
analyzed: aṅga saṅkantitaḥ ārammaṇa saṅkantitaḥ aṅga ārammaṇa saṅkantitaḥ aṅga vavatthāpanataḥ ārammaṇa vavatthāpanato ti
translated: By way of the delimitation of the components, by way of the delimitation of the object, by way of the delimitation of the components and the object, by way of the definition of the components, by way of the definition of the object.

original: Imehi cuddasahi ākārehi cittaṃ paridametabbaṃ.
analyzed: imehi cuddasahi ākārehi cittam paridametabbam
translated: In these fourteen ways the mind is to be steadied.

original: 366. Katamaṃ panettha kasiṇānulomaṃ…pe… katamaṃ ārammaṇavavatthāpananti. Idha bhikkhu🔽pathavīkasiṇe jhānaṃ samāpajjati, tato āpokasiṇeti evaṃ paṭipāṭiyā aṭṭhasu kasiṇesu
analyzed: katamam pana ittha katamam ārammaṇa vavatthāpanam ti idha bhikkhu  pathavī kasiṇe jhānam samāpajjati tatas āpaḥ kasiṇā iti evam paṭipāṭiyā aṭṭhasu kasiṇesu
translated: What, in this context, is the order of the kasiṇas? … What is the definition of the object? Here,

original: satakkhattumpi sahassakkhattumpi samāpajjati, idaṃ kasiṇānulomaṃ nāma.
analyzed: sata khattum pi sahassa khattum pi samāpajjati idam kasiṇānulomam nāma
translated: a bhikkhu attains jhāna in the earth kasiṇa, then in the water kasiṇa, and so on—in the eight kasiṇas in forward order. He attains it in each one a thousand times. This is called the order of the kasiṇas.

original: Odātakasiṇato pana paṭṭhāya tatheva paṭilomakkamena samāpajjanaṃ kasiṇapaṭilomaṃ nāma.
analyzed: odāta kasiṇataḥ pana paṭṭhāya tathā iva paṭiloma kkamena samāpajjanam kasiṇapaṭilomam nāma
translated: But the reverse order is the attaining of jhāna in the white kasiṇa and so on in reverse order in the same way.

original: Pathavīkasiṇato paṭṭhāya yāva odātakasiṇaṃ, odātakasiṇatopi paṭṭhāya yāva pathavīkasiṇanti evaṃ anulomapaṭilomavasena punappunaṃ samāpajjanaṃ kasiṇānulomapaṭilomaṃ nāma.
analyzed: pathavī kasiṇataḥ paṭṭhāya yāva odāta kasiṇaṃ odāta kasiṇataḥ pi paṭṭhāya yāva pathavī kasiṇanti evam anuloma paṭiloma vasena punappunam samāpajjanam kasiṇānulomapaṭilomam nāma
translated: The order and reverse order of the kasiṇas is the attaining of jhāna in the earth kasiṇa and so on in forward order and in the white kasiṇa and so on in reverse order, again and again in each one a thousand times.

original: Paṭhamajjhānato pana paṭṭhāya paṭipāṭiyā yāva nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ, tāva punappunaṃ samāpajjanaṃ jhānānulomaṃ nāma.🔽Nevasaññānāsaññāyatanato paṭṭhāya yāva paṭhamajjhānaṃ, tāva punappunaṃ samāpajjanaṃ jhānapaṭilomaṃ nāma.
analyzed: paṭhamajjhānataḥ pana paṭṭhāya paṭipāṭiyā yāva nevasaññānāsaññāyatanam tāva punappunam samāpajjanam jhāna anulomam nāma  nevasaññānāsaññāyatanataḥ paṭṭhāya yāva paṭhamajjhānam tāva punappunam samāpajjanam jhānapaṭilomam nāma
translated: But the successive attainment of the jhānas in forward order from the first jhāna up to the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception, and the successive attainment of the jhānas in reverse order from the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception down to the first jhāna, is called “the order of the jhānas” .🔽The successive attainment of the jhānas in forward order from the first jhāna up to the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception, and the successive attainment of the jhānas in reverse order from the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception down to the first jhāna, in both instances beginning with the first jhāna, is called “the order of the jhānas in both directions” .🔽The successive attainment of the jhānas in forward order from the first jhāna up to the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception, and the successive attainment of the jhānas in reverse order from the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception down to the first jhāna, in both instances beginning with the first jhāna, is called “the order of the jhānas in both directions” .

original: Paṭhamajjhānato paṭṭhāya yāva nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ, nevasaññānāsaññāyatanato paṭṭhāya🔽yāva paṭhamajjhānanti evaṃ anulomapaṭilomavasena punappunaṃ samāpajjanaṃ jhānānulomapaṭilomaṃ nāma.
analyzed: paṭhamajjhānataḥ paṭṭhāya yāva nevasaññānāsaññāyatanam nevasaññānāsaññāyatanataḥ paṭṭhāya  yāva paṭhama jhānan ti evam anuloma paṭiloma vasena punappunam samāpajjanam jhāna anulomapaṭilomam nāma
translated: The successive attainment of the jhānas in forward order from the first jhāna up to the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception, and the successive attainment of the jhānas in reverse order from the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception down to the first jhāna, in both instances beginning with the first jhāna, is called “the order of the jhānas in both directions” .

original: Pathavīkasiṇe pana paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ samāpajjitvā tattheva tatiyaṃ samāpajjati, tato🔽tadeva ugghāṭetvā ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ, tato ākiñcaññāyatananti evaṃ kasiṇaṃ anukkamitvā🔽jhānasseva ekantarikabhāvena ukkamanaṃ jhānukkantikaṃ nāma. Evaṃ āpokasiṇādimūlikāpi yojanā kātabbā.
analyzed: pathavī kasiṇe pana paṭhamam jhānam samāpajjitvā tattha iva tatiyam samāpajjati tatas 🔽tat eva ugghāṭetvā ākāsa ānañca āyatanam tatas ākiñcaññāyatanam ti evam kasiṇam an ukkamitvā 🔽jhānassa iva ekantarika bhāvena ukkamanam jhānukkantikam nāma evam āpokasiṇa ādi mūlikā api yojanā kātabbā
translated: But the successive attainment of the first jhāna in the earth kasiṇa, and then the third jhāna in the same kasiṇa, and then the attainment of the base consisting of boundless space by surmounting that same kasiṇa, and then the attainment of the base consisting of nothingness by surmounting the base consisting of boundless consciousness, is called “the successive order of the jhānas” . The method should be worked out in detail in the case of the water kasiṇa, etc., too.

original: Pathavīkasiṇe paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ samāpajjitvā puna tadeva tejokasiṇe, tato nīlakasiṇe,🔽tato lohitakasiṇeti iminā nayena jhānaṃ anukkamitvā kasiṇasseva ekantarikabhāvena
analyzed: pathavī kasiṇe paṭhamam jhānam samāpajjitvā puna tat eva tejaḥ kasiṇe tatas nīla kasiṇe  tatas lohitakasiṇa iti iminā nayena jhānam an ukkamitvā kasiṇassa iva ekantarika bhāvena
translated: He enters upon the first jhāna in the earth kasiṇa, and then in the fire kasiṇa, then in the blue kasiṇa,

original: ukkamanaṃ kasiṇukkantikaṃ nāma.🔽Pathavīkasiṇe paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ samāpajjitvā tato tejokasiṇe tatiyaṃ, nīlakasiṇaṃ ugghāṭetvā🔽ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ, lohitakasiṇato ākiñcaññāyatananti iminā nayena jhānassa ceva kasiṇassa
analyzed: ukkamanam kasiṇukkantikam nāma  pathavī kasiṇe paṭhamam jhānam samāpajjitvā tatas tejaḥ kasiṇe tatiyam nīla kasiṇam ugghāṭetvā  ākāsānañcāyatanam lohitakasiṇato ākiñcaññāyatanan ti iminā nayena jhānassa ca iva kasiṇassa
translated: then in the red kasiṇa. This is called “succession of kasiṇas” since it is the succession of kasiṇas alone.

original: ca ukkamanaṃ jhānakasiṇukkantikaṃ nāma.🔽Pathavīkasiṇe pana paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ samāpajjitvā tattheva itaresampi samāpajjanaṃ aṅgasaṅkantikaṃ nāma.
analyzed: ca ukkamanam jhānakasiṇukkantikam nāma  pathavī kasiṇe pana paṭhamam jhānam samāpajjitvā tattha eva itaresam pi samāpajjanam aṅgasaṅkantikam nāma
translated: He enters upon the first jhāna in the earth kasiṇa, then in the fire kasiṇa he enters upon the third, and after removing the blue kasiṇa he enters upon the base consisting of boundless space, and after removing the red kasiṇa he enters upon the base consisting of nothingness. This is called “succession of jhānas and kasiṇas” since it is the succession of jhānas and kasiṇas.🔽But his entering upon the other jhānas in the earth kasiṇa only is called “succession of jhānas” since it is the succession of jhānas alone.

original: Pathavīkasiṇe paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ samāpajjitvā tadeva āpokasiṇe…pe… tadeva odātakasiṇeti evaṃ sabbakasiṇesu ekasseva jhānassa samāpajjanaṃ ārammaṇasaṅkantikaṃ nāma.
analyzed: pathavī kasiṇe paṭhamam jhānam samāpajjitvā tat eva tat eva odāta kasiṇe ti evam sabba kasiṇesu ekassa iva jhānassa samāpajjanam ārammaṇa saṅkantikam nāma
translated: His entering upon the first jhāna in the earth kasiṇa, and then in the water kasiṇa, and so on, and in the white kasiṇa, is called “succession of objects” since it is the succession of objects only.

original: Pathavīkasiṇe paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ samāpajjitvā āpokasiṇe dutiyaṃ, tejokasiṇe tatiyaṃ,
analyzed: pathavī kasiṇe paṭhamam jhānam samāpajjitvā āpaḥ kasiṇe dutiyam tejaḥ kasiṇe tatiyam
translated: Having attained the first jhāna in the earth kasiṇa, he attains the second in the water kasiṇa, the third in the fire kasiṇa,

original: vāyokasiṇe catutthaṃ, nīlakasiṇaṃ ugghāṭetvā ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ, pītakasiṇato viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ,🔽lohitakasiṇato ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ, odātakasiṇato nevasaññānāsaññāyatananti evaṃ ekantarikavasena
analyzed: vāyu kasiṇe catuttham nīla kasiṇam ugghāṭetvā ākāsānañca āyatanam pīta kasiṇataḥ viññāṇañca āyatanam  lohita kasiṇataḥ ākiñcaññāyatanam odāta kasiṇataḥ nevasaññānāsaññāyatanan ti evam ekantarika vasena
translated: the fourth in the air kasiṇa, and having surmounted the blue kasiṇa he attains the base consisting of boundless space, and having surmounted the yellow kasiṇa he attains the base consisting of boundless consciousness,

original: aṅgānañca ārammaṇānañca saṅkamanaṃ aṅgārammaṇasaṅkantikaṃ nāma.
analyzed: aṅgānaṃ ca ārammaṇānaṃ ca saṅkamanaṃ aṅgārammaṇasaṅkantikam nāma
translated: and having surmounted the red kasiṇa he attains the base consisting of nothingness, and having surmounted the white kasiṇa he attains the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception. This is called “interchanging of factors and of object.”

original: Paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ pana pañcaṅgikanti vavatthapetvā dutiyaṃ tivaṅgikaṃ, tatiyaṃ duvaṅgikaṃ,
analyzed: paṭhamam jhānam pana pañcaṅgikanti vavatthapetvā dutiyam tivaṅgikam tatiyam duvaṅgikam
translated: The defining of the first jhāna as having five factors and the second as having three factors, the third as having two factors,

original: tathā catutthaṃ ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ…pe… nevasaññānāsaññāyatananti evaṃ jhānaṅgamattasseva🔽vavatthāpanaṃ aṅgavavatthāpanaṃ nāma.
analyzed: tathā catuttham ākāsa anañcāyatanam pe nevasaññānāsaññāyatananti evam jhāna aṅga mattassa iva  vavatthāpanam aṅgavavatthāpanam nāma
translated: and likewise the fourth, the base consisting of boundless space, and so on, and the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception, is called “defining of factors.”

original: Tathā idaṃ pathavīkasiṇanti vavatthapetvā idaṃ āpokasiṇaṃ…pe… idaṃ odātakasiṇanti
analyzed: tathā idam pathavīkasiṇanti vavatthapetvā idam idam odātakasiṇanti
translated: Likewise, having defined the earth kasiṇa as this and the water kasiṇa as that, and the fire kasiṇa as this and the air kasiṇa as that, and the blue kasiṇa as this and the yellow kasiṇa as that, and the red kasiṇa as this and the white kasiṇa as that,

original: evaṃ ārammaṇamattasseva vavatthāpanaṃ ārammaṇavavatthāpanaṃ nāma. Aṅgārammaṇavavatthāpanampi🔽eke icchanti. Aṭṭhakathāsu pana anāgatattā addhā taṃ bhāvanāmukhaṃ na hoti.🔽367. Imehi pana cuddasahi ākārehi cittaṃ aparidametvā pubbe abhāvitabhāvano ādikammiko
analyzed: evam ārammaṇa mattassa iva vavatthāpanam ārammaṇa vavatthāpanam nāma aṅga ārammaṇa vavatthāpanam pi  eke icchanti aṭṭhakathāsu pana anāgata ttā addhā tam bhāvanā mukham na hoti  imehi pana cuddasahi ākārehi cittam a paridametvā pubbe abhāvita bhāvano ādikammiko
translated: So the defining of the object as mere object is called “defining of the object.”🔽Some want to include the defining of the parts of the kasiṇa as “defining of the object.” But since it is not mentioned in the commentaries, it is certainly not a way of developing it.🔽But if a beginner, who has not previously developed meditation and has not mastered his mind in these fourteen ways,

original: yogāvacaro iddhivikubbanaṃ sampādessatīti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati. Ādikammikassa hi🔽kasiṇaparikammampi bhāro, satesu sahassesu vā ekova sakkoti. Katakasiṇaparikammassa
analyzed: yogāvacaraḥ iddhi vikubbanam sampādessati iti na etam ṭhānam vijjati ādikammikassa hi  kasiṇa parikammam pi bhāraḥ satesu sahassesu vā ekaḥ iva sakkoti kata kasiṇa parikammassa
translated: were to try to accomplish the supernormal powers, it would be impossible.🔽For the preliminary work on the kasiṇa is a burden for one who has not done it, and only one in a hundred can do it.

original: nimittuppādanaṃ bhāro, satesu sahassesu vā ekova sakkoti. Uppanne nimitte taṃ vaḍḍhetvā🔽appanādhigamo bhāro, satesu sahassesu vā ekova sakkoti. Adhigatappanassa cuddasahākārehi
analyzed: nimitta uppādanam bhāraḥ satesu sahassesu vā ekaḥ iva sakkoti uppanne nimitte tam vaḍḍhetvā  appanā adhigamaḥ bhāraḥ satesu sahassesu vā ekaḥ iva sakkoti adhigata ppanassa cuddasahā ākārehi
translated: The production of the jhāna by developing the kasiṇa is a burden, and only one in a hundred can do it.🔽The attainment of absorption by producing the jhāna is a burden, and only one in a hundred can do it.

original: cittaparidamanaṃ bhāro, satesu sahassesu vā ekova sakkoti. Cuddasahākārehi paridamitacittassāpi

translated: The mastering of the mind in the fourteen ways by attaining absorption is a burden, and only one in a hundred can do it.

analyzed: iddhi vikubbanam nāma bhāraḥ satesu sahassesu vā ekaḥ iva sakkoti vikubbana ppattassa api
translated: The ability to perform miracles is a burden: out of a hundred or a thousand only one is able to do so.

analyzed: khippanisanti bhāvaḥ nāma bhāro satesu sahassesu vā ekaḥ iva khippanisantī hoti therambatthale
translated: The ability to make a quick decision is a burden: out of a hundred or a thousand only one is able to make a quick decision.🔽The Elder Ambatthaṭṭhaṇa,

analyzed: mahārohaṇagutta therassa gilāna upaṭṭhānam āgatesu tiṃsa mattesu iddhimanta sahassesu

analyzed: upasampadāya aṭṭhavassikaḥ rakkhita theraḥ viya tassa anubhāvo pathavīkasiṇa niddese  vuttaḥ yā iva tam panassa anubhāvam disvā theraḥ āha āvuso sace rakkhito na abhavissa sabbe

analyzed: garaha ppattāḥ assāma nāga rājānam rakkhitum na asakkhiṃsu iti tasmai attanā gahetvā vicaritabbam  āvudham nāma malam sodhetvā ava gahetvā vicaritum vaṭṭati iti te therassa ovāde ṭhatvā
translated: Seeing his ability, the elder said, “Friends, if Rakkhita had not been there, we all would have been lost. They would have said, ‘They could not protect the king of the nāgas.’ So one should go about taking one’s own protection.🔽A weapon should be cleaned before it is taken up and then used.” The thirty thousand monks, following the elder’s advice,

analyzed: khippa nisantiyā api ca sati parassa patiṭṭhā bhāvaḥ bhāro satesu sahassesu vā ekaḥ uva

translated: is able to do this, like the Elder who, when Māra caused a rain of embers to fall in the Giribhaṇḍavāhana Shrine, made the earth appear in the sky

analyzed: aṅgāra vassa parittārakaḥ theraḥ viya  balava pubba yogānam pana buddha paccekabuddha aggasāvaka ādīnam vinā api iminā vutta ppakārena  bhāvanā anukkamena arahatta paṭilābhena iva idam ca iddhi vikubbanam aññe ca paṭisambhidā ādi bhedā
translated: to protect from the rain of embers.🔽But for those who have previously exerted themselves with strength, such as Buddhas, Paccekabuddhas, chief disciples, etc., this psychic power and other qualities such as the analytical knowledges are successful

analyzed: guṇāḥ ijjhanti tasmai yathā piḷandhana vikatim kattu kāmaḥ suvaṇṇakāraḥ aggi dhamana ādīhi  suvaṇṇam mudum kammaññam katvā ava karoti yathā ca bhājana vikatim kattu kāmaḥ kumbhakāraḥ
translated: even without the development of the aforementioned kind of gradual training, simply by the attainment of arahatship. Therefore, just as a goldsmith who wants to make an ornament🔽makes the gold malleable and wieldy by heating it, etc., and then does his work, and just as a potter who wants to make a pot🔽makes the clay malleable by kneading it and then does his work, so too, the beginner should

original: mattikaṃ suparimadditaṃ muduṃ katvā karoti, evameva ādikammikena imehi cuddasahākārehi
analyzed: mattikam su parimadditam mudum katvā karoti evam eva ādikammikena imehi cuddasahā ākārehi
translated: make the mind malleable and wieldy by means of these fourteen aspects

original: cittaṃ paridametvā chandasīsacittasīsavīriyasīsavīmaṃsāsīsasamāpajjanavasena ceva
analyzed: cittam ca iva
translated: and having controlled his mind, by means of the will, the mind, energy, investigation, and concentration faculties,🔽

original: āvajjanādivasībhāvavasena ca muduṃ kammaññaṃ katvā iddhividhāya yogo karaṇīyo. Pubbahetusampannena
analyzed: āvajjana ādivasībhāva vasena ca mudum kammaññam katvā iddhi vidhāya yogaḥ karaṇīyaḥ pubba hetu sampannena

But one who possesses the requisite conditions for this should do it even though he has not reached jhāna in the earth kasiṇa, etc.,

original: pana kasiṇesu catutthajjhānamatte ciṇṇavasināpi kātuṃ vaṭṭati. Yathā panettha yogo
analyzed: pana kasiṇesu catuttha jhāna matte kātum vaṭṭati yathā pana ittha yogo
translated: and he should do it even though he is not skilled in the attainment of the four jhānas in the earth kasiṇa, etc.

original: kātabbo, taṃ vidhiṃ dassento bhagavā “so evaṃ samāhite citte”tiādimāha.🔽368. Tatrāyaṃ pāḷinayānusāreneva vinicchayakathā. Tattha soti so adhigatacatutthajjhāno
analyzed: kātabbaḥ tam vidhim dassentaḥ bhagavā saḥ evam samāhite citta iti ādim āha  tatra ayam pāḷi naya anusārena iva vinicchaya kathā tattha saḥ ti saḥ adhigata catuttha jhāno
translated: Now, showing the way to undertake it, the Blessed One said, “When his concentrated mind,” etc.🔽Here is a commentary on the text according to the method of exposition by the Ancients. Herein, he: the meditator who has reached the fourth jhāna.

original: yogī. Evanti catutthajjhānakkamanidassanametaṃ. Iminā paṭhamajjhānādhigamādinā kamena
analyzed: yogī evanti catuttha jhāna kkama nidassanam etam iminā paṭhama jhāna adhigama ādinā kamena
translated: Thus: this shows the way to reach the fourth jhāna. By this means, namely, by reaching the first jhāna, etc.,

original: catutthajjhānaṃ paṭilabhitvāti vuttaṃ hoti. Samāhiteti iminā catutthajjhānasamādhinā
analyzed: catuttha jhānam paṭilabhitvā iti vuttam hoti samāhita iti iminā catuttha jhāna samādhinā
translated: he obtains the fourth jhāna: that is what is meant. Concentrated: concentrated by means of the fourth jhāna.

original: samāhite. Citteti rūpāvacaracitte. Parisuddhetiādīsu pana upekkhāsatipārisuddhibhāvena
analyzed: samāhite citta iti rūpāvacara citte parisuddha iti ādīsu pana upekkhā sati pārisuddhi bhāvena
translated: Mind: fine-material-sphere consciousness. Pure:

original: parisuddhe. Parisuddhattāyeva pariyodāte, pabhassareti vuttaṃ hoti. Sukhādīnaṃ paccayānaṃ🔽ghātena vihatarāgādiaṅgaṇattā anaṅgaṇe. Anaṅgaṇattāyeva vigatūpakkilese. Aṅgaṇena
analyzed: parisuddhe parisuddha ttāya iva pariyodāte pabhassarā iti vuttam hoti sukha ādīnam paccayānam  ghātena vihata rāga ādi aṅgaṇa ttā an aṅgaṇe an aṅgaṇa ttāya iva vigata upakkilese aṅgaṇena
translated: It is purified, that is, it is quite clear and bright, quite transparent and pure.🔽It is without blemish, that is, it is free from the stain of lust, etc., that defile the factors of enlightenment.🔽It is without defilement, that is, it is free from the defilements of lust, etc., that defile the mind.

original: hi taṃ cittaṃ upakkilissati. Subhāvitattā mudubhūte, vasībhāvappatteti vuttaṃ hoti.🔽Vase vattamānaṃ hi cittaṃ mudunti vuccati. Muduttāyeva ca kammaniye, kammakkhame
analyzed: hi tam cittam upakkilissati su bhāvita ttā mudu bhūte vasībhāva ppattā iti vuttam hoti  vase vattamānam hi cittam mudunti vuccati mudu ttāya iva ca kammaniye kamma kkhame
translated: It is malleable, that is, it has become wieldy and wieldy in what way?

original: kammayoggeti vuttaṃ hoti. Muduṃ hi cittaṃ kammaniyaṃ hoti sudantamiva suvaṇṇaṃ, tañca🔽ubhayampi subhāvitattāyevāti. Yathāha “nāhaṃ, bhikkhave, aññaṃ ekadhammampi samanupassāmi,
analyzed: kamma yoggā iti vuttam hoti mudum hi cittam kammaniyam hoti su dantam iva suvaṇṇam tat ca  ubhayam pi su bhāvita ttāya iva ati yathā āha na aham bhikkhave aññam eka dhammam pi samanupassāmi
translated: In that it is workable, that is, it is fit for working on, like well-smelted gold that can be worked on by a goldsmith.🔽And both these terms “workable” and “fit for working on” are used because it is well developed.

original: yaṃ evaṃ bhāvitaṃ bahulīkataṃ muduñca hoti kammaniyañca, yathayidaṃ, bhikkhave, citta”nti.
analyzed: yam evam bhāvitam bahulīkatam mudun ca hoti kammaniyam ca yathā idam bhikkhave cittan ti
translated: For it is said: “Bhikkhus, I do not consider any single thing so workable and wieldy as the mind. When the mind is workable and wieldy, bhikkhus, then is the time for exercising it” .

original: Etesu parisuddhabhāvādīsu ṭhitattā ṭhite. Ṭhitattāyeva āneñjappatte, acale niriñjaneti
analyzed: etesu parisuddha bhāva ādīsu ṭhita ttā ṭhite ṭhita ttāya iva āneñja ppatte acale niriñjane iti
translated: It is steady, that is, it is established in the states of purification, etc., mentioned above.🔽It is imperturbable, that is, it has attained the imperturbability of being unmoved by the agitation of lust, etc., and by the agitation of the signs of the material and immaterial dhammas.

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Mudukammaññabhāvena vā attano vase ṭhitattā ṭhite. Saddhādīhi pariggahitattā
analyzed: vuttam hoti mudu kammañña bhāvena vā attanaḥ vase ṭhita ttā ṭhite saddhā ādīhi pariggahita ttā
translated: is what is meant. Or alternatively, it is steady because it is established in its own state by the quality of being malleable and wieldy.🔽It has reached imperturbability because it is possessed of faith, etc.,

original: āneñjappatte. Saddhāpariggahitaṃ hi cittaṃ assaddhiyena na iñjati. Vīriyapariggahitaṃ
analyzed: āneñja ppatte saddhā pariggahitam hi cittam assaddhiyena na iñjati vīriya pariggahitam
translated: for a mind possessed of faith does not waver through lack of faith;🔽a mind possessed of energy does not waver through idleness;

original: kosajjena na iñjati. Satipariggahitaṃ pamādena na iñjati. Samādhipariggahitaṃ uddhaccena
analyzed: kosajjena naḥ iñjati sati pariggahitam pamādena naḥ iñjati samādhi pariggahitam uddhaccena
translated: a mind possessed of mindfulness does not waver through negligence;🔽a mind possessed of concentration does not waver through agitation;

original: na iñjati. Paññāpariggahitaṃ avijjāya na iñjati. Obhāsagataṃ kilesandhakārena na
analyzed: na iñjati paññā pariggahitam avijjāya na iñjati obhāsa gatam kilesa andhakārena na
translated: a mind possessed of understanding does not waver through ignorance;

original: iñjati. Imehi chahi dhammehi pariggahitaṃ āneñjappattaṃ hoti. Evaṃ aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgataṃ
analyzed: iñjati imehi chahi dhammehi pariggahitam āneñja ppattam hoti evam aṭṭhaṅga samannāgatam
translated: a mind possessed of these six things has reached imperturbability.

original: cittaṃ abhinīhārakkhamaṃ hoti abhiññāsacchikaraṇīyānaṃ dhammānaṃ abhiññāsacchikiriyāya.
analyzed: cittam abhinīhāra kkhamam hoti abhiññā sacchikaraṇīyānam dhammānam abhiññā sacchikiriyāya
translated: A mind that possesses these eight factors is fit for exertion in the act of direct-knowledge, for the direct-knowledge of ideas that can be directly known.🔽Another method: it is concentrated by means of the concentration of the fourth jhāna;

original: Aparo nayo, catutthajjhānasamādhinā samāhite. Nīvaraṇadūrabhāvena parisuddhe. Vitakkādisamatikkamena
analyzed: aparaḥ nayaḥ catuttha jjhāna samādhinā samāhite nīvaraṇa dūra bhāvena parisuddhe vitakka ādi samatikkamena
translated: it is purified by means of the purification of the distance of the hindrances;🔽it is bright by means of the surpassing of applied-thoughts, sustained-thoughts, in-breaths and out-breaths, rapture, happiness, and unification of cognizance.

original: pariyodāte. Jhānapaṭilābhapaccayānaṃ icchāvacarānaṃ abhāvena anaṅgaṇe. Abhijjhādīnaṃ
analyzed: pariyodāte jhāna paṭilābha paccayānaṃ icchā avacarānam abhāvena anaṅgaṇe abhijjhā ādīnam
translated: in the purified, in the uncluttered, because of the absence of the requisites of the jhānas, of the sense-desire range.

original: cittassa upakkilesānaṃ vigamena vigatūpakkilese. Ubhayampi cetaṃ anaṅgaṇasuttavatthasuttānusārena🔽veditabbaṃ. Vasippattiyā mudubhūte. Iddhipādabhāvūpagamena kammaniye. Bhāvanāpāripūriyā
analyzed: cittassa upakkilesānam vigamena vigata upakkilese ubhayam pi anaṅgaṇa suttavattha sutta anusārena  veditabbam vasi ppattiyā mudu bhūte iddhipāda bhāva upagamena kammaniye bhāvanā pāripūriyā
translated: and purified. And in the absence of the limbs of greed, such as desire for the attainment of jhāna, it is without blemish. And with the disappearance of the defilements of the mind such as covetousness,🔽it is without stain. And both these terms should be understood here in the way described in the Anaṅgaṇasutta and its commentary.

original: paṇītabhāvūpagamena ṭhite āneñjappatte. Yathā āneñjappattaṃ hoti, evaṃ ṭhiteti attho.
analyzed: paṇīta bhāva upagamena ṭhite āneñjappatte yathā āneñjappattam hoti evam ṭhitā iti attho
translated: It is malleable because it has become wieldy through the attainment of mastery. It is wieldy because it has become a footing for the roads of direct knowledge by the attainment of the roads of psychic power. It is steady because it has become excellent through the completion of development. It is attained to imperturbability because it has reached imperturbability. The meaning is that it is steady in that it has reached imperturbability.

original: Evampi aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgataṃ cittaṃ abhinīhārakkhamaṃ hoti abhiññāsacchikaraṇīyānaṃ
analyzed: evam pi aṭṭhaṅga samannāgatam cittam abhinīhāra kkhamam hoti abhiññā sacchikaraṇīyānam
translated: So when the mind possesses these eight factors it is wieldy for the arousing of direct-knowledge, and it is a footing for the realization of the states of the kinds of direct-knowledge.

original: dhammānaṃ abhiññāsacchikiriyāya pādakaṃ padaṭṭhānabhūtanti.
analyzed: dhammānam abhiññā sacchikiriyāya pādakam padaṭṭhāna bhūtanti
translated: This is the section of the detailed explanation dealing with the question, “What is direct-knowledge?”

original: Dasaiddhikathā🔽369. Iddhividhāya cittaṃ abhinīharati abhininnāmetīti ettha ijjhanaṭṭhena iddhi,
analyzed: dasa aiddhi kathā  iddhi vidhāya cittam abhinīharati abhininnāmeti iti ettha iddhi
translated: The ten powers🔽Herein, it is successful in the sense of succeeding, and in the sense of obtaining,

original: nipphattiatthena paṭilābhaṭṭhena cāti vuttaṃ hoti. Yañhi nipphajjati paṭilabbhati
analyzed: nipphatti atthena paṭilābha aṭṭhena ca ati vuttam hoti yat hi nipphajjati paṭilabbhati
translated: for it is that by means of which one succeeds, by which one obtains, what is to be succeeded in and obtained.

original: ca, taṃ ijjhatīti vuccati. Yathāha “kāmaṃ kāmayamānassa, tassa cetaṃ samijjhatī”ti.
analyzed: ca tam ijjhati iti vuccati yathā āha kāmam kāmayamānassa tassa ca itam samijjhati iti
translated: and that is called success. As it is said: “If one who longs for sensual desires Should gain his wish, he would be happy” .

original: Tathā “nekkhammaṃ ijjhatīti iddhi, paṭiharatīti pāṭihāriyaṃ. Arahattamaggo ijjhatīti
analyzed: tathā nekkhammam ijjhati iti iddhi paṭiharati iti pāṭihāriyam arahatta maggo ijjhati iti
translated: And so too: “Renunciation is success; it is a miracle that one can renounce. The path of arahantship is success;

original: iddhi, paṭiharatīti pāṭihāriya”nti.
analyzed: id hi paṭiharati iti
translated: it is a miracle that one can attain it” .

original: Aparo nayo, ijjhanaṭṭhena iddhi. Upāyasampadāyetamadhivacanaṃ. Upāyasampadā hi ijjhati
analyzed: aparaḥ nayaḥ ijjhan aṭṭhena upāya sampadāya itam adhivacanam upāya sampadā hi ijjhati
translated: Another method: it is success in the sense of succeeding. It is a term for the equipment of the means. For that succeeds in producing the desired fruit,

original: adhippetaphalappasavanato. Yathāha – “ayaṃ kho citto gahapati sīlavā kalyāṇadhammo,
analyzed: adhippeta phala ppasavanataḥ yathā āha ayam kho cittaḥ gahapati sīlavā kalyāṇa dhammo
translated: as it is said: “This Citta the householder is virtuous and of good character.

original: sace paṇidahissati ‘anāgatamaddhānaṃ rājā assaṃ cakkavattī’ti, tassa kho ayaṃ ijjhissati
analyzed: sace paṇidahissati anāgatam addhānam rājā assam cakkavattī iti tassa kho ayam ijjhissati
translated: If he were to aspire to be a Wheel-turning Monarch in the future, that would succeed for him,

original: sīlavato cetopaṇidhi visuddhattā”ti.
analyzed: sīlavataḥ cetaḥ paṇidhi visuddhattā ati
translated: because of the purity of his aspiration due to his virtue” .

original: Aparo nayo, etāya sattā ijjhantīti iddhi. Ijjhantīti iddhā vuddhā ukkaṃsagatā hontīti
analyzed: aparaḥ nayaḥ etāya sattāḥ ijjhanti iti iddhi ijjhanti iti iddhāḥ vuddhāḥ ukkaṃsa gatāḥ honti iti
translated: Another method: it is success because beings succeed by it. They succeed, grow, and reach the summit, is what is meant.

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Sā dasavidhā. Yathāha “kati iddhiyoti dasa iddhiyo”. Puna caparaṃ āha
analyzed: vuttam hoti sā dasavidhā yathā āha kati iddhiyaḥ ti dasa iddhiyaḥ puna ca param āha
translated: It is of ten kinds, according to: “How many kinds of success are there? There are these ten kinds of success” . And he also says:

original: “katamā dasa iddhiyo? Adhiṭṭhānā iddhi, vikubbanā iddhi, manomayā iddhi, ñāṇavipphārā
analyzed: katamāḥ dasa iddhiyaḥ adhiṭṭhānāḥ iddhi vikubbanāḥ iddhi manas mayāḥ iddhi ñāṇa vipphārā
translated: “What are the ten kinds of success? Success through determination, success through transformation, success through mind-mastery, success through knowledge-mastery,

original: iddhi, samādhivipphārā iddhi, ariyā iddhi, kammavipākajā iddhi, puññavato iddhi,
analyzed: iddhi samādhi vipphārāḥ iddhi ariyāḥ iddhi kamma vipāka jāḥ iddhi puññavataḥ iddhi
translated: What are the ten kinds of success? Success by resolve, success by transformation, success by mind-made body, success by supernormal power, success by intervention, success by concentration, noble success, success as kamma-result, success as merit, success as knowledge. Herein, success by resolve is the success shown thus: “One resolves upon one, resolves upon many, resolves upon the diversity of resolve, resolves upon creation, resolves upon transformation” . It is called success by resolve because it is produced by resolve.

original: vijjāmayā iddhi, tattha tattha sammāpayogapaccayā ijjhanaṭṭhena iddhī”ti.
analyzed: vijjā mayā iddhi tattha tattha sammā payoga paccayā iddhi iti
translated: Success by transformation is the success shown thus: “He manifests himself as a youth, with perfect organ s, complete in every respect” , and the rest. It is called success by transformation because it occurs by the transformation of the normal appearance.

original: 370. Tattha “pakatiyā eko bahukaṃ āvajjati. Sataṃ vā sahassaṃ vā satasahassaṃ vā
analyzed: tattha pakatiyā ekaḥ bahukam āvajjati satam vā sahassam vā sata sahassam vā
translated: Success by supernormal power is the success shown thus: “He wields the various kinds of supernormal power: having been one he becomes many” , and the rest. original: āvajjitvā ñāṇena adhiṭṭhāti ‘bahuko homī”’ti evaṃ vibhajitvā dassitā iddhi adhiṭṭhānavasena

original: nipphannattā adhiṭṭhānā iddhi nāma.🔽371. “So pakativaṇṇaṃ vijahitvā kumārakavaṇṇaṃ vā dasseti nāgavaṇṇaṃ vā…pe… vividhampi🔽senābyūhaṃ dassetī”ti evaṃ āgatā iddhi pakativaṇṇavijahanavikāravasena pavattattā

translated: He resolves: he makes it tend towards and strive for the supernormal power to be attained. He,🔽the bhikkhu who has thus directed his mind,🔽Many a kind: of many kinds, of various kinds. Supernormal powers: bases of supernormal power.

original: Paccanubhotīti paccanubhavati, phusati sacchikaroti pāpuṇātīti attho. Idānissa anekavihitabhāvaṃ
analyzed: paccanubhoti iti paccanubhavati phusati sacchikaroti pāpuṇāti iti atthaḥ idānissa aneka vihita bhāvam
translated: He wields: he experiences, he contacts, he realizes, he achieves, is the meaning. Now, in order to show his “many a kind,”

original: dassento “ekopi hutvā”tiādimāha. Tattha ekopi hutvāti iddhikaraṇato pubbe pakatiyā
analyzed: dassentaḥ ekaḥ api hutvā iti ādim āha tattha ekaḥ api hutvā ti iddhikaraṇato pubbe pakatiyā
translated: he said “As one, so many” . Herein, as one: before he exercised supernormal power he was normally one only.

original: ekopi hutvā. Bahudhā hotīti bahūnaṃ santike caṅkamitukāmo vā sajjhāyaṃ vā kattukāmo🔽pañhaṃ vā pucchitukāmo hutvā satampi sahassampi hoti. Kathaṃ panāyamevaṃ hoti? Iddhiyā
analyzed: ekaḥ api hutvā bahudhā hoti iti bahūnam santike caṅkamitu kāmaḥ vā sajjhāyam vā kattu kāmaḥ 🔽pañham vā pucchitu kāmaḥ hutvā satam pi sahassam pi hoti katham pana ayam evam hoti iddhiyā
translated: So many: he becomes two, three, four, and so on up to a hundred, or he becomes more than that.🔽How does he become so many? By means of supernormal power.

original: catasso bhūmiyo cattāro pādā aṭṭha padāni soḷasa ca mūlāni sampādetvā ñāṇena adhiṭṭhahanto.
analyzed: catasso bhūmiyaḥ cattāro pādāḥ aṭṭha padāni soḷasa ca mūlāni sampādetvā ñāṇena adhiṭṭhahanto
translated: He is one who, having completed the four bases of success, the four roads to power, the eight attainments, and the sixteen kinds of knowledge, resolves with knowledge.

original: 381. Tattha catasso bhūmiyoti cattāri jhānāni veditabbāni. Vuttañhetaṃ dhammasenāpatinā🔽“iddhiyā katamā catasso bhūmiyo? Vivekajabhūmi paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ, pītisukhabhūmi dutiyaṃ
analyzed: tattha catasso bhūmiyaḥ ti cattāri jhānāni veditabbāni vuttam ha etam dhammasenāpatinā  iddhiyā katamā catassaḥ bhūmiyaḥ viveka ja bhūmi paṭhamam jhānam pīti sukha bhūmi dutiyam
translated: Herein, the four bases are the four jhānas to be understood. For this is said by the General of the Dhamma:

original: jhānaṃ, upekkhāsukhabhūmi tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ, adukkhamasukhabhūmi catutthaṃ jhānaṃ. Iddhiyā🔽imā catasso bhūmiyo iddhilābhāya iddhipaṭilābhāya iddhivikubbanatāya iddhivisavitāya
analyzed: jhānam upekkhā sukha bhūmi tatiyam jhānam adukkham asukha bhūmi catuttham jhānam iddhiyā  imāḥ catasso bhūmiyaḥ iddhi lābhāya iddhi paṭilābhāya iddhi vikubbanatāya iddhi visavitāya
translated: “What are the four bases for success? The first jhāna is the base consisting of seclusion by suppression of applied and sustained thought; the second jhāna is the base consisting of bliss by fading of happiness; the third jhāna is the base consisting of unity by sweeping aside perception of diversity; the fourth jhāna is the base consisting of neither-pain-nor-pleasure by abandoning pleasure and pain.

original: iddhivasitāya iddhivesārajjāya saṃvattantī”ti. Ettha ca purimāni tīṇi jhānāni yasmā🔽pītipharaṇena ca sukhapharaṇena ca sukhasaññañca lahusaññañca okkamitvā lahumudukammaññakāyo
analyzed: iddhi vasitāya iddhi vesārajjāya saṃvattanti iti ettha ca purimāni tīṇi jhānāni yasmā  pīti pharaṇena ca sukha pharaṇena ca sukha saññañca lahu saññañca okkamitvā lahu mudu kammañña kāyo
translated: These are the four bases for success that lead to obtaining success, to obtaining the various kinds of success, to success in the various kinds of psychic power, to success in the various kinds of creation, to success in the various kinds of resolution, to success in the various kinds of deep knowledge, to success in the various kinds of influence” .

original: iddhiṃ pāpuṇāti, tasmā iminā pariyāyena iddhilābhāya saṃvattanato sambhārabhūmiyoti
analyzed: iddhim pāpuṇāti tasmai iminā pariyāyena iddhi lābhāya saṃvattanataḥ
translated: And here the first three jhānas are called the “base consisting of success in obtaining” because one who has entered upon them obtains success in obtaining the various kinds of psychic power, since he obtains the various kinds of psychic power by entering upon them.🔽And the fourth jhāna is called the “base consisting of success in creation” because one who has entered upon it creates the various kinds of creation, since he creates the various kinds of creation by entering upon it.🔽And the four bases are called “bases for success” because they are the bases for the success consisting of obtaining and the success consisting of creation.

original: veditabbāni. Catutthajjhānaṃ pana iddhilābhāya pakatibhūmiyeva.🔽382. Cattāro pādāti cattāro iddhipādā veditabbā. Vuttañhetaṃ “iddhiyā katame cattāro🔽pādā? Idha bhikkhu chandasamādhipadhānasaṅkhārasamannāgataṃ iddhipādaṃ bhāveti. Vīriya…🔽citta… vīmaṃsāsamādhipadhānasaṅkhārasamannāgataṃ iddhipādaṃ bhāveti. Iddhiyā ime🔽cattāro pādā iddhilābhāya…pe… iddhivesārajjāya saṃvattantī”ti. Ettha ca chandahetuko
analyzed: veditabbāni catuttha jhānam pana iddhi lābhāya pakati bhūmiyā iva  cattāraḥ pādā ti cattāraḥ iddhipādāḥ veditabbāḥ vuttam ha etam iddhiyā katame cattāro  idha bhikkhu chanda samādhi padhāna saṅkhāra samannāgatam iddhipādam bhāveti  vīmaṃsā samādhi padhāna saṅkhāra samannāgatam iddhipādam bhāveti iddhiyai ime  cattāraḥ pādāḥ iddhi lābhāya pe iddhi vesārajjāya saṃvattanti iti ettha ca chanda hetukaḥ
translated: The fourth jhāna is the natural state for the attainment of success.

original: chandādhiko vā samādhi chandasamādhi. Kattukamyatāchandaṃ adhipatiṃ karitvā paṭiladdhasamādhissetaṃ🔽adhivacanaṃ. Padhānabhūtā saṅkhārā padhānasaṅkhārā. Catukiccasādhakassa sammappadhānavīriyassetaṃ🔽adhivacanaṃ. Samannāgatanti chandasamādhinā ca padhānasaṅkhārehi ca upetaṃ. Iddhipādanti
analyzed: chanda adhikaḥ vā samādhi chanda samādhi adhipatim karitvā paṭiladdha samādhiḥ sa etam 🔽adhivacanam padhāna bhūtā saṅkhārā padhāna saṅkhārā catu kicca sādhakassa sammappadhāna vīriyassa etam 🔽adhivacanam chanda samādhinā ca padhāna saṅkhārehi ca upetam
translated: The four bases: the four bases for success should be understood. For this is said: “What are the four bases for success? Here a bhikkhu develops the basis for success that possesses both concentration due to zeal and the will to strive as a factor of concentration. He develops the basis for success that possesses both concentration due to energy … concentration due to purity of consciousness … concentration due to inquiry and the will to strive as a factor of concentration. These four bases for success lead to the attainment of the various kinds of success that are to be attained by one who has energy, by one who is strong, by one of manly effort, by one who is a champion. ” Herein, concentration due to zeal is concentration due to zeal as cause or concentration due to zeal as predominance. This is a term for concentration obtained by making zeal or the desire to act predominant. Striving formations are formations that are striving. This is a term for right effort that accomplishes the fourfold task. Possesses: is endowed with. Bases for success:

original: nipphattipariyāyena vā ijjhanaṭṭhena, ijjhanti etāya sattā iddhā vuddhā ukkaṃsagatā🔽hontīti iminā vā pariyāyena iddhīti saṅkhaṃ gatānaṃ abhiññācittasampayuttānaṃ chandasamādhipadhānasaṅkhārānaṃ
analyzed: nipphatti pariyāyena vā ijjhana ṭṭhena ijjhanti etāya sattāḥ iddhāḥ vuddhāḥ ukkaṃsa gatāḥ  honti iti iminā vā pariyāyena iddhi iti saṅkham gatānam abhiññā citta sampayuttānam chanda samādhi padhāna saṅkhārānam
translated: Or alternatively, they are called success because they succeed in the sense of being accomplished, or because they succeed in the sense of being fulfilled, or because they succeed in the sense of being perfected, or because they succeed in the sense of being attained. Beings are successful, fulfilled, perfected, attained, by means of them, thus they are called success .

original: adhiṭṭhānaṭṭhena pādabhūtaṃ sesacittacetasikarāsinti attho. Vuttañhetaṃ “iddhipādoti
analyzed: adhiṭṭhāna ṭṭhena pāda bhūtam sesa citta cetasika rāsin ti attho vuttam ha etam iddhipādaḥ ti
translated: Or alternatively, they are called success because they are known as “success” in the sense of being the footing for success, which is a term for resolution, and which is the aggregate of consciousness associated with the direct-knowledge consciousness, and which is the aggregate of mental formations consisting of will, concentration, and energy.

original: tathābhūtassa vedanākkhandho…pe… viññāṇakkhandho”ti.
analyzed: tathābhūtassa vedanā kkhandho upe viññāṇa kkhandho ti
translated: For this is said: “The feeling aggregate … the perception aggregate … the formations aggregate … the consciousness aggregate in one who is thus is a footing for success.

original: Atha vā pajjate anenāti pādo. Pāpuṇīyatīti attho. Iddhiyā pādo iddhipādo. Chandādīnametaṃ
analyzed: atha vā pajjate anena ati pādo pāpuṇīyati iti attho iddhiyā pādaḥ iddhi pādaḥ chanda ādīnam etam
translated: Or alternatively, it is a footing because of what is reached by means of it. The meaning is: it is what is reached. The footing for success is success-as-a-footing. This is a term for will, concentration, and energy.

original: adhivacanaṃ. Yathāha – “chandañce, bhikkhave, bhikkhu nissāya labhati samādhiṃ, labhati🔽cittassekaggataṃ, ayaṃ vuccati chandasamādhi. So anuppannānaṃ pāpakānaṃ…pe… padahati,
analyzed: adhivacanam yathā āha chandam ce bhikkhave bhikkhu nissāya labhati samādhim labhati  cittassa ekaggatam ayam vuccati chanda samādhi saḥ anuppannānam pāpakānam pe padahati
translated: As it is said: “Bhikkhus, if a bhikkhu obtains concentration, obtains unification of mind, by depending and relying on will,🔽he is called one who is concentrated through will. He abandons arising, he does not instigate what has not arisen, thus he instigates the non-instigation of what has not arisen.

original: ime vuccanti padhānasaṅkhārā. Iti ayañca chando ayañca chandasamādhi ime ca padhānasaṅkhārā,
analyzed: ime vuccanti padhāna saṅkhārāḥ iti ayam ca chandaḥ ayam ca chanda samādhi ime ca padhāna saṅkhārāḥ
translated: He abandons occurrence, he does not instigate what has not come to be, thus he instigates the non-instigation of what has not come to be.

original: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, chandasamādhipadhānasaṅkhārasamannāgato iddhipādo”ti. Evaṃ
analyzed: ayam vuccati bhikkhave chanda samādhi padhāna saṅkhāra samannāgataḥ iddhipādaḥ ti evam
translated: This is called the road to power that is concentration due to zeal and includes desire.

original: sesiddhipādesupi attho veditabbo.🔽383. Aṭṭha padānīti chandādīni aṭṭha veditabbāni. Vuttañhetaṃ “iddhiyā katamāni aṭṭha
analyzed: sesa siddhi pādesu pi atthaḥ veditabbo  aṭṭha padāni iti chanda ādīni aṭṭha veditabbāni vuttam ha etam iddhiyā katamāni aṭṭha
translated: The meaning should be understood in the same way in the case of the remaining roads to power.🔽Eight steps: the eight steps should be understood as zeal, etc.,

original: padāni? Chandañce bhikkhu nissāya labhati samādhiṃ, labhati cittassekaggataṃ. Chando🔽na samādhi, samādhi na chando. Añño chando, añño samādhi. Vīriyañce bhikkhu… cittañce
analyzed: padāni chandam ce bhikkhu nissāya labhati samādhim labhati cittassa ekagga tam chando  na samādhi samādhi na chandaḥ añño chandaḥ añño samādhi vīriyañce bhikkhu cittañce
translated: for this is said: “What are the eight steps to success? If a bhikkhu obtains concentration, obtains unification of mind, by depending upon zeal,

original: bhikkhu… vīmaṃsañce bhikkhu nissāya labhati samādhiṃ, labhati cittassekaggataṃ. Vīmaṃsā
analyzed: bhikkhu vīmaṃsan ce bhikkhu nissāya labhati samādhim labhati cittassa ekagga tam vīmaṃsā
translated: his zeal is one thing and his concentration is another; his zeal is not his concentration. If a bhikkhu obtains concentration, obtains unification of mind, by depending upon energy … by depending upon natural purity of consciousness … by depending upon inquiry,

original: na samādhi, samādhi na vīmaṃsā. Aññā vīmaṃsā, añño samādhi. Iddhiyā imāni aṭṭha padāni
analyzed: na samādhi samādhi na vīmaṃsā aññā vīmaṃsā aññaḥ samādhi iddhiyā imāni aṭṭha padāni
translated: his inquiry is one thing and his concentration is another; his inquiry is not his concentration. These are the eight steps to success.

original: iddhilābhāya…pe… iddhivesārajjāya saṃvattantī”ti. Ettha hi iddhimuppādetukāmatāchando
analyzed: iddhi lābhāya pe iddhi vesārajjāya saṃvattanti iti ettha hi iddhim uppādetu kāma tā chandaḥ
translated: They lead to the obtaining of success, to the obtaining of concentration, to the obtaining of support, to the obtaining of mindfulness, to the obtaining of enlightenment, to the obtaining of Nibbāna” .🔽Herein, the desire to produce success is zeal.

original: samādhinā ekato niyuttova iddhilābhāya saṃvattati; tathā vīriyādayo. Tasmā imāni
analyzed: samādhinā ekatas iddhi lābhāya saṃvattati tathā vīriya ādayaḥ tasmai imāni
translated: and concentration, when unified, leads to the acquisition of supernormal power. So too with energy and the rest.

original: aṭṭha padāni vuttānīti veditabbāni.
analyzed: aṭṭha padāni vuttāni iti veditabbāni
translated: That is why these eight terms should be understood as said.

original: 384. Soḷasa mūlānīti soḷasahi ākārehi āneñjatā cittassa veditabbā. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: soḷasa mūlāni iti soḷasahi ākārehi āneñja tā cittassa veditabbā vuttam ha etam
translated: Sixteen roots: the imperturbability of consciousness should be understood as being of sixteen kinds. For this is said:

original: “iddhiyā kati mūlāni? Soḷasa mūlāni – anonataṃ cittaṃ kosajje na iñjatīti āneñjaṃ,
analyzed: id dhiyā kati mūlāni soḷasa mūlāni an onatam cittam kosajje naḥ iñjati iti āneñjam
translated: “How many roots of success are there? There are sixteen roots: consciousness that is not bent is imperturbable in idleness;

original: anunnataṃ cittaṃ uddhacce na iñjatīti āneñjaṃ, anabhinataṃ cittaṃ rāge na iñjatīti
analyzed: an unnatam cittam uddhacce naḥ iñjati iti āneñjam an abhinatam cittam rāge naḥ iñjati iti
translated: consciousness that is not puffed up is imperturbable in agitation; consciousness that is not clinging is imperturbable in greed;

original: āneñjaṃ, anapanataṃ cittaṃ byāpāde na iñjatīti āneñjaṃ, anissitaṃ cittaṃ diṭṭhiyā🔽na iñjatīti āneñjaṃ, appaṭibaddhaṃ cittaṃ chandarāge na iñjatīti āneñjaṃ, vippamuttaṃ
analyzed: āneñjam an apanatam cittam byāpāde na iñjati iti āneñjam a nissitam cittam diṭṭhiyā  na iñjati iti āneñjam appaṭibaddham cittam chanda rāge na iñjati iti āneñjam vippamuttam
translated: consciousness that is not grasping is imperturbable in ill will; consciousness that is not dependent is imperturbable in views;🔽consciousness that is not fettered is imperturbable in desire and greed; consciousness that is liberated is imperturbable in sensual lust; consciousness that is unassociated is imperturbable in defilements;

original: cittaṃ kāmarāge na iñjatīti āneñjaṃ, visaṃyuttaṃ cittaṃ kilese na iñjatīti āneñjaṃ,
analyzed: cittam kāma rāge naḥ iñjati iti āneñjam visaṃyuttam cittam kilese naḥ iñjati iti āneñjam
translated: consciousness that is not subject to cankers is imperturbable in the plane of defilements; consciousness that is not subject to death is imperturbable in the plane of death; consciousness that is not subject to rebirth is imperturbable in the plane of rearising;

original: vimariyādikataṃ cittaṃ kilesamariyāde na iñjatīti āneñjaṃ, ekattagataṃ cittaṃ nānattakilese🔽na iñjatīti āneñjaṃ, saddhāya pariggahitaṃ cittaṃ assaddhiye na iñjatīti āneñjaṃ,🔽vīriyena pariggahitaṃ cittaṃ kosajje na iñjatīti āneñjaṃ, satiyā pariggahitaṃ cittaṃ
analyzed: vimariyādikatam cittam kilesa mariyāde na iñjati iti āneñjam ekatta gatam cittam nānatta kilese  na iñjati iti āneñjam saddhāya pariggahitam cittam assaddhiye na iñjati iti āneñjam  vīriyena pariggahitam cittam kosajje naḥ iñjati iti āneñjam satiyā pariggahitam cittam
translated: The mind that has been purified of obstructions does not incline to the defilements’ obstructions, thus it is without-bliss. The mind that has reached unification does not incline to the various defilements,🔽thus it is without-bliss. The mind that has been taken hold of by faith does not incline to lack of faith, thus it is without-bliss.🔽The mind that has been taken hold of by energy does not incline to idleness, thus it is without-bliss. The mind that has been taken hold of by mindfulness does not incline to negligence, thus it is without-bliss.

original: pamāde na iñjatīti āneñjaṃ, samādhinā pariggahitaṃ cittaṃ uddhacce na iñjatīti āneñjaṃ,
analyzed: pamāde naḥ iñjati iti āneñjam samādhinā pariggahitam cittam uddhacce naḥ iñjati iti āneñjam
translated: The mind that has been taken hold of by concentration does not incline to agitation, thus it is without-bliss.

original: paññāya pariggahitaṃ cittaṃ avijjāya na iñjatīti āneñjaṃ, obhāsagataṃ cittaṃ avijjandhakāre
analyzed: paññāya pariggahitam cittam avijjāya na iñjati iti āneñjam obhāsa gatam cittam avijja andhakāre
translated: The mind that has been taken hold of by understanding does not incline to ignorance, thus it is without-bliss. The mind that has reached illumination does not incline to the darkness of ignorance,

original: na iñjatīti āneñjaṃ. Iddhiyā imāni soḷasa mūlāni iddhilābhāya…pe… iddhivesārajjāya saṃvattantī”ti.
analyzed: na iñjati iti āneñjam iddhiyā imāni soḷasa mūlāni iddhi lābhāya pe iddhi vesārajjāya saṃvattanti iti
translated: thus it is without-bliss. These sixteen roots lead to the obtaining of success, to the achieving of success, to the acquisition of success, to the attainment of success, to the realization of success, to the fulfilment of success, to the culmination of success, to the termination of success, to the abandonment of hindrances, to the tranquilization of the defilements of the mind, to the penetration of understanding, to the destruction of the āsavas, to the realization of the fruits, to the acquisition of the fruits, to Nibbāna, to the realization of Nibbāna, to the realization of the fruit of stream-entry, to the realization of the fruit of once-return, to the realization of the fruit of non-return, to the realization of the fruit of arahantship, to the realization of the fruit of the omniscience of a Buddha. “

original: Kāmañca esa attho evaṃ samāhite cittetiādināpi siddhoyeva, paṭhamajjhānādīnaṃ pana
analyzed: esa atthaḥ evam samāhite citta iti ādinā api siddhaḥ yā iva paṭhama jhāna ādīnam pana
translated: But although this meaning is established by the words ‘when his concentrated mind’ and so on, still the words ‘without-bliss’ and so on are stated in order to show the special qualities of the first jhāna and the rest.

original: iddhiyā bhūmipādapadamūlabhāvadassanatthaṃ puna vutto. Purimo ca suttesu āgatanayo.
analyzed: iddhiyā bhūmi pāda pada mūla bhāva dassana attham puna vuttaḥ purimaḥ ca suttesu āgata nayo
translated: It is mentioned again in the text in order to show the plane of supernormal power, the bases, and the factors. And the former method is the one given in the Suttas.

original: Ayaṃ paṭisambhidāyaṃ. Iti ubhayattha asammohatthampi puna vutto.
analyzed: ayam paṭisambhidā ayam iti ubhayattha asammoha attham pi puna vutto
translated: This is the method given in the Paṭisambhidā. So it is mentioned again in order to show non-confusion about both methods.

original: 385. Ñāṇena adhiṭṭhahantoti svāyamete iddhiyā bhūmipādapadabhūte dhamme sampādetvā🔽abhiññāpādakaṃ jhānaṃ samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhāya sace sataṃ icchati “sataṃ homi sataṃ
analyzed: ñāṇena adhiṭṭhahanto ti svāyam ete iddhiyā bhūmi pāda pada bhūte dhamme sampādetvā  abhiññāpādakam jhānam samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhāya sace satam icchati satam homi satam
translated: “By means of knowledge he resolves”: having himself accomplished the states that are the plane of supernormal power, the bases, and the factors,

original: homī”ti parikammaṃ katvā puna abhiññāpādakaṃ jhānaṃ samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhāya adhiṭṭhāti,
analyzed: homi iti parikammam katvā puna abhiññā pādakam jhānam samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhāya adhiṭṭhāti
translated: he attains jhāna as the basis for direct-knowledge and he emerges. If he wants to be one, he does the preliminary work thus, “Let me be one hundred,” and he resolves in the way already described.

original: adhiṭṭhānacittena saheva sataṃ hoti. Sahassādīsupi eseva nayo. Sace evaṃ na ijjhati
analyzed: adhiṭṭhāna cittena saha iva satam hoti sahassa ādīsu pi esa iva nayaḥ sace evam na ijjhati
translated: He becomes one hundred together with the resolve. The same method applies in the case of a thousand, and so on. If it does not succeed thus,

original: puna parikammaṃ katvā dutiyampi samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhāya adhiṭṭhātabbaṃ. Saṃyuttaṭṭhakathāyaṃ
analyzed: puna parikammam katvā dutiyam pi samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhāya adhiṭṭhātabbam saṃyutta ṭṭhakathāyam
translated: he should do the preliminary work again and attain jhāna a second time and emerge and resolve.

original: hi ekavāraṃ dvevāraṃ samāpajjituṃ vaṭṭatīti vuttaṃ. Tattha pādakajjhānacittaṃ nimittārammaṇaṃ.

original: Parikammacittāni satārammaṇāni vā sahassārammaṇāni vā, tāni ca kho vaṇṇavasena, no
analyzed: parikamma cittāni sata ārammaṇāni vā sahassa ārammaṇāni vā tāni ca kho vaṇṇa vasena no
translated: The preliminary-work consciousnesses have a hundred or a thousand or a hundred thousand as their object, but that is only as to colour, not as to name.

original: paṇṇattivasena. Adhiṭṭhānacittampi tatheva satārammaṇaṃ vā sahassārammaṇaṃ vā. Taṃ
analyzed: paṇṇatti vasena adhiṭṭhāna cittam pi tathā iva sata ārammaṇam vā sahassa ārammaṇam vā taṃ
translated: The determining consciousness is likewise either a hundred or a thousand or a hundred thousand.

original: pubbe vuttaṃ appanācittamiva gotrabhuanantaraṃ ekameva uppajjati rūpāvacaracatutthajjhānikaṃ.🔽386. Yampi paṭisambhidāyaṃ vuttaṃ “pakatiyā eko bahukaṃ āvajjati sataṃ vā sahassaṃ
analyzed: pubbe vuttam appanā cittam iva gotra bhu anantaram ekam eva uppajjati rūpāvacara catuttha jhānikam  yat api paṭisambhidā ayam vuttam pakatiyā ekaḥ bahukam āvajjati satam vā sahassam
translated: That has already been stated. The basic consciousness arises only once, next to the change-of-lineage, like the absorption consciousness, and it is of the fine-material sphere, being the fourth jhāna.

original: vā satasahassaṃ vā, āvajjitvā ñāṇena adhiṭṭhāti ‘bahuko homī’ti, bahuko hoti, yathā🔽āyasmā cūḷapanthako”ti. Tatrāpi āvajjatīti parikammavaseneva vuttaṃ. Āvajjitvā ñāṇena🔽adhiṭṭhātīti abhiññāñāṇavasena vuttaṃ. Tasmā bahukaṃ āvajjati, tato tesampi parikammacittānaṃ
analyzed: vā sata sahassam vā āvajjitvā ñāṇena adhiṭṭhāti bahukaḥ homi iti bahukaḥ hoti yathā  cūḷapanthako ti tatra api āvajjati iti parikamma vasena iva vuttam āvajjitvā ñāṇena  adhiṭṭhāti iti abhiññā ñāṇa vasena vuttam tasmā bahukam āvajjati tatas tesam pi parikamma cittānam
translated: And what is said in the Paṭisambhidā should be understood in the same way: “One who possesses the supernormal power of creating, having resolved upon multiplicity as multiplicity thus ‘Let there be many,’ creates many, either through desire or through concentration or through energy or through investigation or through determination” .

original: avasāne samāpajjati, samāpattito vuṭṭhahitvā puna bahuko homīti āvajjitvā tato paraṃ
analyzed: avasāne samāpajjati samāpattitaḥ vuṭṭhahitvā puna bahukaḥ homi iti āvajjitvā tatas param

original: pavattānaṃ tiṇṇaṃ catunnaṃ vā pubbabhāgacittānaṃ anantarā uppannena sanniṭṭhāpanavasena
analyzed: pavattānam tiṇṇam catunnam vā pubbabhāga cittānam anantarā uppannena sanniṭṭhāpana vasena

analyzed: adhiṭṭhānam ti laddha nāmena ekena iva abhiññā ñāṇena adhiṭṭhāti iti evam ettha atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: The meaning should be regarded as follows: “He resolves by means of a single direct-knowledge consciousness that has obtained the name ‘resolution.’”🔽But what was said about the venerable Cūḷa-Panthaka was said

original: Yaṃ pana vuttaṃ “yathā āyasmā cūḷapanthako”ti, taṃ bahudhābhāvassa kāyasakkhidassanatthaṃ🔽vuttaṃ. Taṃ pana vatthunā dīpetabbaṃ. Te kira dvebhātaro panthe jātattā panthakāti
analyzed: yam pana vuttam yathā āyasmā cūḷapanthako ti tam bahudhābhāvassa  vuttam tam pana vatthunā dīpetabbam te kira dve bhātaro jāta ttā panthakā ati
translated: in order to show the existence of the many kinds in the case of one who has direct-knowledge of the body.🔽But that should be illustrated by the story. They were called Panthaka because they were born on a highway.

original: nāmaṃ labhiṃsu. Tesaṃ jeṭṭho mahāpanthako, so pabbajitvā saha paṭisambhidāhi arahattaṃ

analyzed: pāpuṇi arahā hutvā cūḷapanthakam pabbājetvā
translated: After he had become an arahat, he gave Cūḷa-Panthaka the going forth.🔽“As a lotus is not wetted by water,

analyzed: padumam yathā kokanadam sugandham phullam avīta gandham
translated: And as the scent of Tagara spreads not against the wind,🔽So see the Aṅgīrasa shining,

analyzed: aṅgīrasam passa virocamānam tapantam ādiccam ivantalikkha iti
translated: Shining like the sun in the sky.”

original: Imaṃ gāthaṃ adāsi. So taṃ catūhi māsehi paguṇaṃ kātuṃ nāsakkhi. Atha naṃ thero abhabbo
analyzed: imam gātham adāsi saḥ tam catūhi māsehi paguṇam kātum na asakkhi atha nam theraḥ abhabbo
translated: He was unable to master it in four months. Then the elder said, “You are incapable of mastering this verse, Panthaka. You are incapable of mastering it.

original: tvaṃ sāsaneti vihārato nīhari. Tasmiñca kāle thero bhattuddesako hoti. Jīvako theraṃ🔽upasaṅkamitvā “sve, bhante, bhagavatā saddhiṃ pañcabhikkhusatāni gahetvā amhākaṃ
analyzed: tvam sāsana iti vihārataḥ tasmin ca kāle theraḥ bhattuddesakaḥ hoti jīvakaḥ theram  upasaṅkamitvā sve bhante bhagavatā saddhim pañca bhikkhu satāni gahetvā amhākam
translated: “You are in the Dispensation,” and he took him out of the monastery. And at that time the Elder was the assigner of meals. Jīvaka

analyzed: mama sāsane abhabbaḥ nāma hoti mā soci bhikkhu iti tam bāhāyam gahetvā vihāram pavisitvā  iddhiyā pilotika khaṇḍam abhinimminitvā adāsi handa bhikkhu imam parimajjantaḥ rajoharaṇam
translated: saying, “Why are you weeping?” He told him what had happened. The Blessed One said, “One who is unable to do the recitation is not incapable in my Dispensation. Do not weep, bhikkhu,” and taking him by the arm he led him into the monastery.🔽Then he created by his psychic power a piece of a broken roof-tile and gave it to him, saying, “Come, bhikkhu, while you are polishing this you can do the recitation of the ‘Removal of Lust’ again and again, saying ‘Removal of Lust, Removal of Lust.’ ”

translated: The wise, having abandoned this dust,
