analyzed: vā na dissati evam attānam vā param vā kātu kāmo pādakajjhānataḥ vuṭṭhāya idam āloka ṭṭhānam  andhakāram hotu uti vai idam appaṭicchannam paṭicchannam hotu uti vai idam āpātham
translated: or he does not see himself or another, then, wanting to do this to himself or another, he emerges from the basic jhāna and resolves: “Let this place be dark,” or “Let this place be bright,” or “Let this place be concealed,” or “Let this place be unconcealed,” or “Let this place be within the range of my knowledge and vision,” or “Let this place be outside the range of my knowledge and vision.”🔽🔽

original: anāpāthaṃ hotū”ti vā āvajjitvā parikammaṃ katvā vuttanayeneva adhiṭṭhāti. Saha adhiṭṭhānacittena
analyzed: anāpātham hotu uti vā āvajjitvā parikammam katvā vutta nayena iva adhiṭṭhāti saha adhiṭṭhāna cittena
translated: If he wants to make himself or another invisible, he emerges from the basic jhāna and adverts thus, “Let this place which is light become dark” or “Let this place which is concealed become unconcealed” or “Let this place which is within range of the eyes become beyond the range of the eyes.” Then he does the preliminary work and resolves in the way already described.

original: yathādhiṭṭhitameva hoti. Pare samīpe ṭhitāpi na passanti. Sayampi apassitukāmo na passati.
analyzed: yathā adhiṭṭhitam eva hoti pare samīpe ṭhitā api na passanti sayam pi a passitu kāmo na passati
translated: With the arising of the resolution it becomes as resolved. Others standing near do not see even though they want to see. He himself, if he wants to be invisible, is not seen even by those with the divine eye.

original: 390. Etaṃ pana pāṭihāriyaṃ kena katapubbanti? Bhagavatā. Bhagavā hi yasaṃ kulaputtaṃ
analyzed: etam pana pāṭihāriyam kena kata pubban ti bhagavatā bhagavā hi yasam kula puttam
translated: But who has done this miracle before? The Blessed One. For the Blessed One made it possible for the clansman Yasa,

original: samīpe nisinnaṃyeva yathā naṃ pitā na passati, evamakāsi. Tathā vīsayojanasataṃ mahākappinassa
analyzed: samīpe nisinnam yā iva yathā nam pitā na passati evam akāsi tathā vīsa yojana satam mahākappinassa
translated: while sitting in his father’s presence, to be invisible to his father. And he did likewise for the five hundred young men of the Thullanandā,

original: paccuggamanaṃ katvā taṃ anāgāmiphale, amaccasahassañcassa sotāpattiphale patiṭṭhāpetvā,
analyzed: paccuggamanam katvā tam anāgāmi phale amacca sahassam ca assa sotāpatti phale patiṭṭhāpetvā
translated: and for the young brāhmaṇas of Opasāda, and for the young brāhmaṇas of Icchānaṅgala, and for the young brāhmaṇas of Ekanālā, and for the young brāhmaṇas of Taxila, and for the young brāhmaṇas of Verañjā, and for the young brāhmaṇas of Vesālī, and for the young brāhmaṇas of Campā, and for the young brāhmaṇas of Rājagaha, and for the young brāhmaṇas of Bārāṇasī, and for the young brāhmaṇas of Kāsi, and for the young brāhmaṇas of Kosala, and for the young brāhmaṇas of Magadha, and for the young brāhmaṇas of Aṅga, and for the young brāhmaṇas of Assaka, and for the young brāhmaṇas of Avantī, and for the young brāhmaṇas of Aḷāra Kālāma, and for the young brāhmaṇas of Uddaka Rāmaputta, and for the young brāhmaṇas of the Ājīvaka, and for the young brāhmaṇas of the Niganthas, and for the young brāhmaṇas of the Titthiyas, and for the young brāhmaṇas of the Pāvārikas, and for the young brāhmaṇas of the Jains,

original: tassa anumaggaṃ āgatā sahassitthiparivārā anojādevī āgantvā samīpe nisinnāpi yathā
analyzed: tassa anumaggam āgatā sahassa itthi parivārā anojā devī āgantvā samīpe nisinnā api yathā
translated: The Queen Anojā, who had come with the king’s permission, surrounded by a thousand women, sat down near the Elder. But the Elder so arranged that the king and his retinue did not see the queen.

original: saparisaṃ rājānaṃ na passati, tathā katvā “api, bhante, rājānaṃ passathā”ti vutte
analyzed: sa parisam rājānam na passati tathā katvā api bhante rājānam passatha ati vutte
translated: When the king asked, “Venerable sir, have you seen the queen?”🔽the Elder replied, “Which is better for you to search for, the queen or yourself?”

original: “kiṃ pana te rājānaṃ gavesituṃ varaṃ, udāhu attāna”nti? “Attānaṃ, bhante”ti vatvā🔽nisinnāya tassā tathā dhammaṃ desesi, yathā sā saddhiṃ itthisahassena sotāpattiphale🔽patiṭṭhāsi, amaccā anāgāmiphale, rājā arahatteti. Apica tambapaṇṇidīpaṃ āgatadivase
analyzed: kim pana te rājānam gavesitum varam udāhu attānam ananti attānam bhanta iti vatvā  nisinnāya tassā tathā dhammam desesi yathā sā saddhim itthi sahassena sotāpatti phale  amaccā anāgāmi phale rājā arahattā iti apica tamba paṇṇi dīpam āgata divase
translated: When the queen said, “Myself, venerable sir,”🔽the Elder so instructed her that she and the thousand women were established in the fruit of stream-entry, the ministers in the fruit of non-return, and the king in arahantship.🔽Moreover, on the day when the Elder arrived in the island of Tambapaṇṇi, he so arranged that the king did not see the rest of the party who had come with him.

original: yathā attanā saddhiṃ āgate avasese rājā na passati, evaṃ karontena mahindattherenāpi idaṃ katameva.🔽391. Apica sabbampi pākaṭaṃ pāṭihāriyaṃ āvibhāvaṃ nāma. Apākaṭapāṭihāriyaṃ tirobhāvaṃ
analyzed: yathā attanā saddhim āgate avasese rājā na passati evam karontena mahindattherena api idam katam eva  apica sabbam pi pākaṭam pāṭihāriyam āvibhāvam nāma apākaṭa pāṭihāriyam tirobhāvam
translated: This was done by the Elder Mahinda himself.🔽Moreover, all miracles that are evident are called “manifestations.” Those that are not evident are called “disappearances.”

original: nāma. Tattha pākaṭapāṭihāriye iddhipi paññāyati iddhimāpi. Taṃ yamakapāṭihāriyena
analyzed: nāma tattha pākaṭa pāṭihāriye paññāyati tam yamaka pāṭihāriyena
translated: In the case of an evident miracle, both the supernormal power and the possessor of the supernormal power are evident. This is the case with the Twin Miracle .

original: dīpetabbaṃ. Tatra hi “idha tathāgato yamakapāṭihāriyaṃ karoti asādhāraṇaṃ sāvakehi.
analyzed: dīpetabbam tatra hi idha tathāgataḥ yamaka pāṭihāriyam karoti asādhāraṇam sāvakehi
translated: For there it was known thus: “Here the Tathāgata performs the twin miracle, which is not shared by disciples.

original: Uparimakāyato aggikkhandho pavattati, heṭṭhimakāyato udakadhārā pavattatī”ti evaṃ
analyzed: uparima kāyataḥ aggi kkhandho pavattati heṭṭhima kāyataḥ udaka dhārā pavattati iti evam
translated: From the upper part of his body a flame goes forth and from the lower part water flows” .

original: ubhayaṃ paññāyittha. Apākaṭapāṭihāriye iddhiyeva paññāyati, na iddhimā. Taṃ mahakasuttena
analyzed: ubhayam paññāyittha apākaṭa pāṭihāriye iddhiyā iva paññāyati na iddhimā tam mahaka suttena
translated: In the less obvious miracle only the supernormal power is known, not the possessor of supernormal power. It should be illustrated by the Mahaka Sutta

original: ca brahmanimantanikasuttena ca dīpetabbaṃ. Tatra hi āyasmato ca mahakassa, bhagavato
analyzed: ca brahmanimantanika suttena ca dīpetabbam tatra hi āyasmataḥ ca mahakassa bhagavataḥ
translated: and the Brahmanimantanika Sutta. For there only the supernormal power of the venerable Mahaka and the Blessed One

original: ca iddhiyeva paññāyittha, na iddhimā.
analyzed: ca iddhiyā iva paññāyittha na iddhimā
translated: was known, not the possessors of supernormal power.

original: Yathāha –🔽“Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho citto gahapati āyasmantaṃ mahakaṃ etadavoca ‘sādhu me, bhante,🔽ayyo mahako uttarimanussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ dassetū’ti. Tena hi tvaṃ gahapati
analyzed: yathā āha  ekamantam nisinnaḥ khalu cittaḥ gahapati āyasmantam mahakam etat avoca sādhu me bhante  ayyaḥ mahakaḥ uttari manussa dhammā iddhi pāṭihāriyam dassetu uti tena hi tvam gahapati
translated: As it is said:🔽“The layman Citta said: ‘Venerable sir, let the venerable Mahaka show me a supernormal power that is beyond the norm of normal men.’—‘Well then, layman, spread your upper robe out on the terrace and strew it with flowers’” .

original: āḷinde uttarāsaṅgaṃ paññāpetvā tiṇakalāpaṃ okāsehīti. ‘Evaṃ, bhante’ti kho citto
analyzed: āḷinde uttarāsaṅgam paññāpetvā tiṇa kalāpam okāsehi iti evam bhante iti kho citto
translated: “‘Yes, venerable sir,’ the layman Citta replied to the venerable Mahaka.

original: gahapati āyasmato mahakassa paṭissutvā āḷinde uttarāsaṅgaṃ paññāpetvā tiṇakalāpaṃ
analyzed: gahapati āyasmataḥ mahakassa paṭissutvā āḷinde uttarāsaṅgam paññāpetvā tiṇa kalāpam
translated: The householder did as asked.

original: okāsesi. Atha kho āyasmā mahako vihāraṃ pavisitvā tathārūpaṃ iddhābhisaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkhāsi,
analyzed: okāsesi atha kho āyasmā mahakaḥ vihāram pavisitvā tathārūpam iddha abhisaṅkhāram abhisaṅkhāsi
translated: Then the venerable Mahaka entered the dwelling and performed such a feat of supernormal power that the flame from the lamp went out through the keyhole and set fire to the thatch,

original: yathā tālacchiggaḷena ca aggaḷantarikāya ca acci nikkhamitvā tiṇāni jhāpesi, uttarāsaṅgaṃ na jhāpesī”ti.
analyzed: yathā tāla chiggaḷena ca aggaḷa antarikāya ca acci nikkhamitvā tiṇāni jhāpesi uttarāsaṅgam na jhāpesi iti
translated: burning it without setting fire to the upper robe.”

original: Yathā cāha –
analyzed: yathā ca āha
translated: And as he said:

original: “Atha khvāhaṃ, bhikkhave, tathārūpaṃ iddhābhisaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkhāsiṃ ‘ettāvatā brahmā
analyzed: atha khvā aham bhikkhave tathārūpam iddha abhisaṅkhāram ettāvatā brahmā
translated: “Then, monks, I performed such a feat of supernormal power that Brahma Sanankumara

original: ca brahmaparisā ca brahmapārisajjā ca saddañca me sossanti, na ca maṃ dakkhissantī’ti
analyzed: ca brahma parisā ca brahma pārisajjā ca saddam ca me sossanti na ca mama dakkhissanti iti
translated: could hear my voice but could not see me.

original: antarahito imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsiṃ –
analyzed: antara hitaḥ imam gātham abhāsim
translated: And, invisible, I spoke this verse:

original: ‘Bhave vāhaṃ bhayaṃ disvā, bhavañca vibhavesinaṃ;
analyzed: bhave vā aham bhayam disvā bhavan ca vibhavesinam
translated: ‘Having seen danger in existence,🔽I do not assert any existence,

original: Bhavaṃ nābhivadiṃ kiñci, nandiñca na upādiyi”’nti. ;
analyzed: bhavam na abhivadim kiñci nandiñca naḥ
translated: And I do not grasp after delight.’

original: 392. Tirokuṭṭaṃ tiropākāraṃ tiropabbataṃ asajjamāno gacchati seyyathāpi ākāseti ettha
analyzed: tiro kuṭṭam tiro pākāram tiro pabbatam a sajjamānaḥ gacchati sā iyyathā api ākāse iti ettha
translated: He walks unhindered through walls, through enclosures, through mountains, as though in open space;

original: tirokuṭṭanti parakuṭṭaṃ, kuṭṭassa parabhāganti vuttaṃ hoti. Esa nayo itaresu. Kuṭṭoti
analyzed: tirokuṭṭanti para kuṭṭam kuṭṭassa parabhāganti vuttam hoti esa nayaḥ itaresu kuṭṭo ti
translated: Across a wall: across another’s wall. The other side of a wall is what is meant. The same method applies in the other cases. Wall means

original: ca gehabhittiyā etamadhivacanaṃ. Pākāroti gehavihāragāmādīnaṃ parikkhepapākāro. Pabbatoti
analyzed: ca geha bhittiyāḥ etam adhivacanam pākāraḥ ti geha vihāra gāma ādīnam parikkhepa pākāraḥ pabbato ti
translated: the wall of a house. Palisade means a palisade round a house, a monastery, a village, etc. Mountain means

original: paṃsupabbato vā pāsāṇapabbato vā. Asajjamānoti alaggamāno. Seyyathāpi ākāseti ākāse🔽viya. Evaṃ gantukāmena pana ākāsakasiṇaṃ samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhāya kuṭṭaṃ vā pākāraṃ
analyzed: paṃsu pabbataḥ vā pāsāṇa pabbataḥ vā a sajjamānaḥ ati a laggamānaḥ seyyathā api ākāse iti ākāse  viyaḥ evam gantu kāmena pana ākāsa kasiṇam samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhāya kuṭṭam vā pākāram
translated: a mountain of soil or a mountain of rock. Without touching means without clinging to. As through the air means

original: vā sinerucakkavāḷesupi aññataraṃ pabbataṃ vā āvajjitvā kataparikammena ākāso hotūti🔽adhiṭṭhātabbo. Ākāsoyeva hoti. Adho otaritukāmassa, uddhaṃ vā ārohitukāmassa susiro
analyzed: vā sineru cakkavāḷesu pi aññataram pabbatam vā āvajjitvā kata parikammena ākāsaḥ hotu uti  adhiṭṭhātabbaḥ ākāsaḥ yā iva hoti adhas otaritu kāmassa uddham vā ārohitu kāmassa su siraḥ
translated: as though through the air. But one who wants to go thus should attain the air kasiṇa jhāna and emerge. Then he should advert to the wall or palisade or to one of the mountains, Sineru or Sattapaṇṇa, and he should resolve: “Let there be air.”

original: hoti, vinivijjhitvā gantukāmassa chiddo. So tattha asajjamāno gacchati.
analyzed: hoti vinivijjhitvā gantu kāmassa chiddaḥ saḥ tattha a sajjamānaḥ gacchati
translated: It becomes air. If he wants to go down, he should resolve: “Let there be space.” If he wants to go up, he should resolve: “Let there be space.” It becomes space. If he wants to go through, he should resolve: “Let there be space.” It becomes space. He goes through without touching.

original: Tipiṭakacūḷābhayatthero panetthāha – “ākāsakasiṇasamāpajjanaṃ, āvuso, kimatthiyaṃ,
analyzed: tipiṭakacūḷābhaya theraḥ pana itthā āha ākāsa kasiṇa samāpajjanam āvuso kim atthiyam
translated: But the Elder Tipiṭaka Cūḷa Abhaya said: “What is the point, friend, of attaining the air kasiṇa jhāna?

original: kiṃ hatthiassādīni abhinimminitukāmo hatthiassādi kasiṇāni samāpajjati, nanu yattha
analyzed: kim hatthi assa ādīni abhinimminitu kāmaḥ hatthi assa ādi kasiṇāni samāpajjati nanu
translated: Does one who wants to create an elephant, a horse, etc., attain the kasiṇas of the elephant, the horse, etc.?

original: katthaci kasiṇe parikammaṃ katvā aṭṭhasamāpattivasībhāvoyeva pamāṇaṃ. Yaṃ yaṃ icchati,
analyzed: katthaci kasiṇe parikammam katvā pamāṇam yam yam icchati
translated: But after doing the preliminary work on any kasiṇa, it is only when one has mastered the eight attainments that one is able to do this.🔽Whatever one wants becomes that” .

original: taṃ tadeva hotī”ti. Bhikkhū āhaṃsu – “pāḷiyā, bhante, ākāsakasiṇaṃyeva āgataṃ, tasmā
analyzed: tat tat eva hoti iti bhikkhū āhaṃsu pāḷiyā bhante ākāsa kasiṇam yeva āgatam tasmā
translated: The bhikkhus said, “Venerable sir, only the space kasiṇa is given in the texts, so it must be that.”

original: avassametaṃ vattabba”nti. Tatrāyaṃ pāḷi –
analyzed: avassametam vattabbanti tatra ayam
translated: Here is the text:

original: “Pakatiyā ākāsakasiṇasamāpattiyā lābhī hoti. Tirokuṭṭaṃ tiropākāraṃ tiropabbataṃ
analyzed: pakatiyāḥ ākāsakasiṇa samāpattiyāḥ lābhī hoti tirokuṭṭam tiropākāram tiropabbatam
translated: “He obtains mastery in the attainment of the space kasiṇa. He adverts to a wall or a rampart or a mountain or a tree or an earth-mound.

original: āvajjati. Āvajjitvā ñāṇena adhiṭṭhāti – ‘ākāso hotū’ti. Ākāso hoti. Tirokuṭṭaṃ tiropākāraṃ🔽tiropabbataṃ asajjamāno gacchati. Yathā manussā pakatiyā aniddhimanto kenaci anāvaṭe
analyzed: āvajjati āvajjitvā ñāṇena adhiṭṭhāti ākāsaḥ hotu uti ākāsaḥ hoti tirokuṭṭam tiropākāram  tiropabbatam a sajjamānaḥ gacchati yathā manussā pakatiyā an iddhimantaḥ kenaci an āvaṭe
translated: Having adverted, he resolves with knowledge: ‘Let there be space.’ There is space. He moves, crosses over, traverses, and goes to the other side of that wall, that rampart, that mountain, that tree, that earth-mound, without his body being affected by them, just as if it were space.

original: aparikkhitte asajjamānā gacchanti, evameva so iddhimā cetovasippatto tirokuṭṭaṃ tiropākāraṃ
analyzed: a parikkhitte a sajjamānāḥ gacchanti evam eva saḥ iddhimā cetaḥ vasi pattaḥ tirokuṭṭam tiropākāram
translated: Just as men who are not supernormal, not possessing the supernormal power, when not obstructed by intervening mountains, etc., go, cross over, traverse, and reach the other side of a wall, a rampart, a mountain, a tree, an earth-mound, without their bodies being affected by them, so too this possessor of supernormal power, this master of mind, when he resolves thus, ‘Let there be space,’ moves, crosses over, traverses, and goes to the other side of that wall, that rampart, that mountain, that tree, that earth-mound, without his body being affected by them.

original: tiropabbataṃ asajjamāno gacchati, seyyathāpi ākāse”ti.
analyzed: tiropabbatam a sajjamānaḥ gacchati sā iyyathā api ākāse iti
translated: He walks without touching the ground, as though he were walking in space.’

original: Sace panassa bhikkhuno adhiṭṭhahitvā gacchantassa antarā pabbato vā rukkho vā uṭṭheti,
analyzed: sace panassa bhikkhuno adhiṭṭhahitvā gacchantassa antarā pabbataḥ vā rukkho vā uṭṭheti
translated: But if a mountain or a tree should spring up between him and the place he has resolved to go to,

original: kiṃ puna samāpajjitvā adhiṭṭhātabbanti? Doso natthi. Puna samāpajjitvā adhiṭṭhānaṃ🔽hi upajjhāyassa santike nissayaggahaṇasadisaṃ hoti. Iminā ca pana bhikkhunā ākāso
analyzed: kim puna samāpajjitvā adhiṭṭhātabbanti dosaḥ natthi puna samāpajjitvā adhiṭṭhānam  hi upajjhāyassa santike nissaya ggahaṇa sadisam hoti iminā ca pana bhikkhunā ākāsaḥ
translated: then should he re-enter the attainment and resolve again? There is no harm in that.🔽For the resolving again is like the receiving of the dependence on the preceptor.

original: hotūti adhiṭṭhitattā ākāso hotiyeva. Purimādhiṭṭhānabaleneva cassa antarā añño pabbato
analyzed: hotu uti adhiṭṭhita ttā ākāsaḥ hotiyā iva purima adhiṭṭhāna balena iva cassa antarā aññaḥ pabbato
translated: And because this bhikkhu has resolved, ‘Let there be space,’ there is space.

original: vā rukkho vā utumayo uṭṭhahissatīti aṭṭhānamevetaṃ. Aññena iddhimatā nimmite pana
analyzed: vā rukkhaḥ vā utu mayaḥ uṭṭhahissati iti aṭṭhānam eva etam aññena iddhimatā nimmite pana
translated: And it is impossible that another mountain or tree should arise in the interval by its own agency.🔽But if it is created by another possessor of supernormal power,

original: paṭhamanimmānaṃ balavaṃ hoti. Itarena tassa uddhaṃ vā adho vā gantabbaṃ.
analyzed: paṭhama nimmānam balavam hoti itarena tassa uddham vā adhas vā gantabbam
translated: the first creation is the stronger. The other has to go either above or below it.

original: 393. Pathaviyāpi ummujjanimujjanti ettha ummujjanti uṭṭhānaṃ vuccati. Nimujjanti
analyzed: pathaviyā api ummujja nimujjanti ettha ummujjanti uṭṭhānam vuccati nimujjanti
translated: As to ‘rising up and diving down in the earth as in water’: rising up is called upspringing. Diving down is called sinking.

original: saṃsīdanaṃ. Ummujjañca nimujjañca ummujjanimujjaṃ. Evaṃ kātukāmena āpokasiṇaṃ samāpajjitvā
analyzed: saṃsīdanam ummujjam ca nimujjam ca ummujja nimujjam evam kātu kāmena āpokasiṇam samāpajjitvā
translated: He sinks and rises again, sinks and rises again: this is what is meant by “sinking and rising again”.🔽One who wants to do this should attain the earth kasiṇa jhāna and emerge.

original: uṭṭhāya ettake ṭhāne pathavī udakaṃ hotūti paricchinditvā parikammaṃ katvā vuttanayeneva
analyzed: uṭṭhāya ettake ṭhāne pathavī udakam hotu uti paricchinditvā parikammam katvā vutta nayena iva
translated: Then he should delimit a place, thinking, “Let it be so much water,” and after that he should do the preliminary work and resolve in the way already described.

original: adhiṭṭhātabbaṃ. Saha adhiṭṭhānena yathā paricchinne ṭhāne pathavī udakameva hoti.
analyzed: adhiṭṭhātabbam saha adhiṭṭhānena yathā paricchinne ṭhāne pathavī udakam eva hoti
translated: As soon as he resolves, it becomes water in the place delimited.

original: So tattha ummujjanimujjaṃ karoti. Tatrāyaṃ pāḷi –
analyzed: saḥ tattha ummujja nimujjam karoti tatra ayam
translated: Here is the text:

original: “Pakatiyā āpokasiṇasamāpattiyā lābhī hoti. Pathaviṃ āvajjati. Āvajjitvā ñāṇena adhiṭṭhāti🔽– ‘udakaṃ hotū’ti. Udakaṃ hoti. So pathaviyā ummujjanimujjaṃ karoti. Yathā manussā🔽pakatiyā aniddhimanto udake ummujjanimujjaṃ karonti, evameva so iddhimā cetovasippatto
analyzed: pakatiyāḥ āpokasiṇa samāpattiyāḥ lābhī hoti pathavim āvajjati āvajjitvā ñāṇena adhiṭṭhāti  udakam hotu uti udakam hoti saḥ pathaviyāḥ ummujja nimujjam karoti yathā manussā  pakatiyā an iddhimantaḥ udake ummujja nimujjam karonti evam eva saḥ iddhimā cetaḥ vasi patto
translated: “One who has attained jhāna in the earth kasiṇa extends it and projects it, and after that he resolves in the way already described.🔽He sinks and rises again, sinks and rises again, just as men who have no supernormal power sink and rise again when they try to walk on water that has no breeze and is free from ripples.

original: pathaviyā ummujjanimujjaṃ karoti, seyyathāpi udake”ti.
analyzed: pathaviyāḥ ummujja nimujjam karoti sā iyyathā api udaka iti
translated: So too, this possessor of supernormal power who has attained mastery of mind, by his attaining resolution, sinks and rises again in the earth, just as in water” .

original: Na kevalañca ummujjanimujjameva, nhānapānamukhadhovanabhaṇḍakadhovanādīsu yaṃ yaṃ
analyzed: na kevalam ca ummujja nimujjam eva nhāna pāna mukha dhovana bhaṇḍaka dhovana ādīsu yam yam
translated: And not only does he do so with water, but also with whatever he wishes to do with, such as bathing, drinking, washing the mouth, washing a pot, etc.,

original: icchati, taṃ taṃ karoti. Na kevalañca udakameva, sappitelamadhuphāṇitādīsupi yaṃ
analyzed: icchati tam tam karoti na kevalam ca udakam eva sappi tela madhu phāṇi tādī supi yam
translated: he does it with that. And not only with water, but also with ghee, oil, honey, molasses, etc.,

original: yaṃ icchati, taṃ taṃ idañcidañca ettakaṃ hotūti āvajjitvā parikammaṃ katvā adhiṭṭhahantassa🔽yathādhiṭṭhitameva hoti. Uddharitvā bhājanagataṃ karontassa sappi sappimeva hoti.🔽Telādīni telādīniyeva. Udakaṃ udakameva. So tattha temitukāmova temeti, na temitukāmo
analyzed: yam icchati tam tam idañca idañca ettakam hotu uti āvajjitvā parikammam katvā adhiṭṭhahantassa  yathā adhiṭṭhitam eva hoti uddharitvā bhājana gatam karontassa sappi sappim eva hoti  tela ādīni udakam udakam eva saḥ tattha temitu kāmaḥ uva temeti na temitu kāmaḥ
translated: whatever he wishes to do with, he resolves by adverting to it thus, ‘Let so much be so and so,’ and it becomes as he resolves.🔽If he takes it out and puts it in a vessel, the ghee is still ghee,🔽the oil, etc., are still oil, etc., the water is still water.🔽If he wishes to be wetted, he is wetted; if he does not wish to be wetted, he is not wetted.

original: na temeti. Tasseva ca sā pathavī udakaṃ hoti sesajanassa pathavīyeva. Tattha manussā
analyzed: na temeti tassa iva ca sā pathavī udakam hoti sesa janassa tattha manussā
translated: And that earth is water only for him; for the rest it is still earth. Therein,

original: pattikāpi gacchanti, yānādīhipi gacchanti, kasikammādīnipi karontiyeva. Sace panāyaṃ
analyzed: gacchanti yāna ādīhi pi gacchanti sace pana ayam
translated: people walk on foot, they walk in vehicles, etc., and they do their ploughing, etc. But if he wishes,

original: tesampi udakaṃ hotūti icchati, hotiyeva. Paricchinnakālaṃ pana atikkamitvā yaṃ pakatiyā
analyzed: tesam pi udakam hotu uti icchati hotiyā iva paricchinna kālam pana atikkamitvā yam pakatiyā
translated: he can resolve, ‘Let it be water for them too,’ and then it becomes so. But after the time he has determined has elapsed,

original: ghaṭataḷākādīsu udakaṃ, taṃ ṭhapetvā avasesaṃ paricchinnaṭṭhānaṃ pathavīyeva hoti.
analyzed: ghaṭa taḷāka ādīsu udakam tam ṭhapetvā avasesam paricchinna ṭṭhānam pathavīyā iva hoti
translated: Water in water means water in a pool, a tank, etc., except for the water that is being trodden on. The rest is earth.

original: 394. Udakepi abhijjamāneti ettha yaṃ udakaṃ akkamitvā saṃsīdati, taṃ bhijjamānanti🔽vuccati. Viparītaṃ abhijjamānaṃ. Evaṃ gantukāmena pana pathavīkasiṇaṃ samāpajjitvā
analyzed: udake api a bhijjamānā iti ettha yam udakam akkamitvā saṃsīdati tam  vuccati viparītam abhijjamānam evam gantu kāmena pana pathavī kasiṇam samāpajjitvā
translated: In water that is not being trodden on means water that, when trodden on, sinks down is called “being trodden on.” The opposite is “not being trodden on.”

original: vuṭṭhāya ettake ṭhāne udakaṃ pathavī hotūti paricchinditvā parikammaṃ katvā vuttanayeneva
analyzed: vuṭṭhāya ettake ṭhāne udakam pathavī hotu uti paricchinditvā parikammam katvā vutta nayena iva
translated: One who wants to go in this way should attain the earth kasiṇa jhāna and emerge. Then he should define an area in the water, delimiting it thus: “Let the water in this area become earth.” He should then do the preliminary work and resolve in the way already described.

original: adhiṭṭhātabbaṃ. Saha adhiṭṭhānena yathā paricchinnaṭṭhāne udakaṃ pathavīyeva hoti.
analyzed: adhiṭṭhātabbam saha adhiṭṭhānena yathā paricchinna ṭhāne udakam pathavīyā iva hoti
translated: As soon as he resolves, the water in the area becomes earth.

original: So tattha gacchati, tatrāyaṃ pāḷi –🔽“Pakatiyā pathavīkasiṇasamāpattiyā lābhī hoti. Udakaṃ āvajjati. Āvajjitvā ñāṇena
analyzed: saḥ tattha gacchati tatra ayam  pakatiyā pathavī kasiṇa samāpattiyāḥ lābhī hoti udakam āvajjati āvajjitvā ñāṇena
translated: He goes there. The text reads:

original: adhiṭṭhāti – ‘pathavī hotū’ti. Pathavī hoti. So abhijjamāne udake gacchati. Yathā
analyzed: adhiṭṭhāti pathavī hotu uti pathavī hoti saḥ abhijjamāne udake gacchati yathā
translated: “He acquires mastery in the earth kasiṇa jhāna. He adverts to water. Having adverted, he resolves with knowledge: ‘Let there be earth.’ There is earth. He goes in the water that is not being trodden on. As though on earth,

original: manussā pakatiyā aniddhimanto abhijjamānāya pathaviyā gacchanti, evameva so iddhimā
analyzed: manussā pakatiyāḥ an iddhimantaḥ a bhijjamānāya pathaviyā gacchanti evam eva saḥ iddhimā
translated: and people who are not supernormal, though the earth is not cleaving, walk on it. So too, one who has supernormal power,

original: cetovasippatto abhijjamāne udake gacchati, seyyathāpi pathaviya”nti.
analyzed: cetaḥ vasi pattaḥ abhijjamāne udake gacchati sā iyyathā api pathaviyanti
translated: who has attained mental mastery, walks on water as though on earth.”

original: Na kevalañca gacchati, yaṃ yaṃ iriyāpathaṃ icchati, taṃ taṃ karoti. Na kevalañca🔽pathavimeva karoti, maṇisuvaṇṇapabbatarukkhādīsupi yaṃ yaṃ icchati, taṃ taṃ vuttanayeneva
analyzed: na kevalam ca gacchati yam yam iriyāpatham icchati tam tam karoti na kevalam ca  pathavim eva karoti maṇi suvaṇṇa pabbata rukkha ādīsu pi yam yam icchati tam tam vutta nayena iva
translated: And not only does he walk, but he does whatever posture he wishes. And not only does he make earth,

original: āvajjitvā adhiṭṭhāti, yathādhiṭṭhitameva hoti. Tasseva ca taṃ udakaṃ pathavī hoti,🔽sesajanassa udakameva, macchakacchapā ca udakakākādayo ca yathāruci vicaranti. Sace🔽panāyaṃ aññesampi manussānaṃ taṃ pathaviṃ kātuṃ icchati, karotiyeva. Paricchinnakālātikkamena
analyzed: āvajjitvā adhiṭṭhāti yathā dhiṭṭhitam eva hoti tassa iva ca tam udakam pathavī hoti  sesa janassa udakam eva maccha kacchapā ca udaka kāka ādayo ca yathāruci vicaranti sace  pana ayam aññesam pi manussānam tam pathavim kātum icchati paricchinna kāla atikkamena
translated: but whatever he wishes among gems, gold, rocks, trees, etc., he resolves by adverting to it in the way already described, and it becomes just what he has resolved it to be. And that earth is only for him;

original: pana udakameva hoti.
analyzed: pana udakam eva hoti
translated: it is only water for the rest of the people, and the fish, turtles, and water birds move about as they like. But if he wishes to make it earth for other people too, he does so. But after the lapse of the time he has determined on, it becomes water again.

original: 395. Pallaṅkena kamatīti pallaṅkena gacchati. Pakkhī sakuṇoti pakkhehi yuttasakuṇo.
analyzed: pallaṅkena kamati iti pallaṅkena gacchati pakkhī sakuṇaḥ iti pakkhehi yutta sakuṇaḥ
translated: He moves on it as on earth: he walks on it as on earth. A bird: a bird with wings.

original: Evaṃ kātukāmena pana pathavīkasiṇaṃ samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhāya sace nisinno gantumicchati,
analyzed: evam kātu kāmena pana pathavī kasiṇam samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhāya sace nisinnaḥ gantum icchati
translated: One who wants to do this should attain jhāna in the earth kasiṇa, and emerge from it. If he wants to go while sitting,

original: pallaṅkappamāṇaṃ ṭhānaṃ paricchinditvā parikammaṃ katvā vuttanayeneva adhiṭṭhātabbaṃ.
analyzed: pallaṅka ppamāṇam ṭhānam paricchinditvā parikammam katvā vutta nayena iva adhiṭṭhātabbam
translated: he should define a place the size of a seat, do the preliminary work, and resolve in the way already described.

original: Sace nipanno gantukāmo hoti mañcappamāṇaṃ, sace padasā gantukāmo hoti maggappamāṇanti
analyzed: sace nipannaḥ gantu kāmaḥ hoti mañca pamāṇam sace padasā gantu kāmaḥ hoti magga ppamāṇam ti
translated: If he wants to go while lying down, the size of the place should be the size of a bed; if he wants to go on foot, the size of the place should be the size of a road.

original: evaṃ yathānurūpaṃ ṭhānaṃ paricchinditvā vuttanayeneva pathavī hotūti adhiṭṭhātabbaṃ,
analyzed: evam yathānurūpam ṭhānam paricchinditvā vutta nayena iva pathavī hotu iti adhiṭṭhātabbam
translated: So he should define the place as he wishes, and resolve in the way already described, ‘Let there be earth.’

original: saha adhiṭṭhānena pathavīyeva hoti. Tatrāyaṃ pāḷi –🔽“Ākāsepi pallaṅkena kamati, seyyathāpi pakkhī sakuṇoti. Pakatiyā pathavīkasiṇasamāpattiyā🔽lābhī hoti, ākāsaṃ āvajjati. Āvajjitvā ñāṇena adhiṭṭhāti – ‘pathavī hotū’ti. Pathavī
analyzed: saha adhiṭṭhānena pathavīyā iva hoti tatra ayam  ākāse pi pallaṅkena kamati seyyathā api pakkhī sakuṇoti pakatiyā pathavī kasiṇa samāpattiyā  lābhī hoti ākāsam āvajjati āvajjitvā ñāṇena adhiṭṭhāti pathavī hotu uti pathavī
translated: With the resolution, earth comes into being. Here is the text:

original: hoti. So ākāse antalikkhe caṅkamatipi tiṭṭhatipi nisīdatipi seyyampi kappeti. Yathā
analyzed: hoti saḥ ākāse antalikkhe caṅkamati pi tiṭṭhati pi nisīdati seyyampi kappeti yathā
translated: ‘He moves, he walks, he goes on a journey, seated crosslegged through space like a bird with wings. He plunges into the earth as though into water, he dives out of the earth as though into water. He goes on water without breaking through as though on earth. Seated crosslegged he travels in space like a winged bird. He touches and strokes with his hand the moon and sun so mighty and powerful. He exercises mastery with the body as far as the brahma world’ .🔽He who has attained jhāna in the earth kasiṇa in the ordinary way

original: manussā pakatiyā aniddhimanto pathaviyaṃ caṅkamantipi…pe… seyyampi kappenti, evameva
analyzed: manussā pakatiyā an iddhimanto pathaviyam seyyampi kappenti evam eva
translated: and people who have no supernormal power walk on the ground, stand, sit, and lie down, so too

original: so iddhimā cetovasippatto ākāse antalikkhe caṅkamatipi…pe… seyyampi kappetī”ti.
analyzed: saḥ iddhimā cetaḥ vasi pattaḥ ākāse antalikkhe seyyam pi kappeti iti
translated: he, having supernormal power, having attained mental mastery, walks, stands, sits, and lies down in space, in the sky.”

original: Ākāse gantukāmena ca bhikkhunā dibbacakkhulābhināpi bhavitabbaṃ. Kasmā? Antare utusamuṭṭhānā
analyzed: ākāse gantu kāmena ca bhikkhunā dibba cakkhu lābhinā api bhavitabbam kasmai antare utu samuṭṭhānā
translated: But one who wants to go in the sky should obtain the divine eye. Why? Because there may be natural phenomena such as mountains, trees, etc., in the way,

original: vā pabbatarukkhādayo honti, nāgasupaṇṇādayo vā usūyantā māpenti, nesaṃ dassanatthaṃ.
analyzed: vā pabbata rukkha ādayaḥ honti nāga supaṇṇa ādayaḥ vā usūyantāḥ māpenti na esam dassana attham
translated: or nāgas, supaṇṇas, etc., may be obstructing the path.

original: Te pana disvā kiṃ kātabbanti? Pādakajjhānaṃ samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhāya ākāso hotūti parikammaṃ🔽katvā adhiṭṭhātabbaṃ. Thero panāha “samāpattisamāpajjanaṃ, āvuso, kimatthiyaṃ, nanu
analyzed: te pana disvā kim kātabbanti pādakajjhānam samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhāya ākāsaḥ hotu iti parikammaṃ  katvā adhiṭṭhātabbam theraḥ pana āha samāpatti samāpajjanam āvuso kim atthiyam nanu
translated: But when he sees them, what should he do? He should attain jhāna, emerge, and do the preliminary work,

original: samāhitamevassa cittaṃ, tena yaṃ yaṃ ṭhānaṃ ākāso hotūti adhiṭṭhāti, ākāsoyeva hotī”ti.
analyzed: samāhitam eva assa cittam tena yam yam ṭhānam ākāsaḥ hotu uti adhiṭṭhāti ākāsaḥ yā iva hoti iti
translated: resolve: “Let there be space.” But the Elder said: “What is the point of attaining jhāna, friend? Is not his mind concentrated? So whatever place he resolves upon thus, ‘Let there be space,’ becomes space.”

original: Kiñcāpi evamāha, atha kho tirokuṭṭapārihāriye vuttanayeneva paṭipajjitabbaṃ.
analyzed: kiñca api evam āha atha kho tirokuṭṭa pārihāriye vutta nayena iva paṭipajjitabbam
translated: Although he said this, still one should proceed in the way already described under the “going after jumping over seven walls or ramparts” .

original: Apica okāse orohaṇatthampi iminā dibbacakkhulābhinā bhavitabbaṃ, ayañhi sace anokāse🔽nhānatitthe vā gāmadvāre vā orohati. Mahājanassa pākaṭo hoti. Tasmā dibbacakkhunā🔽passitvā anokāsaṃ vajjetvā okāse otaratīti.
analyzed: apica okāse orohaṇa attham pi iminā dibba cakkhu lābhinā bhavitabbam ayan hi sace anokāse  nhāna titthe vā gāma dvāre vā orohati mahājanassa pākaṭaḥ hoti tasmā dibba cakkhunā  passitvā anokāsam vajjetvā okāse otarati iti
translated: Furthermore, he must have the divine eye in order to descend to a suitable place,🔽for if he were to descend to an unsuitable place, such as a bathing place or a village gateway, he would be obvious to the multitude. So he sees with the divine eye and avoids an unsuitable place and descends to a suitable place.

original: 396. Imepi candimasūriye evaṃmahiddhike evaṃmahānubhāve pāṇinā parāmasati parimajjatīti
analyzed: ime api candima sūriye evam mahiddhike evam mahā anubhāve pāṇinā parāmasati parimajjati iti
translated: He touches and strokes the moon and sun so mighty and powerful:

original: ettha candimasūriyānaṃ dvācattālīsayojanasahassassa upari caraṇena mahiddhikatā,
analyzed: ettha candima sūriyānam dvācattālīsa yojana sahassassa upari caraṇena mahiddhika tā
translated: herein, the moon and sun are mighty because they move at a level thirty-four yojanas above the earth,

original: tīsu dīpesu ekakkhaṇe ālokakaraṇena mahānubhāvatā veditabbā. Evaṃ upari caraṇaālokakaraṇehi
analyzed: tīsu dīpesu eka khaṇe āloka karaṇena mahā anubhāva tā veditabbā evam upari caraṇa āloka karaṇehi
translated: and they are powerful because they illuminate the three continents at one and the same time. So they are mighty because they move up there and powerful because they illuminate there.

original: vā mahiddhike teneva mahānubhāve. Parāmasatīti pariggaṇhati ekadese vā chupati. Parimajjatīti🔽samantato ādāsatalaṃ viya parimajjati. Ayaṃ panassa iddhi abhiññāpādakajjhānavaseneva
analyzed: vā mahiddhike tena iva mahā anubhāve parāmasati iti pariggaṇhati ekadese vā chupati parimajjati iti 🔽samantataḥ ādāsa talam viya parimajjati ayam pana assa iddhi abhiññā pādaka jjhāna vasena iva
translated: He touches: he handles. Or he touches in the sense of touching one place. He strokes: he strokes all over like a mirror-surface.

original: ijjhati, natthettha kasiṇasamāpattiniyamo. Vuttañhetaṃ paṭisambhidāyaṃ –🔽“Imepi candimasūriye…pe… parimajjatīti idha so iddhimā cetovasippatto candimasūriye
analyzed: ijjhati nattha ittha kasiṇa samāpatti niyamaḥ vuttam ha etam  ime api candima sūriya pe parimajjati iti idha saḥ cetaḥ vasi patto candima sūriye
translated: It is possible. There is no restriction here to the attainment of the kasiṇa. For this is said in the Paṭisambhidā:

original: āvajjati, āvajjitvā ñāṇena adhiṭṭhāti – ‘hatthapāse hotū’ti. Hatthapāse hoti. So🔽nisinnako vā nipannako vā candimasūriye pāṇinā āmasati parāmasati parimajjati. Yathā
analyzed: āvajjati āvajjitvā ñāṇena adhiṭṭhāti hattha pāse hotu uti hattha pāse hoti so  nisinnakaḥ vā nipannakaḥ vā candima sūriye pāṇinā āmasati parāmasati parimajjati yathā
translated: “He directs, he inclines, he inclines his mind to the moon and sun thus: ‘Come together, come together’; he touches and strokes them with his hand. Just as men who are by nature endowed with supernormal power touch and stroke with their hand an ordinary visible object that is within their reach, so too this possessor of supernormal power, having reached the moon and sun by means of his attainment, touches and strokes them with his hand.🔽He sits or lies down on the moon and sun. Just as men who are by nature endowed with supernormal power sit or lie down on an ordinary visible object that is within their reach, so too this possessor of supernormal power sits or lies down on the moon and sun.

original: manussā pakatiyā aniddhimanto kiñcideva rūpagataṃ hatthapāse āmasanti parāmasanti🔽parimajjanti, evameva so iddhimā…pe… parimajjatī”ti.🔽Svāyaṃ yadi icchati gantvā parāmasituṃ, gantvā parāmasati, yadi pana idheva nisinnako
analyzed: manussā pakatiyā an iddhimanto kiñcid eva rūpa gatam hattha pāse āmasanti parāmasanti  parimajjanti evam eva saḥ iddhimāpe parimajjati iti  svāyam yadi icchati gantvā parāmasitum gantvā parāmasati yadi pana idhā iva nisinnakaḥ
translated: He rolls them up as a roll of leather. Just as men who are by nature endowed with supernormal power roll up an ordinary visible object that is within their reach as a roll of leather, so too this possessor of supernormal power rolls up the moon and sun as a roll of leather.🔽He carries off the moon and sun. Just as men who are by nature endowed with supernormal power carry off an ordinary visible object that is within their reach, so too this possessor of supernormal power carries off the moon and sun.🔽He flings the moon and sun to here and there. Just as men who are by nature endowed with supernormal power fling an ordinary visible object that is within their reach to here and there, so too this possessor of supernormal power flings the moon and sun to here and there.🔽He makes the moon and sun tremble, quake, and quake violently. Just as men who are by nature endowed with supernormal power make an ordinary visible object that is within their reach tremble, quake, and quake violently, so too this possessor of supernormal power makes the moon and sun tremble, quake, and quake violently.

original: vā nipannako vā parāmasitukāmo hoti, hatthapāse hotūti adhiṭṭhāti, adhiṭṭhānabalena
analyzed: vā nipannakaḥ vā parāmasitu kāmo hoti hattha pāse hotu uti adhiṭṭhāti adhiṭṭhāna balena
translated: He overpowers the moon and sun with his glory. Just as men who are by nature endowed with supernormal power overpower with their glory an ordinary visible object that is within their reach, so too this possessor of supernormal power overpowers the moon and sun with his glory.🔽He touches and strokes Brahmā with his hand. Just as men who are by nature endowed with supernormal power touch and stroke with their hand an ordinary visible object that is within their reach, so

original: vaṇṭā muttatālaphalaṃ viya āgantvā hatthapāse ṭhite vā parāmasati, hatthaṃ vā vaḍḍhetvā.
analyzed: vaṇṭā mutta tāla phalam viya āgantvā hattha pāse ṭhite vā parāmasati hattham vā vaḍḍhetvā
translated: He may touch it when it has come within the reach of his hand like a palm fruit on a stalk, or he may extend his hand.

original: Vaḍḍhentassa pana kiṃ upādiṇṇakaṃ vaḍḍhati, anupādiṇṇakanti? Upādiṇṇakaṃ nissāya
analyzed: vaḍḍhentassa pana kim upādiṇṇakam vaḍḍhati an upādiṇṇakam ti upādiṇṇakam nissāya
