original: samādinnanānāvidhakammā, ye ca micchādiṭṭhimūlakesu kāyakammādīsu aññepi samādapenti.
analyzed: samādinna nānāvidha kammā ye ca micchādiṭṭhi mūlakesu kāya kamma ādīsu aññe pi samādapenti
translated: Those who have undertaken actions with wrong view: those who have undertaken various actions because of wrong view, and those who encourage others to do bodily actions, etc., rooted in wrong view.

original: Ettha ca vacīduccaritaggahaṇeneva ariyūpavāde manoduccaritaggahaṇena ca micchādiṭṭhiyā
analyzed: ettha ca vacī duccarita ggahaṇena iva ariya upavāde manaḥ duccarita ggahaṇena ca micchādiṭṭhiyā
translated: And here, by the expression “verbal misconduct”, the action of reviling the noble ones is included, and by the expression “mental misconduct”, wrong view is included.

original: saṅgahitāyapi imesaṃ dvinnaṃ puna vacanaṃ mahāsāvajjabhāvadassanatthanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: imesam dvinnam puna vacanam mahā sāvajja bhāva dassana atthan ti veditabbam
translated: And the mention of these two again should be understood as said in order to show that they are very blamable.

original: Mahāsāvajjo hi ariyūpavādo, ānantariyasadisattā. Vuttampi cetaṃ “seyyathāpi, sāriputta,
analyzed: mahā sāvajjaḥ hi ānantariya sadisa ttā vuttam pi ca itam seyyathā api sāriputta
translated: For the censure of Noble Ones is very blamable, since it is similar to the immediately successive cause of an action that is a form of action with immediate result. And this is said:

original: bhikkhu sīlasampanno samādhisampanno paññāsampanno diṭṭheva dhamme aññaṃ ārādheyya,🔽evaṃsampadamidaṃ, sāriputta, vadāmi taṃ vācaṃ appahāya taṃ cittaṃ appahāya taṃ diṭṭhiṃ
analyzed: bhikkhu sīla sampanno samādhi sampanno paññā sampanno diṭṭhe iva dhamme aññam ārādheyya  evaṃsampadam idam sāriputta vadāmi tam vācam appahāya tam cittam appahāya tam diṭṭhim
translated: “Sāriputta, suppose a bhikkhu endowed with virtue, concentration, and wisdom were to attain final knowledge on the basis of this very life,

original: appaṭinissajjitvā yathābhataṃ nikkhitto, evaṃ niraye”ti. Micchādiṭṭhito ca mahāsāvajjataraṃ
analyzed: a paṭinissajjitvā yathābhatam nikkhittaḥ evam niraya iti micchā diṭṭhitaḥ ca
translated: then I say that unless he abandons that speech, relinquishes it, and gives it up, he will go to hell as surely as if he had been carried off and put there. ”🔽And there is nothing more very blamable than wrong view,

original: nāma aññaṃ natthi. Yathāha “nāhaṃ, bhikkhave, aññaṃ ekadhammampi samanupassāmi, yaṃ
analyzed: nāma aññam natthi yathā āha na aham bhikkhave aññam eka dhammam pi samanupassāmi yam
translated: according as it is said: “Bhikkhus, I see no other single thing so blamable as wrong view,

original: evaṃ mahāsāvajjaṃ, yathayidaṃ, bhikkhave, micchādiṭṭhi. Micchādiṭṭhiparamāni, bhikkhave, vajjānī”ti.
analyzed: evam mahā sāvajjam yathayidam bhikkhave micchādiṭṭhi micchādiṭṭhi paramāni bhikkhave vajjāni iti
translated: wrong view is the most blamable of all wrongnesses” .

original: Kāyassa bhedāti upādiṇṇakkhandhapariccāgā. Parammaraṇāti tadanantaraṃ abhinibbattikkhandhaggahaṇe.
analyzed: kāyassa bhedā ati upādiṇṇa kkhandha pariccāgā parammaraṇā ti tad anantaram abhinibbatti kkhandha ggahaṇe
translated: With the breakup of the body: with the giving up of the appropriated aggregates. After death: in the next rebirth-linking after that.

original: Atha vā kāyassa bhedāti jīvitindriyassa upacchedā. Parammaraṇāti cuticittato uddhaṃ.
analyzed: atha vā kāyassa bhedā ati jīvitindriyassa upacchedā parammaraṇā ati cuti cittataḥ
translated: Or alternatively, with the breakup of the body means with the termination of the life faculty. After death means after the death consciousness.

original: Apāyanti evamādi sabbaṃ nirayavevacanameva.
analyzed: apāyanti evamādi sabbam niraya vevacanam eva
translated: The words “the states of deprivation” and so on are all synonyms for hell.

original: Nirayo hi saggamokkhahetubhūtā puññasammatā ayā apetattā, sukhānaṃ vā āyassa abhāvā🔽apāyo. Dukkhassa gati paṭisaraṇanti duggati, dosabahulatāya vā duṭṭhena kammunā nibbattā
analyzed: nirayaḥ hi saggamokkha hetu bhūtā puñña sammatā ayā apeta ttā sukhānam vā āyassa abhāvā  apāyaḥ dukkhassa gati paṭisaraṇanti duggati dosa bahula tāya vā duṭṭhena kammunā nibbattā
translated: For hell is a state of deprivation because it is not a place of merit that is a cause for rebirth in the heavenly worlds, or because there is no happiness there.🔽It is a bad destination because it is the destination of suffering, or because it is a destination produced by evil kamma that is abundant in hate.🔽It is a bad bourn because it is a bourn that is evil.

original: gatīti duggati. Vivasā nipatanti ettha dukkaṭakārinoti vinipāto. Vinassantā vā ettha
analyzed: gati iti duggati vivasāḥ nipatanti ettha dukkaṭa kārinaḥ ti vinipātaḥ vinassantā vā ettha
translated: Evil-doers fall into it, thus it is a downfall.🔽Or it is a downfall because here they fall and their limbs and joints are smashed.

original: patanti saṃbhijjamānaṅgapaccaṅgātipi vinipāto. Natthi ettha assādasaññito ayoti nirayo.
analyzed: patanti vinipātaḥ na atthi ettha assāda saññitaḥ ayaḥ ti nirayaḥ
translated: There is no perception of pleasure there, thus it is hell .

original: Atha vā apāyaggahaṇena tiracchānayoniṃ dīpeti. Tiracchānayoni hi apāyo sugatito apetattā,
analyzed: atha vā apāya ggahaṇena tiracchānayonim dīpeti tiracchānayoni hi apāyaḥ sugatitaḥ apeta tā
translated: Or alternatively, by the word “deprivation” he shows the animal realm. For the animal realm is a deprivation because it is a place of deprivation of the happy destiny,

original: na duggati mahesakkhānaṃ nāgarājādīnaṃ sambhavato. Duggatiggahaṇena pettivisayaṃ.
analyzed: na duggati mahesakkhānam nāga rāja ādīnam sambhavataḥ duggati ggahaṇena petti visayam
translated: The unhappy destinies are the animal and ghost realms.

original: So hi apāyo ceva duggati ca, sugatito apetattā dukkhassa ca gatibhūtattā. Na tu vinipāto🔽asurasadisaṃ avinipatitattā. Vinipātaggahaṇena asurakāyaṃ. So hi yathāvuttena atthena
analyzed: saḥ hi apāyaḥ ca iva duggati ca sugatitaḥ apeta ttā dukkhassa ca gati bhūta ttā na tu vinipātaḥ  asura sadisam a vinipatita ttā vinipāta ggahaṇena asura kāyam saḥ hi yathāvuttena atthena
translated: For that is a bad destination and an unhappy destiny because it is not a good destination and is a destination for suffering. But it is not a downfall🔽because it is not fallen like the asura world.

original: apāyo ceva duggati ca sabbasamussayehi ca vinipatitattā vinipātoti vuccati. Nirayaggahaṇena
analyzed: apāyo ca iva duggati ca sabba samussayehi ca vinipatita ttā vinipāto ti vuccati niraya ggahaṇena
translated: The downfall is the asura world. For that is a bad destination and an unhappy destiny because of the reasons already given, and it is called a downfall because it is fallen among all the worlds.🔽The hell is the hell world alone, which is of many kinds, such as the Avīci hell, etc.

original: avīciādianekappakāraṃ nirayamevāti. Upapannāti upagatā, tattha abhinibbattāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: avīci ādi aneka ppakāram nirayam eva ati upapannā ati upagatā tattha abhinibbattā ati adhippāyaḥ
translated: “Have been reborn there” : the intention is that they have gone there and been born there.

original: Vuttavipariyāyena sukkapakkho veditabbo.
analyzed: vutta vipariyāyena sukkapakkhaḥ veditabbaḥ
translated: The bright side should be understood in the opposite sense to the dark side.

original: Ayaṃ pana viseso, tattha sugatiggahaṇena manussagatipi saṅgayhati. Saggaggahaṇena
analyzed: ayam pana visesaḥ tattha sugati ggahaṇena manussa gati pi saṅgayhati sagga ggahaṇena
translated: But there is this difference. Here, by the word “good destination” the human destination is included.🔽By the word “heaven”

original: devagatiyeva. Tattha sundarā gatīti sugati. Rūpādīhi visayehi suṭṭhu aggoti saggo.
analyzed: deva gatiyā iva tattha sundarā gatī iti sugati rūpa ādīhi visayehi suṭṭhu aggo ti saggo
translated: only the divine destination is included. Herein, a good destination is a good destination because it is a beautiful destination. Heaven is a destination because it is gone by gods .

original: So sabbopi lujjanapalujjanaṭṭhena lokoti ayaṃ vacanattho.
analyzed: so sabbaḥ api lujjana palujjana ṭṭhena loko ti ayam vacana atthaḥ
translated: All this is the world in the sense of what is broken up and subject to breakage. This is the word meaning.

original: “Iti dibbena cakkhunā”tiādi sabbaṃ nigamanavacanaṃ. Evaṃ dibbena cakkhunā…pe… passatīti ayamettha saṅkhepattho.
analyzed: iti dibbena cakkhunā atiādi sabbam nigamana vacanam evam dibbena cakkhunā āpe passati iti ayam ettha saṅkhepa attho
translated: The rest of the passage beginning “With the divine eye” is a summing up. The meaning in brief is this: he sees with the divine eye, which is purified and superhuman, that beings pass away and arise: that is, he sees the death and reappearance of beings.

original: 412. Evaṃ passitukāmena pana ādikammikena kulaputtena kasiṇārammaṇaṃ abhiññāpādakajjhānaṃ🔽sabbākārena abhinīhārakkhamaṃ katvā “tejokasiṇaṃ, odātakasiṇaṃ, ālokakasiṇa”nti imesu
analyzed: evam passitu kāmena pana ādikammikena kula puttena kasiṇa ārammaṇam abhiññā pādaka jjhānam  sabba ākārena abhinīhāra khamam katvā tejaḥ kasiṇam odāta kasiṇam āloka kasiṇanti imesu
translated: But when a clansman who is a beginner wants to see in this way, he should first of all reach absorption in the fine-material sphere with a meditation subject consisting of a kasiṇa,🔽and he should do this by making the meditation subject of the counterpart sign reach absorption. Then he should make one of the three kasiṇas, namely, the fire kasiṇa, the white kasiṇa, or the light kasiṇa, his proximate cause.

original: tīsu kasiṇesu aññataraṃ āsannaṃ kātabbaṃ. Upacārajjhānagocaraṃ katvā vaḍḍhetvā ṭhapetabbaṃ.
analyzed: tīsu kasiṇesu aññataram āsannam kātabbam upacāra jhāna gocaram katvā vaḍḍhetvā ṭhapetabbam
translated: He should extend it and establish it as the domain of access concentration.

original: Na tattha appanā uppādetabbāti adhippāyo. Sace hi uppādeti, pādakajjhānanissayaṃ
analyzed: na tattha appanā uppādetabbā ti adhippāyaḥ sace hi uppādeti pādaka jhāna nissayam
translated: The intention is that he should not arouse absorption in it. For if he does arouse absorption in it, it will be dependent on the basic jhāna,

original: hoti, na parikammanissayaṃ. Imesu ca pana tīsu ālokakasiṇaṃyeva seṭṭhataraṃ. Tasmā
analyzed: hoti na parikamma nissayam imesu ca pana tīsu āloka kasiṇaṃ yeva seṭṭhataram tasmā
translated: not on the preliminary work. And of the three kasiṇas mentioned, the light kasiṇa is the best.

original: taṃ vā itaresaṃ vā aññataraṃ kasiṇaniddese vuttanayena uppādetvā upacārabhūmiyaṃyeva
analyzed: tam vā itaresam vā aññataram kasiṇa niddese vutta nayena uppādetvā upacāra bhūmiyaṃyeva
translated: So he should arouse whichever of these three kasiṇas he is familiar with in the way already described under the kasiṇa description, and he should make it his domain in access concentration.

original: ṭhatvā vaḍḍhetabbaṃ. Vaḍḍhanānayopi cassa tattha vuttanayeneva veditabbo.
analyzed: ṭhatvā vaḍḍhetabbam vaḍḍhanā nayaḥ api ca ssa tattha vutta nayena iva veditabbaḥ
translated: and it should be extended. And the method of extending it should be understood in the way already described.

original: Vaḍḍhitaṭṭhānassa antoyeva rūpagataṃ passitabbaṃ. Rūpagataṃ passato panassa parikammassa
analyzed: vaḍḍhita ṭṭhānassa antoyeva rūpa gatam passitabbam rūpa gatam passato panassa parikammassa
translated: The materiality should be seen inside the place extended. But when he sees the materiality,

original: vāro atikkamati. Tato āloko antaradhāyati. Tasmiṃ antarahite rūpagatampi na dissati.
analyzed: vāraḥ atikkamati tatas ālokaḥ antaradhāyati tasmin antarahite rūpa gatam pi na dissati
translated: the turn of the preliminary work is passed. Then the light disappears. When it has disappeared, the materiality is not seen.🔽Then he should enter again and again upon the basic jhāna, emerge, and spread the light.

original: Athānena punappunaṃ pādakajjhānameva pavisitvā tato vuṭṭhāya āloko pharitabbo. Evaṃ
analyzed: atha anena punappunam pādakajjhānam eva pavisitvā tatas vuṭṭhāya āloko pharitabbo evam
translated: In this way,🔽as he goes on doing this, the light becomes fixed.

original: anukkamena āloko thāmagato hotīti ettha āloko hotūti yattakaṃ ṭhānaṃ paricchindati,
analyzed: anukkamena āloko thāma gataḥ hoti iti ettha ālokaḥ hotu uti yattakam ṭhānam paricchindati
translated: When he thinks, “Let there be light,” it extends as far as he has delimited the place.

original: tattha āloko tiṭṭhatiyeva. Divasampi nisīditvā passato rūpadassanaṃ hoti. Rattiṃ
analyzed: tattha āloko tiṭṭhatiyā iva divasam pi nisīditvā passataḥ rūpa dassanam hoti rattim
translated: The light remains there. He sees the materiality even if he sits there all day.

original: tiṇukkāya maggapaṭipanno cettha puriso opammaṃ.
analyzed: tiṇukkāya magga paṭipanno ca ittha puriso opammaṃ
translated: The simile here is that of a man who sets out on a journey at night by the light of a torch.

original: Eko kira rattiṃ tiṇukkāya maggaṃ paṭipajji. Tassa sā tiṇukkā vijjhāyi. Athassa samavisamāni
analyzed: ekaḥ kira rattim tiṇukkāya maggam paṭipajji tassa sā tiṇukkā vijjhāyi athassa sama visamāni
translated: It seems that a man once set out on a journey at night by the light of a torch. His torch flared up and went out.

original: na paññāyiṃsu. So taṃ tiṇukkaṃ bhūmiyaṃ ghaṃsitvā tiṇukkā puna ujjālesi. Sā pajjalitvā
analyzed: na paññāyiṃsu saḥ tam tiṇukkam bhūmiyam ghaṃsitvā tiṇukkā punar ujjālesi sā pajjalitvā
translated: They did not. He struck the torch on the ground, and the torch flared up again. It burned

original: purimālokato mahantataraṃ ālokaṃ akāsi. Evaṃ punappunaṃ vijjhātaṃ ujjālayato kamena
analyzed: purima ālokataḥ mahantataram ālokam akāsi evam punappunam vijjhātam ujjālayataḥ kamena
translated: and gave more light than before. As he kept striking it and flaring it up again,

original: sūriyo uṭṭhāsi. Sūriye uṭṭhite ukkāya kammaṃ natthīti taṃ chaḍḍetvā divasampi agamāsi.🔽Tattha ukkāloko viya parikammakāle kasiṇāloko. Ukkāya vijjhātāya samavisamānaṃ adassanaṃ
analyzed: sūriyaḥ uṭṭhāsi sūriye uṭṭhite ukkāya kammam natthi iti tam chaḍḍetvā divasam pi agamāsi  tattha ukka ālokaḥ viya parikamma kāle kasiṇa ālokaḥ ukkāya vijjhātāya sama visamānam adassanam
translated: in the end the sun rose. When the sun rose, there was no more need for the torch, so he threw it away and went on his way for the day.

original: viya rūpagataṃ passato parikammassa vārātikkamena āloke antarahite rūpagatānaṃ adassanaṃ.🔽Ukkāya ghaṃsanaṃ viya punappunaṃ pavesanaṃ. Ukkāya purimālokato mahantatarālokakaraṇaṃ🔽viya puna parikammaṃ karoto balavatarālokapharaṇaṃ. Sūriyuṭṭhānaṃ viya thāmagatālokassa
analyzed: viya rūpa gatam passataḥ parikammassa vāra atikkamena āloke antarahite rūpa gatānam adassanam  ukkāya ghaṃsanam viya punappunam pavesanam ukkāya purima ālokataḥ mahantatara āloka karaṇam  viya puna parikammam karotaḥ balavatara āloka pharaṇam sūriyuṭṭhānam viya thāma gata ālokassa
translated: Herein, the torch’s light is like the kasiṇa’s appearance at the time of the preliminary work. The torch’s not showing what is uneven when it is struck is like the kasiṇa’s not showing the object’s materiality when the preliminary work is done.

original: yathāparicchedena ṭhānaṃ. Tiṇukkaṃ chaḍḍetvā divasampi gamanaṃ viya parittālokaṃ
analyzed: yathā paricchedena ṭhānam tiṇukkam chaḍḍetvā divasam pi gamanam viya paritta ālokam
translated: The striking of the torch is like the repeated attention. The torch’s giving more light than before is like the greater diffusion of light when the preliminary work is done again. The sun’s rising is like the light’s remaining in its own place when it has reached its goal. The man’s going on his way for the day after throwing away the torch is like the abandoning of the limited light.

original: chaḍḍetvā thāmagatenālokena divasampi rūpadassanaṃ.🔽Tattha yadā tassa bhikkhuno maṃsacakkhussa anāpāthagataṃ antokucchigataṃ hadayavatthunissitaṃ
analyzed: chaḍḍetvā thāma gatena ālokena divasam pi rūpa dassanam  tattha yadā tassa bhikkhuno maṃsa cakkhussa anāpātha gatam antar kucchi gatam hadaya vatthu nissitam
translated: and he can see forms by day with the light of the moon and stars.

original: heṭṭhāpathavītalanissitaṃ tirokuṭṭapabbatapākāragataṃ paracakkavāḷagatanti idaṃ rūpaṃ🔽ñāṇacakkhussa āpāthaṃ āgacchati, maṃsacakkhunā dissamānaṃ viya hoti, tadā dibbacakkhu
analyzed: heṭṭhā pathavī tala nissitam tiro kuṭṭa pabbata pākāra gatam para cakkavāḷa gatam idam rūpam  ñāṇa cakkhussa āpātham āgacchati maṃsa cakkhunā dissamānam viya hoti tadā dibba cakkhu
translated: Herein, when the form that is not within the range of the bhikkhu’s physical eye, that is, form that is inside the earth, inside a mountain, inside a wall, inside a rock, inside water, or beyond the reach of the physical eye, comes into the range of his knowledge eye,

original: uppannaṃ hotīti veditabbaṃ. Tadeva cettha rūpadassanasamatthaṃ, na pubbabhāgacittāni.🔽Taṃ panetaṃ puthujjanassa paribandho hoti. Kasmā? So hi yasmā yattha yattha āloko
analyzed: uppannam hoti iti veditabbam tat eva ca ittha rūpa dassana samattham na pubbabhāga cittāni  tam pana itam puthujjanassa paribandho hoti kasmā saḥ hi yasmā yattha yattha āloko
translated: then it is as if it were seen with the physical eye. That is how it should be understood that the divine eye has arisen in him. But only that form is capable of being seen that is capable of being seen with the physical eye. The states of consciousness and its concomitants that occur in the prior stage are not.

original: hotūti adhiṭṭhāti, taṃ taṃ pathavīsamuddapabbate vinivijjhitvāpi ekālokaṃ hoti, athassa
analyzed: hotu uti adhiṭṭhāti tam tam pathavī samudda pabbate vinivijjhitvā api ekālokam hoti athassa
translated: But this is an impediment for the ordinary man. Why? Because wherever he resolves, “Let there be light,” light appears to him even if it is underground, in the sea, inside a mountain, or inside a rock.

original: tattha bhayānakāni yakkharakkhasādirūpāni passato bhayaṃ uppajjati. Yena cittavikkhepaṃ
analyzed: tattha bhayānakāni yakkha rakkhasa ādi rūpāni passataḥ bhayam uppajjati yena citta vikkhepam
translated: Then, when he sees fearful forms such as yakkhas, demons, etc., there, fear arises in him.🔽And when he sees delightful forms such as celestial nymphs, etc., there, lust arises in him. And because of the distraction of consciousness, the divine eye disappears.

original: patvā jhānavibbhantako hoti, tasmā rūpadassane appamattena bhavitabbaṃ.
analyzed: patvā jhāna vibbhantakaḥ hoti tasmā rūpa dassane appamattena bhavitabbam
translated: and he is distracted from jhāna when he has seen the visible object. So one who wants to see a visible object should be heedful.

original: Tatrāyaṃ dibbacakkhuno uppattikkamo. Vuttappakārametaṃ rūpamārammaṇaṃ katvā manodvārāvajjane
analyzed: tatra ayam dibba cakkhuno uppatti kkamaḥ vutta ppakāram etam rūpam ārammaṇam katvā manaḥ dvāra āvajjane
translated: Here is the order in which the divine eye arises. After the adverting, the first cognitive series consisting of impulsions and having that visible object occurs, and then the second cognitive series consisting of impulsions and having that same visible object occurs.

original: uppajjitvā niruddhe tadeva rūpaṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā cattāri pañca vā javanāni uppajjantīti
analyzed: uppajjitvā niruddhe tat eva rūpam ārammaṇam katvā cattāri pañca vā javanāni uppajjanti iti
translated: After that has ceased, four or five impulsion consciousnesses occur having that same visible object.

original: sabbaṃ purimanayeneva veditabbaṃ. Idhāpi pubbabhāgacittāni savitakkasavicārāni kāmāvacarāni.
analyzed: sabbam purima nayena iva veditabbam idha api pubbabhāga cittāni sa vitakka sa vicārāni kāmāvacarāni
translated: All this should be understood in the way already described under the divine ear. Here too the first cognitive series is of the sense sphere and has applied and sustained thought.

original: Pariyosāne atthasādhakacittaṃ catutthajjhānikaṃ rūpāvacaraṃ. Tena sahajātaṃ ñāṇaṃ
analyzed: pariyosāne attha sādhaka cittam catuttha jhānikam rūpa avacaram tena sahajātam ñāṇam
translated: The last consciousness in the cognitive series that accomplishes the purpose is of the fine-material sphere and belongs to the fourth jhāna. The knowledge that is associated with that

original: sattānaṃ cutūpapāte ñāṇantipi dibbacakkhuñāṇantipi vuccatīti.
analyzed: sattānam cutūpapāte ñāṇam tipi dibba cakkhu ñāṇam tipi vuccati iti
translated: is called “knowledge of passing away and reappearance” and “knowledge of the divine eye.”

original: Cutūpapātañāṇakathā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: cutūpapāta ñāṇa kathā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of knowledge of passing away and reappearance is ended.

original: Pakiṇṇakakathā
analyzed: pakiṇṇaka kathā
translated: Miscellaneous Explanations🔽The one who knows the five aggregates thus,

original: Iti pañcakkhandhavidū, pañca abhiññā avoca yā nātho;
analyzed: iti pañcakkhandha vidū pañca abhiññāḥ avoca yāḥ nātho
translated: The five kinds of direct-knowledge the Helper taught;🔽When these are known, the miscellaneous explanations

original: Tā ñatvā tāsu ayaṃ, pakiṇṇakakathāpi viññeyyā.
analyzed: tāḥ ñatvā tāsu ayam pakiṇṇaka kathā api viññeyyā
translated: Should be understood as follows.

original: Etāsu hi yadetaṃ cutūpapātañāṇasaṅkhātaṃ dibbacakkhu, tassa anāgataṃsañāṇañca yathākammupagañāṇañcāti
analyzed: etāsu hi yat etam cutu upapāta ñāṇa saṅkhātam dibba cakkhu tassa anāgataṃsa ñāṇañca yathā kammupaga ñāṇañca ati
translated: For the divine eye, called knowledge of passing away and reappearance, has two kinds of knowledge as its outer limit, that is to say, knowledge of future states and knowledge of faring according to deeds.

original: dvepi paribhaṇḍañāṇāni honti. Iti imāni ca dve iddhividhādīni ca pañcāti satta abhiññāñāṇāni
analyzed: dve api paribhaṇḍañāṇāni honti iti imāni ca dve iddhividha ādīni ca pañca ati satta abhiññāñāṇāni
translated: So these two and the five beginning with the supernormal power make seven kinds of knowledge of the kinds of direct-knowledge.

original: idhāgatāni. Idāni tesaṃ ārammaṇavibhāge asammohatthaṃ –
analyzed: idha āgatāni idāni tesam ārammaṇa vibhāge asammoha attham
translated: They are included here. Now, in order to avoid confusion about the classification of their objects,🔽The four kinds of object have been stated

original: Ārammaṇattikā vuttā, ye cattāro mahesinā;
analyzed: ārammaṇattikāḥ vuttāḥ ye cattāro mahesinā
translated: By the Great Sage; I shall show the way🔽In which the seven kinds of knowledge occur

original: Sattannamapi ñāṇānaṃ, pavattiṃ tesu dīpaye.
analyzed: sattannam api ñāṇānam pavattim tesu dīpaye
translated: In reference to them.

original: Tatrāyaṃ dīpanā. Cattāro hi ārammaṇattikā mahesinā vuttā. Katame cattāro? Parittārammaṇattiko, maggārammaṇattiko, atītārammaṇattiko, ajjhattārammaṇattikoti.
analyzed: tatra ayam dīpanā cattāraḥ hi ārammaṇa attikāḥ mahesinā vuttā katame cattāro paritta ārammaṇa attikaḥ magga ārammaṇa attikaḥ atīta ārammaṇa attikaḥ ajjhatta ārammaṇa attikaḥ ti
translated: Here is the explanation. For four kinds of object have been stated by the Great Sage. What are the four? The limited object, the path object, the past object, and the internal object.

original: 414. Tattha iddhividhañāṇaṃ parittamahaggataatītānāgatapaccuppannaajjhattabahiddhārammaṇavasena
analyzed: tattha iddhividha ñāṇam paritta mahaggata atīta anāgata paccuppanna ajjhatta bahiddha ārammaṇa vasena
translated: Herein, knowledge of supernormal power occurs in reference to seven kinds of object, that is to say, the limited, the exalted, the past, the future, the present, the internal, and the external.

original: sattasu ārammaṇesu pavattati. Kathaṃ? Tañhi yadā kāyaṃ cittasannissitaṃ katvā adissamānena
analyzed: sattasu ārammaṇesu pavattati katham tat hi yadā kāyam citta sannissitam katvā a dissamānena
translated: How? When it is produced by making the body dependent on the mind, then it occurs in reference to the limited object.

original: kāyena gantukāmo cittavasena kāyaṃ pariṇāmeti, mahaggatacitte samodahati samāropeti,
analyzed: kāyena gantu kāmaḥ citta vasena kāyam pariṇāmeti mahaggata citte samodahati samāropeti
translated: When he wants to go by means of the body, he converts the body to accord with the mind, he directs and inclines the exalted consciousness to the body.

original: tadā upayogaladdhaṃ ārammaṇaṃ hotīti katvā rūpakāyārammaṇato parittārammaṇaṃ hoti.🔽Yadā cittaṃ kāyasannissitaṃ katvā dissamānena kāyena gantukāmo kāyavasena cittaṃ
analyzed: tadā upayoga laddham ārammaṇam hoti iti katvā rūpa kāya ārammaṇataḥ paritta ārammaṇam hoti  yadā cittam kāya sannissitam katvā dissamānena kāyena gantu kāmaḥ kāya vasena cittam
translated: Then it is called “having a limited object” because it has material body as its object, which is acquired by use.

original: pariṇāmeti, pādakajjhānacittaṃ rūpakāye samodahati samāropeti, tadā upayogaladdhaṃ
analyzed: pariṇāma iti pādaka jjhāna cittam rūpa kāye samodahati samāropeti tadā upayoga laddham
translated: When he wants to go by means of the body, making the mind dependent on the body, with a visible body, he converts the mind to accord with the body, he directs and inclines the consciousness of the basic jhāna to the material body.

original: ārammaṇaṃ hotīti katvā mahaggatacittārammaṇato mahaggatārammaṇaṃ hoti.
analyzed: ārammaṇam hoti iti katvā mahaggata citta ārammaṇataḥ mahaggata ārammaṇam hoti
translated: Then it is called “having a great object” because it has exalted consciousness as its object, which is acquired by use.

original: Yasmā pana tadeva cittaṃ atītaṃ niruddhaṃ ārammaṇaṃ karoti, tasmā atītārammaṇaṃ hoti.🔽Mahādhātunidhāne mahākassapattherādīnaṃ viya anāgataṃ adhiṭṭhahantānaṃ anāgatārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: yasmai pana tat eva cittam atītam niruddham ārammaṇam karoti tasmai atīta ārammaṇam hoti  mahādhātu nidhāne mahākassapatthera ādīnam viya anāgatam adhiṭṭhahantānam anāgata ārammaṇam
translated: But because it is that same consciousness that makes the past and the ceased object its object, it is called “having a past object.”🔽When they resolve upon the future, as in the case of the Elder Mahā Kassapa and the elders of the Dhātuvamsa, it is called “having a future object.”

original: hoti. Mahākassapatthero kira mahādhātunidhānaṃ karonto “anāgate aṭṭhārasavassādhikāni
analyzed: hoti mahākassapa thero kira mahā dhātu nidhānam karontaḥ anāgate aṭṭhārasa vassa adhikāni
translated: The Elder Mahā Kassapa, it seems, when he was making the Great Council of the Dhamma, resolved upon the future thus, “Let there be no one who, eighteen years hence, will be able to say that the Dhamma has disappeared.”

original: dvevassasatāni ime gandhā mā sussiṃsu, pupphāni mā milāyiṃsu, dīpā mā nibbāyiṃsū”ti
analyzed: dve vassa satāni ime gandhāḥ mā sussiṃsu pupphāni mā milāyiṃsu dīpāḥ mā nibbāyiṃsu iti
translated: “Let these perfumes not fade, let these flowers not wither, let these lamps not go out for two hundred and fifty years.”

original: adhiṭṭhahi. Sabbaṃ tatheva ahosi. Assaguttatthero vattaniyasenāsane bhikkhusaṅghaṃ🔽sukkhabhattaṃ bhuñjamānaṃ disvā udakasoṇḍiṃ divase divase purebhatte dadhirasaṃ hotūti
analyzed: adhiṭṭhahi sabbam tathā iva ahosi assagutta thero vattaniya senāsane bhikkhu saṅgham  sukkhabhattam bhuñjamānam disvā udaka soṇḍim divase divase purebhatte dadhi rasam hotu uti
translated: And all happened as he had resolved. The Elder Assagutta saw the Community of Bhikkhus eating dry food in the dwelling place of the Vattaniya.🔽He resolved, “Let the water-sistrum be curd-juice every day before the meal.”

original: adhiṭṭhāsi. Purebhatte gahitaṃ dadhirasaṃ hoti. Pacchābhatte pākatikaudakameva. Kāyaṃ
analyzed: purebhatte gahitam dadhi rasam hoti pacchābhatte pākatika audakam eva kāyam
translated: When it was taken before the meal it was curd-juice, but when it was taken after the meal it was ordinary water.

original: pana cittasannissitaṃ katvā adissamānena kāyena gamanakāle paccuppannārammaṇaṃ hoti.
analyzed: pana citta sannissitam katvā a dissamānena kāyena gamana kāle paccuppanna ārammaṇam hoti
translated: But when the body is made dependent on the mind and he goes with an invisible body, then the object is a present one.

original: Kāyavasena cittaṃ, cittavasena vā kāyaṃ pariṇāmanakāle attano kumārakavaṇṇādinimmānakāle
analyzed: kāya vasena cittam citta vasena vā kāyam pariṇāmana kāle kumāraka vaṇṇa ādi nimmāna kāle
translated: When he converts the mind by means of the body or the body by means of the mind, or when he creates his own form as a boy, etc.,

original: ca sakāyacittānaṃ ārammaṇakaraṇato ajjhattārammaṇaṃ hoti. Bahiddhā hatthiassādidassanakāle
analyzed: ca sa kāya cittānam ārammaṇa karaṇataḥ ajjhatta ārammaṇam hoti bahiddhā hatthi assa ādi dassana kāle
translated: then the object is an internal one because he makes his own body and mind the object. But when he sees externally an elephant, a horse, and so on,

original: pana bahiddhārammaṇanti evaṃ tāva iddhividhañāṇassa sattasu ārammaṇesu pavatti veditabbā.
analyzed: pana bahiddhā ārammaṇan ti evam tāva iddhividha ñāṇassa sattasu ārammaṇesu pavatti veditabbā
translated: then the object is external. This is how the mode of operation of knowledge of the kinds of supernormal power should be understood in the seven ways.

original: 415. Dibbasotadhātuñāṇaṃ parittapaccuppannaajjhattabahiddhārammaṇavasena catūsu ārammaṇesu🔽pavattati. Kathaṃ? Tañhi yasmā saddaṃ ārammaṇaṃ karoti, saddo ca paritto, tasmā parittārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: dibba sota dhātu ñāṇam paritta paccuppanna ajjhatta bahiddha ārammaṇa vasena catūsu ārammaṇesu  pavattati katham tat hi yasmā saddam ārammaṇam karoti saddo ca parittaḥ tasmā paritta ārammaṇam
translated: Knowledge of the divine ear element occurs with respect to four objects, namely, limited, proximate, internal, and external objects.🔽How? Because it makes sound its object, and sound is limited, its object is limited.

original: hoti. Vijjamānaṃyeva pana saddaṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā pavattanato paccuppannārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: hoti vijjamānam yeva pana saddam ārammaṇam katvā pavattanato paccuppanna ārammaṇam
translated: Because it occurs making sound that is actually present its object, its object is present.

original: hoti. Taṃ attano kucchisaddasavanakāle ajjhattārammaṇaṃ. Paresaṃ saddasavanakāle
analyzed: hoti tam attanaḥ kucchi sadda savana kāle ajjhatta ārammaṇam paresam sadda savana kāle
translated: When it hears one’s own sounds in one’s own belly, its object is internal.

original: bahiddhārammaṇanti evaṃ dibbasotadhātuñāṇassa catūsu ārammaṇesu pavatti veditabbā.🔽416. Cetopariyañāṇaṃ parittamahaggataappamāṇamaggaatītānāgatapaccuppannabahiddhārammaṇavasena
analyzed: bahiddhā ārammaṇan ti evam dibba sota dhātu ñāṇassa catūsu ārammaṇesu pavatti veditabbā  cetas upariya ñāṇam paritta mahaggata appamāṇa magga atīta anāgata paccuppanna bahiddha ārammaṇa vasena
translated: When it hears the sounds of others, its object is external. This is how the divine ear element’s occurrence with respect to the four objects should be understood.🔽Knowledge of penetration of minds occurs with respect to eight objects, namely, limited, exalted, far, near, past, future, present, and external objects.

original: aṭṭhasu ārammaṇesu pavattati. Kathaṃ? Tañhi paresaṃ kāmāvacaracittajānanakāle parittārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: aṭṭhasu ārammaṇesu pavattati katham tat hi paresam kāmāvacara citta jānana kāle paritta ārammaṇam
translated: How? When it knows the consciousnesses of others in the sense-desire realm, its object is limited.

original: hoti. Rūpāvacaraarūpāvacaracittajānanakāle mahaggatārammaṇaṃ hoti. Maggaphalajānanakāle
analyzed: hoti rūpāvacara arūpāvacara citta jānana kāle mahaggata ārammaṇam hoti magga phala jānana kāle
translated: At the time of knowing the consciousnesses of the fine-material and immaterial spheres, it has a great object.

original: appamāṇārammaṇaṃ hoti.
analyzed: appamāṇa ārammaṇam hoti
translated: At the time of knowing the path and fruition, it has an immeasurable object.

original: Ettha ca puthujjano sotāpannassa cittaṃ na jānāti. Sotāpanno vā sakadāgāmissāti evaṃ
analyzed: ettha ca puthujjanaḥ sotāpannassa cittam na jānāti sotāpannaḥ vā sakadāgāmissa ati evam
translated: And here, the consciousness of an ordinary man does not know the consciousness of a stream-enterer. Or the consciousness of a stream-enterer does not know that of a once-returner. Thus it should be understood

original: yāva arahato netabbaṃ. Arahā pana sabbesaṃ cittaṃ jānāti. Aññopi ca uparimo heṭṭhimassāti🔽ayaṃ viseso veditabbo. Maggacittārammaṇakāle maggārammaṇaṃ hoti. Yadā pana atīte
analyzed: yāva arahataḥ netabbam arahā pana sabbesam cittam jānāti aññaḥ api ca uparimaḥ heṭṭhimassa ati  ayam visesaḥ veditabbaḥ magga citta ārammaṇa kāle magga ārammaṇam hoti yadā pana atīte
translated: that the higher does not know the lower. But the arahat knows the consciousness of all. And the higher knows the lower.

original: sattadivasabbhantare ca anāgate sattadivasabbhantare ca paresaṃ cittaṃ jānāti, tadā
analyzed: satta divasa bbhantare ca anāgate satta divasa bbhantare ca paresam cittam jānāti tadā
translated: This is the distinction. At the time of having the path consciousness as object, it has the path as object. But when he knows the consciousness of others within the seven days past and the seven days to come,

original: atītārammaṇaṃ anāgatārammaṇañca hoti.
analyzed: atīta ārammaṇam anāgata ārammaṇam ca hoti
translated: then it has a past object and a future object.

original: Kathaṃ paccuppannārammaṇaṃ hoti. Paccuppannaṃ nāma tividhaṃ – khaṇapaccuppannaṃ,
analyzed: katham paccuppanna ārammaṇam hoti paccuppannam nāma tividham khaṇa paccuppannam
translated: How does it have a present object? The present is threefold: momentary present,

original: santatipaccuppannaṃ, addhāpaccuppannañca. Tattha uppādaṭṭhitibhaṅgappattaṃ khaṇapaccuppannaṃ.
analyzed: santati paccuppannam addhā paccuppannam ca tattha uppāda ṭṭhiti bhaṅga ppattam khaṇa paccuppannam
translated: continuous present, and present as occasion. Herein, the momentary present is what has reached the stage of arising, presence, and dissolution.

original: Ekadvesantativārapariyāpannaṃ santatipaccuppannaṃ. Tattha andhakāre nisīditvā ālokaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: eka dve santati vāra pariyāpannam santati paccuppannam tattha andhakāre nisīditvā āloka ṭṭhānam
translated: and the present in a continuity is the present in a continuity. Herein, when a man sits in the dark and goes to a place where there is light,

original: gatassa na tāva ārammaṇaṃ pākaṭaṃ hoti, yāva pana taṃ pākaṭaṃ hoti, etthantare ekadvesantativārā
analyzed: gatassa na tāva ārammaṇam pākaṭam hoti yāva pana tam pākaṭam hoti etthantare eka dvesantati vārā
translated: the object is not clear to him at first, but while it is becoming clear, the one or two moments should be understood as the present in a moment.

original: veditabbā. Ālokaṭṭhāne vicaritvā ovarakaṃ paviṭṭhassāpi na tāva sahasā rūpaṃ pākaṭaṃ
analyzed: veditabbā āloka ṭṭhāne vicaritvā ovarakam paviṭṭhassa api na tāva sahasā rūpam pākaṭam
translated: And when he has moved about in the light and entered a room, the form is not clear to him at first all of a sudden,

original: hoti, yāva pana taṃ pākaṭaṃ hoti, etthantare ekadvesantativārā veditabbā. Dūre ṭhatvā
analyzed: hoti yāva pana tam pākaṭam hoti etthantare eka dvesantati vārāḥ veditabbāḥ dūre ṭhatvā
translated: but while it is becoming clear, the one or two moments should be understood as the present in a moment.

original: pana rajakānaṃ hatthavikāraṃ, ghaṇḍibherīākoṭanavikārañca disvāpi na tāva saddaṃ
analyzed: pana rajakānam hattha vikāram ghaṇḍi bherī ākoṭana vikāram ca disvā api na tāva saddam
translated: But when he stands far away and sees the movements of the hands of the dyers and the movements of the beating of the gongs and drums,

original: suṇāti, yāva pana taṃ suṇāti, etasmimpi antare ekadvesantativārā veditabbā. Evaṃ
analyzed: suṇāti yāva pana tam suṇāti etasmim pi antare eka dvesantati vārāḥ veditabbāḥ evam
translated: he does not hear the sound at first, but while he is hearing it, the one or two moments should be understood as the present in a moment.

original: tāva majjhimabhāṇakā.
analyzed: tāva majjhima bhāṇakā
translated: This, firstly, is according to the Majjhima reciters.

original: Saṃyuttabhāṇakā pana rūpasantati arūpasantatīti dve santatiyo vatvā udakaṃ akkamitvā
analyzed: saṃyutta bhāṇakā pana rūpa santati arūpa santati iti dve santatiyaḥ vatvā udakam akkamitvā
translated: But the Saṃyutta reciters say that there are two kinds of continuity, namely, material continuity and immaterial continuity. Having stepped into water,

original: gatassa yāva tīre akkantaudakalekhā na vippasīdati, addhānato āgatassa yāva kāye🔽usumabhāvo na vūpasammati, ātapā āgantvā gabbhaṃ paviṭṭhassa yāva andhakārabhāvo
analyzed: gatassa yāva tīre akkanta odaka lekhā na vippasīdati addhānataḥ āgatassa yāva kāye  usuma bhāvaḥ na vūpasammati ātapā āgantvā gabbham paviṭṭhassa yāva andhakāra bhāvaḥ
translated: As long as the line of water on the bank does not disappear,🔽as long as the heat in the body of one who has come from a journey does not subside,🔽as long as the darkness does not disappear in one who has come in from the sun and entered the house,

original: na vigacchati, antogabbhe kammaṭṭhānaṃ manasi karitvā divā vātapānaṃ vivaritvā olokentassa
analyzed: na vigacchati antogabbhe kammaṭṭhānam manasi karitvā divā vāta pānam olokentassa
translated: as long as the winking of the eyes does not subside in one who is contemplating the meditation subject in the womb and looking out through the window by day,

original: yāva akkhīnaṃ phandanabhāvo na vūpasammati, ayaṃ rūpasantati nāma. Dve tayo javanavārā
analyzed: yāva akkhīnam phandana bhāvaḥ na ayam rūpasantati nāma dve tayaḥ javana vārā
translated: this is called the continuity of materiality. Two or three impulsions are called the continuity of the immaterial.

original: arūpasantati nāmāti vatvā tadubhayampi santatipaccuppannaṃ nāmāti vadanti.
analyzed: arūpa santati nāma ati vatvā tat ubhayam pi santati paccuppannam nāma ati vadanti
translated: They say that both together are called the present as continuity.

original: Ekabhavaparicchinnaṃ pana addhāpaccuppannaṃ nāma. Yaṃ sandhāya bhaddekarattasutte
analyzed: eka bhava paricchinnam pana addhāpaccuppannam nāma yam sandhāya bhaddekaratta sutte
translated: But what is limited to a single becoming is called the present as duration. With reference to this it is said in the Bhaddekaratta Sutta:

original: “yo cāvuso, mano ye ca dhammā ubhayametaṃ paccuppannaṃ, tasmiṃ ce paccuppanne chandarāgappaṭibaddhaṃ
analyzed: yaḥ ca āvuso manaḥ ye ca dhammāḥ ubhayam etam paccuppannam tasmin ce paccuppanne chanda rāga ppaṭibaddham
translated: “The mind, friends, and thoughts are both present. If consciousness is bound up with desire and lust for what is present,

original: hoti viññāṇaṃ, chandarāgappaṭibaddhattā viññāṇassa tadabhinandati, tadabhinandanto
analyzed: hoti viññāṇam chanda rāga ppaṭibaddha ttā viññāṇassa tat abhinandati tat abhinandanto
translated: then delight arises. When there is delight there is impulsion.

original: paccuppannesu dhammesu saṃhīratī”ti vuttaṃ. Santatipaccuppannañcettha aṭṭhakathāsu
analyzed: paccuppannesu dhammesu saṃhīrati iti vuttam santati paccuppannam ca ittha aṭṭhakathāsu
translated: and it is said that it is ‘concentrated on presently arisen states.’🔽Herein, the ‘present of continuity’ is found in the Commentaries,

original: āgataṃ. Addhāpaccuppannaṃ sutte.
analyzed: āgatam addhā paccuppannam sutte
translated: and the ‘present of duration’ in the Suttas.

original: Tattha keci khaṇapaccuppannaṃ cittaṃ cetopariyañāṇassa ārammaṇaṃ hotīti vadanti.
analyzed: tattha keci khaṇa paccuppannam cittam cetas pariya ñāṇassa ārammaṇam hoti iti vadanti
translated: Herein, some say that the consciousness that is present at a single moment is the object of the knowledge of penetration of minds.

original: Kiṃ kāraṇā? Yasmā iddhimato ca parassa ca ekakkhaṇe cittaṃ uppajjatīti. Idañca nesaṃ🔽opammaṃ, yathā ākāse khitte pupphamuṭṭhimhi avassaṃ ekaṃ pupphaṃ ekassa vaṇṭena vaṇṭaṃ
analyzed: kim kāraṇā yasmai iddhimataḥ ca parassa ca eka khaṇe cittam uppajjati iti idam ca nesam  opammam yathā ākāse khitte puppha muṭṭhimhi avassam ekam puppham ekassa vaṇṭena vaṇṭam
translated: Why? Because the consciousness of the possessor of supernormal power and that of the other arise at a single moment. And this is their simile:

original: paṭivijjhati, evaṃ parassa cittaṃ jānissāmīti rāsivasena mahājanassa citte āvajjite🔽avassaṃ ekassa cittaṃ ekena cittena uppādakkhaṇe vā ṭhitikkhaṇe vā bhaṅgakkhaṇe vā
analyzed: paṭivijjhati evam parassa cittam jānissāmi iti rāsi vasena mahājanassa citte āvajjite  avassam ekassa cittam ekena cittena uppāda khaṇe vā ṭhiti khaṇe vā bhaṅga khaṇe vā
translated: just as when a handful of flowers is thrown into the air and a single flower is pierced by a single stalk, so too, when many people direct their attention thus, ‘We shall know another’s consciousness,’🔽and they advert with the consciousness of the life-continuum,🔽then it is only one consciousness that is pierced by one consciousness at the moment of arising or the moment of presence or the moment of dissolution.

original: paṭivijjhatīti. Taṃ pana vassasatampi vassasahassampi āvajjanto yena ca cittena āvajjati,
analyzed: paṭivijjhati iti tam pana vassa satam pi vassa sahassam pi āvajjantaḥ yena ca cittena āvajjati
translated: But though he adverts for a hundred or a thousand years,

original: yena ca jānāti. Tesaṃ dvinnaṃ sahaṭhānābhāvato āvajjanajavanānañca aniṭṭhaṭṭhāne
analyzed: yena ca jānāti tesam dvinnam saha ṭhāna abhāvataḥ āvajjana javanānam ca aniṭṭha ṭhāne
translated: and by which he knows. Because these two are not simultaneous and because the object of the adverting and the object of the impulsion are not the same,

original: nānārammaṇabhāvappattidosato ayuttanti aṭṭhakathāsu paṭikkhittaṃ.
analyzed: na anārammaṇa bhāva ppatti dosataḥ ayuttan ti aṭṭhakathāsu paṭikkhittam
translated: it is not right that they should be the same object. So it is rejected in the commentaries.

original: Santatipaccuppannaṃ pana addhāpaccuppannañca ārammaṇaṃ hotīti veditabbaṃ. Tattha
analyzed: santati paccuppannam pana addhā paccuppannam ca ārammaṇam hoti iti veditabbam tattha
translated: But it should be understood that the object is what is present in a continuity and what is present in a single temporal unit. Herein,

original: yaṃ vattamānajavanavīthito atītānāgatavasena dvittijavanavīthiparimāṇe kāle parassa🔽cittaṃ, taṃ sabbampi santatipaccuppannaṃ nāma. “Addhāpaccuppannaṃ pana javanavārena
analyzed: yam vattamāna javana vīthitaḥ atīta anāgata vasena dvitti javana vīthi parimāṇe kāle parassa  cittam tam sabbam pi santati paccuppannam nāma addhā paccuppannam pana javana vārena
translated: the consciousness of another that is in the past or future in the interval between two impulsions in the cognitive series of the consciousness of one who is experiencing the present,

original: dīpetabba”nti saṃyuttaṭṭhakathāyaṃ vuttaṃ. Taṃ suṭṭhu vuttaṃ.🔽Tatrāyaṃ dīpanā, iddhimā parassa cittaṃ jānitukāmo āvajjati, āvajjanaṃ khaṇapaccuppannaṃ
analyzed: dīpetabbam ti saṃyutta ṭṭhakathāyam vuttam tat suṭṭhu vuttam  tatra ayam dīpanā iddhimā parassa cittam jānitu kāmo āvajjati āvajjanam khaṇa paccuppannam
translated: all that is called “present in a continuity.” But it is said in the Saṃyutta Commentary: “What is present in a single temporal unit should be demonstrated by the method of impulsion.” That is well said.

original: ārammaṇaṃ katvā teneva saha nirujjhati. Tato cattāri pañca vā javanāni. Yesaṃ pacchimaṃ
analyzed: ārammaṇam katvā tena iva saha nirujjhati tatas cattāri pañca vā javanāni yesam pacchimam
translated: Here is the demonstration: a possessor of supernormal power who wants to know another’s mind adverts. The adverting, having made that other’s consciousness its object, ceases together with it. Then there are four or five impulsions. The last of these,

original: iddhicittaṃ, sesāni kāmāvacarāni, tesaṃ sabbesampi tadeva niruddhaṃ cittamārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: iddhi cittam sesāni kāmāvacarāni tesam sabbesam pi tat eva niruddham cittam ārammaṇam
translated: The supernormal-power consciousness and the rest are of the sense sphere. The object of all of them is the consciousness that has just ceased.

original: hoti, na ca tāni nānārammaṇāni honti, addhāvasena paccuppannārammaṇattā. Ekārammaṇattepi
analyzed: hoti na ca tāni nānā ārammaṇāni honti addhā vasena paccuppanna ārammaṇa ttā eka ārammaṇa tte pi
translated: And they do not have different objects, because they have present objects in the sense of a moment.

original: ca iddhicittameva parassa cittaṃ jānāti, na itarāni. Yathā cakkhudvāre cakkhuviññāṇameva
analyzed: ca iddhi cittam eva parassa cittam jānāti na itarāni yathā cakkhu dvāre cakkhu viññāṇam eva
translated: And only the supernormal-power consciousness knows another’s consciousness, not the others, just as only eye consciousness sees visible data, not the others, in the eye door.

original: rūpaṃ passati, na itarānīti. Iti idaṃ santatipaccuppannassa ceva addhāpaccuppannassa🔽ca vasena paccuppannārammaṇaṃ hoti. Yasmā vā santatipaccuppannampi addhāpaccuppanneyeva
analyzed: rūpam passati na itarāni iti iti idam santati paccuppannassa ca iva addhā paccuppannassa  ca vasena paccuppanna ārammaṇam hoti yasmā vā santati paccuppannam pi addhā paccuppannā iya iva
translated: So this has a present object in the sense of the present of a continuity and in the sense of the present of a moment.

original: patati, tasmā addhāpaccuppannavasenevetaṃ paccuppannārammaṇanti veditabbaṃ. Parassa
analyzed: patati tasmai addhā paccuppanna vasena iva etam paccuppanna ārammaṇam ti veditabbam parassa
translated: Or alternatively, since what is present in a continuity falls within what is present in a moment, it should be understood that it has a present object only in the sense of the present of a moment.

original: cittārammaṇattāyeva pana bahiddhārammaṇaṃ hotīti evaṃ cetopariyañāṇassa aṭṭhasu ārammaṇesu pavatti veditabbā.
analyzed: citta ārammaṇa ttāya iva pana bahiddhā ārammaṇam hoti iti evam cetaḥ pariya ñāṇassa aṭṭhasu ārammaṇesu pavatti veditabbā
translated: And it has a far object because it has another’s consciousness as its object. This is how knowledge of penetration of minds should be understood to occur with respect to the eight kinds of objects.

original: 417. Pubbenivāsañāṇaṃ parittamahaggataappamāṇamaggaatītaajjhattabahiddhānavattabbārammaṇavasena
analyzed: pubbenivāsa ñāṇam paritta mahaggata appamāṇa magga atīta ajjhatta bahiddhā anavattabba ārammaṇa vasena
translated: Knowledge of past lives occurs with respect to eight kinds of objects, that is to say, as limited, exalted, or measureless, as path, as past, as internal, as external, and as neither-internal-nor-external.

original: aṭṭhasu ārammaṇesu pavattati. Kathaṃ? Tañhi kāmāvacarakkhandhānussaraṇakāle parittārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: aṭṭhasu ārammaṇesu pavattati katham tat hi kāmāvacara kkhandha anussaraṇa kāle paritta ārammaṇam
translated: How? At the time of recollecting aggregates of the sense sphere it has a limited object.

original: hoti. Rūpāvacarārūpāvacarakkhandhānussaraṇakāle mahaggatārammaṇaṃ. Atīte attanā parehi
analyzed: hoti rūpāvacara arūpāvacara khandha anussaraṇa kāle mahaggata ārammaṇam atīte attanā parehi
translated: At the time of recollecting aggregates of the fine-material and immaterial spheres it has an exalted object.

original: vā bhāvitamaggaṃ sacchikataphalañca anussaraṇakāle appamāṇārammaṇaṃ. Bhāvitamaggameva
analyzed: vā bhāvita maggam sacchikata phalam ca anussaraṇa kāle appamāṇa ārammaṇam bhāvita maggam eva
translated: At the time of recollecting a path that has been developed by oneself or another, or a fruition realized by oneself, it has a measureless object.🔽At the time of recollecting only a path that has been developed by oneself it has a path as object.

original: anussaraṇakāle maggārammaṇaṃ. Niyamato panetaṃ atītārammaṇameva.
analyzed: anussaraṇa kāle magga ārammaṇam niyamato pana itam atīta ārammaṇam eva
translated: But it is invariably past as object.

original: Tattha kiñcāpi cetopariyañāṇayathākammupagañāṇānipi atītārammaṇāni honti, atha kho
analyzed: tattha kiñcā api cetaḥ pariya ñāṇa yathā kammupaga ñāṇāni pi atīta ārammaṇāni honti atha kho
translated: Although knowledge of penetration of minds and knowledge of faring according to deeds also have a past object,

original: tesaṃ cetopariyañāṇassa sattadivasabbhantarātītaṃ cittameva ārammaṇaṃ. Tañhi aññaṃ
analyzed: tesam cetas upariya ñāṇassa satta divasa bbhantara atītam cittam eva ārammaṇam tat hi aññam
translated: nevertheless the object of knowledge of penetration of minds is only the mind of the seven days next before the present,

original: khandhaṃ vā khandhapaṭibaddhaṃ vā na jānāti. Maggasampayuttacittārammaṇattā pana
analyzed: khandham vā khandha paṭibaddham vā na jānāti magga sampayutta citta ārammaṇa ttā pana
translated: for that does not know any other aggregate or what is bound up with aggregates. But because it has as its object the mind associated with the path,

original: pariyāyato maggārammaṇanti vuttaṃ. Yathākammupagañāṇassa ca atītaṃ cetanāmattameva🔽ārammaṇaṃ. Pubbenivāsañāṇassa pana atītā khandhā khandhapaṭibaddhañca kiñci anārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: pariyāyataḥ magga ārammaṇan ti vuttam yathā kammupaga ñāṇassa ca atītam cetanā mattam eva  ārammaṇam pubbenivāsa ñāṇassa pana atītā khandhā khandha paṭibaddhañca kiñci anārammaṇam
translated: The knowledge of faring according to deeds has only the volition of the past as its object.

original: nāma natthi. Tañhi atītakkhandhakhandhapaṭibaddhesu dhammesu sabbaññutaññāṇagatikaṃ🔽hotīti ayaṃ viseso veditabbo. Ayamettha aṭṭhakathānayo. Yasmā pana “kusalā khandhā
analyzed: nāma natthi tat hi atīta kkhandha khandha paṭibaddhesu dhammesu sabbaññuta ññāṇa gatikam  hoti iti ayam visesaḥ veditabbaḥ ayam ettha aṭṭhakathā nayaḥ yasmā pana kusalāḥ khandhāḥ
translated: But there is nothing that is not an object for the knowledge of past lives, since the aggregates of the past and what is associated with the aggregates is the province of the knowledge of omniscience.🔽This is the difference that should be understood. This is the method of explanation in the commentaries.

original: iddhividhañāṇassa cetopariyañāṇassa pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇassa yathākammupagañāṇassa🔽anāgataṃsañāṇassa ārammaṇapaccayena paccayo”ti paṭṭhāne vuttaṃ. Tasmā cattāropi khandhā
analyzed: iddhividha ñāṇassa cetas upariya ñāṇassa pubbenivāsa anussati ñāṇassa yathākammupaga ñāṇassa  anāgataṃsañāṇassa ārammaṇa paccayena paccayaḥ ti paṭṭhāne vuttam tasmā cattāro api khandhāḥ
translated: But since it is said in the Paṭṭhāna: “The profitable aggregates are a condition, as object condition, for the knowledge of the kinds of supernormal power, for the knowledge of penetration of minds, for the knowledge of recollection of past lives, for the knowledge of faring according to deeds,🔽for the knowledge of the future, ” therefore the four aggregates are objects for the knowledge of penetration of minds and for the knowledge of faring according to deeds.

original: cetopariyañāṇayathākammupagañāṇānaṃ ārammaṇā honti. Tatrāpi yathākammupagañāṇassa kusalākusalā evāti.
analyzed: cetas upariya ñāṇa yathākammupaga ñāṇānaṃ ārammaṇāḥ honti tatra api yathākammupaga ñāṇassa kusala akusalāḥ eva ati
translated: And here, in the case of the knowledge of faring according to deeds, only the profitable and unprofitable are objects.🔽But when it recollects its own aggregates it is internal-object,

original: Attano khandhānussaraṇakāle panetaṃ ajjhattārammaṇaṃ. Parassa khandhānussaraṇakāle
analyzed: attanaḥ khandha anussaraṇa kāle pana itam ajjhatta ārammaṇam parassa khandha anussaraṇa kāle
translated: and when it recollects another’s aggregates it is external-object.

original: bahiddhārammaṇaṃ. “Atīte vipassī bhagavā ahosi. Tassa mātā bandhumatī, pitā bandhumā”tiādinā
analyzed: bahiddhā ārammaṇam atīte vipassī bhagavā ahosi tassa mātā bandhumatī pitā bandhumāti ādinā
translated: and the object is external. “In the past there was a Blessed One named Vipassī. His mother was Bandhumati, his father Bandhuma” , etc.

original: nayena nāmagottapathavīnimittādianussaraṇakāle navattabbārammaṇaṃ hoti. Nāmagottanti
analyzed: nayena nāma gotta pathavī nimitta ādi anussaraṇa kāle nava ttabba ārammaṇam hoti nāma gottam ti
translated: and external object. When he recollects the sign of the earth, etc., in the way beginning, “In the past the Lord was a Wheel-turning Monarch named Dhataraṭṭha” , then the object is not classifiable. The name and race

original: cettha khandhūpanibandho sammutisiddho byañjanattho daṭṭhabbo, na byañjanaṃ. Byañjanañhi
analyzed: ca ittha khandha upanibandhaḥ sammuti siddhaḥ byañjana atthaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ na byañjanam byañjanam hi
translated: should be regarded as the conventional term for the aggregates bound to the particular life-span, not for the syllables. For the syllables are

original: saddāyatanasaṅgahitattā parittaṃ hoti. Yathāha “niruttipaṭisambhidā parittārammaṇā”ti.
analyzed: sadda āyatana saṅgahita ttā parittam hoti yathā āha nirutti paṭisambhidā paritta ārammaṇā ti
translated: limited, being included among the sound bases, according to the passage, “The discrimination of language has a limited object” .

original: Ayamettha amhākaṃ khanti. Evaṃ pubbenivāsañāṇassa aṭṭhasu ārammaṇesu pavatti veditabbā.🔽418. Dibbacakkhuñāṇaṃ parittapaccuppannaajjhattabahiddhārammaṇavasena catūsu ārammaṇesu
analyzed: ayam ettha amhākam khanti evam pubbenivāsa ñāṇassa aṭṭhasu ārammaṇesu pavatti veditabbā  dibba cakkhu ñāṇam paritta paccuppanna ajjhatta bahiddha ārammaṇa vasena catūsu ārammaṇesu
translated: This is our opinion here. This is how the knowledge of the recollection of past lives should be understood to occur with respect to the eight kinds of objects.

original: pavattati. Kathaṃ? Tañhi yasmā rūpaṃ ārammaṇaṃ karoti, rūpañca parittaṃ, tasmā parittārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: pavattati katham tat hi yasmā rūpam ārammaṇam karoti rūpam ca parittam tasmā paritta ārammaṇam
translated: The knowledge of the divine eye occurs with respect to four kinds of objects, that is to say, as limited, as present, and as internal or external. How? Because it has visible form as its object, and because visible form is limited, its object is limited.

original: hoti. Vijjamāneyeva ca rūpe pavattattā paccuppannārammaṇaṃ. Attano kucchigatādirūpadassanakāle🔽ajjhattārammaṇaṃ. Parassa rūpadassanakāle bahiddhārammaṇanti evaṃ dibbacakkhuñāṇassa
analyzed: hoti vijjamāneya iva ca rūpe pavatta ttā paccuppanna ārammaṇam attano kucchi gata ādi rūpa dassana kāle  ajjhatta ārammaṇam parassa rūpa dassana kāle bahiddhā ārammaṇam ti evam dibba cakkhu ñāṇassa
translated: And because it occurs only in visible data that exist, it has present object. When it sees visible data in one’s own belly, etc.,

original: catūsu ārammaṇesu pavatti veditabbā.🔽419. Anāgataṃsañāṇaṃ parittamahaggataappamāṇamaggaanāgataajjhattabahiddhānavattabbārammaṇavasena
analyzed: catūsu ārammaṇesu pavatti veditabbā  anāgataṃsañāṇam paritta mahaggata appamāṇa magga anāgata ajjhatta bahiddhā anavattabba ārammaṇa vasena
translated: it has internal object. When it sees another’s visible data, it has external object. This is how the knowledge of the divine eye should be understood to occur with the four objects.🔽The knowledge of the future has eight kinds of objects, that is to say, limited, exalted, and measureless, path, future, internal, external, and not so classifiable.

original: aṭṭhasu ārammaṇesu pavattati. Kathaṃ? Tañhi “ayaṃ anāgate kāmāvacare nibbattissatī”ti
analyzed: aṭṭhasu ārammaṇesu pavattati katham tam hi ayam anāgate kāmāvacare nibbattissati iti
translated: How? When it cognizes thus, “He will be reborn in the future in the sense sphere,”

original: jānanakāle parittārammaṇaṃ hoti. “Rūpāvacare arūpāvacare vā nibbattissatī”ti jānanakāle
analyzed: jānana kāle paritta ārammaṇam hoti rūpāvacare arūpāvacare vā nibbattissati iti jānana kāle
translated: it has limited object. When it cognizes thus, “He will be reborn in the fine-material or immaterial sphere,”

original: mahaggatārammaṇaṃ. “Maggaṃ bhāvessati, phalaṃ sacchikarissatī”ti jānanakāle appamāṇārammaṇaṃ.
analyzed: mahaggata ārammaṇam maggam bhāvessati phalam sacchikarissati iti jānana kāle appamāṇa ārammaṇam
translated: it has exalted object. When it cognizes thus, “He will develop the path and realize the fruition,” it has measureless object.

original: “Maggaṃ bhāvessati”cceva jānanakāle maggārammaṇaṃ. Niyamato pana taṃ anāgatārammaṇameva.
analyzed: maggam bhāvessati icca iva jānana kāle magga ārammaṇam niyamato pana tam anāgata ārammaṇam eva
translated: When it cognizes thus, “He will develop the path,” it has path as object. But it has only future object by rule.

original: Tattha kiñcāpi cetopariyañāṇampi anāgatārammaṇaṃ hoti, atha kho tassa sattadivasabbhantarānāgataṃ
analyzed: tattha kiñcā api cetaḥ pariya ñāṇam pi anāgata ārammaṇam hoti atha kho tassa satta divasa bbhantara anāgatam
translated: Herein, although knowledge of penetration of minds has future as its object too, nevertheless it has only the mind of the future that is included in the seven days as its object.

original: cittameva ārammaṇaṃ. Tañhi aññaṃ khandhaṃ vā khandhapaṭibaddhaṃ vā na jānāti. Anāgataṃsañāṇassa🔽pubbenivāsañāṇe vuttanayena anāgate anārammaṇaṃ nāma natthi. “Ahaṃ amutra nibbattissāmī”ti
analyzed: cittam eva ārammaṇam tat hi aññam khandham vā khandha paṭibaddham vā na jānāti anāgataṃsa ñāṇassa  pubbenivāsa ñāṇe vutta nayena anāgate anārammaṇam nāma natthi aham amutra nibbattissāmi iti
translated: For it does not know any aggregate or what is bound up with aggregates other than that.🔽As regards knowledge of the past, there is no such thing as a future object in the way stated under knowledge of past lives.

original: jānanakāle ajjhattārammaṇaṃ. “Asuko amutra nibbattissatī”ti jānanakāle bahiddhārammaṇaṃ.
analyzed: jānana kāle ajjhatta ārammaṇam asukaḥ amutra nibbattissati iti jānana kāle bahiddha ārammaṇam
translated: When it knows, “I shall be reborn there,” it has internal as its object. When it knows, “So-and-so will be reborn there,” it has external as its object.

original: “Anāgate metteyyo bhagavā uppajjissati. Subrahmā nāmassa brāhmaṇo pitā bhavissati.
analyzed: anāgate metteyyaḥ bhagavā uppajjissati subrahmā nāmassa brāhmaṇaḥ pitā bhavissati
translated: “In the future the Blessed One Metteyya will arise. His father will be a brahman called Subhadra.

original: Brahmavatī nāma brāhmaṇī mātā”tiādinā pana nayena nāmagottajānanakāle pubbenivāsañāṇe
analyzed: brahmavatī nāma brāhmaṇī mātā ati ādinā pana nayena nāma gotta jānana kāle pubbenivāsa ñāṇe
translated: His mother will be a brahman woman called Brahmavatī,” and so on—

original: vuttanayeneva na vattabbārammaṇaṃ hotīti evaṃ anāgataṃsañāṇassa aṭṭhasu ārammaṇesu pavatti veditabbā.
analyzed: vutta nayena iva na vattabba ārammaṇam hoti iti evam anāgataṃsañāṇassa aṭṭhasu ārammaṇesu pavatti veditabbā
translated: in this way there is no object that should not be stated, as in the case of knowledge of past lives. This is how it should be understood that knowledge of the future has these eight as its object.

original: 420. Yathākammupagañāṇaṃ parittamahaggataatītaajjhattabahiddhārammaṇavasena pañcasu
analyzed: yathā kammupaga ñāṇam paritta mahaggata atīta ajjhatta bahiddha ārammaṇa vasena pañcasu
translated: Knowledge of faring according to deeds occurs with respect to five kinds of object, that is to say, as limited, exalted, or measureless, and as past or present.

original: ārammaṇesu pavattati. Kathaṃ? Tañhi kāmāvacarakammajānanakāle parittārammaṇaṃ hoti.
analyzed: ārammaṇesu pavattati katham tat hi kāmāvacara kamma jānana kāle paritta ārammaṇam hoti
translated: How? At the time of knowing sense-sphere kamma it has a limited object.

original: Rūpāvacarārūpāvacarakammajānanakāle mahaggatārammaṇaṃ. Atītameva jānātīti atītārammaṇaṃ.
analyzed: rūpāvacara arūpāvacara kamma jānana kāle mahaggata ārammaṇam atītam eva jānāti iti atīta ārammaṇam
translated: At the time of knowing fine-material-sphere and immaterial-sphere kamma it has an exalted object. It knows only what is past, thus its object is past.

original: Attano kammaṃ jānanakāle ajjhattārammaṇaṃ. Parassa kammaṃ jānanakāle bahiddhārammaṇaṃ🔽hoti. Evaṃ yathākammupagañāṇassa pañcasu ārammaṇesu pavatti veditabbā. Yañcettha
analyzed: attano kammam jānana kāle ajjhatta ārammaṇam parassa kammam jānana kāle bahiddha ārammaṇam  hoti evam yathā kammupaga ñāṇassa pañcasu ārammaṇesu pavatti veditabbā yat ca ittha
translated: At the time of knowing one’s own kamma it has an internal object. At the time of knowing another’s kamma it has an external object.

original: ajjhattārammaṇañceva bahiddhārammaṇañcāti vuttaṃ, taṃ kālena ajjhattaṃ kālena bahiddhā
analyzed: ajjhatta ārammaṇam ca iva bahiddha ārammaṇam ca ati vuttam tam kālena ajjhattam kālena bahiddhā
translated: So the occurrence of knowledge of faring according to deeds should be understood as to five kinds of object. And here what is said to be internal object and external object is so at the time of knowing one’s own kamma and another’s kamma respectively;

original: jānanakāle ajjhattabahiddhārammaṇampi hotiyevāti.
analyzed: jānana kāle ajjhatta bahiddha ārammaṇam pi
translated: but at the time of knowing kamma that is past and present it is both internal and external object.

original: Iti sādhujanapāmojjatthāya kate visuddhimagge🔽Abhiññāniddeso nāma
analyzed: iti sādhu jana pāmojjatthāya kate visuddhi magge  abhiññāniddesaḥ nāma
translated: So in the Path of Purification,

original: Terasamo paricchedo.
analyzed: terasamaḥ paricchedaḥ
translated: called “The Description of Knowledge and Vision,”

original: 14. Khandhaniddeso
analyzed: khandha niddeso
translated: The thirteenth chapter🔽The Description of the Aggregates

original: Paññākathā
analyzed: paññākathā
translated: The Discussion of Understanding

original: 421. Idāni yasmā evaṃ abhiññāvasena adhigatānisaṃsāya thiratarāya samādhibhāvanāya
analyzed: idāni yasmai evam abhiññā vasena adhigata anisaṃsāya thiratarāya samādhi bhāvanāya
translated: Now, a bhikkhu who has thus acquired the benefits by direct knowledge and has thus steadied his development of concentration should,

original: samannāgatena bhikkhunā sīle patiṭṭhāya naro sapañño, cittaṃ paññañca bhāvayanti
analyzed: samannāgatena bhikkhunā sīle patiṭṭhāya naro sa paññaḥ cittam paññam ca bhāvayanti
translated: “Endowed with moral discipline, the wise man,

original: ettha cittasīsena niddiṭṭho samādhi sabbākārena bhāvito hoti.
analyzed: ettha citta sīsena niddiṭṭho samādhi sabba ākārena bhāvito hoti
translated: Herein, concentration, which is indicated by the word “mind,” has been developed in all its aspects.

original: Tadanantarā pana paññā bhāvetabbā. Sā ca atisaṅkhepadesitattā viññātumpi tāva na sukarā, pageva bhāvetuṃ. Tasmā tassā vitthāraṃ bhāvanānayañca dassetuṃ idaṃ pañhākammaṃ hoti.🔽Kā paññā, kenaṭṭhena paññā, kānassā lakkhaṇarasapaccupaṭṭhānapadaṭṭhānāni, katividhā paññā, kathaṃ bhāvetabbā, paññābhāvanāya ko ānisaṃsoti?
analyzed: tad anantarā pana paññā bhāvetabbā sā ca ati saṅkhepa desita ttā viññātum pi tāva na sukarā pagā iva bhāvetum tasmā tassāḥ vitthāram bhāvanā nayam ca dassetum idam pañhākammam hoti  kā paññā kenaṭṭhena paññā kānassā lakkhaṇa rasa paccupaṭṭhāna padaṭṭhānāni katividhā paññā katham bhāvetabbā paññā bhāvanāya kaḥ ānisaṃso ti
translated: But the understanding that comes next to it should be developed. And that is not easy to discern even in its bare definition, much less in its development, because of the briefness of the teaching about it. So this question-and-answer section is given in order to point to its detailed explanation and the way to its development.🔽What is understanding? In what sense is it understanding? What are its characteristic, function, manifestation, and proximate cause? How many kinds of understanding are there? How should understanding be developed? What are the benefits of the development of understanding?

original: 422. Tatridaṃ vissajjanaṃ, kā paññāti paññā bahuvidhā nānappakārā. Taṃ sabbaṃ vibhāvayituṃ
analyzed: tatra idam vissajjanam kā paññā iti paññā bahuvidhā nānappakārā tam sabbam vibhāvayitum
translated: Here is the answer: What is understanding? Understanding is of many sorts and of many kinds. To analyse all of it

original: ārabbhamānaṃ vissajjanaṃ adhippetañceva atthaṃ na sādheyya, uttari ca vikkhepāya
analyzed: ārabbhamānam vissajjanam adhippetam ca iva attham na sādheyya uttari ca vikkhepāya
translated: and if the answer were given in terms of that, it would not accomplish the purpose intended, which is the meaning of the question, and it would lead to distraction.

original: saṃvatteyya, tasmā idha adhippetameva sandhāya vadāma. Kusalacittasampayuttaṃ vipassanāñāṇaṃ paññā.
analyzed: tasmai idha adhippetam eva sandhāya vadāma kusala citta sampayuttam vipassanā ñāṇam paññā
translated: So we shall confine ourselves to the purpose intended here. Understanding that is associated with profitable consciousness is wisdom.🔽In what sense is it wisdom? It is wisdom in the sense of understanding.

original: 423. Kenaṭṭhena paññāti pajānanaṭṭhena paññā. Kimidaṃ pajānanaṃ nāma? Sañjānanavijānanākāravisiṭṭhaṃ
analyzed: kena ṭṭhena paññā ati pajānana ṭṭhena paññā kim idam pajānanam nāma sañjānana vijānana ākāra visiṭṭham
translated: But what is this understanding? It is knowing in various ways, distinguished by the act of recognizing and the act of discerning.

original: nānappakārato jānanaṃ. Saññāviññāṇapaññānaṃ hi samānepi jānanabhāve, saññā “nīlaṃ🔽pītaka”nti ārammaṇasañjānanamattameva hoti. “Aniccaṃ dukkhamanattā”ti lakkhaṇapaṭivedhaṃ🔽pāpetuṃ na sakkoti. Viññāṇaṃ “nīlaṃ pītaka”nti ārammaṇañca jānāti, lakkhaṇapaṭivedhañca
analyzed: nānā ppakārataḥ jānanam saññā viññāṇa paññānam hi samāne pi jānana bhāve saññā nīlam  pītakam ti ārammaṇa sañjānana mattam eva hoti aniccam dukkham anattā ati lakkhaṇa paṭivedham  pāpetum na sakkoti viññāṇam nīlam pītakan ti ārammaṇañca jānāti lakkhaṇa paṭivedhañca
translated: For although perception, consciousness and understanding all have the nature of knowing, perception merely recognizes the object as blue, yellow, etc.,🔽and is unable to bring about the penetration of the characteristics of impermanence, suffering, and non-self. Consciousness knows the object as blue, yellow, etc., and it brings about the penetration of the characteristics;

original: pāpeti. Ussakkitvā pana maggapātubhāvaṃ pāpetuṃ na sakkoti. Paññā vuttanayavasena
analyzed: pāpeti ussakkitvā pana magga pātubhāvam pāpetum na sakkoti paññā vutta naya vasena
translated: but it is unable to bring about the manifestation of the path by striving. Understanding, in the way already stated,

original: ārammaṇañca jānāti, lakkhaṇapaṭivedhañca pāpeti, ussakkitvā maggapātubhāvañca pāpeti.🔽Yathā hi heraññikaphalake ṭhapitaṃ kahāpaṇarāsiṃ eko ajātabuddhidārako, eko gāmikapuriso,
analyzed: ārammaṇañca jānāti lakkhaṇa paṭivedhañca pāpa iti ussakkitvā magga pātubhāvañca pāpa iti  yathā hi heraññika phalake ṭhapitam kahāpaṇa rāsim ekaḥ ajāta buddhi dārakaḥ ekaḥ gāmika purisaḥ
translated: He knows the object, he brings about the penetration of the characteristic of skill, he brings about the manifestation of the path by exertion.🔽For just as when a heap of kahāpaṇa coins is placed on a goldsmith’s plate and is seen by three people, namely, a child who has no understanding of money, a country person, and a goldsmith,

original: eko heraññikoti tīsu janesu passamānesu ajātabuddhidārako kahāpaṇānaṃ cittavicittadīghacaturassaparimaṇḍalabhāvamattameva
analyzed: ekaḥ heraññiko ti tīsu janesu passamānesu ajātabuddhi dārako kahāpaṇānam citta vicitta dīgha catur assa parimaṇḍala bhāva mattam eva
translated: then the child who has no understanding of money knows only the mere fact of the coins’ being variously coloured, long, square, round, and so on,

original: jānāti, “idaṃ manussānaṃ upabhogaparibhogaṃ ratanasammata”nti na jānāti. Gāmikapuriso
analyzed: jānāti idam manussānam upabhoga paribhogam ratana sammatanti na jānāti gāmika purisaḥ
translated: but he does not know that they are “jewels” esteemed by people and used by them as wealth. The country person

original: cittavicittādibhāvaṃ jānāti, “idaṃ manussānaṃ upabhogaparibhogaṃ ratanasammata”nti
analyzed: citta vicitta ādi bhāvam jānāti idam manussānam upabhoga paribhogam ratana sammatanti
translated: knows their various colours, and so on, and that they are “jewels” esteemed by people and used by them as wealth,

original: ca. “Ayaṃ cheko, ayaṃ kūṭo, ayaṃ addhasāro”ti imaṃ pana vibhāgaṃ na jānāti. Heraññiko
analyzed: ca ayam chekaḥ ayam kūṭaḥ ayam addhasāraḥ iti imam pana vibhāgam na jānāti heraññikaḥ
translated: but he does not know the analysis of them as “This is fine, this is base, this is half-value.” The goldsmith

original: sabbepi te pakāre jānāti, jānanto ca kahāpaṇaṃ oloketvāpi jānāti, ākoṭitassa saddaṃ
analyzed: sabbe api te pakāre jānāti jānantaḥ ca kahāpaṇam oloketvā api jānāti ākoṭitassa saddam
translated: knows all those modes, and knowing, he knows by looking at the coin, and he knows by the sound of it when struck,

original: sutvāpi, gandhaṃ ghāyitvāpi, rasaṃ sāyitvāpi, hatthena dhārayitvāpi, asukasmiṃ nāma🔽gāme vā nigame vā nagare vā pabbate vā nadītīre vā katotipi, asukācariyena katotipi
analyzed: sutvā api gandham ghāyitvā api rasam sāyitvā api hatthena dhārayitvā api asukasmin nāma  gāme vā nigame vā nagare vā pabbate vā nadī tīre vā kata utipi asuka ācariyena kata utipi
translated: having tasted a flavour with the tongue, he knows: ‘This flavour has been tasted by me’;🔽having touched a tangible with the body, he knows: ‘This tangible has been touched by me’;

original: jānāti, evaṃsampadamidaṃ veditabbaṃ.🔽Saññā hi ajātabuddhino dārakassa kahāpaṇadassanaṃ viya hoti, nīlādivasena ārammaṇassa
analyzed: jānāti evaṃsampadam idam veditabbam  saññā hi ajātabuddhino dārakassa kahāpaṇa dassanam viya hoti nīla ādi vasena ārammaṇassa
translated: having cognized a mental datum with the mind, he knows: ‘This mental datum has been cognized by me.’🔽Having seen a visible datum with the eye, he knows: ‘This visible datum has been seen by me’;🔽having heard a sound with the ear, he knows: ‘This sound has been heard by me’;🔽having smelt an odour with the nose, he knows: ‘This odour has been smelt by me’;

original: upaṭṭhānākāramattagahaṇato. Viññāṇaṃ gāmikassa purisassa kahāpaṇadassanamiva hoti,
analyzed: upaṭṭhāna ākāra matta gahaṇato viññāṇam gāmikassa purisassa kahāpaṇa dassanam iva hoti
translated: having tasted a flavour with the tongue, he knows: ‘This flavour has been tasted by me’;🔽having touched a tangible with the body, he knows: ‘This tangible has been touched by me’;🔽having cognized a mental datum with the mind, he knows: ‘This mental datum has been cognized by me.’

original: nīlādivasena ārammaṇākāragahaṇato, uddhaṃpi ca lakkhaṇapaṭivedhasampāpanato. Paññā
analyzed: nīla ādi vasena ārammaṇa ākāra gahaṇato ca lakkhaṇa paṭivedha sampāpanato paññā
translated: Having seen a visible datum with the eye, he knows: ‘This visible datum has been seen by me’;🔽having heard a sound with the ear, he knows: ‘This sound has been heard by me’;🔽having smelt an odour with the nose, he knows: ‘This odour has been smelt by me’;🔽having tasted a flavour with the tongue, he knows: ‘This flavour has been tasted by me’;🔽having touched a tangible with the body, he knows: ‘This tangible has been touched by me’;

original: heraññikassa kahāpaṇadassanamiva hoti, nīlādivasena ārammaṇākāraṃ gahetvā, lakkhaṇapaṭivedhañca🔽pāpetvā, tato uddhampi maggapātubhāvapāpanato. Tasmā yadetaṃ sañjānanavijānanākāravisiṭṭhaṃ
analyzed: heraññikassa kahāpaṇa dassanam iva hoti nīla ādi vasena ārammaṇa ākāram gahetvā lakkhaṇa paṭivedham ca 🔽pāpetvā tatas tasmai yat etam sañjānana vijānana ākāra visiṭṭham
translated: having cognized a mental datum with the mind

original: nānappakārato jānanaṃ. Idaṃ pajānananti veditabbaṃ. Idaṃ sandhāya hi etaṃ vuttaṃ
analyzed: nānā ppakārataḥ jānanam idam pajānananti veditabbam idam sandhāya hi etam vuttam
translated: and the knowing of it in its various aspects. This is what should be understood by “understanding.” For this is said in the Paṭṭhāna:

original: “pajānanaṭṭhena paññā”ti.
analyzed: pajānana ṭṭhena paññā ti
translated: “Understanding is in the sense of understanding.”

original: Sā panesā yattha saññāviññāṇāni, na tattha ekaṃsena hoti. Yadā pana hoti, tadā avinibbhuttā
analyzed: sā pana isā yattha saññā viññāṇāni na tattha ekaṃsena hoti yadā pana hoti tadā a vinibbhuttā
translated: But this understanding is not invariably found wherever there is perception and consciousness. But when it is found, it is not inseparable

original: tehi dhammehi “ayaṃ saññā, idaṃ viññāṇaṃ, ayaṃ paññā”ti vinibbhujjitvā alabbhaneyyanānattā
analyzed: tehi dhammehi ayam saññā idam viññāṇam ayam paññā ati vinibbhujjitvā a labbha neyya nānattā
translated: from those states. For it is impossible to separate it from them and point to it as a distinct state thus: “This is perception, this is consciousness, this is understanding.”

original: sukhumā duddasā. Tenāha āyasmā nāgaseno “dukkaraṃ, mahārāja, bhagavatā kata”nti.🔽Kiṃ, bhante, nāgasena bhagavatā dukkaraṃ katanti? ‘Dukkaraṃ, mahārāja, bhagavatā
analyzed: sukhumā duddasā tena āha āyasmā nāgasenaḥ dukkaram mahā rāja bhagavatā  kim bhante nāgasena bhagavatā dukkaram dukkaram mahā rāja bhagavatā
translated: It is subtle and hard to see. That is why the venerable Nāgasena said: “It is a difficult thing, sire, that the Blessed One did.”

original: kataṃ yaṃ arūpīnaṃ cittacetasikānaṃ dhammānaṃ ekārammaṇe pavattamānānaṃ vavatthānaṃ
analyzed: katam yam arūpīnam citta cetasikānam dhammānam eka ārammaṇe pavattamānānam vavatthānam
translated: “What, revered sir, is the difficult thing that the Blessed One did?” ‘Sire, it is a difficult thing that the Blessed One did in that he pointed out the analysis of the immaterial states of mind and consciousness that occur with a single object thus:

original: akkhātaṃ ayaṃ phasso, ayaṃ vedanā, ayaṃ saññā, ayaṃ cetanā, idaṃ citta”’nti.
analyzed: akkhātam ayam phassaḥ ayam vedanā ayam saññā ayam cetanā idam cittam ti
translated: “This is contact, this is feeling, this is perception, this is volition, this is consciousness.”’

original: 424. Kānassā lakkhaṇarasapaccupaṭṭhānapadaṭṭhānānīti ettha pana dhammasabhāvapaṭivedhalakkhaṇā
analyzed: lakkhaṇa rasa paccupaṭṭhāna padaṭṭhānāni iti ettha pana dhamma sabhāva paṭivedha lakkhaṇā
translated: What, then, are its characteristic, function, manifestation, and proximate cause? Understanding has the characteristic of penetrating the individual essences of states.

original: paññā, dhammānaṃ sabhāvapaṭicchādakamohandhakāraviddhaṃsanarasā, asammohapaccupaṭṭhānā.
analyzed: paññā dhammānam sabhāva paṭicchādaka moha andhakāra viddhaṃsana rasā asammoha paccupaṭṭhānā
translated: Its function is to dispel the darkness of delusion that conceals the individual essences of states. It is manifested as non-delusion.

original: “Samāhito yathābhūtaṃ jānāti passatī”ti vacanato pana samādhi tassā padaṭṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: samāhitaḥ yathābhūtam jānāti passati iti vacanato pana samādhi tassā padaṭṭhānam
translated: But since it is said, “One who is concentrated knows and sees correctly” , concentration is its proximate cause.

original: Paññāpabhedakathā
analyzed: paññā apabheda kathā
translated: The kinds of understanding

original: 425. Katividhā paññāti dhammasabhāvapaṭivedhalakkhaṇena tāva ekavidhā. Lokiyalokuttaravasena🔽duvidhā. Tathā sāsavānāsavādivasena, nāmarūpavavatthāpanavasena, somanassupekkhāsahagatavasena,
analyzed: katividhā paññā ati dhamma sabhāva paṭivedha lakkhaṇena tāva ekavidhā lokiya lokuttara vasena  duvidhā tathā sa āsava anāsava ādi vasena nāma rūpa vavatthāpana vasena somanassa upekkhā sahagata vasena
translated: How many kinds of understanding are there? Firstly, there is one kind of understanding, that is, penetration of the individual essences of states.🔽There is a twofold understanding as mundane and supramundane.🔽Likewise as with taints and without taints, as discerning mentality-materiality, as accompanied by joy and by equanimity,

original: dassanabhāvanābhūmivasena ca. Tividhā cintāsutabhāvanāmayavasena. Tathā parittamahaggataappamāṇārammaṇavasena,
analyzed: dassana bhāvanā bhūmi vasena ca tividhā cintā suta bhāvanā maya vasena tathā paritta mahaggata appamāṇa ārammaṇa vasena
translated: as the plane of seeing and the plane of development. There is threefold understanding as that consisting in what is heard, that consisting in cogitation, and that consisting in keeping in being.🔽Likewise as having a limited, exalted, or measureless object,🔽as skill in profitable and unprofitable, in blameable and blameless, and in the black and the white, as skill in what is possible and what is impossible, and as skill in aggregates, sense bases, and elements.

original: āyāpāyaupāyakosallavasena, ajjhattābhinivesādivasena ca. Catubbidhā catūsu saccesu
analyzed: āya apāya opāya kosalla vasena ajjhatta abhinivesa ādi vasena ca catubbidhā catūsu saccesu
translated: There is fourfold understanding as insight into the four truths,

original: ñāṇavasena catupaṭisambhidāvasena cāti.
analyzed: ñāṇa vasena catu paṭisambhidā vasena ca ati
translated: and by way of knowledge and by way of the four discriminations.

original: 426. Tattha ekavidhakoṭṭhāso uttānatthoyeva. Duvidhakoṭṭhāse lokiyamaggasampayuttā lokiyā. Lokuttaramaggasampayuttā lokuttarāti evaṃ lokiyalokuttaravasena duvidhā.
analyzed: tattha ekavidha koṭṭhāso uttāna tthaḥ yeva duvidha koṭṭhāse lokiya magga sampayuttāḥ lokiyāḥ lokuttara magga sampayuttāḥ lokuttarā ati evam lokiya lokuttara vasena duvidhā
translated: Herein, the section on the single kind is self-evident. In the section on the twofold, those associated with the mundane path are mundane. Those associated with the supramundane path are supramundane. So they are twofold as mundane and supramundane.

original: Dutiyaduke āsavānaṃ ārammaṇabhūtā sāsavā. Tesaṃ anārammaṇā anāsavā. Atthato panesā
analyzed: dutiya duke āsavānaṃ ārammaṇa bhūtā sa āsavā tesam anārammaṇā anāsavā atthato pana esā
translated: In the second dyad, those that are objects of cankers are with cankers. Those that are not objects of cankers are without cankers. But in fact they are

original: lokiyalokuttarāva hoti. Āsavasampayuttā sāsavā. Āsavavippayuttā anāsavātiādīsupi
analyzed: lokiya lokuttarā ava hoti āsava sampayuttā sa āsavā āsava vippayuttā anāsavā ati ādīsu pi
translated: merely mundane and supramundane. Those associated with cankers are with cankers. Those dissociated from cankers are without cankers.

original: eseva nayo. Evaṃ sāsavānāsavādivasena duvidhā.
analyzed: evam sa āsava anāsava ādi vasena duvidhā
translated: The same method applies in the cases of those associated and unassociated with the sāsavas, etc. So they are twofold as with and without cankers, and so on.

original: Tatiyaduke yā vipassanaṃ ārabhitukāmassa catunnaṃ arūpakkhandhānaṃ vavatthāpane paññā,
analyzed: tatiya duke yā vipassanam ārabhitu kāmassa catunnam arūpa kkhandhānam vavatthāpane paññā
translated: In the third dyad, the understanding that occurs in defining the four immaterial aggregates in one who is about to begin insight is
