original: nesaṃ viññāṇanti evaṃ tāva kamato vinicchayanayo viññātabbo.
analyzed: na isam viññāṇan ti evam tāva kamataḥ vinicchaya nayaḥ viññātabbo
translated: This is how the exposition should be known here “in order of conditionality.”

original: 505. Visesatoti khandhānañca upādānakkhandhānañca visesato. Ko pana nesaṃ viseso, khandhā tāva avisesato vuttā. Upādānakkhandhā sāsavaupādāniyabhāvena visesetvā. Yathāha –
analyzed: visesato ti khandhānam ca upādāna khandhānam ca visesato kaḥ pana nesam visesaḥ khandhā tāva avisesataḥ vuttā upādāna khandhā sa āsava aupādāniya bhāvena visesetvā yathā āha
translated: In particular: in particular as regards the aggregates and the aggregates as objects of clinging. But what is the difference between them? The aggregates are stated without distinction. The aggregates as objects of clinging are stated with the distinction of their being subject to cankers and liable to the clingings, according as it is said:

original: “Pañca ceva vo, bhikkhave, khandhe desessāmi pañcupādānakkhandhe ca, taṃ suṇātha.🔽Katame ca, bhikkhave, pañcakkhandhā, yaṃkiñci, bhikkhave, rūpaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ…pe…
analyzed: pañca ca iva vaḥ bhikkhave khandhe desessāmi pañca upādāna khandhe ca tam suṇātha  katame ca bhikkhave pañca kkhandhāḥ yaṃ kiñci bhikkhave rūpam atīta anāgata paccuppannam pe
translated: “Bhikkhus, I shall teach you the five aggregates and the five aggregates as objects of clinging. Listen and attend closely to what I shall say.

original: santike vā, ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, rūpakkhandho. Yā kāci vedanā…pe… yaṃkiñci viññāṇaṃ…pe…
analyzed: santike vā ayam vuccati bhikkhave rūpa kkhandho yā kāci vedanā pe yaṃ kiñci viññāṇaṃ pe
translated: “And what, bhikkhus, are the five aggregates? Whatever kind of materiality there is, bhikkhus, whether past, future, or present, internal or external, gross or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near—this is called the materiality aggregate. Whatever kind of feeling there is …

original: santike vā, ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, viññāṇakkhandho. Ime vuccanti, bhikkhave, pañcakkhandhā.
analyzed: santike vā ayam vuccati bhikkhave viññāṇa kkhandho ime vuccanti bhikkhave pañca kkhandhā
translated: near—this is called the consciousness aggregate. These are called the five aggregates.

original: Katame ca, bhikkhave, pañcupādānakkhandhā. Yaṃkiñci, bhikkhave, rūpaṃ…pe… santike
analyzed: katame ca bhikkhave pañca upādānakkhandhāḥ yaṃ kiñci bhikkhave santike
translated: “And what, bhikkhus, are the five aggregates as objects of clinging? Whatever kind of materiality there is, bhikkhus, whether past, future, or present, internal or external, gross or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near—

original: vā sāsavaṃ upādāniyaṃ, ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, rūpupādānakkhandho. Yā kāci vedanā…pe…
analyzed: vā sa āsavam upādāniyam ayam vuccati bhikkhave rūpa upādāna khandhaḥ yā kāci
translated: Or whatever feeling is in oneself or externally, or whatever perception is in oneself or externally, or whatever formations are in oneself or externally, or whatever consciousness is in oneself or externally, or whatever in the world is seen, heard, sensed, cognized, reached, sought after, pondered by the intellect, that is in oneself or externally, or whatever there is seen, heard, sensed, cognized, reached, sought after, pondered by the intellect, that is past, future or present, gross or subtle, exalted or unexalted, far or near—for him all that is included in the term ‘ materiality ’.

original: yaṃkiñci viññāṇaṃ…pe… santike vā sāsavaṃ upādāniyaṃ, ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, viññāṇupādānakkhandho.
analyzed: yaṃ kiñci viññāṇam pe santike vā sa āsavam upādāniyam ayam vuccati bhikkhave viññāṇa upādāna kkhandho
translated: Or whatever feeling is in oneself or externally, or whatever perception is in oneself or externally, or whatever formations are in oneself or externally, or whatever consciousness is in oneself or externally, or whatever in the world is seen, heard, sensed, cognized, reached, sought after, pondered by the intellect, that is in oneself or externally, or whatever there is seen, heard, sensed, cognized, reached, sought after, pondered by the intellect, that is past, future or present, gross or subtle, exalted or unexalted, far or near—for him all that is included in the term ‘ materiality ’.

original: Ime vuccanti, bhikkhave, pañcupādānakkhandhā”ti.
analyzed: ime vuccanti bhikkhave pañca upādānakkhandhā ti
translated: These are called the five aggregates as objects of clinging” .

original: Ettha ca yathā vedanādayo anāsavāpi atthi, na evaṃ rūpaṃ. Yasmā panassa rāsaṭṭhena
analyzed: ettha ca yathā vedanā ādayaḥ anāsavā api atthi na evam rūpam yasmā panassa rāsaṭṭhena
translated: And here, just as feeling, etc., are also without cankers, so too materiality is not. But since its state as a category is appropriate as a mass,

original: khandhabhāvo yujjati, tasmā khandhesu vuttaṃ. Yasmā rāsaṭṭhena ca sāsavaṭṭhena ca🔽upādānakkhandhabhāvo yujjati, tasmā upādānakkhandhesu vuttaṃ. Vedanādayo pana anāsavāva
analyzed: khandha bhāvaḥ yujjati tasmā khandhesu vuttam yasmā rāsaṭṭhena ca sāsavaṭṭhena ca  upādāna kkhandha bhāvaḥ yujjati tasmai upādāna kkhandhesu vuttam vedanā ādayaḥ pana anāsavā va
translated: it is therefore stated among the categories. And since its state as an aggregate as objects of clinging is appropriate both as a mass and as subject to cankers,🔽it is therefore stated among the aggregates as objects of clinging. But feeling, etc., which are without cankers are stated among the categories. Those subject to cankers are stated among the aggregates as objects of clinging.

original: khandhesu vuttā. Sāsavā upādānakkhandhesu. Upādānakkhandhāti cettha upādānagocarā
analyzed: khandhesu vuttā sāsavā upādāna khandhesu upādāna khandhā ati ca ittha upādāna gocarā
translated: And here the meaning of “ aggregates as objects of clinging” should be regarded as follows: the categories that are the domain of clinging are aggregates as objects of clinging.

original: khandhā upādānakkhandhāti evamattho daṭṭhabbo. Idha pana sabbepete ekajjhaṃ katvā🔽khandhāti adhippetā.
analyzed: khandhāḥ upādāna khandhā ti evamattho daṭṭhabbo idha pana sabbe pete ekajjham katvā 🔽khandhā ati adhippetā
translated: But here all of them together are intended as “ categories “ .

original: 506. Anūnādhikatoti kasmā pana bhagavatā pañceva khandhā vuttā anūnā anadhikāti.
analyzed: anūna adhikatā ti kasmā pana bhagavatā pañca iva khandhāḥ vuttāḥ anūnā anadhikā ati
translated: Why are only five aggregates stated by the Blessed One, neither less nor more?

original: Sabbasaṅkhatasabhāgekasaṅgahato attattaniyagāhavatthussa etaparamato aññesañca tadavarodhato.🔽Anekappabhedesu hi saṅkhatadhammesu sabhāgavasena saṅgayhamānesu rūpampi rūpasabhāgekasaṅgahavasena
analyzed: sabba saṅkhata sabhāga eka saṅgahato atta tta niya gāha vatthussa eta paramataḥ aññesam ca tad avarodhato  aneka ppabhedesu hi saṅkhata dhammesu sa bhāga vasena saṅgayhamānesu rūpam pi rūpa sabhāga eka saṅgaha vasena
translated: Because of the inclusion of all that is formed under the heading of the component parts that are similar, and because of the limit of two, and because of the inclusion of the rest under those.

original: eko khandho hoti. Vedanā vedanāsabhāgekasaṅgahavasena eko khandho hoti. Esa nayo
analyzed: ekaḥ khandhaḥ hoti vedanā vedanā sabhāga eka saṅgaha vasena ekaḥ khandhaḥ hoti esa nayo
translated: For when formed dhammas are included under the heading of what is similar, then materiality is one aggregate by being included under the heading of the component part that is similar to materiality. Feeling is one aggregate by being included under the heading of the component part that is similar to feeling. So too with perception, and so on.

original: saññādīsu. Tasmā sabbasaṅkhatasabhāgekasaṅgahato pañceva vuttā. Etaparamañcetaṃ attattaniyagāhavatthu
analyzed: saññā ādīsu pañca iva vuttāḥ atta tta niya gāha vatthu
translated: So they are stated as five because of the inclusion of all that is formed under the heading of the component parts that are similar.

original: yadidaṃ rūpādayo pañca. Vuttañhetaṃ “rūpe kho, bhikkhave, sati rūpaṃ upādāya rūpaṃ
analyzed: yat idam rūpa ādayaḥ pañca vuttam ha etam rūpe kho bhikkhave sati rūpam upādāya rūpam
translated: And this is the limit of two in the case of the self-theory that assumes a self and what pertains to a self, that is to say, the five beginning with materiality. For this is said: “When there is materiality, bhikkhus, when materiality is, owing to materiality, depending on materiality,

original: abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati ‘etaṃ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attā’ti. Vedanāya,
analyzed: abhinivissa evam diṭṭhi uppajjati etam mama esaḥ aham asmi esaḥ me attā ati vedanāya
translated: this view arises thus: ‘This is mine, this I am, this is my self’ . When there is feeling …

original: saññāya, saṅkhāresu, viññāṇe sati viññāṇaṃ upādāya viññāṇaṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi
analyzed: saññāya saṅkhāresu viññāṇe sati viññāṇam upādāya viññāṇam abhinivissa evam diṭṭhi
translated: When there is perception, when there is formations, when there is consciousness, depending on consciousness, assuming consciousness, taking consciousness as self,🔽this view arises: ‘This is my self, which is unpercipient, unfeeling,

original: uppajjati ‘etaṃ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attā”ti. Tasmā attattaniyagāhavatthussa
analyzed: uppajjati etam mama esaḥ aham asmi esaḥ me attā ati tasmai atta tta niya gāha vatthussa
translated: and in future will be without consciousness.’ Therefore, because they are the basis for the misapprehension of self and what pertains to self,

original: etaparamatopi pañceva vuttā. Yepi caññe sīlādayo pañca dhammakkhandhā vuttā, tepi
analyzed: pañca iva vuttāḥ ye pi caññe sīla ādayo pañca dhammakkhandhāḥ vuttā te pi
translated: they are stated as five and no more. And the other five aggregates of dhamma stated, namely, virtue, etc.,

original: saṅkhārakkhandhe pariyāpannattā ettheva avarodhaṃ gacchanti. Tasmā aññesaṃ tadavarodhatopi
analyzed: saṅkhāra kkhandhe pariyāpanna ttā ettha iva avarodham gacchanti tasmai aññesam tad avarodhataḥ pi
translated: are included in the formations aggregate. Therefore, because they are included in that,

original: pañceva vuttāti evaṃ anūnādhikato vinicchayanayo viññātabbo.🔽507. Upamātoti ettha hi gilānasālupamo rūpupādānakkhandho, gilānupamassa viññāṇupādānakkhandhassa🔽vatthudvārārammaṇavasena nivāsaṭṭhānato. Gelaññupamo vedanupādānakkhandho, ābādhakattā.
analyzed: pañca iva vuttā ti evam anūnādhikataḥ vinicchaya nayaḥ viññātabbo  upamātaḥ ti ettha hi gilāna sālu pamaḥ rūpa upādāna kkhandhaḥ gilānupamassa viññāṇa upādāna kkhandhassa  vatthu dvāra ārammaṇa vasena nivāsa ṭṭhānataḥ gelaññu upamaḥ vedanu pādānakkhandho ābādhaka ttā
translated: they are stated as five and no more. This is how the exposition should be known here as to neither less nor more.🔽As to simile: the material form aggregate is like a sick man’s bedding,🔽because it is the abode of the consciousness aggregate, which is like the sick man, in the sense of physical basis, door, and object. The feeling aggregate is like the sickness, because it is the cause of affliction.

original: Gelaññasamuṭṭhānupamo saññupādānakkhandho, kāmasaññādivasena rāgādisampayuttavedanāsabbhāvā.
analyzed: gelañña samuṭṭhāna upamaḥ saññā upādāna kkhandho kāma saññā ādi vasena rāga ādi sampayutta vedanā sabbhāvā
translated: The perception aggregate is like the origin of the sickness, because it is not associated with the feeling that is associated with greed, etc., in the way beginning with perception of sense desires.

original: Asappāyasevanupamo saṅkhārupādānakkhandho, vedanāgelaññassa nidānattā. “Vedanaṃ vedanatthāya🔽abhisaṅkharontī”ti hi vuttaṃ. Tathā “akusalassa kammassa katattā upacitattā vipākaṃ🔽kāyaviññāṇaṃ uppannaṃ hoti dukkhasahagata”nti. Gilānupamo viññāṇupādānakkhandho,
analyzed: saṅkhāra upādāna kkhandhaḥ vedanā gelaññassa nidāna ttā vedanam vedana tthāya  abhisaṅkharonti iti hi vuttam tathā akusalassa kammassa kata ttā upacita ttā vipākam  kāya viññāṇam uppannam hoti dukkha sahagatanti gilāna upamaḥ viññāṇa upādāna kkhandho
translated: The clinging aggregate of volitional formations is like the resort to what is unsuitable, because feeling is the source of the arrow of craving. For it is said: “They form volitional formations for the sake of feeling” . And: “Because of the performance and accumulation of unprofitable kamma,🔽eye-consciousness has arisen accompanied by pain” . The clinging aggregate of consciousness is like the sick man,

original: vedanāgelaññena aparimuttattā. Apica cārakakāraṇaaparādhakāraṇakārakaaparādhikupamā
analyzed: vedanā gelaññena a parimutta ttā apica cāraka kāraṇa aparādha kāraṇa kāraka aparādhi kupamā
translated: The clinging aggregate of volitional formations is like the resort to what is unsuitable, because feeling is the source of the arrow. For it is said: “They form volitional formations for the sake of feeling” . And: “Because of the performance and the piling up of unwholesome action, resultant body-consciousness has arisen accompanied by pain” . The clinging aggregate of consciousness is like the sick man, because he is not free from the arrow of feeling. Furthermore, they are like the cause of illness, the crime, the criminal, and the punishment;

original: ete bhājanabhojanabyañjanaparivesakabhuñjakūpamā cāti evaṃ upamāto vinicchayanayo viññātabbo.🔽508. Daṭṭhabbato dvidhāti saṅkhepato vitthārato cāti evaṃ dvidhā daṭṭhabbatopettha
analyzed: ete bhājana bhojana byañjana parivesaka bhuñjaka upamā ca ati evam upamātaḥ vinicchaya nayaḥ viññātabbo  daṭṭhabbataḥ dvidhā iti saṅkhepataḥ vitthārataḥ ca ati evam dvidhā daṭṭhabba tā upa ittha
translated: and they are like the vessel, the food, the seasoning, the waiter, and the diner. This is how the method of exposition by way of simile should be understood.

original: vinicchayanayo viññātabbo. Saṅkhepato hi pañcupādānakkhandhā āsīvisūpame vuttanayena
analyzed: vinicchaya nayaḥ viññātabbo saṅkhepataḥ hi pañca upādāna khandhāḥ āsīvisa upame vutta nayena
translated: As to be seen: here the method of exposition should be understood as twofold, that is to say, as to be seen briefly and as to be seen in detail. For the five aggregates as objects of clinging are to be seen briefly in the way stated in the Simile of the Snake,

original: ukkhittāsikapaccatthikato, bhārasuttavasena bhārato, khajjanīyapariyāyavasena khādakato,

original: yamakasuttavasena aniccadukkhānattasaṅkhatavadhakato daṭṭhabbā. Vitthārato panettha
analyzed: yamaka sutta vasena anicca dukkha anatta saṅkhata vadhakataḥ daṭṭhabbā vitthārato pana ittha
translated: They should be seen as impermanent, painful, not-self, formed, and subject to destruction, according to the Twin Verses. But in detail they should be seen as follows:

original: pheṇapiṇḍo viya rūpaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ, parimaddanāsahanato. Udakapubbuḷaṃ viya vedanā,🔽muhuttaramaṇīyato. Marīcikā viya saññā, vippalambhanato. Kadalikkhandho viya saṅkhārā,
analyzed: pheṇa piṇḍaḥ viya rūpam daṭṭhabbam parimaddana a sahanataḥ udaka pubbuḷam viya vedanā  muhutta ramaṇīyataḥ marīcikāḥ viya saññā vippalambhanato kadali kkhandhaḥ viya saṅkhārā
translated: Rūpa should be seen as a lump of froth because it will not stand squeezing. Feeling should be seen as a bubble on water because it is delightful only for a moment.🔽Perception should be seen as a mirage because it misleads. Formations should be seen as a plantain trunk because they have no core.

original: asārakato. Māyā viya viññāṇaṃ, vañcakato. Visesato ca suḷārampi ajjhattikaṃ rūpaṃ🔽asubhanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Vedanā tīhi dukkhatāhi avinimuttato dukkhāti. Saññāsaṅkhārā
analyzed: asārakataḥ māyā viya viññāṇam vañcakataḥ visesato ca suḷāram pi ajjhattikam rūpam  asubhanti daṭṭhabbam vedanā tīhi dukkha tāhi a vinimuttataḥ dukkhā ati saññā saṅkhārā
translated: Consciousness should be seen as a magic trick because it deceives. And in particular, internal materiality should be seen as foul,

original: avidheyyato anattāti. Viññāṇaṃ udayabbayadhammato aniccanti daṭṭhabbaṃ.🔽509. Evaṃ passantassatthasiddhitoti evañca saṅkhepavitthāravasena dvidhā passato
analyzed: a vidheyyataḥ anattā ati viññāṇam udaya bbaya dhammataḥ aniccanti daṭṭhabbam  evam passantassa attha siddhitaḥ ti evam ca saṅkhepa vitthāra vasena dvidhā passato
translated: feeling as painful, perception and formations as not-self, and consciousness as impermanent.🔽Because the establishment of the meaning is accomplished by seeing in this way: the method of exposition should be understood as the establishment of the meaning that is accomplished by one who sees in this way in the two ways, briefly and in detail.

original: yā atthasiddhi hoti, tatopi vinicchayanayo viññātabbo. Seyyathidaṃ – saṅkhepato tāva
analyzed: yā vinicchaya nayaḥ viññātabbo seyyathidam saṅkhepato tāva
translated: That is to say,🔽briefly,

original: pañcupādānakkhandhe ukkhittāsikapaccatthikādibhāvena passanto khandhehi na vihaññati.
analyzed: pañca upādānakkhandhe ukkhitta asika paccatthika ādi bhāvena passantaḥ khandhehi na vihaññati
translated: He is not troubled by the aggregates when he sees the five aggregates as enemies with uplifted swords, etc.,

original: Vitthārato pana rūpādīni pheṇapiṇḍādisadisabhāvena passanto na asāresu sāradassī hoti.
analyzed: vitthārato pana rūpa ādīni pheṇa piṇḍa ādi sadisa bhāvena passantaḥ na asāresu sāra dassī hoti
translated: In detail, he is not a perceiver of the permanent in the impermanent when he sees material form, etc., as similar to a lump of foam, etc.

original: Visesato ca ajjhattikarūpaṃ asubhato passanto kabaḷīkārāhāraṃ parijānāti, asubhe🔽subhanti vipallāsaṃ pajahati. Kāmoghaṃ uttarati, kāmayogena visaṃyujjati, kāmāsavena
analyzed: visesataḥ ca ajjhattika rūpam asubhataḥ passanto kabaḷīkāra āhāram parijānāti asubhe  vipallāsam pajahati kāma ogham uttarati kāma yogena visaṃyujjati kāma āsavena
translated: And in particular, he fully understands the physical nutriment when he sees internal material form as foul; he abandons the perversion of perceiving beauty in the foul;

original: anāsavo hoti, abhijjhākāyaganthaṃ bhindati, kāmupādānaṃ na upādiyati.
analyzed: anāsavaḥ hoti abhijjhā kāya gantham bhindati kāma upādānam na upādiyati
translated: he crosses the flood of sense desire, he becomes detached through the bond of sense desire, he becomes free from the taint of sense desire; he breaks the bodily tie of covetousness, he does not cling to sense-desire clinging.

original: Vedanaṃ dukkhato passanto phassāhāraṃ parijānāti, dukkhe sukhanti vipallāsaṃ pajahati,🔽bhavoghaṃ uttarati, bhavayogena visaṃyujjati, bhavāsavena anāsavo hoti, byāpādakāyaganthaṃ
analyzed: vedanam dukkhato passanto phassa āhāram parijānāti dukkhe sukhanti vipallāsam pajahati  bhava ogham uttarati bhava yogena visaṃyujjati bhava āsavena anāsavaḥ hoti byāpāda kāya gantham
translated: He fully understands contact as nutriment when he sees feeling as painful; he abandons the perversion of perceiving pleasure in the painful;

original: bhindati, sīlabbatupādānaṃ na upādiyati.
analyzed: bhindati na upādiyati
translated: he crosses the flood of becoming, he becomes detached through the bond of becoming, he becomes free from the taint of becoming; he breaks the bodily tie of ill will, he does not cling to rules-and-vows clinging.

original: Saññaṃ saṅkhāre ca anattato passanto manosañcetanāhāraṃ parijānāti, anattani attāti
analyzed: saññam saṅkhāre ca anattataḥ passantaḥ manaḥ sañcetanā āhāram parijānāti anattani attā ati
translated: Seeing perception and formations as not-self he fully understands mental volition as nutriment, abandons the perversion of perceiving self in what is not-self,

original: vipallāsaṃ pajahati, diṭṭhoghaṃ uttarati, diṭṭhiyogena visaṃyujjati, diṭṭhāsavena
analyzed: vipallāsam pajahati diṭṭha ogham uttarati diṭṭhi yogena visaṃyujjati diṭṭha āsavena
translated: crosses the flood of false view, is detached from the bond of false view, becomes taintless with the destruction of the taint of false view,

original: anāsavo hoti. Idaṃsaccābhinivesakāyaganthaṃ bhindati, attavādupādānaṃ na upādiyati.
analyzed: anāsavaḥ hoti idaṃsacca abhinivesa kāya gantham bhindati attavāt upādānam na upādiyati
translated: and he breaks the bodily tie of insistence on rules and vows and does not cling to the clinging to a doctrine of self.

original: Viññāṇaṃ aniccato passanto viññāṇāhāraṃ parijānāti, anicce niccanti vipallāsaṃ pajahati,🔽avijjoghaṃ uttarati, avijjāyogena visaṃyujjati, avijjāsavena anāsavo hoti, sīlabbataparāmāsakāyaganthaṃ
analyzed: viññāṇam aniccato passantaḥ viññāṇa āhāram parijānāti anicce niccanti vipallāsam pajahati  uttarati avijjā yogena visaṃyujjati avijjā āsavena anāsavaḥ hoti sīlabbata parāmāsa kāyagantham
translated: Seeing consciousness as impermanent he fully understands consciousness as nutriment, abandons the perversion of perceiving permanence in the impermanent,🔽crosses the flood of ignorance, is detached from the bond of ignorance, becomes taintless with the destruction of the taint of ignorance,

original: bhindati, diṭṭhupādānaṃ na upādiyati.
analyzed: bhindati diṭṭhupādānam na upādiyati
translated: breaks the bodily tie of clinging to rules and vows, and does not cling to the clinging to a doctrine of self.🔽So seeing the aggregates as a murderer, etc.,

original: Evaṃ mahānisaṃsaṃ, vadhakādivasena dassanaṃ yasmā;🔽Tasmā khandhe dhīro, vadhakādivasena passeyyāti.
analyzed: evam mahā nisaṃsam vadhaka ādi vasena dassanam yasmā  khandhe dhīraḥ vadhaka ādi vasena passeyya ati
translated: The wise man should see them thus.🔽In the Path of Purification

original: Iti sādhujanapāmojjatthāya kate visuddhimagge
analyzed: iti sādhu jana pāmojjatthāya kate visuddhi magge
translated: composed for the purpose of gladdening the good

original: Paññābhāvanādhikāre🔽Khandhaniddeso nāma
analyzed: paññā bhāvanā adhikāre
translated: in the chapter on the development of understanding🔽called “The Description of the Aggregates,”

original: Cuddasamo paricchedo.
analyzed: paricchedaḥ
translated: the fourteenth chapter.

original: 15. Āyatanadhātuniddeso
analyzed: āyatana dhātu niddeso
translated: 15. Description of Bases and Elements

original: Āyatanavitthārakathā
analyzed: āyatana vitthāra kathā
translated: The exposition of the bases

original: 510. Āyatanānīti dvādasāyatanāni – cakkhāyatanaṃ, rūpāyatanaṃ, sotāyatanaṃ, saddāyatanaṃ,
analyzed: āyatanāni iti dvādasa āyatanāni cakkhāyatanam rūpāyatanam sotāyatanam saddāyatanam
translated: The bases are twelve in number: eye base, form base, ear base, sound base,

original: ghānāyatanaṃ, gandhāyatanaṃ, jivhāyatanaṃ, rasāyatanaṃ, kāyāyatanaṃ, phoṭṭhabbāyatanaṃ,
analyzed: ghāna āyatanam gandha āyatanam jivhā āyatanam rasa āyatanam kāya āyatanam phoṭṭhabba āyatanam
translated: nose base, odour base, tongue base, flavour base, body base, tangible-object base,

original: manāyatanaṃ, dhammāyatananti. Tattha –
analyzed: manāyatanam dhamma āyatananti tattha
translated: mind base, mental-object base. Herein:🔽Meaning, characteristic, and so on, and also,

original: Attha lakkhaṇa tāvatva, kama saṅkhepa vitthārā;
analyzed: attha lakkhaṇa tāvatva kama saṅkhepa vitthārā
translated: Briefly and in detail, and likewise,🔽As to how they should be regarded,

original: Tathā daṭṭhabbato ceva, viññātabbo vinicchayo.🔽Tattha visesato tāva cakkhatīti cakkhu, rūpaṃ assādeti vibhāveti cāti attho. Rūpayatīti
analyzed: tathā daṭṭhabbataḥ ca iva viññātabbaḥ vinicchayaḥ  tattha visesato tāva cakkhati iti cakkhu rūpam assādeti vibhāveti ca ati atthaḥ rūpayati iti
translated: The exposition should be known.

original: rūpaṃ, vaṇṇavikāraṃ āpajjamānaṃ hadayaṅgatabhāvaṃ pakāsetīti attho. Suṇātīti sotaṃ.🔽Sappatīti saddo, udāhariyatīti attho. Ghāyatīti ghānaṃ. Gandhayatīti gandho. Attano
analyzed: rūpam vaṇṇa vikāram āpajjamānam hadayaṅgata bhāvam pakāseti iti attho suṇāti iti sotam  sappati iti saddaḥ udāhariyati iti atthaḥ ghāyati iti ghānam gandhayati iti gandhaḥ attanaḥ
translated: Herein, firstly, as to the specific meaning: It sees , thus it is eye ; the meaning is that it enjoys and discerns visible forms. It makes visible , thus it is form ; the meaning is that it makes known the state of being in the heart when it is undergoing a change of colour. It hears , thus it is ear.

original: vatthuṃ sūcayatīti attho. Jīvitaṃ avhayatīti jivhā. Rasanti taṃ sattāti raso, assādentīti
analyzed: vatthum sūcayati iti atthaḥ jīvitam avhayati iti jivhāḥ rasanti tam rasaḥ assādenti iti
translated: It sounds , thus it is sound; the meaning is that it utters. It smells , thus it is nose. It makes odorous , thus it is odour. The meaning is that it indicates its own physical basis. It savours life , thus it is tongue. It is savoured by beings , thus it is flavour. The meaning is that it is enjoyed by beings.

original: attho. Kucchitānaṃ sāsavadhammānaṃ āyoti kāyo. Āyoti uppattideso. Phusiyatīti phoṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: atthaḥ kucchitānam sāsava dhammānam āyo ti kāyaḥ āyo ti uppatti deso phusiyati iti phoṭṭhabbam
translated: “Body” is the body of defilements, that is, of states subject to cankers. “Origin” is the place of origin. “It is touched” is phusati.

original: Munātīti mano. Attano lakkhaṇaṃ dhārentīti dhammā.
analyzed: munāti iti manaḥ attanaḥ lakkhaṇam dhārenti iti dhammā
translated: “It discerns” is mano. “It bears its own characteristic” is dhamma.

original: 511. Avisesato pana āyatanato, āyānaṃ tananato, āyatassa ca nayanato āyatananti veditabbaṃ.🔽Cakkhurūpādīsu hi taṃtaṃdvārārammaṇā cittacetasikā dhammā sena sena anubhavanādinā
analyzed: avisesataḥ pana āyatanataḥ āyānam tananataḥ āyatassa ca nayanataḥ āyatananti veditabbam  cakkhu rūpa ādīsu hi taṃ taṃ dvāra ārammaṇā citta cetasikā dhammā anubhavana ādinā
translated: But without distinction they are to be understood as bases because they are the extension of the goings , because they are the going of the extended , and because they lead the extended .

original: kiccena āyatanti uṭṭhahanti ghaṭanti, vāyamantīti vuttaṃ hoti. Te ca āyabhūte dhamme🔽etāni tanonti, vitthārentīti vuttaṃ hoti, idañca anamatagge saṃsāre pavattaṃ atīva
analyzed: kiccena āyatanti uṭṭhahanti ghaṭanti vā āyamanti iti vuttam hoti te ca āya bhūte dhamme  etāni tanonti vitthārenti iti vuttam hoti idam ca anamatagge saṃsāre pavattam atīva
translated: For in the eye, visible data, etc., the states of consciousness and its concomitants, by taking each pair as its respective door and object, extend , that is, they arise, are generated, and are active, by the function of experiencing, etc.,

original: āyataṃ saṃsāradukkhaṃ yāva na nivattati, tāva nayanteva, pavattayantīti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: āyatam saṃsāra dukkham yāva na nivattati tāva nayantā iva pavattayanti iti vuttam hoti
translated: and these states that are the goings extend these states that are the bases, that is, they spread them out, is what is said. And this samsāra, which is so extended as to have no beginning or end, is led, is caused to go, is what is said, as long as it does not turn back.

original: Iti sabbepime dhammā āyatanato, āyānaṃ tananato, āyatassa ca nayanato āyatanaṃ āyatananti vuccanti.
analyzed: iti sabbe pi ime dhammā āyatanataḥ āyānam tananataḥ āyatassa ca nayanataḥ āyatanam āyatananti vuccanti
translated: So all these states are called “bases” because they are the extension of the goings, because they are the extension of the bases, and because they lead the extended.

original: 512. Apica nivāsaṭṭhānaṭṭhena ākaraṭṭhena samosaraṇaṭṭhānaṭṭhena sañjātidesaṭṭhena
analyzed: apica nivāsa ṭṭhāna ṭṭhena ākara ṭṭhena samosaraṇa ṭṭhāna ṭṭhena sañjāti desa ṭṭhena
translated: Furthermore, the bases should be understood as the place of abode, as the source, as the place of meeting, as the place of origin,🔽and as the reason. For in the world, in such passages as “The abode of the lord,” “The abode of Vāsudeva,”

original: kāraṇaṭṭhena ca āyatanaṃ veditabbaṃ. Tathā hi loke “issarāyatanaṃ vāsudevāyatana”ntiādīsu🔽nivāsaṭṭhānaṃ āyatananti vuccati. “Suvaṇṇāyatanaṃ rajatāyatana”ntiādīsu ākaro. Sāsane🔽pana “manoramme āyatane sevanti naṃ vihaṅgamā”tiādīsu samosaraṇaṭṭhānaṃ. “Dakkhiṇāpatho
analyzed: kāraṇa ṭṭhena ca āyatanam veditabbam tathā hi loke issara āyatanam vāsudeva āyatana nti ādīsu  nivāsa ṭṭhānam āyatananti vuccati suvaṇṇāyatanam rajatāyatana nti ādīsu ākaraḥ sāsane  pana manoramme āyatane sevanti nam vihaṅgamāti ādīsu samosaraṇa ṭhānam dakkhiṇāpatho
translated: the place of abode is called “base.” In such passages as “The base of gold,” “The base of silver,”🔽in the scriptures, in such passages as “The birds frequent that delightful base,” the place of meeting is called “base.” In such passages as “The base of horses,”

original: gunnaṃ āyatana”ntiādīsu sañjātideso. “Tatra tatreva sakkhibhabbataṃ pāpuṇāti sati
analyzed: gunnam āyatana nti ādīsu sañjā atidesaḥ tatra tatra iva sakkhibhabbatam pāpuṇāti sati
translated: “The base of cattle,” the place of origin is called “base.” In such passages as “He attains the ability to be a witness of those states that are higher, more sublime, and more peaceful than that base whenever he wants, without difficulty, whenever he directs his mind to them,”

original: satiāyatane”tiādīsu kāraṇaṃ.🔽Cakkhuādīsu cāpi te te cittacetasikā dhammā nivasanti tadāyattavuttitāyāti cakkhādayo
analyzed: kāraṇam  cakkhu ādīsu ca api te te citta cetasikāḥ dhammāḥ nivasanti tad āyatta vutti tāya ati cakkhu ādayaḥ
translated: the reason is called “base.”🔽And in the case of the eye, etc., too, those states called eye-consciousness, etc., dwell in the eye, etc., because they exist in dependence on them,

original: ca nesaṃ nivāsaṭṭhānaṃ. Cakkhādīsu ca te ākiṇṇā tannissitattā tadārammaṇattā cāti
analyzed: ca nesam nivāsa ṭṭhānam cakkha ādīsu ca te ākiṇṇā tad nissita ttā tad ārammaṇa ttā ca ati
translated: so the eye, etc., are their place of abode. And they are contained in the eye, etc., because they are dependent on them and because they have them as their object,

original: cakkhādayo nesaṃ ākaro. Cakkhādayo ca nesaṃ samosaraṇaṭṭhānaṃ, tattha tattha vatthudvārārammaṇavasena🔽samosaraṇato. Cakkhādayo ca nesaṃ sañjātideso, tannissayārammaṇabhāvena tattheva
analyzed: cakkhu ādayo ākaro cakkhu ādayo ca nesam samosaraṇa ṭhānam tattha tattha vatthu dvāra ārammaṇa vasena  samosaraṇato cakkha ādayo ca na isam sañjā atideso tad nissaya ārammaṇa bhāvena tattha eva
translated: The eye, etc., are their source.🔽And the eye, etc., are the place where they meet, because they meet there, in the various instances, through the physical basis, the door, and the object.🔽And the eye, etc., are their birthplace, because they arise there, in dependence on them and on the object.

original: uppattito. Cakkhādayo ca nesaṃ kāraṇaṃ, tesaṃ abhāve abhāvatoti. Iti nivāsaṭṭhānaṭṭhena,
analyzed: uppattitaḥ cakkha ādayo ca nesam kāraṇam tesam abhāve abhāvato ti iti nivāsa ṭṭhena
translated: And the eye, etc., are their cause, because they do not occur when these are absent.🔽So they are called bases because they are the place of abode,

original: ākaraṭṭhena, samosaraṇaṭṭhānaṭṭhena, sañjātidesaṭṭhena, kāraṇaṭṭhenacāti imehipi
analyzed: ākara ṭṭhena samosaraṇa ṭhāna ṭṭhena sañjā atidesa ṭṭhena kāraṇa ṭṭhena ca ati imehi pi
translated: because they are the source, because they are the place where they meet, because they are the birthplace, and because they are the cause.

original: kāraṇehi ete dhammā āyatanaṃ āyatananti vuccanti.🔽Tasmā yathāvuttena atthena cakkhu ca taṃ āyatanañcāti cakkhāyatanaṃ…pe… dhammā ca te āyatanañcāti dhammāyatananti evaṃ tāvettha atthato viññātabbo vinicchayo.
analyzed: kāraṇehi ete dhammā āyatanam āyatananti vuccanti 🔽tasmā yathā vuttena atthena cakkhu ca tam āyatanam ca ati cakkhāyatanam pe dhammā ca te āyatanam ca ati dhamma āyatanam ti evam tāva ettha atthataḥ viññātabbaḥ vinicchayaḥ
translated: So that is how the exposition should be known here “as to meaning.”🔽As to order: the order is that of their appearance in the womb.

original: 513. Lakkhaṇāti cakkhādīnaṃ lakkhaṇatopettha viññātabbo vinicchayo. Tāni ca pana tesaṃ lakkhaṇāni khandhaniddese vuttanayeneva veditabbāni.
analyzed: lakkhaṇā ti cakkha ādīnam lakkhaṇa tā upa ittha viññātabbaḥ vinicchayaḥ tāni ca pana tesam lakkhaṇāni khandha niddese vutta nayena iva veditabbāni
translated: and their characteristics should be understood in the way given in the Description of the Aggregates.

original: Tāvatvatoti tāvabhāvato. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – cakkhādayopi hi dhammā eva, evaṃ sati
analyzed: tāva tvataḥ ti tāva bhāvataḥ idam vuttam hoti cakkha ādayaḥ api hi dhammāḥ eva evam sati
translated: As to extent: as to extent of the state. This is what is meant. For the eye, etc., are ideas too,🔽so why are the twelve bases stated instead of just the idea base?

original: dhammāyatanamicceva avatvā kasmā dvādasāyatanānīti vuttānīti ce. Chaviññāṇakāyuppattidvārārammaṇavavatthānato
analyzed: dhammāyatanam iccā iva avatvā kasmā dvādasa āyatanāni iti vuttāni iti ce cha viññāṇa kāya uppatti dvāra ārammaṇa vavatthānato
translated: Because of the delimitation of the door and object for the arising of the six kinds of consciousness.

original: idha channaṃ viññāṇakāyānaṃ dvārabhāvena ārammaṇabhāvena ca vavatthānato ayametesaṃ🔽bhedo hotīti dvādasa vuttāni, cakkhuviññāṇavīthipariyāpannassa hi viññāṇakāyassa
analyzed: idha channam viññāṇa kāyānam dvāra bhāvena ārammaṇa bhāvena ca vavatthānataḥ ayam etesam  bhedaḥ hoti iti dvādasa vuttāni cakkhu viññāṇa vīthi pariyāpannassa hi viññāṇa kāyassa
translated: Herein, the delimitation of these is this:

original: cakkhāyatanameva uppattidvāraṃ, rūpāyatanameva cārammaṇaṃ, tathā itarāni itaresaṃ.
analyzed: cakkhāyatanam eva uppatti dvāram rūpāyatanam eva ca ārammaṇam tathā itarāni itaresam
translated: The eye base is the door for the arising of the consciousness group included in the eye-consciousness process, and the visible-data base is its object. Similarly, the other bases are respectively the doors for the arising of the other consciousness groups,🔽and the respective objects of those same consciousness groups.

original: Chaṭṭhassa pana bhavaṅgamanasaṅkhāto manāyatanekadesova uppattidvāraṃ, asādhāraṇameva
analyzed: chaṭṭhassa pana uppatti dvāram asādhāraṇam eva
translated: But the mind base is the door for the arising of the sixth consciousness group, called the “mind-element” and the “mind-consciousness element,” and the idea base is its object.

original: ca dhammāyatanaṃ ārammaṇanti. Iti channaṃ viññāṇakāyānaṃ uppattidvārārammaṇavavatthānato
analyzed: ca dhamma āyatanam ārammaṇanti iti channam viññāṇa kāyānam uppatti dvāra ārammaṇa vavatthānato
translated: and the mental-data base. Thus, by defining the doors and objects for the arising of the six groups of consciousness,

original: dvādasa vuttānīti evamettha tāvatvato viññātabbo vinicchayo.
analyzed: dvādasa vuttāni iti evam ettha tāva tvataḥ viññātabbaḥ vinicchayaḥ
translated: and the mental-data base as object. So the exposition should be known here as to number thus: “Twelve are stated by defining the doors and objects of the arising of the six groups of consciousness.”

original: 514. Kamatoti idhāpi pubbe vuttesu uppattikkamādīsu desanākkamova yujjati. Ajjhattikesu
analyzed: kamataḥ ti idha api pubbe vuttesu uppatti kkama ādīsu desanā kkamaḥ uva yujjati ajjhattikesu
translated: As to order: here too the order of teaching is appropriate as the order of arising, and so on, stated earlier.

original: hi āyatanesu sanidassanasappaṭighavisayattā cakkhāyatanaṃ pākaṭanti paṭhamaṃ desitaṃ,🔽tato anidassanasappaṭighavisayāni sotāyatanādīni. Atha vā dassanānuttariyasavanānuttariyahetubhāvena
analyzed: hi āyatanesu sa nidassana sa paṭigha visaya ttā cakkha āyatanam pākaṭanti paṭhamam desitam  tatas anidassana sappaṭigha visayāni sotāyatana ādīni atha vā dassana anuttariya savana anuttariya hetu bhāvena
translated: For in the case of the internal bases, the eye base is taught first because it is obvious since it has a visible object that is demonstrable and impinging;

original: bahūpakārattā ajjhattikesu cakkhāyatanasotāyatanāni paṭhamaṃ desitāni, tato ghānāyatanādīni
analyzed: bahu upakāra ttā ajjhattikesu cakkhāyatana sotāyatanāni paṭhamam desitāni tatas ghānāyatana ādīni
translated: after that, the ear base, etc., which have non-demonstrable impinging objects. Or alternatively, the eye and ear bases are taught first among the internal ones because they are of much service as the cause of the unsurpassed seeing and hearing;🔽after that, the three beginning with the nose base.

original: tīṇi, pañcannampi gocaravisayattā ante manāyatanaṃ, cakkhāyatanādīnaṃ pana gocarattā
analyzed: tīṇi gocara visaya ttā ante mana āyatanam cakkhu āyatana ādīnam pana gocara ttā
translated: The mind base is taught last because it is the province of all the five.🔽But the visible-data base, etc., are taught among the external ones between the appropriate ones, that is to say, between the eye base and the ear base, and so on.

original: tassa tassa antarantarāni bāhiresu rūpāyatanādīni. Apica viññāṇuppattikāraṇavavatthānatopi
analyzed: tassa tassa antarantarāni bāhiresu rūpa āyatana ādīni api ca viññāṇa uppatti kāraṇa vavatthānataḥ pi
translated: And again, as to order by defining the cause of the arising of consciousness:

original: ayametesaṃ kamo veditabbo. Vuttañhetaṃ “cakkhuñca paṭicca rūpe ca uppajjati cakkhuviññāṇaṃ…pe…
analyzed: ayam etesam kamaḥ veditabbaḥ vuttam ha etam cakkhuñca paṭicca rūpe ca uppajjati cakkhu viññāṇam pe
translated: This is how the order should be understood here. For this is said: “Eye-consciousness arises in dependence on the eye and forms” , and so on up to

original: manañca paṭicca dhamme ca uppajjati manoviññāṇa”nti. Evaṃ kamatopettha viññātabbo vinicchayo.
analyzed: manam ca paṭicca dhamme ca uppajjati manaḥ viññāṇan ti evam kamataḥ upa ittha viññātabbaḥ vinicchayaḥ
translated: “mind-consciousness arises in dependence on the mind and mental objects” . This is how the exposition should be known here “as to order.”

original: 515. Saṅkhepavitthārāti saṅkhepato hi manāyatanassa ceva dhammāyatanekadesassa ca
analyzed: saṅkhepa vitthārā ti saṅkhepataḥ hi manāyatanassa ca iva dhammāyatana ekadesassa ca
translated: As to brief and detailed: for in brief the mind base and the mental-object base,

original: nāmena tadavasesānañca āyatanānaṃ rūpena saṅgahitattā dvādasāpi āyatanāni nāmarūpamattameva
analyzed: nāmena rūpena dvādasā api āyatanāni nāma rūpa mattam eva
translated: and the rest of the bases, are included under the heading of mentality and corporeality respectively. So the twelve bases are just mentality and corporeality.

original: honti. Vitthārato pana ajjhattikesu tāva cakkhāyatanaṃ jātivasena cakkhupasādamattameva,🔽paccayagatinikāyapuggalabhedato pana anantappabhedaṃ. Tathā sotāyatanādīni cattāri.
analyzed: honti vitthārato pana ajjhattikesu tāva cakkhāyatanam jāti vasena cakkhu pasāda mattam eva  paccaya gati nikāya puggala bhedato pana ananta ppabhedam tathā sotāyatana ādīni cattāri
translated: But in detail, the eye base is just the eye sensitivity as a particular class.🔽But it is of infinite variety according to the distinctions of condition, destiny, station of consciousness, type of being, and so on. So too the ear base, and the rest.

original: Manāyatanaṃ kusalākusalavipākakiriyaviññāṇabhedena ekūnanavutippabhedaṃ ekavīsuttarasatappabhedañca.
analyzed: manāyatanam kusala akusala vipāka kiriya viññāṇa bhedena ekūna navuti ppa bhedam ekavīsa uttara sata ppa bhedam ca
translated: The mind base is of eighty-nine kinds according to the division of consciousness into profitable, unprofitable, and indeterminate, and of two hundred and twelve kinds according to the division of the immaterial-sphere consciousness into the jhānas.

original: Vatthupaṭipadādibhedato pana anantappabhedaṃ. Rūpasaddagandharasāyatanāni visabhāgapaccayādibhedato
analyzed: vatthu paṭipad ādi bhedato pana ananta ppabhedam rūpa sadda gandha rasa āyatanāni visa bhāga paccaya ādi bhedato
translated: But it is of infinite variety according to the difference of the physical basis, the mental orientation, etc.🔽The bases of visible form, sound, odour, and taste are of infinite variety according to the difference of dissimilar conditions, etc.

original: anantappabhedāni. Phoṭṭhabbāyatanaṃ pathavīdhātutejodhātuvāyodhātuvasena tippabhedaṃ.🔽Paccayādibhedato anekappabhedaṃ. Dhammāyatanaṃ vedanāsaññāsaṅkhārakkhandhasukhumarūpanibbānānaṃ
analyzed: ananta ppabhedāni phoṭṭhabbāyatanam pathavī dhātu tejaḥ dhātu vāyaḥ dhātu vasena tippabhedam  paccaya ādi bhedataḥ aneka ppabhedam dhammāyatanam vedanā saññā saṅkhāra kkhandha sukhuma rūpa nibbānānam
translated: The tangible-data base is of three kinds as the earth element, the fire element, and the air element.🔽It is of many kinds according to the difference of conditions, etc.🔽The mental-data base is of many kinds according to the difference of the aggregates of feeling, perception, and formations, of the kinds of subtle matter, and of Nibbāna.

original: sabhāvanānattabhedato anekappabhedanti. Evaṃ saṅkhepavitthārā viññātabbo vinicchayo.🔽516. Daṭṭhabbatoti ettha pana sabbāneva saṅkhatāni āyatanāni anāgamanato aniggamanato🔽ca daṭṭhabbāni. Na hi tāni pubbe udayā kutoci āgacchanti, napi uddhaṃ vayā kuhiñci
analyzed: sabhāva nānatta bhedataḥ aneka ppabhedam ti evam saṅkhepa vitthārā viññātabbaḥ vinicchayaḥ  daṭṭhabbato ti ettha pana sabbān eva saṅkhatāni āyatanāni anāgamanataḥ aniggamanataḥ  ca daṭṭhabbāni na hi tāni pubbe kutoci āgacchanti na pi uddham vayā kuhiñci
translated: This is how the exposition should be known here as to brief and detailed treatment.🔽As to how to be seen: all formed bases should be seen as not coming from anywhere and not going anywhere.🔽For they do not come from anywhere at all before reappearing after coming to be, nor do they go anywhere at all after dissolution.

original: gacchanti, atha kho pubbe udayā appaṭiladdhasabhāvāni, uddhaṃ vayā paribhinnasabhāvāni,
analyzed: gacchanti atha kho pubbe udayā a paṭiladdha sabhāvāni uddham vayā paribhinna sabhāvāni
translated: But rather they are unapprehendable as to individual essence before reappearance after coming to be, and after dissolution they are unapprehendable as to individual essence.

original: pubbantāparantavemajjhe paccayāyattavuttitāya avasāni pavattanti. Tasmā anāgamanato🔽aniggamanato ca daṭṭhabbāni. Tathā nirīhakato abyāpārato ca. Na hi cakkhurūpādīnaṃ
analyzed: pubbanta aparanta vemajjhe paccaya āyatta vutti tāya avasāni pavattanti tasmai an āgamanato  aniggamanato ca daṭṭhabbāni tathā nirīhakataḥ abyāpārato ca na hi cakkhu rūpa ādīnam
translated: They occur in dependence on conditions in the past, future, and present. Therefore they should be seen as not coming from anywhere and not going anywhere.

original: evaṃ hoti “aho vata amhākaṃ sāmaggiyaṃ viññāṇaṃ nāma uppajjeyyā”ti, na ca tāni viññāṇuppādanatthaṃ🔽dvārabhāvena vatthubhāvena ārammaṇabhāvena vā īhanti, na byāpāramāpajjanti, atha
analyzed: evam hoti aho vata amhākam sāmaggiyam viññāṇam nāma uppajjeyyāti na ca tāni viññāṇa uppādana attham  dvāra bhāvena vatthu bhāvena ārammaṇa bhāvena vā īhanti na byāpāram āpajjanti atha
translated: And likewise as not striving and not making assumptions. For the eye and visible data, etc., do not think, “Oh, let there be the consciousness called ‘meeting’!” Nor do they strive or make assumptions about producing consciousness.

original: kho dhammatāvesā, yaṃ cakkhurūpādisāmaggiyaṃ cakkhuviññāṇādīni sambhavantīti. Tasmā🔽nirīhakato abyāpārato ca daṭṭhabbāni. Apica ajjhattikāni suññagāmo viya daṭṭhabbāni,
analyzed: kho dhamma tā āvesā yam cakkhu rūpa ādi sāmaggiyam cakkhu viññāṇa ādīni sambhavanti iti tasmā  nirīhakataḥ abyāpārato ca daṭṭhabbāni apica ajjhattikāni suñña gāmaḥ viya daṭṭhabbāni
translated: But rather it is the nature of things that eye-consciousness, etc., come about when there is a coming together of eye, visible data, and eye-consciousness element, and so on. Therefore they should be seen as not striving and not making assumptions.🔽Moreover, the internal should be seen as an empty village,

original: dhuvasubhasukhattabhāvavirahitattā. Bāhirāni gāmaghātakacorā viya, ajjhattikānaṃ
analyzed: bāhirāni gāma ghātaka corāḥ viya ajjhattikānam
translated: because it lacks any such self as is claimed by the theorists. And the external should be seen as murderers in a village,

original: abhighātakattā. Vuttañhetaṃ “cakkhu, bhikkhave, haññati manāpāmanāpehi rūpehī”ti
analyzed: abhighātaka ttā vuttam ha etam cakkhu bhikkhave haññati manāpa amanāpehi rūpehi iti
translated: because it is the assailant of the internal. For this is said: “Bhikkhus, the eye is assailed by agreeable and disagreeable visible forms” .

original: vitthāro. Apica ajjhattikāni cha pāṇakā viya daṭṭhabbāni, bāhirāni tesaṃ gocarā viyāti.
analyzed: vitthāraḥ apica ajjhattikāni cha pāṇakā viya daṭṭhabbāni bāhirāni tesam gocarā viya ati
translated: and in detail. Moreover, they should be regarded as the six internal creatures, and the external ones as their resort.

original: Evamettha daṭṭhabbato viññātabbo vinicchayo.
analyzed: evam ettha daṭṭhabbataḥ viññātabbaḥ vinicchayaḥ
translated: This is how the exposition should be known here as to how to be seen.

original: Idaṃ tāva āyatanānaṃ vitthārakathāmukhaṃ.
analyzed: idam tāva āyata nānam vitthāra kathā mukham
translated: This, firstly, is the section of the detailed explanation of the bases.

original: Dhātuvitthārakathā
analyzed: dhātu vitthāra kathā
translated: The exposition of the elements

original: 517. Tadanantarā pana dhātuyoti aṭṭhārasa dhātuyo – cakkhudhātu, rūpadhātu, cakkhuviññāṇadhātu,
analyzed: tad anantarā pana dhātuyo ti aṭṭhārasa dhātuyo cakkhu dhātu rūpa dhātu cakkhu viññāṇa dhātu
translated: Next, as to the elements: there are eighteen elements, that is to say, eye element, visible-data element, eye-consciousness element,

original: sotadhātu, saddadhātu, sotaviññāṇadhātu, ghānadhātu, gandhadhātu, ghānaviññāṇadhātu,
analyzed: sota dhātu sadda dhātu sota viññāṇa dhātu ghāna dhātu gandha dhātu ghāna viññāṇa dhātu
translated: ear element, sound element, ear-consciousness element, nose element, odour element, nose-consciousness element,

original: jivhādhātu, rasadhātu, jivhāviññāṇadhātu, kāyadhātu, phoṭṭhabbadhātu, kāyaviññāṇadhātu,
analyzed: jivhā dhātu rasa dhātu jivhā viññāṇa dhātu kāya dhātu phoṭṭhabba dhātu kāya viññāṇa dhātu
translated: tongue element, flavour element, tongue-consciousness element, body element, tangible-data element, body-consciousness element,

original: manodhātu, dhammadhātu, manoviññāṇadhātūti. Tattha –
analyzed: manaḥ dhātu dhammadhātu manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu uti tattha
translated: mind element, mental-data element, mind-consciousness element. Herein:

original: Atthato lakkhaṇādīhi, kama tāvatvasaṅkhato;
analyzed: atthataḥ lakkhaṇa ādīhi
translated: As to meaning, characteristic, Etc., and as to singlefold, etc.,🔽As to condition, and as to how They are to be seen, so too as to how

original: Paccayā atha daṭṭhabbā, veditabbo vinicchayo.
analyzed: paccayāḥ atha daṭṭhabbāḥ veditabbaḥ vinicchayo
translated: The exposition should be known.

original: Tattha atthatoti cakkhatīti cakkhu. Rūpayatīti rūpaṃ. Cakkhussa viññāṇaṃ cakkhuviññāṇanti
analyzed: tattha atthato ti cakkhati iti cakkhu rūpayati iti rūpam cakkhussa viññāṇam cakkhu viññāṇam ti
translated: Herein, as to meaning: it sees , thus it is eye ; it is visible , thus it is visible data ; consciousness of the eye is eye-consciousness ;

original: evamādinā tāva nayena cakkhādīnaṃ visesatthato veditabbo vinicchayo. Avisesena pana
analyzed: evamādinā tāva nayena cakkha ādīnam visesa atthataḥ veditabbaḥ vinicchayaḥ avisesena pana
translated: This is how the exposition should be understood here as to the meaning of the specific characteristic. But as to the meaning of the general characteristic,

original: vidahati, dhīyate, vidhānaṃ, vidhīyate etāya, ettha vā dhīyatīti dhātu. Lokiyā hi🔽dhātuyo kāraṇabhāvena vavatthitā hutvā suvaṇṇarajatādidhātuyo viya suvaṇṇarajatādiṃ,
analyzed: vidahati dhīyate vidhānam vidhīyate etāya ettha vā dhīyati iti dhātu lokiyā hi  dhātuyaḥ kāraṇa bhāvena vavatthitāḥ hutvā suvaṇṇa rajata ādi dhātuyaḥ viya suvaṇṇa rajata ādim
translated: it is the “element” because it is that which disperses , is dispersed, is the dispersing, is dispersed by that, or is dispersed here . For mundane

original: anekappakāraṃ saṃsāradukkhaṃ vidahanti. Bhārahārehi ca bhāro viya, sattehi dhīyante,
analyzed: aneka ppakāram saṃsāra dukkham vidahanti bhāra hārehi ca bhāraḥ viya sattehi dhīyante
translated: elements, having become established as causes, disperse the manifold suffering of the round of rebirths, like gold and silver elements, etc., disperse gold and silver, etc.,

original: dhāriyantīti attho. Dukkhavidhānamattameva cesā, avasavattanato. Etāhi ca karaṇabhūtāhi🔽saṃsāradukkhaṃ sattehi anuvidhīyati. Tathāvihitañca taṃ etāsveva dhīyati, ṭhapiyatīti
analyzed: dhāriyanti iti atthaḥ dukkha vidhāna mattam eva ca isāḥ etāhi ca karaṇa bhūtāhi  saṃsāra dukkham sattehi anuvidhīyati tathā vihitam ca tam etāsu eva dhīyati iti
translated: and they are dispersed by beings, like a load is dispersed by porters. The meaning is that they are borne by beings. They merely disperse suffering, however, not control it, because they are not independent. And by them, which are the means,

original: attho. Iti cakkhādīsu ekeko dhammo yathāsambhavaṃ vidahati, dhīyatītiādinā atthavasena dhātūti vuccati.
analyzed: attho iti cakkha ādīsu ekekaḥ dhammaḥ yathāsambhavam vidahati dhīyati itiādinā attha vasena dhātu ti vuccati
translated: the suffering of the round of rebirths is dispersed by beings. And that, being thus dispersed, is dispersed here in the elements, the meaning is that it is placed here. So each state among the eye, etc., is called an “element” in the sense of dispersing, being dispersed, etc., according to the way in which it is appropriate.

original: 518. Apica yathā titthiyānaṃ attā nāma sabhāvato natthi, na evametā, etā pana attano
analyzed: apica yathā titthiyānam attā nāma sabhāvataḥ natthi na evam etāḥ etāḥ pana attanaḥ
translated: Moreover, just as the self of the sectarians does not exist as a substantive, so too these elements do not exist as substantives.

original: sabhāvaṃ dhārentīti dhātuyo. Yathā loke vicittā haritālamanosilādayo selāvayavā dhātuyoti🔽vuccanti, evametāpi dhātuyo viya dhātuyo. Vicittā hete ñāṇañeyyāvayavāti. Yathā vā
analyzed: sabhāvam dhārenti iti dhātuyaḥ yathā loke vicittāḥ haritāla manaḥsila ādayaḥ sela avayavāḥ  vuccanti evam etā api dhātuyaḥ viya dhātuyaḥ vicittāḥ ha ete ñāṇa ñeyya avayavāti yathā vā
translated: They are elements in the sense of bearing their own characteristics. Just as in the world, the various constituents of a gem such as gold, silver, etc., are called its “elements” ,

original: sarīrasaṅkhātassa samudāyassa avayavabhūtesu rasasoṇitādīsu aññamaññavisabhāgalakkhaṇaparicchinnesu🔽dhātusamaññā, evametesupi pañcakkhandhasaṅkhātassa attabhāvassa avayavesu dhātusamaññā🔽veditabbā. Aññamaññavisabhāgalakkhaṇaparicchinnā hete cakkhādayoti. Apica dhātūti🔽nijjīvamattassevetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Tathā hi bhagavā “cha dhāturo ayaṃ bhikkhu puriso”tiādīsu
analyzed: sarīra saṅkhātassa samudāyassa avayava bhūtesu rasa soṇita ādīsu aññamañña visabhāga lakkhaṇa paricchinnesu  dhātu samaññā evam etesu pi pañca kkhandha saṅkhātassa atta bhāvassa avayavesu dhātu samaññā  veditabbāḥ añña mañña visabhāga lakkhaṇa paricchinnāḥ ha ite cakkha ādayaḥ ti api ca dhātu uti  adhivacanam tathā hi bhagavā ayam bhikkhu purisa iti ādīsu
translated: so these states are called elements in the way that the constituents of knowledge are called elements. For these states are the various constituents of what is to be known. Or just as in the body, which is called a “collection,” the constituents such as blood, flesh, etc., are called its “elements” , being delimited by the particularities of their individual characteristics,

original: jīvasaññāsamūhananatthaṃ dhātudesanaṃ akāsīti.
analyzed: jīva saññā samūhanana attham dhātu desanam akāsi iti
translated: so in the case of the individual, which is called a “collection” of five aggregates, the eye, etc., are called its “elements,” being delimited by the particularities of their individual characteristics. For the eye, etc., are delimited by the particularities of their individual characteristics, such as “able to discern visible forms,” etc. Moreover, “elements” is a term for what is devoid of a living being. For the Blessed One gave the teaching on the elements for the purpose of removing the perception of a living being, as in the passage: “Bhikkhus, this person is a collection of six elements” .

original: Tasmā yathāvuttena atthena cakkhu ca taṃ dhātu ca cakkhudhātu…pe… manoviññāṇañca taṃ dhātu ca manoviññāṇadhātūti. Evaṃ tāvettha atthato veditabbo vinicchayo.
analyzed: tasmai yathā vuttena atthena cakkhu ca tam dhātu ca cakkhu dhātu pe manaḥ viññāṇam ca tam dhātu ca manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu uti evam tāva ettha atthataḥ veditabbaḥ vinicchayaḥ
translated: So the eye is a dhātu in the sense stated, and the visible data are a dhātu in the same sense, and so on. This is how the exposition should be known here “as to meaning. ”

original: 519. Lakkhaṇāditoti cakkhādīnaṃ lakkhaṇāditopettha veditabbo vinicchayo. Tāni ca pana nesaṃ lakkhaṇādīni khandhaniddese vuttanayeneva veditabbāni.
analyzed: lakkhaṇa āditaḥ ti cakkha ādīnam lakkhaṇa āditaḥ upa ittha veditabbaḥ vinicchayaḥ tāni ca pana nesam lakkhaṇa ādīni khandha niddese vutta nayena iva veditabbāni
translated: As to characteristic, etc.? Here the exposition should be known as to the characteristic, etc., of the eye, and so on. But their characteristic, etc., should be understood as stated in the Description of the Aggregates .

original: Kamatoti idhāpi pubbe vuttesu uppattikkamādīsu desanākkamova yujjati. So ca panāyaṃ
analyzed: kamataḥ ti idha api pubbe vuttesu uppatti kkama ādīsu desanā kkamaḥ uva yujjati saḥ ca pana ayam
translated: As to order: here too the order of teaching is appropriate, which was stated thus: “The order of arising is not the only order;🔽for there is also the order of teaching” . And that is stated

original: hetuphalānupubbavavatthānavasena vutto. Cakkhudhātu rūpadhātūti idañhi dvayaṃ hetu,
analyzed: hetu phala anupubba vavatthāna vasena vuttaḥ cakkhu dhātu rūpa dhātu iti idam hi dvayam hetu
translated: in the order of cause and fruit. For the two, namely, the eye dhātu and visible-data dhātu, are the cause,

original: cakkhuviññāṇadhātūti phalaṃ. Evaṃ sabbattha.
analyzed: cakkhu viññāṇa dhātū ti phalam evam sabbattha
translated: while eye-consciousness dhātu is the fruit. So with all the rest.

original: 520. Tāvatvatoti tāvabhāvato. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – tesu tesu hi suttābhidhammappadesesu
analyzed: tāva tvataḥ ti tāva bhāvataḥ idam vuttam hoti tesu tesu hi sutta abhidhamma ppadesesu
translated: As to what is proper: this is a term for what is suitable. What is meant is this: in the various instances of suttas and of the Abhidhamma,

original: “ābhādhātu, subhadhātu, ākāsānañcāyatanadhātu, viññāṇañcāyatanadhātu, ākiñcaññāyatanadhātu,
analyzed: ābhā dhātu subha dhātu ākāsānañca āyatana dhātu viññāṇañca āyatana dhātu ākiñcaññāyatana dhātu
translated: the light element, the beauty element, the infinite-space element, the infinite-consciousness element, the nothingness element,

original: nevasaññānāsaññāyatanadhātu, saññāvedayitanirodhadhātu”, “kāmadhātu, byāpādadhātu,🔽vihiṃsādhātu, nekkhammadhātu, abyāpādadhātu, avihiṃsādhātu”, “sukhadhātu, dukkhadhātu,
analyzed: nevasaññā nāsañña āyatana dhātu saññā vedayita nirodha dhātu kāmadhātu byāpāda dhātu  vihiṃsā dhātu nekkhamma dhātu a byāpāda dhātu a vihiṃsā dhātu sukha dhātu dukkha dhātu
translated: the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception element, the element of the cessation of perception and feeling” , “the sensual desire element, the ill will element,🔽the cruelty element, the renunciation element, the non-ill will element, the non-cruelty element” , “the pleasure element, the pain element,

original: somanassadhātu, domanassadhātu, upekkhādhātu, avijjādhātu”, “ārambhadhātu, nikkamadhātu,
analyzed: somanassa dhātu domanassa dhātu upekkhā dhātu avijjā dhātu ārambha dhātu nikkama dhātu
translated: the joy element, the grief element, the equanimity element, the ignorance element” , “the element of instigation, the element of exertion,

original: parakkamadhātu”, “hīnadhātu, majjhimadhātu, paṇītadhātu”, “pathavīdhātu, āpodhātu,
analyzed: parakkama dhātu hīna dhātu majjhima dhātu paṇīta dhātu pathavī dhātu āpodhātu
translated: the element of striving” , “the inferior element, the medium element, the superior element” , “the earth element, the water element,

original: tejodhātu, vāyodhātu, ākāsadhātu, viññāṇadhātu”, “saṅkhatadhātu, asaṅkhatadhātu”,
analyzed: tejaḥ dhātu vāyo dhātu ākāsa dhātu viññāṇa dhātu saṅkhata dhātu asaṅkhata dhātu
translated: the fire element, the air element, the space element, the consciousness element” , “the formed element, the unformed element” ,

original: “anekadhātu nānādhātu loko”ti evamādayo aññāpi dhātuyo dissanti. Evaṃ sati sabbāsaṃ🔽vasena paricchedaṃ akatvā kasmā aṭṭhārasāti ayameva paricchedo katoti ce. Sabhāvato
analyzed: aneka dhātu nānā dhātu loko ti evamādayaḥ aññā api dhātuyaḥ dissanti evam sati sabbāsam  vasena paricchedam a katvā kasmai ayam eva paricchedo kato ti ce sabhāvato
translated: “the world is of many elements, of various elements” . When there are these and other elements besides,🔽why is this particular limitation made, omitting all the rest and specifying only eighteen?

original: vijjamānānaṃ sabbadhātūnaṃ tadantogadhattā.
analyzed: vijjamānānam sabba dhātūnam tad anta gadhattā
translated: Because all the elements that exist in the ultimate sense are included in these eighteen.

original: Rūpadhātuyeva hi ābhādhātu, subhadhātu pana rūpādipaṭibaddhā. Kasmā, subhanimittattā.
analyzed: hi ābhā dhātu subha dhātu pana rūpa ādi paṭibaddhā kasmāt subha nimitta ttā
translated: Why? Because it is the sign of beauty.

original: Subhanimittañhi subhadhātu. Tañca rūpādivinimuttaṃ na vijjati. Kusalavipākārammaṇā
analyzed: subha nimittam hi subha dhātu tat ca rūpa ādi vinimuttam na vijjati kusala vipāka ārammaṇā
translated: For the beauty element is the sign of beauty, and that is not found apart from visible data, etc.

original: vā rūpādayo eva subhadhātūti rūpādimattamevesā. Ākāsānañcāyatanadhātuādīsu cittaṃ
analyzed: vā rūpa ādayaḥ eva subha dhātu uti rūpa ādimattam eva īsā ākāsa anañcāyatana dhātu ādīsu cittam
translated: Or else it is the visible data, etc., themselves as objects of profitable resultant consciousness that are the beauty element. So this is just visible data, etc.,🔽In the case of the elements of the base consisting of boundless space, etc., the consciousness is the mind element,

original: manoviññāṇadhātuyeva, sesā dhammadhātu. Saññāvedayitanirodhadhātu pana sabhāvato
analyzed: manaḥ viññāṇa dhātuyā iva sesā dhammadhātu saññā vedayita nirodha dhātu pana sabhāvato
translated: the rest are the mental-data element. But as to the element of the cessation of perception and feeling,🔽it does not exist as a real entity,

original: natthi. Dhātudvayanirodhamattameva hi sā.🔽Kāmadhātu dhammadhātumattaṃ vā hoti. Yathāha – “tattha katamā kāmadhātu? Kāmapaṭisaṃyutto
analyzed: natthi dhātu dvaya nirodha mattam eva hi sā  kāmadhātu dhammadhātumattam vā hoti yathā āha tattha katamā kāmadhātu kāma paṭisaṃyuttaḥ
translated: for it is just the mere cessation of the two elements.🔽Or it is the mental-data element, as in the case of the element of sensual desire,🔽for this is said: “Herein, what is the element of sensual desire? It is wrong thinking that is associated with sensual desire” .

original: takko vitakko micchāsaṅkappo”ti. Aṭṭhārasāpi vā dhātuyo. Yathāha – “heṭṭhato avīcinirayaṃ
analyzed: takkaḥ vitakkaḥ micchā saṅkappo ti aṭṭhārasā api vā dhātuyaḥ yathā āha heṭṭhatas avīci nirayam
translated: Or it is the eighteen elements, as in the case of the element of ill will,

original: pariyantaṃ karitvā uparito paranimmitavasavattī deve antokaritvā yaṃ etasmiṃ antare
analyzed: pariyantam karitvā uparitas deve antokaritvā yam etasmin antare
translated: for this is said: “Having made the hell realm below and the Brahmā realm above, one can include between them all that is called the eighteen elements” .

original: etthāvacarā ettha pariyāpannā khandhadhātuāyatanā rūpā vedanā saññā saṅkhārā viññāṇaṃ,
analyzed: etthāvacarā ettha pariyāpannā khandha dhātu āyatanā rūpāḥ vedanā saññā saṅkhārāḥ viññāṇam
translated: the aggregates, elements, and sense bases that occur and are included here, form, feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness,

original: ayaṃ vuccati kāmadhātū”ti.
analyzed: ayam vuccati kāmadhātu uti
translated: this is called the sense-sphere of sensual desires.”

original: Nekkhammadhātu dhammadhātu eva, “sabbepi kusalā dhammā nekkhammadhātū”ti vacanato
analyzed: nekkhammadhātu dhammadhātu eva sabbe pi kusalāḥ dhammāḥ nekkhammadhātu iti vacanato
translated: The element of renunciation is the element of mental objects. Because of the statement: “All wholesome mental objects are the element of renunciation,”

original: manoviññāṇadhātupi hotiyeva. Byāpādavihiṃsā-abyāpāda-avihiṃsāsukha-dukkha-somanassa-domanassupekkhā-avijjāārambha-nikkama-parakkamadhātuyo dhammadhātuyeva.
analyzed: manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu pi hotiyā iva byāpāda vihiṃsā abyāpāda avihiṃsā sukha dukkha somanassa domanassa upekkhā avijjā ārambha nikkama parakkama dhātuyaḥ dhammadhātuyā iva
translated: the element of mind-consciousness also is included. The elements of ill-will and cruelty, non-ill-will and non-cruelty, pleasure, pain, joy, grief, equanimity, ignorance, initiative, escape, and exertion are the element of mental objects.

original: Hīnamajjhimapaṇītadhātuyo aṭṭhārasa dhātumattameva. Hīnā hi cakkhādayo hīnā dhātu,
analyzed: hīna majjhima paṇīta dhātuyaḥ aṭṭhārasa dhātumattam eva hīnāḥ hi cakkha ādayaḥ hīnāḥ dhātu
translated: The elements of the inferior, medium, and superior are just the eighteen elements. For the inferior eye, etc., are the inferior element,

original: majjhimapaṇītā majjhimā ceva paṇītā ca. Nippariyāyena pana akusalā dhammadhātumanoviññāṇadhātuyo
analyzed: majjhima paṇītā majjhimā ca iva paṇītā ca nippariyāyena pana akusalāḥ dhammadhātu manaḥ viññāṇa dhātuyo
translated: the medium and superior are the medium and superior. But in the ultimate sense, the unwholesome element and the element of mind-consciousness

original: hīnadhātu, lokiyā kusalābyākatā ubhopi cakkhudhātuādayo ca majjhimadhātu, lokuttarā🔽pana dhammadhātumanoviññāṇadhātuyo paṇītadhātu.
analyzed: hīna dhātu lokiyā kusalā abyākatā ubho pi cakkhu dhātu ādayo ca majjhima dhātu lokuttarā 🔽pana dhammadhātu manaḥ viññāṇa dhātuyo paṇīta dhātu
translated: are the inferior element, the mundane wholesome and indeterminate are the medium element, and the supramundane🔽are the superior element.

original: Pathavītejovāyodhātuyo phoṭṭhabbadhātuyeva, āpodhātu ākāsadhātu ca dhammadhātuyeva. Viññāṇadhātu cakkhuviññāṇādisattaviññāṇadhātusaṅkhepoyeva.
analyzed: pathavī tejaḥ vāyo dhātuyo phoṭṭhabba dhātuyā iva āpodhātu ākāsa dhātu ca dhammadhātuyā iva viññāṇa dhātu cakkhu viññāṇa ādi satta viññāṇa dhātu saṅkhepoyā iva
translated: The earth, fire and air elements are the tangible-data element only. The water element and the space element are the mental-data element only. The consciousness element is a summary of the seven beginning with eye-consciousness.

original: Sattarasa dhātuyo dhammadhātuekadeso ca saṅkhatadhātu, asaṅkhatā pana dhātu dhammadhātuekadesova.🔽Anekadhātunānādhātuloko pana aṭṭhārasa dhātuppabhedamattamevāti. Iti sabhāvato vijjamānānaṃ
analyzed: sattarasa dhātuyaḥ dhammadhātu ekadeso ca saṅkhata dhātu asaṅkhatā pana dhātu dhammadhātu ekadesaḥ uva  aneka dhātu nānā dhātu loko pana aṭṭhārasa dhātu ppabheda mattam eva ati iti sabhāvataḥ
translated: The seventeen elements and one part of the mental-data element are the formed element. The unformed element is one part of the mental-data element only.🔽The world of many elements and various elements is just the eighteen elements classed in different ways. So they are stated as only eighteen because all the elements that exist in the true individual essence

original: sabbadhātūnaṃ tadantogadhattā aṭṭhāraseva vuttāti.
analyzed: sabba dhātūnam tad anta gadha ttā aṭṭhārasā iva vuttā iti
translated: are included in those eighteen.

original: 521. Apica vijānanasabhāve viññāṇe jīvasaññīnaṃ saññāsamūhananatthampi aṭṭhāraseva🔽vuttā. Santi hi sattā vijānanasabhāve viññāṇe jīvasaññino, tesaṃ cakkhusotaghānajivhākāyamanodhātumanoviññāṇadhātubhedena
analyzed: apica vijānana sabhāve viññāṇe jīva saññīnam saññā samūhana nattham pi aṭṭhārasā iva  vuttā santi hi sattā vijānana sabhāve viññāṇe jīva saññinaḥ tesam cakkhu sota ghāna jivhā kāya manaḥ dhātu manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu bhedena
translated: Besides, they are stated as only eighteen in order to confound the perception of a soul in consciousness, which has the individual essence of cognizing.

original: tassa anekataṃ cakkhurūpādipaccayāyattavuttitāya aniccatañca pakāsetvā dīgharattānusayitaṃ
analyzed: tassa aneka tam cakkhu rūpa ādi paccaya āyatta vutti tāya anicca tam ca pakāsetvā dīgha ratta anusayitam
translated: For there are beings who perceive a soul in consciousness, which has the individual essence of cognizing. In order to make them abandon the long-standing latent tendency to that perception by showing them that it is multiple and impermanent since it occurs in dependence on eye, visible data, etc.,

original: jīvasaññaṃ samūhanitukāmena bhagavatā aṭṭhārasa dhātuyo pakāsitā. Kiñca bhiyyo tathā
analyzed: jīva saññam samūhanitu kāmena bhagavatā aṭṭhārasa dhātuyaḥ pakāsitā kiñca bhiyyo tathā
translated: The eighteen elements were taught by the Blessed One who wishes to destroy the perception of a living being.🔽And more than that,🔽according to the inclinations of those to be trained.

original: veneyyajjhāsayavasena ca. Ye ca imāya anatisaṅkhepavitthārāya desanāya veneyyasattā,
analyzed: veneyya ajjhāsaya vasena ca ye ca imāya an ati saṅkhepa vitthārāya desanāya veneyya sattā
translated: And those beings to be trained for whom the teaching is given in this way, without being too condensed or too expanded,

original: tadajjhāsayavasena ca aṭṭhāraseva pakāsitā.🔽Saṅkhepavitthāranayena tathā tathā hi,
analyzed: tad ajjhāsaya vasena ca aṭṭhārasā iva pakāsitā  saṅkhepa vitthāra nayena tathā tathā hi
translated: are taught in eighteen elements according to their inclinations.🔽For in this way and that,

original: Dhammaṃ pakāsayati esa yathā yathāssa;🔽Saddhammatejavihataṃ vilayaṃ khaṇena,
analyzed: dhammam pakāsayati yathā yathā assa  saddhamma teja vihatam vilayam khaṇena
translated: he teaches the Dhamma in this way and that,

original: Veneyyasattahadayesu tamo payātīti.
analyzed: veneyya satta hadayesu tamaḥ payāti iti
translated: and the darkness in the hearts of beings to be trained is dispelled in an instant by the radiance of his faith in the Dhamma.

original: Evamettha tāvatvato veditabbo vinicchayo.
analyzed: evam ettha tāva tvataḥ veditabbaḥ vinicchayaḥ
translated: This, in the first place, is how the exposition should be understood here as to “how many.”

original: 522. Saṅkhatoti cakkhudhātu tāva jātito eko dhammotveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati cakkhupasādavasena,🔽tathā sotaghānajivhākāyarūpasaddagandharasadhātuyo sotappasādādivasena, phoṭṭhabbadhātu
analyzed: saṅkhato ti cakkhu dhātu tāva jātitaḥ ekaḥ dhammo tvā iva saṅkham gacchati cakkhu pasāda vasena  tathā sota ghāna jivhā kāya rūpa sadda gandha rasa dhātuyo sota ppasāda ādi vasena phoṭṭhabba dhātu
translated: As to “formed”: the eye element, firstly, is reckoned as a single element according to individual essence as eye sensitivity.🔽So too the ear, nose, tongue, and body elements as ear, nose, tongue, and body sensitivities. The visible-data element is reckoned as a single element according to individual essence as visible data.

original: pana pathavītejovāyovasena tayo dhammāti saṅkhaṃ gacchati. Cakkhuviññāṇadhātu kusalākusalavipākavasena
analyzed: pana pathavī tejaḥ vāyaḥ vasena tayo dhammā ati saṅkham gacchati cakkhu viññāṇa dhātu kusala akusala vipāka vasena
translated: So too the sound, odour, flavour, and tangible-data elements as sounds, odours, flavours, and tangible data. The tangible-data element, however, is reckoned as three elements according to individual essence as earth, fire, and air. The eye-consciousness element is reckoned as a single element according to individual essence as profitable resultant eye-consciousness.

original: dve dhammāti saṅkhaṃ gacchati, tathā sotaghānajivhākāyaviññāṇadhātuyo. Manodhātu
analyzed: dve dhammā ati saṅkham gacchati tathā sota ghāna jivhā kāya viññāṇa dhātuyaḥ manaḥ dhātu
translated: and so it is reckoned as two ideas. So too with the ear-, nose-, tongue-, and body-element.🔽The mind element, however, is reckoned as three ideas,

original: pana pañcadvārāvajjanakusalākusalavipākasampaṭicchanavasena tayo dhammāti saṅkhaṃ
analyzed: pana pañca dvāra āvajjana kusala akusala vipāka sampaṭicchana vasena tayaḥ dhammā ati saṅkham
translated: as registration at the five doors, and as profitable, unprofitable, and functional.🔽The mental-data element is reckoned as twenty ideas,

original: gacchati. Dhammadhātu tiṇṇaṃ arūpakkhandhānaṃ soḷasannaṃ sukhumarūpānaṃ asaṅkhatāya🔽ca dhātuyā vasena vīsati dhammāti saṅkhaṃ gacchati. Manoviññāṇadhātu sesakusalākusalābyākataviññāṇavasena
analyzed: gacchati dhammadhātu tiṇṇam arūpa khandhānam soḷasannam sukhuma rūpānam asaṅkhatāya  ca dhātuyāḥ vasena vīsati dhammā ati saṅkham gacchati manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu sesa kusala akusala abyākata viññāṇa vasena
translated: as the three immaterial aggregates, the sixteen kinds of subtle materiality, and the unformed element.🔽The mind-consciousness element is reckoned as seventy-six ideas,

original: chasattati dhammāti saṅkhaṃ gacchati. Evamettha saṅkhatopi veditabbo vinicchayo.🔽523. Paccayāti ettha ca cakkhudhātu tāva cakkhuviññāṇadhātuyā vippayuttapurejātaatthiavigatanissayindriyapaccayānaṃ
analyzed: saṅkham gacchati evam ettha veditabbaḥ vinicchayaḥ  paccayā ti ettha ca cakkhu dhātu tāva cakkhu viññāṇa dhātuyāḥ vippayutta purejāta atthi avigata nissaya indriya paccayānaṃ
translated: as the remaining kinds of consciousness, profitable, unprofitable, and indeterminate. This is how the exposition should be known here as to the formed.🔽As to condition: here the eye element is a condition for the eye-consciousness element in six ways, as proximity, prenascence, postnascence, nutriment, faculty, and presence conditions.

original: vasena chahi paccayehi paccayo hoti, rūpadhātu purejātaatthiavigatārammaṇapaccayānaṃ
analyzed: vasena chahi paccayehi paccayaḥ hoti rūpa dhātu purejāta atthi avigata ārammaṇa paccayānam
translated: The visible-data element is a condition for it in four ways, as prenascence, presence, object, and decisive-support conditions.

original: vasena catūhi paccayehi paccayo hoti. Evaṃ sotaviññāṇadhātuādīnaṃ sotadhātusaddadhātuādayo.🔽Pañcannaṃ pana nesaṃ āvajjanamanodhātu anantarasamanantaranatthivigatānantarūpanissayavasena
analyzed: vasena catūhi paccayehi paccayaḥ hoti evam sota viññāṇa dhātu ādīnam sota dhātu sadda dhātu ādayo  pañcannam pana āvajjana manaḥ dhātu anantara samanantara natthi vigata ananta rūpa nissaya vasena
translated: It is a condition for the four kinds of consciousness by means of the four conditions. So too with the ear-element, sound-element, etc.,🔽But the adverting mind-element is a condition for the five by means of five conditions, that is to say, by means of proximity, contiguity, absence, disappearance, and support conditions.

original: pañcahi paccayehi paccayo hoti, tā ca pañcapi sampaṭicchanamanodhātuyā. Tathā sampaṭicchanamanodhātu
analyzed: pañcahi paccayehi paccayaḥ hoti tā ca sampaṭicchana manaḥ dhātuyā tathā sampaṭicchana manaḥ dhātu
translated: And the five are conditions for the receiving mind-element in the same way. So too the receiving mind-element

original: santīraṇamanoviññāṇadhātuyā, sā ca voṭṭhabbanamanoviññāṇadhātuyā, voṭṭhabbanamanoviññāṇadhātu
analyzed: santīraṇa manaḥ viññāṇa dhātuyā sā ca voṭṭhabbana manaḥ viññāṇa dhātuyā voṭṭhabbana manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu
translated: is for the investigating mind-consciousness element, and that is for the determining mind-consciousness element, and the determining mind-consciousness element

original: ca javanamanoviññāṇadhātuyā. Javanamanoviññāṇadhātu pana anantarāya javanamanoviññāṇadhātuyā
analyzed: ca javana manaḥ viññāṇa dhātuyā javana manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu pana anantarāya javana manaḥ viññāṇa dhātuyā
translated: is for the impulsion mind-consciousness element. But the impulsion mind-consciousness element is a condition for the impulsion mind-consciousness element that follows it

original: tehi ceva pañcahi āsevanapaccayena cāti chahi paccayehi paccayo hoti. Esa tāva pañcadvāre nayo.
analyzed: tehi ca iva pañcahi āsevana paccayena ca ati chahi paccayehi paccayaḥ hoti esa tāva pañca dvāre nayo
translated: by means of those five and by means of the repetition condition, that is to say, by means of six conditions. This is the method in the case of the five doors.

original: Manodvāre pana bhavaṅgamanoviññāṇadhātu āvajjanamanoviññāṇadhātuyā. Āvajjanamanoviññāṇadhātu
analyzed: manaḥ dvāre pana bhavaṅga manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu āvajjana manaḥ viññāṇa dhātuyāḥ āvajjana manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu
translated: But in the case of the mind door the life-continuum mind-consciousness element is a condition for the adverting mind-consciousness element. The adverting mind-consciousness element

original: ca javanamanoviññāṇadhātuyā purimehi pañcahi paccayehi paccayo hoti. Dhammadhātu🔽pana sattannampi viññāṇadhātūnaṃ sahajātaaññamaññanissayasampayuttaatthiavigatādīhi
analyzed: ca javana manaḥ viññāṇa dhātuyāḥ purimehi pañcahi paccayehi paccayaḥ hoti dhammadhātu  pana sattannam pi viññāṇa dhātūnam sahajāta aññamañña nissaya sampayutta atthi avigata ādīhi
translated: And the mind-element is a condition for the javana mind-consciousness element by means of the first five conditions.

original: bahudhā paccayo hoti. Cakkhudhātuādayo pana ekaccā ca dhammadhātu ekaccāya manoviññāṇadhātuyā
analyzed: bahudhā paccayaḥ hoti cakkhu dhātu ādayaḥ pana ekaccā ca dhammadhātu ekaccāya manaḥ viññāṇa dhātuyā
translated: But the mental-data element is a condition in many ways, namely, by conascence, mutuality, support, association, presence, non- disappearance, root, faculty, and object conditions, for the seven consciousness elements.

original: ārammaṇapaccayādīhipi paccayā honti. Cakkhuviññāṇadhātuādīnañca na kevalaṃ cakkhurūpādayo🔽paccayā honti, atha kho ālokādayopi. Tenāhu pubbācariyā –
analyzed: ārammaṇa paccaya ādīhi pi paccayāḥ honti cakkhu viññāṇa dhātu ādīnam ca na kevalam cakkhu rūpa ādayo  paccayāḥ honti atha kho āloka ādayaḥ api tena āhu pubba ācariyā
translated: But the eye element and some of the mental-data element are a condition by way of object condition, etc., for some of the mind-consciousness element.🔽And for the eye-consciousness element, etc., eye and visible data, etc., are not the only conditions; light, etc., are also conditions. Hence the former teachers have said:

original: “Cakkhurūpālokamanasikāre paṭicca uppajjati cakkhuviññāṇaṃ. Sotasaddavivaramanasikāre🔽paṭicca uppajjati sotaviññāṇaṃ. Ghānagandhavāyumanasikāre paṭicca uppajjati ghānaviññāṇaṃ.
analyzed: cakkhu rūpa āloka manasikāre paṭicca uppajjati cakkhu viññāṇam sota sadda vivara manasikāre  paṭicca uppajjati sota viññāṇam ghāna gandha vāyu manasikāre paṭicca uppajjati ghāna viññāṇam
translated: “Eye-consciousness arises with eye and visible data and attention.🔽Ear-consciousness arises with ear and sound and attention.🔽Nose-consciousness arises with nose and odour and air and attention.

original: Jivhārasaāpamanasikāre paṭicca uppajjati jivhāviññāṇaṃ. Kāyaphoṭṭhabbapathavīmanasikāre
analyzed: jivhā rasa āpa manasikāre paṭicca uppajjati jivhā viññāṇam kāya phoṭṭhabba pathavī manasikāre
translated: Tongue-consciousness arises with tongue and flavour and water and attention. Body-consciousness arises with body and tangible datum and earth and attention.

original: paṭicca uppajjati kāyaviññāṇaṃ. Bhavaṅgamanadhammamanasikāre paṭicca uppajjati manoviññāṇa”nti.
analyzed: paṭicca uppajjati kāya viññāṇam bhavaṅgamana dhamma manasikāre paṭicca uppajjati manaḥ viññāṇan ti
translated: and bodily consciousness arises in dependence on the eye and forms. And mind-consciousness arises in dependence on the mind and mental objects” .

original: Ayamettha saṅkhepo. Vitthārato pana paccayappabhedo paṭiccasamuppādaniddese āvibhavissatīti evamettha paccayatopi veditabbo vinicchayo.
analyzed: ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ vitthārataḥ pana paccaya ppabhedaḥ paṭiccasamuppāda niddese āvibhavissati iti evam ettha paccayataḥ pi veditabbaḥ vinicchayaḥ
translated: This is the brief treatment. But the analysis of conditions will be given in the Description of Dependent Origination . This is how the exposition should be known here “as to condition.”

original: 524. Daṭṭhabbatoti daṭṭhabbatopettha vinicchayo veditabboti attho. Sabbā eva hi saṅkhatadhātuyo
analyzed: daṭṭhabbato ti daṭṭhabba tā upa ittha vinicchayaḥ veditabbaḥ iti attho sabbāḥ eva hi saṅkhata dhātuyaḥ
translated: As to how to be seen: the meaning is that here the exposition should be known as to how the various kinds of states should be seen. For all formed elements

original: pubbantāparantavivittato dhuvasubhasukhattabhāvasuññato paccayāyattavuttito ca daṭṭhabbā.🔽Visesato panettha bheritalaṃ viya cakkhudhātu daṭṭhabbā, daṇḍo viya rūpadhātu, saddo🔽viya cakkhuviññāṇadhātu. Tathā ādāsatalaṃ viya cakkhudhātu, mukhaṃ viya rūpadhātu,
analyzed: pubbanta aparanta vivittataḥ dhuva subha sukhatta bhāva suññataḥ paccaya āyatta vuttitaḥ ca daṭṭhabbā  visesataḥ pana ittha bheri talam viya cakkhu dhātu daṭṭhabbā daṇḍaḥ viya rūpa dhātu saddo  viya cakkhu viññāṇa dhātu tathā ādāsa talam viya cakkhu dhātu mukham viya rūpa dhātu
translated: should be seen as devoid of past and future, as void of any self or pleasure or beauty, and as existing only by dependence on conditions.🔽And in particular here the eye element should be seen as a drum skin, the form element as a drumstick, and eye-consciousness element as the sound

original: mukhanimittaṃ viya cakkhuviññāṇadhātu. Atha vā ucchutilā viya cakkhudhātu, yantacakkayaṭṭhi
analyzed: mukha nimittam viya cakkhu viññāṇa dhātu atha vā ucchuti lā viya cakkhu dhātu
translated: of the drum. Likewise the eye element should be seen as a looking glass, the form element as a face, and eye-consciousness element as the reflection of the face. Or the eye element should be seen as a lamp, the form element as the object, and eye-consciousness element as the perception of the object. Or the eye element should be seen as a dog’s mouth, the form element as a bone, and eye-consciousness element as the dog’s desire to eat the bone.

original: viya rūpadhātu, ucchurasatelāni viya cakkhuviññāṇadhātu. Tathā adharāraṇī viya cakkhudhātu,
analyzed: viya rūpa dhātu ucchu rasa telāni viya cakkhu viññāṇa dhātu tathā adharāraṇī viya cakkhu dhātu
translated: the visible-data base is like the fire-sticks, and eye-consciousness is like the sparks.🔽So too, the eye base is like the lower fire-stick,

original: uttarāraṇī viya rūpadhātu, aggi viya cakkhuviññāṇadhātu. Esa nayo sotadhātuādīsu.
analyzed: uttarāraṇī viya rūpa dhātu aggi viya cakkhu viññāṇa dhātu esa nayo sota dhātu ādīsu
translated: the visible-data base is like the upper fire-stick, and eye-consciousness is like the fire. The same method applies in the case of the ear base, and so on.
