translated: By the loss of one’s wisdom,🔽By the loss of one’s freedom,🔽By the loss of one’s good name,🔽By the loss of one’s judgment,🔽By the loss of one’s reason,

original: “Pappoti dukkhaṃ yaṃ macco, kāyikaṃ mānasaṃ tathā;
analyzed: pappoti dukkham yam macco kāyikam mānasam tathā
translated: By the loss of one’s life,🔽By the loss of one’s faith,🔽By the loss of one’s energy,🔽By the loss of one’s mindfulness,🔽By the loss of one’s concentration,🔽By the loss of one’s wisdom,🔽By the loss of one’s good qualities,

original: Sabbametaṃ jarāhetu, yasmā tasmā jarā dukhā”ti.
analyzed: sabbam etam jarā hetu yasmai tasmai jarā
translated: By the loss of one’s good name,🔽By the loss of one’s freedom,🔽By the loss of one’s judgment,🔽By the loss of one’s reason,

original: Ayaṃ jarāyaṃ vinicchayo.
analyzed: ayam jarā ayam
translated: By the loss of one’s life,🔽By the loss of one’s wealth,🔽By the loss of one’s wife and children,🔽By the loss of one’s virtue,🔽By the loss of one’s wisdom,

original: Maraṇaniddeso
analyzed: maraṇa niddeso
translated: By the loss of one’s freedom,🔽By the loss of one’s good name,🔽By the loss of one’s judgment,🔽By the loss of one’s reason,

original: 543. Maraṇampi dukkhanti etthāpi duvidhaṃ maraṇaṃ saṅkhatalakkhaṇañca, yaṃ sandhāya
analyzed: maraṇam pi dukkhanti ettha api duvidham maraṇam saṅkhata lakkhaṇam ca yam sandhāya
translated: By the loss of one’s life,🔽By the loss of one’s wealth,🔽By the loss of one’s wife and children,🔽By the loss of one’s virtue,🔽By the loss of one’s wisdom,🔽By the loss of one’s freedom,🔽By the loss of one’s good name,

original: vuttaṃ “jarāmaraṇaṃ dvīhi khandhehi saṅgahita”nti. Ekabhavapariyāpannajīvitindriyappabandhavicchedo
analyzed: vuttam jarā maraṇam dvīhi khandhehi saṅgahitanti eka bhava pariyāpanna jīvitindriya ppabandha vicchedo
translated: and it is said that aging-and-death is included in two aggregates.

original: ca, yaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ “niccaṃ maraṇato bhaya”nti. Taṃ idha adhippetaṃ. Jātipaccayā
analyzed: ca yam sandhāya vuttam niccam maraṇataḥ bhayanti tam idha adhippetam jāti paccayā
translated: The severance of the continuity of the life faculty included in a single becoming is what is intended here, and it is said: “There is constant danger of death” .

original: maraṇaṃ upakkamamaraṇaṃ sarasamaraṇaṃ āyukkhayamaraṇaṃ puññakkhayamaraṇantipi tasseva🔽nāmaṃ. Tayidaṃ cutilakkhaṇaṃ, viyogarasaṃ, gativippavāsapaccupaṭṭhānaṃ. Dukkhassa
analyzed: maraṇam upakkama maraṇam sa rasa maraṇam āyu kkhaya maraṇam puñña kkhaya maraṇam ti pi tassa iva  nāmam tayā idam cuti lakkhaṇam viyoga rasam gati vippavāsa paccupaṭṭhānam dukkhassa
translated: The cause of death is called birth, and it is also called “death due to violence,” “natural death,” “death from exhaustion of life span,” and “death from exhaustion of merit.”

original: pana vatthubhāvato dukkhanti veditabbaṃ. Tenetaṃ vuccati –
analyzed: pana vatthu bhāvataḥ dukkhanti veditabbam tena itam vuccati
translated: It has the characteristic of falling away; its function is to separate; it is manifested as the departure of the various kinds of existence. It should be understood as suffering because it is the basis for suffering. Hence it is said:

original: “Pāpassa pāpakammādi-nimittamanupassato;
analyzed: pāpassa pāpa kamma ādi nimittam anupassataḥ
translated: “When he contemplates the sign of evil, evil kamma and so on,

original: Bhaddassāpasahantassa, viyogaṃ piyavatthukaṃ;
analyzed: bhaddassa apasahantassa viyogam piya vatthukam
translated: And when he cannot bear the separation that has as its object the loved one,

original: Mīyamānassa yaṃ dukkhaṃ, mānasaṃ avisesato.
analyzed: mīyamānassa yam dukkham mānasam avisesato
translated: The suffering that arises in the mind, without distinction, when one is dying,

original: Sabbesañcāpi yaṃ sandhi-bandhanacchedanādikaṃ;🔽Vitujjamānamammānaṃ, hoti dukkhaṃ sarīrajaṃ.
analyzed: yam sandhibandhana chedana ādikam  vitujjamāna mammānam hoti dukkham sarīra jam
translated: And the suffering that arises in the body, when one’s limbs are cut off, and so on,🔽Because one’s self is being destroyed, and one cannot retaliate,

original: Asayhamappatikāraṃ, dukkhassetassidaṃ yato;
analyzed: asayham appatikāram dukkhassa itassidam yatas
translated: Since this is the basis for suffering,

original: Maraṇaṃ vatthu tenetaṃ, dukkhamicceva bhāsita”nti.
analyzed: maraṇam vatthu tena itam dukkham iccā iva bhāsitanti
translated: So it is rightly called a suffering.

original: Ayaṃ maraṇe vinicchayo.🔽Sokādiniddesā
analyzed: ayam maraṇe  soka ādi niddesā
translated: This is the exposition of death.

original: 544. Sokādīsu soko nāma ñātibyasanādīhi phuṭṭhassa cittasantāpo. So kiñcāpi atthato
analyzed: soka ādīsu sokaḥ nāma ñāti byasana ādīhi phuṭṭhassa citta santāpaḥ so kiñcā api atthato
translated: In the case of sorrow and so on, sorrow is the grief in one who has met with misfortune such as the loss of a relative, etc. Although in meaning it is just grief,

original: domanassameva hoti. Evaṃ santepi antonijjhānalakkhaṇo, cetaso parijjhāpanaraso, anusocanapaccupaṭṭhāno.
analyzed: domanassam eva hoti evam sante pi antar nijjhāna lakkhaṇaḥ cetaso parijjhāpana rasaḥ anusocana paccupaṭṭhāno
translated: nevertheless it has the characteristic of inward burning, the function of consuming the heart, and manifestation as continued grieving.

original: Dukkho pana dukkhadukkhato dukkhavatthuto ca. Tenetaṃ vuccati –
analyzed: dukkhaḥ pana dukkha dukkhataḥ dukkha vatthutaḥ ca tena itam vuccati
translated: It is suffering because it is suffering due to pain and because it is a basis for suffering. Hence it is said:🔽Sorrow in beings’ hearts

original: “Sattānaṃ hadayaṃ soko, visasallaṃva tujjati;
analyzed: hadayam sokaḥ tujjati
translated: Like poison stabs and stings;🔽Like a red-hot iron dart

original: Aggitattova nārāco, bhusaṃva dahate puna.
analyzed: aggi tattā uva nārācaḥ dahate puna
translated: It burns and burns again.🔽And it is said to be the cause

original: “Samāvahati ca byādhi-jarāmaraṇabhedanaṃ;
analyzed: samāvahati ca byādhi jarā maraṇa bhedanam
translated: Of sickness, age, and death;🔽And since it is the source of many a kind of pain,

original: Dukkhampi vividhaṃ yasmā, tasmā dukkhoti vuccatī”ti.
analyzed: dukkham pi vividham yasmā tasmā dukkhā iti vuccati iti
translated: It is called sorrow too.

original: Ayaṃ soke vinicchayo.🔽Paridevo
analyzed: ayam soke  paridevaḥ
translated: This is the exposition of sorrow.

original: 545. Paridevo nāma ñātibyasanādīhi phuṭṭhassa vacīpalāpo. So lālappanalakkhaṇo, guṇadosakittanaraso,
analyzed: paridevaḥ nāma ñāti byasana ādīhi phuṭṭhassa vacī palāpaḥ saḥ lālappana lakkhaṇaḥ guṇa dosa kittana raso
translated: Wailing is the lamentation of one who has met with misfortune such as the loss of a relative, etc. It has the characteristic of moaning, the function of expressing one’s virtues and faults, or

original: sambhamapaccupaṭṭhāno. Dukkho pana saṅkhāradukkhabhāvato dukkhavatthuto ca. Tenetaṃ vuccati –
analyzed: sambhama paccupaṭṭhānaḥ dukkhaḥ pana saṅkhāra dukkha bhāvataḥ dukkha vatthutaḥ ca tena itam vuccati
translated: and it is manifested as the state of being a condition for sorrow. But it is painful because of the pain of formations and because it is a basis for pain. Hence it is said:

original: “Yaṃ sokasallavihato paridevamāno,
analyzed: yam soka salla vihataḥ paridevamānaḥ
translated: “When one, struck down by the dart of sorrow, is lamenting,

original: Kaṇṭhoṭṭhatālutalasosajamappasayhaṃ;
analyzed: kaṇṭha uṭṭha tālu tala sosa jam appa sayham
translated: And, with throat, lips, and palate dry, is weeping,

original: Bhiyyodhimattamadhigacchatiyeva dukkhaṃ,
analyzed: bhiyyaḥ udhimattam adhigacchatiyā iva dukkham
translated: One’s pain is increased beyond measure;

original: Dukkhoti tena bhagavā paridevamāhā”ti.
analyzed: dukkhā ti tena bhagavā paridevam āha ati
translated: Therefore the Blessed One said ‘lamentation is pain.’

original: Ayaṃ parideve vinicchayo.
analyzed: ayam parideve vinicchayaḥ
translated: This is the exposition of ‘lamentation.’

original: Dukkhaṃ
analyzed: dukkham
translated: Pain

original: 546. Dukkhaṃ nāma kāyikaṃ dukkhaṃ, taṃ kāyapīḷanalakkhaṇaṃ, duppaññānaṃ domanassakaraṇarasaṃ,
analyzed: dukkham nāma kāyikam dukkham tam kāya pīḷana lakkhaṇam duppaññānam domanassa karaṇa rasam
translated: Pain is bodily pain. Its characteristic is the tormenting of the body. Its function is to cause grief in the ignorant.

original: kāyikābādhapaccupaṭṭhānaṃ. Dukkhaṃ pana dukkhadukkhato mānasadukkhāvahanato ca. Tenetaṃ vuccati –
analyzed: kāyika ābādha paccupaṭṭhānam dukkham pana dukkha dukkhato mānasa dukkha āvahanato ca tena itam vuccati
translated: It is manifested as bodily affliction. But it is pain because of the pain of pain and because it causes mental pain. Hence it is said:

original: “Pīḷeti kāyikamidaṃ, dukkhañca mānasaṃ bhiyyo;
analyzed: pīḷeti kāyikam idam dukkham ca mānasam bhiyyas
translated: “This bodily pain and mental pain in excess,🔽Because it generates, therefore it is said

original: Janayati yasmā tasmā, dukkhanti visesato vutta”nti.
analyzed: janayati yasmā tasmā dukkhanti visesataḥ vuttanti
translated: To be pain in particular.”

original: Ayaṃ dukkhe vinicchayo.
analyzed: ayam dukkhe vinicchayaḥ
translated: This is the exposition of ‘pain.’

original: Domanassaṃ
analyzed: domanassam
translated: Sorrow

original: 547. Domanassaṃ nāma mānasaṃ dukkhaṃ. Taṃ cittapīḷanalakkhaṇaṃ, manovighātarasaṃ,
analyzed: domanassam nāma mānasam dukkham tam citta pīḷana lakkhaṇam manaḥ vighāta rasam
translated: Sorrow is mental pain. Its characteristic is the tormenting of consciousness. Its function is to afflict the mind.

original: mānasabyādhipaccupaṭṭhānaṃ. Dukkhaṃ pana dukkhadukkhato kāyikadukkhāvahanato ca.
analyzed: mānasa byādhi paccupaṭṭhānam dukkham pana dukkha dukkhato kāyika dukkha āvahanato ca
translated: and it is manifested as mental affliction. But it is painful in the sense of painfulness of pain and in the sense of causing bodily pain.

original: Cetodukkhasamappitā hi kese pakiriya kandanti, urāni paṭipisanti, āvaṭṭanti, vivaṭṭanti,
analyzed: cetaḥ dukkha samappitāḥ hi kese pakiriya kandanti urāni paṭipisanti āvaṭṭanti vivaṭṭanti
translated: For when the mind is afflicted with grief people tear their hair, weep, beat their breasts, roll to and fro,🔽throw dust on their bodies, go without food, lie on the bare ground, take to a path of perversity,

original: uddhaṃpādaṃ papatanti, satthaṃ āharanti, visaṃ khādanti, rajjuyā ubbandhanti, aggiṃ
analyzed: uddhaṃpādam papatanti sattham āharanti visam khādanti rajjuyā ubbandhanti aggim
translated: take poison, hang themselves with a rope, throw themselves off a cliff,

original: pavisantīti taṃ nānappakārakaṃ dukkhamanubhavanti. Tenetaṃ vuccati –
analyzed: pavisanti iti tam nānā ppakārakam dukkham anubhavanti tena itam vuccati
translated: or enter a fire. So they experience pain in various ways. Hence it is said:

original: “Pīḷeti yato cittaṃ, kāyassa ca pīḷanaṃ samāvahati;
analyzed: pīḷeti yatas cittam kāyassa ca pīḷanam samāvahati
translated: “Because it afflicts the mind, And because it brings affliction to the body,

original: Dukkhanti domanassaṃ, vidomanassā tato āhū”ti.
analyzed: dukkhanti domanassam vidomanassā tatas
translated: Grief is pain; and what is without grief Is said to be without pain.”

original: Ayaṃ domanasse vinicchayo.
analyzed: ayam domanasse vinicchayaḥ
translated: This is the exposition of grief.

original: Upāyāso
analyzed: upāyāsaḥ
translated: Vexation

original: 548. Upāyāso nāma ñātibyasanādīhi phuṭṭhassa adhimattacetodukkhappabhāvito dosoyeva.
analyzed: upāyāsaḥ nāma ñāti byasana ādīhi phuṭṭhassa adhimatta cetaḥ dukkha ppabhāvito
translated: Vexation is hate itself, which is manifested as excessive mental pain in one who has met with the loss of relatives, etc.,

original: Saṅkhārakkhandhapariyāpanno eko dhammoti eke. So cittaparidahanalakkhaṇo, nitthunanaraso,
analyzed: saṅkhāra kkhandha pariyāpannaḥ ekaḥ dhammaḥ ti eke so citta paridahana lakkhaṇaḥ nitthunana rasaḥ
translated: Some say that it is a single state, namely, the aggregate of mental formations. It has the characteristic of burning the mind. Its function is to make one shrivel up. Its manifestation is to be found in the state of one who is vexed.

original: visādapaccupaṭṭhāno. Dukkho pana saṅkhāradukkhabhāvato cittaparidahanato kāyavisādanato
analyzed: visāda paccupaṭṭhānaḥ dukkhaḥ pana saṅkhāra dukkha bhāvato citta paridahanato kāya visādanato
translated: It is manifested as depression. But it is painful because of the painfulness of formations, because of the burning of the mind, and because of the depression of the body.

original: ca. Tenetaṃ vuccati –
analyzed: ca tena itam vuccati
translated: Hence it is said:🔽“Because of the burning of the mind,

original: “Cittassa ca paridahanā, kāyassa visādanā ca adhimattaṃ;
analyzed: cittassa ca paridahanā kāyassa visādanā ca adhimattam
translated: And the depression of the body,🔽The pain that is the outcome of seeking,

original: Yaṃ dukkhamupāyāso, janeti dukkho tato vutto”ti.
analyzed: yam dukkham upāyāsaḥ janeti dukkho tatas vuttaḥ ti
translated: Is said to be painfulness” .

original: Ayaṃ upāyāse vinicchayo.🔽Ettha ca mandagginā antobhājane pāko viya soko. Tikkhagginā paccamānassa bhājanato🔽bahinikkhamanaṃ viya paridevo. Bahinikkhantāvasesassa nikkhamituṃ appahontassa antobhājaneyeva
analyzed: ayam upāyāse  ettha ca mandagginā antobhājane pākaḥ viya sokaḥ tikkhagginā paccamānassa bhājanato  bahi nikkhamanam viya paridevaḥ bahi nikkhanta avasesassa nikkhamitum
translated: This is the exposition of seeking.

original: yāva parikkhayā pāko viya upāyāso daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: yāva parikkhayā pākaḥ viya upāyāsaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: And here grief is like the cooking in the pot over the mild fire; lamentation is like the overflow of the cooking liquid from the pot because of the intensity of the cooking; and seeking is like the cooking until exhaustion of the remainder of the liquid that has overflowed and is unable to overflow any more because there is no more pot.

original: Appiyasampayogo
analyzed: appiya sampayogaḥ
translated: Contact with the unloved

original: 549. Appiyasampayogo nāma amanāpehi sattasaṅkhārehi samodhānaṃ. So aniṭṭhasamodhānalakkhaṇo,
analyzed: appiya sampayogaḥ nāma amanāpehi satta saṅkhārehi samodhānam so aniṭṭha samodhāna lakkhaṇo
translated: Contact with the unloved is the association with what is unwanted, with living beings and with formations. It has the characteristic of association with what is unloved.

original: cittavighātakaraṇaraso, anatthabhāvapaccupaṭṭhāno. Dukkho pana dukkhavatthuto. Tenetaṃ vuccati –
analyzed: citta vighāta karaṇa rasaḥ anattha bhāva paccupaṭṭhāno dukkhaḥ pana dukkha vatthutaḥ tena itam vuccati
translated: Its function is to afflict the mind. It is manifested as misfortune. But it is painful because it is a basis for pain. Hence it is said:

original: “Disvāva appiye dukkhaṃ, paṭhamaṃ hoti cetasi;
analyzed: disvāva appiye dukkham paṭhamam hoti cetasi
translated: “Seeing the painful, first there is pain in the mind,

original: Tadupakkamasambhūta-mathakāye yato idha.
analyzed: tad upakkama sambhūta matha kāye yatas
translated: And then in the body born of that, here.

original: “Tato dukkhadvayassāpi, vatthuto so mahesinā;
analyzed: tatas dukkha dvayassa api vatthutaḥ saḥ mahesinā
translated: “Therefore, the Great Sage said that the painful🔽Is the meeting with the unloved,

original: Dukkho vuttoti viññeyyo, appiyehi samāgamo”ti.
analyzed: dukkhaḥ vuttaḥ ti viññeyyaḥ appiyehi samāgamaḥ ti
translated: From the source of the twofold pain.”

original: Ayaṃ appiyasampayoge vinicchayo.
analyzed: ayam appiya sampayoge vinicchayaḥ
translated: This is the exposition of the meeting with the unloved.

original: Piyavippayogo
analyzed: piya vippayogaḥ
translated: The Unloved Meeting with the Unloved

original: 550. Piyavippayogo nāma manāpehi sattasaṅkhārehi vinābhāvo. So iṭṭhavatthuviyogalakkhaṇo,
analyzed: piya vippayogaḥ nāma manāpehi satta saṅkhārehi vinābhāvo saḥ iṭṭha vatthu viyoga lakkhaṇo
translated: The unloved meeting with the unloved is the non-possession of unlovely formations. It is characterized as the separation from a desirable object.

original: sokuppādanaraso, byasanapaccupaṭṭhāno. Dukkho pana sokadukkhassa vatthuto. Tenetaṃ vuccati –
analyzed: soka uppādana rasaḥ byasana paccupaṭṭhāno dukkhaḥ pana soka dukkhassa vatthutaḥ tena itam vuccati
translated: Its function is to cause sorrow. It is manifested as misfortune. But it is painful because it is the source of the pain of sorrow. Hence it is said:

original: “Ñātidhanādiviyogā,🔽Sokasarasamappitā vitujjanti;🔽Bālā yato tato yaṃ,
analyzed: ñāti dhana ādi viyogā  soka sarasam appitāḥ vitujjanti  bālāḥ tatas yam
translated: “From the separation of relatives, wealth, etc.,🔽The foolish are drenched with the essence of sorrow, and they are scattered in all directions.🔽Therefore, the unloved meeting with the unloved

original: Dukkhoti mato piyavippayogo”ti.
analyzed: dukkhaḥ ti mataḥ piya vippayogaḥ ti
translated: Is considered painful.”

original: Ayaṃ piyavippayoge vinicchayo.🔽Icchitālābho
analyzed: ayam piya vippayoge vinicchayo  icchita alābho
translated: This is the exposition of the unloved meeting with the unloved.🔽The Non-Attainment of the Desired

original: 551. Yampicchaṃ na labhatīti ettha “aho vata mayaṃ na jātidhammā assāmā”tiādīsu alabbhaneyyavatthūsu
analyzed: yam piccham na labhati iti ettha aho vata mayam na jāti dhammāḥ assāma ati ādīsu alabbhaneyya vatthūsu
translated: As to the non-attainment of the desired, the desired is the desirable. The non-attainment of the desired is the non-possession of the desirable. It is characterized as the non-attainment of a desirable object.

original: icchāva yampicchaṃ na labhati, tampi dukkhanti vuttā. Sā alabbhaneyyavatthuicchanalakkhaṇā,
analyzed: icchāva yam piccham na labhati tam pi dukkhanti vuttā sā alabbhaneyya vatthu icchana lakkhaṇā
translated: and what one wants but does not get is suffering too. It has the characteristic of wanting what is unobtainable.

original: tappariyesanarasā, tesaṃ appattipaccupaṭṭhānā. Dukkhā pana dukkhavatthuto. Tenetaṃ vuccati –
analyzed: tad pariyesana rasā tesam appatti paccupaṭṭhānā dukkhā pana dukkha vatthutaḥ tena itam vuccati
translated: Its function is to seek that. It is manifested as the non-attainment of those things. But it is suffering because of the suffering of suffering. Hence it is said:

original: “Taṃ taṃ patthayamānānaṃ, tassa tassa alābhato;
analyzed: tam tam patthayamānānam tassa tassa alābhato
translated: “Because of not getting what they want,🔽Beings here are subject to frustration,

original: Yaṃ vighātamayaṃ dukkhaṃ, sattānaṃ idha jāyati.
analyzed: yam vighāta mayam dukkham sattānam idha jāyati
translated: Which is suffering born of suffering.🔽“The cause of that is wanting

original: “Alabbhaneyyavatthūnaṃ, patthanā tassa kāraṇaṃ;
analyzed: a labbha neyya vatthūnam patthanā tassa kāraṇam
translated: What is unobtainable. Therefore the Jina said

original: Yasmā tasmā jino dukkhaṃ, icchitālābhamabravī”ti.
analyzed: yasmai tasmai jinaḥ dukkham icchita lābham abravīti
translated: That suffering is the want of what is unobtainable.”

original: Ayaṃ icchitālābhe vinicchayo.
analyzed: ayam icchitā lābhe
translated: This is the exposition of the want of what is unobtainable.

original: Pañcupādānakkhandhā
analyzed: pañca upādānakkhandhāḥ
translated: The five aggregates as objects of clinging

original: 552. Saṃkhittena pañcupādānakkhandhā dukkhāti ettha pana –
analyzed: saṃkhittena pañca upādānakkhandhāḥ dukkhā ti ettha pana
translated: . In brief, the five aggregates as objects of clinging are suffering. Herein,🔽The suffering beginning with birth,

original: Jātippabhutikaṃ dukkhaṃ, yaṃ vuttamidha tādinā;
analyzed: jāti ppabhutikam dukkham yam vuttam idha tādinā
translated: Which the Peerless One has taught,🔽And all that has not been taught

original: Avuttaṃ yañca taṃ sabbaṃ, vinā ete na vijjati.
analyzed: avuttam yat ca tam sabbam vinā ete na vijjati
translated: Cannot exist without these.

original: Yasmā tasmā upādāna-kkhandhā saṅkhepato ime;
analyzed: yasmai tasmai upādāna khandhā saṅkhepataḥ ime
translated: Therefore these aggregates as objects of clinging🔽Are said to be suffering in brief

original: Dukkhāti vuttā dukkhanta-desakena mahesinā.
analyzed: dukkhā ti vuttā dukkhanta desakena mahesinā
translated: By the Great Sage who taught the end of suffering.

original: Tathā hi indhanamiva pāvako, lakkhamiva paharaṇāni, gorūpaṃ viya ḍaṃsamakasādayo,
analyzed: tathā hi indhanam iva pāvakaḥ lakkham iva paharaṇāni go rūpam viya ḍaṃsa makasa ādayaḥ
translated: For just as fire burns grass, sticks, logs, etc.,🔽just as weapons wound, just as flies, etc., afflict a cow’s hide,

original: khettamiva lāyakā, gāmaṃ viya gāmaghātakā upādānakkhandhapañcakameva jātiādayo nānappakārehi
analyzed: khettam iva lāyakāḥ gāmam viya gāma ghātakāḥ upādāna khandha pañcakam eva jāti ādayaḥ nānappakārehi
translated: just as village-raiders afflict a village, so too, birth, etc., afflict the five aggregates as objects of clinging in various ways.

original: vibādhentā tiṇalatādīni viya bhūmiyaṃ, pupphaphalapallavāni viya rukkhesu upādānakkhandhesuyeva
analyzed: vibādhentā tiṇa latā ādīni viya bhūmiyam puppha phala pallavāni viya rukkhesu upādāna kkhandhesu yeva
translated: They arise in the aggregates as objects of clinging, not elsewhere, just as grass, sticks, logs, etc., arise on the ground, and flowers, fruits, sprouts, etc., arise on trees, etc.

original: nibbattanti. Upādānakkhandhānañca ādidukkhaṃ jāti, majjhedukkhaṃ jarā, pariyosānadukkhaṃ
analyzed: nibbattanti upādāna khandhānaṃ ca ādi dukkham jāti majjhedukkham jarā pariyosāna dukkham
translated: And the aggregates as objects of clinging are subject to suffering in the beginning, in the middle, and in the end. Birth is suffering in the beginning; aging is suffering in the middle; and death is suffering in the end.

original: maraṇaṃ, māraṇantikadukkhābhighātena pariḍayhanadukkhaṃ soko, tadasahanato lālappanadukkhaṃ
analyzed: maraṇam māraṇa antika dukkha abhighātena pariḍayhana dukkham sokaḥ tad asahanataḥ lālappana dukkham
translated: Sorrow is the suffering of being scorched by the grief that arises when death is near. Lamentation is the suffering of the cries that arise because of the inability to bear the grief.

original: paridevo, tato dhātukkhobhasaṅkhātaaniṭṭhaphoṭṭhabbasamāyogato kāyassa ābādhanadukkhaṃ
analyzed: paridevaḥ tatas dhātu kkhobha saṅkhāta aniṭṭha phoṭṭhabba samāyogataḥ kāyassa ābādhana dukkham
translated: Pain is the suffering of the affliction of the body that arises through the contact of disagreeable mental objects with the physical body.

original: dukkhaṃ, tena bādhiyamānānaṃ puthujjanānaṃ tattha paṭighuppattito cetobādhanadukkhaṃ
analyzed: dukkham tena bādhiyamānānam puthujjanānam tattha paṭigha uppattitaḥ cetaḥ bādhana dukkham
translated: Grief is the suffering of the affliction of the mind that arises in the case of ordinary people who are afflicted by pain and who experience resistance to it.

original: domanassaṃ, sokādivuddhiyā janitavisādānaṃ anutthunanadukkhaṃ upāyāso, manorathavighātappattānaṃ
analyzed: domanassam soka ādi vuddhiyā janita visādānam an utthunana dukkham upāyāsaḥ manoratha vighāta ppattānam
translated: and the sorrow that arises in those who are depressed by the increase of grief, etc., is the suffering that is due to despair. The suffering that is due to frustration of wishes is the suffering that is due to the frustration of desire.

original: icchāvighātadukkhaṃ icchitālābhoti evaṃ nānappakārato upaparikkhiyamānā upādānakkhandhāva
analyzed: icchā vighāta dukkham icchitā lābhaḥ ti evam nānā pakārataḥ upaparikkhiyamānāḥ upādāna kkhandhāḥ ava
translated: So the aggregates as objects of clinging are suffering in various ways.

original: dukkhāti. Yadetaṃ ekamekaṃ dassetvā vuccamānaṃ anekehipi kappehi na sakkā asesato🔽vattuṃ, tasmā taṃ sabbampi dukkhaṃ ekajalabindumhi sakalasamuddajalarasaṃ viya yesu🔽kesuci pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu saṃkhipitvā dassetuṃ “saṃkhittena pañcupādānakkhandhā
analyzed: dukkhā iti yat etam ekam ekam dassetvā vuccamānam anekehi pi kappehi na sakkā asesataḥ  vattum tasmā tam sabbam pi dukkham eka jala bindumhi sakala samudda jala rasam viya yesu  kesuci pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu saṃkhipitvā dassetum saṃkhittena pañca upādānakkhandhāḥ
translated: And since it is impossible to tell this by pointing to each kind in more than a few instances even in many aeons,

original: dukkhā”ti bhagavā avocāti. Ayaṃ upādānakkhandhesu vinicchayo.🔽Ayaṃ tāva dukkhaniddese nayo.
analyzed: dukkhā ati bhagavā avoca ati ayam upādāna khandhesu vinicchayo  ayam tāva dukkha niddese nayo
translated: the Blessed One therefore included all that suffering in just the five aggregates as objects of clinging, as one does the taste of the whole ocean in a drop of water, and he taught it by the single expression “The five aggregates as objects of clinging are suffering.” This is the exposition of the aggregates as objects of clinging.

original: Samudayaniddesakathā
analyzed: samudaya niddesa kathā
translated: This, firstly, is the method of explanation in the case of the description of suffering.🔽In the case of the description of the origin,🔽in the clause “With craving as condition” , craving is that stated in the way beginning, “With feeling as condition, craving” .

original: 553. Samudayaniddese pana yāyaṃ taṇhāti yā ayaṃ taṇhā. Ponobbhavikāti punabbhavakaraṇaṃ
analyzed: samudaya niddese pana yā ayam taṇhā ati yā ayam taṇhā ponobbhavikā ati punabbhava karaṇam
translated: It is productive of further becoming ;

original: punobbhavo, punobbhavo sīlametissāti ponobbhavikā. Nandīrāgena sahagatāti nandīrāgasahagatā,
analyzed: punobbhavaḥ punobbhavaḥ sīlam etissa ati ponobbhavikā nandī rāgena sahagatā ati nandī rāga sahagatā
translated: and rebirth is the “re-becoming” . “ Associated with delight and greed” : they are associated with delight and greed. The meaning is that they have gone to the same state as delight and greed. “ Approaching and adopting” :

original: nandīrāgena saddhiṃ atthato ekattameva gatāti vuttaṃ hoti. Tatra tatrābhinandinīti🔽yatra yatra attabhāvo nibbattati, tatra tatrābhinandinī. Seyyathidanti nipāto, tassa
analyzed: nandī rāgena saddhim atthataḥ ekattam eva gatā ati vuttam hoti tatra tatra abhinandinī iti  yatra yatra atta bhāvaḥ nibbattati tatra tatra abhinandinī nipātaḥ tassa
translated: approaching and adopting here and there. “ Such as” : this is a particle.

original: sā katamāti ceti attho. Kāmataṇhā bhavataṇhā vibhavataṇhāti imā paṭiccasamuppādaniddese🔽āvibhavissanti. Idha panāyaṃ tividhāpi dukkhasaccassa nibbattakaṭṭhena ekattaṃ upanetvā
analyzed: sā katamā ati ca iti attho kāma taṇhā bhava taṇhā vibhava taṇhā ti imā paṭiccasamuppāda niddese  idha pana ayam tividhā api dukkha saccassa nibbatta kaṭṭhena ekattam upanetvā
translated: The meaning is: “what?” Craving for sense pleasures, craving for becoming, and craving for non-becoming. These will be explained in the exposition of dependent origination.

original: dukkhasamudayaṃ ariyasaccanti vuttāti veditabbā.
analyzed: dukkha samudayam ariya saccan ti vuttā iti veditabbā
translated: But here they should be understood as the truth of the origin of suffering, since they lead to the same state as the truth of suffering by being its producer.

original: Ayaṃ samudayaniddese nayo.
analyzed: ayam samudaya niddese nayo
translated: This is the method of exposition in the case of the truth of the origin.

original: Nirodhaniddesakathā
analyzed: nirodha niddesa kathā
translated: The exposition of the truth of cessation

original: 554. Dukkhanirodhaniddese yo tassāyeva taṇhāyātiādinā nayena samudayanirodho vutto,
analyzed: dukkha nirodha niddese yaḥ tassāya eva taṇhāya ati ādinā nayena samudaya nirodhaḥ vutto
translated: In the exposition of the truth of cessation, the cessation of the origin is stated by the method beginning with “the remainderless fading away and cessation of that same craving.”

original: so kasmāti ce? Samudayanirodhena dukkhanirodho. Samudayanirodhena hi dukkhaṃ nirujjhati,
analyzed: so kasmā ati ce samudaya nirodhena dukkha nirodhaḥ samudaya nirodhena hi dukkham nirujjhati
translated: Why? Because of the cessation of the origin, there is the cessation of suffering. For suffering ceases through the cessation of its origin,

original: na aññathā. Tenāha –
analyzed: na aññathā tena āha
translated: not otherwise. Hence it is said:

original: “Yathāpi mūle anupaddave daḷhe,
analyzed: yathā api mūle anupaddave daḷhe
translated: “As when a tree is cut down,

original: Chinnopi rukkho punadeva rūhati;
analyzed: chinnaḥ api rukkhaḥ punar eva rūhati
translated: If its root is not destroyed, it will grow again;

original: Evampi taṇhānusaye anūhate,
analyzed: evam pi taṇhā anusaye
translated: So it is with this suffering,

original: Nibbattatī dukkhamidaṃ punappuna”nti. ;
analyzed: nibbattatī dukkham idam punappunanti
translated: If the underlying tendency is not destroyed.”

original: Iti yasmā samudayanirodheneva dukkhaṃ nirujjhati, tasmā bhagavā dukkhanirodhaṃ desento
analyzed: iti yasmai samudaya nirodhena iva dukkham nirujjhati tasmai bhagavā dukkha nirodham desento
translated: Thus, since suffering ceases only through the cessation of its origin, the Exalted One, in teaching the cessation of suffering,

original: samudayanirodheneva desesi. Sīhasamānavuttino hi tathāgatā. Te dukkhaṃ nirodhentā
analyzed: samudaya nirodhena iva desesi sīha samāna vuttinaḥ hi tathāgatā te dukkham nirodhentā
translated: taught it through the cessation of its origin. For the Tathāgatas conduct themselves like lions. When they put an end to suffering

original: dukkhanirodhañca desentā hetumhi paṭipajjanti, na phale. Suvānavuttino pana titthiyā.🔽Te dukkhaṃ nirodhentā dukkhanirodhañca desentā attakilamathānuyogadesanādīhi phale🔽paṭipajjanti, na hetumhīti. Evaṃ tāva dukkhanirodhassa samudayanirodhavasena desanāya
analyzed: dukkha nirodhañca desentā hetumhi paṭipajjanti na phale suvāna vuttinaḥ pana titthiyā  te dukkham nirodhentā dukkha nirodhañca desentā atta kilamatha anuyoga desanā ādīhi phale  paṭipajjanti na hetumhi iti evam tāva dukkha nirodhassa samudaya nirodha vasena desanāya
translated: and teach the cessation of suffering, they proceed by way of the cause, not by way of the effect. But the sectarians conduct themselves like dogs.

original: payojanaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: payojanam veditabbam
translated: When they put an end to suffering and teach the cessation of suffering, they proceed by way of the effect, not by way of the cause, through the teaching of self-mortification, etc. This, firstly, is how the purpose of the teaching of the cessation of suffering through the cessation of its origin should be understood.

original: 555. Ayaṃ panattho – tassāyeva taṇhāyāti tassā “ponobbhavikā”ti vatvā kāmataṇhādivasena🔽vibhattataṇhāya. Virāgo vuccati maggo. “Virāgā vimuccatī”ti hi vuttaṃ. Virāgena nirodho
analyzed: ayam pana atthaḥ tassāya eva taṇhāya ati tassā ponobbhavikā iti vatvā kāma taṇhā ādi vasena  vibhatta taṇhāya virāgaḥ vuccati maggaḥ virāgā vimuccati iti hi vuttam virāgena nirodhaḥ
translated: The meaning is this. Of that craving: of that craving already mentioned as “reviving” and then analyzed as sense-desire craving, etc.,

original: virāganirodho. Anusayasamugghātato aseso virāganirodho asesavirāganirodho. Atha vā
analyzed: virāga nirodhaḥ anusaya samugghātataḥ asesaḥ virāga nirodhaḥ asesa virāga nirodhaḥ atha vā
translated: Cessation through fading away of lust is cessation by fading away of lust. Cessation through fading away of lust without remainder is cessation by fading away of lust without remainder. Or alternatively,

original: virāgoti pahānaṃ vuccati, tasmā aseso virāgo aseso nirodhoti evampettha yojanā daṭṭhabbā.
analyzed: virāgaḥ iti pahānam vuccati tasmai asesaḥ virāgaḥ asesaḥ nirodho ti evam pa ittha yojanā daṭṭhabbā
translated: fading away is called abandoning, thus cessation by fading away of lust without remainder is cessation by abandoning of lust without remainder.

original: Atthato pana sabbāneva etāni nibbānassa vevacanāni. Paramatthato hi dukkhanirodho
analyzed: atthataḥ pana sabbāni eva etāni nibbānassa vevacanāni paramatthataḥ hi dukkha nirodho
translated: In the ultimate sense all these are mere synonyms for Nibbāna, for it is Nibbāna that is called “cessation of suffering,”

original: ariyasaccanti nibbānaṃ vuccati. Yasmā pana taṃ āgamma taṇhā virajjati ceva nirujjhati
analyzed: ariya saccanti nibbānam vuccati yasmā pana tam āgamma taṇhā virajjati ca iva nirujjhati
translated: an ariyan truth. But since craving fades away and ceases on arrival at Nibbāna,

original: ca, tasmā virāgoti ca nirodhoti ca vuccati. Yasmā ca tadeva āgamma tassā cāgādayo
analyzed: ca tasmā virāgaḥ ti ca nirodhaḥ ti ca vuccati yasmā ca tat eva āgamma tassā cāga ādayo
translated: it is called “fading away” and “cessation.” And since on arrival at Nibbāna there is the giving up, etc., of that craving,

original: honti, kāmaguṇālayesu cettha ekopi ālayo natthi, tasmā “cāgo paṭinissaggo mutti anālayo”ti vuccati.
analyzed: honti kāma guṇa ālayesu ca ittha ekaḥ api ālayaḥ natthi tasmā cāgaḥ paṭinissaggo mutti anālayaḥ ti vuccati
translated: there is no storing up of any of the five kinds of seeds in the sense-desire element, the element of fine-materiality, the element of immateriality, the element of form, and the formless element, and so it is called “giving up,” “disgorging,” “renunciation,” “non- storing.”

original: 556. Tayidaṃ santilakkhaṇaṃ, accutirasaṃ, assāsakaraṇarasaṃ vā, animittapaccupaṭṭhānaṃ, nippapañcapaccupaṭṭhānaṃ vā.
analyzed: tayidam santi lakkhaṇam accuti rasam assāsa karaṇa rasam vā animitta paccupaṭṭhānam nippapañca paccupaṭṭhānam vā
translated: This serenity has the characteristic of peace; its function is to extinguish, or its function is to comfort; its manifestation is signless or its manifestation is voidness.

original: Nibbānakathā
analyzed: nibbāna kathā
translated: The Discussion of Nibbāna🔽If it be said that “Nibbāna does not exist because it is not found like the hare’s horn,”

original: 557. Nattheva nibbānaṃ, sasavisāṇaṃ viya anupalabbhanīyatoti ce? Na, upāyena upalabbhanīyato.
analyzed: nattha iva nibbānam sa sa visāṇam viya an upalabbhanīya to ti ce na upāyena upalabbhanīyato
translated: then it can be replied that it is found by a method,

original: Upalabbhati hi taṃ tadanurūpapaṭipattisaṅkhātena upāyena, cetopariyañāṇena paresaṃ
analyzed: upalabbhati hi tam tad anurūpa paṭipatti saṅkhātena upāyena cetaḥ pariya ñāṇena paresam
translated: for it is found by a method called the practice that accords with it, by means of the knowledge of penetration of another’s thoughts,

original: lokuttaracittaṃ viya, tasmā “anupalabbhanīyato natthī”ti na vattabbaṃ. Na hi “yaṃ
analyzed: lokuttara cittam viya tasmai anupalabbhanīyataḥ natthi iti na vattabbam na hi yam
translated: like the supramundane consciousness of others. So it should not be said that it does not exist because it is not found.

original: bālaputhujjanā na upalabhanti, taṃ natthī”ti vattabbaṃ.
analyzed: bāla puthujjanāḥ na upalabhanti tat natthi iti vattabbam
translated: For it should not be said that “what fools and ordinary men do not find exists.”🔽Besides, it should not be said that Nibbāna does not exist,

original: 558. Apica nibbānaṃ natthīti na vattabbaṃ, kasmā? Paṭipattiyā vañjhabhāvāpajjanato.
analyzed: apica nibbānam natthi iti na vattabbam kasmā paṭipattiyāḥ vañjha bhāva āpajjanato
translated: because that would imply the futility of the practice.

original: Asati hi nibbāne sammādiṭṭhipurejavāya sīlādikhandhattayasaṅgahāya sammāpaṭipattiyā
analyzed: asati hi nibbāne sammādiṭṭhi purejavāya sīla ādi khandha ttaya saṅgahāya sammā paṭipattiyā
translated: For if Nibbāna did not exist, the right practice consisting of the three aggregates of profitable consciousness headed by right view

original: vañjhabhāvo āpajjati. Na cāyaṃ vañjhā, nibbānapāpanatoti. Na paṭipattiyā vañjhabhāvāpatti,
analyzed: vañjha bhāvaḥ āpajjati na ca ayam vañjhā nibbāna pāpanato ti na paṭipattiyāḥ vañjha bhāva āpatti
translated: would be futile. But it is not futile, because it does lead to Nibbāna.

original: abhāvapāpakattāti ce. Na, atītānāgatābhāvepi nibbānapattiyā abhāvato. Vattamānānampi
analyzed: abhāva pāpaka ttā ti ce na atīta anāgata abhāve pi nibbāna pattiyāḥ abhāvataḥ vattamānānam pi
translated: If you say that it is the non-existence of evil, then no; for there is no non-existence of the attainment of Nibbāna even when the past and future do not exist.

original: abhāvo nibbānanti ce. Na, tesaṃ abhāvāsambhavato, abhāve ca avattamānabhāvāpajjanato,
analyzed: abhāvaḥ nibbānan ti ce na tesam abhāva asambhavataḥ abhāve ca avattamāna bhāva āpajjanato
translated: If you say that the non-existence of what is present is Nibbāna, then no; for that is impossible, and because if it were, then what is not present would be produced.

original: vattamānakkhandhanissitamaggakkhaṇe ca sopādisesanibbānadhātuppattiyā abhāvadosato.
analyzed: vattamāna kkhandha nissita magga kkhaṇe ca sa upādisesa nibbāna dhātu pattiyāḥ abhāva dosato
translated: And because there is no production of the Nibbāna element with residual support at the moment of the path, which is dependent on the present aggregates.

original: Tadā kilesānaṃ avattamānattā na dosoti ce. Na, ariyamaggassa niratthakabhāvāpajjanato.
analyzed: tadā kilesānam avattamāna ttā na doso ti ce na ariya maggassa niratthaka bhāva āpajjanato
translated: If you say that there is no fault because defilements are not present then, then no; because it would follow that the noble path is useless.

original: Evañhi sati ariyamaggakkhaṇato pubbepi kilesā na santīti ariyamaggassa niratthakabhāvo
analyzed: evam hi sati ariya magga kkhaṇato pubbe pi kilesā na santi iti ariya maggassa niratthaka bhāvaḥ
translated: For if it were so, then it would follow that defilements are not present even before the moment of the noble path, and so the noble path is useless.

original: āpajjati. Tasmā akāraṇametaṃ.🔽559. “Yo kho, āvuso, rāgakkhayo”tiādivacanato “khayo nibbāna”nti ce. Na, arahattassāpi
analyzed: āpajjati tasmai akāraṇam etam  yaḥ kho āvuso rāga khayaḥ ti ādi vacanataḥ khayaḥ nibbānan ti ce na arahattassa api
translated: So this is no reason.🔽If you say that Nibbāna is the destruction because of the words, “Friends, the destruction of greed” , then no;

original: khayamattāpajjanato. Tampi hi “yo kho, āvuso, rāgakkhayo”tiādinā nayena niddiṭṭhaṃ.
analyzed: khaya matta āpajjanataḥ tam pi hi yaḥ kho āvuso rāga khayaḥ iti ādinā nayena niddiṭṭham
translated: because it would follow that Arahantship is mere destruction. For that is also demonstrated in the way beginning, “Friends, the destruction of greed” .

original: Kiñca bhiyyo nibbānassa ittarakālādippattidosato. Evañhi sati nibbānaṃ ittarakālaṃ,
analyzed: kiñca bhiyyas nibbānassa ittara kāla ādi ppatti dosataḥ evam hi sati nibbānam ittara kālam
translated: for if it were so, nibbana would be a time-span,🔽it would have the characteristic of the formed,

original: saṅkhatalakkhaṇaṃ, sammāvāyāmanirapekkhādhigamanīyabhāvañca āpajjati. Saṅkhatalakkhaṇattāyeva
analyzed: saṅkhata lakkhaṇam sammāvāyāma nirapekkha adhigamanīya bhāvañca āpajjati saṅkhata lakkhaṇa ttāya iva
translated: and it would be attainable independently of right endeavour. And because it would have the characteristic of the formed,🔽it would be included among formed things,

original: ca saṅkhatapariyāpannaṃ, saṅkhatapariyāpannattā rāgādīhi aggīhi ādittaṃ, ādittattā
analyzed: ca saṅkhata pariyāpannam saṅkhata pariyāpanna ttā rāga ādīhi aggīhi ādittam āditta ttā
translated: and because it would be included among formed things, it would be ablaze with lust, etc.,🔽and it would be suffering.

original: dukkhañcātipi āpajjati. Yasmā khayā paṭṭhāya na bhiyyo pavatti nāma hoti, tassa nibbānabhāvato
analyzed: dukkham ca ati pi āpajjati yasmā khayā paṭṭhāya na bhiyyas pavatti nāma hoti tassa nibbāna bhāvato
translated: If it be said that it is not a fault that nibbana is not a non-recurrence because there is no recurrence after exhaustion,

original: na dosoti ce. Na, tādisassa khayassa abhāvato. Bhāvepi cassa vuttappakāradosānativattanato,
analyzed: na dosaḥ ti ce na tādisassa khayassa abhāvataḥ bhāve pi ca ssa vutta ppakāra dosa anativattanato
translated: no, because there is no such exhaustion, and because even if there were, the faults stated would not be avoided.🔽And because the noble path is what makes nibbana come into being.

original: ariyamaggassa ca nibbānabhāvāpajjanato. Ariyamaggo hi dose khīṇeti, tasmā khayoti
analyzed: ariya maggassa ca nibbāna bhāva āpajjanato ariya maggaḥ hi dose khīṇe ti tasmā
translated: For the noble path is what “exhausts” the defilements, and so it is called “exhaustion” .

original: vuccati. Tato ca paṭṭhāya na bhiyyo dosānaṃ pavattīti.
analyzed: vuccati tatas ca paṭṭhāya na bhiyyas dosānam pavatti iti
translated: And because there is no recurrence of defilements after that,

original: Anuppattinirodhasaṅkhātassa pana khayassa pariyāyena upanissayattā, yassa upanissayo
analyzed: anuppatti nirodha saṅkhātassa pana khayassa pariyāyena upanissaya ttā yassa upanissayaḥ
translated: but because of the conditionality of exhaustion, which is the attainment of cessation,

original: hoti tadupacārena “khayo”ti vuttaṃ. Sarūpeneva kasmā na vuttanti ce. Atisukhumattā.
analyzed: tad upacārena khayaḥ iti vuttam sarūpena iva kasmā na vuttam iti ce ati sukhuma tā
translated: If it be asked, why is it not stated in its own individual essence? —because it is too subtle.

original: Atisukhumatā cassa bhagavato apposukkabhāvāvahanato, ariyena cakkhunā passitabbato ca siddhāti.
analyzed: ati sukhumatā ca ssa bhagavataḥ apposukka bhāva āvahanataḥ ariyena cakkhunā passitabbato ca siddhā ati
translated: And its subtlety is established because it causes no trouble for the Blessed One and because it is to be seen by the noble eye.

original: 560. Tayidaṃ maggasamaṅginā pattabbato asādhāraṇaṃ, purimakoṭiyā abhāvato appabhavaṃ.
analyzed: tayā idam magga samaṅginā pattabbataḥ asādhāraṇam purima koṭiyāḥ abhāvataḥ appabhavam
translated: And this is not shared by others because it is to be attained by one who possesses the path, and it is not a coming into being because it does not exist at the prior limit.

original: Maggabhāve bhāvato na appabhavanti ce. Na, maggena anuppādanīyato. Pattabbameva hetaṃ
analyzed: magga bhāve bhāvataḥ na appabhavanti ce na maggena anuppādanīyataḥ pattabbam eva hetam
translated: If it be said that it is not a non-coming into being because it comes into being in the state of the path, —no; because it is not to be brought into being by the path. For this is only to be attained by the path,

original: maggena, na uppādetabbaṃ. Tasmā appabhavameva. Appabhavattā ajarāmaraṇaṃ. Pabhavajarāmaraṇānaṃ abhāvato niccaṃ.
analyzed: maggena na uppādetabbam tasmai appabhavam eva appabhava ttā ajara amaraṇam abhāvataḥ niccam
translated: not to be brought into being by it. Therefore it is a non-coming into being. And because it is a non-coming into being, it is ageless and deathless. And because there is no coming into being, aging, and death, it is permanent.

original: Nibbānasseva aṇuādīnampi niccabhāvāpattīti ce. Na, hetuno abhāvā. Nibbānassa niccattā
analyzed: nibbānassa iva aṇu ādīnam pi nicca bhāva āpatti iti ce na hetunaḥ abhāvā nibbānassa nicca ttā
translated: If it be said that if that is so, then even an atom is permanent, —no; because there is no cause for it.

original: te niccāti ce. Na, hetulakkhaṇassa anupapattito. Niccā uppādādīnaṃ abhāvato nibbānaṃ
analyzed: te nicca ati ce na hetu lakkhaṇassa anupapattitaḥ niccāḥ uppāda ādīnam abhāvataḥ nibbānam
translated: If it be said that it is permanent because Nibbāna is permanent, —no; because the characteristic of a cause is not applicable to it. Nibbāna is permanent

original: viyāti ce. Na, aṇuādīnaṃ asiddhattā.
analyzed: ce na asiddha ttā
translated: because it is devoid of arising, etc., like the unformed element, —no; because atoms, etc., are not established.

original: 561. Yathāvuttayuttisabbhāvato pana idameva niccaṃ, rūpasabhāvātikkamato arūpaṃ.
analyzed: yathā vutta yutti sabbhāvataḥ pana idam eva niccam rūpa sabhāva atikkamataḥ arūpam
translated: But because of the stated reason it is permanent, and because of the surmounting of the form element it is formless.

original: Buddhādīnaṃ niṭṭhāya visesābhāvato ekāva niṭṭhā. Yena bhāvanāya pattaṃ, tassa kilesavūpasamaṃ,🔽upādisesañca upādāya paññāpanīyattā saha upādisesena paññāpiyatīti saupādisesaṃ.
analyzed: buddha ādīnam niṭṭhāya visesa abhāvato ekā ava niṭṭhā yena bhāvanāya pattam tassa kilesa vūpasamam  upādisesam ca upādāya paññāpanīya ttā saha upādisesena paññāpiyati iti saupādisesam
translated: It is the one final goal because there is no difference in the final goal of Buddhas, Paccekabuddhas, and disciples, and because it is the cessation of defilements and of the aggregates reached by a single path of practice.

original: Yo cassa samudayappahānena upahatāyatikammaphalassa carimacittato ca uddhaṃ pavattikhandhānaṃ🔽anuppādanato, uppannānañca antaradhānato upādisesābhāvo, taṃ upādāya paññāpanīyato
analyzed: yaḥ ca samudaya ppahānena upahata āyati kamma phalassa carima cittataḥ ca uddham pavatti khandhānam  an uppādanataḥ uppannānam ca antaradhānataḥ upādisesa abhāvaḥ tam upādāya paññāpanīyato
translated: It is called “with trace left” because it can be pointed out as the cessation that is due to the exhaustion of the underlying tendency to lust, etc., and because it can be pointed out as the cessation that is due to the exhaustion of the aggregates that remain in existence owing to past action and defilement.

original: natthi ettha upādisesoti anupādisesaṃ.
analyzed: na atthi ettha upādisesaḥ ti anupādisesam
translated: It is called “without trace left” because there is no trace left of the aggregates that have occurred in the past owing to the exhaustion of the aggregates that remain in existence owing to past action and defilement, and because there is no arising of aggregates that would occur in the future owing to the exhaustion of defilements.🔽It is called “without trace left” because it can be pointed out as the cessation that is due to the exhaustion of the aggregates that remain in existence owing to past action and defilement, and because it can be pointed out as the cessation that is due to the exhaustion of defilements.

original: Asithilaparakkamasiddhena ñāṇavisesena adhigamanīyato, sabbaññuvacanato ca paramatthena
analyzed: asithila parakkama siddhena ñāṇa visesena adhigamanīyataḥ sabbaññu vacanataḥ ca paramatthena
translated: It is not non-existent in the ultimate sense, because it is to be reached by the special knowledge of the path that is successful through its unshakable progress, and because it is spoken of by the all-knowing Buddhas.

original: sabhāvato nibbānaṃ nāvijjamānaṃ. Vuttañhetaṃ “atthi, bhikkhave, ajātaṃ abhūtaṃ akataṃ asaṅkhata”nti.
analyzed: sabhāvataḥ nibbānam na a vijjamānam vuttam ha etam atthi bhikkhave a jātam a bhūtam a katam a saṅkhatam ti
translated: For this is said: “Bhikkhus, there is an unborn, an unbecome, an unmade, an unformed. If there were not, there would be known an unborn, an unbecome, an unmade, an unformed.

original: Idaṃ dukkhanirodhaniddese vinicchayakathāmukhaṃ.
analyzed: idam dukkha nirodha niddese vinicchaya kathā mukham
translated: This is the section of the detailed explanation dealing with the description of the cessation of suffering.

original: Magganiddesakathā
analyzed: magga niddesa kathā
translated: The description of the path

original: 562. Dukkhanirodhagāminipaṭipadāniddese vuttā pana aṭṭha dhammā kāmaṃ khandhaniddesepi
translated: The eight ideas stated in the description of the path leading to the cessation of suffering are in fact demonstrated in the description of the aggregates too,

original: atthato pakāsitāyeva, idha pana nesaṃ ekakkhaṇe pavattamānānaṃ visesāvabodhanatthaṃ
analyzed: atthataḥ pakāsitāya iva idha pana nesam eka khaṇe pavattamānānam visesa avabodhana attham
translated: but we shall mention them here in order to show their distinction when occurring in a single moment.

original: vadāma. Saṅkhepato hi catusaccapaṭivedhāya paṭipannassa yogino nibbānārammaṇaṃ avijjānusayasamugghātakaṃ
analyzed: vadāma saṅkhepataḥ hi catu sacca paṭivedhāya paṭipannassa yogino nibbāna ārammaṇam avijjā anusaya samugghātakam
translated: For in a single moment of the meditator who is practising for the penetration of the four truths, the eye of understanding, which has Nibbāna as its object and which eradicates the underlying tendency to ignorance,

original: paññācakkhu sammādiṭṭhi. Sā sammā dassanalakkhaṇā, dhātuppakāsanarasā, avijjandhakāraviddhaṃsanapaccupaṭṭhānā.
analyzed: paññācakkhu sammādiṭṭhi sā sammā dassana lakkhaṇā dhātu pakāsana rasā avijja andhakāra viddhaṃsana paccupaṭṭhānā
translated: is right view. Its characteristic is seeing rightly. Its function is to illuminate the element. It is manifested as the dispelling of the darkness of ignorance.

original: Tathā sampannadiṭṭhino taṃsampayuttaṃ micchāsaṅkappanighātakaṃ cetaso nibbānapadābhiniropanaṃ
analyzed: tathā sampanna diṭṭhinaḥ tad sampayuttam micchā saṅkappa nighātakam cetasaḥ nibbāna pada abhiniropanam
translated: Likewise, the directing of the mind on to the stage of Nibbāna, which is associated with that right view and which overthrows wrong thinking,

original: sammāsaṅkappo. So sammā cittābhiniropanalakkhaṇo, appanāraso, micchāsaṅkappappahānapaccupaṭṭhāno.
analyzed: sammāsaṅkappo so sammā citta abhiniropana lakkhaṇo appanā rasaḥ micchā saṅkappa ppahāna paccupaṭṭhāno
translated: is right thought. Its characteristic is the right directing of the mind. Its function is to penetrate. It is manifested as the abandoning of wrong thinking.

original: Tathā passato vitakkayato ca taṃsampayuttāva vacīduccaritasamugghātikā micchāvācāya
analyzed: tathā passataḥ vitakkayataḥ ca vacī duccarita samugghātikā micchā vācāya
translated: And when he sees and ponders thus, the abstinence from wrong speech that accompanies that knowledge is right speech.

original: virati sammāvācā nāma. Sā pariggahalakkhaṇā, viramaṇarasā, micchāvācāppahānapaccupaṭṭhānā.
analyzed: virati sammāvācā nāma sā pariggaha lakkhaṇā viramaṇa rasā micchāvācā ppahāna paccupaṭṭhānā
translated: It has the characteristic of restraint. Its function is to abstain. It is manifested as the abandoning of wrong speech.

original: Tathā viramato taṃsampayuttāva micchākammantasamucchedikā pāṇātipātādivirati sammākammanto
analyzed: tathā viramataḥ micchā kammanta samucchedikā pāṇa atipāta ādi virati sammā kammantaḥ
translated: And the abstinence from wrong action that accompanies that knowledge and cuts off wrong action is right action.

original: nāma. So samuṭṭhāpanalakkhaṇo, viramaṇaraso, micchākammantappahānapaccupaṭṭhāno.
analyzed: nāma so samuṭṭhāpana lakkhaṇaḥ viramaṇa rasaḥ micchā kammanta ppahāna paccupaṭṭhāno
translated: It has the characteristic of originating. Its function is to abstain. It is manifested as the abandoning of wrong action.

original: Yā panassa tesaṃ sammāvācākammantānaṃ visuddhibhūtā taṃsampayuttāva kuhanādiupacchedikā
analyzed: yā pana assa tesam sammā vācā kammantānam visuddhi bhūtā tad sampayuttā ava kuhanā ādi upacchedikā
translated: But the abstinence from wrong livelihood that accompanies that knowledge and cuts off scheming, etc., is right livelihood.

original: micchājīvavirati, so sammāājīvo nāma. So vodānalakkhaṇo, ñāyājīvapavattiraso, micchājīvappahānapaccupaṭṭhāno.
analyzed: micchājīva virati so sammāājīvaḥ nāma saḥ vodāna lakkhaṇaḥ ñāyājīva pavatti rasaḥ micchājīva ppahāna paccupaṭṭhāno
translated: It has the characteristic of cleansing. Its function is to abstain. It is manifested as the abandoning of wrong livelihood.

original: Athassa yo tassā sammāvācākammantājīvasaṅkhātāya sīlabhūmiyaṃ patiṭṭhitassa tadanurūpo
analyzed: athassa yaḥ tassā sammā vācā kammanta ājīva saṅkhātāya sīla bhūmiyam patiṭṭhitassa tad anurūpaḥ
translated: Then the knowledge that accompanies right speech, right action, and right livelihood, which is the purification of that plane,

original: taṃsampayuttova kosajjasamucchedako vīriyārambho, esa sammāvāyāmo nāma. So paggahalakkhaṇo,
analyzed: tad sampayuttaḥ uva kosajja samucchedako vīriya ārambho esa sammāvāyāmaḥ nāma so paggaha lakkhaṇo
translated: The arousing of energy that cuts off idleness associated with it is right effort. It has the characteristic of exertion.🔽Its function is to overcome non-utilization of energy;

original: anuppannaakusalānuppādanādiraso, micchāvāyāmappahānapaccupaṭṭhāno. Tassevaṃ vāyamato
analyzed: anuppanna akusala anuppādana ādi rasaḥ micchāvāyāma pahāna paccupaṭṭhāno tassa ivam vāyamataḥ
translated: it is manifested as the abandoning of wrong effort. When he makes effort in this way,

original: taṃsampayuttova micchāsativiniddhunano cetaso asammoso sammāsati nāma. Sā upaṭṭhānalakkhaṇā,🔽asammussanarasā, micchāsatippahānapaccupaṭṭhānā. Evaṃ anuttarāya satiyā saṃrakkhiyamānacittassa
analyzed: tad sampayuttaḥ uva micchā sati viniddhunanaḥ cetasaḥ asammoso sammāsati nāma sā upaṭṭhāna lakkhaṇā  a sammussana rasāḥ micchāsati pahāna paccupaṭṭhānāḥ evam anuttarāya satiyā saṃrakkhiyamāna cittassa
translated: the non-distraction of mind that shakes off wrong mindfulness associated with it is right mindfulness. It has the characteristic of establishing .🔽Its function is not to forget ;🔽it is manifested as the abandoning of wrong mindfulness. When his mind is guarded by supreme mindfulness in this way,

original: taṃsampayuttāva micchāsamādhividdhaṃsikā cittekaggatā sammāsamādhi nāma. So avikkhepalakkhaṇo,
analyzed: tad sampayuttā ava citta ekagga tā sammāsamādhi nāma saḥ avikkhepa lakkhaṇo
translated: the unification of mind that cuts off wrong concentration associated with it is right concentration. It has the characteristic of non-distraction.🔽Its function is to concentrate ;

original: samādhānaraso, micchāsamādhippahānapaccupaṭṭhānoti. Ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminipaṭipadāniddese
analyzed: samādhāna rasaḥ micchāsamādhi ppahāna paccupaṭṭhāno ti ayaṃ dukkha nirodha gāmini paṭipadā niddese
translated: it is manifested as the abandoning of wrong concentration. This is the method in the description of the way leading to the cessation of suffering.

original: nayo. Evamettha jātiādīnaṃ vinicchayo veditabbo.
analyzed: evam ettha jāti ādīnam vinicchayaḥ veditabbo
translated: This is how the exposition should be understood here as to the round of kamma and its result.

original: 563. Ñāṇakiccatoti saccañāṇassa kiccatopi vinicchayo veditabbo. Duvidhaṃ hi saccañāṇaṃ
analyzed: ñāṇa kiccato ti sacca ñāṇassa kiccataḥ pi vinicchayaḥ veditabbaḥ duvidham hi sacca ñāṇam
translated: As to the function of the knowledge: the exposition should be understood as to function of the knowledge of the four truths. For the knowledge of the four truths is twofold, namely,

original: – anubodhañāṇaṃ paṭivedhañāṇañca. Tattha anubodhañāṇaṃ lokiyaṃ anussavādivasena nirodhe
analyzed: anubodha ñāṇam paṭivedha ñāṇam ca tattha anubodha ñāṇam lokiyam anussava ādi vasena nirodhe
translated: The knowledge of the known and the knowledge of penetration. Herein, the knowledge of the known is mundane and occurs in regard to cessation and the path by way of hearsay, etc.,

original: magge ca pavattati. Paṭivedhañāṇaṃ lokuttaraṃ nirodhamārammaṇaṃ katvā kiccato cattāri🔽saccāni paṭivijjhati. Yathāha – “yo, bhikkhave, dukkhaṃ passati, dukkhasamudayampi
analyzed: magge ca pavattati paṭivedha ñāṇam lokuttaram nirodham ārammaṇam katvā kiccato cattāri  saccāni paṭivijjhati yathā āha yaḥ bhikkhave dukkham passati dukkha samudayam pi
translated: The knowledge of penetration is supramundane and penetrates the four truths in their function by making cessation its object.

original: so passati, dukkhanirodhampi passati, dukkhanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadampi passatī”ti
analyzed: so passati dukkha nirodham pi passati dukkha nirodha gāminim paṭipadam pi passati iti
translated: As it is said: “Bhikkhus, he who sees suffering also sees its origin, also sees its cessation, also sees the way leading to its cessation” .

original: sabbaṃ vattabbaṃ. Taṃ panassa kiccaṃ ñāṇadassanavisuddhiyaṃ āvibhavissati.
analyzed: sabbam vattabbam tam panassa kiccam ñāṇa dassana visuddhiyam
translated: All should be quoted. But its function will be made clear in the purification by knowledge and vision.

original: Yaṃ panetaṃ lokiyaṃ, tattha dukkhañāṇaṃ pariyuṭṭhānābhibhavavasena pavattamānaṃ sakkāyadiṭṭhiṃ
analyzed: yam pana etam lokiyam tattha dukkha ñāṇam pariyuṭṭhāna abhibhava vasena pavattamānam sakkāyadiṭṭhim
translated: But as for this mundane knowledge, the knowledge of suffering, occurring by way of the overcoming of obsession, eliminates the view of individuality.

original: nivatteti. Samudayañāṇaṃ ucchedadiṭṭhiṃ. Nirodhañāṇaṃ sassatadiṭṭhiṃ. Maggañāṇaṃ
analyzed: nivatteti samudaya ñāṇam uccheda diṭṭhim nirodha ñāṇam sassata diṭṭhim magga ñāṇam
translated: The knowledge of origination eliminates the view of annihilation. The knowledge of cessation eliminates the view of eternalism. The knowledge of the path eliminates the view of non-cause and the view of wrong cause.

original: akiriyadiṭṭhiṃ. Dukkhañāṇaṃ vā dhuvasubhasukhattabhāvavirahitesu khandhesu dhuvasubhasukhattabhāvasaññāsaṅkhātaṃ🔽phale vippaṭipattiṃ. Samudayañāṇaṃ issarapadhānakālasabhāvādīhi loko pavattatīti
analyzed: akiriya diṭṭhim dukkha ñāṇam vā dhuva subha sukhatta bhāva virahitesu khandhesu dhuva subha sukhatta bhāva saññā saṅkhātam  phale vippaṭipattim samudaya ñāṇam issara padhāna kāla sabhāva ādīhi loko pavattati iti
translated: and the view that there is no doing. Or the knowledge of suffering stops the wrong practice in the fruit, which is called the perception of permanence, pleasure, beauty, and self in the aggregates that are impermanent, painful, foul, and not self.🔽The knowledge of origination stops the wrong practice in the cause, which is the occurrence of the conceit “I am,” having as its support the false view that the world is made by a supreme being, by Brahmā, by time, by atoms, by primal substance, by evolution, by transformation, by nature, by destiny, by chance.

original: akāraṇe kāraṇābhimānappavattaṃ hetumhi vippaṭipattiṃ. Nirodhañāṇaṃ arūpalokalokathūpikādīsu🔽apavaggagāhabhūtaṃ nirodhe vippaṭipattiṃ. Maggañāṇaṃ kāmasukhallikaattakilamathānuyogappabhede
analyzed: akāraṇe kāraṇa abhimāna ppavattam hetumhi vippaṭipattim nirodha ñāṇam arūpa loka loka thūpika ādīsu  apavagga gāha bhūtam nirodhe vippaṭipattim magga ñāṇam kāma sukhallika atta kilamatha anuyoga ppabhede
translated: The knowledge of cessation stops the wrong practice in cessation, which is the occurrence of the view that there is annihilation, extermination, and destruction of an existing being in the case of the non-existent world beyond, in the case of the world beyond as a world of visible objects, as a world of space, as a world of a sign, and so on.

original: avisuddhimagge visuddhimaggagāhavasena pavattaṃ upāye vippaṭipattiṃ nivatteti. Tenetaṃ vuccati –
analyzed: a visuddhi magge visuddhi magga gāha vasena pavattam upāye vippaṭipattim nivatteti tena itam vuccati
translated: The knowledge of the path stops the wrong practice in the means, which is the occurrence of the view that the way of practice that is not the way is the way in the case of the practice of sensual indulgence, the practice of self-mortification, and the practice that is the middle way. Therefore it is said:

original: “Loke lokappabhave, lokatthagame sive ca tadupāye;
analyzed: loke loka ppabhave lokattha game sive ca tad upāye
translated: “As long as a man is deluded, he is confused about the world, about the origin of the world, about the cessation of the world, about the means to the cessation of the world.

original: Sammuyhati tāva naro, na vijānāti yāva saccānī”ti.
analyzed: sammuyhati tāva naraḥ na vijānāti yāva saccāni iti
translated: He does not know, does not see the truths.”

original: Evamettha ñāṇakiccatopi vinicchayo veditabbo.
analyzed: evam ettha ñāṇa kiccataḥ pi vinicchayaḥ veditabbo
translated: This is how the exposition should be understood here as to the function of the kinds of knowledge.

original: 564. Antogadhānaṃ pabhedāti dukkhasaccasmiṃ hi ṭhapetvā taṇhañceva anāsavadhamme
analyzed: antogadhānam dukkha saccasmim hi ṭhapetvā taṇham ca iva anāsava dhamme
translated: The kinds included are: In the case of the truth of suffering, craving and the states without greed are excluded.

original: ca sesā sabbadhammā antogadhā. Samudayasacce chattiṃsa taṇhāvicaritāni. Nirodhasaccaṃ🔽asammissaṃ. Maggasacce sammādiṭṭhimukhena vīmaṃsiddhipādapaññindriyapaññābaladhammavicayasambojjhaṅgāni.🔽Sammāsaṅkappāpadesena tayo nekkhammavitakkādayo. Sammāvācāpadesena cattāri vacīsucaritāni.🔽Sammākammantāpadesena tīṇi kāyasucaritāni. Sammājīvamukhena appicchatā santuṭṭhitā🔽ca. Sabbesaṃyeva vā etesaṃ sammāvācākammantājīvānaṃ ariyakantasīlattā ariyakantasīlassa
analyzed: ca sesā sabba dhammā antogadhā samudaya sacce chattiṃsa taṇhā vicaritāni nirodha saccam  a sammissam magga sacce sammādiṭṭhi mukhena vīmaṃsi ddhipāda paññindriya paññā bala dhammavicaya sambojjhaṅgāni  sammā saṅkappa apadesena tayaḥ nekkhamma vitakka ādayaḥ sammā vācā apadesena cattāri vacī su caritāni  sammā kammanta apadesena tīṇi kāya su caritāni sammājīva mukhena appiccha tā santuṭṭhi tā  ca sabbesam yeva vā etesam sammā vācā kammanta ājīvānam ariya kanta sīla ttā ariya kanta sīlassa
translated: The kinds included are of two kinds, classed as those included in the truths and those included in the path. Herein, in the case of the truth of suffering, all states except craving and the states without root-cause are included. In the case of the truth of origination, the thirty-six classes of craving are included. In the case of the truth of cessation,

original: ca saddhāhatthena paṭiggahetabbattā tesaṃ atthitāya atthibhāvato saddhindriyasaddhābalachandiddhipādā.
analyzed: ca saddhā hatthena paṭiggahetabba ttā tesam atthitāya atthi bhāvato saddhi indriya saddhā bala chandi ddhipādā
translated: cessation without trace left is included. In the case of the truth of the path, right view, as the heading, is included under the three aggregates, the four path factors, the four path kinds of direct knowledge, the four path kinds of purification of the way, the four path kinds of full-understanding, the four path kinds of rightness, the four path kinds of rightness in what is not mixed, the four path kinds of rightness in what is mixed, the four path kinds of rightness in conformity, the four path kinds of rightness in transcending, the four path kinds of rightness in purification of the way, the four path kinds of rightness in full-understanding, the four path kinds of rightness in what is not mixed, the four path kinds of rightness in what is mixed, the four path kinds of rightness in conformity, the four path kinds of rightness in transcending, the four path kinds of rightness in purification of the way, the four path kinds of rightness in full-understanding, the four path kinds of rightness in what is not mixed, the four path kinds of rightness in what is mixed, the four path kinds of rightness in conformity, the four path kinds of rightness in transcending, the four path kinds of rightness in purification of the way, the four path kinds of rightness in full-understanding, the four path kinds of rightness in what is not mixed, the four path kinds of rightness in what is mixed, the four path kinds of rightness in conformity, the four path kinds of rightness in transcending, the four path kinds of rightness in purification of the way, the four path kinds of rightness in full-understanding, the four path kinds of rightness in what is not mixed, the four path kinds of rightness in what is mixed, the four path kinds of rightness in conformity, the four path kinds of rightness in transcending, the four path kinds of rightness in purification of the way, the four path kinds of rightness in full-understanding, the four path kinds of right

original: Sammāvāyāmāpadesena catubbidhasammappadhānavīriyindriyavīriyabalavīriyasambojjhaṅgāni.🔽Sammāsatiapadesena catubbidhasatipaṭṭhānasatindriyasatibalasatisambojjhaṅgāni. Sammāsamādhiapadesena
analyzed: sammāvāyāma apadesena catubbidha sammappadhāna vīriyindriya vīriya bala vīriya sambojjhaṅgāni  sammā sati apadesena catubbidha sati paṭṭhāna sati indriya sati bala sati sambojjhaṅgāni sammā samādhi apadesena
translated: By the expression “right effort” the four right efforts, the energy faculty, the energy power, and the energy enlightenment factor are included.🔽By the expression “right mindfulness” the four establishments of mindfulness, the mindfulness faculty, the mindfulness power, and the mindfulness enlightenment factor are included. By the expression “right concentration”

original: savitakkasavicārādayo tayo samādhī cittasamādhi samādhindriyasamādhibalapītipassaddhisamādhiupekkhāsambojjhaṅgāni
analyzed: sa vitakka sa vicāra ādayo tayo samādhī citta samādhi samādhi indriya samādhi bala pīti passaddhi samādhi upekkhā sambojjhaṅgāni
translated: the three kinds of concentration with thinking and with investigation, etc., the concentration faculty, the concentration power, the rapture, tranquillity, concentration, and equanimity enlightenment factors are included.

original: antogadhānīti evamettha antogadhānaṃ pabhedatopi vinicchayo veditabbo.
analyzed: antogadhāni iti evam ettha antogadhānam pabhedataḥ pi vinicchayaḥ veditabbo
translated: Thus the exposition should be known here as to what is included by the terms.

original: 565. Upamātoti bhāro viya hi dukkhasaccaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ, bhārādānamiva samudayasaccaṃ,
analyzed: upamātaḥ ti bhāraḥ viya hi dukkha saccam daṭṭhabbam bhāra ādānam iva samudaya saccam
translated: As to simile: the truth of suffering should be seen as a burden, the truth of origin as the taking up of the burden,

original: bhāranikkhepanamiva nirodhasaccaṃ, bhāranikkhepanupāyo viya maggasaccaṃ. Rogo viya
analyzed: bhāra nikkhepanam iva nirodha saccam bhāra nikkhepana upāyaḥ viya magga saccam rogaḥ viya
translated: the truth of cessation as the setting down of the burden, and the truth of the path as the means to the setting down of the burden. And as a disease,

original: ca dukkhasaccaṃ, roganidānamiva samudayasaccaṃ, rogavūpasamo viya nirodhasaccaṃ,
analyzed: ca dukkha saccam roga nidānam iva samudaya saccam roga vūpasamaḥ viya nirodha saccam
translated: the truth of suffering should be seen, the truth of origin as the origin of the disease, the truth of cessation as the stilling of the disease,

original: bhesajjamiva maggasaccaṃ. Dubbhikkhamiva vā dukkhasaccaṃ, dubbuṭṭhi viya samudayasaccaṃ,
analyzed: bhesajjam iva magga saccam dubbhikkham iva vā dukkha saccam viya samudaya saccam
translated: The truth of the path is like the medicine. The truth of suffering is like the famine, and the truth of origin is like the drought.🔽The truth of cessation is like the good harvest, and the truth of the path is like the good rainfall.

original: subhikkhamiva nirodhasaccaṃ, suvuṭṭhi viya maggasaccaṃ. Apica verī-veramūla-verasamugghāta-verasamugghātupāyehi,
analyzed: subhikkham iva nirodha saccam viya magga saccam apica verī vera mūla vera samugghāta vera samugghāta upāyehi
translated: Moreover, they can be understood by analogy with an enemy, the root of the enemy, the uprooting of the enemy, and the means of uprooting the enemy;

original: visarukkha-rukkhamūla-mūlupaccheda-tadupacchedupāyehi, bhaya-bhayamūla-nibbhaya-tadadhigamupāyehi,
analyzed: visa rukkha rukkha mūla mūla upaccheda tad upaccheda upāyehi bhaya bhaya mūla nibbhaya tad adhigama upāyehi
translated: with a poisonous tree, the root of the tree, the cutting of the root, and the means of cutting it; with fear, the root of fear, the absence of fear, and the means of attaining it;

original: orimatīra-mahoghapārimatīra-taṃsampāpakavāyāmehi ca yojetvāpetāni upamāto veditabbānīti
analyzed: ca upamātaḥ veditabbāni iti
translated: and with the near shore, the great flood, the far shore, and the effort to reach it.

original: evamettha upamāto vinicchayo veditabbo.
analyzed: evam ettha upamātaḥ vinicchayaḥ veditabbo
translated: This is how the exposition should be understood here “as to analogy.”

original: 566. Catukkatoti atthi cettha dukkhaṃ na ariyasaccaṃ, atthi ariyasaccaṃ na dukkhaṃ,
analyzed: catukkato ti atthi ca ittha dukkham na ariya saccaṃ atthi ariya saccam na dukkham
translated: As to the fourfold: here there is suffering that is not a noble truth, there is a noble truth that is not suffering,

original: atthi dukkhañceva ariyasaccañca, atthi neva dukkhaṃ na ariyasaccaṃ. Esa nayo samudayādīsu.
analyzed: atthi dukkham ca iva ariya saccaṃ ca atthi na iva dukkham na ariya saccaṃ esa nayaḥ samudaya ādīsu
translated: there is suffering that is a noble truth, and there is what is neither suffering nor a noble truth. The same method applies in the case of origin and the rest.

original: Tattha maggasampayuttā dhammā sāmaññaphalāni ca “yadaniccaṃ taṃ dukkha”nti vacanato
analyzed: tattha magga sampayuttāḥ dhammāḥ sāmañña phalāni ca yat aniccam tat dukkhan ti vacanato
translated: Herein, states associated with the path and fruits of asceticism are “suffering” in the sense of “what is impermanent is suffering” .

original: saṅkhāradukkhatāya dukkhaṃ, na ariyasaccaṃ. Nirodho ariyasaccaṃ, na dukkhaṃ. Itaraṃ
analyzed: saṅkhāra dukkha tāya dukkham na ariya saccam nirodhaḥ ariya saccam na dukkham itaram
translated: Suffering is not a noble truth because of the suffering inherent in formations. Cessation is a noble truth, but it is not suffering.🔽The other two noble truths

original: pana ariyasaccadvayaṃ siyā dukkhaṃ aniccato, na pana yassa pariññāya bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ
analyzed: pana ariya sacca dvayam siyā dukkham aniccataḥ na pana yassa pariññāya bhagavati brahmacariyam
translated: are suffering in the sense of being impermanent, but not in the sense of which needs to be fully understood, for which purpose the life of purity is lived under the Blessed One.

original: vussati tathattena. Sabbākārena pana upādānakkhandhapañcakaṃ dukkhañceva ariyasaccañca🔽aññatra taṇhāya. Maggasampayuttā dhammā sāmaññaphalāni ca yassa pariññatthaṃ bhagavati
analyzed: vussati tathattena sabba ākārena pana upādāna khandha pañcakam dukkham ca iva ariya saccañca  aññatra taṇhāya magga sampayuttāḥ dhammāḥ sāmañña phalāni ca yassa bhagavati
translated: But the five aggregates as objects of clinging are both suffering and a noble truth in all ways, except for craving.🔽The states associated with the path and the fruits of asceticism are neither suffering nor a noble truth in the sense of which needs to be fully understood, for which purpose the life of purity is lived under the Blessed One.

original: brahmacariyaṃ vussati tathattena neva dukkhaṃ na ariyasaccaṃ. Evaṃ samudayādīsupi
analyzed: brahmacariyam tathattena na iva dukkham na ariya saccam evam samudaya ādīsu pi
translated: So too with the origin, etc.

original: yathāyogaṃ yojetvā catukkatopettha vinicchayo veditabbo.
analyzed: yathāyogam yojetvā vinicchayaḥ veditabbo
translated: The exposition should be understood here in the fourfold way by applying this method in each case.

original: 567. Suññatekavidhādīhītiettha suññato tāva paramatthena hi sabbāneva saccāni vedakakārakanibbutagamakābhāvato suññānīti veditabbāni. Tenetaṃ vuccati –
analyzed: suññatā ekavidha ādīhi iti ettha suññatas tāva paramatthena hi sabbān eva saccāni vedaka kāraka nibbuta gamaka abhāvataḥ suññāni iti veditabbāni tena itam vuccati
translated: . As to the kinds of voidness, etc., here firstly, as to voidness: all the truths should be understood as void in the ultimate sense because of the absence of any self or what belongs to a self. Hence it is said:

original: “Dukkhameva hi, na koci dukkhito;
analyzed: dukkham eva hi na koci dukkhitaḥ
translated: “There is suffering, but no sufferer;

original: Kārako na, kiriyāva vijjati.
analyzed: kārakaḥ na vijjati
translated: There is no doer, but the deed is there.

original: Atthi nibbuti, na nibbuto pumā;
analyzed: atthi nibbuti na nibbutaḥ pumā
translated: There is extinction, but no man extinct;

original: Maggamatthi, gamako na vijjatī”ti.
analyzed: maggam atthi gamakaḥ na vijjati iti
translated: There is the path, but no traveler on it.

original: Atha vā,
analyzed: atha vā
translated: Or else:

original: Dhuvasubhasukhattasuññaṃ, purimadvayamattasuññamamatapadaṃ;
analyzed: dhuva subha sukhatta suññam purima dvaya matta suññam amata padam
translated: The first two are void of permanence, beauty, pleasure, and self; the last is void of the first two terms;

original: Dhuvasukhaattavirahito, maggoiti suññatā tesu.
analyzed: dhuva sukha atta virahitaḥ maggo iti suñña tā tesu
translated: The path is void of permanence and pleasure and self.

original: Nirodhasuññāni vā tīṇi, nirodho ca sesattayasuñño. Phalasuñño vā ettha hetu samudaye
analyzed: nirodha suññāni vā tīṇi nirodho ca sesa ttaya suñño phala suñño vā ettha hetu samudaye
translated: Or else the three are void of cessation, and cessation is void of the other three. Or else the fruit is void of the cause in the origin and path,

original: dukkhassābhāvato, magge ca nirodhassa, na phalena sagabbho pakativādīnaṃ pakati viya.
analyzed: dukkhassa abhāvataḥ magge ca nirodhassa na phalena sa gabbhaḥ pakati vādīnam pakati viya
translated: because there is no suffering there, and cessation is void of the path, like the natural state of those who profess natural fruit.

original: Hetusuññañca phalaṃ dukkhasamudayānaṃ nirodhamaggānañca asamavāyā, na hetusamavetaṃ
analyzed: hetu suññam ca phalam dukkha samudayānam nirodha maggānam ca asamavāyāḥ na hetu samavetam
translated: And the fruit is void of cause in the origin and path because of non-conascence with the cause,

original: hetuphalaṃ samavāyavādīnaṃ dviaṇukādi viya. Tenetaṃ vuccati –
analyzed: hetu phalam dvi aṇuka ādi viya tena itam vuccati
translated: like the natural state of those who profess conascent fruit. Hence it is said:

original: “Tayamidha nirodhasuññaṃ, tayena tenāpi nibbuti suññā;
analyzed: tayam idha nirodha suññam tayena tena api nibbuti suññā
translated: “Herein, cessation is void of the three, and extinction is void of the other two.

original: Suñño phalena hetu, phalampi taṃhetunā suñña”nti.
analyzed: suññaḥ phalena hetu phalampi taṃhetunā suññanti
translated: The cause is void of the fruit, and the fruit is void of the cause.”

original: Evaṃ tāva suññato vinicchayo veditabbo.
analyzed: evam tāva suññataḥ vinicchayaḥ veditabbo
translated: This, in the first place, is how the exposition should be known here as to voidness.

original: Ekavidhādivinicchayakathā
translated: As to the singlefold, etc., classification

original: 568. Ekavidhādīhīti sabbameva cettha dukkhaṃ ekavidhaṃ pavattibhāvato. Duvidhaṃ nāmarūpato.
analyzed: ekavidha ādīhi iti sabbam eva ca ittha dukkham ekavidham pavatti bhāvataḥ duvidham nāma rūpataḥ
translated: Herein, all suffering is of one kind as to occurrence. It is of two kinds as mentality-materiality.

original: Tividhaṃ kāmarūpārūpūpapattibhavabhedato. Catubbidhaṃ catuāhārabhedato. Pañcavidhaṃ
analyzed: tividham catubbidham catu āhāra bhedataḥ pañcavidham
translated: It is of three kinds as the three kinds of becoming, namely, sensual-desire, material, and immaterial becoming. It is of four kinds as the four kinds of nutriment. It is of five kinds as the five aggregates as objects of clinging.

original: pañcupādānakkhandhabhedato.
analyzed: pañca upādāna khandha bhedataḥ
translated: It is of six kinds as the sixfold base.

original: Samudayopi ekavidho pavattakabhāvato. Duvidho diṭṭhisampayuttāsampayuttato. Tividho
analyzed: samudayaḥ api ekavidho pavattaka bhāvataḥ duvidho diṭṭhi sampayutta asampayuttato tividho
translated: Origination is of one kind as to occurrence. It is of two kinds as associated and not associated with false view.

original: kāmabhavavibhavataṇhābhedato. Catubbidho catumaggappaheyyato. Pañcavidho rūpābhinandanādibhedato.
analyzed: kāma bhava vibhava taṇhā bhedato catubbidhaḥ catu magga ppaheyyato pañcavidhaḥ rūpa abhinandana ādi bhedataḥ
translated: It is of three kinds as the craving for sensual desires, for becoming, and for non-becoming. It is of four kinds as to be abandoned by the four paths. It is of five kinds as the five kinds of delighting.

original: Chabbidho chataṇhākāyabhedato.
analyzed: chabbidhaḥ chata ṇhā kāya bhedataḥ
translated: It is of six kinds as the six classes of craving.

original: Nirodhopi ekavidho asaṅkhatadhātubhāvato. Pariyāyena pana duvidho saupādisesaanupādisesabhedato.
analyzed: nirodhaḥ api ekavidhaḥ asaṅkhata dhātu bhāvato pariyāyena pana duvidhaḥ saupādisesa anupādisesa bhedato
translated: Cessation is of one kind as the unformed element. But it is of two kinds as the remainderless cessation of virtue and duty, and as the remainderless cessation of perception and feeling.

original: Tividho bhavattayavūpasamato. Catubbidho catumaggādhigamanīyato. Pañcavidho pañcābhinandanavūpasamato.
analyzed: tividhaḥ bhava taya vūpasamataḥ catubbidhaḥ catu magga adhigamanīyataḥ pañcavidhaḥ pañca abhinandana vūpasamataḥ
translated: It is of three kinds as the stilling of the three kinds of becoming. It is of four kinds as to be reached by the four paths. It is of five kinds as the stilling of the five kinds of delighting.

original: Chabbidho chataṇhākāyakkhayabhedato.
analyzed: chabbidhaḥ chat aṇhā kāya kkhaya bhedataḥ
translated: It is of six kinds as the destruction of the six classes of craving.

original: Maggopi ekavidho bhāvetabbato. Duvidho samathavipassanābhedato, dassanabhāvanābhedato🔽vā. Tividho khandhattayabhedato. Ayañhi sappadesattā nagaraṃ viya rajjena nippadesehi
analyzed: maggaḥ api ekavidhaḥ bhāvetabbataḥ duvidhaḥ samatha vipassanā bhedataḥ dassana bhāvanā bhedato  vā tividhaḥ khandha ttaya bhedataḥ ayan hi sappadesa ttā nagaram viya rajjena nippadesehi
translated: And the path is of one kind as what is to be developed. It is of two kinds as the division of serenity and insight,🔽or as the division of seeing and developing.🔽It is of three kinds as the division of the three aggregates. For this path is included in the three aggregates that have a counterpart, like a city by the three boundaries that have a counterpart,

original: tīhi khandhehi saṅgahito. Yathāha –🔽“Na kho, āvuso visākha, ariyena aṭṭhaṅgikena maggena tayo khandhā saṅgahitā, tīhi
analyzed: tīhi khandhehi saṅgahitaḥ yathā āha  na kho āvuso visākha ariyena aṭṭhaṅgikena maggena tayaḥ khandhā saṅgahitā tīhi
translated: as it is said:🔽“Friend Visākha, the three aggregates are not included in the Noble Eightfold Path,

original: ca kho, āvuso visākha, khandhehi ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo saṅgahito. Yā cāvuso visākha,🔽sammāvācā, yo ca sammākammanto, yo ca sammāājīvo, ime dhammā sīlakkhandhe saṅgahitā.🔽Yo ca sammāvāyāmo, yā ca sammāsati, yo ca sammāsamādhi, ime dhammā samādhikkhandhe
analyzed: ca kho āvuso visākha khandhehi ariyaḥ aṭṭhaṅgikaḥ maggo saṅgahitaḥ yā ca āvuso visākha  sammā vācā yo ca sammā kammanto yo ca sammā ājīvo ime dhammā sīla kkhandhe saṅgahitā  yā ca sammā vāyāmaḥ yā ca sammā sati yaḥ ca sammā samādhi ime dhammā samādhi kkhandhe
translated: but the three aggregates are included in the Noble Eightfold Path.🔽And, friend Visākha, right speech, right action, and right livelihood are included in the virtue aggregate;🔽and right effort, right mindfulness, and right concentration are included in the concentration aggregate;
