original: saṅgahitā. Yā ca sammādiṭṭhi, yo ca sammāsaṅkappo, ime dhammā paññākkhandhe saṅgahitā”ti.
analyzed: saṅgahitā yā ca sammādiṭṭhi yaḥ ca sammāsaṅkappo ime dhammā paññā kkhandhe saṅgahitā ati
translated: and right view and right thought are included in the understanding aggregate” .

original: Ettha hi sammāvācādayo tayo sīlameva, tasmā te sajātito sīlakkhandhena saṅgahitā.
analyzed: ettha hi sammāvācā ādayo tayo sīlam eva tasmā te sajātitaḥ sīla kkhandhena saṅgahitā
translated: Herein, the three beginning with right speech are virtue, so they are included in the virtue category because of having the same characteristic of non-greed, etc.,🔽and because of being similar in the function of non-affliction, etc., and because of having the same proximate cause of non-greed, etc., and because of having the same culmination in the non-greed, etc., and because of having the same fruit in the form of the avoidance of the states of loss, and because of having the same nutriment in the form of the avoidance of the states of loss, and because of having the same expression in the form of the avoidance of the states of loss, and because of having the same aspect in the form of the avoidance of the states of loss, and because of having the same purification in the form of the avoidance of the states of loss.

original: Kiñcāpi hi pāḷiyaṃ sīlakkhandheti bhummena niddeso kato, attho pana karaṇavaseneva🔽veditabbo. Sammāvāyāmādīsu pana tīsu samādhi attano dhammatāya ārammaṇe ekaggabhāvena
analyzed: kiñca api hi pāḷiyam sīlakkhandha iti bhummena niddeso kataḥ atthaḥ pana karaṇa vasena iva  veditabbaḥ sammāvāyāma ādīsu pana tīsu samādhi attanaḥ dhammatāya ārammaṇe ekagga bhāvena
translated: And although the description is given in the text in terms of the category of virtue, the meaning should be regarded in terms of the function of virtue.

original: appetuṃ na sakkoti, vīriye pana paggahakiccaṃ sādhente satiyā ca apilāpanakiccaṃ
analyzed: appetum na sakkoti vīriye pana paggaha kiccam sādhente satiyā ca apilāpana kiccam
translated: But in the case of the three beginning with right effort, concentration is unable to occur in the object by its own characteristics owing to the lack of the unification of mind. But when energy has fulfilled its function of exerting, and mindfulness has fulfilled its function of preventing wobbling,

original: sādhentiyā laddhupakāro hutvā sakkoti.
analyzed: sādhentiyāḥ laddha upakāraḥ hutvā sakkoti
translated: then it is able to do so with their assistance.

original: Tatrāyaṃ upamā – yathā hi nakkhattaṃ kīḷissāmāti uyyānaṃ paviṭṭhesu tīsu sahāyesu
analyzed: tatra ayam upamā yathā hi nakkhattam kīḷissāma ati uyyānam paviṭṭhesu tīsu sahāyesu
translated: Here is a simile. Suppose there were three friends, and they had gone into the forest to collect firewood.🔽One of them saw a beautiful flowering champaka tree and raised his hand in order to take hold of it.

original: eko supupphitaṃ campakarukkhaṃ disvā hatthaṃ ukkhipitvā gahetumpi na sakkuṇeyya.🔽Athassa dutiyo onamitvā piṭṭhiṃ dadeyya, so tassa piṭṭhiyaṃ ṭhatvāpi kampamāno gahetuṃ
analyzed: ekaḥ su pupphitam campaka rukkham disvā hattham ukkhipitvā gahetum pi na sakkuṇeyya 🔽athassa dutiyaḥ onamitvā piṭṭhim dadeyya saḥ tassa piṭṭhiyam ṭhatvā api kampamānaḥ gahetum
translated: But he was unable to do so,

original: na sakkuṇeyya. Athassa itaro aṃsakūṭaṃ upanāmeyya. So ekassa piṭṭhiyaṃ ṭhatvā ekassa
analyzed: na sakkuṇeyya athassa itaraḥ aṃsakūṭam upanāmeyya saḥ ekassa piṭṭhiyam ṭhatvā ekassa
translated: He could not. Then the other would offer him his shoulder. Standing on the back of one and climbing on to the shoulder of the other,

original: aṃsakūṭaṃ olubbha yathāruci pupphāni ocinitvā piḷandhitvā nakkhattaṃ kīḷeyya. Evaṃsampadamidaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: aṃsakūṭam olubbha yathāruci pupphāni ocinitvā piḷandhitvā nakkhattam kīḷeyya evaṃsampadam idam daṭṭhabbam
translated: he would pick the flowers as he pleased, and after weaving them into a garland he would play with it. This is how it should be regarded.

original: Ekato uyyānaṃ paviṭṭhā tayo sahāyā viya hi ekato jātā sammāvāyāmādayo tayo dhammā.🔽Supupphitacampako viya ārammaṇaṃ. Hatthaṃ ukkhipitvāpi gahetuṃ asakkonto viya attano
analyzed: ekatas uyyānam paviṭṭhā tayo sahāyāḥ viya hi ekatas jātā sammāvāyāma ādayo tayo dhammā  su pupphita campakaḥ viya ārammaṇam hattham ukkhipitvā api gahetum a sakkontaḥ viya attanaḥ
translated: For just as the three friends entered the park together, so the three things, right effort and the rest, arise together.

original: dhammatāya ārammaṇe ekaggabhāvena appetuṃ asakkonto samādhi. Piṭṭhiṃ datvā onatasahāyo🔽viya vāyāmo. Aṃsakūṭaṃ datvā ṭhitasahāyo viya sati. Yathā tesu ekassa piṭṭhiyaṃ ṭhatvā🔽ekassa aṃsakūṭaṃ olubbha itaro yathāruci pupphaṃ gahetuṃ sakkoti, evameva vīriye
analyzed: dhamma tāya ārammaṇe ekagga bhāvena appetum asakkonto samādhi piṭṭhim datvā onata sahāyaḥ  viya vāyāmaḥ aṃsakūṭam da tvā ṭhita sahāyaḥ viya sati yathā tesu ekassa piṭṭhiyam ṭhatvā  ekassa aṃsakūṭam olubbhe itaraḥ yathāruci puppham gahetum sakkoti evam eva vīriye
translated: The object is like the flowering tree. Concentration is like the man who, though he raises his hand, cannot pick the flowers because he is unable to steady himself on the object with one-pointedness of mind.🔽Effort is like the friend who, giving his back, bends down. Mindfulness is like the friend who, giving his shoulder, stands by.

original: paggahakiccaṃ sādhente satiyā ca apilāpanakiccaṃ sādhentiyā laddhupakāro samādhi
analyzed: paggaha kiccam sādhente satiyā ca apilāpana kiccam sādhentiyā laddha upakāraḥ samādhi
translated: Just as the man can pick the flowers as he pleases, standing on the back of one and climbing on to the shoulder of the other, so too, when energy is accomplishing its function of exerting, and when mindfulness is accomplishing its function of preventing wobbling, then concentration, which is helped by them,🔽can accomplish its function of steadying the mind on the object.

original: sakkoti ārammaṇe ekaggabhāvena appetuṃ. Tasmā samādhiyevettha sajātito samādhikkhandhena
analyzed: sakkoti ārammaṇe ekagga bhāvena appetum tasmā samādhi yā iva itthā sajātitaḥ samādhi kkhandhena
translated: and it can be concentrated on the object with one-pointedness. That is why concentration is called a concentration factor in the sense of kind.

original: saṅgahito, vāyāmasatiyo pana kiriyato saṅgahitā honti.
analyzed: saṅgahitaḥ pana saṅgahitāḥ honti
translated: It can focus on the object with the one-pointedness of concentration. That is why concentration is included in the concentration category as being of the same kind. But the energy and the mindfulness are included in the category of formations.

original: Sammādiṭṭhisammāsaṅkappesupi paññā attano dhammatāya aniccaṃ dukkhamanattāti ārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: sammādiṭṭhi sammāsaṅkappesu pi paññā attanaḥ dhamma tāya aniccam dukkham anattā ati ārammaṇaṃ
translated: As regards right view and right thinking, understanding cannot by its own nature determine an object as impermanent, painful, not-self.

original: nicchetuṃ na sakkoti. Vitakke pana ākoṭetvā ākoṭetvā dente sakkoti. Kathaṃ? Yathā🔽hi heraññiko kahāpaṇaṃ hatthe ṭhapetvā sabbabhāgesu oloketukāmo samānopi na cakkhutaleneva
analyzed: nicchetum na sakkoti vitakke pana ākoṭetvā ākoṭetvā dente sakkoti katham yathā  hi heraññikaḥ kahāpaṇam hatthe ṭhapetvā sabba bhāgesu oloketu kāmo samānaḥ api na cakkhu talena iva
translated: But it can when it is given a prod by applied thoughts. How?

original: parivattetuṃ sakkoti. Aṅgulipabbehi pana parivattetvā parivattetvā ito cito ca oloketuṃ
analyzed: parivattetum sakkoti aṅguli pabbehi pana parivattetvā parivattetvā itas ca itas ca oloketum
translated: For just as a goldsmith, though he may be looking at gold in all its parts with his eyes wide open, is unable to turn it round with his eyes and look at it from above, but can do so by means of the tongs;

original: sakkoti, evameva na paññā attano dhammatāya aniccādivasena ārammaṇaṃ nicchetuṃ sakkoti.
analyzed: sakkoti evam eva na paññā attanaḥ dhamma tāya anicca ādi vasena ārammaṇam nicchetum sakkoti
translated: so too understanding cannot by its own nature determine an object as impermanent, etc.,

original: Abhiniropanalakkhaṇena pana āhananapariyāhananarasena vitakkena ākoṭentena viya parivattentena
analyzed: abhiniropana lakkhaṇena pana āhanana pariyāhanana rasena vitakkena ākoṭentena viya parivattentena
translated: but it can when it is given a prod by applied thoughts, which are like tongs in turning the object over.

original: viya ca ādāyādāya dinnameva nicchetuṃ sakkoti. Tasmā idhāpi sammādiṭṭhiyeva sajātito
analyzed: ca ādāya ādāya dinnam eva nicchetum sakkoti tasmai idha api sammādiṭṭhiyā iva sajātitaḥ
translated: and it can only be determined by giving it in the same way as it is given in the Paṭṭhāna.🔽

original: paññākkhandhena saṅgahitā, sammāsaṅkappo pana kiriyavasena saṅgahito hoti.
analyzed: paññā kkhandhena saṅgahitā sammāsaṅkappo pana kiriya vasena saṅgahitaḥ hoti
translated: and it can only be sure of what is given to it by being brought to it. So here too right view is included in the wisdom category as being of the same kind as that. But right thought is included as action.

original: Iti imehi tīhi khandhehi maggo saṅgahaṃ gacchati. Tena vuttaṃ “tividho khandhattayabhedato”ti. Catubbidho sotāpattimaggādivaseneva.
analyzed: iti imehi tīhi khandhehi maggo saṅgaham gacchati tena vuttam tividhaḥ khandha ttaya bhedataḥ ti catubbidhaḥ sotāpatti magga ādi vasena iva
translated: So the path is included in these three categories. Hence it was said above “In three ways by the division of the three categories.” It is fourfold just as the stream-entry path, and so on, are.

original: Apica sabbāneva saccāni ekavidhāni avitathattā, abhiññeyyattā vā. Duvidhāni lokiyalokuttarato,
analyzed: apica sabbāneva saccāni ekavidhāni avitatha ttā abhiññeyya ttā vā duvidhāni lokiya lokuttarato
translated: Besides, all the truths are singlefold as not false, or as what has to be directly known. They are twofold as mundane and supramundane,

original: saṅkhatāsaṅkhatato vā. Tividhāni dassana-bhāvanāhi pahātabbato, appahātabbato ca.
analyzed: saṅkhata asaṅkhatataḥ vā tividhāni dassana bhāvanāhi pahātabbataḥ a pahātabbataḥ ca
translated: or as formed and unformed. They are threefold as to be given up by seeing and by keeping in being and not to be given up.

original: Catubbidhāni pariññeyyādibhedatoti evamettha ekavidhādīhi vinicchayo veditabbo.
analyzed: catubbidhāni pariññeyyā ādi bhedataḥ ti evam ettha ekavidha ādīhi vinicchayaḥ veditabbo
translated: They are fourfold as to be fully understood and so on. This is how the exposition should be understood here as to singlefold, and so on.

original: 569. Sabhāgavisabhāgatoti sabbāneva saccāni aññamaññaṃ sabhāgāni avitathato attasuññato dukkarapaṭivedhato ca. Yathāha –
analyzed: sabhāga visabhāgato ti sabbān eva saccāni aññam aññam sabhāgāni avitathataḥ atta suññataḥ dukkara paṭivedhato ca yathā āha
translated: As similar and dissimilar: all the truths are similar to each other as not false, as void of self, and as hard to penetrate, according to:

original: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, ānanda, katamaṃ nu kho dukkarataraṃ vā durabhisambhavataraṃ vā,
analyzed: tam kim maññasi ānanda katamam nu kho dukkarataram vā durabhisambhavataram vā
translated: which is more difficult to penetrate —

original: yo vā dūratova sukhumena tāḷacchiggaḷena asanaṃ atipāteyya poṅkhānupoṅkhaṃ avirādhitaṃ,
analyzed: yaḥ vā dūratas uva su khumena tāḷa chiggaḷena asanam atipāteyya a virādhitam
translated: to shoot an arrow through a very small keyhole from a distance, with the arrow not touching the door-frame,🔽or to penetrate the meaning of this statement:

original: yo vā satadhā bhinnassa vālassa koṭiyā koṭiṃ paṭivijjheyyāti? Etadeva, bhante, dukkaratarañceva
analyzed: yaḥ vā satadhā bhinnassa vālassa koṭiyā koṭim paṭivijjheyyāti etat eva bhante dukkarataram ca iva
translated: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the way leading to the cessation of suffering’?”🔽“Venerable sir, to penetrate the meaning of this statement is certainly more difficult

original: durabhisambhavatarañca, yo vā satadhā bhinnassa vālassa koṭiyā koṭiṃ paṭivijjheyyāti.
analyzed: durabhisambhavatarañca yaḥ vā satadhā bhinnassa vālassa koṭiyā koṭim paṭivijjheyya ati
translated: than to shoot an arrow through a very small keyhole from a distance, with the arrow not touching the door-frame.

original: Tato kho te, ānanda, duppaṭivijjhataraṃ paṭivijjhanti. Ye idaṃ dukkhanti yathābhūtaṃ🔽paṭivijjhanti…pe… ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadāti yathābhūtaṃ paṭivijjhantī”ti.🔽Visabhāgāni salakkhaṇavavatthānato. Purimāni ca dve sabhāgāni duravagāhatthena gambhīrattā
analyzed: tatas kho te ānanda duppaṭivijjhataram paṭivijjhanti ye idam dukkhanti yathābhūtam 🔽paṭivijjhanti pe ayam dukkha nirodha gāminī paṭipadā ati yathābhūtam paṭivijjhanti iti 🔽visabhāgāni sa lakkhaṇa vavatthānato purimāni ca dve sabhāgāni duravagāha atthena gambhīra ttā
translated: “Ananda, they penetrate what is more difficult to penetrate.

original: lokiyattā sāsavattā ca. Visabhāgāni phalahetubhedato pariññeyyappahātabbato ca. Pacchimānipi
analyzed: lokiya ttā sāsava ttā ca visabhāgāni phala hetu bhedato ca pacchimāni pi
translated: because they are mundane, and because they are subject to cankers. They are dissimilar because they are respectively result and cause, and because they are to be fully understood and to be abandoned. The last two are similar

original: dve sabhāgāni gambhīrattena duravagāhattā lokuttarattā anāsavattā ca. Visabhāgāni
analyzed: dve sabhāgāni gambhīra ttena duravagāha ttā lokuttara ttā anāsava ttā ca visabhāgāni
translated: because they are profound, hard to see, supramundane, and free from cankers. They are dissimilar

original: visayavisayībhedato sacchikātabbabhāvetabbato ca. Paṭhamatatiyāni cāpi sabhāgāni
analyzed: visaya visayī bhedato ca paṭhama tatiyāni ca api sa bhāgāni
translated: because they are respectively the object and the subject, and because they are to be realized and to be developed. The first and third are similar🔽because they are stated as result. They are dissimilar because they are respectively formed and unformed. The second and fourth are similar

original: phalāpadesato. Visabhāgāni saṅkhatāsaṅkhatato. Dutiyacatutthāni cāpi sabhāgāni hetuapadesato.
analyzed: phala apadesataḥ visabhāgāni saṅkhata asaṅkhatataḥ dutiya catutthāni ca api sabhāgāni hetu apadesato
translated: because they are stated as cause.🔽They are dissimilar because they are respectively exclusively profitable and exclusively unprofitable. The first and fourth are similar

original: Visabhāgāni ekantakusalākusalato. Paṭhamacatutthāni cāpi sabhāgāni saṅkhatato. Visabhāgāni
analyzed: visabhāgāni ekanta kusala akusalataḥ paṭhama catutthāni ca api sabhāgāni saṅkhatataḥ visabhāgāni
translated: because they are formed. They are dissimilar🔽because they are respectively mundane and supramundane. The second and third are similar

original: lokiyalokuttarato. Dutiyatatiyāni cāpi sabhāgāni nevasekkhānāsekkhabhāvato. Visabhāgāni
analyzed: lokiya lokuttarataḥ dutiya tatiyāni ca api sabhāgāni nevasekkha anāsekkha bhāvataḥ visabhāgāni
translated: because they are neither in training nor beyond training. They are dissimilar

original: sārammaṇānārammaṇato.
analyzed: sa ārammaṇa anārammaṇato
translated: because they are respectively with object and without object.

original: Iti evaṃ pakārehi, nayehi ca vicakkhaṇo;
analyzed: iti evam pakārehi nayehi ca vicakkhaṇaḥ
translated: So by these and other such methods🔽The wise should understand the Noble Truths’

original: Vijaññā ariyasaccānaṃ, sabhāgavisabhāgatanti.
analyzed: vijaññāḥ ariya saccānam sabhāga visabhāga tanti
translated: Similarity and dissimilarity.

original: Iti sādhujanapāmojjatthāya kate visuddhimagge
analyzed: iti sādhu jana pāmojjatthāya kate visuddhi magge
translated: In the Path of Purification composed for the purpose of gladdening the heart of good people,

original: Paññābhāvanādhikāre🔽Indriyasaccaniddeso nāma
analyzed: paññā bhāvanā adhikāre
translated: In the chapter on the development of wisdom🔽The Description of the Faculties and Truths

original: Soḷasamo paricchedo.
analyzed: soḷasamaḥ paricchedo
translated: The chapter on the discernment of the faculties and truths is finished.

original: 17. Paññābhūminiddeso
translated: The chapter on the planes of discernment

original: Paṭiccasamuppādakathā🔽570. Idāni “khandhāyatanadhātuindriyasaccapaṭiccasamuppādādibhedā dhammā bhūmī”ti
analyzed: paṭiccasamuppāda kathā  idāni khandha āyatana dhātu indriya sacca paṭicca samuppāda ādi bhedāḥ dhammāḥ bhūmi iti
translated: The exposition of dependent origination

original: evaṃ vuttesu imissā paññāya bhūmibhūtesu dhammesu yasmā paṭiccasamuppādoceva, ādisaddena
analyzed: evam vuttesu imissā paññāya bhūmi bhūtesu dhammesu yasmā ādi saddena
translated: Now, in the case of the states classed as aggregates, sense bases, elements, faculties, truths, dependent origination, etc., it is the states that are the plane of this discernment, which was said above to have a plane.🔽But since dependent origination itself and the states originated dependently are included by the word “etc.,”

original: saṅgahitā paṭiccasamuppannā dhammā ca avasesā honti, tasmā tesaṃ vaṇṇanākkamo anuppatto.
analyzed: saṅgahitā paṭicca samuppannāḥ dhammāḥ ca avasesāḥ honti tasmā tesam vaṇṇanā kkamaḥ an uppatto
translated: they are left over. So the order of exposition comes to be that of the aggregates, etc.,

original: Tattha avijjādayo tāva dhammā paṭiccasamuppādoti veditabbā. Vuttañhetaṃ bhagavatā –
analyzed: tattha avijjā ādayaḥ tāva dhammā paṭiccasamuppādaḥ ti veditabbā vuttam ha etam bhagavatā
translated: Herein, firstly, the states beginning with ignorance should be understood as dependent origination. For this is said by the Blessed One:

original: “Katamo ca, bhikkhave, paṭiccasamuppādo? Avijjāpaccayā, bhikkhave, saṅkhārā, saṅkhārapaccayā
analyzed: katamaḥ ca bhikkhave paṭiccasamuppādaḥ avijjā paccayāḥ bhikkhave saṅkhārāḥ saṅkhāra paccayāḥ
translated: “And what, bhikkhus, is dependent origination? With ignorance as condition, bhikkhus, there are formations;

original: viññāṇaṃ, viññāṇapaccayā nāmarūpaṃ, nāmarūpapaccayā saḷāyatanaṃ, saḷāyatanapaccayā
analyzed: viññāṇam viññāṇa paccayā nāma rūpam nāma rūpa paccayā saḷāyatanam saḷāyatana paccayā
translated: with formations as condition, consciousness … … with the arising of ignorance, formations arise; with the cessation of ignorance, formations cease” .

original: phasso, phassapaccayā vedanā, vedanāpaccayā taṇhā, taṇhāpaccayā upādānaṃ, upādānapaccayā
analyzed: phassaḥ phassa paccayā vedanā vedanā paccayā taṇhā taṇhā paccayā upādānam upādāna paccayā
translated: Contact is impermanent, bhikkhus, changing, becoming otherwise; feeling is impermanent, bhikkhus, changing, becoming otherwise; craving is impermanent, bhikkhus, changing, becoming otherwise;

original: bhavo, bhavapaccayā jāti, jātipaccayā jarāmaraṇaṃ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā
analyzed: bhavaḥ bhava paccayā jāti jāti paccayā jarā maraṇam soka parideva dukkha domanassa upāyāsā
translated: clinging is impermanent, bhikkhus, changing, becoming otherwise; existence is impermanent, bhikkhus, changing, becoming otherwise; birth is impermanent, bhikkhus, changing, becoming otherwise; aging and death are impermanent, bhikkhus, changing, becoming otherwise.

original: sambhavanti. Evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa samudayo hoti. Ayaṃ vuccati,
analyzed: sambhavanti evam etassa kevalassa dukkha kkhandhassa samudayaḥ hoti ayam vuccati
translated: In this way, bhikkhus, there is the arising of this whole mass of suffering.

original: bhikkhave, paṭiccasamuppādo”ti.
analyzed: bhikkhave paṭiccasamuppādaḥ ti
translated: This, bhikkhus, is called dependent origination.”

original: Jarāmaraṇādayo pana paṭiccasamuppannā dhammāti veditabbā. Vuttañhetaṃ bhagavatā –
analyzed: jarā maraṇa ādayaḥ pana paṭicca samuppannāḥ dhammā ti veditabbāḥ vuttam ha etam bhagavatā
translated: But aging and death, etc., should be understood as states originated dependently. For this is said:

original: “Katame ca, bhikkhave, paṭiccasamuppannā dhammā? Jarāmaraṇaṃ, bhikkhave, aniccaṃ

translated: They want to say it in two ways. For since it occurs for the benefit and welfare of beings, therefore the wise want to return thanks to it, thus it is paccaya . And it occurs together and rightly, not singly or without a cause, thus it is samuppāda . So it is paccaya and it is samuppāda , thus it is paṭiccasamuppāda . Furthermore, it occurs together, thus it is samuppāda ; but it does so only in dependence on a concurrence of conditions, not independently of them, thus it is paṭiccasamuppāda . And since this is a collection of causes that is a condition for that , this is a condition for that , thus this is also paṭiccasamuppāda . Just as in the world sugar is called “sugar-cane” since it is a condition for sugar-cane, and just as in the Dispensation the arising of Buddhas is called “the bliss of Buddhas” since it is a condition for the bliss of Buddhas,

original: uppādo”ti vuccati, tathā paṭiccasamuppādo icceva phalavohārena vuttoti veditabbo.
analyzed: uppādaḥ ti vuccati tathā paṭiccasamuppādo icca iva phala vohārena vutto ti veditabbo
translated: They want to say it in two ways. For since it occurs for the benefit and welfare of beings, therefore the wise want to return thanks to it, thus it is paccaya . And it occurs together and rightly, not singly or without a cause, thus it is samuppāda . So it is paccaya and it is samuppāda , thus it is paccaya samuppāda . Furthermore, it occurs together, thus it is samuppāda ; but it occurs in dependence on a concurrence of conditions, not independently, thus it is paccaya samuppāda . And this is a condition for that , thus it is paccaya ; and because it is a condition for that , this is also called paccaya samuppāda in the way that in the world molasses is called “the condition for phlegm” since it is a condition for phlegm , and in the Dispensation the arising of Buddhas is called “the bliss of the arising of Buddhas” since it is a condition for bliss . translated: In particular, the teaching that proceeds in forward order from the beginning should be understood as proceeding in order to show the occurrence of the various kinds of becoming by means of their respective causes and in order to show the order of arising.

original: dukkhassa attanā adhigatakāraṇasandassanatthaṃ. Yā majjhato paṭṭhāya yāva ādi pavattā,🔽sā āhāranidānavavatthāpanānusārena yāva atītaṃ addhānaṃ atiharitvā puna atītaddhato
analyzed: dukkhassa attanā adhigata kāraṇa sandassana attham yā majjhatas paṭṭhāya yāva ādi pavattā 🔽sā āhāra nidāna vavatthāpana anusārena atītam addhānam atiharitvā punar

translated: is given for the purpose of showing the future life, beginning with the cause of the future life in the present life.🔽Of these, the forward order teaching given from the beginning for the purpose of showing the occurrence of the round by means of its several causes to the person to be trained who is confused about the cause of occurrence

original: 584. Kasmā panettha avijjā ādito vuttā, kiṃ pakativādīnaṃ pakati viya avijjāpi akāraṇaṃ
analyzed: kasmā pana ittha avijjā āditas vuttā kim pakati vādīnam pakati viya avijjā api akāraṇam
translated: But why is ignorance stated as the beginning here? Is ignorance, like the natural order of the natural philosophers, a cause of the world that is not a cause?

analyzed: mūla kāraṇam lokassa ati na akāraṇam āsava samudayā avijjā samudayaḥ iti hi avijjāya
translated: Is it the root-cause of the world? It is not not a cause. For ignorance’s cause is said to be the arising of cankers thus, “With the arising of cankers there is the arising of ignorance” .

original: kāraṇaṃ vuttaṃ. Atthi pana pariyāyo yena mūlakāraṇaṃ siyā, ko pana soti? Vaṭṭakathāya sīsabhāvo.

translated: But there is a method whereby it can be the root-cause, and what is that? It is the state of being the head of the round.

original: Bhagavā hi vaṭṭakathaṃ kathento dve dhamme sīsaṃ katvā katheti, avijjaṃ vā. Yathāha
analyzed: bhagavā hi vaṭṭa katham kathentaḥ dve dhamme sīsam katvā katheti avijjam vā yathā āha
translated: For the Blessed One, when expounding the round, expounds it with these two things as the head, either ignorance or craving for being. As it is said:

translated: “Bhikkhus, no first point of ignorance is discerned, though the result of ignorance is discerned.🔽If it were said, ‘Prior to its arising ignorance existed without a cause,’ that too would be mere words.🔽And if it were said, ‘From the arising of a cause ignorance arises,’ that too would be mere words.

original: samabhavī’ti, evañcetaṃ, bhikkhave, vuccati, atha ca pana paññāyati idappaccayā avijjā”ti.
analyzed: samabhavi iti evañca itam bhikkhave vuccati atha ca pana paññāyati idappaccayā avijjāti
translated: But, bhikkhus, it is said: ‘With the arising of cankers ignorance arises,’ and that is not mere words.

original: Bhavataṇhaṃ vā. Yathāha – “purimā, bhikkhave, koṭi na paññāyati bhavataṇhāya ‘ito
analyzed: bhava taṇham vā yathā āha purimā bhikkhave koṭi na paññāyati bhava taṇhāya itas
translated: “Bhikkhus, no first point of craving for being is discerned, though the result of craving for being is discerned.

original: pubbe bhavataṇhā nāhosi, atha pacchā samabhavī’ti, evañcetaṃ, bhikkhave, vuccati,
analyzed: pubbe bhava taṇhā na ahosi atha pacchā samabhavi iti evam ca itam bhikkhave vuccati
translated: If it were said, ‘Prior to its arising craving for being existed without a cause,’ that too would be mere words.🔽And if it were said, ‘From the arising of a cause craving for being arises,’ that too would be mere words.

original: atha ca pana paññāyati idappaccayā bhavataṇhā”ti.
analyzed: atha ca pana paññāyati idappaccayā bhava taṇhā ati
translated: But, bhikkhus, it is said: ‘With the arising of ignorance craving for being arises,’ and that is not mere words” .

original: 585. Kasmā pana bhagavā vaṭṭakathaṃ kathento ime dve dhamme sīsaṃ katvā kathetīti?
analyzed: kasmā pana bhagavā vaṭṭa katham kathentaḥ ime dve dhamme sīsam katvā katheti iti
translated: Why does the Blessed One, when expounding the round, expound it with these two things as the head?

original: Sugatiduggatigāmino kammassa visesahetubhūtattā. Duggatigāmino hi kammassa visesahetu
analyzed: sugati duggati gāmino kammassa visesa hetu bhūtattā duggati gāmino hi kammassa visesa hetu
translated: Because they are the specific conditions for the kamma that leads to good and bad destinations.

original: avijjā. Kasmā? Yasmā avijjābhibhūto puthujjano aggisantāpalaguḷābhighātaparissamābhibhūtā🔽vajjhagāvī tāya parissamāturatāya nirassādampi attano anatthāvahampi ca uṇhodakapānaṃ🔽viya kilesasantāpato nirassādampi duggatinipātanato ca attano anatthāvahampi pāṇātipātādiṃ
analyzed: avijjā kasmai yasmai avijjā abhibhūtaḥ puthujjanaḥ aggi santāpa laguḷa abhighāta parissama abhibhūtā  vajjhagāvī tāya parissama ātura tāya nirassādampi attanaḥ anattha āvahampi ca uṇha udaka pānam  viya kilesa santāpataḥ duggati nipātanato ca attanaḥ anattha āvaham pi pāṇātipāta ādim
translated: Why? Because the worldling, being overwhelmed by ignorance, is like the cow in the above example, which, because of its great thirst, drinks even hot water that is unpalatable and harmful to itself.

original: anekappakāraṃ duggatigāmikammaṃ ārabhati. Sugatigāmino pana kammassa visesahetu bhavataṇhā.🔽Kasmā? Yasmā bhavataṇhābhibhūto puthujjano sā vuttappakārā gāvī sītūdakataṇhāya saassādaṃ
analyzed: aneka ppakāram duggati gāmi kammam ārabhati sugati gāminaḥ pana kammassa visesa hetu bhava taṇhā  kasmai yasmai bhava taṇhā abhibhūto puthujjano sā vutta ppakārā gāvī sītu udaka taṇhāya
translated: The worldling, because of the thirst for existence, undertakes the various kinds of kamma that lead to an unhappy rebirth, even though it is unpalatable because of the fever of defilements and harmful to himself because it causes him to fall into an unhappy rebirth.🔽But the craving for existence is the cause for the special kind of kamma that leads to a happy rebirth.

original: attano parissamavinodanañca sītūdakapānaṃ viya kilesasantāpavirahato saassādaṃ sugatisampāpanena
analyzed: attano parissama vinodanam ca sītu udaka pānam viya kilesa santāpa virahato sa assādam sugati sampāpanena
translated: Why? Because the worldling, being overwhelmed by the craving for existence, is like the cow in the above example, which, because of its thirst for cool water, drinks cool water that is palatable and refreshing and that removes its thirst.

original: attano duggatidukkhaparissamavinodanañca pāṇātipātā veramaṇiādiṃ anekappakāraṃ sugatigāmikammaṃ ārabhati.
analyzed: attanaḥ duggati dukkha parissama vinodanam ca pāṇa atipātāḥ veramaṇi ādim aneka ppakāram sugati gāmi kammam ārabhati
translated: The worldling, because of the absence of the fever of defilements, undertakes the various kinds of kamma that lead to a happy rebirth, which is palatable and refreshing and removes the suffering of an unhappy rebirth.

original: 586. Etesu pana vaṭṭakathāya sīsabhūtesu dhammesu katthaci bhagavā ekadhammamūlikaṃ🔽desanaṃ deseti. Seyyathidaṃ, “iti kho, bhikkhave, avijjūpanisā saṅkhārā, saṅkhārūpanisaṃ
analyzed: etesu pana vaṭṭa kathāya sīsa bhūtesu dhammesu katthaci bhagavā eka dhamma mūlikam  desanam deseti sā iyyathidam iti kho bhikkhave avijju upanisā saṅkhārā saṅkhāra upanisam
translated: In these things which are the heads of the round, the Blessed One sometimes teaches a teaching with a single thing as its root,🔽as follows: “So, bhikkhus, ignorance is the root-cause of formations, formations are the root-cause of consciousness,

original: viññāṇa”ntiādi. Tathā “upādāniyesu, bhikkhave, dhammesu assādānupassino viharato
analyzed: viññāṇa ntiādi tathā upādāniyesu bhikkhave dhammesu assāda anupassinaḥ viharataḥ

analyzed: taṇhā pavaḍḍhati taṇhā paccayā upādāna nti ādi katthaci ubhaya mūlikam pi seyyathīdam
translated: and so on. Sometimes he teaches with both as root, as follows:

original: “avijjānīvaraṇassa, bhikkhave, bālassa taṇhāya sampayuttassa evamayaṃ kāyo samudāgato.
analyzed: avijjā nīvaraṇassa bhikkhave bālassa taṇhāya sampayuttassa evam ayam kāyaḥ samudāgataḥ
translated: “Bhikkhus, this body of the fool obstructed by ignorance and fettered by craving has come to be.

original: Iti ayañceva kāyo bahiddhā ca nāmarūpaṃ itthetaṃ dvayaṃ. Dvayaṃ paṭicca phasso saḷevāyatanāni,
analyzed: iti ayam ca iva kāyaḥ bahiddhā ca nāma rūpam itthā itam dvayam dvayam paṭicca phassaḥ
translated: This is the duality here. With the duality as condition there is contact. The six bases of contact are the six internal sense bases.

original: yehi phuṭṭho bālo sukhadukkhaṃ paṭisaṃvedetī”tiādi. Tāsu desanāsu “avijjāpaccayā
analyzed: yehi phuṭṭhaḥ bālaḥ sukha dukkham paṭisaṃvedeti itiādi tāsu desanāsu avijjā paccayā

original: saṅkhārā”ti ayamidha avijjāvasena ekadhammamūlikā desanāti veditabbā. Evaṃ tāvettha
analyzed: saṅkhārā ti ayam idha avijjā vasena eka dhamma mūlikā desanā ati veditabbā evam tāva ettha
translated: and so on. Of these teachings, the one with a single thing as its root should be understood here as the teaching with ignorance as its root, stated thus: “With ignorance as condition there are formations” .🔽So far,

analyzed: atthato ti avijjā ādīnam padānam atthato seyyathidam pūretum ayutta ṭṭhena kāya duccarita ādi

analyzed: avindiyam nāma a laddhabbanti attho tam avindiyam vindati iti avijjā tad biparītataḥ
translated: because it is not proper to fulfill it. The meaning is that it is not to be obtained. It is ignorance because it finds that which is not to be attained.

original: kāyasucaritādi vindiyaṃ nāma, taṃ vindiyaṃ na vindatīti avijjā. Khandhānaṃ rāsaṭṭhaṃ,
analyzed: kāya su carita ādi vindiyam nāma tam vindiyam na vindati iti avijjā khandhānam rāsaṭṭham
translated: The opposite of that, “misconduct by way of body,” etc., is called “to be attained.” It is ignorance because it does not find that which is to be attained. It is ignorance because it makes unknown the mass of aggregates,

original: āyatanānaṃ āyatanaṭṭhaṃ, dhātūnaṃ suññaṭṭhaṃ, indriyānaṃ adhipatiyaṭṭhaṃ, saccānaṃ🔽tathaṭṭhaṃ aviditaṃ karotītipi avijjā. Dukkhādīnaṃ pīḷanādivasena vuttaṃ catubbidhaṃ🔽atthaṃ aviditaṃ karotītipi avijjā. Antavirahite saṃsāre sabbayonigatibhavaviññāṇaṭṭhitisattāvāsesu
analyzed: āyatanānam āyatana ṭṭham dhātūnam suñña ṭṭham indriyānam adhipatiya ṭṭham saccānam  tathaṭṭham aviditam karoti iti pi avijjā dukkha ādīnam pīḷana ādi vasena vuttam catubbidham  attham a viditam karoti iti pi avijjā anta virahite saṃsāre sabba yoni gati bhava viññāṇa ṭṭhiti sattā vāsesu
translated: the state of the sense bases as bases, the state of the elements as void, the state of the faculties as dominant, the state of the truths as real,🔽and so on. It is ignorance because it makes unknown the fourfold meaning stated as oppression, etc., in the case of suffering, etc. It is ignorance because it impels beings to all the wombs, destinies, existences, stations of consciousness, and abodes of beings in the samsara which is without discoverable beginning.

original: satte javāpetīti avijjā. Paramatthato avijjamānesu itthipurisādīsu javati, vijjamānesupi
analyzed: satte javāpeti iti avijjā paramatthataḥ a vijjamānesu itthi purisa ādīsu javati vijjamānesu pi
translated: It is ignorance because it impels beings to women, men, etc., which do not exist in the ultimate sense, and because it impels beings to women, men, etc., which do exist in the conventional sense.

original: khandhādīsu na javatīti avijjā. Apica cakkhuviññāṇādīnaṃ vatthārammaṇānaṃ paṭiccasamuppādapaṭiccasamuppannānañca
analyzed: khandha ādīsu na javati iti avijjā apica cakkhu viññāṇa ādīnam vattha ārammaṇānam paṭiccasamuppāda paṭiccasamuppannānam ca
translated: It is ignorance because it does not see the aggregates, etc., as they are. Furthermore, it is ignorance because it conceals the eye-consciousness, etc., and their bases and objects, and it conceals the dependently-originated states that arise in dependence on conditions.

original: dhammānaṃ chādanatopi avijjā.🔽Yaṃ paṭicca phalameti, so paccayo. Paṭiccāti na vinā apaccakkhatvāti attho. Etīti
analyzed: dhammānam chādanataḥ pi avijjā  yam paṭicca phalam eti saḥ paccayaḥ paṭicca ati na vinā a paccakkha tvā ati atthaḥ eti iti
translated: The meaning of “conceals” is the meaning of “ignorance.”🔽The meaning of “arises in dependence on” is the meaning of “condition.” The meaning of “arises” is the meaning of “comes into existence” and “occurs.”

original: uppajjati ceva pavattati cāti attho. Apica upakārakaṭṭho paccayaṭṭho. Avijjā ca sā
analyzed: uppajjati ca iva pavattati ca ati atthaḥ apica upakāraka ṭṭhaḥ paccaya ṭṭhaḥ avijjā ca sā
translated: Moreover, the meaning of “helper” is the meaning of “condition.” Ignorance is a condition,

original: paccayo cāti avijjāpaccayo. Tasmā avijjāpaccayā.
analyzed: paccayaḥ ca ati avijjā paccayaḥ tasmai avijjā paccayā
translated: therefore it is called “ignorance as a condition.”

original: Saṅkhatamabhisaṅkharontīti saṅkhārā. Apica avijjāpaccayā saṅkhārā, saṅkhārasaddena
analyzed: saṅkhatam abhisaṅkharonti iti saṅkhārāḥ api ca avijjā paccayā saṅkhārā saṅkhāra saddena
translated: They form the formed: thus they are formations. Furthermore, formations have ignorance as a condition, and they are also called “formations” because they are included in the category of formations.

original: āgatasaṅkhārāti duvidhā saṅkhārā. Tattha puññāpuññāneñjābhisaṅkhārā tayo, kāyavacīcittasaṅkhārā
analyzed: āgata saṅkhārā ti duvidhā saṅkhārā tattha kāya vacī citta saṅkhārā
translated: There are two kinds of formations: the three kinds of formations, namely, meritorious, demeritorious, and imperturbable, and the three kinds of formations, namely, bodily, verbal, and mental.

original: tayoti ime cha avijjāpaccayā saṅkhārā. Te sabbepi lokiyakusalākusalacetanāmattameva honti.
analyzed: tayo ti ime cha avijjā paccayā saṅkhārā te sabbe pi lokiya kusala akusala cetanā mattam eva honti
translated: These six kinds of formations have ignorance as a condition. All of them are simply mundane wholesome and unwholesome volition.

original: Saṅkhatasaṅkhāro, abhisaṅkhatasaṅkhāro, abhisaṅkharaṇakasaṅkhāro, payogābhisaṅkhāroti🔽ime pana cattāro saṅkhāra-saddena āgatasaṅkhārā. Tattha “aniccā vata saṅkhārā”tiādīsu🔽vuttā sabbepi sappaccayā dhammā saṅkhatasaṅkhārā nāma. Kammanibbattā tebhūmakā rūpārūpadhammā
analyzed: saṅkhata saṅkhāraḥ abhisaṅkhata saṅkhāraḥ abhisaṅkharaṇaka saṅkhāraḥ payoga abhisaṅkhāraḥ iti  ime pana cattāro saṅkhāra saddena āgata saṅkhārā tattha aniccāḥ vata saṅkhārā ti ādīsu  vuttā sabbe api sa paccayāḥ dhammāḥ saṅkhata saṅkhārāḥ nāma kamma nibbattā tebhūmakāḥ rūpa arūpa dhammā
translated: The formed formation, the formed formation as formed, the formation as forming, and the formation as exertion.🔽But these four formations that have come in with the word “formation” are called the formed formation,🔽all formed things with conditions, which are stated in the passage beginning, “Impermanent, alas, are formations” .

original: abhisaṅkhatasaṅkhārāti aṭṭhakathāsu vuttā, tepi “aniccā vata saṅkhārā”ti ettheva
analyzed: abhisaṅkhata saṅkhārā ti aṭṭhakathāsu vuttā te pi aniccāḥ vata saṅkhārā ti ettha eva
translated: The material and immaterial dhammas of the three planes that are generated by kamma are called the formed formation as formed. They too are included here in the passage beginning, “Impermanent, alas, are formations” .

original: saṅgahaṃ gacchanti. Visuṃ pana nesaṃ āgataṭṭhānaṃ na paññāyati. Tebhūmikakusalākusalacetanā🔽pana abhisaṅkharaṇakasaṅkhāroti vuccati, tassa “avijjāgatoyaṃ, bhikkhave, purisapuggalo🔽puññañceva saṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharotī”tiādīsu āgataṭṭhānaṃ paññāyati. Kāyikacetasikaṃ
analyzed: saṅgaham gacchanti visum pana nesam āgata ṭṭhānam na paññāyati tebhūmika kusala akusala cetanā  pana abhisaṅkharaṇaka saṅkhāro ti vuccati tassa a vijjā gataḥ yam bhikkhave purisa puggalo  puññam ca iva saṅkhāram abhisaṅkharoti itiādīsu āgata ṭṭhānam paññāyati kāyika cetasikam
translated: But no separate place of occurrence for them is discerned.🔽But the profitable and unprofitable volition of the three planes is called the formation as forming. Its place of occurrence is discerned in the passage beginning, “Bhikkhus, this person is overcome by ignorance and obsessed by it” .

original: pana vīriyaṃ payogābhisaṅkhāroti vuccati, so “yāvatikā abhisaṅkhārassa gati, tāvatikā
analyzed: pana vīriyam payoga abhisaṅkhāro ti vuccati saḥ yāvatikā abhisaṅkhārassa gati tāvatikā
translated: But bodily and mental energy is called the formation as exertion. Its place of occurrence is discerned in the passage beginning, “As far as there are formations subject to cankers, subject to attachment, so far there is a plane for describing formations” .

original: gantvā akkhāhataṃ maññe aṭṭhāsī”tiādīsu āgato.🔽Na kevalañca eteyeva, aññepi “saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpajjantassa kho, āvuso visākha,
analyzed: gantvā akkha āhatam maññe aṭṭhāsi iti ādīsu āgataḥ  na kevalam ca ete yeva aññe pi saññā vedayita nirodham samāpajjantassa kho āvuso visākha
translated: and “He stood as if nailed to the spot” .

original: bhikkhuno paṭhamaṃ nirujjhati vacīsaṅkhāro, tato kāyasaṅkhāro, tato cittasaṅkhāro”tiādinā🔽nayena saṅkhāra-saddena āgatā aneke saṅkhārā. Tesu natthi so saṅkhāro, yo saṅkhatasaṅkhārehi
analyzed: bhikkhuno paṭhamam nirujjhati vacī saṅkhāro tato kāya saṅkhāro tato citta saṅkhāro tiādinā  nayena saṅkhāra saddena āgatāḥ aneke saṅkhārā tesu natthi so saṅkhāro yaḥ saṅkhata saṅkhārehi
translated: And not only these, but also many other formations have come down in the texts with the word “formation” , such as “When a bhikkhu enters upon the cessation of perception and feeling, friend Visākha, first his bodily formation ceases, then his verbal formation, then his mental formation” ,

original: saṅgahaṃ na gaccheyya, ito paraṃ saṅkhārapaccayā viññāṇantiādīsu vuttaṃ vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: saṅgaham na gaccheyya itas param saṅkhāra paccayā viññāṇam ti ādīsu vuttam vutta nayena iva veditabbam
translated: and so on. There is no formation that does not come under the heading of formed formations. The rest of the passage should be understood in the way already stated.

original: Avutte pana vijānātīti viññāṇaṃ. Namatīti nāmaṃ. Ruppatīti rūpaṃ. Āye tanoti āyatañca🔽nayatīti āyatanaṃ. Phusatīti phasso. Vedayatīti vedanā. Paritassatīti taṇhā. Upādiyatīti
analyzed: a vutte pana vijānāti iti viññāṇam namati iti nāmam ruppati iti rūpam āye tanoti āyatam ca  nayati iti āyatanam phusati iti phassaḥ vedayati iti vedanā paritassati iti taṇhā upādiyati iti
translated: But in the unexpounded triad “It cognizes, thus it is consciousness” , “It bends, thus it is mentality” , “It distorts, thus it is materiality” ,🔽“It extends, thus it is an ‘āyatana’ ” , “It contacts, thus it is contact” , “It feels, thus it is feeling” , “It craves, thus it is craving” ,

original: upādānaṃ. Bhavati bhāvayati cāti bhavo. Jananaṃ jāti. Jiraṇaṃ jarā. Maranti etenāti
analyzed: upādānam bhavati bhāvayati ca ati bhavaḥ jananam jāti jiraṇam jarā maranti etena ati
translated: “It clings, thus it is clinging” , “It becomes, thus it is becoming” , “It generates, thus it is generation” , “It ages, thus it is aging” , “It dies, thus it is death” ,

original: maraṇaṃ. Socanaṃ soko. Paridevanaṃ paridevo. Dukkhayatīti dukkhaṃ. Uppādaṭṭhitivasena
analyzed: maraṇam socanam soko paridevanam paridevaḥ dukkhayati iti dukkham uppāda ṭṭhiti vasena
translated: and death. The sorrowing is sorrow. The lamenting is lamentation. It oppresses is suffering. Or it oppresses by the two kinds of oppression, that is, by arising and by occurrence.

original: vā dvidhā khaṇatītipi dukkhaṃ. Dummanabhāvo domanassaṃ. Bhuso āyāso upāyāso.
analyzed: vā dvidhā dukkham dummana bhāvaḥ domanassam bhusaḥ āyāsaḥ upāyāsaḥ
translated: It oppresses in two ways is suffering. The dejectedness is grief. The great burden is despair.

original: Sambhavantīti abhinibbattanti. Na kevalañca sokādīheva, atha kho sabbapadehi sambhavanti-saddassa
analyzed: sambhavanti iti abhinibbattanti na kevalam ca soka ādīhi iva atha kho sabba padehi sambhavanti saddassa
translated: They come into play is that they are generated. And not only with sorrow, etc., but the word “come into play” should be construed with all the terms.

original: yojanā kātabbā. Itarathā hi “avijjāpaccayā saṅkhārā”ti vutte kiṃ karontīti na paññāyeyya,🔽sambhavantīti pana yojanāya sati avijjā ca sā paccayo cāti avijjāpaccayo. Tasmā avijjāpaccayā
analyzed: yojanā kātabbā itarathā hi avijjā paccayā saṅkhārā ti vutte kim karonti iti na paññāyeyya  sambhavanti iti pana yojanāya sati avijjā ca sā paccayaḥ ca ati avijjā paccayaḥ tasmai avijjā paccayā
translated: For if it were not so, then when it is said, “With ignorance as condition there are formations,” it would not be known what they do.

original: saṅkhārā sambhavantīti paccayapaccayuppannavavatthānaṃ kataṃ hoti. Esa nayo sabbattha.
analyzed: saṅkhārā sambhavanti iti paccaya paccaya uppanna vavatthānam katam hoti esa nayo sabbattha
translated: But when the construction is made with the words “come into play,” then it is known that ignorance is a condition and that formations come into play, so that the distinction between the condition and the conditionally-arisen is made. And so with all the rest.

original: Evanti niddiṭṭhanayanidassanaṃ. Tena avijjādīheva kāraṇehi, na issaranimmānādīhīti
analyzed: evam ti niddiṭṭha naya nidassanam tena avijjā ādīhi iva kāraṇehi na issara nimmāna ādīhi iti
translated: Thus is the showing of the method of exposition. By means of ignorance, etc., as the cause, not by means of a permanent, single, independent God, etc.,

original: dasseti. Etassāti yathāvuttassa. Kevalassāti asammissassa, sakalassa vā. Dukkhakkhandhassāti
analyzed: dassa iti etassa ati yathā vuttassa kevalassa ati asammissassa sakalassa vā dukkha kkhandhassa ati
translated: he shows. Of this: of what has been said. Entire: unmixed, or complete. Mass of suffering:

original: dukkhasamūhassa, na sattassa, na sukhasubhādīnaṃ. Samudayoti nibbatti. Hotīti sambhavati.
analyzed: dukkha samūhassa na sattassa na sukha subha ādīnam samudayo ti nibbatti hoti iti sambhavati
translated: aggregate of suffering, not of a being, not of pleasure, beauty, and so on. Origin: generation. Comes to be: comes into existence.

original: Evamettha atthato viññātabbo vinicchayo.
analyzed: evam ettha atthataḥ viññātabbaḥ vinicchayaḥ
translated: Thus the exposition should be known here as to meaning.

original: 588. Lakkhaṇāditoti avijjādīnaṃ lakkhaṇādito. Seyyathidaṃ – aññāṇalakkhaṇā avijjā,
analyzed: lakkhaṇa āditaḥ ti avijjā ādīnam lakkhaṇa āditaḥ sā iyyathā idam aññāṇa lakkhaṇā avijjā
translated: As to characteristic, etc.: as to the characteristic, etc., of ignorance, and so on. That is to say: ignorance has the characteristic of unknowing,

original: sammohanarasā, chādanapaccupaṭṭhānā, āsavapadaṭṭhānā. Abhisaṅkharaṇalakkhaṇā saṅkhārā,
analyzed: sammohana rasā chādana paccupaṭṭhānāḥ āsava padaṭṭhānāḥ abhisaṅkharaṇa lakkhaṇāḥ saṅkhārāḥ
translated: its function is to delude, its manifestation is to conceal, its proximate cause is the taints. Formations have the characteristic of forming,

original: āyūhanarasā, cetanāpaccupaṭṭhānā, avijjāpadaṭṭhānā. Vijānanalakkhaṇaṃ viññāṇaṃ, pubbaṅgamarasaṃ,
analyzed: āyūhana rasā cetanā paccupaṭṭhānā avijjā padaṭṭhānā vijānana lakkhaṇam viññāṇam pubbaṅgama rasam
translated: their function is to accumulate, their manifestation is volition, their proximate cause is ignorance. Consciousness has the characteristic of cognizing,

original: paṭisandhipaccupaṭṭhānaṃ, saṅkhārapadaṭṭhānaṃ, vatthārammaṇapadaṭṭhānaṃ vā. Namanalakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: paṭisandhi paccupaṭṭhānam saṅkhāra padaṭṭhānam vattha ārammaṇa padaṭṭhānam vā namana lakkhaṇam
translated: its function is to precede , its manifestation is rebirth-linking, its proximate cause is formations, or its proximate cause is the physical basis and object. Mentality has the characteristic of bending ,

original: nāmaṃ, sampayogarasaṃ, avinibbhogapaccupaṭṭhānaṃ, viññāṇapadaṭṭhānaṃ. Ruppanalakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: nāmam sampayoga rasam avinibbhoga paccupaṭṭhānam viññāṇa padaṭṭhānam ruppana lakkhaṇam
translated: its function is to associate, its manifestation is non-division, its proximate cause is consciousness. Materiality has the characteristic of deformation,

original: rūpaṃ, vikiraṇarasaṃ, abyākatapaccupaṭṭhānaṃ, viññāṇapadaṭṭhānaṃ. Āyatanalakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: rūpam vikiraṇa rasam abyākata paccupaṭṭhānam viññāṇa padaṭṭhānam āyatana lakkhaṇam
translated: Materiality has the characteristic of deformation. Its function is to be disarranged. It is manifested as the undeclared. Its proximate cause is consciousness.

original: saḷāyatanaṃ, dassanādirasaṃ, vatthudvārabhāvapaccupaṭṭhānaṃ, nāmarūpapadaṭṭhānaṃ.
translated: The sixfold base has the characteristic of being a sense-sphere. Its function is to see, etc., and to be the door for the arising of contact. It is manifested as the physical basis and the door. Its proximate cause is mentality-materiality.

original: Phusanalakkhaṇo phasso, saṅghaṭṭanaraso, saṅgatipaccupaṭṭhāno, saḷāyatanapadaṭṭhāno.🔽Anubhavanalakkhaṇā vedanā, visayarasasambhogarasā, sukhadukkhapaccupaṭṭhānā, phassapadaṭṭhānā.
analyzed: phusana lakkhaṇo phassaḥ saṅghaṭṭana raso saṅgati paccupaṭṭhāno saḷāyatana padaṭṭhāno  anubhavana lakkhaṇā vedanā visaya rasa sambhoga rasā sukha dukkha paccupaṭṭhānā phassa padaṭṭhānā
translated: Contact has the characteristic of touching. Its function is to impinge. It is manifested as the meeting of the three. Its proximate cause is the sixfold base.🔽Feeling has the characteristic of being sensed. Its function is to experience the stimulus of an object. It is manifested as pleasure and pain. Its proximate cause is contact.

original: Hetulakkhaṇā taṇhā, abhinandanarasā, atittabhāvapaccupaṭṭhānā, vedanāpadaṭṭhānā.
analyzed: hetu lakkhaṇā taṇhā abhinandana rasā a titta bhāva paccupaṭṭhānā vedanā padaṭṭhānā
translated: Craving has the characteristic of seeking. Its function is to delight. It is manifested as strong desire. Its proximate cause is feeling.

original: Gahaṇalakkhaṇaṃ upādānaṃ, amuñcanarasaṃ, taṇhādaḷhattadiṭṭhipaccupaṭṭhānaṃ, taṇhāpadaṭṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: gahaṇa lakkhaṇam upādānam amuñcana rasam taṇhā daḷha tta diṭṭhi paccupaṭṭhānam taṇhā padaṭṭhānam
translated: Clinging has the characteristic of grasping. Its function is not to release. It is manifested as the state of being hard to subdue, and as the state of being a thicket owing to wrong view. Its proximate cause is craving.

original: Kammakammaphalalakkhaṇo bhavo, bhāvanabhavanaraso, kusalākusalābyākatapaccupaṭṭhāno,
analyzed: kamma kamma phala lakkhaṇaḥ bhavaḥ bhāvana bhavana raso kusala akusala abyākata paccupaṭṭhāno
translated: Becoming has the characteristic of kamma and its result. Its function is to cause to be. It is manifested as the state of being formed by profitable, unprofitable, and undeclared kamma.

original: upādānapadaṭṭhāno. Jātiādīnaṃ lakkhaṇādīni saccaniddese vuttanayeneva veditabbāni.
analyzed: upādāna padaṭṭhānaḥ jāti ādīnam lakkhaṇa ādīni sacca niddese vutta nayena iva veditabbāni
translated: Its proximate cause is clinging. The characteristics, etc., of birth, etc., should be understood in the way given in the Description of the Truths .

original: Evamettha lakkhaṇāditopi viññātabbo vinicchayo.
analyzed: evam ettha lakkhaṇa āditaḥ pi viññātabbaḥ vinicchayaḥ
translated: This is how the exposition should be known here by characteristics, etc.🔽As to singlefold, etc.: ignorance is singlefold as not knowing, not seeing, delusion, etc.;

original: 589. Ekavidhāditoti ettha avijjā aññāṇādassanamohādibhāvato ekavidhā. Appaṭipattimicchāpaṭipattito
analyzed: ekavidha āditaḥ ti ettha avijjā aññāṇa dassana moha ādi bhāvataḥ ekavidhā appaṭipatti micchā paṭipattitaḥ
translated: it is twofold as non-practice and wrong practice;🔽so too as with formations and without formations; it is threefold as associated with the three kinds of feeling;

original: duvidhā. Tathā sasaṅkhārāsaṅkhārato. Vedanattayasampayogato tividhā. Catusaccapaṭivedhato🔽catubbidhā. Gatipañcakādīnavacchādanato pañcavidhā. Dvārārammaṇato pana sabbesupi
analyzed: duvidhā tathā sa saṅkhāra asaṅkhārataḥ vedanā ttaya sampayogato tividhā catu sacca paṭivedhato  catubbidhā gati pañcaka ādīnava chādanato pañcavidhā dvāra ārammaṇato pana sabbesu pi
translated: it is fourfold as to be penetrated by the four noble truths;

original: arūpadhammesu chabbidhatā veditabbā.
analyzed: arūpa dhammesu chabbidha tā veditabbā
translated: it is fivefold as concealing the danger in the five kinds of destinies; but as to doors and objects it should be understood as sixfold in all immaterial states.🔽Formations are singlefold as states subject to cankers, states with resultant nature, and so on;

original: Saṅkhārā sāsavavipākadhammadhammādibhāvato ekavidhā. Kusalākusalato duvidhā. Tathā
analyzed: saṅkhārā sa āsava vipāka dhamma dhamma ādi bhāvataḥ ekavidhā kusala akusalataḥ duvidhā tathā
translated: they are twofold as profitable and unprofitable; so too

original: parittamahaggatahīnamajjhimamicchattaniyatāniyatato. Tividhā puññābhisaṅkhārādibhāvato.
analyzed: tividhā puñña abhisaṅkhāra ādi bhāvataḥ
translated: as limited and exalted, as inferior, medium, and medium-superior, and as subject to cankers and not subject to cankers; they are threefold as the formations of merit, of demerit, and of imperturbability;

original: Catubbidhā catuyonisaṃvattanato. Pañcavidhā pañcagatigāmito.
analyzed: catubbidhā catu yoni saṃvattanataḥ pañcavidhā pañca gati gāmitaḥ
translated: they are fourfold as determining the four kinds of generation; they are fivefold as leading to the five kinds of destinies;

original: Viññāṇaṃ lokiyavipākādibhāvato ekavidhaṃ. Sahetukāhetukādito duvidhaṃ. Bhavattayapariyāpannato,
analyzed: viññāṇam lokiya vipāka ādi bhāvataḥ ekavidham sa hetuka ahetuka āditaḥ duvidham bhava taya pariyāpannato
translated: Consciousness is singlefold as mundane resultant, etc.; it is twofold as with root cause and without root cause, etc.; it is threefold as included in the three kinds of becoming,

original: vedanattayasampayogato, ahetukadvihetukatihetukato ca tividhaṃ. Yonigativasena catubbidhaṃ, pañcavidhañca.
analyzed: vedanā ttaya sampayogataḥ ahetuka dvi hetuka ti hetukataḥ ca tividham yoni gati vasena catubbidham pañcavidham ca
translated: It is threefold as associated with the three kinds of feeling, and as without root-cause, with one root-cause, and with two root-causes. It is fourfold and fivefold according to the kinds of destiny and rebirth-linking.

original: Nāmarūpaṃ viññāṇasannissayato kammapaccayato ca ekavidhaṃ. Sārammaṇanārammaṇato duvidhaṃ. Atītādito tividhaṃ. Yonigativasena catubbidhaṃ, pañcavidhañca.
analyzed: nāma rūpam viññāṇa sannissayato kamma paccayato ca ekavidham sa ārammaṇa anārammaṇataḥ duvidham atīta āditaḥ tividham yoni gati vasena catubbidham pañcavidham ca
translated: Name-and-form is singlefold as the support for consciousness and as a condition for kamma. It is twofold as with object and without object. It is threefold according to past, etc. It is fourfold and fivefold according to the kinds of destiny and rebirth-linking.

original: Saḷāyatanaṃ sañjātisamosaraṇaṭṭhānato ekavidhaṃ. Bhūtappasādaviññāṇādito duvidhaṃ.
analyzed: saḷāyatanam sañjāti samosaraṇa ṭhānataḥ ekavidham bhūta ppasāda viññāṇa āditaḥ duvidham
translated: The sixfold base is singlefold as the place of rebirth-linking and of reappearance. It is twofold as the eye sensitive matter, etc., and as the mind-element and mind-consciousness element.

original: Sampattāsampattanobhayagocarato tividhaṃ. Yonigatipariyāpannato catubbidhaṃ pañcavidhañcāti
analyzed: tividham yoni gati pariyāpannataḥ catubbidham pañcavidham ca ati
translated: It is threefold as the domain of the three kinds of being, namely, sensual-desire- bound, form-bound, and formless-bound. It is fourfold and fivefold according to the kinds of destiny and rebirth-linking.

original: iminā nayena phassādīnampi ekavidhādibhāvo veditabboti evamettha ekavidhāditopi viññātabbo vinicchayo.
analyzed: iminā nayena phassa ādīnam pi ekavidha ādi bhāvaḥ veditabbaḥ ti evam ettha ekavidha āditaḥ pi viññātabbaḥ vinicchayaḥ
translated: So too with contact, etc., which should be understood as singlefold, and so on. This is how the exposition should be known here as singlefold, and so on.

original: 590. Aṅgānañca vavatthānāti sokādayo cettha bhavacakkassa avicchedadassanatthaṃ vuttā.
analyzed: aṅgānam ca soka ādayo ca ittha bhava cakkassa a viccheda dassana tham vuttā
translated: As to the definition of the factors: grief, etc., are mentioned here in order to show the unbroken continuity of the round of existence.

original: Jarāmaraṇabbhāhatassa hi bālassa te sambhavanti. Yathāha – “assutavā, bhikkhave,🔽puthujjano sārīrikāya dukkhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno socati kilamati paridevati🔽urattāḷiṃ kandati sammohamāpajjatī”ti. Yāva ca tesaṃ pavatti, tāva avijjāyāti punapi🔽avijjāpaccayā saṅkhārāti sambandhameva hoti bhavacakkaṃ. Tasmā tesaṃ jarāmaraṇeneva
analyzed: jarā maraṇa abbha āhatassa hi bālassa te sambhavanti yathā āha assutavā bhikkhave  puthujjanaḥ sārīrikāya dukkhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno socati kilamati paridevati  urat tāḷim kandati sammoham āpajjati iti yāva ca tesam tāva avijjāya ati puna api  avijjā paccayā saṅkhārā ati sambandham eva hoti bhava cakkam tasmā tesam jarā maraṇena iva
translated: For they occur in the fool who is struck down by ageing and death. As it is said: “Bhikkhus, when the uninstructed worldling is contacted by a painful feeling, he sorrows, grieves and laments, he weeps beating his breast and becomes distraught” . And while they occur, so long as there is ignorance. So the Wheel of Becoming with its twelve factors and three rounds goes on revolving with ignorance as the first factor and ageing-and-death as the last. Therefore: “With ageing-and-death as condition, ignorance” ,🔽🔽

original: ekasaṅkhepaṃ katvā dvādaseva paṭiccasamuppādaṅgānīti veditabbāni. Evamettha aṅgānaṃ🔽vavatthānatopi viññātabbo vinicchayo.
analyzed: eka saṅkhepam katvā dvādasa iva paṭiccasamuppāda aṅgāni iti veditabbāni evam ettha aṅgānam  vavatthānataḥ api viññātabbaḥ vinicchayaḥ
translated: For they occur in a fool who is afflicted by ageing and death. As it is said: “Bhikkhus, when an untaught ordinary man is afflicted by ageing, by sickness, by death, by sorrow and lamentation, pain, grief and despair, he sorrows, grieves and laments, weeps beating his breast and becomes distraught” . And while they occur, so long does ignorance continue. So the Wheel of Becoming turns on with the condition of ignorance as the first term. Therefore it should be understood that the twelve factors of the dependent origination are included in the two, namely, ageing-and-death and ignorance. This is how the exposition should be known here “as to defining of the factors.”

original: Ayaṃ tāvettha saṅkhepakathā.🔽Avijjāpaccayāsaṅkhārapadakathā🔽561. Ayaṃ pana vitthāranayo – avijjāti suttantapariyāyena dukkhādīsu catūsu ṭhānesu
analyzed: ayam tau ettha saṅkhepa kathā  avijjā paccaya asaṅkhāra pada kathā  ayam pana vitthāra nayaḥ suttanta pariyāyena dukkha ādīsu catūsu ṭhānesu
translated: This, firstly, is the brief treatment.🔽The exposition of the clause “With ignorance as condition there are formations” is as follows.🔽As to ignorance: in the Suttanta method it is unknowing about the four truths beginning with suffering,

original: aññāṇaṃ, abhidhammapariyāyena pubbantādīhi saddhiṃ aṭṭhasu. Vuttañhetaṃ “tattha katamā
analyzed: aññāṇam abhidhamma pariyāyena pubbanta ādīhi saddhim aṭṭhasu vuttam ha etam tattha katamā
translated: and in the Abhidhamma method it is unknowing about the past, etc., making eight. For this is said: “Herein, what is ignorance?

original: avijjā, dukkhe aññāṇaṃ…pe… dukkhanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya aññāṇaṃ, pubbante aññāṇaṃ,🔽aparante, pubbantāparante, idappaccayatāpaṭiccasamuppannesu dhammesu aññāṇa”nti.🔽Tattha kiñcāpi ṭhapetvā lokuttaraṃ saccadvayaṃ sesaṭṭhānesu ārammaṇavasena avijjā
analyzed: avijjā dukkhe aññāṇaṃ pe dukkha nirodha gāminiyā paṭipadāya aññāṇaṃ pubbante aññāṇaṃ  apara ante pubbanta apara ante idappaccaya tā paṭicca samuppannesu dhammesu aññāṇanti  tattha kiñca api ṭhapetvā lokuttaram sacca dvayam sesa ṭṭhānesu ārammaṇa vasena avijjā
translated: Not knowing suffering, not knowing the origin of suffering, not knowing the cessation of suffering, not knowing the way leading to the cessation of suffering, not knowing the near shore,🔽not knowing the far shore, not knowing both shores, not knowing the middle, not knowing the beginning, not knowing the end, not knowing conditions, not knowing conditional origination.”🔽Herein, although ignorance is not the object in the case of the two supramundane truths, still it is ignorance of the truths that is called ignorance here.

original: cittasaṅkhāro. Ayaṃ tiko kammāyūhanakkhaṇe puññābhisaṅkhārādīnaṃ dvārato pavattidassanatthaṃ🔽vutto. Kāyaviññattiṃ samuṭṭhāpetvā hi kāyadvārato pavattā aṭṭha kāmāvacarakusalacetanā,🔽dvādasa akusalacetanāti samavīsati cetanā kāyasaṅkhāro nāma. Tā eva vacīviññattiṃ
analyzed: citta saṅkhāraḥ ayam tiko kamma āyūhana khaṇe puñña abhisaṅkhāra ādīnam dvārataḥ pavatti dassana attham  vuttaḥ kāya viññattim samuṭṭhāpetvā hi kāya dvārataḥ pavattā aṭṭha kāmāvacara kusala cetanā  dvādasa akusala cetanā ati sama vīsati cetanā kāya saṅkhāraḥ nāma tāḥ eva vacī viññattim
translated: This triad is stated for the purpose of showing the way in which the three kinds of formations occur by way of the door in the instance of the accumulation of kamma.🔽For the twenty-three kinds of volition, namely, the eight kinds of profitable volition and the twelve kinds of unprofitable volition that occur by way of the bodily door after giving rise to bodily intimation,

original: samuṭṭhāpetvā vacīdvārato pavattā vacīsaṅkhāro nāma. Abhiññācetanā panettha parato
analyzed: samuṭṭhāpetvā vacī dvārataḥ pavattā vacīsaṅkhāro nāma abhiññā cetanā pana ittha paratas
translated: are called bodily formations. The same kinds of volition that occur by way of the verbal door after giving rise to verbal intimation are called verbal formations. But the kinds of volition that are direct knowledges are not included here,

original: viññāṇassa paccayo na hotīti na gahitā. Yathā ca abhiññācetanā, evaṃ uddhaccacetanāpi
analyzed: viññāṇassa paccayaḥ na hoti iti na gahitā yathā ca abhiññā cetanā evam uddhacca cetanā api
translated: because they are not conditions for consciousness. And just as the kinds of volition that are direct knowledges, so too the kinds of volition that are agitation are not conditions for consciousness.

original: na hoti. Tasmā sāpi viññāṇassa paccayabhāve apanetabbā, avijjāpaccayā pana sabbāpetā
analyzed: na hoti tasmā sā api viññāṇassa paccaya bhāve apanetabbā avijjā paccayā pana sabba apetā
translated: Therefore they too should be excluded from the condition for consciousness. But all of them are conditions for consciousness by way of ignorance.

original: honti. Ubhopi viññattiyo asamuṭṭhāpetvā manodvāre uppannā pana sabbāpi ekūnatiṃsati
analyzed: honti ubho pi viññattiyaḥ a samuṭṭhāpetvā manodvāre uppannā pana sabbā api ekūnatiṃsati
translated: But the twenty-nine kinds of volition that arise by way of the mind door without giving rise to either kind of intimation are called mental formations.

original: cetanā cittasaṅkhāroti. Iti ayaṃ tiko purimattikameva pavisatīti atthato puññābhisaṅkhārādīnaṃyeva
analyzed: cetanā citta saṅkhāro ti iti ayam purima tikam eva pavisati iti atthato
translated: Thus this triad falls within the first triad itself. So in meaning the three kinds of formations are only the formations of merit, etc.

original: vasena avijjāya paccayabhāvo veditabbo.
analyzed: vasena avijjāya paccaya bhāvaḥ veditabbo
translated: The conditionality of ignorance should be understood in this way.

original: 593. Tattha siyā – kathaṃ panetaṃ jānitabbaṃ “ime saṅkhārā avijjā paccayā hontī”ti?
analyzed: tattha siyā  katham pana etam jānitabbam ime saṅkhārāḥ avijjā paccayāḥ honti iti
translated: Here it may be asked: But how is it to be known that these formations have ignorance as their condition?

original: Avijjābhāve bhāvato. Yassa hi dukkhādīsu avijjāsaṅkhātaṃ aññāṇaṃ appahīnaṃ hoti,🔽so dukkhe tāva pubbantādīsu ca aññāṇena saṃsāradukkhaṃ sukhasaññāya gahetvā tasseva
analyzed: avijjā abhāve bhāvataḥ yassa hi dukkha ādīsu avijjā saṅkhātam aññāṇam appahīnam hoti  so dukkhe tāva pubbanta ādīsu ca aññāṇena saṃsāra dukkham sukha saññāya gahetvā tassa iva
translated: Because of presence and absence. For in the case of anyone in whom ignorance, called “ignorance about suffering,” etc., is unabandoned,🔽he generates the three kinds of formations that are the cause of suffering, taking the suffering of the round of rebirths, which is due to ignorance about the past, etc., as pleasant owing to ignorance about the past, etc.,

original: hetubhūte tividhepi saṅkhāre ārabhati. Samudaye aññāṇena dukkhahetubhūtepi taṇhāparikkhāre🔽saṅkhāre sukhahetuto maññamāno ārabhati. Nirodhe pana magge ca aññāṇena dukkhassa🔽anirodhabhūtepi gativisese dukkhanirodhasaññī hutvā nirodhassa ca amaggabhūtesupi🔽yaññāmaratapādīsu nirodhamaggasaññī hutvā dukkhanirodhaṃ patthayamāno yaññāmaratapādimukhena
analyzed: hetu bhūte tividhe api saṅkhāre ārabhati samudaye aññāṇena dukkha hetu bhūte api taṇhā parikkhāre  saṅkhāre sukha hetutaḥ maññamānaḥ ārabhati nirodhe pana magge ca aññāṇena dukkhassa  anirodha bhūte api gati visese dukkha nirodha saññī hutvā nirodhassa ca amagga bhūtesu pi  yaññā amaratapādīsu nirodha magga saññī hutvā dukkha nirodham patthayamānaḥ yaññā amaratapādi mukhena
translated: and thinking that the formations that are the requisites of craving, which are the cause of suffering, are the cause of pleasure owing to ignorance about the origin of suffering.

original: tividhepi saṅkhāre ārabhati.
analyzed: tividhe api saṅkhāre ārabhati
translated: But in the case of anyone in whom ignorance about cessation and ignorance about the path are unabandoned, he generates the three kinds of formations that are the cause of suffering, taking the various kinds of rebirth that are not the cessation of suffering as the cessation of suffering owing to ignorance about cessation,🔽and taking sacrifices, etc., that are not the path as the path owing to ignorance about the path, and aspiring to the cessation of suffering.

original: Apica so tāya catūsu saccesu appahīnāvijjatāya visesato jātijarārogamaraṇādianekādīnavavokiṇṇampi
analyzed: apica saḥ tāya catūsu saccesu visesataḥ jāti jarā roga maraṇa ādi aneka ādīnava vokiṇṇam pi
translated: Moreover, he does not know that the suffering called the fruit of merit, which is beset with the manifold dangers of birth, aging, disease, death, etc.,

original: puññaphalasaṅkhātaṃ dukkhaṃ dukkhato ajānanto tassa adhigamāya kāyavacīcittasaṅkhārabhedaṃ🔽puññābhisaṅkhāraṃ ārabhati devaccharakāmako viya maruppapātaṃ. Sukhasammatassāpi🔽ca tassa puññaphalassa ante mahāpariḷāhajanikaṃ vipariṇāmadukkhataṃ appassādatañca
analyzed: puñña phala saṅkhātam dukkham dukkhataḥ a jānantaḥ tassa adhigamāya kāya vacī citta saṅkhāra bhedam  puñña abhisaṅkhāram ārabhati deva chara kāmakaḥ viya maru ppapātam sukha sammatassa api  ca tassa puñña phalassa ante mahā pariḷāha janikam vipariṇāma dukkha taṃ appassāda tañca
translated: is suffering because of the ignorance that has not been eliminated in him with regard to the four truths. original: 603. Paṭhamataraṃ uppajjitvā vattamānabhāvena upakārako dhammo purejātapaccayo. So🔽pañcadvāre vatthārammaṇahadayavatthuvasena ekādasavidho hoti. Yathāha – “cakkhāyatanaṃ🔽cakkhuviññāṇadhātuyā taṃsampayuttakānañca dhammānaṃ purejātapaccayena paccayo. Sota…pe…

translated: A state that is helpful by occurring earlier and continuing to be present is a prenascence condition.🔽It is of eleven kinds as object-base-door, object-object, and heart-basis,

original: taṃsampayuttakānañca dhammānaṃ purejātapaccayena paccayo. Rūpa, sadda, gandha, rasa,🔽phoṭṭhabbāyatanaṃ manodhātuyā. Yaṃ rūpaṃ nissāya manodhātu ca manoviññāṇadhātu ca

original: paccayo. Manoviññāṇadhātuyā taṃsampayuttakānañca dhammānaṃ kiñcikāle purejātapaccayena

translated: The mind-consciousness element and the states associated with it are, at the time of the first impulsion, a condition, as a pre-nascence condition, for the material instances that arise together with the impulsions.

original: paccayo. Kiñcikāle na purejātapaccayena paccayo”ti.

original: 604. Purejātānaṃ rūpadhammānaṃ upatthambhakattena upakārako arūpadhammo pacchājātapaccayo🔽gijjhapotakasarīrānaṃ āhārāsācetanā viya. Tena vuttaṃ “pacchājātā cittacetasikā dhammā
analyzed: purejātānam rūpa dhammānam upatthambhaka ttena upakārakaḥ arūpa dhammaḥ pacchājāta paccayo  gijjha potaka sarīrānaṃ viya tena vuttam pacchājātāḥ citta cetasikāḥ dhammāḥ
