translated: Contact touches the contacted and is a condition for feeling. Feeling feels the felt and is a condition for craving. Craving craves the craved and is a condition for clinging. Clinging clings to the clung-to and is a condition for existence. Existence exists in the existent and is a condition for birth. Birth gives birth to the born and is a condition for aging and death. Aging ages the aged and is a condition for death. Death causes the dead to die and is a condition for sorrow, etc. Sorrow sorrows the sorrowful and is a condition for lamentation. Lamentation laments the lamented and is a condition for pain. Pain pains the pained and is a condition for grief. Grief grieves the grieved and is a condition for despair. Despair despairs the desperate and is a condition for the whole mass of suffering. Thus this should be understood as to condition.

original: paccayo ca hoti phassassa. Phassopi ārammaṇañca phusati, paccayo ca hoti vedanāya.
analyzed: paccayaḥ ca hoti phassassa phassaḥ api ārammaṇañca phusati paccayaḥ ca hoti vedanāya
translated: And it is a condition for contact. Contact too contacts the object and is a condition for feeling.

original: Vedanāpi ārammaṇarasañca anubhavati, paccayo ca hoti taṇhāya. Taṇhāpi rajjanīye ca
analyzed: vedanā api ārammaṇa rasañca anubhavati paccayo ca hoti taṇhāya taṇhā api rajjanīye ca
translated: Feeling too experiences the object’s taste and is a condition for craving. Craving too lusts after lust-arousing things

original: dhamme rajjati, paccayo ca hoti upādānassa. Upādānampi upādāniye ca dhamme upādiyati,
analyzed: dhamme rajjati paccayaḥ ca hoti upādānassa upādānam pi upādāniye ca dhamme upādiyati
translated: and is a condition for assuming. Assuming too assumes things that can be assumed

original: paccayo ca hoti bhavassa. Bhavopi nānāgatīsu ca vikkhipati, paccayo ca hoti jātiyā.
analyzed: paccayaḥ ca hoti bhavassa bhavaḥ api nānā gatīsu ca vikkhipati paccayaḥ ca hoti jātiyā
translated: and is a condition for being. Being too distributes itself among the various future lives and is a condition for birth.

original: Jātipi khandhe ca janeti tesaṃ abhinibbattibhāvena pavattattā, paccayo ca hoti jarāmaraṇassa.
analyzed: khandhe ca janeti tesam abhinibbatti bhāvena pavatta ttā paccayaḥ ca hoti jarā maraṇassa
translated: Birth too generates the aggregates, occurring as it does by the generation of those aggregates, and is a condition for ageing and death.

original: Jarāmaraṇampi khandhānaṃ pākabhedabhāvañca adhitiṭṭhati, paccayo ca hoti bhavantarapātubhāvāya
analyzed: jarā maraṇam pi khandhānam pāka bheda bhāvañca adhitiṭṭhati paccayo ca hoti bhavantara pātubhāvāya
translated: Ageing and death too maintain the state of ripening and dissolution of the aggregates and are a condition for the manifestation of the next becoming.

original: sokādīnaṃ adhiṭṭhānattā. Tasmā sabbapadesu dvedhā pavattikiccatopi idaṃ viññātabbaṃ yathārahaṃ.
analyzed: soka ādīnam adhiṭṭhāna ttā tasmā sabba padesu dvedhā pavatti kiccataḥ pi idam viññātabbam yathāraham
translated: And they maintain the state of grief, etc., too, by being their foundation. So this should be understood in all instances according to the way of looking at it in two ways as to function.

original: 657. Yasmā cettha avijjāpaccayā saṅkhārāti idaṃ kārakadassananivāraṇaṃ. Saṅkhārapaccayā🔽viññāṇanti attasaṅkantidassananivāraṇaṃ. Viññāṇapaccayā nāmarūpanti “attā”tiparikappitavatthubhedadassanato🔽ghanasaññānivāraṇaṃ. Nāmarūpapaccayā saḷāyatanantiādi attā passati…pe… vijānāti,🔽phusati, vedayati, taṇhiyati, upādiyati, bhavati, jāyati, jīyati, mīyatītievamādidassananivāraṇaṃ.
analyzed: yasmai ca ittha avijjā paccayā saṅkhārā ati idam kāraka dassana nivāraṇam saṅkhāra paccayā  viññāṇanti atta saṅkanti dassana nivāraṇam viññāṇa paccayā nāma rūpam ti attā ati parikappita vatthu bheda dassanato  ghana saññā nivāraṇam nāma rūpa paccayā attā vijānāti  phusati vedayati taṇhiyati upādiyati bhavati jāyati jīyati mīyati iti evamādi dassana nivāraṇam
translated: Now, as to the words “With ignorance as condition there are formations”: this is a prevention of seeing a doer. With formations as condition, consciousness: this is a prevention of seeing a self. With consciousness as condition, mentality-materiality: this is a prevention of the perception of compactness because it shows the analysis of the “self” into its different components. With mentality-materiality as condition, the sixfold base: this is a prevention of the seeing of the self as a seer, etc., as a feeler, as a cognizer, as a hearer, as a smeller, as a taster, as a toucher, as a conceiver, as a determiner, as a knower, as a witness, as a master, as a doer, as an origin- ator, as an enjoyer, as a possessor of the deeds, as one who experiences the results of the deeds. With the sixfold base as condition, contact: this is a prevention of the seeing of the self as one who sees, etc., as one who touches, as one who feels, as one who craves, as one who clings, as one who becomes, as one who is born, as one who ages, as one who dies.🔽🔽

original: Tasmā micchādassananivāraṇatopetaṃ bhavacakkaṃ viññātabbaṃ yathārahaṃ.🔽658. Yasmā panettha salakkhaṇasāmaññalakkhaṇavasena dhammānaṃ adassanato andho viya🔽avijjā. Andhassa upakkhalanaṃ viya avijjāpaccayā saṅkhārā. Upakkhalitassa patanaṃ🔽viya saṅkhārapaccayā viññāṇaṃ. Patitassa gaṇḍapātubhāvo viya viññāṇapaccayā nāmarūpaṃ.
analyzed: tasmā micchā dassana nivāraṇa tā upetam bhava cakkam viññātabbam yathāraham 🔽yasmā pana ittha sa lakkhaṇa sāmañña lakkhaṇa vasena dhammānam a dassanataḥ andhaḥ viya 🔽avijjā andhassa upakkhalanam viya avijjā paccayā saṅkhārāḥ upakkhalitassa patanam 🔽viya saṅkhāra paccayā viññāṇam patitassa gaṇḍa pātubhāvaḥ viya viññāṇa paccayā nāma rūpam
translated: But here, since ignorance is a condition for formations, it prevents the seeing of a doer. Since formations are a condition for consciousness, it prevents the seeing of the self’s migration. Since consciousness is a condition for mentality-materiality, it prevents the seeing of the various states that are assumed to be a self. Since mentality-materiality is a condition for the sixfold base, it prevents the seeing of the self as a single unit. Since the sixfold base is a condition for contact, it prevents the seeing of the self as a single unit. Since contact is a condition for feeling, it prevents the seeing of the self as a single unit. Since feeling is a condition for craving, it prevents the seeing of the self as a single unit. Since craving is a condition for clinging, it prevents the seeing of the self as a single unit. Since clinging is a condition for becoming, it prevents the seeing of the self as a single unit. Since becoming is a condition for birth, it prevents the seeing of the self as a single unit. Since birth is a condition for ageing and death, it prevents the seeing of the self as a single unit. Since ageing and death are a condition for sorrow, etc., it prevents the seeing of the self as a single unit. Since sorrow, etc., are a condition for the search for a self, it prevents the seeing of the self as a single unit. Since the search for a self is a condition for the search for sensual pleasures, it prevents the seeing of the self as a single unit. Since the search for sensual pleasures is a condition for sensual desire, it prevents the seeing of the self as a single unit. Since sensual desire is a condition for the pursuit of sensual desires, it prevents the seeing of the self as a single unit. Since the pursuit of sensual desires is a condition for gain, it prevents the seeing of the self as a single unit. Since gain is a condition for grief, etc., it prevents the seeing of the self as a single unit. Since grief, etc., are a condition for ignorance, it prevents the seeing of the self as a single unit. Since ignorance is a condition for formations, it prevents the seeing of the self as a single unit. Since formations are a condition for consciousness, it prevents the seeing of the self’s migration. Since consciousness is a condition for mentality-materiality, it prevents the seeing of the various states that are assumed to be a self. Since mentality-materiality is a condition for the six

original: Gaṇḍabhedapīḷakā viya nāmarūpapaccayā saḷāyatanaṃ. Gaṇḍapīḷakāghaṭṭanaṃ viya saḷāyatanapaccayā🔽phasso. Ghaṭṭanadukkhaṃ viya phassapaccayā vedanā, dukkhassa paṭikārābhilāso viya
analyzed: gaṇḍa bheda pīḷakā viya nāma rūpa paccayā saḷāyatanam gaṇḍa pīḷakā ghaṭṭanam viya saḷāyatana paccayā  phassaḥ ghaṭṭana dukkham viya phassa paccayā vedanā dukkhassa paṭikāra abhilāso viya
translated: Contact has the sixfold base as its condition in the way the contact of the boils has the contact of the abscesses as its condition.🔽Feeling has contact as its condition in the way the pain has the contact as its condition. Craving has feeling as its condition in the way the desire for relief has the pain as its condition.

original: vedanāpaccayā taṇhā. Paṭikārābhilāsena asappāyaggahaṇaṃ viya taṇhāpaccayā upādānaṃ.🔽Upādiṇṇaasappāyālepanaṃ viya upādānapaccayā bhavo. Asappāyālepanena gaṇḍavikārapātubhāvo
analyzed: vedanā paccayā taṇhā paṭikāra abhilāsena asappāya ggahaṇam viya taṇhā paccayā upādānam  upādiṇṇa asappāya ālepanam viya upādāna paccayā bhavaḥ asappāya ālepanena gaṇḍa vikāra pātubhāvo
translated: Clinging has craving as its condition in the way the taking of unsuitable food has the desire for relief as its condition.🔽Becoming has clinging as its condition in the way the spreading of the unsuitable ointment has the taking of the unsuitable food as its condition.

original: viya bhavapaccayā jāti. Gaṇḍavikārato gaṇḍabhedo viya jātipaccayā jarāmaraṇaṃ. Yasmā
analyzed: viya bhava paccayā gaṇḍa vikārataḥ gaṇḍa bhedaḥ viya jāti paccayā jarā maraṇam yasmā
translated: Birth has becoming as its condition in the way the manifestation of the boil has the spreading of the unsuitable ointment as its condition. Aging-and-death has birth as its condition in the way the bursting of the boil has the manifestation of the boil as its condition.

original: vā panettha avijjā appaṭipattimicchāpaṭipattibhāvena satte abhibhavati paṭalaṃ viya
analyzed: vā pana ittha avijjā appaṭipattim icchā paṭipatti bhāvena satte abhibhavati paṭalam viya
translated: Or alternatively, ignorance overpowers beings by means of the modes of non-contention and wrong contention, as the cataract overpowers the eye.

original: akkhīni. Tadabhibhūto ca bālo punabbhavikehi saṅkhārehi attānaṃ veṭheti kosakārakimi
analyzed: akkhīni tad abhibhūtaḥ ca bālaḥ punabbhavikehi saṅkhārehi attānam veṭheti
translated: And the fool, being overpowered by it, wraps himself up in volitions that lead to renewed existence, as the caterpillar does with its web.

original: viya kosappadesehi. Saṅkhārapariggahitaṃ viññāṇaṃ gatīsu patiṭṭhaṃ labhati pariṇāyakapariggahito
analyzed: viya kosa ppadesehi saṅkhāra pariggahitam viññāṇam gatīsu patiṭṭham labhati pariṇāyaka pariggahitaḥ
translated: as with the districts of Kosala. Consciousness, which is accompanied by formations, obtains a footing in the destinies as consciousness, which is accompanied by the conditions for rebirth, does in rebirth-linking.

original: viya rājakumāro rajje. Upapattinimittaparikappanato viññāṇaṃ paṭisandhiyaṃ anekappakāraṃ
analyzed: viya rāja kumāraḥ rajje upapatti nimitta parikappanataḥ viññāṇam paṭisandhiyam aneka ppakāram
translated: as with the prince accompanied by his escort being established in the kingdom. Consciousness, which is accompanied by the signs of the rebirth-linking, produces the various kinds of mentality-materiality in rebirth-linking.

original: nāmarūpaṃ abhinibbatteti māyākāro viya māyaṃ. Nāmarūpe patiṭṭhitaṃ saḷāyatanaṃ vuddhiṃ
analyzed: nāma rūpam abhinibbattā iti māyākāraḥ viya māyam nāma rūpe patiṭṭhitam saḷāyatanam vuddhim
translated: as a magician does a magical creation. The sixfold base, which is established in mentality-materiality, reaches growth, increase, and fulfilment.

original: virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ pāpuṇāti subhūmiyaṃ patiṭṭhito vanappagumbo viya. Āyatanaghaṭṭanato🔽phasso jāyati araṇisahitābhimanthanato aggi viya. Phassena phuṭṭhassa vedanā pātubhavati
analyzed: virūḷhim vepullam pāpuṇāti subhūmiyam patiṭṭhitaḥ vanappagumbaḥ viya āyatana ghaṭṭanato  phassaḥ jāyati araṇi sahita abhimanthanataḥ aggi viya phassena phuṭṭhassa vedanā pātubhavati
translated: as a tree in a good field does. Contact arises from the impingement of the three.🔽as fire does from the rubbing together of two sticks. Feeling occurs in one who is touched by contact.🔽as burning does in one touched by fire. Craving increases in one who feels.

original: agginā phuṭṭhassa dāho viya. Vedayamānassa taṇhā pavaḍḍhati loṇūdakaṃ pivato pipāsā🔽viya. Tasito bhavesu abhilāsaṃ karoti pipāsito viya pānīye. Tadassupādānaṃ, upādānena
analyzed: agginā phuṭṭhassa dāhaḥ viya vedayamānassa taṇhā pavaḍḍhati loṇūdakam pivataḥ pipāsā  viya tasitaḥ bhavesu abhilāsam karoti pipāsitaḥ viya pānīye tat assa upādānam upādānena
translated: as thirst does in one who drinks salt water. The one who is tormented longs for the kinds of becoming.🔽as the thirsty man for water. That is his clinging.🔽as the fish is for the bait through greed for the food. When there is becoming, there is birth.

original: bhavaṃ upādiyati āmisalobhena maccho baḷisaṃ viya. Bhave sati jāti hoti bīje sati
analyzed: bhavam āmisa lobhena macchaḥ baḷisam bhave sati jāti hoti bīje sati
translated: as when there is a seed there is a shoot.

original: aṅkuro viya. Jātassa avassaṃ jarāmaraṇaṃ uppannassa rukkhassa patanaṃ viya. Tasmā
analyzed: aṅkuraḥ viya jātassa avassam jarā maraṇam uppannassa rukkhassa patanam viya tasmā
translated: like the sprout. And aging-and-death is inevitable for one who has been born, like the falling of the fruits of trees when they are ripe.

original: evaṃ upamāhipetaṃ bhavacakkaṃ viññātabbaṃ yathārahaṃ.🔽659. Yasmā ca bhagavatā atthatopi dhammatopi desanatopi paṭivedhatopi gambhīrabhāvaṃ
analyzed: evam bhava cakkam viññātabbam yathāraham  yasmā ca bhagavatā atthataḥ api dhammataḥ api desanataḥ api paṭivedhataḥ api gambhīra bhāvam
translated: So this Wheel of Becoming should be known as it really is by means of these similes.🔽And since the Blessed One said: “Deep, I say, is this dependent origination, and deep its appearance” , referring to its profundity in the following five aspects,

original: sandhāya “gambhīro cāyaṃ, ānanda, paṭiccasamuppādo gambhīrāvabhāso cā”ti vuttaṃ,
analyzed: sandhāya gambhīraḥ ca ayam ānanda paṭiccasamuppādaḥ gambhīra avabhāso ca ati vuttam
translated: namely, as meaning, as law, as teaching, as penetration, and as consecutiveness,

original: tasmā gambhīrabhedatopetaṃ bhavacakkaṃ viññātabbaṃ yathārahaṃ.
analyzed: tasmā gambhīra bheda tā upetam bhava cakkam viññātabbam yathāraham
translated: therefore this Wheel of Becoming should be known as it really is by means of its profundity in these five aspects.

original: Tattha yasmā na jātito jarāmaraṇaṃ na hoti, na ca jātiṃ vinā aññato hoti, itthañca🔽jātito samudāgacchatīti evaṃ jātipaccayasamudāgataṭṭhassa duravabodhanīyato jarāmaraṇassa
analyzed: tattha yasmā na jātitaḥ jarā maraṇam na hoti na ca jātim vinā aññatas hoti itthat ca  jātitaḥ samudāgacchati iti evam jāti paccaya samudāgata ṭṭhassa duravabodhanīyataḥ jarā maraṇassa
translated: Herein, aging-and-death does not come about without being born, nor from being born does it come about from anything else, but rather:🔽It comes about only from being born. So the meaning of aging-and-death as arisen with birth as its condition is hard to see,

original: jātipaccayasambhūtasamudāgataṭṭho gambhīro. Tathā jātiyā bhavapaccaya…pe… saṅkhārānaṃ
analyzed: jāti paccaya sambhūta samudāgata ṭṭho gambhīro tathā jātiyā bhava paccaya pe saṅkhārānaṃ
translated: and the meaning of aging-and-death as arisen with birth as its source, as arisen with birth as its origin, as arisen with birth as its cause, as arisen with birth as its impetus, as arisen with birth as its means, as arisen with birth as its manner, is deep. So too, the meaning of birth as arisen with becoming as its condition … the meaning of formations as arisen with ignorance as their condition …

original: avijjāpaccayasambhūtasamudāgataṭṭho gambhīro. Tasmā idaṃ bhavacakkaṃ atthagambhīranti🔽ayaṃ tāvettha atthagambhīratā. Hetuphalañhi atthoti vuccati. Yathāha – “hetuphale
analyzed: avijjā paccaya sambhūta samudāgata ṭṭhaḥ gambhīro tasmai idam bhava cakkam attha gambhīran ti  ayam tāva ettha attha gambhīra tā hetu phalam hi attho ti vuccati yathā āha hetu phale
translated: So this round of becoming is deep in meaning.

original: ñāṇaṃ atthapaṭisambhidā”ti.🔽Yasmā pana yenākārena yadavatthā ca avijjā tesaṃ tesaṃ saṅkhārānaṃ paccayo hoti,
analyzed: ñāṇam attha paṭisambhidā ti  yasmā pana yena ākārena yad avatthā ca avijjā tesam tesam saṅkhārānam paccayaḥ hoti
translated: This is the depth of meaning here. For cause and fruit are called “meaning,” according to the text: “Knowledge of cause and fruit is the discrimination of meaning” .🔽But the meaning of condition in the sense of cause is deep in the case of ignorance as condition for formations, etc.,

original: tassa duravabodhanīyato avijjāya saṅkhārānaṃ paccayaṭṭho gambhīro. Tathā saṅkhārānaṃ…pe…
analyzed: tassa duravabodhanīyataḥ avijjāya saṅkhārānam paccaya ṭṭhaḥ gambhīraḥ tathā saṅkhārānam pe
translated: because it is hard to know in what way and in what period ignorance is a condition for formations, etc.,

original: jātiyā jarāmaraṇassa paccayaṭṭho gambhīro, tasmā idaṃ bhavacakkaṃ dhammagambhīranti
analyzed: jātiyāḥ jarā maraṇassa paccaya ṭṭhaḥ gambhīro tasmai idam bhava cakkam dhamma gambhīranti
translated: and in what way and in what period formations, etc., are a condition for birth, etc., and for ageing-and-death. So this round of becoming is deep in ideas.

original: ayamettha dhammagambhīratā. Hetuno hi dhammoti nāmaṃ. Yathāha – “hetumhi ñāṇaṃ dhammapaṭisambhidā”ti.
analyzed: ayam ettha dhamma gambhīra tā hetunaḥ hi dhammaḥ ti nāmam yathā āha hetumhi ñāṇam dhamma paṭisambhidā ti
translated: This is the depth of ideas here. For the name “idea” is given to the cause, according to the text: “Knowledge of the cause is the discrimination of ideas” .

original: Yasmā cassa tena tena kāraṇena tathā tathā pavattetabbattā desanāpi gambhīrā, na
analyzed: yasmā ca ssa tena tena kāraṇena tathā tathā desanā api gambhīrā na
translated: And because the teaching must be conducted in such and such a way for such and such a reason, the teaching is also deep.

original: tattha sabbaññutaññāṇato aññaṃ ñāṇaṃ patiṭṭhaṃ labhati. Tathāhetaṃ katthaci sutte
analyzed: tattha sabbaññu ta ññāṇataḥ aññam ñāṇam patiṭṭham labhati tathā āha etam katthaci sutte
translated: Herein, knowledge other than the knowledge of omniscience finds support in the knowledge of omniscience. So it is said in some sutta:

original: anulomato, katthaci paṭilomato, katthaci anulomapaṭilomato, katthaci vemajjhato paṭṭhāya
analyzed: anulomataḥ katthaci paṭilomataḥ katthaci anuloma paṭilomataḥ katthaci vemajjhato paṭṭhāya
translated: sometimes in forward order, sometimes in reverse order, sometimes in forward and reverse order, sometimes from the middle to the end and from the end to the middle,

original: anulomato vā paṭilomato vā, katthaci tisandhicatusaṅkhepaṃ, katthaci dvisandhitisaṅkhepaṃ,
analyzed: anulomataḥ vā paṭilomataḥ vā katthaci ti sandhi catu saṅkhepam katthaci dvi sandhi ti saṅkhepam
translated: sometimes with three links and four sections, sometimes with two links and three sections,

original: katthaci ekasandhidvisaṅkhepaṃ desitaṃ, tasmā idaṃ bhavacakkaṃ desanāgambhīranti
analyzed: katthaci eka sandhi dvi saṅkhepam desitam tasmai idam bhava cakkam desanā gambhīram ti
translated: sometimes with one link and two sections. Therefore this Wheel of Becoming is deep in teaching.

original: ayaṃ desanāgambhīratā.🔽Yasmā cettha yo so avijjādīnaṃ sabhāvo, yena paṭividdhena avijjādayo sammā salakkhaṇato
analyzed: ayam desanā gambhīra tā  yasmā ca ittha yaḥ saḥ avijjā ādīnam sabhāvaḥ yena paṭividdhena avijjā ādayo sammā salakkhaṇato
translated: This is its depth of teaching.

original: paṭividdhā honti, so duppariyogāhattā gambhīro, tasmā idaṃ bhavacakkaṃ paṭivedhagambhīraṃ.
analyzed: paṭividdhāḥ honti tasmai idam bhava cakkam paṭivedha gambhīram
translated: But it is deep in penetration too, since the specific nature of ignorance, etc., which is penetrated in such a way that ignorance, etc., are rightly penetrated by its being penetrated, is hard to penetrate because it is not within the compass of the disciples’ knowledge. Therefore this Wheel of Becoming is deep in penetration.

original: Tathā hettha avijjāya aññāṇādassanasaccāsampaṭivedhaṭṭho gambhīro, saṅkhārānaṃ abhisaṅkharaṇāyūhanasarāgavirāgaṭṭho,
analyzed: tathā ha ittha avijjāya aññāṇa a dassana sacca a sampaṭivedha ṭṭho gambhīraḥ saṅkhārānaṃ abhisaṅkharaṇa a yūhana sa rāga virāga ṭṭho
translated: And here ignorance is deep in the sense of non-penetration, non-seeing, and non-discovery of the four noble truths; formations are deep in the sense of forming, accumulating, and passionlessness; consciousness is deep in the sense of being conscious, of being the forerunner, and of being the appearance of an object;

original: viññāṇassa suññataabyāpāraasaṅkantipaṭisandhipātubhāvaṭṭho, nāmarūpassa ekuppādavinibbhogāvinibbhoganamanaruppanaṭṭho,
analyzed: viññāṇassa suññata a byāpāra asaṅkanti paṭisandhi pātubhāva ṭho nāma rūpassa eka uppāda vinibbhoga avinibbhoga namana ruppana ṭho
translated: The meaning of the emptiness of consciousness is the meaning of non-doing, non-afflicting, non-interacting, rebirth-linking, and manifestation. The meaning of mentality-materiality is the meaning of arising together, non-division, non-separation, bending, and deformation.

original: saḷāyatanassa adhipatilokadvārakhettavisayibhāvaṭṭho, phassassa phusanasaṅghaṭṭanasaṅgatisannipātaṭṭho,
analyzed: saḷāyatanassa adhipati loka dvāra khetta visayi bhāva ṭho phassassa phusana saṅghaṭṭana saṅgati sannipāta ṭho
translated: The meaning of the sixfold base is the meaning of predominance, world, door, field, and possessor of an object. The meaning of contact is the meaning of touching, impingement, meeting, and conjunction.

original: vedanāya ārammaṇarasānubhavanasukhadukkhamajjhattabhāvanijjīvavedayitaṭṭho. Taṇhāya
analyzed: vedanāya taṇhāya
translated: The meaning of feeling is the meaning of experiencing the taste of an object, and of pleasant, painful, and neither-painful-nor-pleasant states, of living, and of being felt. The meaning of craving is

original: abhinanditajjhosānasaritālatānadītaṇhāsamuddaduppūraṭṭho, upādānassa ādānaggahaṇābhinivesaparāmāsaduratikkamaṭṭho,
analyzed: abhinandita jhosāna sarita alatā nadī taṇhā samudda duppūra aṭṭho upādānassa ādāna ggahaṇa abhinivesa parāmāsa duratikkamaṭṭho
translated: the meaning of delighting, cleaving, flowing, streaming, and flooding, and of filling up the ocean of craving. The meaning of assuming is the meaning of grasping, holding, cleaving, and not letting go.

original: bhavassa āyūhanābhisaṅkharaṇayonigatiṭhitinivāsesukhipanaṭṭho, jātiyā jāti sañjāti
analyzed: bhavassa āyūhana abhisaṅkharaṇa yoni gati ṭhiti nivāse su khipana ṭhaḥ jātiyā jāti sañjāti
translated: The meaning of being is the meaning of accumulating, determining, womb, destiny, station, and abode, and of projecting. The meaning of birth is the meaning of birth, rebirth,

original: okkanti nibbatti pātubhāvaṭṭho, jarāmaraṇassa khayavayabhedavipariṇāmaṭṭho gambhīroti
analyzed: okkanti nibbatti pātubhāva ṭṭhaḥ jarā maraṇassa khaya vaya bheda vipariṇāma ṭṭhaḥ gambhīraḥ ti
translated: descent into the womb, rebirth, and manifestation. The meaning of ageing-and-death is the meaning of exhaustion, change, dissolution, and alteration. Deep is

original: ayamettha paṭivedhagambhīratā.
analyzed: ayam ettha paṭivedha gambhīra tā
translated: the meaning of penetration here.

original: 660. Yasmā panettha ekattanayo, nānattanayo, abyāpāranayo, evaṃdhammatānayoti cattāro atthanayā honti, tasmā nayabhedatopetaṃ bhavacakkaṃ viññātabbaṃ yathārahaṃ.
analyzed: yasmā pana ittha ekatta nayaḥ nānatta nayaḥ abyāpāra nayaḥ evaṃdhammatā nayaḥ cattāro attha nayāḥ honti tasmā naya bheda tā upetam bhava cakkam viññātabbam yathāraham
translated: But since there are four ways of interpreting the wheel of existence, namely, as continuity, as diversity, as non-affliction, and as the nature of things, it should be understood that the wheel of existence is to be interpreted according to the way in which it is appropriate.

original: Tattha avijjāpaccayā saṅkhārā, saṅkhārapaccayā viññāṇanti evaṃ bījassa aṅkurādibhāvena🔽rukkhabhāvappatti viya santānānupacchedo ekattanayo nāma. Yaṃ sammā passanto hetuphalasambandhena
analyzed: tattha avijjā paccayā saṅkhārā saṅkhāra paccayā viññāṇan ti evam bījassa aṅkura ādi bhāvena  rukkha bhāva ppatti viya santāna an upacchedaḥ eka ttanayaḥ nāma yam sammā passantaḥ hetu phala sambandhena
translated: Herein, the way of continuity is the continuity of the process of becoming, like the occurrence of a tree by the method of seed and shoot, etc., as follows: “With ignorance as condition there are formations; with formations as condition, consciousness” .

original: santānassa anupacchedāvabodhato ucchedadiṭṭhiṃ pajahati. Micchā passanto hetuphalasambandhena🔽pavattamānassa santānānupacchedassa ekattagahaṇato sassatadiṭṭhiṃ upādiyati.🔽Avijjādīnaṃ pana yathāsakaṃlakkhaṇavavatthānaṃ nānattanayo nāma. Yaṃ sammā passanto
analyzed: santānassa an upaccheda avabodhataḥ uccheda diṭṭhim pajahati micchā passantaḥ hetu phala sambandhena  pavattamānassa santāna an upacchedassa ekatta gahaṇataḥ sassata diṭṭhim upādiyati  avijjā ādīnam pana yathā sakam lakkhaṇa vavatthānam nānattanayaḥ nāma yam sammā passanto
translated: One who sees this correctly abandons the annihilation view by understanding the continuity of the process of becoming by means of the connection between cause and effect. One who sees it wrongly acquires the eternity view by taking the continuity of the process of becoming, which occurs by means of the connection between cause and effect, as a single, truly existent entity.

original: navanavānaṃ uppādadassanato sassatadiṭṭhiṃ pajahati. Micchā passanto ekasantānapatitassa
analyzed: nava navānam uppāda dassanataḥ sassata diṭṭhim pajahati micchā passantaḥ eka santāna patitassa
translated: The way of diversity is the definition of the characteristics of ignorance, etc., each in its own place. One who sees this correctly abandons the eternity view by seeing the arising of each new one of the fresh occurrences. One who sees it wrongly acquires the annihilation view by taking the continuity of the process of becoming, which occurs by means of the connection between cause and effect, as a single, truly existent entity.

original: bhinnasantānasseva nānattaggahaṇato ucchedadiṭṭhiṃ upādiyati.
analyzed: bhinna santānassa iva nānatta gahaṇataḥ uccheda diṭṭhim upādiyati
translated: and he misapprehends annihilationism because he apprehends diversity in what is a single continuum.

original: Avijjāya saṅkhārā mayā uppādetabbā, saṅkhārānaṃ vā viññāṇaṃ amhehīti evamādibyāpārābhāvo
analyzed: avijjāya saṅkhārāḥ mayā uppādetabbā saṅkhārānam vā viññāṇam amhehi iti evamādi byāpāra abhāvaḥ
translated: The “non-intervention method” is the non-intervention of ignorance in the production of formations, or of formations in the production of consciousness, and so on.

original: abyāpāranayo nāma. Yaṃ sammā passanto kārakassa abhāvāvabodhato attadiṭṭhiṃ pajahati.🔽Micchā passanto yo asatipi byāpāre avijjādīnaṃ sabhāvaniyamasiddho hetubhāvo, tassa
analyzed: abyāpāra nayaḥ nāma yam sammā passanto kārakassa abhāva avabodhataḥ atta diṭṭhim pajahati  micchā passanto yaḥ asati api byāpāre avijjā ādīnam sa bhāva niyama siddho hetu bhāvaḥ tassa
translated: One who sees rightly abandons the embodiment-view because he understands that there is no maker.

original: aggahaṇato akiriyadiṭṭhiṃ upādiyati.
analyzed: aggahaṇataḥ akiriya diṭṭhim upādiyati
translated: One who sees wrongly misapprehends nihilism because he fails to grasp the fact that the state of being a cause of the formations, etc., by ignorance, etc., is established by the regularity of dhammas, even though there is no intervention.

original: Avijjādīhi pana kāraṇehi saṅkhārādīnaṃyeva sambhavo khīrādīhi dadhiādīnaṃ viya, na🔽aññesanti ayaṃ evaṃdhammatānayo nāma. Yaṃ sammā passanto paccayānurūpato phalāvabodhā
analyzed: avijja ādīhi pana kāraṇehi saṅkhāra ādīnam yeva sambhavaḥ khīra ādīhi dadhi ādīnam na  aññesanti ayam evaṃdhammatā ānayaḥ nāma yam sammā passantaḥ paccaya anurūpataḥ phala avabodhā
translated: The “method of the nature of dhammas” is the fact that only the formations, etc., are produced by ignorance, etc., as conditions, just as curd, etc., are produced by milk, etc., as their respective conditions, and not anything else.🔽One who sees rightly abandons the view that there is no cause and the view that there is no efficacy of action because he understands the fruit in accordance with its conditions.

original: ahetukadiṭṭhiṃ akiriyadiṭṭhiñca pajahati. Micchā passanto paccayānurūpaṃ phalappavattiṃ
analyzed: ahetuka diṭṭhim akiriya diṭṭhiñca pajahati micchā passantaḥ paccaya anurūpam phala ppavattim
translated: One who sees wrongly misapprehends the view that there is no cause and the view that there is no efficacy of action because he fails to grasp the occurrence of the fruit in accordance with its conditions.

original: aggahetvā yato kutoci yassa kassaci asambhavaggahaṇato ahetukadiṭṭhiñceva niyatavādañca
analyzed: aggahetvā yatas kutoci yassa kassaci asambhava ggahaṇataḥ ahetuka diṭṭhiñca iva niyata vādañca
translated: and it is clung to, in the sense of being taken up, from anywhere at all, by anyone at all, without any cause, as a view of no-cause, and as a doctrine of no-cause,

original: upādiyatīti evamidaṃ bhavacakkaṃ,
analyzed: evam idam bhava cakkam
translated: and so this wheel of becoming🔽Is deep, and has a base, and work,🔽And is like a door, and deep,

original: Saccappabhavato kiccā, vāraṇāupamāhi ca;
analyzed: sacca ppabhavataḥ kiccā ca
translated: And has a way of being split;🔽So it should be understood, as fits,

original: Gambhīranayabhedā ca, viññātabbaṃ yathārahaṃ.
analyzed: gambhīra naya bhedā ca viññātabbam yathāraham
translated: By one who has the proper wit.

original: 661. Idañhi atigambhīrato agādhaṃ. Nānānayagahanato duratiyānaṃ. Ñāṇāsinā samādhipavarasilāyaṃ sunisitena,🔽Bhavacakkamapadāletvā, asanivicakkamiva niccanimmathanaṃ;
analyzed: idam hi ati gambhīrataḥ agādham nānā naya gahanataḥ duratiyānam ñāṇa asinā samādhi pavara silāyam su nisitena  bhava cakkam a padāletvā asani vicakkam iva nicca nimmathanam
translated: For it is unfathomable because it is very deep, hard to cross because it is a jungle of many ways,🔽and it is always being churned like a water wheel by the churning of the three kinds of becoming.

original: Saṃsārabhayamatīto, na koci supinantarepyatthi.
analyzed: saṃsāra bhayam atītaḥ na koci
translated: So no one has ever got beyond the fear of the round of rebirths, not even in a dream.

original: Vuttampi hetaṃ bhagavatā – “gambhīro cāyaṃ, ānanda, paṭiccasamuppādo gambhīrāvabhāso🔽ca. Etassa cānanda, dhammassa ananubodhā appaṭivedhā evamayaṃ pajā tantākulakajātā
analyzed: vuttam pi ha itam bhagavatā gambhīraḥ ca ayam ānanda paṭiccasamuppādaḥ gambhīra avabhāso  ca etassa ca ānanda dhammassa ananubodhā appaṭivedhā evam ayam pajā tantā kulaka jātā
translated: And this is said by the Blessed One: “This dependent origination is deep, Ānanda, and deep-looking.

original: kulāgaṇṭhikajātā muñjapabbajabhūtā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ saṃsāraṃ nātivattatī”ti.
analyzed: kulāgaṇṭhika jātā muñja pabbaja bhūtā apāyam duggatim vinipātam saṃsāram na ativattati iti
translated: Because of the failure to penetrate and understand this Dhamma, Ānanda, this generation has become like a tangled skein, like a knotted ball of thread, like muñja grass and reeds in a tangled mass, and it does not transcend the plane of misery, the bad destinations, ruin, the round of rebirths” .

original: Tasmā attano vā paresaṃ vā hitāya ca sukhāya ca paṭipanno avasesakiccāni pahāya,
analyzed: tasmai attanaḥ vā paresam vā hitāya ca sukhāya ca paṭipannaḥ avasesa kiccāni pahāya
translated: So, abandoning all other duties,

original: Gambhīre paccayākārappabhede idha paṇḍito;
analyzed: gambhīre paccaya ākāra ppabhede idha paṇḍito
translated: The wise man here should strive🔽To gain a footing in the deep

original: Yathā gādhaṃ labhethevamanuyuñje sadā satoti.🔽Iti sādhujanapāmojjatthāya kate visuddhimagge
analyzed: yathā gādham labhetha ivam anuyuñje sadā satā iti  iti sādhu jana pāmojjatthāya kate visuddhi magge
translated: Analysis of conditions, ever mindful.🔽In the Path of Purification🔽Compiled for the serene joy and happiness of the multitude

original: Paññābhāvanādhikāre
analyzed: paññā bhāvanā adhikāre
translated: Composed for the sake of devotion

original: Paññābhūminiddeso nāma🔽Sattarasamo paricchedo.
analyzed: sattarasamaḥ paricchedaḥ
translated: The chapter on the planes of existence,🔽The seventeenth chapter

original: 18. Diṭṭhivisuddhiniddeso
analyzed: diṭṭhivisuddhi niddesaḥ
translated: The exposition of the purification of view

original: Nāmarūpapariggahakathā
analyzed: nāma rūpa pariggaha kathā
translated: The explanation of the discernment of mind and matter

original: 662. Idāni yā “imesu bhūmibhūtesu dhammesu uggahaparipucchāvasena ñāṇaparicayaṃ katvā
analyzed: idāni yā imesu bhūmi bhūtesu dhammesu uggaha paripucchā vasena ñāṇa paricayam katvā
translated: Now, it was said earlier: “Having thus gained familiarity with knowledge by learning and questioning about these states that are the basis for the planes,

original: ‘sīlavisuddhi ceva cittavisuddhi cā’ti dve mūlabhūtā visuddhiyo sampādetabbā”ti vuttā.
analyzed: sīla visuddhi ca iva citta visuddhi ca ati dve mūla bhūtāḥ visuddhiyaḥ sampādetabbā ati vuttā
translated: two kinds of purification should be accomplished, that is to say, purification of virtue and purification of consciousness” .

original: Tattha sīlavisuddhi nāma suparisuddhaṃ pātimokkhasaṃvarādicatubbidhaṃ sīlaṃ, tañca
analyzed: tattha nāma su parisuddham pātimokkha saṃvara ādi catubbidham sīlam tat ca
translated: Herein, purification of virtue is virtue that is quite purified in the fourfold sense of being possessed, untorn, unbroken, and unsmutted,🔽and that has been extended by the development of the meditation subjects.

original: sīlaniddese vitthāritameva. Cittavisuddhi nāma saupacārā aṭṭha samāpattiyo, tāpi
analyzed: sīla niddese vitthāritam eva cittavisuddhi nāma sa upacārāḥ aṭṭha samāpattiyaḥ
translated: Purification of consciousness is the eight attainments with access concentration and with absorption concentration.

original: cittasīsena vuttasamādhiniddese sabbākārena vitthāritā eva. Tasmā tā tattha vitthāritanayeneva veditabbā.
analyzed: cittasīsena vutta samādhi niddese sabba ākārena vitthāritāḥ eva tasmā tā tattha vitthārita nayena iva veditabbā
translated: so it should be understood in the way given there.

original: Yaṃ pana vuttaṃ “diṭṭhivisuddhi, kaṅkhāvitaraṇavisuddhi, maggāmaggañāṇadassanavisuddhi,
analyzed: yam pana vuttam diṭṭhi visuddhi kaṅkhā vitaraṇa visuddhi magga amagga ñāṇa dassana visuddhi
translated: But it was said above, “The five kinds of purification are the purification by over- coming doubt, the purification by crossing the doubt-entanglements, the purification by knowledge and vision of what is the path and what is not the path,

original: paṭipadāñāṇadassanavisuddhi, ñāṇadassanavisuddhīti imā pana pañca visuddhiyo sarīra”nti,
analyzed: paṭipadā ñāṇa dassana visuddhi ñāṇa dassana visuddhi iti imāḥ pana pañca visuddhiyaḥ sarīranti
translated: the purification by knowledge and vision of the way, and the purification by knowledge and vision. These five kinds of purification are the body of the path” .

original: tattha nāmarūpānaṃ yāthāvadassanaṃ diṭṭhivisuddhi nāma.
analyzed: tattha nāma rūpānam yāthāvadassanam diṭṭhivisuddhi nāma
translated: Herein, the seeing of mentality-materiality as it actually is is called purification by over- coming doubt.

original: 663. Taṃ sampādetukāmena samathayānikena tāva ṭhapetvā nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ avasesarūpārūpāvacarajjhānānaṃ
analyzed: tam sampādetu kāmena samatha yānikena tāva ṭhapetvā nevasaññānāsaññāyatanam avasesa rūpa arūpāvacara jhānānam
translated: One who wants to accomplish that, firstly, as a serenity worker should emerge from any one of the jhānas of the fine-material sphere or immaterial sphere except the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception,

original: aññatarato vuṭṭhāya vitakkādīni jhānaṅgāni, taṃsampayuttā ca dhammā lakkhaṇarasādivasena🔽pariggahetabbā. Pariggahetvā sabbampetaṃ ārammaṇābhimukhaṃ namanato namanaṭṭhena
analyzed: aññataratas vuṭṭhāya vitakka ādīni jhāna aṅgāni tad sampayuttā ca dhammā lakkhaṇa rasa ādi vasena  pariggahetabbā pariggahetvā sabbam petam ārammaṇa abhimukham namanataḥ namanaṭṭhena
translated: and he should discern the jhāna factors, such as applied thought, and the states associated with the jhāna, such as the co-nascence conditions, etc., by means of their characteristics, their functions, etc.,

original: nāmanti vavatthapetabbaṃ.
analyzed: nāmanti vavatthapetabbam
translated: and he should define all of them as “mentality” since they are all turned towards the object by being bent on it.

original: Tato yathā nāma puriso antogehe sappaṃ disvā taṃ anubandhamāno tassa āsayaṃ passati,🔽evameva ayampi yogāvacaro taṃ nāmaṃ upaparikkhanto “idaṃ nāmaṃ kiṃ nissāya pavattatī”ti
analyzed: tatas yathā nāma purisaḥ antar gehe sappam disvā tam anubandhamāno tassa āsayam passati  evam eva ayam pi yogāvacaraḥ tam nāmam upaparikkhantaḥ idam nāmam kim nissāya pavattati iti
translated: Then just as a man, seeing a snake in the house, follows it to find where it lurks,

original: pariyesamāno tassa nissayaṃ hadayarūpaṃ passati. Tato hadayarūpassa nissayabhūtāni,
analyzed: pariyesamāno tassa nissayam hadaya rūpam passati tatas hadaya rūpassa nissaya bhūtāni
translated: so too this meditator, while examining that name, seeks to find out what it is that the name occurs with, and he sees the materiality that is its physical basis. Then he sees the material instances that are the basis for the heart- basis,

original: bhūtanissitāni ca sesupādāyarūpānīti rūpaṃ pariggaṇhāti. So sabbampetaṃ ruppanato🔽rūpanti vavatthapeti. Tato namanalakkhaṇaṃ nāmaṃ, ruppanalakkhaṇaṃ rūpanti saṅkhepato
analyzed: bhūta nissitāni ca rūpam pariggaṇhāti saḥ sabbam petam ruppanataḥ  rūpanti vavatthapeti tatas namana lakkhaṇam nāmam ruppana lakkhaṇam rūpanti saṅkhepato
translated: and the rest of the derived materiality that is based on the great primaries. So he discerns materiality. He defines all that as “materiality” because it is subject to destruction.

original: nāmarūpaṃ vavatthapeti.🔽664. Suddhavipassanāyāniko pana ayameva vā samathayāniko catudhātuvavatthāne vuttānaṃ🔽tesaṃ tesaṃ dhātupariggahamukhānaṃ aññataramukhavasena saṅkhepato vā vitthārato vā
analyzed: nāma rūpam vavatthapa iti  suddha vipassanā yāniko pana ayam eva vā samatha yāniko catu dhātu vavatthāne vuttānam  tesam tesam dhātu pariggaha mukhānam aññatara mukha vasena saṅkhepataḥ vā vitthārataḥ vā
translated: Then he defines mentality-materiality in brief as follows: “Mentality is the state of cognizing, and materiality is the state of being molested.”

original: catasso dhātuyo pariggaṇhāti. Athassa yāthāvasarasalakkhaṇato āvibhūtāsu dhātūsu
analyzed: catassaḥ dhātuyaḥ pariggaṇhāti athassa yāthāvasa rasa lakkhaṇataḥ āvibhūtāsu dhātūsu
translated: But one who is a pure-vision type or one who is a serenity-vehicle type should discern the four elements in brief or in detail by whichever of the following methods of insight described under the section on the elements in the description of serenity in the “Purification of View” chapter.

original: kammasamuṭṭhānamhi tāva kese “catasso dhātuyo, vaṇṇo, gandho, raso, ojā, jīvitaṃ,🔽kāyappasādo”ti evaṃ kāyadasakavasena dasa rūpāni, tattheva bhāvassa atthitāya bhāvadasakavasena
analyzed: kamma samuṭṭhānamhi tāva kese catasso dhātuyaḥ vaṇṇaḥ gandhaḥ rasaḥ ojā jīvitam  kāya ppasādaḥ ti evam kāya dasaka vasena dasa rūpāni tattha iva bhāvassa atthitāya bhāva dasaka vasena
translated: As regards the “arisen from kamma” , there are ten material instances in the head, namely, the four primary elements, colour, odour, flavour, nutritive essence, and life,🔽and the ten instances of the body, namely, the four primary elements, colour, odour, flavour, nutritive essence, life, and bodily pliant-ness.

original: dasa, tattheva āhārasamuṭṭhānaṃ ojaṭṭhamakaṃ, utusamuṭṭhānaṃ, cittasamuṭṭhānanti
analyzed: dasa tattha eva āhāra samuṭṭhānam ojaṭṭhamakam utu samuṭṭhānam citta samuṭṭhānanti
translated: There are ten instances of the “present” , namely, the four primary elements, colour, odour, flavour, nutritive essence, and the “present” life,🔽and there are twenty-four instances in the four remaining origins, namely, nutriment-origin, season-origin, and consciousness-origin.

original: aparānipi catuvīsatīti evaṃ catusamuṭṭhānesu catuvīsatikoṭṭhāsesu catucattālīsa catucattālīsa🔽rūpāni, sedo, assu, kheḷo, siṅghāṇikāti imesu pana catūsu utucittasamuṭṭhānesu dvinnaṃ
analyzed: catuvīsati iti evam catu samuṭṭhānesu catuvīsati koṭṭhāsesu catucattālīsa catucattālīsa  rūpāni sedaḥ assu kheḷaḥ siṅghāṇikā ati imesu pana catūsu utu citta samuṭṭhānesu dvinnam
translated: So in the four origins there are forty-four instances in the twenty-four sections.

original: ojaṭṭhamakānaṃ vasena soḷasa soḷasa rūpāni, udariyaṃ, karīsaṃ, pubbo, muttanti imesu
analyzed: vasena soḷasa soḷasa rūpāni udariyam karīsam pubbaḥ muttanti imesu
translated: In the four instances of sweat, tears, spittle, and snot, which are in the season-origin and consciousness-origin, there are sixteen instances in each, namely, the four primary elements, colour, odour, flavour, nutritive essence, and the two kinds of “present” nutritive essence.

original: catūsu utusamuṭṭhānesu utusamuṭṭhānasseva ojaṭṭhamakassa vasena aṭṭha aṭṭha rūpāni
analyzed: catūsu utu samuṭṭhānesu utu samuṭṭhānassa iva ojaṭṭhamakassa vasena aṭṭha aṭṭha rūpāni
translated: In the four instances of stomach, dung, pus, and urine, which are in the season-origin, there are eight instances in each, namely, the four primary elements, colour, odour, flavour, and nutritive essence, which is the only kind of “present” nutritive essence.

original: pākaṭāni hontīti. Esa tāva dvattiṃsākāre nayo.
analyzed: pākaṭāni honti iti tāva dvattiṃsa ākāre
translated: So these are the thirty-two aspects.

original: Ye pana imasmiṃ dvattiṃsākāre āvibhūte apare dasa ākārā āvibhavanti. Tattha asitādiparipācake
analyzed: ye pana imasmin dvattiṃsa ākāre āvibhūte apare dasa ākārāḥ āvibhavanti asita ādi paripācake
translated: But when these thirty-two aspects are made plain, ten other aspects become plain too. Herein, the maturing of what is eaten, etc.,

original: tāva kammaje tejokoṭṭhāsamhi ojaṭṭhamakañceva jīvitañcāti nava rūpāni, tathā cittaje
analyzed: tāva kamma je tejaḥ koṭṭhāsamhi nava rūpāni tathā citta je
translated: But when these thirty-two aspects have become evident, ten more aspects become evident. Herein, in the case of the fire element that ripens what is eaten, etc., there are nine material instances, that is to say, the octad consisting of the postnascence temperature and the life faculty, and in the case of the mind-born fire element

original: assāsapassāsakoṭṭhāsepi ojaṭṭhamakañceva saddo cāti nava, sesesu catusamuṭṭhānesu
analyzed: assāsa passāsa koṭṭhāse pi saddaḥ ca ati nava sesesu catu samuṭṭhānesu
translated: there are nine material instances, that is to say, the octad consisting of the postnascence temperature and the sound, and in the remaining eight that are originated by all four causes

original: aṭṭhasu jīvitanavakañceva tīṇi ca ojaṭṭhamakānīti tettiṃsa rūpāni pākaṭāni honti.
analyzed: aṭṭhasu tīṇi ca oja ṭṭhamakāni iti tettiṃsa rūpāni pākaṭāni honti
translated: there are thirty-three material instances, that is to say, the life-faculty decad and three octads consisting of the postnascence temperature.

original: Tassevaṃ vitthārato dvācattālīsākāravasena imesu bhūtupādāyarūpesu pākaṭesu jātesu
analyzed: tassa evam vitthārataḥ dvācattālīsa ākāra vasena imesu bhūta upādāya rūpesu pākaṭesu jātesu
translated: So when these forty-two aspects have become evident in detail in this way in the primary elements and the materiality derived from primary elements,

original: vatthudvāravasena pañca cakkhudasakādayo, hadayavatthudasakañcāti aparānipi saṭṭhirūpāni
analyzed: vatthu dvāra vasena pañca cakkhu dasaka ādayaḥ hadaya vatthu dasakam ca ati aparāni pi
translated: then another sixty material instances become evident, that is to say, the five sets of ten beginning with the eye, and the ten heart- basis instances.

original: pākaṭāni honti. So sabbānipi tāni ruppanalakkhaṇena ekato katvā “etaṃ rūpa”nti passati.
analyzed: pākaṭāni honti so sabbāni api tāni ruppana lakkhaṇena ekatas katvā etam rūpanti passati
translated: So he sees all these as “materiality” taken together by means of the characteristic of being molested .

original: Tassevaṃ pariggahitarūpassa dvāravasena arūpadhammā pākaṭā honti. Seyyathidaṃ – dvepañcaviññāṇāni,
analyzed: tassa ivam pariggahita rūpassa dvāra vasena arūpa dhammā pākaṭāḥ honti seyyathidam dve pañca viññāṇāni
translated: the two sets of five consciousnesses,

original: tisso manodhātuyo, aṭṭhasaṭṭhi manoviññāṇadhātuyoti ekāsīti lokiyacittāni, avisesena
analyzed: tissaḥ manaḥ dhātuyaḥ aṭṭha saṭṭhi manaḥ viññāṇa dhātuyaḥ ti ekāsīti lokiya cittāni avisesena
translated: the three mind elements, and the sixty-eight kinds of mind-consciousness element—in all one hundred and eighty kinds of mundane consciousness,

original: ca tehi cittehi sahajāto phasso, vedanā, saññā, cetanā, jīvitaṃ, cittaṭṭhiti, manasikāroti
analyzed: ca tehi cittehi sahajātaḥ phassaḥ vedanā saññā cetanā jīvitam citta ṭṭhiti manasikāraḥ ti
translated: and also the seven kinds of mental factors that are invariably conascent with those consciousnesses, namely, contact, feeling, perception, volition, life, the faculty of mind, and attention.

original: ime satta satta cetasikāti. Lokuttaracittāni pana neva suddhavipassakassa, na samathayānikassa
analyzed: ime satta satta cetasikā ati lokuttara cittāni pana na iva suddha vipassakassa na samatha yānikassa
translated: But the supramundane kinds of consciousness are not discerned by one who is a mere suta-dhammānusārī or a mere samathayānika.

original: pariggahaṃ gacchanti anadhigatattāti. So sabbepi te arūpadhamme namanalakkhaṇena🔽ekato katvā “etaṃ nāma”nti passati. Evameko catudhātuvavatthānamukhena vitthārato
analyzed: pariggaham gacchanti an adhigata ttā ati saḥ sabbe api te arūpa dhamme namana lakkhaṇena  ekatas katvā etam nāmanti passati evam ekaḥ catu dhātu vavatthāna mukhena vitthārato
translated: He sees all these immaterial states as “this” by way of their characteristic of bending or inclining .

original: nāmarūpaṃ vavatthapeti.
analyzed: nāma rūpam vavatthapa iti
translated: Thus he defines mentality-materiality in detail by way of the analysis of the four elements.

original: 665. Aparo aṭṭhārasadhātuvasena. Kathaṃ? Idha bhikkhu atthi imasmiṃ attabhāve cakkhudhātu…pe…
analyzed: aparaḥ aṭṭhārasa dhātu vasena katham idha bhikkhu atthi imasmin atta bhāve cakkhu dhātupe
translated: Another defines mentality-materiality by way of the eighteen elements. How? Here a bhikkhu considers thus: “In this person there are the eye element,🔽the form element, the eye-consciousness element;

original: manoviññāṇadhātūti dhātuyo āvajjitvā yaṃ loko setakaṇhamaṇḍalavicittaṃ āyatavitthataṃ🔽akkhikūpake nhārusuttakena ābaddhaṃ maṃsapiṇḍaṃ “cakkhū”ti sañjānāti, taṃ aggahetvā
analyzed: manaḥ viññāṇa dhātū uti dhātuyaḥ āvajjitvā yam seta kaṇha maṇḍala vicittam āyata vitthatam  akkhikūpake nhārusuttakena ābaddham maṃsa piṇḍam cakkhu iti sañjānāti tam aggahetvā
translated: “Mind-consciousness element” : after adverting to the elements, the world cognizes the lump of flesh in the eye socket, which is white and black, variegated, long, and wide,🔽as “eye” without taking it as a “lump of flesh bound by sinews in the eye socket.”🔽

original: khandhaniddese upādārūpesu vuttappakāraṃ cakkhupasādaṃ “cakkhudhātū”ti vavatthapeti.
analyzed: khandha niddese upādā rūpesu vutta ppakāram cakkhu pasādam cakkhu dhātu uti vavatthapeti
translated: The mind-consciousness element: having adverted to the elements, he defines the visible-data base as the eye faculty, which is the visible-data element, in the way already stated in the Description of the Aggregates under the “derived materiality” heading.

original: Yāni panassa nissayabhūtā catasso dhātuyo, parivārakāni cattāri vaṇṇa-gandha-rasa-ojā-rūpāni,🔽anupālakaṃ jīvitindriyanti nava sahajātarūpāni, tattheva ṭhitāni kāyadasakabhāvadasakavasena
analyzed: yāni panassa nissaya bhūtā catasso dhātuyaḥ parivārakāni cattāri vaṇṇa gandha rasa ojā rūpāni  anupālakam nava sahajāta rūpāni tattha iva ṭhitāni kāya dasaka bhāva dasaka vasena
translated: But the nine conascent material instances, namely, the four primary elements that are its support, the four primaries that are its surrounding, and the life faculty that is its guardian,🔽and the twenty instances of materiality that are its conascent and postnascent instances, that is to say, the ten instances of materiality that are its conascent instances, and the ten instances of materiality that are its postnascent instances,🔽and the twenty-four instances of materiality that are its instances of derived materiality originating from nutriment, etc.,

original: vīsati kammajarūpāni, āhārasamuṭṭhānādīnaṃ tiṇṇaṃ ojaṭṭhamakānaṃ vasena catuvīsati🔽anupādinnarūpānīti evaṃ sesāni tepaṇṇāsa rūpāni honti, na tāni ca “cakkhudhātū”ti
analyzed: vīsati kamma ja rūpāni āhāra samuṭṭhāna ādīnam tiṇṇam oja ṭṭhamakānam vasena catuvīsati  an upādinna rūpāni iti evam sesāni tepaṇṇāsa rūpāni honti na tāni ca cakkhu dhātū ti
translated: and the twenty-four instances of materiality that are its instances of undeclared materiality, that is to say, the twenty-four instances of materiality that are its instances of derived materiality originating from temperature, from consciousness, and from kamma,🔽are not defined by him as “eye element.”🔽The same method of explanation applies in the case of the ear element, etc.,

original: vavatthapeti. Esa nayo sotadhātuādīsupi. Kāyadhātuyaṃ pana avasesāni tecattālīsa
analyzed: vavatthapa iti esa nayo pana avasesāni tecattālīsa
translated: but in the case of the body element there are forty-three instances of materiality that are not defined as “body element.”

original: rūpāni honti. Keci pana utucittasamuṭṭhānāni saddena saha nava nava katvā pañcacattālīsāti vadanti.
analyzed: rūpāni honti keci pana utu citta samuṭṭhānāni saddena saha nava nava katvā pañcacattālīsā ati vadanti
translated: Some, however, say that there are forty-five kinds by taking the nine kinds of visible data, sounds, and tactile objects together with the temperature-born and consciousness-born kinds.

original: Iti ime pañca pasādā, tesañca visayā rūpasaddagandharasaphoṭṭhabbā pañcāti dasa rūpāni
analyzed: iti ime pañca tesam ca visayā rūpa sadda gandha rasa phoṭṭhabbā dasa rūpāni
translated: So these five sensitive faculties and their five respective objects, visible data, etc., make ten kinds of materiality.

original: dasa dhātuyo honti. Avasesarūpāni dhammadhātuyeva honti. Cakkhuṃ pana nissāya rūpaṃ
analyzed: dasa dhātuyaḥ honti avasesa rūpāni dhammadhātuyā iva honti cakkhum pana nissāya rūpam
translated: The remaining kinds of materiality are only the materiality of the mental data base.

original: ārabbha pavattaṃ cittaṃ cakkhuviññāṇadhātu nāmāti evaṃ dvepañcaviññāṇāni pañca viññāṇadhātuyo
analyzed: ārabbha pavattam cittam cakkhu viññāṇa dhātu nāma ati evam dve pañca viññāṇāni pañca viññāṇa dhātuyaḥ
translated: But the consciousness that occurs in the eye door with visible data as its object is called eye-consciousness element. So the two kinds of five consciousnesses are the five consciousness elements.

original: honti. Tīṇi manodhātucittāni ekā manodhātu, aṭṭhasaṭṭhi manoviññāṇadhātucittāni manoviññāṇadhātūti
analyzed: honti tīṇi manaḥ dhātu cittāni ekā manaḥ dhātu aṭṭha saṭṭhi manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu cittāni manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu uti
translated: The three kinds of mind element are the mind element, and the sixty-eight kinds of mind-consciousness element are the mind-consciousness element.

original: sabbānipi ekāsīti lokiyacittāni satta viññāṇadhātuyo. Taṃsampayuttā phassādayo dhammadhātūti
analyzed: sabbāni api ekāsīti lokiya cittāni satta viññāṇa dhātuyo tad sampayuttā phassa ādayaḥ dhammadhātu ti
translated: So all the eighty-one mundane kinds of consciousness are the seven consciousness elements. The contact, etc., associated therewith are the mental-data element.

original: evamettha aḍḍhekādasa dhātuyo rūpaṃ, aḍḍhaṭṭhamā dhātuyo nāmanti evameko aṭṭhārasadhātuvasena🔽nāmarūpaṃ vavatthapeti.
analyzed: evam ettha aḍḍha ekādasa dhātuyaḥ rūpam aḍḍha aṭṭhamāḥ dhātuyaḥ nāmanti evam ekaḥ aṭṭhārasa dhātu vasena 🔽nāma rūpam vavatthapa iti
translated: So here eleven and a half elements are materiality, and seven and a half elements are mentality. This is how one defines mentality-materiality by the eighteen elements.

original: 666. Aparo dvādasāyatanavasena. Kathaṃ? Cakkhudhātuyaṃ vuttanayeneva ṭhapetvā tepaṇṇāsa🔽rūpāni cakkhupasādamattaṃ “cakkhāyatana”nti vavatthapeti. Tattha vuttanayeneva ca
analyzed: aparaḥ dvādasa āyatana vasena katham cakkhudhātuyam vutta nayena iva ṭhapetvā  rūpāni cakkhu upasāda mattam cakkha āyatanan ti vavatthapeti tattha vutta nayena iva ca
translated: Another does so by means of the twelve bases. How? He defines the eye base as the eye sensitivity alone, leaving out the fifty-two kinds of materiality mentioned in the way beginning, “There is, in dependence on the eye and forms, eye-consciousness” . And he defines the visible-data base in the way beginning, “There are visible objects cognizable by the eye that are desirable, desirable and beautiful” .

original: sotaghānajivhākāyadhātuyo “sotaghānajivhākāyāyatanānī”ti, tesaṃ visayabhūte pañcadhamme🔽“rūpasaddagandharasaphoṭṭhabbāyatanānī”ti, lokiyasattaviññāṇadhātuyo “manāyatana”nti,
analyzed: sota ghāna jivhā kāya dhātuyo sota ghāna jivhā kāya āyatanāni iti tesam visaya bhūte pañca dhamme  rūpa sadda gandha rasa phoṭṭhabba āyatanāni iti lokiya satta viññāṇa dhātuyaḥ manāyatananti
translated: Another does so by means of the twelve bases. How? He defines the eye base as the eye sensitivity, leaving out the fifty-five kinds of materiality mentioned in the way beginning, “There are, Ānanda, in this body head hairs, body hairs, …” . And he defines the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind bases in the way already given .🔽He defines the visible-data base, etc., as the five kinds of materiality that are their respective objects. He defines the mind base as the seven mundane kinds of consciousness.

original: taṃsampayuttā phassādayo sesarūpañca “dhammāyatana”nti evamettha aḍḍhekādasa āyatanāni
analyzed: tad sampayuttā phassa ādayo sesa rūpañca dhammāyatananti evam ettha aḍḍha ekādasa āyatanāni
translated: He defines the mental-data base as the remaining kinds of materiality and as the mental factors and so on .

original: rūpaṃ, diyaḍḍhaāyatanāni nāmanti evameko dvādasāyatanavasena nāmarūpaṃ vavatthapeti.🔽667. Aparo tato saṃkhittataraṃ khandhavasena vavatthapeti. Kathaṃ? Idha bhikkhu imasmiṃ
analyzed: rūpam evam ekaḥ dvādaśa āyatana vasena nāma rūpam vavatthapeti  aparaḥ tatas saṃkhittataram khandha vasena vavatthapeti katham idha bhikkhu imasmin
translated: Thus eleven of the twelve bases are materiality, and the mind base is mentality. So one defines mentality-materiality by means of the twelve bases.

original: sarīre catusamuṭṭhānā catasso dhātuyo, taṃnissito vaṇṇo, gandho, raso, ojā, cakkhupasādādayo
analyzed: sarīre catu samuṭṭhānā catasso dhātuyo tad nissitaḥ vaṇṇaḥ gandhaḥ rasaḥ ojā cakkhu pasāda ādayo
translated: Another defines it more briefly by means of the aggregates. How? Here a bhikkhu considers the four primary elements and the materiality derived by clinging to the four primary elements in this way: “In this body there are the earth element, the water element, the fire element, and the air element.” He defines the colour, odour, flavour and nutritive essence that are clung to by the four primary elements in this way: “There is the earth element, the water element, the fire element, and the air element.”

original: pañca pasādā, vatthurūpaṃ, bhāvo, jīvitindriyaṃ, dvisamuṭṭhāno saddoti imāni sattarasa
analyzed: pañca pasādāḥ vatthu rūpam bhāvaḥ jīvitindriyam dvi samuṭṭhānaḥ saddo ti imāni sattarasa
translated: The five sensitive-matter faculties, the materiality of the physical basis, the state, the life faculty, and sound as the dual-originated kind: these seventeen🔽material instances are produced materiality that is not reducible to other material instances. Bodily intimation,

original: rūpāni sammasanupagāni nipphannāni rūparūpāni. Kāyaviññatti, vacīviññatti, ākāsadhātu,🔽rūpassa lahutā, mudutā, kammaññatā, upacayo, santati, jaratā, aniccatāti imāni pana
analyzed: rūpāni sammasanupagāni nipphannāni rūpa rūpāni kāya viññatti vacī viññatti ākāsa dhātu  rūpassa lahu tā mudu tā kammañña tā upacayaḥ santati jara tā anicca tā ati imāni pana
translated: verbal intimation, the space element,🔽lightness of matter, malleability of matter, wieldiness of matter, growth of matter, continuity of matter, ageing of matter, and impermanence of matter: these ten

original: dasa rūpāni na sammasanupagāni, ākāravikāraantaraparicchedamattakāni, na nipphannarūpāni,
analyzed: dasa rūpāni na ākāra vikāra antara pariccheda mattakāni na nipphanna rūpāni
translated: material instances are not reducible to other material instances, they are mere delimitation of the alteration and the specific-nature of matter, they are not produced materiality,

original: na rūparūpāni. Apica kho rūpānaṃ ākāravikāraantaraparicchedamattato rūpanti saṅkhaṃ🔽gatāni. Iti sabbāni petāni sattavīsati rūpāni rūpakkhandho, ekāsītiyā lokiyacittehi
analyzed: na rūpa rūpāni apica ākāra vikāra antara pariccheda mattataḥ  gatāni iti sabbāni petāni sattavīsati rūpāni rūpa kkhandho ekāsītiyā lokiya cittehi
translated: they are not material instances. But they are called “materiality” because they are the mere delimitation of the alteration and the specific-nature of material instances.

original: saddhiṃ uppannā vedanā vedanākkhandho, taṃsampayuttā saññā saññākkhandho, saṅkhārā
analyzed: saddhim uppannā vedanā vedanā khandho tad sampayuttā saññā saññā khandho saṅkhārā
translated: So all these twenty-seven material instances are the materiality aggregate. The feeling that arises together with the eighty-one mundane consciousnesses is the feeling aggregate. Perception associated therewith is the perception aggregate. The formations associated therewith are the formations aggregate. Consciousness is the consciousness aggregate.

original: saṅkhārakkhandho, viññāṇaṃ viññāṇakkhandhoti. Iti rūpakkhandho rūpaṃ, cattāro arūpino
analyzed: saṅkhāra kkhandhaḥ viññāṇam viññāṇa kkhandho ti iti rūpa kkhandhaḥ rūpam cattāro arūpino
translated: So the materiality aggregate is materiality. The four immaterial aggregates are immaterial.

original: khandhā nāmanti evameko pañcakkhandhavasena nāmarūpaṃ vavatthapeti.🔽668. Aparo “yaṃkiñci rūpaṃ sabbaṃ rūpaṃ cattāri mahābhūtāni catunnañca mahābhūtānaṃ🔽upādāyarūpa”nti evaṃ saṃkhitteneva imasmiṃ attabhāve rūpaṃ pariggahetvā, tathā manāyatanañceva
analyzed: khandhāḥ nāmanti evam ekaḥ pañca kkhandha vasena nāma rūpam vavatthapeti  aparaḥ yaṃkiñci rūpam sabbam rūpam cattāri mahābhūtāni catunnam ca mahābhūtānam  evam saṃkhittena iva imasmin atta bhāve rūpam pariggahetvā tathā
translated: So he defines mentality-materiality by means of the five aggregates.

original: dhammāyatanekadesañca nāmanti pariggahetvā “iti idañca nāmaṃ idañca rūpaṃ, idaṃ vuccati🔽nāmarūpa”nti saṅkhepato nāmarūpaṃ vavatthapeti.🔽669. Sace panassa tena tena mukhena rūpaṃ pariggahetvā arūpaṃ pariggaṇhato sukhumattā🔽arūpaṃ na upaṭṭhāti, tena dhuranikkhepaṃ akatvā rūpameva punappunaṃ sammasitabbaṃ
analyzed: dhamma āyatana ekadesam ca nāmanti pariggahetvā iti idam ca nāmam idam ca rūpam idam vuccati  nāma rūpanti saṅkhepataḥ nāma rūpam vavatthapeti  sace pana assa tena tena mukhena rūpam pariggahetvā arūpam pariggaṇhato sukhuma tā  arūpam na upaṭṭhāti tena dhura nikkhepam a katvā rūpam eva punappunam sammasitabbam
translated: Another defines materiality in this way: “Any kind of materiality whatever, all that is the four great primaries and the four derived materiality in this person, and he defines the mind base and the mental-data base as mentality, thus: “So this mentality and this materiality are what is called mentality-materiality” .

original: manasikātabbaṃ pariggahetabbaṃ vavatthapetabbaṃ. Yathā yathā hissa rūpaṃ suvikkhālitaṃ
analyzed: manasikātabbam pariggahetabbam vavatthapetabbam yathā yathā hissa rūpam su vikkhālitam
translated: But if, when he defines materiality in this way by means of the various modes of materiality, immateriality does not appear to him as such owing to its subtlety, then he should not give up the task of defining immateriality but should again and again comprehend materiality, give his attention to it, define it and determine it. For as he does so materiality becomes more and more refined, more and more rarefied, more and more unwound, more and more subdued.

original: hoti nijjaṭaṃ suparisuddhaṃ, tathā tathā tadārammaṇā arūpadhammā sayameva pākaṭā honti.
analyzed: hoti nijjaṭam su parisuddham tathā tathā tad ārammaṇāḥ arūpa dhammā sayam eva pākaṭāḥ honti
translated: and the mirror becomes very clean, so too, the immaterial states that have that as their object become clear by themselves.

original: Yathā hi cakkhumato purisassa aparisuddhe ādāse mukhanimittaṃ olokentassa nimittaṃ
analyzed: yathā hi cakkhumataḥ purisassa a parisuddhe ādāse mukha nimittam olokentassa nimittam
translated: Just as, when a man with good eyesight is looking at an uncleaned looking-glass, the reflection

original: na paññāyati, so “nimittaṃ na paññāyatī”ti na ādāsaṃ chaḍḍeti, atha kho naṃ punappunaṃ
analyzed: na paññāyati saḥ nimittam na paññāyati iti na ādāsam chaḍḍeti atha kho nam punappunam
translated: does not appear in it, and he does not throw the looking-glass away thinking that the reflection does not appear because of the looking-glass, but rather he polishes it again and again,

analyzed: udake a vippasīdante na katakaṭṭhim chaḍḍeti atha kho nam punappunam ghaṃsati tassa evam

analyzed: pariggahetabbam vavatthapetabbam  yathā yathā hissa rūpam su vikkhālitam hoti nijjaṭam su parisuddham tathā tathā tad paccanīka kilesā

original: Arūpadhammānaṃ upaṭṭhānākārakathā
analyzed: arūpa dhammānam upaṭṭhāna ākāra kathā
translated: The way in which immaterial states become evident

original: phassavasena vā vedanāvasena vā viññāṇavasena vā. Kathaṃ? Ekassa tāva “pathavīdhātu🔽kakkhaḷalakkhaṇā”tiādinā nayena dhātuyo pariggaṇhantassa paṭhamābhinipāto phasso,🔽taṃsampayuttā vedanā vedanākkhandho, saññā saññākkhandho, saddhiṃ phassena cetanā
analyzed: phassa vasena vā vedanā vasena vā viññāṇa vasena vā katham ekassa tāva pathavī dhātu  kakkhaḷa lakkhaṇa ati ādinā nayena dhātuyaḥ pariggaṇhantassa paṭhama abhinipātaḥ phassaḥ  tad sampayuttā vedanā vedanā kkhandho saññā saññā kkhandho saddhim phassena cetanā
translated: Or else they appear through contact, through feeling, or through consciousness. How? To one who discerns the elements in the way beginning, “The earth element has the characteristic of hardness,” the first impact is contact,

analyzed: assāsa passāse pathavī dhātu kakkhaḷa lakkhaṇā ati paṭhama abhinipātaḥ phassaḥ tad sampayuttā

original: vedanā vedanākkhandho…pe… cittaṃ viññāṇakkhandhoti upaṭṭhāti. Evaṃ arūpadhammā phassavasena upaṭṭhahanti.

original: Ekassa “pathavīdhātu kakkhaḷalakkhaṇā”ti tadārammaṇarasānubhavanakavedanā vedanākkhandho,
analyzed: ekassa pathavī dhātu kakkhaḷa lakkhaṇā ti tad ārammaṇa rasa anubhavanaka vedanā vedanā khandho
translated: To one who discerns the element in the way beginning, “The earth element has the characteristic of hardness,” the feeling that experiences the object of that is the feeling aggregate,

original: taṃsampayuttā saññā saññākkhandho, taṃsampayutto phasso ca cetanā ca saṅkhārakkhandho,
analyzed: tad sampayuttā saññā saññā kkhandho tad sampayuttaḥ phassaḥ ca cetanā ca saṅkhāra kkhandho

original: taṃsampayuttaṃ cittaṃ viññāṇakkhandhoti upaṭṭhāti. Tathā “kese pathavīdhātu kakkhaḷalakkhaṇā
analyzed: tad sampayuttam cittam viññāṇa kkhandho ti upaṭṭhāti tathā kese pathavī dhātu kakkhaḷa lakkhaṇā

analyzed: pe assāsa passāse pathavī dhātu kakkhaḷa lakkhaṇā ati tad ārammaṇa rasa anubhavanaka vedanā
translated: Similarly, when he has defined the head hairs as the earth element, the characteristic of hardness, and so on, then the feeling that experiences the taste of that object is the feeling aggregate.🔽… the perception is the perception aggregate. The contact and the choice are the formations aggregate.

original: vedanākkhandho…pe… taṃsampayuttaṃ cittaṃ viññāṇakkhandhoti upaṭṭhāti. Evaṃ vedanāvasena

original: taṃsampayuttā vedanā vedanākkhandho, saññā saññākkhandho, phasso ca cetanā ca saṅkhārakkhandhoti🔽upaṭṭhāti. Tathā “kese pathavīdhātu kakkhaḷalakkhaṇā…pe… assāsapassāse pathavīdhātu
analyzed: tad sampayuttā vedanā vedanā kkhandho saññā saññā kkhandho phasso ca cetanā ca saṅkhāra kkhandho ti 🔽upaṭṭhāti tathā kese pathavī dhātu kakkhaḷa lakkhaṇa āpe assāsa passāse pathavī dhātu

original: kakkhaḷalakkhaṇā”ti ārammaṇapaṭivijānanaṃ viññāṇaṃ viññāṇakkhandho, taṃsampayuttā
analyzed: kakkhaḷa lakkhaṇā ti ārammaṇa paṭivijānanam viññāṇam viññāṇa kkhandho tad sampayuttā
translated: the characteristic of hardness is the material form aggregate. The consciousness that is the experiencing of the object is the consciousness aggregate. The feeling that is associated with that is the feeling aggregate.

analyzed: vedanā vedanā kkhandho saññā saññā kkhandho phasso ca cetanā ca saṅkhāra kkhandho ti
translated: The consciousness that is the discerning of the object’s individual essence is the consciousness aggregate. The feeling associated with that is the feeling aggregate. The perception is the perception aggregate. The contact and the volition are the formations aggregate.

analyzed: etena iva upāyena kamma samuṭṭhāne kese pathavī dhātu kakkhaḷa lakkhaṇā iti ādinā nayena  dvācattālīsāya dhātu koṭṭhāsesu catunnam catunnam dhātūnam vasena sesesu ca cakkhu dhātu ādīsu
translated: In the same way, by the method stated thus, “In what is derived from kamma, the earth element in the head hairs is characterized by stiffenedness,”

analyzed: sambahula suttanta saṃsandanā  saḥ evam yāthāvasarasataḥ nāma rūpam vavatthapetvā suṭṭhutaram sattaḥ puggalo ti  imissā loka samaññāya pahāna atthāya satta sammohassa samatikkama atthāya a sammoha bhūmiyam  cittam ṭhapana tthāya sambahula suttanta vasena nāma rūpa mattam eva idam na sattaḥ na

analyzed: vohāra mattam hoti doṇi tanti ādīsu vīṇā ati hatthi assa ādīsu senā ati pākāra geha gopura ādīsu  nagaranti khandha sākhā palāsa ādīsu ekena ākārena ṭhitesu rukkho ti vohāra mattam hoti
translated: “army,” “grove,” “forest,” “hill,” “mountain,” “town,” “village,” “city,” “woman,” “man,” “boy,” “girl,”

original: paramatthato ekekasmiṃ avayave upaparikkhiyamāne rukkho nāma natthi. Evamevaṃ pañcasu🔽upādānakkhandhesu sati “satto, puggalo”ti vohāramattaṃ hoti, paramatthato ekekasmiṃ🔽dhamme upaparikkhiyamāne “asmīti vā ahanti vā”ti gāhassa vatthubhūto satto nāma natthi.
analyzed: paramatthataḥ ekekasmin avayave upaparikkhiyamāne rukkhaḥ nāma na atthi evam evam pañcasu  upādānakkhandhesu sati satto puggalo ti vohāra mattam hoti paramatthataḥ ekekasmin  dhamme upaparikkhiyamāne asmi iti vā aham iti vā ti gāhassa vatthu bhūto satto nāma natthi
translated: “two,” “three,” “four,” “five,” “many,” “great,” “small,” “long,” “short,” “square,” “round,” “high,” “low,”

analyzed: paramatthato pana nāma rūpam attam eva atthi iti evam passataḥ hi dassanam yathābhūtadassanam nāma hoti
