original: 674. Yo panetaṃ yathābhūtadassanaṃ pahāya “satto atthī”ti gaṇhāti. So tassa vināsaṃ
analyzed: yaḥ pana etam yathābhūta dassanam pahāya satto atthi iti gaṇhāti saḥ tassa vināsam
translated: But one who, abandoning the seeing of this as it actually is, holds that “a being exists” must either admit its non-disappearance

original: anujāneyya avināsaṃ vā. Avināsaṃ anujānanto sassate patati. Vināsaṃ anujānanto ucchede
analyzed: anujāneyya avināsam vā avināsam anujānantaḥ sassate patati vināsam anujānantaḥ ucchede
translated: or its disappearance. If he admits its non-disappearance, he falls into the view of eternalism. If he admits its disappearance, he falls into the view of annihilationism.

original: patati. Kasmā? Khīranvayassa dadhino viya tadanvayassa aññassa abhāvato. So “sassato
analyzed: patati kasmā khīḥ anvayassa dadhinaḥ viya tad anvayassa aññassa abhāvato saḥ sassato
translated: Why? Because there is no other subsequent continuity of the same kind as that of milk and curd.🔽So he who holds that “a being is eternal” is said to “lean to eternalism,” and he who holds that “it is annihilated” is said to “lean to annihilationism.”

original: satto”ti gaṇhanto olīyati nāma. “Ucchijjatī”ti gaṇhanto atidhāvati nāma. Tenāha bhagavā –
analyzed: satto iti gaṇhantaḥ olīyati nāma ucchijjati iti gaṇhantaḥ atidhāvati nāma tena āha bhagavā
translated: Hence the Blessed One said:

original: “Dvīhi, bhikkhave, diṭṭhigatehi pariyuṭṭhitā devamanussā olīyanti eke, atidhāvanti eke, cakkhumanto ca passanti.
analyzed: dvīhi bhikkhave diṭṭhi gatehi pariyuṭṭhitāḥ deva manussāḥ olīyanti eke atidhāvanti eke cakkhumanto ca passanti
translated: “Monks, gods and men lean on two ideas, and some lean on the idea of eternity and some on the idea of annihilation. But those with eyes see” .

original: “Kathañca, bhikkhave, olīyanti eke? Bhavārāmā, bhikkhave, devamanussā bhavaratā bhavasamuditā.
analyzed: kathañca bhikkhave olīyanti eke bhava ārāmāḥ bhikkhave deva manussāḥ bhava ratāḥ bhava samuditā
translated: “And how, monks, do some lean to eternalism? Monks, gods and men delight in becoming, are devoted to becoming, bound to the bondage of becoming.

original: Tesaṃ bhavanirodhāya dhamme desiyamāne cittaṃ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati
analyzed: tesam bhava nirodhāya dhamme desiyamāne cittam na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati
translated: When the Dhamma is taught to them for the cessation of becoming, their minds do not enter into it, acquire confidence in it, settle upon it, or resolve upon it.

original: nādhimuccati. Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, olīyanti eke.
analyzed: na adhimuccati evam kho bhikkhave olīyanti eke
translated: That is how some lean to eternalism.

original: “Kathañca, bhikkhave, atidhāvanti eke? Bhaveneva kho paneke aṭṭīyamānā harāyamānā🔽jigucchamānā vibhavaṃ abhinandanti, yato kira bho ayaṃ attā kāyassa bhedā ucchijjati
analyzed: katham ca bhikkhave atidhāvanti eke bhavena iva kho pana eke aṭṭīyamānāḥ harāyamānāḥ  jigucchamānāḥ vibhavam abhinandanti yatas kira bho ayam attā kāyassa bhedāt ucchijjati
translated: “And how, bhikkhus, do some run too far? There are some ascetics and brahmins who, being distressed, ashamed, and disgusted with this world, delight in non-existence thus: ‘If only this self, when the body perishes, would be destroyed and annihilated!🔽

original: vinassati, na hoti paraṃmaraṇā, etaṃ santaṃ, etaṃ paṇītaṃ, etaṃ yāthāvanti. Evaṃ
analyzed: vinassati na hoti paraṃmaraṇā etam santam etam paṇītam etam yāthāvanti evam
translated: “And how do some run too far? There are some who, being distressed, ashamed, and disgusted with existence itself, delight in non-existence, thinking, ‘When this self, with the breakup of the body, is cut off, annihilated, does not become any more after death, that is peaceful, that is sublime, that is just the way things are.’

original: kho, bhikkhave, atidhāvanti eke.🔽“Kathañca, bhikkhave, cakkhumanto passanti? Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu bhūtaṃ bhūtato
analyzed: kho bhikkhave atidhāvanti eke  katham ca bhikkhave cakkhumantaḥ passanti idha bhikkhave bhikkhu bhūtam bhūtatas
translated: “Thus, bhikkhus, some run too far.

original: passati, bhūtaṃ bhūtato disvā bhūtassa nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti.
analyzed: passati bhūtam bhūtataḥ disvā bhūtassa nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti
translated: “And how do those with eyes see? There is the case where a bhikkhu sees any phenomenon that arises as arisen, sees any phenomenon that persists as persisted, sees any phenomenon that ceases as ceased.

original: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, cakkhumanto passantī”ti.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave cakkhumanto passanti iti
translated: “This is how those with eyes see.”

original: 675. Tasmā yathā dāruyantaṃ suññaṃ nijjīvaṃ nirīhakaṃ, atha ca pana dārurajjukasamāyogavasena
analyzed: tasmai yathā dāruyantam suññam nijjīvam nirīhakam atha ca pana dāru rajjuka samāyoga vasena
translated: Therefore, just as a wooden doll is empty, lifeless, and inert, yet moves and is seen moving by means of the combination and cooperation of strings, pulleys, and a mechanical device,

original: gacchatipi tiṭṭhatipi. Saīhakaṃ sabyāpāraṃ viya khāyati, evamidaṃ nāmarūpampi suññaṃ
analyzed: gacchati pi tiṭṭhati pi sa īhakam sa byāpāram viya khāyati evam idam nāma rūpam pi suññam
translated: and appears to have movement and activity, though lacking any inner movement or activity, so too is this mentality-materiality empty,

original: nijjīvaṃ nirīhakaṃ, atha ca pana aññamaññasamāyogavasena gacchatipi tiṭṭhatipi. Saīhakaṃ
analyzed: nijjīvam nirīhakam atha ca pana aññamañña samāyoga vasena gacchati pi tiṭṭhati pi sa īhakam
translated: and yet it moves and stands by the combination of the two. It should be regarded as though it were a machine,

original: sabyāpāraṃ viya khāyatīti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Tenāhu porāṇā –
analyzed: sa byāpāram viya khāyati iti daṭṭhabbam tena āhu porāṇā
translated: as though it were a contrivance of wood and string, which moves and stands by the combination of the two. Hence the Ancients said:

original: “Nāmañca rūpañca idhatthi saccato,
analyzed: nāmañca rūpañca idhatthi saccatas
translated: “Herein, name-and-form is true,

original: Na hettha satto manujo ca vijjati;
analyzed: na ha ittha sattaḥ manujaḥ ca vijjati
translated: But here no being is to be found;

original: Suññaṃ idaṃ yantamivābhisaṅkhataṃ,
analyzed: suññam idam yantam iva abhisaṅkhatam
translated: This frame is void, a mere mechanism,

original: Dukkhassa puñjo tiṇakaṭṭhasādiso”ti.
analyzed: dukkhassa puñjaḥ tiṇa kaṭṭha sādisaḥ ti
translated: A mass of suffering like grass and sticks” .

original: Na kevalañcetaṃ dāruyantupamāya, aññāhipi naḷakalāpīādīhi upamāhi vibhāvetabbaṃ –🔽yathā hi dvīsu naḷakalāpīsu aññamaññaṃ nissāya ṭhapitāsu ekā ekissā upatthambho hoti,
analyzed: na kevalam ca itam dāruyanta upamāya aññāhi pi naḷa kalāpī ādīhi upamāhi vibhāvetabbam  yathā hi dvīsu naḷa kalāpīsu aññam aññam nissāya ṭhapitāsu ekā ekissāḥ upatthambhaḥ hoti
translated: And this should be illustrated not only by the machine simile but also by the other similes of the reed-bundle, the sack of grain, etc.,

original: ekissā patamānāya itarāpi patati, evamevaṃ pañcavokārabhave nāmarūpaṃ aññamaññaṃ🔽nissāya pavattati, ekaṃ ekassa upatthambho hoti. Maraṇavasena ekasmiṃ patamāne itarampi
analyzed: ekissā patamānāya itarā api patati evam evam pañcavokāra bhave nāma rūpam aññam aññam  nissāya pavattati ekam ekassa upatthambhaḥ hoti maraṇa vasena ekasmin patamāne itaram pi
translated: For just as two bundles of reeds stand firm when they are bound together, and if one falls down the other supports it, and if that one falls down the first supports it, so too, in the five-constituent becoming, name-and-form occurs in dependence on the other,

original: patati. Tenāhu porāṇā –
analyzed: patati tena āhu porāṇā
translated: and each is a support for the other. When one falls down the other falls down with death as the falling down. Hence the Ancients said:

original: “Yamakaṃ nāmarūpañca, ubho aññoññanissitā;
analyzed: yamakam nāma rūpam ca ubho aññoñña nissitā
translated: “Name-and-form and twin-born death

original: Ekasmiṃ bhijjamānasmiṃ, ubho bhijjanti paccayā”ti.
analyzed: ekasmin bhijjamānasmin ubho bhijjanti paccayā ati
translated: When one of the two breaks up, both conditions break up.🔽And just as when a drum is beaten, the sound occurs contingent on the drum, and the drum is not the sound,

original: 676. Yathā ca daṇḍābhihataṃ bheriṃ nissāya sadde pavattamāne aññā bherī, añño saddo,
analyzed: yathā ca daṇḍa abhihatam bherim nissāya sadde pavattamāne aññā bherī aññaḥ saddo
translated: nor is the sound anything else apart from the drum,

original: bherisaddā asammissā, bherī saddena suññā, saddo bheriyā suñño, evamevaṃ vatthudvārārammaṇasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: bheri saddāḥ asammissāḥ bherī saddena suññā saddaḥ bheriyā suññaḥ evam evam vatthu dvāra ārammaṇa saṅkhātam
translated: so too, contingent on the materiality called the physical basis, the door, and the object, the mentality called the associated and co-existent states occurs, and the materiality is not the mentality,

original: rūpaṃ nissāya nāme pavattamāne aññaṃ rūpaṃ, aññaṃ nāmaṃ, nāmarūpā asammissā, nāmaṃ🔽rūpena suññaṃ, rūpaṃ nāmena suññaṃ, apica kho bheriṃ paṭicca saddo viya rūpaṃ paṭicca
analyzed: rūpam nissāya nāme pavattamāne aññam rūpam aññam nāmam nāma rūpāḥ asammissāḥ nāmaṃ  rūpena suññam rūpam nāmena suññam api ca kho bherim paṭicca saddaḥ viya rūpam paṭicca
translated: nor is the mentality anything else apart from the materiality.

original: nāmaṃ pavattati. Tenāhu porāṇā –
analyzed: nāmam tena āhu porāṇāḥ
translated: Moreover, just as the sound occurs contingent on the drum, so mentality occurs contingent on materiality. Hence the Ancients said:

original: “Na cakkhuto jāyare phassapañcamā,
analyzed: na cakkhutaḥ phassa pañcamā
translated: “The five beginning with contact are not born from the eye,

original: Na rūpato no ca ubhinnamantarā;
analyzed: na rūpataḥ na u ca ubhin nam antarā
translated: Nor from the visible form, nor from both, in between;

original: Hetuṃ paṭiccappabhavanti saṅkhatā,
analyzed: hetum paṭicca ppabhavanti saṅkha tā
translated: They come to be contingent on a cause,

original: Yathāpi saddo pahaṭāya bheriyā.
analyzed: yathā api saddo pahaṭāya bheriyā
translated: Just as the sound from a beaten drum.

original: “Na sotato jāyare phassapañcamā,
analyzed: na sotataḥ jāyare phassa pañcamā
translated: “The five beginning with contact are not born from the ear,

original: Na saddato no ca ubhinnamantarā…pe….
analyzed: na sad dataḥ na u ca ubhin nam antara āpe
translated: Nor from the sound, nor from both, in between …

original: “Na ghānato jāyare phassapañcamā,
analyzed: na ghānataḥ phassa pañcamā
translated: “The five beginning with contact are not born from the nose,

original: Na gandhato no ca ubhinnamantarā…pe….🔽“Na jivhāto jāyare phassapañcamā,
analyzed: na gandhataḥ na u ca  na jivhātaḥ phassa pañcamā
translated: Nor from smell, nor from both, nor from no cause.

original: Na rasato no ca ubhinnamantarā…pe….🔽“Na kāyato jāyare phassapañcamā,
analyzed: na rasataḥ na u ca  na kāyataḥ phassa pañcamā
translated: Nor from tongue, nor from taste, nor from both, nor from no cause.🔽Nor from body, nor from tangibles, nor from both, nor from no cause.

original: Na phassato no ca ubhinnamantarā…pe….
analyzed: na phassataḥ no ca ubhinnam antarāpe
translated: Nor from mind, nor from mental phenomena, nor from both, nor from no cause.

original: “Na vatthurūpā pabhavanti saṅkhatā,
analyzed: na vatthurūpā pabhavanti saṅkhatā
translated: “The formed do not originate from the visible form base,

original: Na cāpi dhammāyatanehi niggatā;
analyzed: na ca api dhamma āyatanehi niggatā
translated: Nor do they originate from the other sense bases.

original: Hetuṃ paṭiccappabhavanti saṅkhatā,
analyzed: hetum paṭicca ppabhavanti saṅkha tā
translated: The formed originate from a cause,

original: Yathāpi saddo pahaṭāya bheriyā”ti.🔽677. Apicettha nāmaṃ nittejaṃ na sakena tejena pavattituṃ sakkoti, na khādati, na🔽pivati, na byāharati, na iriyāpathaṃ kappeti. Rūpampi nittejaṃ na sakena tejena pavattituṃ🔽sakkoti. Na hi tassā khāditukāmatā, nāpi pivitukāmatā, na byāharitukāmatā, na iriyāpathaṃ
analyzed: yathā api saddo pahaṭāya bheriyā ati  api ca ittha nāmam nittejam na sakena tejena pavattitum sakkoti na khādati na  pivati na byāharati na iriyāpatham kappeti rūpam pi nittejam na sakena tejena pavattitum  sakkoti na hi tassā khāditu kāma tā na api pivitu kāma tā na byāharitu kāma tā na iriyāpatham
translated: Just as a sound originates from a beaten drum.”

original: kappetukāmatā, atha kho nāmaṃ nissāya rūpaṃ pavattati, rūpaṃ nissāya nāmaṃ pavattati,
analyzed: kappetu kāma tā atha kho nāmam nissāya rūpam pavattati rūpam nissāya nāmam pavattati
translated: Herein, mentality does not occur by its own power. It does not eat, nor drink, nor speak, nor does it perform any postures. Nor does materiality occur by its own power. It does not want to eat, nor to drink, nor to speak, nor to perform any postures. But rather, materiality occurs supported by mentality, and mentality occurs supported by materiality.

original: nāmassa khāditukāmatāya pivitukāmatāya byāharitukāmatāya iriyāpathaṃ kappetukāmatāya
analyzed: nāmassa khāditu kāma tāya pivitu kāma tāya byāharitu kāma tāya iriyāpatham kappetu kāma tāya
translated: When the name is desirous of eating, desirous of drinking, desirous of speaking, desirous of making bodily-action,

original: sati rūpaṃ khādati, pivati, byāharati, iriyāpathaṃ kappeti.
analyzed: sati rūpam khādati pivati byāharati iriyāpatham kappeti
translated: then the materiality eats, drinks, speaks, makes bodily-action.

original: Imassa panatthassa vibhāvanatthāya imaṃ upamaṃ udāharanti – yathā jaccandho ca pīṭhasappī🔽ca disāpakkamitukāmā assu, jaccandho pīṭhasappiṃ evamāha “ahaṃ kho bhaṇe, sakkomi🔽pādehi pādakaraṇīyaṃ kātuṃ, natthi ca me cakkhūni yehi samavisamaṃ passeyya”nti.🔽Pīṭhasappīpi jaccandhaṃ evamāha “ahaṃ kho bhaṇe, sakkomi cakkhunā cakkhukaraṇīyaṃ
analyzed: imassa pana atthassa vibhāvana tthāya imam upamam udāharanti yathā ca pīṭhasappī  ca disā pakkamitu kāmāḥ assu pīṭha sappim evam āha aham kho bhaṇe sakkomi  pādehi pāda karaṇīyam kātum natthi ca me cakkhūni yehi sama visamam passeyyanti  evam āha aham kho bhaṇe sakkomi cakkhunā cakkhu karaṇīyam
translated: In order to elucidate this meaning, this simile is given: Suppose a man blind from birth and a man with eyes🔽were desirous of travelling in a certain direction, and the man blind from birth said to the man with eyes: ‘I want to travel in such and such a direction. I am able to do what has to be done with the feet, but I have no eyes to see what is even and uneven’,

original: kātuṃ, natthi ca me pādāni yehi abhikkameyyaṃ vā paṭikkameyyaṃ vā”ti. So tuṭṭhahaṭṭho
analyzed: kātum natthi ca me pādāni yehi abhikkameyyam vā paṭikkameyyam vā ati so tuṭṭha haṭṭhaḥ
translated: and the man with eyes said to the man blind from birth: ‘I want to travel in such and such a direction. I am able to do what has to be done with the eyes, but I have no feet with which to go forward or return’, and the man blind from birth was pleased with the man with eyes and mounted him on his shoulder,

original: jaccandho pīṭhasappiṃ aṃsakūṭaṃ āropesi. Pīṭhasappī jaccandhassa aṃsakūṭe nisīditvā
analyzed: jat candhaḥ pīṭha sappim aṃsakūṭam āropesi pīṭha sappī jat candhassa aṃsakūṭe nisīditvā
translated: and the man with eyes sat on the man blind from birth’s shoulder,

original: evamāha “vāmaṃ muñca dakkhiṇaṃ gaṇha, dakkhiṇaṃ muñca vāmaṃ gaṇhā”ti. Tattha jaccandhopi
analyzed: evam āha vāmam muñca dakkhiṇam gaṇha dakkhiṇam muñca vāmam gaṇhāti
translated: He says: “Let go of the left, take hold with the right; let go of the right, take hold with the left.” Herein, the born-blind man

original: nittejo dubbalo na sakena tejena sakena balena gacchati, pīṭhasappīpi nittejo dubbalo
analyzed: nittejaḥ dubbalaḥ na sakena tejena sakena balena gacchati nittejaḥ dubbalaḥ
translated: has no power of his own, no strength of his own, and so he does not go by his own power, by his own strength. The man with the wooden leg

original: na sakena tejena sakena balena gacchati, na ca tesaṃ aññamaññaṃ nissāya gamanaṃ nappavattati,
analyzed: na sakena tejena sakena balena gacchati na ca tesam aññam aññam nissāya gamanam na ppavattati
translated: has no power of his own, no strength of his own, and so he does not go by his own power, by his own strength. But their going does not fail to occur by depending on each other.

original: evamevaṃ nāmampi nittejaṃ na sakena tejena uppajjati, na tāsu tāsu kiriyāsu pavattati.
analyzed: evam evam nāmam pi nittejam na sakena tejena uppajjati na tāsu tāsu kiriyāsu pavattati
translated: So too, mentality has no power of its own, no strength of its own, and so it does not occur by its own power, by its own strength, and it does not occur in the various kinds of activity.

original: Rūpampi nittejaṃ na sakena tejena uppajjati, na tāsu tāsu kiriyāsu pavattati, na
analyzed: rūpam pi nittejam na sakena tejena uppajjati na tāsu tāsu kiriyāsu pavattati na
translated: Mentality-materiality has no power of its own, no strength of its own, and so it does not occur by its own power, by its own strength,

original: ca tesaṃ aññamaññaṃ nissāya uppatti vā pavatti vā na hoti. Tenetaṃ vuccati –
analyzed: ca tesam aññam aññam nissāya uppatti vā pavatti vā na hoti tena itam vuccati
translated: and yet their occurrence does not fail to take place by depending on each other. Hence it is said:

original: “Na sakena balena jāyare,
analyzed: na sakena balena jāyare
translated: “They are not born by their own strength,

original: Nopi sakena balena tiṭṭhare;
analyzed: na upi sakena balena tiṭṭhare
translated: Nor do they stand by their own strength.

original: Paradhammavasānuvattino,
analyzed: para dhamma vasa anuvattino
translated: They follow the course of other dhammas,

original: Jāyare saṅkhatā attadubbalā.
analyzed: jāyare saṅkhatā atta dubbalā
translated: Born compounded, weak in self.

original: “Parapaccayato ca jāyare,
analyzed: ca jāyare
translated: “They are born by dependence on another,

original: Paraārammaṇato samuṭṭhitā;
analyzed: para ārammaṇato samuṭṭhitā
translated: Arisen by support of another;

original: Ārammaṇapaccayehi ca,
analyzed: ārammaṇa paccayehi ca
translated: By conditions for their object,

original: Paradhammehi cime pabhāvitā.
analyzed: para dhammehi cime pabhāvitā
translated: And by the other dhammas that are dependent on them.🔽“Just as people go about in a boat,

original: “Yathāpi nāvaṃ nissāya, manussā yanti aṇṇave;
analyzed: yathā api nāvam nissāya manussāḥ yanti aṇṇave
translated: Relying on it on the water,🔽So too the mental body occurs,

original: Evameva rūpaṃ nissāya, nāmakāyo pavattati.
analyzed: evam eva rūpam nissāya nāmakāyaḥ pavattati
translated: Relying on the material body.🔽“And just as the boat goes about,

original: “Yathā ca manusse nissāya, nāvā gacchati aṇṇave;
analyzed: yathā ca manusse nissāya nāvā gacchati aṇṇave
translated: Relying on the people on it,🔽So too the material body occurs,

original: Evameva nāmaṃ nissāya, rūpakāyo pavattati.
analyzed: evam eva nāmam nissāya rūpa kāyo pavattati
translated: Relying on the mental body.🔽“The people and the boat go about

original: “Ubho nissāya gacchanti, manussā nāvā ca aṇṇave;
analyzed: ubho nissāya gacchanti manussāḥ nāvā ca aṇṇave
translated: Relying on each other on the water;🔽So too the mental and material bodies

original: Evaṃ nāmañca rūpañca, ubho aññoññanissitā”ti.
analyzed: evam nāman ca rūpañca ubho aññoñña nissitā ati
translated: Occur, each relying on the other.”

original: Evaṃ nānānayehi nāmarūpaṃ vavatthāpayato sattasaññaṃ abhibhavitvā asammohabhūmiyaṃ🔽ṭhitaṃ nāmarūpānaṃ yāthāvadassanaṃ diṭṭhivisuddhīti veditabbaṃ. Nāmarūpavavatthānantipi
analyzed: evam nānā nayehi nāma rūpam vavatthāpayato satta saññam abhibhavitvā a sammoha bhūmiyam  ṭhitam nāma rūpānam yāthāva dassanam diṭṭhi visuddhi iti veditabbam nāma rūpa vavatthānam ti pi
translated: When he has defined mentality-materiality in this way by these various methods, he abandons the perception of beings and reaches the plane of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.🔽The seeing of mentality-materiality as it actually is is what is called purification by overcoming doubt.

original: saṅkhāraparicchedotipi etasseva adhivacanaṃ.
analyzed: saṅkhāra pariccheda utipi etassa iva adhivacanam
translated: This is also called “defining of mentality-materiality” and “defining of formations.”🔽In the Path of Purification

original: Iti sādhujanapāmojjatthāya kate visuddhimagge🔽Paññābhāvanādhikāre
analyzed: iti sādhu jana pāmojjatthāya kate visuddhi magge  paññā bhāvanā adhikāre
translated: composed for the purpose of gladdening good people,

original: Diṭṭhivisuddhiniddeso nāma
analyzed: diṭṭhivisuddhiniddesaḥ nāma
translated: called “The Description of Purification by Overcoming Doubt,”

original: Aṭṭhārasamo paricchedo.🔽19. Kaṅkhāvitaraṇavisuddhiniddeso🔽Paccayapariggahakathā
analyzed: aṭṭhārasamaḥ paricchedaḥ 🔽kaṅkhā vitaraṇa visuddhi niddesaḥ 🔽paccaya pariggaha kathā
translated: The eighteenth chapter.

original: 678. Etasseva pana nāmarūpassa paccayapariggahaṇena tīsu addhāsu kaṅkhaṃ vitaritvā ṭhitaṃ ñāṇaṃ kaṅkhāvitaraṇavisuddhi nāma.
analyzed: etassa iva pana nāma rūpassa paccaya pariggahaṇena tīsu addhāsu kaṅkham vitaritvā ṭhitam ñāṇam kaṅkhāvitaraṇavisuddhi nāma
translated: The knowledge that is established by the defining of the conditions of that same mentality-materiality, after removing doubt about the three periods of time, is called purification by overcoming doubt.🔽A bhikkhu who wants to accomplish that should first of all seek out the conditions for that mentality-materiality in this way.

original: Taṃ sampādetukāmo bhikkhu yathā nāma kusalo bhisakko rogaṃ disvā tassa samuṭṭhānaṃ🔽pariyesati. Yathā vā pana anukampako puriso daharaṃ kumāraṃ mandaṃ uttānaseyyakaṃ
analyzed: tam sampādetu kāmaḥ bhikkhu yathā nāma kusalaḥ bhisakkaḥ rogam disvā tassa samuṭṭhānam  pariyesati yathā vā pana anukampakaḥ purisaḥ daharam kumāram mandam uttānaseyyakam
translated: Just as a skilled physician, when a patient has come for treatment, first seeks out the cause of the disease,🔽or just as a compassionate person, seeing a small child lying prone with its face to the ground, confused and babbling,

original: rathikāya nipannaṃ disvā “kassa nu kho ayaṃ puttako”ti tassa mātāpitaro āvajjati,
analyzed: rathikāya nipannam disvā kassa nu kho ayam puttakaḥ ti tassa mātā pitaraḥ āvajjati
translated: would seek out its mother and father,

original: evameva tassa nāmarūpassa hetupaccayapariyesanaṃ āpajjati.
analyzed: evam eva tassa nāma rūpassa hetu paccaya pariyesanam āpajjati
translated: so too, he should seek out the cause and condition for that mentality-materiality.

original: So āditova iti paṭisañcikkhati “na tāvidhaṃ nāmarūpaṃ ahetukaṃ, sabbattha sabbadā
analyzed: saḥ āditas vas iti paṭisañcikkhati na tāvidham nāma rūpam ahetukam sabbattha sabbadā
translated: He should first of all consider thus: “That mentality-materiality is not without cause, since it is not found to exist all the time,

original: sabbesañca ekasadisabhāvāpattito, na issarādihetukaṃ, nāmarūpato uddhaṃ issarādīnaṃ
analyzed: sabbesam ca eka sadisa bhāva āpattitaḥ na issara ādi hetukam nāma rūpataḥ issara ādīnam
translated: nor is it caused by a single cause, since it is not found to exist in the same way all the time, nor is it caused by a permanent being such as a supreme being,🔽since there is no existence of a supreme being, etc., apart from mentality-materiality.

original: abhāvato. Yepi nāmarūpamattameva issarādayoti vadanti, tesaṃ issarādisaṅkhātanāmarūpassa
analyzed: abhāvataḥ ye pi nāma rūpam attam eva issara ādayaḥ ti vadanti tesam issara ādi saṅkhāta nāma rūpassa
translated: And those who say that a supreme being, etc., is merely another name for mentality-materiality,

original: ahetukabhāvappattito. Tasmā bhavitabbamassa hetupaccayehi, ke nu kho te”ti.
analyzed: ahetuka bhāva ppattitaḥ tasmā bhavitabbam assa hetu paccayehi ke nu kho te iti
translated: because of the consequence that it would be without cause. So it must have causes and conditions. What are they? ”

original: 679. So evaṃ nāmarūpassa hetupaccaye āvajjetvā imassa tāva rūpakāyassa evaṃ hetupaccaye
analyzed: saḥ evam nāma rūpassa hetu paccaye āvajjetvā imassa tāva rūpa kāyassa evam hetu paccaye
translated: Having thus adverted to the causes and conditions for mentality-materiality, he discerns the causes and conditions for the material body in this way:

original: pariggaṇhāti – “ayaṃ kāyo nibbattamāno neva uppalapadumapuṇḍarīkasogandhikādīnaṃ
analyzed: pariggaṇhāti ayam kāyaḥ nibbattamānaḥ na iva uppala paduma puṇḍarīka sogandhika ādīnam
translated: “This body, when it is being born, is not born inside a blue, red or white lotus or in a clean place such as a crystal casket, etc.,

original: abbhantare nibbattati, na maṇimuttāhārādīnaṃ, atha kho āmāsayapakkāsayānaṃ antare🔽udarapaṭalaṃ pacchato piṭṭhikaṇṭakaṃ purato katvā antaantaguṇaparivārito sayampi
analyzed: abbhantare nibbattati na maṇi mutta āhāra ādīnam atha kho āmāsaya pakkāsayānam antare  udara paṭalam pacchatas piṭṭhikaṇṭakam puratas katvā anta anta guṇa parivārito sayam pi
translated: but rather in the midst of the foul slums of the mother’s belly,🔽between the stomach and the backbone, with the head pointing downwards and the back upwards, enclosed by the intestines and the bowels, surrounded by the liver and lungs,

original: duggandhajegucchapaṭikkūlo duggandhajegucchapaṭikkūle paramasambādhe okāse pūtimacchapūtikummāsaoḷigallacandanikādīsu🔽kimiva nibbattati. Tassevaṃ nibbattamānassa ‘avijjā taṇhā upādānaṃ kamma’nti ime
analyzed: duggandha jeguccha paṭikkūlaḥ duggandha jeguccha paṭikkūle parama sambādhe okāse pūtima cha pūti kummāsa oḷigalla candanikā ādīsu  kim iva nibbattati tassa ivam nibbattamānassa avijjā taṇhā upādānam kammanti ime
translated: and in a place that is fouler still than a public lavatory, in a place that is dark like a charcoal pit, that smells fouler than a cesspit, and that is more constricting than a narrow dungeon.🔽And when it is being born, it is born from four things, namely, ignorance, craving, clinging, and kamma,

original: cattāro dhammā nibbattakattā hetu, āhāro upatthambhakattā paccayoti pañca dhammā
analyzed: cattāro dhammā nibbattaka ttā hetu āhāraḥ upatthambhaka ttā paccayaḥ ti pañca dhammā
translated: which are its causes as generator, and nutriment, which is its condition as supporter. So there are five things.

original: hetupaccayā honti. Tesupi avijjādayo tayo imassa kāyassa mātā viya dārakassa upanissayā
analyzed: hetu paccayāḥ honti tesu pi avijjā ādayo tayo imassa kāyassa mātā viya dārakassa upanissayā
translated: and they are conditions for the material body. And of these, ignorance, etc., are the support conditions for the material body, as the mother is for the child;

original: honti. Kammaṃ pitā viya puttassa janakaṃ. Āhāro dhāti viya dārakassa sandhārako”ti.🔽Evaṃ rūpakāyassa paccayapariggahaṃ katvā, puna “cakkhuñca paṭicca rūpe ca uppajjati
analyzed: honti kammam pitā viya puttassa janakam āhāraḥ dhāti viya dārakassa sandhārakaḥ ti  evam rūpa kāyassa paccaya pariggaham katvā puna cakkhuñca paṭicca rūpe ca uppajjati
translated: kamma is the producing condition, as the father is for the child; and nutriment is the maintaining condition, as the nurse is for the child.”

original: cakkhuviññāṇa”ntiādinā nayena nāmakāyassa paccayapariggahaṃ karoti.
analyzed: cakkhu viññāṇa nti ādinā nayena nāmakāyassa paccaya pariggaham karoti
translated: Having thus discerned the conditions for the material body, he discerns the conditions for the mentality-materiality of the present time in the way beginning, “With eye and visible data as condition, eye-consciousness arises” .

original: So evaṃ paccayato nāmarūpassa pavattiṃ disvā yathā idaṃ etarahi, evaṃ atītepi addhāne paccayato pavattittha, anāgatepi paccayato pavattissatīti samanupassati.
analyzed: saḥ evam paccayataḥ nāma rūpassa pavattim disvā yathā idam etarahi evam atīte api addhāne paccayato pavattittha anāgate pi paccayato pavattissati iti samanupassati
translated: Having seen the occurrence of mentality-materiality as a condition, he sees that it occurred in the past time by the same principle of conditionality and that it will occur in the future time by the same principle of conditionality.

original: 680. Tassevaṃ samanupassato yā sā pubbantaṃ ārabbha “ahosiṃ nu kho ahaṃ atītamaddhānaṃ,
analyzed: tassa ivam samanupassataḥ yā sā pubbantam ārabbha ahosim nu kho aham atītam addhānam
translated: As he sees it thus, the doubt as to the past as to whether he existed in the past or not,

original: na nu kho ahosiṃ atītamaddhānaṃ, kiṃ nu kho ahosiṃ atītamaddhānaṃ, kathaṃ nu kho
analyzed: na nu kho ahosim atīta maddhānam kim nu kho ahosim atīta maddhānam katham nu kho
translated: as to whether he did not exist, as to whether he both did and did not exist, as to whether he neither did nor did not exist,

original: ahosiṃ atītamaddhānaṃ, kiṃ hutvā kiṃ ahosiṃ nu kho ahaṃ atītamaddhāna”nti pañcavidhā
analyzed: ahosim atīta maddhānam kim hutvā kim ahosim nu khalu aham atīta maddhānam iti pañcavidhā
translated: “Was I in the past? What was I in the past? What will I be in the future? What will I be in the future? What am I now that has come to be?”

original: vicikicchā vuttā, yāpi aparantaṃ ārabbha “bhavissāmi nu kho ahaṃ anāgatamaddhānaṃ,🔽na nu kho bhavissāmi anāgatamaddhānaṃ, kiṃ nu kho bhavissāmi anāgatamaddhānaṃ, kathaṃ🔽nu kho bhavissāmi anāgatamaddhānaṃ, kiṃ hutvā kiṃ bhavissāmi nu kho ahaṃ anāgatamaddhāna”nti
analyzed: vicikicchā vuttā yā api aparantam ārabbha bhavissāmi nu kho aham anāgatamaddhānam  na nu kho bhavissāmi anāgata maddhānam kim nu kho bhavissāmi anāgata maddhānam katham  nu kho bhavissāmi anāgatam addhānam kim hutvā kim bhavissāmi nu kho aham anāgatam addhānam ti
translated: and the five kinds of doubt stated thus: “Was I in the past? Was I not in the past? What was I in the past? How was I in the past? Having been what, what was I in the past?”

original: pañcavidhā vicikicchā vuttā, yāpi paccuppannaṃ ārabbha “etarahi vā pana paccuppannaṃ🔽addhānaṃ ajjhattaṃ kathaṃkathī hoti – ahaṃ nu khosmi, no nu khosmi, kiṃ nu khosmi,
analyzed: pañcavidhā vicikicchā vuttā yā api paccuppannam ārabbha etarahi vā pana paccuppannam  addhānam ajjhattam kathaṃkathī hoti aham nu khalu asmi no nu khalu asmi kim nu khalu asmi
translated: and the five kinds of doubt stated thus: “Shall I be in the future? Shall I not be in the future? What shall I be in the future? How shall I be in the future? Having been what, what shall I be in the future?”

original: kathaṃ nu khosmi, ayaṃ nu kho satto kuto āgato, so kuhiṃ gāmī bhavissatī”ti chabbidhā
analyzed: katham nu kha asmi ayam nu kho satto kutas āgataḥ saḥ kuhim gāmī bhavissati iti chabbidhā
translated: and the six kinds of doubt stated thus: “Or else, having taken present finiteness as the theme, he is doubtful, uncertain, undecided, and unconfident thus: ‘Am I? Am I not? What am I? How am I? This being what is? This being what will be? ‘”

original: vicikicchā vuttā, sā sabbāpi pahīyati.
analyzed: vicikicchā vuttā sā sabbā api pahīyati
translated: All this is abandoned.

original: 681. Aparo sādhāraṇāsādhāraṇavasena duvidhaṃ nāmassa paccayaṃ passati, kammādivasena🔽catubbidhaṃ rūpassa. Duvidho hi nāmassa paccayo sādhāraṇo asādhāraṇo ca. Tattha cakkhādīni
analyzed: aparo sādhāraṇa asādhāraṇa vasena duvidham nāmassa paccayam passati kamma ādi vasena  catubbidham rūpassa duvidhaḥ hi nāmassa paccayaḥ sādhāraṇaḥ asādhāraṇaḥ ca tattha cakkha ādīni
translated: Another sees the condition for mentality as twofold, as common and not common, and the condition for materiality as fourfold, as kamma, and so on.

original: cha dvārāni, rūpādīni cha ārammaṇāni nāmassa sādhāraṇo paccayo, kusalādibhedato sabbappakārassāpi
analyzed: cha dvārāni rūpa ādīni cha ārammaṇāni nāmassa sādhāraṇaḥ paccayaḥ kusala ādi bhedato sabba ppakārassa api
translated: For the condition for mentality is twofold as common and not common. Herein, the six doors beginning with the eye and the six objects beginning with visible data are the common condition for mentality, because it occurs in all kinds of mentality classed as profitable, etc.,

original: tato pavattito. Manasikārādiko asādhāraṇo. Yoniso manasikārasaddhammassavanādiko
analyzed: tatas pavattitaḥ manasikāra ādikaḥ asādhāraṇaḥ yonisaḥ manasikāra saddhamma ssavana ādikaḥ
translated: because it occurs in all kinds of mentality classed as sense sphere, and so on. Attention, etc., are not common.

original: hi kusalasseva hoti, viparīto akusalassa, kammādiko vipākassa, bhavaṅgādiko kiriyassāti.
analyzed: hi kusalassa iva hoti viparītaḥ akusalassa kamma ādikaḥ vipākassa bhavaṅga ādikaḥ kiriyassa ati
translated: For right reflection, hearing the true Dhamma, etc., are the condition for profitable only; wrong reflection, hearing the false Dhamma, etc., are the condition for unprofitable only; kamma, etc., are the condition for kamma-resultant only; the life-continuum, etc., are the condition for functional only.

original: Rūpassa pana kammaṃ cittaṃ utu āhāroti ayaṃ kammādiko catubbidho paccayo. Tattha
analyzed: rūpassa pana kammam cittam utu āhāro ti ayam kamma ādikaḥ catubbidhaḥ paccayaḥ tattha
translated: But the condition for materiality is fourfold as kamma, consciousness, temperature, and nutriment. Herein,

original: kammaṃ atītameva kammasamuṭṭhānassa rūpassa paccayo hoti. Cittaṃ cittasamuṭṭhānassa
analyzed: kammam atītam eva kamma samuṭṭhānassa rūpassa paccayaḥ hoti cittam citta samuṭṭhānassa
translated: kamma is a condition only for kamma-originated materiality as past action. Consciousness is a condition for consciousness-originated materiality🔽as present adverting. Temperature and nutriment are conditions for temperature-originated and nutriment-originated materiality

original: uppajjamānaṃ. Utuāhārā utuāhārasamuṭṭhānassa ṭhitikkhaṇe paccayā hontīti. Evameveko
analyzed: uppajjamānam utuāhārā utuāhāra samuṭṭhānassa ṭhiti kkhaṇe paccayāḥ honti iti evam eva eko
translated: as the actual moment of their presence.

original: nāmarūpassa paccayapariggahaṃ karoti.🔽So evaṃ paccayato nāmarūpassa pavattiṃ disvā yathā idaṃ etarahi, evaṃ atītepi addhāne
analyzed: nāma rūpassa paccaya pariggaham karoti  saḥ evam paccayataḥ nāma rūpassa pavattim disvā yathā idam etarahi evam atīte api addhāne
translated: He discerns the conditions for mentality-materiality.🔽Having seen the occurrence of mentality-materiality by means of conditions in this way, he sees that in the past too

original: paccayato pavattittha, anāgatepi paccayato pavattissatīti samanupassati. Tassevaṃ
analyzed: paccayataḥ pavattittha anāgate pi paccayato pavattissati iti samanupassati tassa evam
translated: its occurrence was by means of conditions in the same way, and that in the future too its occurrence will be by means of conditions in the same way.

original: samanupassato vuttanayeneva tīsupi addhāsu vicikicchā pahīyati.🔽682. Aparo tesaṃyeva nāmarūpasaṅkhātānaṃ saṅkhārānaṃ jarāpattiṃ jiṇṇānañca bhaṅgaṃ🔽disvā idaṃ saṅkhārānaṃ jarāmaraṇaṃ nāma jātiyā sati hoti, jāti bhave sati, bhavo🔽upādāne sati, upādānaṃ taṇhāya sati, taṇhā vedanāya sati, vedanā phasse sati, phasso
analyzed: samanupassataḥ vutta nayena iva tīsu pi addhāsu vicikicchā pahīyati  aparaḥ tesam yeva nāma rūpa saṅkhātānam saṅkhārānam jarā āpattim jiṇṇānam ca bhaṅgam  disvā idam jarāmaraṇam nāma jātiyā sati hoti jāti bhave sati bhavo  upādāne sati upādānam taṇhāya sati taṇhā vedanāya sati vedanā phasse sati phassaḥ
translated: As he sees thus, his uncertainty is abandoned by the same method as before.🔽Another sees the ageing of formations consisting of mentality-materiality and the dissolution of what has aged,

original: saḷāyatane sati, saḷāyatanaṃ nāmarūpe sati, nāmarūpaṃ viññāṇe sati, viññāṇaṃ saṅkhāresu
analyzed: saḷāyatane sati saḷāyatanam nāma rūpe sati nāma rūpam viññāṇe sati viññāṇam saṅkhāresu
translated: and he concludes: “This ageing and death of formations has birth as its condition. Birth has existence as its condition. Existence has clinging as its condition. Clinging has craving as its condition. Craving has feeling as its condition. Feeling has contact as its condition. Contact has the sixfold base as its condition. The sixfold base has mentality-materiality as its condition. Mentality-materiality has consciousness as its condition. Consciousness has formations as its condition.

original: sati, saṅkhārā avijjāya satīti evaṃ paṭilomapaṭiccasamuppādavasena nāmarūpassa paccayapariggahaṃ🔽karoti. Athassa vuttanayeneva vicikicchā pahīyati.
analyzed: sati saṅkhārāḥ avijjāya sati iti evam paṭiloma paṭiccasamuppāda vasena nāma rūpassa paccaya pariggaham  karoti atha assa vutta nayena iva vicikicchā pahīyati
translated: He discerns the conditions for mentality-materiality by means of the reverse order of dependent origination thus: “With ignorance as condition there are formations; with formations as condition, consciousness … with consciousness as condition, mentality-materiality” . Then his doubt is abandoned by the method already stated.

original: 683. Aparo “iti kho avijjāpaccayā saṅkhārā”ti pubbe vitthāretvā dassitaanulomapaṭiccasamuppādavaseneva nāmarūpassa paccayapariggahaṃ karoti. Athassa vuttanayeneva kaṅkhā pahīyati.🔽684. Aparo “purimakammabhavasmiṃ moho avijjā, āyūhanā saṅkhārā, nikanti taṇhā, upagamanaṃ🔽upādānaṃ, cetanā bhavoti ime pañca dhammā purimakammabhavasmiṃ idha paṭisandhiyā🔽paccayā, idha paṭisandhi viññāṇaṃ, okkanti nāmarūpaṃ, pasādo āyatanaṃ, phuṭṭho phasso,
analyzed: aparaḥ iti kho avijjā paccayā saṅkhārā ti pubbe vitthāretvā dassita anuloma paṭiccasamuppāda vasena iva nāma rūpassa paccaya pariggaham karoti atha assa vutta nayena iva kaṅkhā pahīyati  aparo purima kamma bhavasmim mohaḥ avijjā āyūhanā saṅkhārāḥ nikanti taṇhā upagamanam  upādānam cetanā bhavo ti ime pañca dhammā purima kamma bhavasmiṃ idha paṭisandhiyā  paccayāḥ idha paṭisandhi viññāṇam okkanti nāma rūpam pasādaḥ āyatanam phuṭṭhaḥ phasso
translated: Another discerns the conditions for mentality-materiality by means of the forward order of dependent origination, which is given in detail thus: “With ignorance as condition there are formations” , and so on. Then his doubt is abandoned by the method already stated.

original: vedayitaṃ vedanāti ime pañca dhammā idhūpapattibhavasmiṃ purekatassa kammassa paccayā.
analyzed: vedayitam vedanā ati ime pañca dhammā idha upapatti bhavasmim purekatassa kammassa paccayā
translated: Another discerns the conditions for mentality-materiality in this way: “In the previous kamma process becoming, delusion is ignorance, the accumulation is formations, affection is craving, adhesion is clinging, volition is becoming. These five things in the previous kamma process becoming are conditions for rebirth-linking here. Herein, rebirth-linking is consciousness, descent into the womb is mentality-materiality, sensitivity is sense base, contact is contact, and feeling is feeling. These five things in the rebirth-process becoming here are conditions for the kamma already stored up in the previous becoming.

original: Idha paripakkattā āyatanānaṃ moho avijjā…pe… cetanā bhavoti ime pañca dhammā idha
analyzed: idha paripakka ttā āyatanānam mohaḥ cetanā ime pañca dhammā idha
translated: When the bases are matured here, delusion is ignorance, and so on as in the Paṭṭhāna till with the arising of ignorance formations arise. These five states here🔽are conditions for rebirth-linking in the future in kamma existence.”

original: kammabhavasmiṃ āyatiṃ paṭisandhiyā paccayā”ti evaṃ kammavaṭṭavipākavaṭṭavasena nāmarūpassa🔽paccayapariggahaṃ karoti.
analyzed: kamma bhavasmim āyatim paṭisandhiyā paccayā ti evam kamma vaṭṭa vipāka vaṭṭa vasena nāma rūpassa  paccaya pariggaham karoti
translated: So he discerns the conditions for mentality-materiality in the round of kamma and the round of kamma-result.

original: 685. Tattha catubbidhaṃ kammaṃ – diṭṭhadhammavedanīyaṃ, upapajjavedanīyaṃ, aparāpariyavedanīyaṃ,🔽ahosikammanti. Tesu ekajavanavīthiyaṃ sattasu cittesu kusalā vā akusalā vā paṭhamajavanacetanā
analyzed: tattha catubbidham kammam diṭṭhadhamma vedanīyam upapajja vedanīyam apara apariya vedanīyam  tesu eka javana vīthiyam sattasu cittesu kusalā vā akusalā vā paṭhama javana cetanā
translated: Herein, kamma is of four kinds: kamma resulting in rebirth in the next moment of consciousness, kamma resulting in rebirth in the same life, kamma resulting in rebirth in a later life,

original: diṭṭhidhammavedanīyakammaṃ nāma. Taṃ imasmiññeva attabhāve vipākaṃ deti. Tathā asakkontaṃ
analyzed: diṭṭhi dhamma vedanīya kammam nāma tam imasmin ñeva atta bhāve vipākam deti tathā a sakkontam
translated: and kamma that is laid by. Of these, the profitable or unprofitable volition in the first impulsion in a single impulsion-moment is called kamma resulting in rebirth in the next moment of consciousness. It gives its result in this very present becoming. But if it is unable to do so,

original: pana “ahosikammaṃ nāhosi kammavipāko, na bhavissati kammavipāko, natthi kammavipāko”ti
analyzed: pana ahosikammam na ahosi kamma vipāko na bhavissati kamma vipāko na atthi kamma vipāko ti
translated: then it is called kamma that is laid by, according to the method of the following triad: “There is kamma that is done and stored up; there is kamma that is done but not stored up; there is kamma that is neither done nor stored up” .

original: imassa tikassa vasena ahosikammaṃ nāma hoti. Atthasādhikā pana sattamajavanacetanā
analyzed: imassa tikassa vasena ahosikammam nāma hoti attha sādhikā pana sattama javana cetanā
translated: The seventh impulsion-moment volition that is effective in achieving its purpose is called kamma resulting in rebirth in the same life.

original: upapajjavedanīyakammaṃ nāma. Taṃ anantare attabhāve vipākaṃ deti. Tathā asakkontaṃ
analyzed: upapajja vedanīya kammam nāma tam anantare atta bhāve vipākam deti tathā a sakkontam
translated: and kamma to be experienced in a future becoming. It gives its result in the next becoming if it cannot do so in the present one.🔽Then it becomes kamma to be experienced in some future period.

original: vuttanayeneva ahosikammaṃ nāma hoti. Ubhinnaṃ antare pañca javanacetanā aparāpariyavedanīyakammaṃ🔽nāma. Taṃ anāgate yadā okāsaṃ labhati, tadā vipākaṃ deti. Sati saṃsārappavattiyā
analyzed: vutta nayena iva ahosikammam nāma hoti ubhinnam antare pañca javana cetanāḥ apara apariya vedanīya kammam  nāma tam anāgate yadā okāsam labhati tadā vipākam deti sati saṃsāra ppavattiyā
translated: The five impulsions of the cognitive series between the two are called kamma to be experienced in some future period.🔽It gives its result in some future period when it finds an opportunity to do so.

original: ahosikammaṃ nāma na hoti.
analyzed: ahosikammam nāma na hoti
translated: But if there is no more becoming, it does not become kamma to be experienced in some future period.

original: 686. Aparampi catubbidhaṃ kammaṃ – yaṃ garukaṃ, yaṃ bahulaṃ, yadāsannaṃ, kaṭattā🔽vā pana kammanti. Tattha kusalaṃ vā hotu akusalaṃ vā, garukāgarukesu yaṃ garukaṃ🔽mātughātādikammaṃ vā mahaggatakammaṃ vā, tadeva paṭhamaṃ vipaccati. Tathā bahulābahulesupi
analyzed: aparam pi catubbidham kammam yam garukam yam bahulam yat āsannam kaṭattā  vā pana kammanti tattha kusalam vā hotu akusalam vā garuka agarukesu yam garukam  mātughāta ādi kammam vā mahaggata kammam vā tat eva paṭhamam vipaccati tathā bahula abahulesu pi
translated: Again, there is kamma of four kinds as weighty, as habitual, as that which has been done nearest in time, and as that done in the presence of an Enlightened One.

original: yaṃ bahulaṃ hoti susīlyaṃ vā dussīlyaṃ vā, tadeva paṭhamaṃ vipaccati. Yadāsannaṃ🔽nāma maraṇakāle anussaritakammaṃ. Yañhi āsannamaraṇo anussarituṃ sakkoti, teneva
analyzed: yam bahulam hoti susīlyam vā dussīlyam vā tat eva paṭhamam vipaccati yat āsannam 🔽nāma maraṇa kāle anussarita kammam yat hi āsanna maraṇaḥ anussaritum sakkoti tena iva
translated: Herein, whether it is profitable or unprofitable, it is the weightier of two weighty deeds that comes to fruition first, or, if there are two weightier ones, the more habitual of the two, or, if there are two of equal frequency, the more recently performed of the two, or, if of equal currency and equal performance, the one done in the presence of an Enlightened One.

original: upapajjati. Etehi pana tīhi muttaṃ punappunaṃ laddhāsevanaṃ kaṭattā vā pana kammaṃ
analyzed: upapajjati etehi pana tīhi muttam punappunam laddha āsevanam kaṭattā vā pana kammam
translated: But that which is free from these three is called “kamma that is to be experienced after rebirth-linking” because it is kamma that is to be experienced in the course of an existence after rebirth-linking.

original: nāma hoti, tesaṃ abhāve taṃ paṭisandhiṃ ākaḍḍhati.
analyzed: nāma hoti tesam abhāve tam paṭisandhim ākaḍḍhati
translated: And in the absence of these three kinds of kamma, it is that which leads to rebirth-linking.

original: 687. Aparampi catubbidhaṃ kammaṃ – janakaṃ, upatthambhakaṃ, upapīḷakaṃ, upaghātakanti.🔽Tattha janakaṃ nāma kusalampi hoti akusalampi. Taṃ paṭisandhiyampi pavattepi rūpārūpavipākakkhandhe🔽janeti. Upatthambhakaṃ pana vipākaṃ janetuṃ na sakkoti, aññena kammena dinnāya paṭisandhiyā
analyzed: aparam pi catubbidham kammam janakam upatthambhakam upapīḍakam upaghātakam ti  tattha janakam nāma kusalam pi hoti akusalam pi tam paṭisandhiyam pi pavatte pi rūpa arūpa vipāka khandhe  janeti upatthambhakam pana vipākam janetum na sakkoti aññena kammena dinnāya paṭisandhiyā
translated: Again, kamma is of four kinds as productive, consolidating, frustrating, and suppressive.🔽Herein, kamma that is productive is both profitable and unprofitable. It produces the aggregates that are the result of profitable and unprofitable kamma both in rebirth-linking and in the course of an existence.

original: janite vipāke uppajjamānakasukhadukkhaṃ upatthambheti, addhānaṃ pavatteti. Upapīḷakaṃ
analyzed: janite vipāke uppajjamānaka sukha dukkham upatthambheti addhānam pavatteti upapīḷakam
translated: But kamma that is consolidating is unable to produce result. It consolidates the result that is produced by other kamma and makes it last. It prolongs the course. Kamma that is frustrating

original: aññena kammena dinnāya paṭisandhiyā janite vipāke uppajjamānakasukhadukkhaṃ pīḷeti
analyzed: aññena kammena dinnāya paṭisandhiyāḥ janite vipāke uppajjamānaka sukha dukkham pīḷeti
translated: frustrates the pleasure and pain that arise in the course of an existence produced by other kamma.

original: bādhati, addhānaṃ pavattituṃ na deti. Upaghātakaṃ pana sayaṃ kusalampi akusalampi
analyzed: bādhati addhānam pavattitum na deti upaghātakam pana sayam kusalam pi akusalam pi
translated: It hinders them and does not allow the course to continue. But kamma that is suppressive is itself either profitable or unprofitable.

original: samānaṃ aññaṃ dubbalakammaṃ ghātetvā tassa vipākaṃ paṭibāhitvā attano vipākassa okāsaṃ
analyzed: samānam aññam dubbala kammam ghātetvā tassa vipākam paṭibāhitvā attanaḥ vipākassa okāsam
translated: and he destroys the other, weaker kamma, and wards off its result, and makes room for his own result.

original: karoti. Evaṃ pana kammena kate okāse taṃ vipākaṃ uppannaṃ nāma vuccati.
analyzed: karoti evam pana kammena kate okāse tam vipākam uppannam nāma vuccati
translated: and it destroys the other, weaker, kamma, and it makes room for its own result by warding off the other’s result. But when the room has been made by the kamma in this way, then that result is said to have “arisen.”

original: Iti imesaṃ dvādasannaṃ kammānaṃ kammantarañceva vipākantarañca buddhānaṃ kammavipākañāṇasseva
analyzed: iti imesam dvādasannam kammānam kamma antaram ca iva vipāka antaram ca buddhānam kamma vipāka ñāṇassa iva
translated: So the difference between the kinds of kamma and the difference between the kinds of result of the twelve kinds of kamma are evident in their true nature only to the knowledge of kamma and of the result of kamma of Buddhas,

original: yāthāvasarasato pākaṭaṃ hoti, asādhāraṇaṃ sāvakehi. Vipassakena pana kammantarañca🔽vipākantarañca ekadesato jānitabbaṃ. Tasmā ayaṃ mukhamattadassanena kammaviseso pakāsitoti.🔽688. Iti imaṃ dvādasavidhaṃ kammaṃ kammavaṭṭe pakkhipitvā evaṃ eko kammavaṭṭavipākavaṭṭavasena
analyzed: yāthāvasa rasataḥ pākaṭam hoti asādhāraṇam sāvakehi vipassakena pana kammantaram ca  vipāka antaram ca eka desataḥ jānitabbam tasmai ayam mukhamatta dassanena kamma viseso pakāsito ti  iti imam dvādasavidham kammam kamma vaṭṭe pakkhipitvā evam ekaḥ kamma vaṭṭa vipāka vaṭṭa vasena
translated: and they are not shared by disciples. But a meditator should know them in part.🔽So this difference in kamma is shown here by a mere indication.🔽. Thus, after including this twelve-fold kamma in the round of kamma, he discerns the conditionality of mentality-materiality in this way by means of the round of kamma and the round of kamma-result.

original: nāmarūpassa paccayapariggahaṃ karoti. So evaṃ kammavaṭṭavipākavaṭṭavasena paccayato
analyzed: nāma rūpassa paccaya pariggaham karoti saḥ evam kamma vaṭṭa vipāka vaṭṭa vasena paccayato
translated: He discerns conditionality by means of the round of kamma and the round of kamma-result in this way.

original: nāmarūpassa pavattiṃ disvā “yathā idaṃ etarahi, evaṃ atītepi addhāne kammavaṭṭavipākavaṭṭavasena
analyzed: nāma rūpassa pavattim disvā yathā idam etarahi evam atīte api addhāne kamma vaṭṭa vipāka vaṭṭa vasena
translated: Having seen the occurrence of mentality-materiality, he sees that “Just as it occurs now by means of conditions, so also in the past it occurred by means of conditions,

original: paccayato pavattittha, anāgatepi kammavaṭṭavipākavaṭṭavaseneva paccayato pavattissatī”ti.
analyzed: paccayataḥ pavattittha anāgate pi kamma vaṭṭa vipāka vaṭṭa vasena iva paccayataḥ pavattissati iti
translated: by the repetition of kamma and the repetition of result, and in the future it will occur by means of conditions, by the repetition of kamma and the repetition of result.”

original: Iti kammañceva kammavipāko ca, kammavaṭṭañca vipākavaṭṭañca, kammapavattañca vipākapavattañca,
analyzed: iti kammam ca iva kamma vipāko ca kamma vaṭṭañca vipāka vaṭṭañca kamma pavattañca vipāka pavattañca
translated: Thus kamma and kamma-result, the repetition of kamma and the repetition of result, the occurrence of kamma and the occurrence of result,

original: kammasantati ca vipākasantati ca, kiriyā ca kiriyāphalañca.
analyzed: kamma santati ca vipāka santati ca kiriyā ca kiriyā phalañca
translated: the continuity of kamma and the continuity of result, action and fruition—

original: Kammā vipākā vattanti, vipāko kammasambhavo;
analyzed: kammā vipākā vattanti vipāko kamma sambhavo
translated: Kamma and kamma-result occur, Result is born of kamma too;

original: Kammā punabbhavo hoti, evaṃ loko pavattatīti. –
analyzed: kammā punabbhavaḥ hoti evam loko pavattati iti
translated: Kamma is the cause of rebirth, Thus the world revolves.

original: Samanupassati. Tassevaṃ samanupassato yā sā pubbantādayo ārabbha “ahosiṃ nu kho aha”ntiādinā🔽nayena vuttā soḷasavidhā vicikicchā, sā sabbā pahīyati. Sabbabhavayonigatiṭṭhitinivāsesu
analyzed: samanupassati tassa ivam samanupassataḥ yā sā pubbanta ādayaḥ ārabbha ahosim nu kho aham ti ādinā  nayena vuttā soḷasavidhā vicikicchā sā sabbā pahīyati sabba bhava yoni gati ṭṭhiti nivāsesu
translated: When he sees thus, all his sixteenfold doubt stated thus: “Was I in the past? Was I not in the past? What was I in the past? How was I in the past? Where did I exist in the past?🔽What will I be in the future? What will I not be in the future? What will I be and what will I not be in the future? What will I not be in the future? How will I be in the future? Where will I exist in the future?”

original: hetuphalasambandhavasena pavattamānaṃ nāmarūpamattameva khāyati. So neva kāraṇato
analyzed: hetu phala sambandha vasena pavattamānam nāma rūpa mattam eva khāyati saḥ na iva kāraṇataḥ
translated: is abandoned. Only mentality-materiality occurring by the relation of cause and fruit appears to him in all its modes of being, wombs, destinations, modes of origin, stations of consciousness, and abodes of beings.

original: uddhaṃ kārakaṃ passati, na vipākappavattito uddhaṃ vipākapaṭisaṃvedakaṃ. Kāraṇe pana
analyzed: uddham kārakam passati na vipāka pavattitaḥ uddham vipāka paṭisaṃvedakam kāraṇe pana
translated: He sees the doer as above the doing, but not as above the experiencing of the result. But when there is a reason for calling it a doer, then the wise, as though reckoning, say “doer” by a mere term of common usage, since there is the occurrence of kamma.

original: sati “kārako”ti, vipākappavattiyā sati “paṭisaṃvedako”ti samaññāmattena paṇḍitā voharanticcevassa
analyzed: sati kārako ti vipāka ppavattiyā sati paṭisaṃvedako ti samaññā mattena paṇḍitāḥ voharanti iccā iva assa
translated: And when there is a reason for calling it an experiencer, then they say “experiencer” by a mere term of common usage, since there is the occurrence of the result.

original: sammappaññāya sudiṭṭhaṃ hoti.
analyzed: sammappaññāya su diṭṭham hoti
translated: So it is rightly seen by him with right understanding.

original: 689. Tenāhu porāṇā –
analyzed: tena āhuḥ porāṇā
translated: Hence the Ancients said:🔽“There is no doer of the deed,

original: “Kammassa kārako natthi, vipākassa ca vedako;
analyzed: kammassa kārakaḥ natthi vipākassa ca vedakaḥ
translated: Nor one who reaps the deed’s result;

original: Suddhadhammā pavattanti, evetaṃ sammadassanaṃ.
analyzed: suddha dhammāḥ pavattanti eva itam sammadassanam
translated: Pure being only is the term For what occurs in suchwise.🔽“When thus the deed and its result

original: “Evaṃ kamme vipāke ca, vattamāne sahetuke;
analyzed: evam kamme vipāke ca vattamāne sa hetuke
translated: Occur together with a cause,🔽The prior limit is not known,

original: Bījarukkhādikānaṃva, pubbā koṭi na nāyati;
analyzed: bīja rukkha ādikānaṃ va pubbā na na āyati
translated: As with a seed and growing tree.🔽And in the future round of births

original: Anāgatepi saṃsāre, appavattaṃ na dissati.
analyzed: anāgate pi saṃsāre appavattam na dissati
translated: No beginning can be seen.🔽“Not knowing this, the sectarians,

original: “Etamatthaṃ anaññāya, titthiyā asayaṃvasī;🔽Sattasaññaṃ gahetvāna, sassatucchedadassino;
analyzed: etam attham an aññāya titthiyā a sayaṃvasī  satta saññam gahetvāna
translated: Who are without self-control,🔽Seizing the concept of a being,🔽See annihilation or eternalism.🔽They hold the sixty-twofold view,

original: Dvāsaṭṭhidiṭṭhiṃ gaṇhanti, aññamaññavirodhitā.
analyzed: dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhim gaṇhanti aññamañña virodhi tā
translated: Which is in conflict with itself.🔽Bound by the fetter of their view,

original: “Diṭṭhibandhanabaddhā te, taṇhāsotena vuyhare;
analyzed: diṭṭhi bandhana baddhā te taṇhā sotena vuyhare
translated: They are swept on by craving’s flood.🔽Being swept on by craving’s flood,

original: Taṇhāsotena vuyhantā, na te dukkhā pamuccare.
analyzed: taṇhā sotena vuyhantā na te dukkhā pamuccare
translated: They are not freed from suffering.

original: “Evametaṃ abhiññāya, bhikkhu buddhassa sāvako;
analyzed: evam etam abhiññāya bhikkhu buddhassa sāvakaḥ
translated: “Having directly known this, the monk, the disciple of the Buddha,

original: Gambhīraṃ nipuṇaṃ suññaṃ, paccayaṃ paṭivijjhati.
analyzed: gambhīram nipuṇam suññam paccayam paṭivijjhati
translated: penetrates the deep, the subtle, the void, the conditioned.

original: “Kammaṃ natthi vipākamhi, pāko kamme na vijjati;
analyzed: kammam natthi vipākamhi pāko kamme na vijjati
translated: “There is no kamma in ripening, ripening is not found in kamma;

original: Aññamaññaṃ ubho suññā, na ca kammaṃ vinā phalaṃ.
analyzed: aññamaññam ubho suññā na ca kammam vinā phalam
translated: each is void of the other, yet there is no fruit without kamma.

original: “Yathā na sūriye aggi, na maṇimhi na gomaye;
analyzed: yathā na sūriye aggi na maṇimhi na gomaye
translated: “As fire is not in the sun, in the gem, or in the kindling wood,

original: Na tesaṃ bahi so atthi, sambhārehi ca jāyati.
analyzed: na tesam bahi saḥ atthi sambhārehi ca jāyati
translated: but it is produced from these things,

original: “Tathā na anto kammassa, vipāko upalabbhati;
analyzed: tathā na antaḥ kammassa vipākaḥ upalabbhati
translated: “So in the kamma there is no ripening to be found,

original: Bahiddhāpi na kammassa, na kammaṃ tattha vijjati.
analyzed: bahiddhā api na kammassa na kammam tattha vijjati
translated: nor is kamma found outside of ripening.

original: “Phalena suññaṃ taṃ kammaṃ, phalaṃ kamme na vijjati;
analyzed: phalena suññam tam kammam phalam kamme na vijjati
translated: “Kamma is void of fruit, the fruit is not found in kamma;

original: Kammañca kho upādāya, tato nibbattate phalaṃ.
analyzed: kammañca kho upādāya tatas nibbattate phalam
translated: but it is on the basis of kamma that the fruit comes into being.

original: “Na hettha devo brahmā vā, saṃsārassatthikārako;
analyzed: na ha ittha devaḥ brahmā vā saṃsārassa atthi kārakaḥ
translated: “Herein there is no god or brahmā who is the maker of the round,

original: Suddhadhammā pavattanti, hetusambhārapaccayā”ti.
analyzed: suddha dhammāḥ pavattanti hetu sambhāra paccayā ti
translated: but pure phenomena occur by way of cause and condition.”

original: 690. Tassevaṃ kammavaṭṭavipākavaṭṭavasena nāmarūpassa paccayapariggahaṃ katvā tīsu
analyzed: tassa evam kamma vaṭṭa vipāka vaṭṭa vasena nāma rūpassa paccaya pariggaham katvā tīsu
translated: Having thus investigated the conditions for mentality-materiality in terms of the round of kamma and the round of kamma-result, he should next investigate it in terms of the three periods of time.

original: addhāsu pahīnavicikicchassa sabbe atītānāgatapaccuppannadhammā cutipaṭisandhivasena
analyzed: addhāsu pahīna vicikicchassa sabbe atīta anāgata paccuppanna dhammā cuti paṭisandhi vasena
translated: and he has abandoned doubt about the Dhamma, then all dhammas of the past and future and present are known to him as they really are in the manner of arising and passing away.

original: viditā honti, sāssa hoti ñātapariññā.
analyzed: viditāḥ honti sā assa hoti ñāta pariññā
translated: This is his knowledge of what is familiar.

original: So evaṃ pajānāti – ye atīte kammapaccayā nibbattā khandhā, te tattheva niruddhā,
analyzed: saḥ evam pajānāti ye atīte kamma paccayāḥ nibbattāḥ khandhāḥ te tattha eva niruddhā
translated: He understands thus: ‘The aggregates that arose in the past through a particular condition have ceased there itself.

original: atītakammapaccayā pana imasmiṃ bhave aññe nibbattā, atītabhavato imaṃ bhavaṃ āgato
analyzed: atīta kamma paccayā pana imasmin bhave aññe nibbattāḥ atīta bhavataḥ imam bhavam āgato
translated: But through that particular condition other aggregates have arisen in this present existence. Nothing has come from the past existence to this existence.

original: ekadhammopi natthi, imasmimpi bhave kammapaccayena nibbattā khandhā nirujjhissanti,
analyzed: eka dhammaḥ api natthi imasmim pi bhave kamma paccayena nibbattāḥ khandhāḥ nirujjhissanti
translated: And in this existence too, the aggregates that arose through a particular condition will cease here itself.

original: punabbhave aññe nibbattissanti, imamhā bhavā punabbhavaṃ ekadhammopi na gamissati.🔽Apica kho yathā na ācariyamukhato sajjhāyo antevāsikassa mukhaṃ pavisati, na ca tappaccayā
analyzed: punabbhave aññe nibbattissanti imamhā bhavā punabbhavam eka dhammaḥ api na gamissati  apica kho yathā na ācariya mukhataḥ sajjhāyaḥ antevāsikassa mukham pavisati na ca tad paccayā
translated: But through that particular condition other aggregates will arise in the future existence. Nothing will go from this existence to the next existence.🔽Moreover, just as the recitation from the teacher’s mouth does not enter the pupil’s mouth, and yet the recitation is not absent from the pupil’s mouth,

original: tassa mukhe sajjhāyo na vattati, na dūtena mantodakaṃ pītaṃ rogino udaraṃ pavisati,
analyzed: tassa mukhe sajjhāyaḥ na vattati na dūtena mantodakam pītam roginaḥ udaram pavisati
translated: and just as the water drunk by the messenger does not reach the stomach of the sick man,

original: na ca tassa tappaccayā rogo na vūpasammati, na mukhe maṇḍanavidhānaṃ ādāsatalādīsu
analyzed: na ca tassa tad paccayā rogaḥ na na mukhe maṇḍana vidhānam ā dāsa tala ādīsu
translated: and because of that the disease does not subside, and the adornment of the face does not appear in the looking-glass, etc.,

original: mukhanimittaṃ gacchati, na ca tattha tappaccayā maṇḍanavidhānaṃ na paññāyati, na
analyzed: mukha nimittam gacchati na ca tattha tad paccayā maṇḍana vidhānam na paññāyati na
translated: and because of that the adornment of the face is not seen there, and

original: ekissā vaṭṭiyā dīpasikhā aññaṃ vaṭṭiṃ saṅkamati, na ca tattha tappaccayā dīpasikhā
analyzed: ekissā vaṭṭiyāḥ dīpa sikhā aññam vaṭṭim saṅkamati na ca tattha tad paccayā dīpa sikhā
translated: the flame of the lamp does not pass on to the other wick, and because of that

original: na nibbattati, evameva na atītabhavato imaṃ bhavaṃ, ito vā punabbhavaṃ koci dhammo🔽saṅkamati, na ca atītabhave khandhāyatanadhātupaccayā idha, idha vā khandhāyatanadhātupaccayā
analyzed: na nibbattati evam eva na atīta bhavataḥ imam bhavam itas vā punabbhavam koci dhammo  saṅkamati na ca atīta bhave khandha āyatana dhātu paccayā idha idha vā khandha āyatana dhātu paccayā
translated: the flame of the lamp does not arise there, so too, no idea passes over from a past becoming to this becoming or from this becoming to a future becoming,

original: punabbhave khandhāyatanadhātuyo na nibbattantīti.
analyzed: punabbhave khandha āyatana dhātuyaḥ na nibbattanti iti
translated: and yet the aggregates, bases, and elements in this becoming do not arise because of the aggregates, bases, and elements in a past becoming, or the aggregates, bases, and elements in a future becoming because of the aggregates, bases, and elements in this becoming.

original: Yatheva cakkhuviññāṇaṃ, manodhātuanantaraṃ;
analyzed: yathā iva cakkhu viññāṇam manaḥ dhātu anantaram
translated: Just as visual consciousness, immediately after the mind element,

original: Na ceva āgataṃ nāpi, na nibbattaṃ anantaraṃ.🔽Tatheva paṭisandhimhi, vattate cittasantati;
analyzed: na ca iva āgatam na api na nibbattam anantaram  tathā iva paṭisandhimhi vattate citta santati
translated: Has not come from the past, nor will it be born in the future,🔽So too, in rebirth-linking, the continuity of consciousness occurs,

original: Purimaṃ bhijjate cittaṃ, pacchimaṃ jāyate tato.
analyzed: purimam bhijjate cittam pacchimam jāyate tatas
translated: The previous consciousness has ceased, and the next is born from that.

original: Tesaṃ antarikā natthi, vīci tesaṃ na vijjati;
analyzed: tesam antarikā na atthi vīci tesam na vijjati
translated: No break is found in them.🔽Nothing passes on to anything,

original: Na cito gacchati kiñci, paṭisandhi ca jāyatīti.🔽691. Evaṃ cutipaṭisandhivasena viditasabbadhammassa sabbākārena nāmarūpassa paccayapariggahañāṇaṃ🔽thāmagataṃ hoti, soḷasavidhā kaṅkhā suṭṭhutaraṃ pahīyati. Na kevalañca sā eva, “satthari🔽kaṅkhatī”ti ādinayappavattā aṭṭhavidhāpi kaṅkhā pahīyatiyeva, dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhigatāni🔽vikkhambhanti. Evaṃ nānānayehi nāmarūpapaccayapariggahaṇena tīsu addhāsu kaṅkhaṃ
analyzed: na citaḥ gacchati kiñci paṭisandhi ca jāyati iti  evam cuti paṭisandhi vasena vidita sabba dhammassa sabba ākārena nāma rūpassa paccaya pariggaha ñāṇam  thāma gatam hoti soḷasavidhā kaṅkhā suṭṭhutaram pahīyati na kevalam ca sā eva satthari  kaṅkhati iti ādi naya ppavattā aṭṭhavidhā api kaṅkhā dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhigatāni  vikkhambhanti evam nānā nayehi nāma rūpa paccaya pariggahaṇena tīsu addhāsu kaṅkham
translated: And yet rebirth-linking comes to be.

original: vitaritvā ṭhitaṃ ñāṇaṃ kaṅkhāvitaraṇavisuddhīti veditabbaṃ. Dhammaṭṭhitiñāṇantipi🔽yathābhūtañāṇantipi sammādassanantipi etassevādhivacanaṃ. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: vitaritvā ṭhitam ñāṇam kaṅkhā vitaraṇa visuddhi iti veditabbam dhamma ṭṭhiti ñāṇam ti pi 🔽etassa iva adhivacanam vuttam ha etam
translated: So when he has thus penetrated all ideas by means of death and rebirth-linking, his knowledge of how to discern conditions for mentality-materiality in all its modes is now on the way to being perfected, and the sixteen kinds of doubt are now abandoned still more effectively. And not only that doubt, but also the eight kinds of doubt described in the way beginning, “He is doubtful about the Teacher” , are abandoned, and the sixty-two kinds of views are suppressed. So when he has thus dispelled doubt about the three periods of time by discerning mentality-materiality in its various modes, his knowledge is called “purification by overcoming doubt” . And it is also called “knowledge of the constitution of the true way” , “knowledge of how things are” , and “right view” . For this is said:

original: “Avijjā paccayo, saṅkhārā paccayasamuppannā. Ubhopete dhammā paccayasamuppannāti paccayapariggahe paññā dhammaṭṭhitiñāṇa”nti.🔽“Aniccato manasikaronto katame dhamme yathābhūtaṃ jānāti passati, kathaṃ sammādassanaṃ🔽hoti, kathaṃ tadanvayena sabbe saṅkhārā aniccato sudiṭṭhā honti, kattha kaṅkhā pahīyati?🔽Dukkhato…pe… anattato manasikaronto katame dhamme yathābhūtaṃ jānāti passati…pe…
analyzed: avijjā paccayaḥ saṅkhārā paccaya samuppannāḥ ubho upete dhammā paccaya samuppannā ti paccaya pariggahe paññā dhamma ṭṭhiti ñāṇam ti  aniccataḥ manasikaronto katame dhamme yathābhūtam jānāti passati katham sammādassanam  hoti katham tad anvayena sabbe saṅkhārāḥ aniccato su diṭṭhāḥ honti kattha kaṅkhā pahīyati  dukkha tope anattataḥ manasikarontaḥ katame dhamme yathābhūtam jānāti passati pe
translated: ‘Ignorance is a condition, determinations are conditionally arisen. Both these ideas are conditionally arisen’: understanding of this discerning of conditions is knowledge of the stability of dhammas.🔽When he brings inconstancy to mind, what ideas does he know & see in accordance with reality? How does right view come about? How, by inference, are all formations seen to be impermanent? Where does doubt-reckoning come to an end?

original: kattha kaṅkhā pahīyatīti?
analyzed: kattha kaṅkhā pahīyati iti
translated: When he brings suffering to mind… When he brings not-self to mind, what ideas does he know & see in accordance with reality? How does right view come about? How, by inference, are all formations seen to be not-self? Where does doubt-reckoning come to an end?

original: “Aniccato manasikaronto nimittaṃ yathābhūtaṃ jānāti passati, tena vuccati sammādassanaṃ.
analyzed: aniccataḥ manasikarontaḥ nimittam yathābhūtam jānāti passati tena vuccati sammādassanam
translated: When he brings inconstancy to mind, he knows & sees the sign in accordance with reality. Thus right view comes about.

original: Evaṃ tadanvayena sabbe saṅkhārā aniccato sudiṭṭhā honti. Ettha kaṅkhā pahīyati. Dukkhato
analyzed: evam tad anvayena sabbe saṅkhārāḥ aniccato su diṭṭhāḥ honti ettha kaṅkhā pahīyati dukkhato
translated: In this way, by inference, all formations are well seen to be impermanent. Here doubt-reckoning comes to an end.

original: manasikaronto pavattaṃ yathābhūtaṃ jānāti passati…pe… anattato manasikaronto nimittañca
analyzed: manasikarontaḥ pavattam yathābhūtam jānāti passati pe anattataḥ manasikarontaḥ nimittam ca
translated: When he brings suffering to mind, he knows & sees occurrence in accordance with reality. … When he brings not-self to mind, he knows & sees the sign in accordance with reality. …

original: pavattañca yathābhūtaṃ jānāti passati, tena vuccati sammādassanaṃ. Evaṃ tadanvayena
analyzed: pavattam ca yathābhūtam jānāti passati tena vuccati sammādassanam evam tad anvayena
translated: And he knows and sees how it occurs in accordance with actuality. Hence it is called right view.

original: sabbe dhammā anattato sudiṭṭhā honti. Ettha kaṅkhā pahīyati.🔽“Yañca yathābhūtañāṇaṃ yañca sammādassanaṃ yā ca kaṅkhāvitaraṇā, ime dhammā nānatthā
analyzed: sabbe dhammā anattataḥ su diṭṭhāḥ honti ettha kaṅkhā pahīyati  yat ca yathābhūta ñāṇam yat ca sammādassanam yā ca kaṅkhā vitaraṇā ime dhammā nānatthā
translated: Thus all ideas are well seen as not self in accordance with this. Doubt has been abandoned here.

original: ceva nānābyañjanā ca, udāhu ekatthā byañjanameva nānanti? Yañca yathābhūtañāṇaṃ yañca
analyzed: ca iva nānā byañjanā ca udāhu ekatthā byañjanam eva yat ca yathā bhūta ñāṇam yat ca
translated: “Now, is the knowledge of how it is, and right view, and the surmounting of doubt, different in meaning and different in phrasing, or are they one in meaning and only different in the phrasing? “

original: sammādassanaṃ yā ca kaṅkhāvitaraṇā, ime dhammā ekatthā, byañjanameva nāna”nti.
analyzed: sammādassanam yā ca kaṅkhā vitaraṇā ime dhammā ekatthāḥ byañjanam eva nānanti
translated: “The knowledge of how it is, and right view, and the surmounting of doubt, are one in meaning and only different in the phrasing.”

original: Iminā pana ñāṇena samannāgato vipassako buddhasāsane laddhassāso laddhapatiṭṭho niyatagatiko cūḷasotāpanno nāma hoti.
analyzed: iminā pana ñāṇena samannāgataḥ vipassakaḥ buddha sāsane laddha ssāsaḥ laddha patiṭṭhaḥ niyata gatiko cūḷasotāpannaḥ nāma hoti
translated: But when a Vipassaka is possessed of this knowledge, he is one who has gained confidence in the Buddha’s Dispensation, he is one who has gained steadiness, he is one who has a fixed course, he is one who has entered upon the plane of the Noble Ones, he is called a “stream-enterer”.

original: Tasmā bhikkhu sadā sato, nāmarūpassa sabbaso;🔽Paccaye pariggaṇheyya, kaṅkhāvitaraṇatthikoti.
analyzed: tasmā bhikkhu sadā sataḥ nāma rūpassa sabbaso  paccaye pariggaṇheyya kaṅkhā vitaraṇa atthiko ti
translated: Therefore a bhikkhu who is ever mindful,🔽Should investigate the conditions of name-and-form,🔽If he would surmount all doubt.

original: Iti sādhujanapāmojjatthāya kate visuddhimagge
analyzed: iti sādhu jana pāmojjatthāya kate visuddhi magge
translated: In the Path of Purification composed for the purpose of gladdening good people,

original: Paññābhāvanādhikāre
analyzed: paññā bhāvanā adhikāre
translated: In the Treatise on the Development of Understanding,

original: Kaṅkhāvitaraṇavisuddhiniddeso nāma
analyzed: kaṅkhāvitaraṇavisuddhiniddesaḥ nāma
translated: The Description of the Purification by Overcoming Doubt

original: Ekūnavīsatimo paricchedo.
analyzed: ekūnavīsatimaḥ paricchedo
translated: The Description of Purification by Overcoming Doubt is finished.🔽Nineteenth chapter

original: 20. Maggāmaggañāṇadassanavisuddhiniddeso
translated: The Description of Purification by Knowledge and Vision of What Is and Is Not the Path

original: Sammasanañāṇakathā
analyzed: sammasana ñāṇa kathā
translated: The Description of the Investigation of Ideas

original: 692. Ayaṃ maggo, ayaṃ na maggoti evaṃ maggañca amaggañca ñatvā ṭhitaṃ ñāṇaṃ pana maggāmaggañāṇadassanavisuddhi nāma.
analyzed: ayam maggo ayam na maggo ti evam maggañca amaggañca ñatvā ṭhitam ñāṇam pana magga amagga ñāṇadassanavisuddhi nāma
translated: Knowledge and vision of what is and is not the path is the name for the knowledge that occurs when he has thus known and seen the path and the not-path.

original: Taṃ sampādetukāmena kalāpasammasanasaṅkhātāya nayavipassanāya tāva yogo karaṇīyo.🔽Kasmā? Āraddhavipassakassa obhāsādisambhave maggāmaggañāṇasambhavato. Āraddhavipassakassa
analyzed: tam sampādetu kāmena kalāpa sammasana saṅkhātāya naya vipassanāya tāva yogaḥ karaṇīyaḥ  kasmai āraddha vipassakassa obhāsa ādi sambhave magga amagga ñāṇa sambhavataḥ āraddha vipassakassa
translated: He who wants to perfect that must first apply himself to the method of insight called “contemplation of aggregates.”🔽Why? Because when illumination, etc., occur in one who has begun insight, knowledge of the path and the not-path occurs.

original: hi obhāsādīsu sambhūtesu maggāmaggañāṇaṃ hoti, vipassanāya ca kalāpasammasanaṃ ādi.
analyzed: hi obhāsa ādīsu sambhūtesu magga amagga ñāṇam hoti vipassanāya ca kalāpa sammasanam ādi
translated: For when illumination, etc., have occurred in one who has begun insight, there is knowledge of the path and the not-path. And the contemplation of aggregates is the beginning of insight.

original: Tasmā etaṃ kaṅkhāvitaraṇānantaraṃ uddiṭṭhaṃ. Apica yasmā tīraṇapariññāya vattamānāya
analyzed: tasmai etam kaṅkhā vitaraṇa anantaram uddiṭṭham api ca yasmai tīraṇa pariññāya vattamānāya
translated: That is why it is next to overcoming doubt in the exposition.

original: maggāmaggañāṇaṃ uppajjati, tīraṇapariññā ca ñātapariññānantarā, tasmāpi taṃ maggāmaggañāṇadassanavisuddhiṃ
analyzed: maggāmagga ñāṇam uppajjati tīraṇa pariññā ca ñāta pariññā anantarā tasmā api tam maggāmagga ñāṇa dassana visuddhim
translated: Besides, knowledge of the path and the not-path arises when the kind of full-understanding called “investigation” is occurring, and that kind of full-understanding comes next to the kind called “knowing” , that is why that purification by knowledge and vision of what is and is not the path is next to the purification by knowledge and vision of what is the path and is not the path in the exposition.

original: sampādetukāmena kalāpasammasane tāva yogo kātabbo.🔽693. Tatrāyaṃ vinicchayo – tisso hi lokiyapariññā ñātapariññā tīraṇapariññā pahānapariññā
analyzed: sampādetu kāmena kalāpa sammasane tāva yogaḥ kātabbo  tatra ayam vinicchayaḥ tissaḥ hi lokiya pariññāḥ ñāta pariññā tīraṇa pariññā pahāna pariññā
translated: One who wants to accomplish this should first apply himself to the comprehending of the aggregates.🔽Here is the exposition: There are three kinds of mundane full-understanding, namely, full-understanding as the known, full-understanding as investigation, and full-understanding as abandoning.

original: ca. Yā sandhāya vuttaṃ “abhiññāpaññā ñātaṭṭhe ñāṇaṃ. Pariññāpaññā tīraṇaṭṭhe ñāṇaṃ.🔽Pahānapaññā pariccāgaṭṭhe ñāṇa”nti. Tattha “ruppanalakkhaṇaṃ rūpaṃ, vedayitalakkhaṇā
analyzed: ca yā sandhāya vuttam abhiññā paññā ñāta ṭṭhe ñāṇam pariññā paññā tīraṇa ṭṭhe ñāṇam  pahāna paññā pariccāga ṭṭhe ñāṇan ti tattha ruppana lakkhaṇam rūpam vedayita lakkhaṇā
translated: It is with reference to these that it is said: “The understanding that is direct-knowledge is knowledge in the sense of the known. The understanding that is full-understanding is knowledge in the sense of investigating.🔽The understanding that is abandoning is knowledge in the sense of relinquishing” .

original: vedanā”ti evaṃ tesaṃ tesaṃ dhammānaṃ paccattalakkhaṇasallakkhaṇavasena pavattā paññā🔽ñātapariññā nāma. “Rūpaṃ aniccaṃ, vedanā aniccā”tiādinā nayena tesaṃyeva dhammānaṃ🔽sāmaññalakkhaṇaṃ āropetvā pavattā lakkhaṇārammaṇikavipassanā paññā tīraṇapariññā
analyzed: vedanā ti evam tesam tesam dhammānam paccatta lakkhaṇa sat lakkhaṇa vasena pavattā paññā  ñāta pariññā nāma rūpam aniccam vedanā aniccā ati ādinā nayena tesam yeva dhammānam  sāmañña lakkhaṇam āropetvā pavattā lakkhaṇa ārammaṇika vipassanā paññā tīraṇa pariññā
translated: Herein, understanding that occurs by defining the specific characteristics of the various states, according to such passages as “Rūpa has the characteristic of being fashioned: … feeling has the characteristic of being felt” ,🔽is called “full-understanding as the known.” Understanding that occurs by superimposing the general characteristics on those same states according to the passage, “Rūpa is impermanent, suffering, and changeable; feeling is impermanent, suffering, and changeable” ,

original: nāma. Tesuyeva pana dhammesu niccasaññādipajahanavasena pavattā lakkhaṇārammaṇikavipassanā
analyzed: nāma tesu yeva pana dhammesu nicca saññā ādi pajahana vasena pavattā lakkhaṇa ārammaṇika vipassanā
translated: is called “full-understanding as investigation.” Understanding that occurs by abandoning the perception of permanence, etc., in those same states

original: paññā pahānapariññā nāma.
analyzed: paññā pahānapariññā nāma
translated: is called “full-understanding as abandoning.”

original: Tattha saṅkhāraparicchedato paṭṭhāya yāva paccayapariggahā ñātapariññāya bhūmi. Etasmiṃ
analyzed: tattha saṅkhāra paricchedataḥ paṭṭhāya yāva paccaya pariggahā ñāta pariññāya bhūmi etasmin
translated: Herein, the section dealing with the formations up to the section dealing with the conditions is the plane of full-understanding as a known fact.

original: hi antare dhammānaṃ paccattalakkhaṇapaṭivedhasseva ādhipaccaṃ hoti. Kalāpasammasanato🔽pana paṭṭhāya yāva udayabbayānupassanā tīraṇapariññāya bhūmi. Etasmiṃ hi antare sāmaññalakkhaṇapaṭivedhasseva
analyzed: hi antare dhammānam paccatta lakkhaṇa paṭivedhassa iva ādhipaccam hoti kalāpa sammasanato  pana paṭṭhāya yāva udaya bbaya anupassanā tīraṇa pariññāya bhūmi etasmin hi antare sāmañña lakkhaṇa paṭivedhassa iva
translated: For in this section the pre-eminent thing is the penetration of the individual essences of states.🔽But the section dealing with the contemplation of dissolution is the plane of full-understanding as a matter of course.🔽For in this section the pre-eminent thing is the penetration of the general characteristics.

original: ādhipaccaṃ hoti. Bhaṅgānupassanaṃ ādiṃ katvā upari pahānapariññāya bhūmi. Tato paṭṭhāya🔽hi aniccato anupassanto niccasaññaṃ pajahati, dukkhato anupassanto sukhasaññaṃ, anattato🔽anupassanto attasaññaṃ, nibbindanto nandiṃ, virajjanto rāgaṃ, nirodhento samudayaṃ,
analyzed: ādhipaccam hoti bhaṅga anupassanam ādim katvā upari pahāna pariññāya bhūmi tatas paṭṭhāya  hi aniccataḥ anupassanto nicca saññam pajahati dukkhataḥ anupassanto sukha saññam anattato  anupassantaḥ atta saññam nibbindantaḥ nandim virajjantaḥ rāgam nirodhentaḥ samudayam
translated: The section dealing with the contemplation of dispassion, etc., is the plane of full-understanding as abandoning.

original: paṭinissajjanto ādānaṃ pajahatīti evaṃ niccasaññādipahānasādhikānaṃ sattannaṃ anupassanānaṃ
analyzed: paṭinissajjantaḥ ādānam pajahati iti evam nicca saññā ādi pahāna sādhikānam sattannam anupassanānam
translated: For from there onwards, contemplating as impermanent, he abandons the perception of permanence; contemplating as painful, he abandons the perception of pleasure; contemplating as not-self, he abandons the perception of self; contemplating as dispassion, he abandons delight; contemplating as fading away, he abandons greed; contemplating as cessation, he abandons arising; contemplating as relinquishment, he abandons grasping. So these seven contemplations, which effect the abandoning of the perception of permanence, etc.,

original: ādhipaccaṃ. Iti imāsu tīsu pariññāsu saṅkhāraparicchedassa ceva paccayapariggahassa

analyzed: ca sādhita ttā iminā yoginā ñāta pariññā ava adhigatā hoti itarā ca adhigantabbā tena  vuttam yasmā tīraṇa pariññāya vattamānāya magga amagga ñāṇam uppajjati tīraṇa pariññā
translated: So when the delimitation of formations and the discernment of conditions have been accomplished in these three kinds of full understanding, then the meditator has reached the full understanding of what is to be fully understood by the means of purification consisting in knowledge and vision of what is the path and what is not the path. translated: Hence it was said: “When the full understanding of contemplation is occurring, knowledge of what is the path and what is not the path arises.
