analyzed: katham paratas vutta nayena vuttam ha etam rūpam atīta anāgata paccuppannam aniccam khaya ṭṭhena ati
translated: How? In the way stated thus: “Materiality, whether past, future, or present, is impermanent in the sense of destruction” .

original: Tasmā esa yaṃ atītaṃ rūpaṃ, taṃ yasmā atīteyeva khīṇaṃ, nayimaṃ bhavaṃ sampattanti aniccaṃ khayaṭṭhena.🔽Yaṃ anāgataṃ anantarabhave nibbattissati, tampi tattheva khīyissati, na tato paraṃ bhavaṃ gamissatīti aniccaṃ khayaṭṭhena.
analyzed: tasmai yam atītam rūpam tam yasmai khīṇam na imam bhavam sampattanti aniccam khaya ṭṭhena  yam anāgatam anantara bhave nibbattissati tam pi tattha eva khīyissati na tatas param bhavam gamissati iti aniccam khaya ṭṭhena
translated: So he comprehends it as impermanent in the sense of destruction thus: “That materiality which is past has perished there, it has not come down to this becoming;🔽that which is future will also perish there, it will not come down to this becoming;

original: Yaṃ paccuppannaṃ rūpaṃ, tampi idheva khīyati, na ito gacchatīti aniccaṃ khayaṭṭhena.
analyzed: yam paccuppannam rūpam tam pi idhā iva khīyati na itas gacchati iti aniccam khaya ṭṭhena
translated: that which is present perishes here, it does not go to another becoming.”

original: Yaṃ ajjhattaṃ, tampi ajjhattameva khīyati, na bahiddhābhāvaṃ gacchatīti aniccaṃ khayaṭṭhena.
analyzed: yam ajjhattam tam pi ajjhattam eva khīyati na bahiddhā bhāvam gacchati iti aniccam khaya ṭṭhena
translated: He comprehends it as impermanent in the sense of destruction thus: “That which is internal perishes there, it does not go to become external;

original: Yaṃ bahiddhā…pe… oḷārikaṃ…pe… sukhumaṃ…pe… hīnaṃ…pe… paṇītaṃ…pe… dūre…pe… santike, tampi tattheva khīyati, na dūrabhāvaṃ gacchatīti aniccaṃ khayaṭṭhenāti sammasati.
analyzed: yam bahiddhā pe oḷārikaṃpe sukhumaṃpe hīnaṃpe paṇītaṃpe dūre pe santike tam pi tattha iva khīyati na dūra bhāvam gacchati iti aniccam khaya ṭṭhena ati sammasati
translated: that which is external … that which is gross … that which is subtle … that which is far … that which is near perishes there, it does not go to a distance.”

original: Idaṃ sabbampi “aniccaṃ khayaṭṭhenā”ti etassa vasena ekaṃ sammasanaṃ. Bhedato pana ekādasavidhaṃ hoti.
analyzed: idam sabbam pi aniccam khaya ṭṭhena ati etassa vasena ekam sammasanam bhedato pana ekādasavidham hoti
translated: This is one kind of comprehension, that is to say, as impermanent in the sense of destruction. But when it is classed according to its different aspects, it is of eleven kinds.

original: Sabbameva ca taṃ dukkhaṃ bhayaṭṭhena. Bhayaṭṭhenāti sappaṭibhayatāya. Yañhi aniccaṃ,
analyzed: sabbam eva ca tat dukkham bhaya ṭṭhena bhaya ṭṭhena ati sa paṭibhaya tāya yat hi aniccam
translated: And all that is suffering in the sense of terror. In the sense of terror: in the sense of being full of terror. For what is impermanent

original: taṃ bhayāvahaṃ hoti sīhopamasutte devānaṃ viya. Iti idampi “dukkhaṃ bhayaṭṭhenā”ti
analyzed: tam bhaya āvaham hoti sīhopamasutte devānam viya iti idam pi dukkham bhaya ṭṭhena ati
translated: is a bringer of terror, like the gods’ “snake simile” . So this is one kind of comprehension by means of “suffering in the sense of terror. ”

original: etassa vasena ekaṃ sammasanaṃ. Bhedato pana ekādasavidhaṃ hoti.🔽Yathā ca dukkhaṃ, evaṃ sabbampi taṃ anattā asārakaṭṭhena. Asārakaṭṭhenāti “attā nivāsī
analyzed: etassa vasena ekam sammasanam bhedato pana ekādasavidham hoti  yathā ca dukkham evam sabbam pi tam anattā asāra kaṭṭhena asāra kaṭṭhena ati attā nivāsī
translated: But when classified, it is of eleven kinds.

original: kārako vedako sayaṃvasī”ti evaṃ parikappitassa attasārassa abhāvena. Yañhi aniccaṃ,
analyzed: kārakaḥ vedakaḥ sayaṃvasī iti evam parikappitassa atta sārassa abhāvena yat hi aniccam
translated: And as with suffering, so too all that is impermanent is not-self in the sense of having no core. In the sense of having no core: in the sense of the absence of a core of self in what is imagined thus “The self dwells ,” “The self acts,” “The self experiences,” “The self is in its own power. ” For what is impermanent

original: dukkhaṃ, taṃ attanopi aniccataṃ vā udayabbayapīḷanaṃ vā vāretuṃ na sakkoti, kuto🔽tassa kārakādibhāvo. Tenāha – “rūpañca hidaṃ, bhikkhave, attā abhavissa. Nayidaṃ
analyzed: dukkham tam attanaḥ api aniccatam vā udaya bbaya pīḷanam vā vāretum na sakkoti kutas  tassa kāraka ādi bhāvaḥ tena āha rūpam ca hi idam bhikkhave attā abhavissa na idam
translated: and suffering is unable to ward off the impermanence or the affliction of rise and fall even of itself, so how

original: rūpaṃ ābādhāya saṃvatteyyā”tiādi. Iti idampi “anattā asārakaṭṭhenā”ti etassa vasena
analyzed: rūpam ābādhāya saṃvatteyya atiādi iti idam pi anattā asāra kaṭṭhena ati etassa vasena
translated: could it be a self that acts, etc.? That is why it is said, “If now this form, bhikkhus, were the self, this form would not lead to affliction, and it should be possible to have in regard to form: ‘Let my form be thus, let my form be not thus’ ” . So this is one kind of comprehension by means of “not-self in the sense of having no core. ”

original: ekaṃ sammasanaṃ. Bhedato pana ekādasavidhaṃ hoti. Esa nayo vedanādīsu.
analyzed: ekam sammasanam bhedato pana ekādasavidham hoti esa nayaḥ vedanā ādīsu
translated: and one kind of comprehension. But when classed according to breach it is of eleven kinds. So too with feeling, and so on.

original: 696. Yaṃ pana aniccaṃ, taṃ yasmā niyamato saṅkhatādibhedaṃ hoti. Tenassa pariyāyadassanatthaṃ,
analyzed: yam pana aniccam tam yasmā niyamataḥ saṅkhata ādi bhedam hoti tena assa pariyāya dassana attham
translated: But since what is impermanent is necessarily of the nature of suffering, and so on, the text is stated again in order to show the synonyms for it,🔽or in order to show the occurrence of attention in various modes.

original: nānākārehi vā manasikārappavattidassanatthaṃ “rūpaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ aniccaṃ
analyzed: nānā ākārehi vā manasikāra ppavatti dassana attham rūpam atīta anāgata paccuppannam aniccam
translated: So it is said: “Materiality, whether past, future, or present, is impermanent,

original: saṅkhataṃ paṭiccasamuppannaṃ khayadhammaṃ vayadhammaṃ virāgadhammaṃ nirodhadhamma”nti
analyzed: saṅkhatam paṭicca samuppannam khaya dhammam vaya dhammam virāga dhammam nirodha dhammanti
translated: formed, dependently arisen, subject to destruction, subject to fall, subject to fading away, subject to cessation” .

original: puna pāḷi vuttā. Esa nayo vedanādīsūti.
analyzed: puna vuttā esa nayaḥ vedanā ādīsu iti
translated: And so too with feeling, and so on.

original: Cattārīsākāraanupassanākathā
analyzed: cattārīsa ākāra anupassanā kathā
translated: The exposition of the contemplations of impermanence, etc., in the four paths

original: 697. So tasseva pañcasu khandhesu aniccadukkhānattasammasanassa thirabhāvatthāya,🔽yaṃ taṃ bhagavatā “katamehi cattārīsāya ākārehi anulomikaṃ khantiṃ paṭilabhati, katamehi
analyzed: saḥ tassa iva pañcasu khandhesu anicca dukkha anatta sammasanassa thira bhāva tthāya  yam tam bhagavatā katamehi cattārīsāya ākārehi anulomikam khantim paṭilabhati katamehi
translated: In order to make that comprehension of impermanence, etc., in the five aggregates of the same kind as the previous comprehension,

original: cattārīsāya ākārehi sammattaniyāmaṃ okkamatī”ti etassa vibhaṅge –
analyzed: cattārīsāya ākārehi sammatta niyāmam okkamati iti etassa vibhaṅge
translated: the Blessed One has the Elder Ānanda ask: “In what way, friend Gotama, does a noble disciple contemplate the body as a body? … And how does he dwell perceiving after and before: ‘As before, so after; as after, so before; as below, so above; as above, so below; as by day, so at night; as at night, so by day’?”

original: “Pañcakkhandhe aniccato, dukkhato, rogato, gaṇḍato, sallato, aghato, ābādhato, parato,
analyzed: pañca kkhandhe aniccataḥ dukkhataḥ rogataḥ gaṇḍataḥ sallataḥ aghataḥ ābādhataḥ paratas
translated: as disintegrating, as a plague, as a disaster, as a bondage, as a calamity born of affection, as impermanent,🔽as painful, as a disease, as a tumour, as a dart, as a calamity, as an affliction, as alien,

original: palokato, ītito, upaddavato, bhayato, upasaggato, calato, pabhaṅguto, addhuvato,🔽atāṇato, aleṇato, asaraṇato, rittato, tucchato, suññato, anattato, ādīnavato, vipariṇāmadhammato,
analyzed: palokataḥ ītitaḥ upaddavataḥ bhayataḥ upasaggataḥ calataḥ pabhaṅgutaḥ addhuvataḥ  a tāṇataḥ a leṇataḥ a saraṇataḥ rittataḥ tucchataḥ suññataḥ anattataḥ ādīnavataḥ vipariṇāma dhammataḥ
translated: as disintegrating, as a plague, as a disaster, as a bondage, as a calamity born of affection, as empty, as non-self, as a danger, as subject to change,🔽as having no core, as the root of calamity, as murderous, as having no shelter, as having no refuge, as having no mainstay, as void, as vain, as isolated, as not self, as a disease, as a tumour, as a dart, as a calamity, as an affliction, as alien,

original: asārakato, aghamūlato, vadhakato, vibhavato, sāsavato, saṅkhatato, mārāmisato, jātidhammato,
analyzed: asārakataḥ agha mūlataḥ vadhakataḥ vibhavataḥ sāsavataḥ saṅkhatataḥ māra āmisataḥ jāti dhammataḥ
translated: as disintegrating, as a plague, as a disaster, as a bondage, as a calamity born of affection, as impermanent,

original: jarādhammato, byādhidhammato, maraṇadhammato, sokadhammato, paridevadhammato, upāyāsadhammato,🔽saṃkilesikadhammato”ti –🔽Cattārīsāya ākārehi,
analyzed: jarā dhammataḥ byādhi dhammataḥ maraṇa dhammataḥ soka dhammataḥ parideva dhammataḥ upāyāsa dhammataḥ  saṃkilesika dhammato ti  cattārīsāya ākārehi
translated: as painful, as a disease, as a tumour, as a dart, as a calamity, as an affliction, as alien,🔽as disintegrating, as a plague, as a disaster, as a bondage, as a calamity born of affection, as empty, as non-self, as a danger, as subject to change,🔽as having no core, as the root of calamity, as murderous, as having no shelter, as having no refuge, as having no mainstay, as void, as vain, as isolated, as not self, as a disease, as a tumour, as a dart, as a calamity, as an affliction, as alien,

original: “Pañcakkhandhe aniccato passanto anulomikaṃ khantiṃ paṭilabhati. Pañcannaṃ khandhānaṃ nirodho niccaṃ nibbānanti passanto sammattaniyāmaṃ okkamatī”tiādinā nayena,
analyzed: pañca kkhandhe aniccato passantaḥ anulomikam khantim paṭilabhati pañcannam khandhānam nirodhaḥ niccam nibbānam ti passantaḥ sammatta niyāmam okkamati iti ādinā nayena
translated: as disintegrating, as a plague, as a disaster, as a bondage, as a calamity born of affection, as impermanent,🔽as painful, as a disease, as a tumour, as a dart, as a calamity, as an affliction, as alien,🔽as disintegrating, as a plague, as a disaster, as a bondage, as a calamity born of affection, as empty, as non-self, as a danger, as subject to change,🔽as having no core, as the root of calamity, as murderous, as having no shelter, as having no refuge, as having no mainstay, as void, as vain, as isolated, as not self, as a disease, as a tumour, as a dart, as a calamity

original: Anulomañāṇaṃ vibhajantena pabhedato aniccādisammasanaṃ vuttaṃ. Tassāpi vasena ime pañcakkhandhe sammasati.
analyzed: anuloma ñāṇam vibhajantena pabhedataḥ anicca ādi sammasanam vuttam tassa api vasena ime pañca kkhandhe sammasati
translated: The discernment of mentality-materiality is stated in the Vibhaṅga in the description of conformity knowledge, which is given in terms of the discerning of impermanence, etc., in the five aggregates. He discerns these five aggregates in the following way.

original: 698. Kathaṃ? So hi ekekaṃ khandhaṃ anaccantikatāya, ādiantavantatāya ca aniccato.
analyzed: katham saḥ hi ekekam khandham anaccantika tāya ādi antavanta tāya ca aniccato
translated: He discerns the aggregate of material form as impermanent because it is not lasting, because it is subject to destruction, dissolution, and evanescence.🔽He discerns it as painful because it is the basis for suffering, because it is subject to suffering through arising, and because it is subject to suffering through change.

original: Uppādavayapaṭipīḷanatāya, dukkhavatthutāya ca dukkhato. Paccayayāpanīyatāya, rogamūlatāya🔽ca rogato. Dukkhatāsūlayogitāya, kilesāsucipaggharaṇatāya, uppādajarābhaṅgehi uddhumātaparipakkapabhinnatāya
analyzed: uppāda vaya paṭipīḍana tāya dukkha vatthu tāya ca dukkhataḥ paccaya yāpanīya tāya roga mūla tāya  ca rogataḥ dukkha tā sūla yogi tāya kilesa asuci paggharaṇa tāya uppāda jarā bhaṅgehi uddhumāta paripakka pabhinna tāya
translated: He discerns it as a disease because it is subject to disease, because it is the root cause of disease, and because it is subject to disease through the elements.🔽He discerns it as a tumour because it is subject to tumours, because it is the root cause of tumours, and because it is subject to tumours through the elements.🔽He discerns it as a barb because it is subject to barbs, because it is the root cause of barbs, and because it is subject to barbs through the elements.🔽He discerns it as misery because it is subject to misery, because it is the root cause of misery, and because it is subject to misery through the elements.🔽He discerns it as a calamity because it is subject to calamities, because it is the root cause of calamities, and because it is subject to calamities through the elements.🔽He discerns it as a misfortune because it is subject to misfortunes, because it is the root cause of misfortunes, and because it is subject to misfortunes through the elements.

original: ca gaṇḍato. Pīḷājanakatāya, antotudanatāya, dunnīharaṇīyatāya ca sallato. Vigarahaṇīyatāya,🔽avaḍḍhiāvahanatāya, aghavatthutāya ca aghato. Aseribhāvajanakatāya, ābādhapadaṭṭhānatāya
analyzed: ca gaṇḍataḥ pīḷā janaka tāya antotudana tāya dunnīharaṇīya tāya ca sallataḥ vigarahaṇīya tāya  avaḍḍhi āvahana tāya agha vatthu tāya ca aghataḥ aseri bhāva janaka tāya ābādha padaṭṭhāna tāya
translated: He discerns it as an affliction because it is subject to afflictions, because it is the root cause of afflictions, and because it is subject to afflictions through the elements.🔽He discerns it as alien because it is subject to aliens, because it is the root cause of aliens, and because it is subject to aliens through the elements.🔽He discerns it as not self because it is subject to non-self, because it is the root cause of non-self, and because it is subject to non-self through the elements.🔽He discerns it as empty because it is subject to emptiness, because it is the root cause of emptiness, and because it is subject to emptiness through the elements.

original: ca ābādhato. Avasatāya, avidheyyatāya ca parato. Byādhijarāmaraṇehi palujjanatāya
analyzed: ca ābādhataḥ avasatāya avidheyyatāya ca paratas byādhi jarā maraṇehi palujjana tāya
translated: He discerns it as vain because it is subject to vanity, because it is the root cause of vanity, and because it is subject to vanity through the elements.

original: palokato. Anekabyasanāvahanatāya ītito. Aviditānaṃyeva vipulānaṃ anatthānaṃ āvahanato,🔽sabbupaddavavatthutāya ca upaddavato. Sabbabhayānaṃ ākaratāya, dukkhavūpasamasaṅkhātassa🔽paramassāsassa paṭipakkhabhūtatāya ca bhayato. Anekehi anatthehi anubaddhatāya, dosūpasaṭṭhatāya,
analyzed: palokataḥ aneka byasana āvahana tāyai ītitaḥ aviditānaṃ yeva vipulānam anatthānam āvahanato  sabba upaddava vatthu tāya ca upaddavataḥ sabba bhayānam ākara tāya dukkha vūpasama saṅkhātassa  parama ssāsassa paṭipakkha bhūta tāya ca bhayataḥ anekehi anatthehi anubaddha tāya dosa upasaṭṭha tāya
translated: and as “perishable” because it is the source of many kinds of loss. It is “from here” because it is the source of many kinds of harm that are unknown .🔽And it is “perilous” because it is the basis for all calamities. And it is “fearful” because it is the source of all fears. It is “full of terrors” because it is beset by many kinds of harm. It is “dangerous” because it is mixed with hatred.

original: upasaggo viya anadhivāsanārahatāya ca upasaggato. Byādhijarāmaraṇehi ceva lābhālābhādīhi
analyzed: upasaggaḥ ca upasaggāt byādhi jarā maraṇehi ca iva lābha a lābha ādīhi
translated: And it is “dangerous” because it is not fit to be dwelt in, like a dangerous road. It is “unstable” because it is shaken by many kinds of harm, by gain and loss, etc.,

original: ca lokadhammehi pacalitatāya calato. Upakkamena ceva sarasena ca pabhaṅgupagamanasīlatāya🔽pabhaṅguto. Sabbāvatthanipātitāya, thirabhāvassa ca abhāvatāya addhuvato. Atāyanatāya
analyzed: ca loka dhammehi pacalita tāya calataḥ upakkamena ca iva sarasena ca pabhaṅgu pagamana sīla tāya  pabhaṅgutaḥ sabbāvattha nipāti tāya thira bhāvassa ca abhāva tāya addhuvataḥ atāyana tāya
translated: and by the world’s vicissitudes. It is “unsubstantial” because it is subject to breaking up by assault and by wasting away.🔽It is “unsubstantial” because it is the basis for all determinations, and because it has no firmness. It is “no protection” because it is not a shelter and because it is unreliable.

original: ceva, alabbhaneyyakhematāya ca atāṇato. Allīyituṃ anarahatāya, allīnānampi ca leṇakiccākāritāya
analyzed: ca iva a labbha neyya khema tāya ca a tāṇataḥ allīyitum an arahatāya ca leṇa kiccā kāritāya
translated: And it is “no protection” because it is not fit to be clung to, and because it does not do the work of a shelter for those who cling to it.

original: aleṇato. Nissitānaṃ bhayasārakattābhāvena asaraṇato. Yathāparikappitehi dhuvasubhasukhattabhāvehi
analyzed: a leṇataḥ nissitānam bhaya sāraka ttā abhāvena a saraṇataḥ yathā parikappitehi dhuva subha sukhatta bhāvehi
translated: and not as a refuge, because of the absence of any refuge in what is dependent, since it is subject to fear.

original: rittatāya rittato. Rittatāyeva tucchato appakattā vā, appakampi hi loke tucchanti
analyzed: rittatāya rittataḥ rittatāya iva tucchataḥ appakattā vai appakam hi loke tucchanti
translated: and as void, because of its voidness, or because of its worthlessness, for in the world what is worthless is called “void” .

original: vuccati. Sāmi-nivāsi-kāraka-vedakādhiṭṭhāyakavirahitatāya suññato. Sayañca assāmikabhāvāditāya🔽anattato. Pavattidukkhatāya, dukkhassa ca ādīnavatāya ādīnavato, atha vā ādīnaṃ vāti
analyzed: vuccati sāmi nivāsi kāraka vedaka adhiṭṭhāyaka virahita tāya suññatas sayam ca a sāmika bhāva ādi tāya  anattataḥ pavatti dukkha tāya dukkhassa ca ādīnava tāya ādīnavataḥ atha vā ādīnam vāti
translated: and as not self, because of its absence of owner-ship, etc.,

original: gacchati pavattatīti ādīnavo, kapaṇamanussassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ, khandhāpi ca kapaṇāyevāti
analyzed: gacchati pavattati iti ādīnavaḥ kapaṇa manussassa etam adhivacanam ca kapaṇāya iva ati
translated: and as a danger, because of the suffering in its occurrence and because of the danger in suffering. Or alternatively, it goes by the way of danger, thus it is a danger ; this is a term for a wretched man, and the aggregates are indeed wretched,🔽therefore they are a danger in the sense of being similar to a danger.

original: ādīnavasadisatāya ādīnavato. Jarāya ceva maraṇena cāti dvedhā pariṇāmapakatitāya
analyzed: ādīnava sadisatāya ādīnavataḥ jarāya ca iva maraṇena ca ati dvedhā pariṇāma pakatitāya
translated: and as subject to change, because of the twofold change in ageing and death.🔽and as without core, because of its weakness and because of its lack of essence, like a lump of foam.

original: vipariṇāmadhammato. Dubbalatāya, pheggu viya sukhabhañjanīyatāya ca asārakato. Aghahetutāya
analyzed: vipariṇāma dhammataḥ dubbala tāya sukha bhañjanīya tāya ca asārakataḥ agha hetu tāya
translated: and as a dart, because of its causing grief.

original: aghamūlato. Mittamukhasapatto viya vissāsaghātitāya vadhakato. Vigatabhavatāya, vibhavasambhūtatāya
analyzed: agha mūlataḥ mitta mukha sapattaḥ viya vissāsa ghāti tāya vadhakataḥ vigata bhava tāya vibhava sambhūta tāya
translated: From the root of evil. As a murderer from the fact of his destroying confidence, like a treacherous friend. From the fact of its being devoid of being, and from the fact of its being originated by the breakup of the aggregates,

original: ca vibhavato. Āsavapadaṭṭhānatāya sāsavato. Hetupaccayehi abhisaṅkhatatāya saṅkhatato.🔽Maccumārakilesamārānaṃ āmisabhūtatāya mārāmisato. Jāti-jarā-byādhimaraṇapakatitāya
analyzed: ca vibhavataḥ āsava padaṭṭhāna tāya sa āsavataḥ hetu paccayehi abhisaṅkhata tāya saṅkhatataḥ  āmisa bhūta tāya māra āmisataḥ jāti jarā byādhi maraṇa pakati tāya
translated: from the fact of its being subject to breakup. From the fact of its being the footing for the taints, from the fact of its being subject to the taints. From the fact of its being resolved by causes and conditions, from the fact of its being formed.🔽From the fact of its being the bait of Mara, as it is the bait of Mara for the three kinds of Mara, namely, the Mara of Death, the Mara of the Depravities, and the Mara of the Lord of Death. From the fact of its being subject to birth, ageing, and death,

original: jāti-jarā-byādhi-maraṇadhammato. Soka-parideva-upāyāsahetutāya soka-paridevaupāyāsadhammato.
analyzed: jāti jarā byādhi maraṇa dhammato soka parideva aupāyāsa hetutāya soka parideva aupāyāsa dhammato
translated: from the fact of its being subject to birth, ageing, and death. From the fact of its being subject to sorrow, lamentation, pain, grief, and despair, from the fact of its being subject to sorrow, lamentation, pain, grief, and despair.

original: Taṇhādiṭṭhiduccaritasaṃkilesānaṃ visayadhammatāya saṃkilesikadhammatoti evaṃ pabhedato
analyzed: taṇhā diṭṭhi duccarita saṃkilesānam visaya dhamma tāya saṃkilesika dhamma to ti evam pabhedato
translated: From the fact of its being subject to defilement, as it is the province of the defilements of craving, of views, and of misconduct. Thus he comprehends by means of the comprehending of the impermanent, etc.,

original: vuttassa aniccādisammasanassa vasena sammasati.
analyzed: vuttassa anicca ādi sammasanassa vasena sammasati
translated: which has been stated with its special divisions.

original: Ettha hi aniccato, palokato, calato, pabhaṅguto, addhuvato, vipariṇāmadhammato, asārakato,
analyzed: ettha hi aniccataḥ palokataḥ calataḥ pabhaṅgutaḥ addhuvataḥ vipariṇāma dhammataḥ asārakataḥ
translated: Herein, as regards the words “as impermanent,” “as liable to fall away,” “as having no stability,” “as having no core,” “as having no shelter,” “as having no refuge,” “as having no essence,”

original: vibhavato, saṅkhatato, maraṇadhammatoti ekekasmiṃ khandhe dasa dasa katvā paññāsa
analyzed: vibhavataḥ saṅkhatataḥ maraṇa dhammato ti ekekasmin khandhe dasa dasa katvā paññāsa

original: aniccānupassanāni. Parato, rittato, tucchato, suññato, anattatoti ekekasmiṃ khandhe🔽pañca pañca katvā pañcavīsati anattānupassanāni. Sesāni dukkhato, rogatotiādīni ekekasmiṃ
analyzed: anicca anupassanāni paratas rittataḥ tucchataḥ suññataḥ anattataḥ ti ekekasmin khandhe  pañca pañca katvā pañcavīsati anatta anupassanāni sesāni dukkhataḥ rogataḥ ti ādīni ekekasmin
translated: and contemplations of impermanence.🔽and five each on the other four aggregates, making twenty-five contemplations of not-self.

original: khandhe pañcavīsati pañcavīsati katvā pañcavīsatisataṃ dukkhānupassanānīti.
analyzed: khandhe pañcavīsati pañcavīsati katvā pañcavīsati satam dukkha anupassanāni iti
translated: The remaining contemplations, namely, on suffering, on disease, and so on, are twenty-five each on the five aggregates, making a hundred and twenty-five contemplations of suffering.

original: Iccassa iminā dvisatabhedena aniccādisammasanena pañcakkhandhe sammasato taṃ nayavipassanāsaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: iccassa iminā dvi sata bhedena anicca ādi sammasanena pañca kkhandhe sammasataḥ tam naya vipassanā saṅkhātam
translated: So when he comprehends the five aggregates by means of this two-hundred- fold comprehending of impermanence, etc.,

original: aniccadukkhānattasammasanaṃ thiraṃ hoti. Idaṃ tāvettha pāḷinayānusārena sammasanārambhavidhānaṃ.
analyzed: anicca dukkha anatta sammasanam thiram hoti idam tāva ettha pāḷi naya anusārena sammasana ārambha vidhānam
translated: his comprehending of impermanence, suffering, and not-self, called “comprehending by groups,” becomes stabilized. This, firstly, is the method of commencing the comprehending according to the method of the texts.

original: Indriyatikkhakāraṇanavakakathā
analyzed: indriya tikkha kāraṇa navaka kathā
translated: The nine ways of making the faculties keen

original: 699. Yassa pana evaṃ nayavipassanāya yogaṃ karotopi nayavipassanā na sampajjati,
analyzed: yassa pana evam naya vipassanāya yogam karotaḥ api naya vipassanā na sampajjati
translated: But if insight does not succeed in this way,

analyzed: tena navahā ākārehi indriyāni tikkhāni bhavanti uppanna uppannānam saṅkhārānam khayam eva
translated: then his faculties become keen in nine ways: he sees only the dissolution of presently arisen formations,

original: passati, tattha ca sakkaccakiriyāya sampādeti, sātaccakiriyāya sampādeti, sappāyakiriyāya
analyzed: passati tattha ca sakkacca kiriyāya sampādeti sātacca kiriyāya sampādeti sappāya kiriyāya
translated: and he applies himself to it eagerly, and he applies himself continuously, and he applies himself suitably,

analyzed: sampādeti samādhissa ca nimitta ggāhena bojjhaṅgānaṃ ca an upavatta natāya kāye ca
translated: and he attends to the sign of concentration, and he does not neglect the arousing of energy, and he maintains equanimity that is not concerned either for his body or for his life,

original: jīvite ca anapekkhataṃ upaṭṭhāpeti, tattha ca abhibhuyya nekkhammena, antarā ca abyosānenā”ti🔽evaṃ vuttānaṃ navannaṃ ākārānaṃ vasena indriyāni tikkhāni katvā pathavīkasiṇaniddese
analyzed: jīvite ca an apekkhatam upaṭṭhāpeti tattha ca abhibhuyya nekkhammena antarā ca a byosānena ati  evam vuttānam navannam ākārānam vasena indriyāni tikkhāni katvā pathavī kasiṇa niddese
translated: and he maintains a desire for the state of desirelessness, and he does not neglect the right endeavour that is concerned with the present life and that with the future life” .🔽When the faculties have been sharpened by means of these nine aspects, he should, as described under the earth kasiṇa , avoid the seven unsuitable things and cultivate the seven suitable things, and then he should bring the kasiṇa to mind as a sign.🔽He should bring it to mind as “earth, earth” in the way already described under the earth kasiṇa .🔽He should bring it to mind as “beautiful, beautiful” in order to avoid the sign losing its hold.

original: vuttanayena satta asappāyāni vajjetvā satta sappāyāni sevamānena kālena rūpaṃ sammasitabbaṃ,🔽kālena arūpaṃ. Rūpaṃ sammasantena rūpassa nibbatti passitabbā.
analyzed: vutta nayena satta asappāyāni vajjetvā satta sappāyāni sevamānena kālena rūpam sammasitabbam  kālena arūpam rūpam sammasantena rūpassa nibbatti passitabbā
translated: He should bring it to mind as “one, one” in order to avoid taking the kasiṇa as a multiplicity.🔽He should bring it to mind as “earth” in order to avoid the sign of the kasiṇa becoming mixed up with the sign of the surrounding signs.🔽He should bring it to mind as “not soul” in order to avoid misinterpreting the sign.

original: Rūpanibbattipassanākārakathā
analyzed: rūpa nibbatti passanā kāra kathā
translated: He should bring it to mind as “not soul” in order to avoid misinterpreting the sign.🔽He should bring it to mind as “void” in order to avoid misinterpreting the sign.🔽He should bring it to mind as “void” in order to avoid misinterpreting the sign.🔽He should bring it to mind as “void” in order to avoid misinterpreting the sign.🔽He should bring it to mind as “void” in order to avoid misinterpreting the sign.🔽He should bring it to mind as “void” in order to avoid misinterpreting the sign.🔽He should bring it to mind as “void” in order to avoid misinterpreting the sign.🔽He should bring it to mind as “void” in order to avoid misinterpreting the sign.🔽He should bring it to mind as “void” in order to avoid misinterpreting the sign.🔽He should bring it to mind as “void” in order to avoid misinterpreting the sign.

original: 700. Seyyathidaṃ – idaṃ rūpaṃ nāma kammādivasena catūhi kāraṇehi nibbattati. Tattha
analyzed: idam rūpam nāma kamma ādi vasena catūhi kāraṇehi nibbattati tattha
translated: He should bring it to mind as “void” in order to avoid misinterpreting the sign.🔽He should bring it to mind

original: sabbesaṃ sattānaṃ rūpaṃ nibbattamānaṃ paṭhamaṃ kammato nibbattati. Paṭisandhikkhaṇeyeva🔽hi gabbhaseyyakānaṃ tāva tisantativasena vatthu-kāya-bhāvadasakasaṅkhātāni tiṃsa
analyzed: sabbesam sattānam rūpam nibbattamānam paṭhamam kammataḥ nibbattati paṭisandhi khaṇe yeva  hi gabbhaseyyakānam tāva ti santati vasena vatthu kāya bhāva dasaka saṅkhātāni tiṃsa
translated: The materiality of all beings arises first from kamma.🔽For in the case of those who are to be reborn in a womb, thirty kinds of materiality arise in three successive stages at the very moment of rebirth-linking.

original: rūpāni nibbattanti, tāni ca kho paṭisandhicittassa uppādakkhaṇeyeva. Yathā ca uppādakkhaṇe,
analyzed: rūpāni nibbattanti tāni ca kho paṭisandhi cittassa uppāda khaṇe yeva yathā ca uppāda khaṇe
translated: And they arise at the moment of arising of the rebirth-linking consciousness,

original: tathā ṭhitikkhaṇepi bhaṅgakkhaṇepi.
analyzed: tathā ṭhiti khaṇe pi bhaṅga khaṇe pi
translated: and just as at the moment of arising, so also at the moment of presence and at the moment of dissolution.

original: Tattha rūpaṃ dandhanirodhaṃ garuparivatti, cittaṃ khippanirodhaṃ lahuparivatti. Tenāha
analyzed: tattha rūpam dandha nirodham garu parivatti cittam khippa nirodham lahu parivatti tena āha
translated: Herein, materiality has slow arising and slow revolution, while consciousness has quick arising and quick revolution. Hence it is said:

original: – “nāhaṃ, bhikkhave, aññaṃ ekadhammampi samanupassāmi, yaṃ evaṃ lahuparivattaṃ yathayidaṃ,
analyzed: na aham bhikkhave aññam eka dhammam pi samanupassāmi yam evam lahu parivattam yathayidam
translated: “Bhikkhus, I see no other one thing that has such quick arising and quick revolution as the mind” .

original: bhikkhave, citta”nti. Rūpe dharanteyeva hi soḷasavāre bhavaṅgacittaṃ uppajjitvā nirujjhati.
analyzed: bhikkhave cittam ti rūpe dharanteya iva hi soḷasa vāre bhavaṅga cittam uppajjitvā nirujjhati
translated: For while materiality persists, the life-continuum consciousness arises and dissolves sixteen times.🔽The moment of arising, the moment of presence, and the moment of dissolution of consciousness are the same,

original: Cittassa uppādakkhaṇopi ṭhitikkhaṇopi bhaṅgakkhaṇopi ekasadisā. Rūpassa pana uppādabhaṅgakkhaṇāyeva
analyzed: cittassa uppāda khaṇo api ṭhiti khaṇo api bhaṅga kkhaṇo api eka sadisā rūpassa pana uppāda bhaṅga khaṇāya eva
translated: but the moment of arising and the moment of dissolution of materiality are different.

original: lahukā, tehi sadisā. Ṭhitikkhaṇo pana mahā, yāva soḷasa cittāni uppajjitvā nirujjhanti,🔽tāva vattati. Paṭisandhicittassa uppādakkhaṇe uppannaṃ ṭhānappattaṃ purejātaṃ vatthuṃ
analyzed: lahukā tehi sadisā ṭhiti khaṇaḥ pana mahā yāva soḷasa cittāni uppajjitvā nirujjhanti  tāva vattati paṭisandhi cittassa uppāda khaṇe uppannam ṭhāna ppattam purejātam vatthum
translated: but the life-continuum is heavy, and it is similar to that. But the moment of its presence is long, for it occurs for as long as sixteen consciousnesses arise and cease.

original: nissāya dutiyaṃ bhavaṅgaṃ uppajjati. Tena saddhiṃ uppannaṃ ṭhānappattaṃ purejātaṃ🔽vatthuṃ nissāya tatiyaṃ bhavaṅgaṃ uppajjati. Iminā nayena yāvatāyukaṃ cittappavatti
analyzed: nissāya dutiyam bhavaṅgam uppajjati tena saddhim uppannam ṭhāna ppattam purejātam  vatthum nissāya tatiyam bhavaṅgam uppajjati iminā nayena yāvatāyukam citta ppavatti
translated: The second life-continuum arises contingent upon the physical heart- basis that has reached presence at the moment of arising of the rebirth-linking consciousness. The physical heart-basis that has reached presence together with that arises contingent upon the physical heart-basis that has reached presence at the moment of arising of the second life-continuum.

original: veditabbā. Āsannamaraṇassa pana ekameva ṭhānappattaṃ purejātaṃ vatthuṃ nissāya soḷasa cittāni uppajjanti.🔽Paṭisandhicittassa uppādakkhaṇe uppannaṃ rūpaṃ paṭisandhicittato uddhaṃ soḷasamena
analyzed: veditabbā āsannamaraṇassa pana ekam eva ṭhānappattam purejātam vatthum nissāya soḷasa cittāni uppajjanti  paṭisandhi cittassa uppāda kkhaṇe uppannam rūpam paṭisandhi cittataḥ uddham soḷasamena
translated: The third life-continuum arises contingent upon the physical heart-basis that has reached presence together with the second life-continuum. In this way the occurrence of consciousness should be understood for as long as life lasts. But in the case of one whose death is imminent, sixteen consciousnesses arise contingent upon the one physical heart-basis that has reached presence.

original: cittena saddhiṃ nirujjhati. Ṭhānakkhaṇe uppannaṃ sattarasamassa uppādakkhaṇena saddhiṃ
analyzed: cittena saddhim nirujjhati ṭhāna kkhaṇe uppannam sattarasamassa uppāda kkhaṇena saddhim
translated: The materiality that arose at the moment of arising of the rebirth-linking consciousness ceases together with the sixteenth consciousness after the rebirth-linking consciousness. That which arose at the moment of presence ceases together with the seventeenth consciousness at the moment of arising of the seventeenth consciousness.

original: nirujjhati. Bhaṅgakkhaṇe uppannaṃ sattarasamassa ṭhānakkhaṇaṃ patvā nirujjhati. Yāva🔽pavatti nāma atthi, evameva pavattati. Opapātikānampi sattasantativasena sattati
analyzed: nirujjhati bhaṅga kkhaṇe uppannam sattarasamassa ṭhāna kkhaṇam patvā nirujjhati yāva  pavatti nāma atthi evam eva pavattati opapātikānam pi satta santati vasena sattati
translated: It ceases at the moment of its presence in the seventeenth.🔽As long as there is occurrence, it occurs thus.

original: rūpāni evameva pavattanti.🔽701. Tattha kammaṃ, kammasamuṭṭhānaṃ, kammapaccayaṃ, kammapaccayacittasamuṭṭhānaṃ,
analyzed: rūpāni evam eva pavattanti  tattha kammam kamma samuṭṭhānam kamma paccayam kamma paccaya citta samuṭṭhānam
translated: In the case of those who are spontaneously born, the seventy-two kinds of materiality occur thus in the continuity of the being.

original: kammapaccayaāhārasamuṭṭhānaṃ, kammapaccayautusamuṭṭhānanti esa vibhāgo veditabbo.🔽Tattha kammaṃ nāma kusalākusalacetanā. Kammasamuṭṭhānaṃ nāma vipākakkhandhā ca, cakkhudasakādi🔽samasattatirūpañca. Kammapaccayaṃ nāma tadeva, kammaṃ hi kammasamuṭṭhānassa upatthambhakapaccayopi
analyzed: kamma paccaya āhāra samuṭṭhānam kamma paccaya otu samuṭṭhānam ti esa vibhāgaḥ veditabbo  tattha kammam nāma kusala akusala cetanā kamma samuṭṭhānam nāma vipāka khandhā ca cakkhu dasaka ādi  sama sattati rūpam ca kammapaccayam nāma tat eva kammam hi kamma samuṭṭhānassa upatthambhaka paccayaḥ api
translated: Herein, the analysis should be understood thus: kamma, kamma-originated, kamma-condition, kamma-condition-consciousness-originated, kamma-condition- nutriment-originated, and kamma-condition-temperature-originated.

original: hoti. Kammapaccayacittasamuṭṭhānaṃ nāma vipākacittasamuṭṭhānaṃ rūpaṃ. Kammapaccayaāhārasamuṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: hoti kamma paccaya citta samuṭṭhānam nāma vipāka citta samuṭṭhānam rūpam kamma paccaya āhāra samuṭṭhānam
translated: Herein, kamma is profitable and unprofitable volition. Kamma-originated is the resultant aggregates and the seventy-two kinds of materiality beginning with eye-sensitivity. Kamma-condition is the same as the above. For kamma is a condition for kamma-originated materiality as a support condition. Kamma-condition-consciousness-originated is materiality originated by resultant consciousness. Kamma-condition-nutriment-originated is materiality originated by nutriment when the condition of kamma is present. Kamma-condition-temperature-originated is materiality originated by temperature when the condition of kamma is present.

original: nāma kammasamuṭṭhānarūpesu ṭhānappattā ojā aññaṃ ojaṭṭhamakaṃ samuṭṭhāpeti, tatrāpi
analyzed: nāma kamma samuṭṭhāna rūpesu ṭhāna ppattā ojā aññam oja ṭṭhamakam samuṭṭhāpeti tatra api
translated: Nutriment-born nutriment- derived matter is the nutriment that has reached presence among the kinds of matter originated by kamma. It generates another octad-with-nutriment- derived-matter-as-eighth. There too

original: ojā ṭhānaṃ patvā aññanti evaṃ catasso vā pañca vā pavattiyo ghaṭeti. Kammapaccayautusamuṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: ojā ṭhānam patvā evam catassaḥ vā pañca vā pavattiyaḥ ghaṭeti kamma paccaya otu samuṭṭhānam
translated: the nutriment that has reached presence generates another octad-with-nutriment- derived-matter-as-eighth. So it goes on for four or five occurrences.

original: nāma kammajatejodhātu ṭhānappattā utusamuṭṭhānaṃ ojaṭṭhamakaṃ samuṭṭhāpeti, tatrāpi🔽utu aññaṃ ojaṭṭhamakanti evaṃ catasso vā pañca vā pavattiyo ghaṭeti. Evaṃ tāva kammajarūpassa
analyzed: nāma kamma ja tejaḥ dhātu ṭhāna ppattā utu samuṭṭhānam oja ṭṭhamakam samuṭṭhāpeti tatra api  evam catassaḥ vā pañca vā pavattiyaḥ ghaṭeti evam tāva kamma ja rūpassa
translated: Temperature-born matter originated by kamma is the temperature-born matter that has reached presence among the kinds of matter originated by kamma. It generates the octad-with-nutriment-derived-matter-as-eighth. There too

original: nibbatti passitabbā.
analyzed: nibbatti passitabbā
translated: the temperature generates another octad-with-nutriment-derived-matter-as-eighth. So it goes on for four or five occurrences. This is how the occurrence of matter originated by kamma should be seen.

original: 702. Cittajesupi cittaṃ, cittasamuṭṭhānaṃ, cittapaccayaṃ, cittapaccayaāhārasamuṭṭhānaṃ, cittapaccayautusamuṭṭhānanti esa vibhāgo veditabbo. Tattha cittaṃ nāma ekūnanavuticittāni.
analyzed: citta jesu pi cittam citta samuṭṭhānam citta paccayam citta paccaya āhāra samuṭṭhānam citta paccaya otu samuṭṭhānam ti esa vibhāgaḥ veditabbaḥ tattha cittam nāma ekūnanavuti cittāni
translated: . As regards the consciousness-born kinds, the analysis should be understood thus: consciousness, consciousness-originated, consciousness- condition, consciousness-condition-food-originated, and consciousness- condition-temperature-originated. Herein, consciousness is the eighty-nine kinds of consciousness.🔽Among them, thirty-two kinds of consciousness,

original: Tesu dvattiṃsa cittāni, chabbīsekūnavīsati;🔽Soḷasa rūpiriyāpathaviññattijanakā matā.
analyzed: tesu dvattiṃsa cittāni chabbīsa ikūnavīsati 🔽soḷasa rūpa iriyāpatha viññatti janakā matā
translated: Twenty-six kinds, and sixteen,🔽Are held to generate respectively

original: Kāmāvacarato hi aṭṭha kusalāni, dvādasākusalāni, manodhātuvajjā dasa kiriyā, kusalakiriyato
analyzed: kāma avacarataḥ hi aṭṭha kusalāni dvādasa akusalāni manaḥ dhātu vajjā dasa kiriyā kusala kiriyato
translated: For in the sense sphere there are eight kinds of profitable, twelve kinds of unprofitable, ten kinds of functional except for the mind element and the mind-consciousness element, and the four of the immaterial sphere.

original: dve abhiññācittānīti dvattiṃsa cittāni rūpaṃ, iriyāpathaṃ, viññattiñca janenti. Vipākavajjāni
analyzed: dve abhiññā cittāni iti dvattiṃsa cittāni rūpam iriyāpatham viññattim ca janenti vipāka vajjāni
translated: For thirty-two kinds of consciousness generate materiality, bodily- intimation, and verbal-intimation: the eight kinds of profitable consciousness belonging to the sense sphere, the twelve kinds of unprofitable consciousness, and the ten kinds of functional consciousness except the mind element .🔽The remaining twenty-five kinds of consciousness generate materiality and bodily-intimation, but not verbal-intimation: the twenty kinds of resultant consciousness except the mind element ;

original: sesadasarūpāvacarāni, aṭṭha arūpāvacarāni, aṭṭha lokuttaracittānīti chabbīsati cittāni
analyzed: sesa dasa rūpāvacarāni aṭṭha arūpāvacarāni aṭṭha lokuttara cittāni iti chabbīsati cittāni
translated: the eight kinds of sense-sphere functional consciousness; the eight kinds of fine-material-sphere consciousness; and the eight supramundane kinds of consciousness.

original: rūpaṃ, iriyāpathañca janayanti, na viññattiṃ. Kāmāvacare dasa bhavaṅgacittāni, rūpāvacare
analyzed: rūpam iriyāpatham ca janayanti na viññattim kāmāvacare dasa bhavaṅga cittāni rūpāvacare
translated: Nineteen kinds of consciousness generate materiality only, not bodily-intimation or verbal-intimation: the ten kinds of sense-sphere consciousness belonging to the life-continuum ;

original: pañca, tisso manodhātuyo, ekā vipākāhetukamanoviññāṇadhātusomanassasahagatāti ekūnavīsati
analyzed: pañca tissaḥ manaḥ dhātuyaḥ ekā vipāka ahetuka manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu somanassa sahagatā ati ekūnavīsati
translated: the five kinds of fine-material-sphere consciousness; the three mind elements; and the single kind of resultant mind-consciousness element that is profitable-result and is accompanied by joy .

original: cittāni rūpameva janayanti, na iriyāpathaṃ, na viññattiṃ. Dvepañcaviññāṇāni, sabbasattānaṃ
analyzed: cittāni rūpam eva janayanti na iriyāpatham na viññattim dve pañca viññāṇāni sabba sattānam
translated: Sixteen kinds of consciousness generate neither materiality nor intimation:

original: paṭisandhicittaṃ, khīṇāsavānaṃ cuticittaṃ, cattāri āruppavipākānīti soḷasa cittāni
analyzed: paṭisandhi cittam khīṇāsavānam cuti cittam cattāri āruppa vipākāni iti soḷasa cittāni
translated: the five consciousnesses ; the rebirth-linking consciousness of all beings; the death consciousness of those whose cankers are destroyed; and the four immaterial-sphere resultants.

original: neva rūpaṃ janayanti, na iriyāpathaṃ, na viññattiṃ. Yāni cettha rūpaṃ janenti, tāni
analyzed: na iva rūpam janayanti na iriyāpatham na viññattim yāni ca ittha rūpam janenti tāni
translated: They do not generate materiality, posture, or intimation. But those that do generate materiality do so

original: na ṭhitikkhaṇe, bhaṅgakkhaṇe vā, tadā hi cittaṃ dubbalaṃ hoti. Uppādakkhaṇe pana
analyzed: na ṭhiti kkhaṇe bhaṅga kkhaṇe vā tadā hi cittam dubbalam hoti uppāda kkhaṇe pana
translated: not at the moment of their presence or at the moment of their dissolution, for then the consciousness is weak. But at the moment of their arising

original: balavaṃ, tasmā taṃ tadā purejātaṃ vatthuṃ nissāya rūpaṃ samuṭṭhāpeti.
analyzed: balavam tasmai tam tadā purejātam vatthum nissāya rūpam samuṭṭhāpeti
translated: it is strong, and so it generates materiality in dependence on the prenascent physical heart-basis.

original: Cittasamuṭṭhānaṃ nāma tayo arūpino khandhā, “saddanavakaṃ, kāyaviññatti, vacīviññatti,
analyzed: citta samuṭṭhānam nāma tayo arūpino khandhāḥ sadda navakam kāya viññatti vacī viññatti
translated: “Derived from consciousness” is the three immaterial aggregates and the seventeen kinds of materiality, namely, the sound ennead, bodily intimation, verbal intimation,

original: ākāsadhātu, lahutā, mudutā, kammaññatā, upacayo, santatī”ti sattarasavidhaṃ rūpañca.🔽Cittapaccayaṃ nāma “pacchājātā cittacetasikā dhammā purejātassa imassa kāyassā”ti
analyzed: ākāsadhātu lahu tā mudu tā kammañña tā upacayaḥ santati iti sattarasavidham rūpañca  citta paccayam nāma pacchājātāḥ citta cetasikāḥ dhammāḥ purejātassa imassa kāyassa ati
translated: space element, lightness, malleability, wieldiness, growth, and continuity.

original: evaṃ vuttaṃ catusamuṭṭhānarūpaṃ. Cittapaccayaāhārasamuṭṭhānaṃ nāma cittasamuṭṭhānarūpesu
analyzed: evam vuttam catu samuṭṭhāna rūpam citta paccaya āhāra samuṭṭhānam nāma citta samuṭṭhāna rūpesu
translated: “Derived from consciousness and nutriment” is the materiality of the fourfold origin that is described thus: “Postnascent states of consciousness and its concomitants are a condition, as postnascent condition, for this prenascent body” .

original: ṭhānappattā ojā aññaṃ ojaṭṭhamakaṃ samuṭṭhāpeti, evaṃ dve tisso pavattiyo ghaṭeti.
analyzed: ṭhāna ppattā ojā aññam ojaṭṭhamakam samuṭṭhāpeti evam dve tissaḥ pavattiyaḥ ghaṭeti
translated: “Derived from consciousness and nutriment and temperature” is the nutriment essence that has reached presence in the materiality derived from consciousness and generates another octad with nutriment as its basis, and so on, thus making two or three occurrences.

original: Cittapaccayautusamuṭṭhānaṃ nāma cittasamuṭṭhāno utu ṭhānappatto aññaṃ ojaṭṭhamakaṃ
analyzed: citta paccaya otu samuṭṭhānam nāma citta samuṭṭhānaḥ utu ṭhāna ppattaḥ aññam oja ṭṭhamakam
translated: Arisen by temperature originating from consciousness: temperature originating from consciousness, having reached presence, originates another octad-with-nutritive-essence.

original: samuṭṭhāpeti, evaṃ dve tisso pavattiyo ghaṭeti. Evaṃ cittajarūpassa nibbatti passitabbā.
analyzed: samuṭṭhāpeti evam dve tissaḥ pavattiyaḥ ghaṭeti evam citta ja rūpassa nibbatti passitabbā
translated: Thus it combines two or three occurrences. This is how the generation of materiality derived from consciousness should be seen.

original: 703. Āhārajesupi āhāro, āhārasamuṭṭhānaṃ, āhārapaccayaṃ, āhārapaccayaāhārasamuṭṭhānaṃ,
analyzed: āhāra jesu pi āhāraḥ āhāra samuṭṭhānam āhāra paccayam āhāra paccaya āhāra samuṭṭhānam
translated: In the case of the nutriment-born kinds too, the exposition should be understood thus: nutriment, what is originated by nutriment, what has nutriment as its condition, what is originated by nutriment and has nutriment as its condition,

original: āhārapaccayautusamuṭṭhānanti esa vibhāgo veditabbo. Tattha āhāro nāma kabaḷīkāro🔽āhāro. Āhārasamuṭṭhānaṃ nāma upādiṇṇaṃ kammajarūpaṃ paccayaṃ labhitvā tattha patiṭṭhāya
analyzed: āhāra paccaya otu samuṭṭhānanti esa vibhāgaḥ veditabbo tattha āhāraḥ nāma kabaḷīkāro  āhāraḥ āhāra samuṭṭhānam nāma upādiṇṇam kamma ja rūpam paccayam labhitvā tattha patiṭṭhāya
translated: what is originated by temperature and has nutriment as its condition. Herein, nutriment is physical food as nutriment.

original: ṭhānappattāya ojāya samuṭṭhāpitaṃ ojaṭṭhamakaṃ, ākāsadhātu, lahutā, mudutā, kammaññatā,🔽upacayo, santatīti cuddasavidhaṃ rūpaṃ. Āhārapaccayaṃ nāma “kabaḷīkāro āhāro imassa
analyzed: ṭhāna ppattāya ojāya samuṭṭhāpitam oja ṭhamakam ākāsa dhātu lahu tā mudu tā kammañña tā  upacayaḥ santati iti cuddasavidham rūpam āhāra paccayam nāma kabaḷīkāraḥ āhāraḥ imassa
translated: What is originated by nutriment is the fourteenfold materiality, namely, the four primary elements, and the tenfold materiality that originates in dependence on the four primary elements thus: the octad-with-nutritive-essence originated by the nutritive essence that has reached presence and is based on the primary elements that have obtained presence, and the space element, and the four characteristics beginning with plasticity.🔽What has nutriment as its condition is the four primary elements and the four derived materialities originated by them, which are called “The physical nutriment is for this body a condition by nutriment condition” .

original: kāyassa āhārapaccayena paccayo”ti evaṃ vuttaṃ catusamuṭṭhānarūpaṃ. Āhārapaccayaāhārasamuṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: kāyassa āhāra paccayena paccayaḥ ti evam vuttam catu samuṭṭhāna rūpam āhāra paccaya āhāra samuṭṭhānam
translated: What is originated by nutriment and has nutriment as its condition is the fourteenfold materiality already mentioned.

original: nāma āhārasamuṭṭhānesu rūpesu ṭhānappattā ojā aññaṃ ojaṭṭhamakaṃ samuṭṭhāpeti, tatrāpi🔽ojā aññanti evaṃ dasadvādasavāre pavattiṃ ghaṭeti. Ekadivasaṃ paribhuttāhāro sattāhampi🔽upatthambheti. Dibbā pana ojā ekamāsaṃ dvemāsampi upatthambheti. Mātarā paribhuttāhāropi🔽dārakassa sarīraṃ pharitvā rūpaṃ samuṭṭhāpeti. Sarīre makkhitāhāropi rūpaṃ samuṭṭhāpeti.
analyzed: nāma āhāra samuṭṭhānesu rūpesu ṭhāna ppattā ojā aññam oja ṭṭhamakam samuṭṭhāpeti tatra api  evam dasa dvādasa vāre pavattim ghaṭeti eka divasam paribhutta āhāraḥ satta aham pi  upatthambheti dibbā pana ojā eka māsam dve māsam pi upatthambheti mātarā paribhutta āhāraḥ api  dārakassa sarīram pharitvā rūpam samuṭṭhāpeti sarīre makkhita āhāraḥ api rūpam samuṭṭhāpeti
translated: Nutriment-originated materiality is the nutriment-originated materiality that has reached presence. The nutriment-originated materiality that has reached presence generates another octad with nutriment as eighth. The nutriment-originated materiality in that generates another octad with nutriment as eighth. Thus it goes on for ten or twelve turns. Nutriment eaten one day maintains the body for seven days. But divine nutriment maintains for a month or two months. Nutriment eaten by the mother and converted into blood and lymph generates materiality in the child’s body. Nutriment smeared on the body generates materiality.🔽🔽

original: Kammajāhāro upādiṇṇakāhāro nāma. Sopi ṭhānappatto rūpaṃ samuṭṭhāpeti, tatrāpi ojā🔽aññaṃ samuṭṭhāpetīti evaṃ catasso vā pañca vā pavattiyo ghaṭeti. Āhārapaccayautusamuṭṭhānaṃ🔽nāma āhārasamuṭṭhānā tejodhātu ṭhānappattā utusamuṭṭhānaṃ ojaṭṭhamakaṃ samuṭṭhāpeti.
analyzed: kamma ja āhāro upādiṇṇaka āhāraḥ nāma saḥ api ṭhāna ppattaḥ rūpam samuṭṭhāpeti tatra api ojā 🔽aññam samuṭṭhāpeti iti evam catassaḥ vā pañca vā pavattiyaḥ ghaṭeti āhāra paccaya otu samuṭṭhānam 🔽nāma āhāra samuṭṭhānā tejodhātu ṭhāna ppattā utu samuṭṭhānam ojaṭṭhamakam samuṭṭhāpeti

original: Tatrāyaṃ āhāro āhārasamuṭṭhānānaṃ janako hutvā paccayo hoti, sesānaṃ nissayāhāraatthiavigatavasenāti
analyzed: tatra ayam āhāraḥ āhāra samuṭṭhānānam janakaḥ hutvā paccayaḥ hoti sesānam nissaya āhāra atthi avigata vasena ati
translated: Herein, nutriment is a condition for what is originated by nutriment as its progenitor. It is a condition for the rest as support, presence, non-disappearance.

original: evaṃ āhārajarūpassa nibbatti passitabbā.🔽704. Utujesupi utu, utusamuṭṭhānaṃ, utupaccayaṃ, utupaccayautusamuṭṭhānaṃ, utupaccayaāhārasamuṭṭhānanti🔽esa vibhāgo veditabbo. Tattha utu nāma catusamuṭṭhānā tejodhātu, uṇhautu sītautūti
analyzed: evam āhāra ja rūpassa nibbatti passitabbā  utu jesu pi utu utu samuṭṭhānam utu paccayam utu paccaya otu samuṭṭhānam utu paccaya āhāra samuṭṭhānanti  esa vibhāgaḥ veditabbo tattha utu nāma catu samuṭṭhānā tejaḥ dhātu uṇhautu sītautu uti
translated: This is how the arising of the materiality originated by nutriment should be seen.🔽As regards that originated by temperature, etc., the analysis should be understood thus: temperature, what is originated by temperature, what is a condition by temperature, what is originated by temperature and is a condition by temperature, what is originated by nutriment and is a condition by temperature.

original: evaṃ panesa duvidho hoti. Utusamuṭṭhānaṃ nāma catusamuṭṭhāno utu upādiṇṇakaṃ paccayaṃ🔽labhitvā ṭhānappatto sarīre rūpaṃ samuṭṭhāpeti. Taṃ saddanavakaṃ, ākāsadhātu, lahutā,
analyzed: evam pana esa duvidhaḥ hoti utu samuṭṭhānam nāma catu samuṭṭhānaḥ utu upādiṇṇakam paccayam  labhitvā ṭhāna ppattaḥ sarīre rūpam samuṭṭhāpeti tam sadda navakam ākāsadhātu lahu tā
translated: Herein, temperature is the fire element that has four origins, and it is twofold as hot temperature and cold temperature.🔽But it is threefold as the temperature of the earth, etc., and as that originated by kamma, etc.

original: mudutā, kammaññatā, upacayo, santatīti pannarasavidhaṃ hoti. Utupaccayaṃ nāma utu
analyzed: mudu tā kammañña tā upacayaḥ santati iti pannarasavidham hoti utu paccayam nāma utu
translated: What is originated by temperature is the materiality originated by the temperature that has four origins, which occurs in the physical basis when it has obtained a conascent condition. It is fifteenfold, namely, the sound ennead, space element, lightness, malleability, wieldiness, growth, and continuity.

original: catusamuṭṭhānikarūpānaṃ pavattiyā ca vināsassa ca paccayo hoti. Utupaccayautusamuṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: catu samuṭṭhānika rūpānam pavattiyāḥ ca vināsassa ca paccayaḥ hoti utu paccaya otu samuṭṭhānam
translated: What is a condition by temperature is a condition for the occurrence and dissolution of the fourfold temperature.🔽What is originated by temperature and is a condition by temperature is temperature.

original: nāma utusamuṭṭhānā tejodhātu ṭhānappattā aññaṃ ojaṭṭhamakaṃ samuṭṭhāpeti, tatrāpi
analyzed: nāma utu samuṭṭhānā tejaḥ dhātu ṭhāna ppattā aññam oja ṭṭhamakam samuṭṭhāpeti tatra api
translated: The materiality originated by temperature is the temperature itself, which is the materiality originated by temperature. The temperature that is the support for the materiality originated by temperature generates another octad of which it is the primary element.

original: utu aññanti evaṃ dīghampi addhānaṃ anupādiṇṇapakkhe ṭhatvāpi utusamuṭṭhānaṃ pavattatiyeva.
analyzed: evam dīgham pi addhānam an upādiṇṇa pakkhe ṭhatvā api utu samuṭṭhānam pavattatiyā iva
translated: And the temperature in that is the support for the materiality originated by temperature that it generates, and that generates another octad of which it is the primary element. So it goes on occurring for a long time, still belonging to the past, in the past phase of the continuity.

original: Utupaccayaāhārasamuṭṭhānaṃ nāma utusamuṭṭhānā ṭhānappattā ojā aññaṃ ojaṭṭhamakaṃ
analyzed: utu paccaya āhāra samuṭṭhānam nāma utu samuṭṭhānā ṭhāna ppattā ojā aññam ojaṭṭhamakam
translated: The materiality originated by nutriment is the nutriment itself, which is the materiality originated by nutriment. The nutriment that is the support for the materiality originated by nutriment generates another octad of which it is the primary element.

original: samuṭṭhāpeti, tatrāpi ojā aññanti evaṃ dasadvādasavāre pavattiṃ ghaṭeti. Tatrāyaṃ
analyzed: samuṭṭhāpeti tatra api ojā evam dasa dvādasa vāre pavattim ghaṭeti tatra ayam
translated: And the nutriment in that is the support for the materiality originated by nutriment that it generates, and that generates another octad of which it is the primary element. So it goes on occurring for ten or twelve turns.

original: utu utusamuṭṭhānānaṃ janako hutvā paccayo hoti, sesānaṃ nissayaatthiavigatavasenāti
analyzed: utu utu samuṭṭhānānam janakaḥ hutvā paccayaḥ hoti sesānam nissaya atthi avigata vasena ati
translated: Herein, temperature is a condition for the materiality originated by temperature as decisive-support condition, and for the rest as support, absence of obstruction, and presence.

original: evaṃ utujarūpassa nibbatti passitabbā. Evañhi rūpassa nibbattiṃ passanto kālena rūpaṃ sammasati nāma.
analyzed: evam utu ja rūpassa nibbatti passitabbā evam hi rūpassa nibbattim passantaḥ kālena rūpam sammasati nāma
translated: So the occurrence of materiality originated by temperature should be seen. One who sees the occurrence of materiality in this way is said to “comprehend materiality by groups” .

original: Arūpanibbattipassanākārakathā
analyzed: arūpa nibbatti passanā kāra kathā
translated: The way of seeing the occurrence of immaterial things

original: 705. Yathā ca rūpaṃ sammasantena rūpassa, evaṃ arūpaṃ sammasantenapi arūpassa nibbatti passitabbā. Sā ca kho ekāsīti lokiyacittuppādavaseneva.
analyzed: yathā ca rūpam sammasantena rūpassa evam arūpam sammasantena api arūpassa nibbatti passitabbā sā ca kho ekā asi iti lokiya cittuppāda vasena iva
translated: And just as one who comprehends materiality does so by seeing the occurrence of materiality, so too one who comprehends immateriality does so by seeing the occurrence of immateriality. And that is only in the case of the eighty-nine kinds of mundane consciousness.

original: Seyyathidaṃ – idañhi arūpaṃ nāma purimabhave āyūhitakammavasena paṭisandhiyaṃ tāva🔽ekūnavīsaticittuppādappabhedaṃ nibbattati. Nibbattanākāro panassa paṭiccasamuppādaniddese
analyzed: seyyathīdam idam hi arūpam nāma purima bhave āyūhita kamma vasena  ekūnavīsati cittuppāda ppabhedam nibbattati nibbattana ākāraḥ panassa paṭiccasamuppāda niddese
translated: That is to say, this so-called immateriality is generated in the rebirth-linking consciousness, which is of the kind already described as occurring nineteen times in the cognitive series. But the way in which it is generated should be understood in the way already stated in the description of dependent origination .

original: vuttanayeneva veditabbo. Tadeva paṭisandhicittassa anantaracittato paṭṭhāya bhavaṅgavasena,
analyzed: vutta nayena iva veditabbo tat eva paṭisandhi cittassa anantara cittataḥ paṭṭhāya bhavaṅga vasena
translated: That same rebirth-linking consciousness, next to which the life-continuum arises, and at the end of which the death consciousness occurs, is also called “bhavanga” .

original: āyupariyosāne cutivasena. Yaṃ tattha kāmāvacaraṃ, taṃ chasu dvāresu balavārammaṇe tadārammaṇavasena.
analyzed: āyu pariyosāne cuti vasena yam tattha kāmāvacaram tam chasu dvāresu balava ārammaṇe tad ārammaṇa vasena
translated: The kamma-resultant consciousness of the sense sphere occurs in the six doors as object-determining consciousness when there is a powerful object,

original: Pavatte pana asambhinnattā cakkhussa āpāthagatattā rūpānaṃ ālokasannissitaṃ manasikārahetukaṃ🔽cakkhuviññāṇaṃ nibbattati saddhiṃ sampayuttadhammehi. Cakkhupasādassa hi ṭhitikkhaṇe
analyzed: pavatte pana asambhinna ttā cakkhussa āpātha gata ttā rūpānaṃ āloka sannissitam manasikāra hetukam  cakkhu viññāṇam nibbattati saddhim sampayutta dhammehi cakkhu pasādassa hi ṭhiti kkhaṇe
translated: but in the course of an existence it does not occur in the eye door because the eye door is not uninterrupted like the other doors.🔽When a visible datum comes into the eye’s focus, eye-consciousness arises with the appropriate concomitants, supported by light, and caused by inattention.🔽For the visible datum impinges on the eye at the moment of the eye’s presence,

original: ṭhitippattameva rūpaṃ cakkhuṃ ghaṭṭeti. Tasmiṃ ghaṭṭite dvikkhattuṃ bhavaṅgaṃ uppajjitvā
analyzed: ṭhiti pattam eva rūpam cakkhum ghaṭṭeti tasmin ghaṭṭite dvi khattum bhavaṅgam uppajjitvā
translated: and when it has done so, the life-continuum ceases twice, and then rebirth-linking consciousness occurs.

original: nirujjhati. Tato tasmiṃyeva ārammaṇe kiriyamanodhātu āvajjanakiccaṃ sādhayamānā uppajjati.
analyzed: nirujjhati tatas tasmin yeva ārammaṇe kiriya manaḥ dhātu āvajjana kiccam sādhayamānā uppajjati
translated: and then the functional mind element arises in that same object accomplishing the function of adverting.

original: Tadanantaraṃ tadeva rūpaṃ passamānaṃ kusalavipākaṃ akusalavipākaṃ vā cakkhuviññāṇaṃ.🔽Tato tadeva rūpaṃ sampaṭicchamānā vipākamanodhātu. Tato tadeva rūpaṃ santīrayamānā
analyzed: tad anantaram tat eva rūpam passamānam kusala vipākam akusala vipākam vā cakkhu viññāṇam  tatas tat eva rūpam vipāka manaḥ dhātu tatas tat eva rūpam santi īrayamānā
translated: Next to that, eye-consciousness, which is either profitable resultant or unprofitable resultant, sees that same visible datum.🔽Next to that, the resultant mind element receives that same visible datum. Next to that, the resultant root-causeless mind-consciousness element investigates that same visible datum.

original: vipākāhetukamanoviññāṇadhātu. Tato tadeva rūpaṃ vavatthāpayamānā kiriyāhetukamanoviññāṇadhātu🔽upekkhāsahagatā. Tato paraṃ kāmāvacarakusalākusalakiriyacittesu ekaṃ vā upekkhāsahagatāhetukaṃ
analyzed: vipāka ahetuka manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu tatas tat eva rūpam vavatthāpayamānā kiriyā hetuka manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu  upekkhā sahagatā tato param kāmāvacara kusala akusala kiriya cittesu ekam vā upekkhā sahagatā ahetukam
translated: Next to that, the functional root-causeless mind-consciousness element determines that same visible datum accompanied by equanimity.🔽Next to that, either one of the two kinds of root-causeless mind-consciousness element accompanied by equanimity occurs in one of the profitable, unprofitable, or functional consciousnesses of the sense sphere.

original: cittaṃ pañca satta vā javanāni. Tato kāmāvacarasattānaṃ ekādasasu tadārammaṇacittesu
analyzed: cittam pañca satta vā javanāni tatas kāmāvacara sattānam ekādasasu tad ārammaṇa cittesu
translated: Then there are either one or five impulsions of the kind already stated. Next to that, in the case of those of the sense sphere, there are eleven receiving consciousnesses of the kind already stated.

original: javanānurūpaṃ yaṃkiñci tadārammaṇanti. Esa nayo sesadvāresupi. Manodvāre pana mahaggatacittānipi
analyzed: javana anurūpam yaṃkiñci manaḥ dvāre pana mahaggata cittāni pi
translated: So there are impulsions corresponding to the receiving consciousnesses. This is the method in the case of the other doors. But in the case of the mind door, consciousnesses of the fine-material sphere and immaterial sphere also occur.

original: uppajjantīti. Evaṃ chasu dvāresu arūpassa nibbatti passitabbā. Evañhi arūpassa nibbattiṃ
analyzed: uppajjanti iti evam chasu dvāresu arūpassa nibbatti passitabbā evam hi arūpassa nibbattim
translated: For when he sees the generation of the immaterial in this way,

original: passanto kālena arūpaṃ sammasati nāma.
analyzed: passantaḥ kālena arūpam sammasati nāma
translated: then he is said to “comprehend the immaterial by means of the temporal” .🔽Having thus comprehended materiality and the immaterial by means of the temporal, he should go on to apply the three characteristics in due succession.

original: Evaṃ kālena rūpaṃ kālena arūpaṃ sammasitvāpi tilakkhaṇaṃ āropetvā anukkamena paṭipajjamāno eko paññābhāvanaṃ sampādeti.
analyzed: evam kālena rūpam kālena arūpam sammasitvā api ti lakkhaṇam āropetvā anukkamena paṭipajjamānaḥ ekaḥ paññā bhāvanam sampādeti
translated: The development of understanding is accomplished by one who practices in this way.

original: Rūpasattakasammasanakathā
analyzed: rūpa sattaka sammasana kathā
translated: Comprehension of the seven kinds of materiality

original: 706. Aparo rūpasattakaarūpasattakavasena tilakkhaṇaṃ āropetvā saṅkhāre sammasati.
analyzed: aparaḥ rūpa sattaka arūpa sattaka vasena ti lakkhaṇam āropetvā saṅkhāre sammasati
translated: Another comprehends formations by applying the three characteristics in the case of the seven kinds of materiality and the seven kinds of immateriality.

original: Tattha ādānanikkhepanato, vayovuḍḍhatthaṅgamato, āhāramayato, utumayato, kammajato,🔽cittasamuṭṭhānato, dhammatārūpatoti imehi ākārehi āropetvā sammasanto rūpasattakavasena
analyzed: tattha ādāna nikkhepanataḥ vayaḥ vuḍḍhatthaṅgamataḥ āhāra mayataḥ utu mayataḥ kamma jataḥ  citta samuṭṭhānataḥ dhamma tā rūpato ti imehi ākārehi āropetvā sammasantaḥ rūpa sattaka vasena
translated: Herein, he comprehends by applying the characteristics in the following seven ways: as to assuming and rejecting, as to ageing, as to change of temperature, as to nutriment, as to kamma-born,🔽as to consciousness-originated, and as to natural materiality.

original: āropetvā sammasati nāma. Tenāhu porāṇā –
analyzed: āropetvā sammasati nāma tena āhu porāṇā
translated: He comprehends by applying the characteristics in the case of the seven kinds of materiality in this way. Hence the Ancients said:

original: “Ādānanikkhepanato, vayovuḍḍhatthagāmito;
analyzed: ādāna nikkhepanataḥ vayaḥ vuḍḍhattha gāmitaḥ
translated: “By assuming and rejecting, by ageing, by change of temperature,

original: Āhārato ca ututo, kammato cāpi cittato;
analyzed: āhārataḥ ca ututaḥ kammataḥ ca api cittataḥ
translated: By nutriment, and by kamma, and also by consciousness,

original: Dhammatārūpato satta, vitthārena vipassatī”ti.
analyzed: dhamma tā rūpato satta vitthārena vipassati iti
translated: And by naturalness, he sees the seven kinds of materiality in detail.”

original: Tattha ādānanti paṭisandhi. Nikkhepananti cuti. Iti yogāvacaro imehi ādānanikkhepehi
analyzed: tattha ādānanti paṭisandhi nikkhepananti cuti iti yoga avacaraḥ imehi ādāna nikkhepehi
translated: Herein, taking up is rebirth-linking. Putting down is death.

original: ekaṃ vassasataṃ paricchinditvā saṅkhāresu tilakkhaṇaṃ āropeti. Kathaṃ? Etthantare
analyzed: ekam vassa satam paricchinditvā saṅkhāresu ti lakkhaṇam āropeti katham etthantare
translated: So the meditator defines a hundred years by these takings up and puttings down, and he attributes the three characteristics to formations in this way:🔽“In this period all formations are impermanent,

original: sabbe saṅkhārā aniccā. Kasmā? Uppādavayavattito, vipariṇāmato, tāvakālikato, niccapaṭikkhepato🔽ca. Yasmā pana uppannā saṅkhārā ṭhitiṃ pāpuṇanti, ṭhitiyaṃ jarāya kilamanti, jaraṃ🔽patvā avassaṃ bhijjanti, tasmā abhiṇhasampaṭipīḷanato, dukkhamato dukkhavatthuto,
analyzed: sabbe saṅkhārāḥ aniccā kasmā uppāda vaya vattitaḥ vipariṇāmataḥ tāvakālikataḥ nicca paṭikkhepato  ca yasmā pana uppannā saṅkhārāḥ ṭhitim pāpuṇanti ṭhitiyam jarāya kilamanti jaram  patvā a vassam bhijjanti tasmai abhiṇha sampaṭipīḍanataḥ dukkhamataḥ dukkha vatthutaḥ
translated: why? Because they occur as arising and vanishing, because they occur as changing, because they occur as lasting only a moment, because they are denied as permanent.

original: sukhapaṭikkhepato ca dukkhā. Yasmā ca “uppannā saṅkhārā ṭhitiṃ mā pāpuṇantu, ṭhānappattā
analyzed: sukha paṭikkhepato ca dukkhāḥ yasmā ca uppannā saṅkhārāḥ ṭhitim mā pāpuṇantu ṭhāna ppattā
translated: But because formations that have arisen reach occurrence, they are exhausted by ageing in occurrence, and they break up without fail when they have reached ageing, therefore they are suffering because of oppression by frequent renewal, because of being the basis for suffering, because of being denied as pleasant.

original: mā jīrantu, jarappattā mā bhijjantū”ti imesu tīsu ṭhānesu kassaci vasavattibhāvo
analyzed: mā jīrantu jara pattāḥ mā bhijjantu iti imesu tīsu ṭhānesu kassaci vasa vatti bhāvaḥ
translated: And because there is no being who can say to them, ‘Arisen formations, do not reach occurrence! Occurrences, do not age! Aged ones, do not break up!’ in these three instances,🔽therefore they are not-self because of being unmanageable.

original: natthi, suññā tena vasavattanākārena, tasmā suññato, assāmikato, avasavattito, attapaṭikkhepato ca anattāti.🔽707. Evaṃ ādānanikkhepanavasena vassasataparicchinne rūpe tilakkhaṇaṃ āropetvā tato🔽paraṃ vayovuḍḍhatthaṅgamato āropeti. Tattha vayovuḍḍhatthaṅgamo nāma vayavasena vuḍḍhassa
analyzed: natthi suññā tena vasa vattana ākārena tasmā suññataḥ a ssāmikataḥ a vasa vattitaḥ atta paṭikkhepato ca an attā ati  evam ādāna nikkhepana vasena vassa sata paricchinne rūpe ti lakkhaṇam āropetvā tatas  param vayaḥ vuḍḍha tthaṅgamataḥ āropeti tattha vayaḥ vuḍḍha tthaṅgamaḥ nāma vaya vasena vuḍḍhassa
translated: it is void of that sort of owner, that sort of master, that sort of self, that sort of designation.🔽Having thus imposed the three characteristics on materiality delimited by a hundred years in the way beginning “What is taken up … ” he should impose them next as “ subject to destruction, subject to fall, subject to fading away, subject to cessation. ” Herein, destruction is the breakup of the aggregates. Fall is the falling of the aggregates from the plane of existence reached. Fading away is the fading away of the continuity of aggregates. Cessation is the cessation of the aggregates.🔽

original: vaḍḍhitassa rūpassa atthaṅgamo. Tassa vasena tilakkhaṇaṃ āropetīti attho.🔽Kathaṃ? So tameva vassasataṃ paṭhamavayena majjhimavayena pacchimavayenāti tīhi vayehi🔽paricchindati. Tattha ādito tettiṃsa vassāni paṭhamavayo nāma. Tato catuttiṃsa majjhimavayo🔽nāma. Tato tettiṃsa pacchimavayo nāmāti. Iti imehi tīhi vayehi paricchinditvā, “paṭhamavaye
analyzed: vaḍḍhitassa rūpassa atthaṅgamaḥ tassa vasena tilakkhaṇam āropeti iti attho 🔽katham saḥ tam eva vassa satam paṭhama vayena majjhima vayena pacchima vayena ati tīhi vayehi 🔽paricchindati tattha āditas tettiṃsa vassāni paṭhamavayaḥ nāma tato catuttiṃsa majjhimavayaḥ 🔽nāma nāma ati iti imehi tīhi vayehi paricchinditvā paṭhama vaye
translated: It is empty of self, of what belongs to self, of a master, of a possessor, of a being, of a person, of a man, of a human, of a human being, of a human person, of a human individual, of a
