original: pavattaṃ rūpaṃ majjhimavayaṃ appatvā tattheva nirujjhati, tasmā taṃ aniccaṃ. Yadaniccaṃ,
analyzed: pavattam rūpam majjhima vayam ap patvā tattha iva nirujjhati tasmā tam aniccam yat aniccam
translated: The materiality occurring in the middle stage ceases there without reaching the last stage, thus it is impermanent.🔽What is impermanent is painful. What is painful is not self.

original: taṃ dukkhaṃ. Yaṃ dukkhaṃ, tadanattā. Majjhimavaye pavattarūpampi pacchimavayaṃ appatvā🔽tattheva nirujjhati, tasmā tampi aniccaṃ dukkhamanattā. Pacchimavaye tettiṃsa vassāni
analyzed: tat dukkham yat dukkham tad anattā majjhima vaye pavatta rūpam pi pacchima vayam a patvā  tattha iva nirujjhati tasmā aniccam dukkham anattā pacchima vaye tettiṃsa vassāni
translated: The materiality occurring in the last stage ceases there without reaching the next birth, thus it is impermanent, painful, not self.

original: pavattarūpampi maraṇato paraṃ gamanasamatthaṃ nāma natthi, tasmā tampi aniccaṃ dukkhamanattā”ti
analyzed: pavatta rūpam pi maraṇataḥ param gamana samattham nāma natthi tasmā tam pi aniccam dukkham anattā ti
translated: The materiality occurring in the last thirty years of the last stage has no power to go beyond death, thus it is impermanent, painful, not self.”

original: tilakkhaṇaṃ āropeti.
analyzed: tilakkhaṇam āropeti
translated: He attributes the three characteristics to it thus.

original: 708. Evaṃ paṭhamavayādivasena vayovuḍḍhatthaṅgamato tilakkhaṇaṃ āropetvā puna “mandadasakaṃ,🔽khiḍḍādasakaṃ, vaṇṇadasakaṃ, baladasakaṃ, paññādasakaṃ, hānidasakaṃ, pabbhāradasakaṃ,
analyzed: evam paṭhama vayā ādi vasena ti lakkhaṇam āropetvā puna manda dasakam  khiḍḍā dasakam vaṇṇa dasakam bala dasakam paññā dasakam hāni dasakam pabbhāra dasakam
translated: Having attributed the three characteristics to materiality by the method of the passing away of what grows old in each stage, he again attributes the three characteristics to it by the method of the passing away of what grows old in the ten decades.

original: vaṅkadasakaṃ, momūhadasakaṃ, sayanadasaka”nti imesaṃ dasannaṃ dasakānaṃ vasena vayovuḍḍhatthaṅgamato
analyzed: vaṅka dasakam momūha dasakam sayana dasakanti imesam dasannam dasakānam vasena vayaḥ vuḍḍhatthaṅgamato
translated: The ten decades are the decade of the slow, the decade of play, the decade of beauty, the decade of strength, the decade of understanding, the decade of vanity, the decade of indulgence, the decade of crookedness, the decade of stupidity, and the decade of grey hairs.

original: tilakkhaṇaṃ āropeti.
analyzed: tilakkhaṇam āropeti
translated: He attributes the three characteristics to materiality by the method of the passing away of what grows old in these ten decades.

original: Tattha dasakesu tāva vassasatajīvino puggalassa paṭhamāni dasa vassāni mandadasakaṃ
analyzed: tattha dasakesu tāva vassa sata jīvinaḥ puggalassa paṭhamāni dasa vassāni manda dasakam
translated: Herein, firstly, in the case of a person who lives a hundred years, the first ten years are called the “decade of infancy”

original: nāma, tadā hi so mando hoti capalo kumārako. Tato parāni dasa khiḍḍādasakaṃ nāma,🔽tadā hi so khiḍḍāratibahulo hoti. Tato parāni dasa vaṇṇadasakaṃ nāma, tadā hissa🔽vaṇṇāyatanaṃ vepullaṃ pāpuṇāti. Tato parāni dasa baladasakaṃ nāma, tadā hissa balañca🔽thāmo ca vepullaṃ pāpuṇāti. Tato parāni dasa paññādasakaṃ nāma, tadā hissa paññā🔽suppatiṭṭhitā hoti, pakatiyā kira dubbalapaññassāpi tasmiṃ kāle appamattakā paññā🔽uppajjatiyeva. Tato parāni dasa hānidasakaṃ nāma, tadā hissa khiḍḍārativaṇṇabalapaññā
analyzed: nāma tadā hi saḥ mandaḥ hoti capalaḥ kumārako tatas parāni dasa khiḍḍādasakam nāma  tadā hi saḥ khiḍḍārati bahulaḥ hoti tatas parāni dasa vaṇṇadasakam nāma tadā hissa  vaṇṇa āyatanam vepullam pāpuṇāti tato parāni dasa baladasakam nāma tadā hissa balam ca  thāmo ca vepullam pāpuṇāti tato parāni dasa paññādasakam nāma tadā hissa paññā  su patiṭṭhitā hoti pakatiyā kira dubbala paññassa api tasmin kāle appamattakā paññā  uppajjatiyā iva tato parāni dasa hānidasakam nāma tadā hissa khiḍḍā rati vaṇṇa bala paññā
translated: because he is then feeble, unsteady, a mere child. The next ten years are called the “decade of play”

original: parihāyanti. Tato parāni dasa pabbhāradasakaṃ nāma, tadā hissa attabhāvo purato pabbhāro
analyzed: parihāyanti tatas parāni dasa pabbhāradasakam nāma tadā hissa atta bhāvaḥ puratas pabbhāro
translated: because he delights in play. The next ten years are called the “decade of beauty” because his beauty then reaches its full extent. The next ten years are called the “decade of strength” because his strength and vigour then reach their full extent. The next ten years are called the “decade of understanding” because his understanding is then well established. Even one who is naturally feeble in understanding has at least a little understanding at that time. The next ten years are called the “decade of decline” because his beauty, strength, and understanding decline then. The next ten years are called the “decade of white hairs” because white hairs appear in him then. The next ten years are called the “decade of bent back” because his back then begins to bend. The next ten years are called the “decade of dotage” because he is then subject to dotage.

original: hoti. Tato parāni dasa vaṅkadasakaṃ nāma, tadā hissa attabhāvo naṅgalakoṭi viya vaṅko🔽hoti. Tato parāni dasa momūhadasakaṃ nāma. Tadā hi so momūho hoti, kataṃ kataṃ pamussati.
analyzed: hoti tatas parāni dasa vaṅkadasakam nāma tadā hissa atta bhāvaḥ viya vaṅko  hoti tato parāni dasa momūhadasakam nāma tadā hi saḥ momūhaḥ hoti katam katam pamussati
translated: After that, the next ten years are called the decade of crookedness, for by then his body has become crooked like the handle of a plough.🔽After that, the next ten years are called the decade of dotage, for by then he has become senile and forgets what he has just done.

original: Tato parāni dasa sayanadasakaṃ nāma, vassasatiko hi sayanabahulova hoti.
analyzed: tato parāni dasa sayanadasakam nāma vassa satikaḥ hi sayana bahulaḥ uva hoti
translated: After that, the next ten years are called the decade of lying, for by then he spends most of his time lying down.

original: Tatrāyaṃ yogī etesaṃ dasakānaṃ vasena vayovuḍḍhatthaṅgamato tilakkhaṇaṃ āropetuṃ🔽iti paṭisañcikkhati – “paṭhamadasake pavattarūpaṃ dutiyadasakaṃ appatvā tattheva🔽nirujjhati, tasmā taṃ aniccaṃ dukkhamanattā. Dutiyadasake…pe… navamadasake pavattarūpaṃ🔽dasamadasakaṃ appatvā tattheva nirujjhati. Dasamadasake pavattarūpaṃ punabbhavaṃ
analyzed: tatra ayam yogī etesam dasakānam vasena ti lakkhaṇam āropetum  iti paṭisañcikkhati paṭhama dasake pavatta rūpam dutiya dasakam a patvā tattha eva  nirujjhati tasmā tam aniccam dukkham anattā dutiya dasa kepe navama dasake pavatta rūpam  dasama dasakam ap patvā tattha iva nirujjhati dasama dasake pavatta rūpam punabbhavam
translated: Here the meditator should attribute the three characteristics to the materiality of the various decades in the order stated, according to age, thus:

original: appatvā idheva nirujjhati, tasmā tampi aniccaṃ dukkhamanattā”ti tilakkhaṇaṃ āropeti.
analyzed: a patvā idha iva nirujjhati tasmā tam pi aniccam dukkham anattā ti ti lakkhaṇam āropeti
translated: “The materiality occurring in the first decade ceases there without reaching the second decade. Therefore it is impermanent, painful, not-self. That occurring in the second decade … without reaching the third decade … That occurring in the ninth decade ceases there without reaching the tenth decade. That occurring in the tenth decade ceases there without reaching rebirth-linking. Therefore it too is impermanent, painful, not-self.” He attributes the three characteristics in this way according to age.

original: 709. Evaṃ dasakavasena vayovuḍḍhatthaṅgamato tilakkhaṇaṃ āropetvā puna tadeva vassasataṃ
analyzed: evam dasaka vasena vayaḥ vuḍḍhatthaṅgamataḥ ti lakkhaṇam āropetvā puna tat eva vassa satam
translated: Having thus ascribed the three characteristics to the life-span by the decade, he ascribes them again by the century.

original: pañcapañcavassavasena vīsatikoṭṭhāse katvā vayovuḍḍhatthaṅgamato tilakkhaṇaṃ āropeti.🔽Kathaṃ? So hi iti paṭisañcikkhati – “paṭhame vassapañcake pavattarūpaṃ dutiyaṃ vassapañcakaṃ
analyzed: pañca pañca vassa vasena vīsati koṭṭhāse katvā vayaḥ vuḍḍhatthaṅgamataḥ ti lakkhaṇam āropeti  katham saḥ hi iti paṭisañcikkhati paṭhame vassa pañcake pavatta rūpam dutiyam vassa pañcakam
translated: He does so by dividing the same hundred years into twenty periods of five years each.

original: appatvā tattheva nirujjhati, tasmā taṃ aniccaṃ dukkhamanattā. Dutiye vassapañcake
analyzed: a patvā tattha iva nirujjhati tasmā tam aniccam dukkham anattā dutiye vassa pañcake
translated: He considers thus: “The materiality occurring in the first pentad of five years ceases there without reaching the second pentad of five years. Therefore it is impermanent, painful, not-self.🔽That occurring in the second pentad of five years …

original: pavattarūpaṃ tatiyaṃ…pe… ekūnavīsatime vassapañcake pavattarūpaṃ vīsatimaṃ vassapañcakaṃ🔽appatvā tattheva nirujjhati. Vīsatime vassapañcake pavattarūpaṃ maraṇato paraṃ gamanasamatthaṃ
analyzed: pavatta rūpam ekūnavīsatime vassa pañcake pavatta rūpam vīsatimam vassa pañcakam  a patvā tattha eva nirujjhati vīsatime vassa pañcake pavatta rūpam maraṇataḥ param gamana samattham
translated: That occurring in the nineteenth pentad of five years ceases there without reaching the twentieth pentad of five years.

original: nāma natthi, tasmā tampi aniccaṃ dukkhamanattā”ti.
analyzed: nāma natthi tasmā tam pi aniccam dukkham anattā ti
translated: That occurring in the twentieth pentad of five years has no ability to go beyond death. Therefore it too is impermanent, painful, not-self.”

original: Evaṃ vīsatikoṭṭhāsavasena vayovuḍḍhatthaṅgamato tilakkhaṇaṃ āropetvā puna pañcavīsati
analyzed: evam vīsati koṭṭhāsa vasena vayaḥ vuḍḍhatthaṅgamataḥ ti lakkhaṇam āropetvā puna pañcavīsati
translated: Having thus ascribed the three characteristics by the life-span’s running out in twenty periods, he ascribes them again by the life-span’s running out in twenty-five periods.

original: koṭṭhāse katvā catunnaṃ catunnaṃ vassānaṃ vasena āropeti. Tato tettiṃsa koṭṭhāse🔽katvā tiṇṇaṃ tiṇṇaṃ vassānaṃ vasena, paññāsa koṭṭhāse katvā dvinnaṃ dvinnaṃ vassānaṃ🔽vasena, sataṃ koṭṭhāse katvā ekekavassavasena. Tato ekaṃ vassaṃ tayo koṭṭhāse katvā
analyzed: koṭṭhāse katvā catunnam catunnam vassānam vasena āropeti tato tettiṃsa koṭṭhāse  katvā tiṇṇam tiṇṇam vassānam vasena paññāsa koṭṭhāse katvā dvinnam dvinnam vassānam  vasena satam koṭṭhāse katvā ekeka vassa vasena tatas ekam vassam tayaḥ koṭṭhāse katvā
translated: He then divides it into three months and describes it in terms of the three seasons, and into two months and describes it in terms of the two terms, and into one month and describes it in terms of the one term, and into fifteen days and describes it in terms of the two halves of the fortnight, and into seven days and describes it in terms of the seven days of the week, and into three days and describes it in terms of the three terms, and into one day and describes it in terms of the four postures.

original: vassānahemantagimhesu tīsu utūsu ekekautuvasena tasmiṃ vayovuḍḍhatthaṅgamarūpe tilakkhaṇaṃ āropeti.🔽Kathaṃ? “Vassāne catumāsaṃ pavattarūpaṃ hemantaṃ appatvā tattheva niruddhaṃ. Hemante
analyzed: vassāna hemanta gimhesu tīsu utūsu ekeka otu vasena tasmin vayaḥ vuḍḍhatthaṅgama rūpe ti lakkhaṇam āropeti  katham vassāne catu māsam pavatta rūpam hemantam ap patvā tattha eva niruddham hemante
translated: Then he divides the one day into three parts, morning, etc., and describes it in terms of the three terms, and into two parts, day and night, and describes it in terms of the two terms, and into morning, noon, and evening, and describes it in terms of the three terms, and into morning and afternoon, and describes it in terms of the two terms, and into four parts, the four watches of the night, and describes it in terms of the four terms, and into two parts, the first and last watches, and describes it in terms of the two terms, and into three parts, the first, middle, and last watches, and describes it in terms of the three terms.🔽Then he divides the morning, etc., into three parts, and describes it in terms of the three terms, and into two parts, and describes it in terms of the two terms, and into four parts, and describes it in terms of the four terms.

original: pavattarūpaṃ gimhaṃ appatvā tattheva niruddhaṃ. Gimhe pavattarūpaṃ puna vassānaṃ🔽appatvā tattheva niruddhaṃ, tasmā taṃ aniccaṃ dukkhamanattā”ti. Evaṃ āropetvā puna
analyzed: pavatta rūpam gimham ap patvā tattha iva niruddham gimhe pavatta rūpam puna vassānam  a patvā tattha iva niruddham tasmā tam aniccam dukkham anattā ti evam āropetvā punar
translated: Then he divides the morning into three parts, and describes it in terms of the three terms, and into two parts, and describes it in terms of the two terms, and into four parts, and describes it in terms of the four terms.

original: ekaṃ vassaṃ cha koṭṭhāse katvā – “vassāne dvemāsaṃ pavattarūpaṃ saradaṃ appatvā tattheva
analyzed: ekam vassam cha koṭṭhāse katvā vassāne dve māsam pavatta rūpam saradam a patvā tattha eva
translated: Then he divides the first part of the morning into three parts, and describes it in terms of the three terms, and into two parts, and describes it in terms of the two terms, and into four parts, and describes it in terms of the four terms.🔽Then he divides the first part of the first part of the morning into three parts, and describes it in terms of the three terms, and into two parts, and describes it in terms of the two terms, and into four parts, and describes it in terms of the four terms.

original: niruddhaṃ. Sarade pavattarūpaṃ hemantaṃ. Hemante pavattarūpaṃ sisiraṃ. Sisire pavattarūpaṃ🔽vasantaṃ. Vasante pavattarūpaṃ gimhaṃ. Gimhe pavattarūpaṃ puna vassānaṃ appatvā tattheva
analyzed: niruddham sarade pavatta rūpam hemantam hemante pavatta rūpam sisiram sisire pavatta rūpam  vasantam vasante pavatta rūpam gimham gimhe pavatta rūpam puna vassānam ap patvā tattha eva
translated: The materiality occurring in autumn ceases there without reaching winter. The materiality occurring in winter ceases there without reaching cold weather. The materiality occurring in cold weather ceases there without reaching

original: niruddhaṃ, tasmā aniccaṃ dukkhamanattā”ti evaṃ tasmiṃ vayovuḍḍhatthaṅgamarūpe tilakkhaṇaṃ āropeti.
analyzed: niruddham tasmai aniccam dukkham anattā ati evam tasmim vayaḥ vuḍḍhatthaṅgama rūpe ti lakkhaṇam āropeti
translated: spring. The materiality occurring in spring ceases there without reaching summer. The materiality occurring in summer ceases there without reaching the rains again, but ceases there itself. So it is impermanent, painful, not-self. He thus imposes the three characteristics on the materiality that has reached its maximum span of life.

original: Evaṃ āropetvā tato kāḷajuṇhavasena – “kāḷe pavattarūpaṃ juṇhaṃ appatvā. Juṇhe pavattarūpaṃ
analyzed: evam āropetvā tatas kāḷa juṇha vasena kāḷe pavatta rūpam juṇham appatvā juṇhe pavatta rūpam
translated: After imposing them in this way, he imposes the three characteristics by means of the dark and bright halves of the moon thus: The materiality occurring in the dark half of the moon ceases there without reaching the bright half. The materiality occurring in the bright half of the moon ceases there without reaching the dark half.

original: kāḷaṃ appatvā tattheva niruddhaṃ, tasmā aniccaṃ dukkhamanattā”ti tilakkhaṇaṃ āropeti.
analyzed: kāḷam ap patvā tattha iva niruddham tasmai aniccam dukkham anattā ati ti lakkhaṇam āropeti
translated: So it is impermanent, painful, not-self.

original: Tato rattindivavasena – “rattiṃ pavattarūpaṃ divasaṃ appatvā tattheva niruddhaṃ.
analyzed: tatas rattindiva vasena rattim pavatta rūpam divasam tattha iva niruddham
translated: After that, by means of night and day, he imposes the three characteristics thus: The materiality occurring in the night ceases there without reaching the day.

original: Divasaṃ pavattarūpampi rattiṃ appatvā tattheva niruddhaṃ, tasmā aniccaṃ dukkhamanattā”ti
analyzed: divasam pavatta rūpam pi rattim ap patvā tattha iva niruddham tasmai aniccam dukkham anattā ti
translated: The materiality occurring in the day ceases there without reaching the night. So it is impermanent, painful, not-self.

original: tilakkhaṇaṃ āropeti. Tato tadeva rattindivaṃ pubbaṇhādivasena cha koṭṭhāse katvā🔽– “pubbaṇhe pavattarūpaṃ majjhanhaṃ appatvā. Majjhanhe pavattarūpaṃ sāyanhaṃ. Sāyanhe
analyzed: tilakkhaṇam āropeti tatas tat eva rattindivam pubbaṇhā divasena cha koṭṭhāse katvā  pubbaṇhe pavatta rūpam majjhanham ap patvā majjhanhe pavatta rūpam sāyanham sāyanhe
translated: He attributes the three characteristics to it. Then he divides the same materiality into six parts by means of the morning, etc., of a single day and night,🔽as follows: “The materiality occurring in the morning does not reach the noon; the materiality occurring at noon does not reach the evening;

original: pavattarūpaṃ paṭhamayāmaṃ. Paṭhamayāme pavattarūpaṃ majjhimayāmaṃ. Majjhimayāme pavattarūpaṃ
analyzed: pavatta rūpam paṭhama yāmam paṭhama yāme pavatta rūpam majjhima yāmam majjhima yāme pavatta rūpam
translated: the materiality occurring in the evening does not reach the first watch of the night; the materiality occurring in the first watch of the night does not reach the middle watch; the materiality occurring in the middle watch of the night does not reach the last watch of the night;

original: pacchimayāmaṃ appatvā tattheva niruddhaṃ. Pacchimayāme pavattarūpaṃ puna pubbaṇhaṃ
analyzed: pacchima yāmam a patvā tattha iva niruddham pacchima yāme pavatta rūpam puna pubbaṇham
translated: the materiality occurring in the last watch of the night does not reach the morning again but ceases there;

original: appatvā tattheva niruddhaṃ, tasmā aniccaṃ dukkhamanattā”ti tilakkhaṇaṃ āropeti.
analyzed: a patvā tattha iva niruddham tasmai aniccam dukkham anattā ati ti lakkhaṇam āropeti
translated: therefore it is impermanent, painful, not-self.” He attributes the three characteristics to it.

original: 710. Evaṃ āropetvā puna tasmiṃyeva rūpe abhikkamapaṭikkamaālokanavilokanasamiñjanapasāraṇavasena
analyzed: evam āropetvā puna tasmin yeva rūpe abhikkama paṭikkama ālokana vilokana samiñjana pasāraṇa vasena
translated: Having attributed them thus, he again attributes the three characteristics to that same materiality by means of going forwards and backwards, looking ahead and looking away, bending and stretching,

original: – “abhikkame pavattarūpaṃ paṭikkamaṃ appatvā tattheva nirujjhati. Paṭikkame pavattarūpaṃ
analyzed: abhikkame pavatta rūpam paṭikkamam a patvā tattha eva nirujjhati paṭikkame pavatta rūpam
translated: as follows: “The materiality occurring in going forwards does not reach going backwards; it ceases there; the materiality occurring in going backwards does not reach looking ahead;

original: ālokanaṃ. Ālokane pavattarūpaṃ vilokanaṃ. Vilokane pavattarūpaṃ samiñjanaṃ. Samiñjane
analyzed: ālokanam ālokane pavatta rūpam vilokanam vilokane pavatta rūpam samiñjanam samiñjane
translated: the materiality occurring in looking ahead does not reach looking away; the materiality occurring in looking away does not reach bending; the materiality occurring in bending does not reach stretching;

original: pavattarūpaṃ pasāraṇaṃ appatvā tattheva nirujjhati. Tasmā aniccaṃ dukkhamanattā”ti
analyzed: pavatta rūpam pasāraṇam ap patvā tattha iva nirujjhati tasmai aniccam dukkham anattā ti
translated: and the materiality that has arisen ceases there without reaching the spreading out. That is why it is impermanent, painful, not-self.”

original: tilakkhaṇaṃ āropeti.
analyzed: tilakkhaṇam āropeti
translated: He attributes the three characteristics to it.

original: Tato ekapadavāraṃ uddharaṇa atiharaṇavītiharaṇavossajjanasannikkhepanasannirumbhanavasena cha koṭṭhāse karoti.
analyzed: eka pada vāram cha koṭṭhāse karoti
translated: Then he makes the single-foot phrase into six sections by way of lifting up, shifting, shifting again, putting down, placing, and pressing down.

original: Tattha uddharaṇaṃ nāma pādassa bhūmito ukkhipanaṃ. Atiharaṇaṃ nāma purato haraṇaṃ.
analyzed: tattha uddharaṇam nāma pādassa bhūmitaḥ ukkhipanam atiharaṇam nāma puratas haraṇam
translated: Herein, lifting up is raising the foot from the ground. Shifting is moving it forward.

original: Vītiharaṇaṃ nāma khāṇukaṇṭakadīghajātiādīsu kiñcideva disvā ito cito ca pādasañcāraṇaṃ.🔽Vossajjanaṃ nāma pādassa heṭṭhā oropanaṃ. Sannikkhepanaṃ nāma pathavītale ṭhapanaṃ.
analyzed: vītiharaṇam nāma khāṇu kaṇṭaka dīgha jāti ādīsu kiñcid eva itas citas ca pāda sañcāraṇam  vossajjanam nāma pādassa heṭṭhā oropanam sannikkhepanam nāma pathavī tale ṭhapanam
translated: Shifting again is moving the foot to and fro when one sees a stump, a stone, a termite-mound, etc., in the place where one is going to put it down.🔽Putting down is lowering the foot on to the ground. Placing is putting the foot on the ground.

original: Sannirumbhanaṃ nāma puna pāduddharaṇakāle pādassa pathaviyā saddhiṃ abhinippīḷanaṃ.
analyzed: saṃnirumbhanam nāma puna pāda uddharaṇa kāle pādassa pathaviyā saddhim abhinippīḷanam
translated: Pressing down is pressing the foot on the ground when one lifts up the other foot in order to go.

original: Tattha uddharaṇe pathavīdhātu āpodhātūti dve dhātuyo omattā honti mandā, itarā dve
analyzed: uddharaṇe pathavī dhātu āpaḥ dhātu uti dve dhātuyaḥ omattāḥ honti mandāḥ itarāḥ dve
translated: Herein, in the lifting up, two elements, that is to say, the earth element and the water element, are diminished and weak, and the other two🔽are strong.

original: adhimattā honti balavatiyo. Tathā atiharaṇavītiharaṇesu. Vossajjane tejodhātu vāyodhātūti
analyzed: adhimattāḥ honti tathā atiharaṇa vītiharaṇesu vossajjane tejaḥ dhātu vāyo dhātu uti
translated: and the two elements of heat and air are strong, powerful.🔽So too with the carrying out and the carrying on. When the carrying out is taking place, the two elements of earth and water are weak, feeble, and the two elements of heat and air are strong, powerful.

original: dve dhātuyo omattā honti mandā, itarā dve adhimattā honti balavatiyo. Tathā sannikkhepanasannirumbhanesu.
analyzed: dve dhātuyaḥ omattāḥ honti mandāḥ itarāḥ dve adhimattāḥ honti balavatiyaḥ tathā sannikkhepana sannirumbhanesu
translated: So too with the depositing and the settling down.

original: Evaṃ cha koṭṭhāse katvā tesaṃ vasena tasmiṃ vayovuḍḍhatthaṅgamarūpe tilakkhaṇaṃ āropeti.🔽Kathaṃ? So iti paṭisañcikkhati – “yā uddharaṇe pavattā dhātuyo, yāni ca tadupādāyarūpāni,
analyzed: evam cha koṭṭhāse katvā tesam vasena tasmin vayaḥ vuḍḍhatthaṅgama rūpe ti lakkhaṇam āropeti  katham saḥ iti paṭisañcikkhati yāḥ uddharaṇe pavattāḥ dhātuyaḥ yāni ca tad upādāya rūpāni
translated: Having thus made a division into six sections, he extends the three characteristics over that materiality which is subject to destruction by ageing in virtue of that division.

original: sabbe te dhammā atiharaṇaṃ appatvā ettheva nirujjhanti, tasmā aniccā dukkhā anattā.
analyzed: sabbe te dhammā atiharaṇam a patvā ettha iva nirujjhanti tasmai aniccā dukkhā anattā
translated: How? He considers thus: “The elements that occur in the carrying out and the kinds of derived materiality associated with them all cease right here without reaching the carrying on. Therefore they are impermanent, painful, not-self.

original: Tathā atiharaṇe pavattā vītiharaṇaṃ. Vītiharaṇe pavattā vossajjanaṃ. Vossajjane pavattā
analyzed: tathā atiharaṇe pavattā vītiharaṇam vītiharaṇe pavattā vossajjanam vossajjane pavattā
translated: So too with the elements and kinds of derived materiality that occur in the carrying on, in the carrying out, in the depositing,

original: sannikkhepanaṃ. Sannikkhepane pavattā sannirumbhanaṃ appatvā ettheva nirujjhanti.
analyzed: sannikkhepanam sannikkhepane pavattā sannirumbhanam ap patvā ettha iva nirujjhanti
translated: and in the settling down. They all cease right here without reaching the next stage.

original: Iti tattha tattha uppannā itaraṃ itaraṃ koṭṭhāsaṃ appatvā tattha tattheva pabbaṃ🔽pabbaṃ sandhi sandhi odhi odhi hutvā tattakapāle pakkhittatilā viya taṭataṭāyantā
analyzed: iti tattha tattha uppannā itaram itaram koṭṭhāsam ap patvā tattha tattha iva pabbam  pabbam sandhi sandhi odhi odhi hutvā tatta kapāle pakkhitta tilāḥ viya taṭataṭāyantā
translated: So they break up there and then, without reaching the other parts, and they break up there and then,🔽each part breaking up into particles, each particle into atoms, each atom into a directional unit, each directional unit into a directional unit’s worth of dross.

original: saṅkhārā bhijjanti. Tasmā aniccā dukkhā anattā”ti. Tassevaṃ pabbapabbagate saṅkhāre
analyzed: saṅkhārāḥ bhijjanti tasmai aniccāḥ dukkhāḥ anattā ati tassa ivam pabba pabba gate saṅkhāre
translated: So they break up, and they are impermanent, painful, not-self.

original: vipassato rūpasammasanaṃ sukhumaṃ hoti.
analyzed: vipassataḥ rūpa sammasanam sukhumam hoti
translated: As he contemplates formations thus in their aspect of breaking up, his insight into materiality becomes refined.

original: 711. Sukhumatte ca panassa idaṃ opammaṃ. Eko kira dārutiṇukkādīsu kataparicayo adiṭṭhapubbapadīpo🔽paccantavāsiko nagaramāgamma antarāpaṇe jalamānaṃ padīpaṃ disvā ekaṃ purisaṃ pucchi🔽ambho “kiṃ nāmetaṃ evaṃ manāpa”nti? Tamenaṃ so āha “kimettha manāpaṃ, padīpo nāmesa
analyzed: sukhuma tte ca panassa idam opammam ekaḥ kira dāru tiṇukka ādīsu kata paricayaḥ a diṭṭha pubba padīpo  paccantavāsikaḥ nagaram āgamma antarāpaṇe jalamānam padīpam disvā ekam purisam pucchi  ambho kim nāma etam evam manāpanti tam enam saḥ āha kim ettha manāpam padīpaḥ nāma isa
translated: Here is a simile for the refinement. A man skilled in the use of torches to burn forests, it seems, had been given a torch to burn a forest.🔽He saw a forest fire burning in a frontier district and asked a man, “Good man, why is that place so pleasant?”🔽The man said, “How can it be pleasant? It is a forest fire. When the oil and the wick are used up, its path will not be seen.”

original: telakkhayena vaṭṭikkhayena ca gatamaggopissa na paññāyissatī”ti. Tamañño evamāha
analyzed: tela khayena vaṭṭi khayena ca na paññāyissati iti tamaññaḥ evam āha
translated: Another said:

original: “idaṃ oḷārikaṃ, imissā hi vaṭṭiyā anupubbena ḍayhamānāya tatiyabhāge tatiyabhāge🔽jālā itarītaraṃ padesaṃ appatvāva nirujjhissatī”ti. Tamañño evamāha “idampi oḷārikaṃ,🔽imissā hi aṅgulaṅgulantare aḍḍhaṅgulaḍḍhaṅgulantare tantumhi tantumhi aṃsumhi aṃsumhi
analyzed: idam oḷārikam imissā hi vaṭṭiyāḥ anupubbena ḍayhamānāya tatiya bhāge tatiya bhāge  jālā itarītaram padesam ap patvā ava nirujjhissati iti tamaññaḥ evam āha idam pi oḷārikam  imissā hi aṅgula aṅgula antare aḍḍhaṅgula ḍḍhaṅgula antare tantumhi tantumhi aṃsumhi aṃsumhi
translated: “This is gross, for when the wick is gradually burning down, the flame will cease in each third part before reaching the other third.” Another said, “This is gross too,

original: jālā itarītaraṃ aṃsuṃ appatvāva nirujjhissati. Aṃsuṃ pana muñcitvā na sakkā jālaṃ paññāpetu”nti.🔽Tattha “telakkhayena vaṭṭikkhayena ca padīpassa gatamaggopi na paññāyissatī”ti purisassa
analyzed: jālā itarītaram aṃsum ap patvā ava nirujjhissati aṃsum pana muñcitvā na sakkā jālam paññāpetunti  tattha tela khayena vaṭṭi khayena ca padīpassa gata maggaḥ api na paññāyissati iti purisassa
translated: for in each finger’s breadth, in each half-finger’s breadth, in each thread, in each strand, the flame will cease before reaching the other strands. But it is impossible to point to the flame apart from the strands.”

original: ñāṇaṃ viya yogino ādānanikkhepanato vassasatena paricchinnarūpe tilakkhaṇāropanaṃ.
analyzed: ñāṇam viya yoginaḥ ādāna nikkhepanataḥ vassa satena paricchinna rūpe ti lakkhaṇa āropanam
translated: Herein, just as the man’s knowledge was that “the lamp’s course will not be evident when the oil and the wick are used up,” so the meditator’s is the imposition of the three characteristics on the materiality delimited by a hundred years by means of the taking up and putting down.

original: “Vaṭṭiyā tatiyabhāge tatiyabhāge jālā itarītaraṃ padesaṃ appatvāva nirujjhissatī”ti🔽purisassa ñāṇaṃ viya yogino vassasatassa tatiyakoṭṭhāsaparicchinne vayovuḍḍhatthaṅgamarūpe
analyzed: vaṭṭiyā tatiya bhāge tatiya bhāge jālā itarītaram padesam ap patvā ava nirujjhissati iti 🔽purisassa ñāṇam viya yoginaḥ vassa satassa tatiya koṭṭhāsa paricchinne vayaḥ vuḍḍhatthaṅgama rūpe
translated: Just as the man’s knowledge was that “the flame will cease in each third part of the wick before reaching the other third,”🔽so the meditator’s is the knowledge that “in the materiality delimited by the third part of a hundred years, that is, by thirty-three years and four months, there is fall of aggregates, fall of elements, fall of bases, fall of faculties, fall of sustenances, fall of ignorance, fall of craving, fall of kamma, fall of kamma-result, fall of aggregates generated by kamma-result, fall of aggregates generated by kamma, fall of aggregates generated by nutriment, fall of aggregates generated by temperature, fall of aggregates generated by consciousness, fall of aggregates generated by nutriment, temperature and consciousness.”

original: tilakkhaṇāropanaṃ. “Aṅgulaṅgulantare jālā itarītaraṃ appatvāva nirujjhissatī”ti purisassa🔽ñāṇaṃ viya yogino dasavassa pañcavassa catuvassa tivassa dvivassa ekavassa paricchinne
analyzed: tilakkhaṇa āropanam aṅgula aṅgula antare jālā itarītaram appatvā ava nirujjhissati iti purisassa  ñāṇam viya yoginaḥ paricchinne
translated: and he superimposes the three characteristics on it.🔽Just as the man’s knowledge was that the flame would cease without reaching the other end of the fingers, so too, the meditator’s knowledge is that the thirty-two parts will cease after reaching the ten years, the five years, the four years, the three years, the two years, or the one year.

original: rūpe tilakkhaṇāropanaṃ. “Aḍḍhaṅgulaḍḍhaṅgulantare jālā itarītaraṃ appatvāva nirujjhissatī”ti🔽purisassa ñāṇaṃ viya yogino ekekautuvasena ekaṃ vassaṃ tidhā, chadhā ca vibhajitvā
analyzed: rūpe ti lakkhaṇa āropanam aḍḍhaṅgula ḍḍhaṅgula antare jālā itarītaram appatvā ava nirujjhissati iti  purisassa ñāṇam viya yoginaḥ eka ekautuvasena ekam vassam tidhā chadhā ca vibhajitvā
translated: and the three characteristics are imposed. Just as the man’s knowledge is that the flame will cease without reaching the other end of the fingers, so too the meditator’s knowledge is that the materiality delimited by ten years, five years, four years, three years, two years, or one year will cease without reaching the end of the one year.

original: catumāsa-dvimāsaparicchinne rūpe tilakkhaṇāropanaṃ. “Tantumhi tantumhi jālā itarītaraṃ🔽appatvāva nirujjhissatī”ti purisassa ñāṇaṃ viya yogino kāḷajuṇhavasena, rattindivavasena,
analyzed: catu māsa dvi māsa paricchinne rūpe ti lakkhaṇa āropanam tantumhi tantumhi jālāḥ itarītaram  a patvā ava nirujjhissati iti purisassa ñāṇam viya yogino kāḷajuṇha vasena rattindiva vasena
translated: Just as the man’s knowledge is that the flame will cease without reaching the other end of the half-fingers, so too the meditator’s knowledge is that the materiality delimited by one year divided into three or six parts, or by four months or two months, will cease without reaching the end of the two months or four months or six parts or three parts.

original: ekarattindivaṃ cha koṭṭhāse katvā pubbaṇhādivasena ca paricchinne rūpe tilakkhaṇāropanaṃ.
analyzed: eka rattindivam cha koṭṭhāse katvā pubbaṇhā ādi vasena ca paricchinne rūpe ti lakkhaṇa āropanam
translated: Just as the man’s knowledge is that the flame will cease without reaching the other end of the finger joints, so too the meditator’s knowledge is that the materiality delimited by the dark and bright halves of the moon, by night and day, by the six periods of the day, by the morning, etc., will cease without reaching the end of the morning, etc.

original: “Aṃsumhi aṃsumhi jālā itarītaraṃ appatvāva nirujjhissatī”ti purisassa ñāṇaṃ viya
analyzed: aṃsumhi aṃsumhi jālā itarītaram appatvā ava nirujjhissati iti purisassa ñāṇam viya
translated: Just as the man’s knowledge that the net will stop in each successive part without reaching the other parts.

original: yogino abhikkamādivasena ceva uddharaṇādīsu ca ekekakoṭṭhāsavasena paricchinne rūpe
analyzed: yoginaḥ abhikkama ādi vasena ca iva uddharaṇa ādīsu ca ekeka koṭṭhāsa vasena paricchinne rūpe
translated: When the meditator has thus defined materiality by successive delimitations of the parts beginning with the act of going forwards, etc., and the act of lifting up, etc.,

original: tilakkhaṇāropananti.
analyzed: ti lakkhaṇa āropananti
translated: he should superimpose the three characteristics on the materiality that is subject to destruction through ageing.

original: 712. So evaṃ nānākārehi vayovuḍḍhatthaṅgamarūpe tilakkhaṇaṃ āropetvā puna tadeva
analyzed: saḥ evam nānā ākārehi vayaḥ vuḍḍhatthaṅgama rūpe tilakkhaṇam āropetvā puna tat eva
translated: Having thus super- imposed the three characteristics on materiality subject to destruction through ageing in its various aspects, he should again break up that materiality

original: rūpaṃ visaṅkharitvā āhāramayādivasena cattāro koṭṭhāse katvā ekekakoṭṭhāse tilakkhaṇaṃ🔽āropeti. Tatrāssa āhāramayaṃ rūpaṃ chātasuhitavasena pākaṭaṃ hoti. Chātakāle samuṭṭhitaṃ🔽rūpaṃ hi jhattaṃ hoti kilantaṃ, jhāmakhāṇuko viya, aṅgārapacchiyaṃ nilīnakāko viya
analyzed: rūpam visaṅkharitvā āhāra maya ādi vasena cattāro koṭṭhāse katvā ekeka koṭṭhāse ti lakkhaṇam  āropeti āhāra mayam rūpam chāta suhita vasena pākaṭam hoti chāta kāle samuṭṭhitam  rūpam hi jhattam hoti kilantam jhāma khāṇukaḥ viya aṅgārapacchiyam nilīna kākaḥ viya
translated: and make it into four parts classed as derived from the four primary elements, and he should superimpose the three characteristics on each part🔽as derived from the primary elements. Herein, materiality derived from nutriment is evident as “worn” and “mended.”🔽Materiality arisen at the time of wearing is “worn,” “weary,” “wearying,” like a ploughman wearying the bull, like a carter wearying the horse, like a farmer wearying the plough animal, like a soldier wearying the elephant, like a butcher wearying the ox, like a hunter wearying the dog, like a carter wearying the donkey, like a thief wearying the cat, like a thief wearying the horse, etc.; it is “dull,” “dull-looking,” “dull-coloured,” like a fire of charred wood, like a crow of the dunghill, like a pumpkin growing in a drain, like a razor- clam, like a snake of the rubbish heap;

original: ca dubbaṇṇaṃ dussaṇṭhitaṃ. Suhitakāle samuṭṭhitaṃ dhātaṃ pīṇitaṃ mudu siniddhaṃ phassavantaṃ
analyzed: ca dubbaṇṇam dussaṇṭhitam su hita kāle samuṭṭhitam dhātam pīṇitam mudu siniddham phassavantam
translated: Materiality arisen at the time of mending is “fat,” “fattened,” “fattening,” “smooth,” “soft,” “yielding to pressure.”

original: hoti. So taṃ pariggahetvā “chātakāle pavattarūpaṃ suhitakālaṃ appatvā ettheva nirujjhati.
analyzed: hoti saḥ tam pariggahetvā chāta kāle pavatta rūpam su hita kālam a patvā etthā iva nirujjhati
translated: He discerns it thus: “The materiality occurring at the time of the heat does not reach the time of the cold, but ceases there itself.

original: Suhitakāle samuṭṭhitampi chātakālaṃ appatvā ettheva nirujjhati, tasmā taṃ aniccaṃ
analyzed: su hita kāle samuṭṭhitam pi chāta kālam a patvā ettha iva nirujjhati tasmā tam aniccam
translated: The materiality occurring at the time of the cold does not reach the time of the heat, but ceases there itself. Therefore it is impermanent,

original: dukkhamanattā”ti evaṃ tattha tilakkhaṇaṃ āropeti.
analyzed: dukkham anattā ati evam tattha ti lakkhaṇam āropeti
translated: unpleas-ant, and non-self.” He thus imposes the three characteristics on it.

original: 713. Utumayaṃ sītuṇhavasena pākaṭaṃ hoti. Uṇhakāle samuṭṭhitaṃ rūpaṃ hi jhattaṃ hoti
analyzed: utu mayam sītuṇha vasena pākaṭam hoti uṇha kāle samuṭṭhitam rūpam hi jhattam hoti
translated: The materiality originated by temperature is evident as cold and heat. For the materiality that arises in the hot season is parched,

original: kilantaṃ dubbaṇṇaṃ. Sītautunā samuṭṭhitaṃ rūpaṃ dhātaṃ pīṇitaṃ siniddhaṃ hoti. So🔽taṃ pariggahetvā “uṇhakāle pavattarūpaṃ sītakālaṃ appatvā ettheva nirujjhati. Sītakāle
analyzed: kilantam dubbaṇṇam sītautunā samuṭṭhitam rūpam dhātam pīṇitam siniddham hoti so  tam pariggahetvā uṇha kāle pavatta rūpam sīta kālam a patvā ettha iva nirujjhati sīta kāle
translated: dried up, and discoloured. That which arises in the cold season is moist, plump, and smooth. He discerns it thus:

original: pavattarūpaṃ uṇhakālaṃ appatvā ettheva nirujjhati, tasmā taṃ aniccaṃ dukkhamanattā”ti
analyzed: pavatta rūpam uṇha kālam a patvā ettha iva nirujjhati tasmā tam aniccam dukkham anattā ti
translated: “The materiality occurring at the time of the heat does not reach the time of the cold, but ceases there itself. The materiality occurring at the time of the cold does not reach the time of the heat, but ceases there itself. Therefore it is impermanent,

original: evaṃ tattha tilakkhaṇaṃ āropeti.
analyzed: evam tattha ti lakkhaṇam āropeti
translated: unpleasant, and non-self.” He thus imposes the three characteristics on it.

original: 714. Kammajaṃ āyatanadvāravasena pākaṭaṃ hoti. Cakkhudvārasmiṃ hi cakkhukāyabhāvadasakavasena
analyzed: kamma jam āyatana dvāra vasena pākaṭam hoti cakkhu dvārasmiṃ hi cakkhu kāya bhāva dasaka vasena
translated: The materiality originated by kamma is evident as the door of the sense bases. For in the eye door there are eleven kinds of materiality, namely, the ten faculties beginning with the eye and the materiality of the physical heart-basis.

original: tiṃsa kammajarūpāni, upatthambhakāni pana tesaṃ utucittāhārasamuṭṭhānāni catuvīsatīti🔽catupaṇṇāsa honti. Tathā sotaghānajivhādvāresu. Kāyadvāre kāyabhāvadasakavasena ceva
analyzed: tiṃsa kamma ja rūpāni upatthambhakāni pana tesam utu citta āhāra samuṭṭhānāni catuvīsati iti  honti tathā sota ghāna jivhā dvāresu kāya dvāre kāya bhāva dasaka vasena ca iva
translated: The thirty kinds of action-resultant materiality, and the forty-two kinds of materiality originated by temperature, nutriment and consciousness, which are the supports of the former,🔽make fifty-four kinds of materiality in all. The same applies to the ear, nose and tongue doors.🔽At the body door there are forty-four kinds of materiality, namely, the ten kinds of materiality of the physical basis of the body,

original: utusamuṭṭhānādivasena ca catucattālīsa. Manodvāre hadayavatthukāyabhāvadasakavasena
analyzed: utu samuṭṭhāna ādi vasena ca manaḥ dvāre hadaya vatthu kāya bhāva dasaka vasena
translated: and the thirty-four kinds of materiality originated by temperature, etc. At the mind door there are fifty-two kinds of materiality, namely, the ten kinds of materiality of the physical basis of the heart,

original: ceva utusamuṭṭhānādivasena ca catupaṇṇāsameva.🔽So sabbampi taṃ rūpaṃ pariggahetvā “cakkhudvāre pavattarūpaṃ sotadvāraṃ appatvā ettheva🔽nirujjhati. Sotadvāre pavattarūpaṃ ghānadvāraṃ. Ghānadvāre pavattarūpaṃ jivhādvāraṃ.🔽Jivhādvāre pavattarūpaṃ kāyadvāraṃ. Kāyadvāre pavattarūpaṃ manodvāraṃ appatvā ettheva
analyzed: ca iva utu samuṭṭhāna ādi vasena ca catu paṇṇāsam eva  so sabbam pi tam rūpam pariggahetvā cakkhu dvāre pavatta rūpam sota dvāram a patvā ettha iva  nirujjhati sota dvāre pavatta rūpam ghāna dvāram ghāna dvāre pavatta rūpam jivhā dvāram  jivhā dvāre pavatta rūpam kāya dvāram kāya dvāre pavatta rūpam manaḥ dvāram ap patvā etthā iva
translated: and the forty-two kinds of materiality originated by temperature, etc.

original: nirujjhati, tasmā taṃ aniccaṃ dukkhamanattā”ti evaṃ tattha tilakkhaṇaṃ āropeti.
analyzed: nirujjhati tasmā tam aniccam dukkham anattā ati evam tattha ti lakkhaṇam āropeti
translated: Having discerned all that materiality, he attributes the three characteristics to it thus: “The materiality occurring at the eye door ceases there without reaching the ear door. The materiality occurring at the ear door … The materiality occurring at the nose door … The materiality occurring at the tongue door … The materiality occurring at the body door … The materiality occurring at the mind door ceases there without reaching the eye door. Therefore it is impermanent, painful, not-self” .

original: 715. Cittasamuṭṭhānaṃ somanassitadomanassitavasena pākaṭaṃ hoti, somanassitakāle
analyzed: citta samuṭṭhānam somanassita domanassita vasena pākaṭam hoti somanassita kāle
translated: The materiality originated by consciousness becomes evident through the state of joy and through the state of grief. For the materiality that has arisen at the time of joy

original: uppannaṃ hi rūpaṃ siniddhaṃ mudu pīṇitaṃ phassavantaṃ hoti. Domanassitakāle uppannaṃ🔽jhattaṃ kilantaṃ dubbaṇṇaṃ hoti. So taṃ pariggahetvā “somanassitakāle pavattarūpaṃ🔽domanassitakālaṃ appatvā ettheva nirujjhati. Domanassitakāle pavattarūpaṃ somanassitakālaṃ
analyzed: uppannam hi rūpam siniddham mudu pīṇitam phassavantam hoti domanassita kāle uppannam  jhattam kilantam dubbaṇṇam hoti so tam pariggahetvā somanassita kāle pavatta rūpam  domanassita kālam a patvā ettha iva nirujjhati domanassita kāle pavatta rūpam somanassita kālam
translated: is smooth, soft, plump, and full-fleshed. That which has arisen at the time of grief

original: appatvā ettheva nirujjhati, tasmā taṃ aniccaṃ dukkhamanattā”ti evaṃ tattha tilakkhaṇaṃ āropeti.
analyzed: a patvā ettha iva nirujjhati tasmā tam aniccam dukkham anattā ati evam tattha ti lakkhaṇam āropeti
translated: is rough, hard, withered, and thin. He discerns it thus: “The materiality occurring at the time of joy ceases there without reaching the time of grief. The materiality occurring at the time of grief ceases there without reaching the time of joy. Therefore it is impermanent, painful, not-self” . So he imposes the three characteristics on it in this way.

original: Tassevaṃ cittasamuṭṭhānarūpaṃ pariggahetvā tattha tilakkhaṇaṃ āropayato ayamattho pākaṭo hoti –🔽Jīvitaṃ attabhāvo ca, sukhadukkhā ca kevalā;🔽Ekacittasamāyuttā, lahuso vattate khaṇo.🔽Cullāsīti sahassāni, kappaṃ tiṭṭhanti ye marū;
analyzed: tassa ivam citta samuṭṭhāna rūpam pariggahetvā tattha ti lakkhaṇam āropayataḥ ayam attho pākaṭaḥ hoti 🔽jīvitam atta bhāvaḥ ca sukha dukkhā ca kevalā 🔽eka citta samāyuttā lahusaḥ vattate khaṇo 🔽sahassāni kappam tiṭṭhanti ye marū
translated: When he discerns the materiality originated by consciousness in this way and imposes the three characteristics on it, the meaning of impermanence becomes evident to him in this way:

original: Na tveva tepi tiṭṭhanti, dvīhi cittehi samohitā.
analyzed: na tu eva te pi tiṭṭhanti dvīhi cittehi samohitā
translated: But they do not stand, being mixed up with two kinds of consciousness.

original: Ye niruddhā marantassa, tiṭṭhamānassa vā idha;
analyzed: ye niruddhāḥ marantassa tiṭṭhamānassa vai idha
translated: Those that have ceased in one who is dying Or in one who is living here,

original: Sabbeva sadisā khandhā, gatā appaṭisandhikā.
analyzed: sabbe iva sadisāḥ khandhāḥ gatāḥ appaṭisandhikā
translated: All the kinds of aggregates are alike, Gone without being born again.

original: Anantarā ca ye bhaggā, ye ca bhaggā anāgate;
analyzed: anantarā ca ye bhaggāḥ ye ca bhaggāḥ anāgate
translated: And those that have been broken off in the past, And those that will be broken off in the future,

original: Tadantarā niruddhānaṃ, vesamaṃ natthi lakkhaṇe.
analyzed: tad antarā niruddhānam vesamam natthi lakkhaṇe
translated: There is no difference in the characteristics Of those that have ceased in the interval.

original: Anibbattena na jāto, paccuppannena jīvati;
analyzed: a nibbattena na jātaḥ paccuppannena jīvati
translated: Not born with what is unarisen, It lives with what is present,

original: Cittabhaṅgā mato loko, paññatti paramatthiyā.
analyzed: citta bhaṅgā mataḥ
translated: The world dies with the dissolution of consciousness, The description is in ultimate reality.

original: Anidhānagatā bhaggā, puñjo natthi anāgate;
analyzed: a nidhāna gatā bhaggā puñjaḥ na atthi anāgate
translated: Broken off without being stored, There is no heap in the future,

original: Nibbattā yepi tiṭṭhanti, āragge sāsapūpamā.
analyzed: nibbattāḥ ye pi tiṭṭhanti āragge
translated: Those that have arisen and stand Are like mustard seeds on the point of an awl.

original: Nibbattānañca dhammānaṃ, bhaṅgo nesaṃ purakkhato;
analyzed: nibbattānam ca dhammānam bhaṅgaḥ na īsam purakkhataḥ
translated: And the dissolution of those ideas That have arisen is in the lead,

original: Palokadhammā tiṭṭhanti, purāṇehi amissitā.
analyzed: paloka dhammā tiṭṭhanti purāṇehi a missitā
translated: They stand with their falling away, Unmixed with what is old.

original: Adassanato āyanti, bhaggā gacchantudassanaṃ;
analyzed: a dassanataḥ āyanti bhaggāḥ gacchantu dassanam
translated: They come from the unseen, Broken off, they go to the unseen,

original: Vijjuppādova ākāse, uppajjanti vayanti cāti. ;
analyzed: ākāse uppajjanti vayanti ca ati
translated: Like lightning flashes in the sky, They arise and they disappear.

original: 716. Evaṃ āhāramayādīsu tilakkhaṇaṃ āropetvā puna dhammatārūpe tilakkhaṇaṃ āropeti.
analyzed: evam āhāra maya ādīsu ti lakkhaṇam āropetvā puna dhamma tā rūpe ti lakkhaṇam āropeti
translated: Having thus ascribed the three characteristics to the nutriment-born, etc., he next ascribes them to the natural materiality:

original: Dhammatārūpaṃ nāma bahiddhā anindriyabaddhaṃ ayalohatipusīsasuvaṇṇarajatamuttāmaṇiveḷuriyasaṅkhasilāpavāḷalohitaṅgamasāragallabhūmipāsāṇapabbatatiṇarukkhalatādibhedaṃ
analyzed: dhamma tā rūpam nāma bahiddhā anindriya baddham aya loha tipu sīsa suvaṇṇa rajata muttāmaṇi veḷuriya saṅkha silā pavāḷa lohitaṅgama sāragalla bhūmi pāsāṇa pabbata tiṇa rukkha latā ādi bhedam
translated: Materiality as natural kind is the materiality that occurs from the time of the world’s expansion onwards, and it is classed as iron, copper, tin, silver, gold, pearl, gem, cat’s eye, shell, stone, coral, red pearl, quartz, rock, earth, gravel, sand, mountain, grass, tree, creeper, etc., which are not bound up with faculties.

original: vivaṭṭakappato paṭṭhāya uppajjanakarūpaṃ. Tadassa asokaṅkurādivasena pākaṭaṃ hoti.
analyzed: vivaṭṭa kappataḥ paṭṭhāya uppajjanaka rūpam tat assa asokaṅkura ādi vasena pākaṭam hoti
translated: The materiality of the asoka shoot, etc., is evident as the natural kind.

original: Asokaṅkuraṃ hi āditova tanurattaṃ hoti, tato dvīhatīhaccayena ghanarattaṃ, puna dvīhatīhaccayena
analyzed: asokaṅkuram hi tanu rattam tatas dvīhatīhaccayena ghana rattam punar
translated: For the asoka shoot is at first tender red, then after two or three days it is dense red,

original: mandarattaṃ, tato taruṇapallavavaṇṇaṃ, tato pariṇatapallavavaṇṇaṃ, tato haritapaṇṇavaṇṇaṃ.
analyzed: manda rattam tato taruṇa pallava vaṇṇam tato pariṇata pallava vaṇṇam tato harita paṇṇa vaṇṇam
translated: then after two or three days it is pale red, then it is the colour of young leaves, then it is the colour of ripe leaves, then it is the colour of green leaves.

original: Tato nīlapaṇṇavaṇṇaṃ. Tato nīlapaṇṇavaṇṇakālato paṭṭhāya sabhāgarūpasantatimanuppabandhāpayamānaṃ
analyzed: tatas nīla paṇṇa vaṇṇam tatas nīla paṇṇa vaṇṇa kālataḥ paṭṭhāya sa bhāga rūpa santatim anuppabandhāpayamānam
translated: Then it is the colour of blue leaves. From the time it is the colour of blue leaves onwards it causes the continuity of similar material instances to be produced,

original: saṃvaccharamattena paṇḍupalāsaṃ hutvā vaṇṭato chijjitvā patati.
analyzed: saṃvacchara mattena paṇḍu palāsam hutvā vaṇṭataḥ chijjitvā patati
translated: and after a year it becomes withered leaf and falls off from the stalk.

original: So taṃ pariggahetvā “tanurattakāle pavattarūpaṃ ghanarattakālaṃ appatvā nirujjhati.
analyzed: saḥ tam pariggahetvā tanu ratta kāle pavatta rūpam ghana ratta kālam ap patvā nirujjhati
translated: He discerns it thus: “The materiality occurring at the time of tender redness ceases without reaching the time of dense redness.

original: Ghanarattakāle pavattarūpaṃ mandarattakālaṃ. Mandarattakāle pavattarūpaṃ taruṇapallavavaṇṇakālaṃ.🔽Taruṇapallavavaṇṇakāle pavattaṃ pariṇatapallavavaṇṇakālaṃ. Pariṇatapallavavaṇṇakāle🔽pavattaṃ haritapaṇṇavaṇṇakālaṃ. Haritapaṇṇakāle pavattaṃ nīlapaṇṇavaṇṇakālaṃ. Nīlapaṇṇavaṇṇakāle
analyzed: ghana ratta kāle pavatta rūpam manda ratta kālam manda ratta kāle pavatta rūpam taruṇa pallava vaṇṇa kālam  taruṇa pallava vaṇṇa kāle pavattam pariṇata pallava vaṇṇa kālam pariṇata pallava vaṇṇa kāle  pavattam harita paṇṇa vaṇṇa kālam harita paṇṇa kāle pavattam nīla paṇṇa vaṇṇa kālam nīla paṇṇa vaṇṇa kāle
translated: The materiality occurring at the time of the dark of the moon occurs at the time of the bright of the moon. The materiality occurring at the time of the bright of the moon occurs at the time of the young of the moon.🔽The materiality occurring at the time of the young of the moon occurs at the time of the mature of the moon. The materiality occurring at the time of the mature of the moon occurs at the time of the green of the leaves.

original: pavattaṃ paṇḍupalāsakālaṃ. Paṇḍupalāsakāle pavattaṃ vaṇṭato chijjitvā patanakālaṃ
analyzed: pavattam paṇḍu palāsa kālam paṇḍu palāsa kāle pavattam vaṇṭataḥ chijjitvā patana kālam
translated: The materiality occurring at the time of the green of the leaves occurs at the time of the blue of the leaves. The materiality occurring at the time of the blue of the leaves occurs at the time of the withered leaves.

original: appatvāva nirujjhati, tasmā taṃ aniccaṃ dukkhamanattā”ti tilakkhaṇaṃ āropeti, evaṃ🔽tattha tilakkhaṇaṃ āropetvā iminā nayena sabbampi dhammatārūpaṃ sammasati.
analyzed: appa tvā ava nirujjhati tasmā tam aniccam dukkham anattā ati ti lakkhaṇam āropeti evam  tattha ti lakkhaṇam āropetvā iminā nayena sabbam pi dhamma tā rūpam sammasati
translated: The materiality occurring at the time of the withered leaves ceases without reaching the time of falling off from the stalk. Therefore it is impermanent, painful, not-self.” He attributes the three characteristics in this way.

original: Evaṃ tāva rūpasattakavasena tilakkhaṇaṃ āropetvā saṅkhāre sammasati.
analyzed: evam tāva rūpa sattaka vasena ti lakkhaṇam āropetvā saṅkhāre sammasati
translated: Having thus attributed the three characteristics in this way by means of the sevenfold base consisting of materiality, he comprehends formations in this way.

original: Arūpasattakasammasanakathā
analyzed: arūpa sattaka sammasana kathā
translated: Comprehension by means of the sevenfold base consisting of the immaterial

original: 717. Yaṃ pana vuttaṃ “arūpasattakavasenā”ti, tattha ayaṃ mātikā – kalāpato, yamakato, khaṇikato, paṭipāṭito, diṭṭhiugghāṭanato, mānasamugghāṭanato, nikantipariyādānatoti.
analyzed: yam pana vuttam arūpa sattaka vasena ati tattha ayam mātikā kalāpataḥ yamakataḥ khaṇikataḥ paṭipāṭitaḥ diṭṭhi ugghāṭanataḥ mānasam ugghāṭanataḥ nikanti pariyādānataḥ ti
translated: By groups, by pairs, by instants, by continuity, by turning upside down, by uprooting, by exhausting the attraction.🔽Herein, by groups: the five aggregates beginning with bodily form.

original: Tattha kalāpatoti phassapañcamakā dhammā. Kathaṃ kalāpato sammasatīti? Idha bhikkhu🔽iti paṭisañcikkhati – “ye ime ‘kesā aniccā dukkhā anattā’ti sammasane uppannā phassapañcamakā
analyzed: tattha kalāpato ti phassa pañcamakā dhammā katham kalāpato sammasati iti idha bhikkhu  iti paṭisañcikkhati ye ime kesāḥ aniccāḥ dukkhāḥ anattā ati sammasane uppannā phassa pañcamakā

translated: The five aggregates beginning with bodily form that arise and become dissolved in this way are impermanent, painful, not-self.

original: viya taṭataṭāyantā vinaṭṭhā, tasmā aniccā dukkhā anattā”ti. Ayaṃ tāva visuddhikathāyaṃ nayo.
analyzed: viya taṭataṭāyantā vinaṭṭhā tasmai aniccā dukkhā anattā ati ayam tāva visuddhi kathā ayam nayo
translated: All these things, without reaching beyond the impermanent, painful, not-self, are destroyed, worn away, their life is shortened, they decay and perish. Therefore they are impermanent, painful, not-self.” This is the method in the Visuddhimagga.

original: Ariyavaṃsakathāyaṃ pana “heṭṭhā rūpasattake sattasu ṭhānesu ‘rūpaṃ aniccaṃ dukkhamanattā’ti

original: ugghāṭitā hoti. Sattasaññaṃ ugghāṭitacittena saṅkhāre pariggaṇhato diṭṭhi nuppajjati.
