translated: “With the arising of ignorance there is the arising of material form”: he sees the rise of the materiality aggregate by the rise of its condition.🔽“With the arising of craving … With the arising of kamma … With the arising of nutriment there is the arising of material form”: he sees the rise of the materiality aggregate by the rise of its condition.

original: rūpakkhandhassa udayaṃ passati. Nibbattilakkhaṇaṃ passantopi rūpakkhandhassa udayaṃ
analyzed: rūpakkhandhassa udayam passati nibbatti lakkhaṇam passantaḥ api rūpakkhandhassa udayam
translated: And he sees the rise of the materiality aggregate by seeing the characteristic of generation.

original: passati. Rūpakkhandhassa udayaṃ passanto imāni pañca lakkhaṇāni passati.
analyzed: passati rūpakkhandhassa udayam passantaḥ imāni pañca lakkhaṇāni passati
translated: When he sees the rise of the materiality aggregate, he sees these five characteristics.

original: “Avijjānirodhā rūpanirodhoti paccayanirodhaṭṭhena rūpakkhandhassa vayaṃ passati.
analyzed: avijjā nirodhā rūpa nirodho ti paccaya nirodha ṭṭhena rūpa kkhandhassa vayam passati
translated: “With the cessation of ignorance there is the cessation of material form”: he sees the fall of the materiality aggregate by the cessation of its condition.

original: Taṇhānirodhā… kammanirodhā… āhāranirodhā rūpanirodhoti paccayanirodhaṭṭhena rūpakkhandhassa
analyzed: taṇhā nirodhā kamma nirodhā āhāra nirodhā rūpa nirodho ti paccaya nirodha ṭṭhena rūpa kkhandhassa
translated: “With the cessation of craving … With the cessation of kamma … With the cessation of nutriment there is the cessation of material form”: he sees the fall of the materiality aggregate by the cessation of its condition.

original: vayaṃ passati. Vipariṇāmalakkhaṇaṃ passantopi rūpakkhandhassa vayaṃ passati. Rūpakkhandhassa
analyzed: vayam passati vipariṇāma lakkhaṇam passantaḥ api rūpa kkhandhassa vayam passati rūpa kkhandhassa
translated: and he sees the sign of its change.🔽And when he sees the sign of its change, he sees the sign of the materiality aggregate’s passing away.

original: vayaṃ passantopi imāni pañca lakkhaṇāni passati”.🔽Tathā “avijjāsamudayā vedanāsamudayoti paccayasamudayaṭṭhena vedanākkhandhassa udayaṃ🔽passati. Taṇhāsamudayā… kammasamudayā… phassasamudayā vedanāsamudayoti paccayasamudayaṭṭhena
analyzed: vayam passantaḥ api imāni pañca lakkhaṇāni passati  tathā avijjā samudayā vedanā samudayo ti paccaya samudaya ṭṭhena vedanā kkhandhassa udayam  passati taṇhā samudayā kamma samudayā phassa samudayā vedanā samudayā ti paccaya samudaya ṭṭhena
translated: and he sees the rise of the materiality aggregate. Seeing the rise of the materiality aggregate, he sees these five characteristics.

original: vedanākkhandhassa udayaṃ passati. Nibbattilakkhaṇaṃ passantopi vedanākkhandhassa🔽udayaṃ passati. Vedanākkhandhassa udayaṃ passanto imāni pañca lakkhaṇāni passati.🔽Avijjānirodhā… taṇhānirodhā… kammanirodhā… phassanirodhā vedanānirodhoti paccayanirodhaṭṭhena
analyzed: vedanā khandhassa udayam passati nibbatti lakkhaṇam passantaḥ api vedanā khandhassa  udayam passati vedanā kkhandhassa udayam passanto imāni pañca lakkhaṇāni passati  avijjā nirodhā taṇhā nirodhā kamma nirodhā phassa nirodhā vedanā nirodho ti paccaya nirodha aṭṭhena
translated: “‘With the arising of ignorance there is the arising of feeling’: he sees the rise of the feeling aggregate by the method of condition for the arising of the feeling aggregate. ‘With the arising of craving … with the arising of kamma … with the arising of contact there is the arising of feeling’: he sees the rise of the feeling aggregate by the method of condition for the arising of the feeling aggregate. Seeing the characteristic of generation, he sees the rise of the feeling aggregate. Seeing the rise of the feeling aggregate, he sees these five characteristics.

original: vedanākkhandhassa vayaṃ passati. Vipariṇāmalakkhaṇaṃ passantopi vedanākkhandhassa
analyzed: vedanā khandhassa vayam passati vipariṇāma lakkhaṇam passantaḥ api vedanā khandhassa
translated: ‘With the cessation of ignorance there is the cessation of feeling’: he sees the fall of the feeling aggregate by the method of condition for the cessation of the feeling aggregate. ‘With the cessation of craving … with the cessation of kamma … with the cessation of contact there is the cessation of feeling’: he sees the fall of the feeling aggregate by the method of condition for the cessation of the feeling aggregate. Seeing the characteristic of change, he sees the fall of the feeling aggregate.🔽Seeing the fall of the feeling aggregate, he sees these five characteristics.”

original: vayaṃ passati. Vedanākkhandhassa vayaṃ passanto imāni pañca lakkhaṇāni passati”.
analyzed: vayam passati vedanā khandhassa vayam passantaḥ imāni pañca lakkhaṇāni passati
translated: He sees the arising of the feeling aggregate. He sees the passing away of the feeling aggregate. He sees the gratification in the feeling aggregate. He sees the danger in the feeling aggregate. He sees the escape from the feeling aggregate. “When he sees the arising and passing away of the feeling aggregate, he sees these five characteristics.”

original: Vedanākkhandhassa viya ca saññāsaṅkhāraviññāṇakkhandhānaṃ. Ayaṃ pana viseso, viññāṇakkhandhassa phassaṭṭhāne “nāmarūpasamudayā, nāmarūpanirodhā”ti –
analyzed: vedanā kkhandhassa viya ca saññā saṅkhāra viññāṇa kkhandhānam ayam pana visesaḥ viññāṇa kkhandhassa phassa ṭṭhāne nāma rūpa samudayā nāma rūpa nirodhā ti
translated: And so too in regard to the perception aggregate, the formations aggregate, and the consciousness aggregate. But there is this difference: in the place where contact is stated in the case of the feeling aggregate, “With the arising of contact there is the arising of the feeling aggregate” ,

original: Evaṃ ekekassa khandhassa udayabbayadassane dasa dasa katvā paññāsa lakkhaṇāni vuttāni.🔽Tesaṃ vasena evampi rūpassa udayo evampi rūpassa vayo, evampi rūpaṃ udeti, evampi
analyzed: evam ekekassa khandhassa udaya bbaya dassane dasa dasa katvā paññāsa lakkhaṇāni vuttāni  tesam vasena evam pi rūpassa udayaḥ evam pi rūpassa vayaḥ evam pi rūpam udeti evam pi
translated: Thus, by taking ten characteristics for each aggregate in the seeing of the arising and passing away of each aggregate, fifty characteristics are stated.🔽By means of them he gives his attention to form in detail as to how it arises through conditions and as to how it passes away through conditions,

original: rūpaṃ vetīti paccayato ceva khaṇato ca vitthārena manasikāraṃ karoti.🔽725. Tassevaṃ manasikaroto “iti kirime dhammā ahutvā sambhonti, hutvā paṭiventī”ti
analyzed: rūpam veti iti paccayataḥ ca iva khaṇataḥ ca vitthārena manasikāram karoti  tassa ivam manasikaroto iti kirime dhammā a hutvā sambhonti hutvā paṭiventi iti
translated: how it arises by moment and how it passes away by moment.🔽As he gives his attention to it in this way, his knowledge becomes clearer thus: “So these things, not having been, come into being; having been, they vanish again.”

original: ñāṇaṃ visadataraṃ hoti. Tassevaṃ paccayato ceva khaṇato ca dvedhā udayabbayaṃ passato
analyzed: ñāṇam visadataram hoti tassa ivam paccayataḥ ca iva khaṇataḥ ca dvedhā udaya bbayam passato
translated: As he sees the arising and passing away in two ways thus as to condition and as to moment,

original: saccapaṭiccasamuppādanayalakkhaṇabhedā pākaṭā honti.
analyzed: sacca paṭiccasamuppāda naya lakkhaṇa bhedāḥ pākaṭāḥ honti
translated: the characteristics of what is real, of dependent origination, and of the method become evident to him.

original: 726. Yañhi so avijjādisamudayā khandhānaṃ samudayaṃ, avijjādinirodhā ca khandhānaṃ🔽nirodhaṃ passati, idamassa paccayato udayabbayadassanaṃ. Yaṃ pana nibbattilakkhaṇavipariṇāmalakkhaṇāni🔽passanto khandhānaṃ udayabbayaṃ passati, idamassa khaṇato udayabbayadassanaṃ, uppattikkhaṇeyeva
analyzed: yat hi saḥ avijjā ādi samudayā khandhānam samudayam avijjā ādi nirodhā ca khandhānam  nirodham passati idam assa paccayataḥ udaya bbaya dassanam yam pana nibbatti lakkhaṇa vipariṇāma lakkhaṇāni  passantaḥ khandhānam udaya bbayam passati idam assa khaṇataḥ udaya bbaya dassanam uppatti khaṇeya eva
translated: When he sees the arising of the aggregates as the arising of ignorance, etc., and their cessation as the cessation of ignorance, etc., this is his seeing of arising and cessation according to condition. But when he sees the arising and falling away of the aggregates by seeing the characteristic of generation and the characteristic of dissolution, this is his seeing of arising and cessation according to instant.

original: hi nibbattilakkhaṇaṃ. Bhaṅgakkhaṇe ca vipariṇāmalakkhaṇaṃ.🔽727. Iccassevaṃ paccayato ceva khaṇato ca dvedhā udayabbayaṃ passato paccayato udayadassanena🔽samudayasaccaṃ pākaṭaṃ hoti janakāvabodhato. Khaṇato udayadassanena dukkhasaccaṃ🔽pākaṭaṃ hoti jātidukkhāvabodhato. Paccayato vayadassanena nirodhasaccaṃ pākaṭaṃ hoti
analyzed: hi nibbatti lakkhaṇam bhaṅga kkhaṇe ca vipariṇāma lakkhaṇam  iccassa ivam paccayataḥ ca iva khaṇataḥ ca dvedhā udaya bbayam passato paccayataḥ udaya dassanena  samudaya saccam pākaṭam hoti janaka avabodhataḥ khaṇataḥ udaya dassanena dukkha saccam  pākaṭam hoti jāti dukkha avabodhataḥ paccayataḥ vaya dassanena nirodha saccam pākaṭam hoti
translated: When he sees the arising of the aggregates as the arising of ignorance, etc., and their cessation as the cessation of ignorance, etc., this is his seeing of rise and fall by way of condition. But when he sees the rise and fall of the aggregates by seeing the characteristic of generation and the characteristic of dissolution, this is his seeing of rise and fall by way of instant. For the characteristic of generation is only the instant of arising, and the characteristic of dissolution is only the instant of dissolution.

original: paccayānuppādena paccayavataṃ anuppādāvabodhato. Khaṇato vayadassanena dukkhasaccameva
analyzed: paccaya anuppādena paccayavatam anuppāda avabodhato khaṇataḥ vaya dassanena dukkha saccam eva
translated: So when he sees rise and fall in two ways, by way of condition and by way of instant, then by seeing rise by way of condition the truth of suffering becomes evident to him through the understanding of the suffering of birth. By seeing rise by way of instant the truth of suffering becomes evident to him through the understanding of the suffering of birth. By seeing fall by way of condition the truth of cessation becomes evident to him through the understanding of the non-arising of the conditioned by the non-occurrence of conditions. By seeing fall by way of instant the truth of suffering itself becomes evident to him through the understanding of the suffering of death.

original: pākaṭaṃ hoti maraṇadukkhāvabodhato. Yañcassa udayabbayadassanaṃ, maggovāyaṃ lokikoti🔽maggasaccaṃ pākaṭaṃ hoti tatra sammohavighātato.🔽728. Paccayato cassa udayadassanena anulomo paṭiccasamuppādo pākaṭo hoti, “imasmiṃ
analyzed: pākaṭam hoti maraṇa dukkha avabodhataḥ yat ca assa udaya bbaya dassanam magga uvāyam lokika uti  magga saccam pākaṭam hoti tatra sammoha vighātato  paccayataḥ ca ssa udaya dassanena anulomaḥ paṭiccasamuppādaḥ pākaṭaḥ hoti imasmin
translated: because he has understood the suffering of death. And the Path is clear to him as the Truth of the Path because he has no more confusion about it.

original: sati idaṃ hotī”ti avabodhato. Paccayato vayadassanena paṭilomo paṭiccasamuppādo pākaṭo
analyzed: sati idam hoti iti avabodhataḥ paccayataḥ vaya dassanena paṭilomaḥ paṭiccasamuppādaḥ pākaṭaḥ
translated: And the arising of the dependent origination is clear to him by his seeing the arising of suffering, because he has understood “When this exists, that comes to be” .

original: hoti, “imassa nirodhā idaṃ nirujjhatī”ti avabodhato. Khaṇato pana udayabbayadassanena
analyzed: hoti imassa nirodhā idam nirujjhati iti avabodhataḥ khaṇataḥ pana udaya bbaya dassanena
translated: And the cessation of the dependent origination is clear to him by his seeing the cessation of suffering, because he has understood “With the cessation of this, that ceases” .

original: paṭiccasamuppannā dhammā pākaṭā honti saṅkhatalakkhaṇāvabodhato. Udayabbayavanto
analyzed: paṭicca samuppannāḥ dhammāḥ pākaṭāḥ honti saṅkhata lakkhaṇa avabodhataḥ udaya bbayavanto
translated: And the dependently- arisen states are clear to him by his seeing the arising and falling away of the aggregates, because he has understood the characteristic of the formed.

original: hi saṅkhatā, te ca paṭiccasamuppannāti.🔽729. Paccayato cassa udayadassanena ekattanayo pākaṭo hoti hetuphalasambandhena santānassa
analyzed: hi saṅkhatā te ca paṭicca samuppannā ti  paccayataḥ ca ssa udaya dassanena eka ttanayaḥ pākaṭaḥ hoti hetu phala sambandhena santānassa
translated: For what has arising and falling away is formed, and that is dependently arisen.

original: anupacchedāvabodhato. Atha suṭṭhutaraṃ ucchedadiṭṭhiṃ pajahati. Khaṇato udayadassanena
analyzed: an upaccheda avabodhataḥ atha suṭṭhutaram uccheda diṭṭhim pajahati khaṇataḥ udaya dassanena
translated: And the method of unity is clear to him by his seeing the arising of suffering through conditions, because he has understood the continuity’s non-interruption by the connection of cause and fruit. Then he abandons the annihilation view all the more thoroughly.🔽And the method of diversity is clear to him by his seeing the arising of suffering through conditions, because he has understood the diversity of the continuity’s direction by the diversity of conditions. Then he abandons the eternity view all the more thoroughly.

original: nānattanayo pākaṭo hoti navanavānaṃ uppādāvabodhato. Atha suṭṭhutaraṃ sassatadiṭṭhiṃ🔽pajahati. Paccayato cassa udayabbayadassanena abyāpāranayo pākaṭo hoti dhammānaṃ🔽avasavattibhāvāvabodhato. Atha suṭṭhutaraṃ attadiṭṭhiṃ pajahati. Paccayato pana udayadassanena
analyzed: nānat tanayaḥ pākaṭaḥ hoti nava navānam uppāda avabodhataḥ atha suṭṭhutaram sassata diṭṭhim  pajahati paccayataḥ ca ssa udaya bbaya dassanena a byāpāra nayaḥ pākaṭaḥ hoti dhammānam  avasavatti bhāva avabodhataḥ atha suṭṭhutaram atta diṭṭhim pajahati paccayataḥ pana udaya dassanena
translated: The mode of non-eternality becomes evident to him with the understanding of the arising of new and new states. Then he abandons the eternalist view more thoroughly.🔽The mode of non-afflictive- ness becomes evident to him with the seeing of arising and falling in terms of conditions, with the understanding of the non-mastery of states. Then he abandons the self-theorist view more thoroughly.

original: evaṃdhammatānayo pākaṭo hoti paccayānurūpena phalassa uppādāvabodhato. Atha suṭṭhutaraṃ🔽akiriyadiṭṭhiṃ pajahati.🔽730. Paccayato cassa udayadassanena anattalakkhaṇaṃ pākaṭaṃ hoti dhammānaṃ nirīhakattapaccayapaṭibaddhavuttitāvabodhato.
analyzed: evaṃdhammatā anayaḥ pākaṭaḥ hoti paccaya anurūpena phalassa uppāda avabodhataḥ atha suṭṭhutaram  a kiriya diṭṭhim pajahati  paccayataḥ ca ssa udaya dassanena anatta lakkhaṇam pākaṭam hoti dhammānam nirīhaka tta paccaya paṭibaddha vutti tā avabodhato
translated: The mode of natural law becomes evident to him with the seeing of arising in terms of conditions, with the understanding of the arising of the fruit in accordance with the conditions. Then he abandons the view of nihilism more thoroughly.🔽The characteristic of non-self becomes evident to him with the seeing of arising in terms of conditions, with the understanding of the occurrence of states as dependent on conditions without any controller.

original: Khaṇato udayabbayadassanena aniccalakkhaṇaṃ pākaṭaṃ hoti hutvā abhāvāvabodhato, pubbantāparantavivekāvabodhato
analyzed: khaṇataḥ udaya bbaya dassanena anicca lakkhaṇam pākaṭam hoti hutvā abhāva avabodhataḥ pubbanta aparanta viveka avabodhataḥ
translated: The characteristic of impermanence becomes evident to him with the seeing of arising and falling, with the understanding of non-existence after having been, and with the understanding of the separation of the past and future.

original: ca. Dukkhalakkhaṇampi pākaṭaṃ hoti udayabbayehi paṭipīḷanāvabodhato. Sabhāvalakkhaṇampi
analyzed: ca dukkha lakkhaṇam pi pākaṭam hoti udaya bbayehi paṭipīḷana avabodhato sabhāva lakkhaṇam pi
translated: The characteristic of pain also becomes evident to him with the understanding of oppression by arising and falling. The characteristic of individual essence becomes evident to him with the understanding of the individual essences of the states.

original: pākaṭaṃ hoti udayabbayaparicchinnāvabodhato. Sabhāvalakkhaṇe saṅkhatalakkhaṇassa
analyzed: pākaṭam hoti udaya bbaya paricchinna avabodhataḥ sabhāva lakkhaṇe saṅkhata lakkhaṇassa
translated: and the fact that it is impermanent is evident because of the knowledge that it is limited by rise and fall.

original: tāvakālikattampi pākaṭaṃ hoti udayakkhaṇe vayassa, vayakkhaṇe ca udayassa abhāvāvabodhatoti.🔽731. Tassevaṃ pākaṭībhūtasaccapaṭiccasamuppādanayalakkhaṇabhedassa “evaṃ kira nāmime
analyzed: tāvakālika ttam pi pākaṭam hoti udaya khaṇe vayassa vaya khaṇe ca udayassa abhāva avabodhato ti  tassa ivam pākaṭībhūta sacca paṭiccasamuppāda naya lakkhaṇa bhedassa evam kira nāma ime
translated: And the fact that it is unstable is evident because of the knowledge that at the moment of its rise there is fall, and at the moment of its fall there is no rise.

original: dhammā anuppannapubbā uppajjanti, uppannā nirujjhantī”ti niccanavāva hutvā saṅkhārā🔽upaṭṭhahanti. Na kevalañca niccanavā, sūriyuggamane ussāvabindu viya udakabubbuḷo🔽viya udake daṇḍarāji viya āragge sāsapo viya vijjuppādo viya ca parittaṭṭhāyino.🔽Māyāmarīcisupinantaalātacakkagandhabbanagarapheṇakadaliādayo viya assārā nissārāti cāpi upaṭṭhahanti.
analyzed: dhammāḥ an uppanna pubbāḥ uppajjanti uppannāḥ nirujjhanti iti hutvā saṅkhārā  upaṭṭhahanti na kevalam ca nicca navā sūri yuggamane ussāva bindu viya udaka bubbuḷaḥ  viya udake daṇḍa rāji viya āragge sāsapaḥ viya vijjuppādaḥ viya ca paritta ṭṭhāyinaḥ  māyā marīci supi nanta alāta cakka gandhabba nagara pheṇaka dali ādayaḥ ca api upaṭṭhahanti
translated: When the characteristics of rise and fall have thus become evident in the case of the aggregates, which are the basis for the knowledge of rise and fall, and in the case of the dependent origination, which is the object of the knowledge of origination and cessation, the formations appear to him as “newly arisen” and “newly arisen,” being newly arisen and ceasing in this way, and as “newly arisen” and “newly arisen,” being newly arisen and ceasing in that way.

original: Ettāvatānena “vayadhammameva uppajjati, uppannañca vayaṃ upetī”ti iminā ākārena samapaññāsa
analyzed: ettāvatā anena vaya dhammam eva uppajjati uppannam ca vayam upeti iti iminā ākārena samapaññāsa
translated: And not only as “newly arisen,” but also as “of brief duration,” like a bubble of water, like a drop of dew, like a flash of lightning, like a line drawn on water, like a mustard seed placed on an awl, like a dog’s mouthful of food, like a stroke of the thunderbolt, like a puppet made to move by strings, like a monkey in a dream, like a city of gandhabbas, like a mirage, like a conjuring trick, like a reflected image, like a loan, like a stage performance, like a dream, like a flash of lightning, like a water bubble, like a mustard seed on the point of an awl, like a dog’s mouthful of food, like a stroke of the thunderbolt, like a puppet made to move by strings, like a monkey in a dream, like a city of gandhabbas, like a mirage, like a conjuring trick, like a reflected image, like a loan, like a stage performance, like a dream, like a flash of lightning, like a water bubble, like a mustard seed on the point of an awl, like a dog’s mouthful of food, like a stroke of the thunderbolt, like a puppet made to move by strings, like a monkey in a dream, like a city of gandhabbas, like a mirage, like a conjuring trick, like a reflected image, like a loan, like a stage performance, like a dream, like a flash of lightning, like a water bubble, like a mustard seed on the point of an awl, like a dog’s mouthful of food, like a stroke of the thunderbolt, like a puppet made to move by strings, like

original: lakkhaṇāni paṭivijjhitvā ṭhitaṃ udayabbayānupassanaṃ nāma taruṇavipassanāñāṇaṃ adhigataṃ
analyzed: lakkhaṇāni paṭivijjhitvā ṭhitam udaya bbaya anupassanam nāma taruṇa vipassanā ñāṇam adhigatam
translated: Understanding that has arisen in this way, and which is called “contemplation of rise and fall,” is called “newly-begotten insight knowledge.”

original: hoti, yassādhigamā āraddhavipassakoti saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
analyzed: hoti yassa adhigamā āraddha vipassakaḥ ti saṅkham gacchati
translated: When it has been reached, he is called “one who has begun insight.”

original: Vipassanupakkilesakathā🔽732. Athassa imāya taruṇavipassanāya āraddhavipassakassa dasa vipassanupakkilesā🔽uppajjanti. Vipassanupakkilesā hi paṭivedhappattassa ariyasāvakassa ceva vippaṭipannakassa
analyzed: vipassanā upakkilesa kathā  athassa imāya taruṇa vipassanāya āraddha vipassakassa dasa vipassanu pakkilesā  uppajjanti vipassanu pakkilesāḥ hi paṭivedha ppattassa ariyasāvakassa ca iva vippaṭipannakassa
translated: The ten imperfections of insight🔽Now, ten imperfections of insight arise in one who has begun insight in this way.

original: ca nikkhittakammaṭṭhānassa kusītapuggalassa nuppajjanti. Sammāpaṭipannakassa pana
analyzed: ca nikkhitta kammaṭṭhānassa kusīta puggalassa nu pajjanti sammāpaṭipannakassa pana
translated: For these imperfections of insight do not arise in a noble disciple who has reached penetration or in one who has given up the meditation subject or in one who is lazy.

original: yuttapayuttassa āraddhavipassakassa kulaputtassa uppajjantiyeva.
analyzed: yutta payuttassa āraddha vipassakassa kula puttassa uppajjantiyā iva
translated: But they arise only in a clansman who is diligent and who is rightly applying himself to insight.🔽What are the ten? They are illumination, knowledge, rapturous happiness, tranquillity, bliss, resolution, exertion, steadiness, equanimity, and desire.

original: Katame pana te dasa upakkilesāti? Obhāso, ñāṇaṃ, pīti, passaddhi, sukhaṃ, adhimokkho, paggaho, upaṭṭhānaṃ, upekkhā, nikantīti. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: katame pana te dasa upakkilesā ti obhāsaḥ ñāṇam pīti passaddhi sukham adhimokkhaḥ paggahaḥ upaṭṭhānam upekkhā nikanti iti vuttam ha etam
translated: For this is said:

original: “Kathaṃ dhammuddhaccaviggahitamānasaṃ hoti? Aniccato manasikaroto obhāso uppajjati,
analyzed: katham dhamma uddhacca viggahita mānasam hoti aniccataḥ manasikarotaḥ obhāsaḥ uppajjati
translated: “How is his mind seized by agitation about ideas? When he is bringing to mind as impermanent, a light arises in him.

original: ‘obhāso dhammo’ti obhāsaṃ āvajjati, tato vikkhepo uddhaccaṃ. Tena uddhaccena viggahitamānaso
analyzed: obhāsaḥ dhammaḥ ti obhāsam āvajjati tatas vikkhepaḥ uddhaccam tena uddhaccena viggahita mānasaḥ
translated: He adverts to the light as ‘light idea’, and then there is distraction and agitation. With that agitation his mind is seized by distraction.

original: aniccato upaṭṭhānaṃ yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti. Dukkhato… anattato upaṭṭhānaṃ yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti”.🔽Tathā “aniccato manasikaroto ñāṇaṃ uppajjati…pe… pīti… passaddhi… sukhaṃ… adhimokkho…
analyzed: aniccataḥ upaṭṭhānam yathābhūtam na pajānāti dukkhataḥ anattataḥ upaṭṭhānam yathābhūtam na pajānāti  tathā aniccataḥ manasikarotaḥ ñāṇam uppajjati pe pīti passaddhi sukham adhimokkhaḥ
translated: He does not understand as it actually is the appearance of the sign as impermanent. He does not understand as it actually is the appearance of the sign as painful. He does not understand as it actually is the appearance of the sign as not-self” .

original: paggaho… upaṭṭhānaṃ… upekkhā… nikanti uppajjati, ‘nikanti dhammo’ti nikantiṃ āvajjati,🔽tato vikkhepo uddhaccaṃ. Tena uddhaccena viggahitamānaso aniccato upaṭṭhānaṃ yathābhūtaṃ🔽nappajānāti. Dukkhato… anattato upaṭṭhānaṃ yathābhūtaṃ nappajānātī”ti.
analyzed: paggahaḥ upaṭṭhānam upekkhā nikanti uppajjati nikanti dhammo ti nikantim āvajjati  tatas vikkhepaḥ uddhaccam tena uddhaccena viggahita mānasaḥ aniccataḥ upaṭṭhānam yathābhūtam  na ppajānāti dukkhataḥ anattataḥ upaṭṭhānam yathābhūtam na ppajānāti iti
translated: Similarly, “When he is bringing to mind as impermanent, knowledge arises in him … and so on with the rest of the list up to … he does not understand as it actually is the appearance of the sign as not-self” .

original: 733. Tattha obhāsoti vipassanobhāso. Tasmiṃ uppanne yogāvacaro “na vata me ito pubbe
analyzed: tattha obhāsaḥ ti vipassanā ubhāsaḥ tasmin uppanne yogāvacaraḥ na vata me itas pubbe
translated: Herein, light is insight light. When it arises in him, the meditator thinks, “Never before have I seen such light as this.

original: evarūpo obhāso uppannapubbo, addhā maggappattosmi phalapattosmī”ti amaggameva “maggo”ti,
analyzed: evarūpaḥ obhāsaḥ uppanna pubbaḥ addhā magga ppattaḥ asmi phala pattaḥ asmi iti amaggam eva maggo ti
translated: “Such a light has arisen before. Surely I have attained the path, I have attained the fruit.” He takes what is not the path to be the path and

original: aphalameva ca “phala”nti gaṇhāti. Tassa amaggaṃ “maggo”ti aphalaṃ “phala”nti gaṇhato
analyzed: aphalam eva ca phalanti gaṇhāti tassa amaggam maggoti aphalam phalanti gaṇhato
translated: what is not the fruit to be the fruit.

original: vipassanāvīthi ukkantā nāma hoti. So attano mūlakammaṭṭhānaṃ vissajjetvā obhāsameva assādento nisīdati.
analyzed: vipassanāvīthi ukkantā nāma hoti so attanaḥ mūlakammaṭṭhānam vissajjetvā obhāsam eva assādentaḥ nisīdati
translated: When he does so, his insight process is said to have “fallen away.” He abandons his basic meditation subject and sits just enjoying the light.

original: So kho panāyaṃ obhāso kassaci bhikkhuno pallaṅkaṭṭhānamattameva obhāsento uppajjati.
analyzed: saḥ kho pana ayam obhāsaḥ kassaci bhikkhuno pallaṅka ṭṭhāna mattam eva obhāsentaḥ uppajjati
translated: This light arises in some bhikkhu just enough to illuminate the place where he is sitting.

original: Kassaci antogabbhaṃ. Kassaci bahigabbhampi. Kassaci sakalavihāraṃ, gāvutaṃ, aḍḍhayojanaṃ,
analyzed: kassaci antogabbham kassaci bahigabbham pi kassaci sakalavihāram gāvutam aḍḍha yojanam
translated: In another it illuminates the interior of the house. In another the interior of the house and the outside as well. In another the whole monastery, a gāvuta, a half-yojana,

original: yojanaṃ, dviyojanaṃ, tiyojanaṃ…pe… kassaci pathavītalato yāva akaniṭṭhabrahmalokā
analyzed: yojanam dvi yojanam ti yojanam pe kassaci pathavī talataḥ yāva akaniṭṭha brahma lokā
translated: a yojana, two or three yojanas … In another it illuminates the whole earth from the ocean’s edge to the rim of the world-sphere.

original: ekālokaṃ kurumāno. Bhagavato pana dasasahassilokadhātuṃ obhāsento udapādi.
analyzed: ekālokam kurumānaḥ bhagavataḥ pana dasa sahassi lokadhātum obhāsentaḥ udapādi
translated: In the Blessed One it arose illuminating the ten-thousandfold world system.

original: Evaṃ vemattatāya cassa idaṃ vatthu – cittalapabbate kira dvikuṭṭagehassa anto dve
analyzed: evam vemattatāya ca ssa idam vatthu cittalapabbate kira dvi kuṭṭa gehassa antaḥ dve
translated: The following story illustrates the diversity of this light. Two bhikkhus were living in a two-storied dwelling on the Cittalapabbata.

original: therā nisīdiṃsu. Taṃdivasañca kāḷapakkhuposatho hoti, meghapaṭalacchannā disā, rattibhāge🔽caturaṅgasamannāgataṃ tamaṃ pavattati. Atheko thero āha – “bhante, mayhaṃ idāni cetiyaṅgaṇamhi
analyzed: therāḥ nisīdiṃsu taṃ divasam ca kāḷa pakkha uposathaḥ hoti megha paṭala channāḥ disāḥ ratti bhāge  catur aṅga samannāgatam tamam pavattati atha ikaḥ theraḥ āha bhante mayham idāni
translated: The elders sat down. It was the Uposatha day of the dark fortnight, and the directions were covered with a network of clouds.🔽In the night

original: sīhāsane pañcavaṇṇāni kusumāni paññāyantī”ti. Taṃ itaro āha – “anacchariyaṃ, āvuso,
analyzed: sīhāsane pañcavaṇṇāni kusumāni paññāyanti iti tam itaraḥ āha anacchariyam āvuso
translated: a four-ingredient darkness spread. Then one elder said, “Venerable sir, I now see five-coloured flowers on the lion throne in the shrine terrace.” The other said, “It is not wonderful, friend,

original: kathesi, mayhaṃ panetarahi mahāsamuddamhi yojanaṭṭhāne macchakacchapā paññāyantī”ti.🔽Ayaṃ pana vipassanupakkileso yebhuyyena samathavipassanālābhino uppajjati. So samāpattivikkhambhitānaṃ
analyzed: kathesi mayham pana itarahi mahā samuddamhi yojana ṭṭhāne maccha kacchapā paññāyanti iti  ayam pana vipassanā upakkilesaḥ yebhuyyena samatha vipassanā lābhinaḥ uppajjati saḥ samāpatti vikkhambhitānam
translated: that you say this. But I now see fish and turtles a league away in the ocean.”

original: kilesānaṃ asamudācārato “arahā aha”nti cittaṃ uppādeti uccavālikavāsī mahānāgatthero🔽viya haṃkanakavāsī mahādattatthero viya cittalapabbate niṅkapeṇṇakapadhānagharavāsī
analyzed: kilesānam asamudācārataḥ arahā cittam uppādeti uccavālika vāsī mahānāga tthero  viya haṃkanaka vāsī mahādatta theraḥ viya cittala pabbate niṅka peṇṇaka padhāna ghara vāsī
translated: But this defilement of insight usually arises in one who has attained serenity and insight. He thinks, “I am an Arahant” because the defilements that have been suppressed by the attainment do not occur.🔽The elder Uccāvālika-vāsi, the elder Mahānāga,

original: cūḷasumanatthero viya ca.
analyzed: cūḷasumanattheraḥ ca
translated: the elder Mahādattatthero, the elder Cūḷasumanatthero.

original: Tatridaṃ ekavatthuparidīpanaṃ – talaṅgaravāsī dhammadinnatthero kira nāma eko pabhinnapaṭisambhido
analyzed: tatra idam eka vatthu paridīpanam talaṅgara vāsī dhammadinna theraḥ kira nāma ekaḥ pabhinna paṭisambhidaḥ
translated: Here is an illustration. A certain Elder named Dhammadinna, it seems, who lived at Talangara, was a master of the texts.

original: mahākhīṇāsavo mahato bhikkhusaṅghassa ovādadāyako ahosi. So ekadivasaṃ attano divāṭṭhāne
analyzed: mahākhīṇāsavaḥ mahataḥ bhikkhu saṅghassa ovāda dāyakaḥ ahosi saḥ eka divasam attanaḥ divāṭṭhāne
translated: Here is an illustration. The Elder Dhammadinna, it seems, who lived at Taḷaṅgara, was a master of the analytical knowledges and a great arahant. He was a teacher of a large community of bhikkhus. One day, while sitting in his day-quarters,

original: nisīditvā “kinnu kho amhākaṃ ācariyassa uccavālikavāsīmahānāgattherassa samaṇabhāvakiccaṃ
analyzed: nisīditvā kinnu kho amhākam ācariyassa uccavālika vāsī mahānāga ttherassa samaṇa bhāva kiccam
translated: he asked himself, “Has the task of a recluse been accomplished by our teacher, the Elder Mahā-Nāga, who lived at Uccavālika? ”

original: matthakaṃ pattaṃ, no”ti āvajjanto puthujjanabhāvamevassa disvā “mayi agacchante puthujjanakālakiriyameva
analyzed: matthakam pattam no ti āvajjantaḥ puthujjana bhāvam eva assa disvā mayi agacchante puthujjana kālakiriyam eva
translated: He saw that he was still an ordinary man. He thought, “If I do not go to him, he will die an ordinary man’s death.”

original: karissatī”ti ca ñatvā iddhiyā vehāsaṃ uppatitvā divāṭṭhāne nisinnassa therassa samīpe🔽orohitvā vanditvā vattaṃ dassetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. “Kiṃ, āvuso dhammadinna, akāle🔽āgatosī”ti ca vutte “pañhaṃ, bhante, pucchituṃ āgatomhī”ti āha. Tato “pucchāvuso,
analyzed: karissati iti ca ñatvā iddhiyā vehāsam uppatitvā divāṭṭhāne nisinnassa therassa samīpe  orohitvā vanditvā vattam dassetvā ekamantam nisīdi kim āvuso dhammadinna akāle  āgataḥ asi iti ca vutte pañham bhante pucchitum āgataḥ amhi iti āha tatas puccha avuso
translated: So he rose up in the air by his psychic power, alighted near the elder, who was sitting in his day-quarters,🔽and after paying homage to him, he sat down. “Why have you come at this time, friend Dhammadinna? ” he was asked. “Venerable sir, I have come to ask a question.”

original: jānamānā kathayissāmā”ti vutte pañhasahassaṃ pucchi.
analyzed: jānamānā kathayissāma ati vutte pañha sahassam pucchi
translated: Then, when he was told, “Ask, friend, if you have any question, and we shall tell you what you ask,” he asked a thousand questions.

original: Thero pucchitapucchitaṃ asajjamānova kathesi. Tato “atitikkhaṃ vo, bhante, ñāṇaṃ,
analyzed: thero pucchita pucchitam a sajjamānaḥ iva kathesi tatas atitikkham vaḥ bhante ñāṇam
translated: The Elder answered all the questions without hesitation. Then the king said, “Your knowledge is very keen, venerable sir.

original: kadā tumhehi ayaṃ dhammo adhigato”ti vutte “ito saṭṭhivassakāle, āvuso”ti āha. Samādhimpi,🔽bhante, vaḷañjethāti, na yidaṃ, āvuso, bhāriyanti. Tena hi, bhante, ekaṃ hatthiṃ🔽māpethāti. Thero sabbasetaṃ hatthiṃ māpesi. Idāni, bhante, yathā ayaṃ hatthī añcitakaṇṇo
analyzed: kadā tumhehi ayam dhammaḥ adhigataḥ ti vutte itas saṭṭhivassa kāle āvuso ti āha samādhim pi  bhante vaḷañjetha ati na āvuso tena hi bhante ekam hatthim  māpetha ati theraḥ sabbasetam hatthim māpesi idāni bhante yathā ayam hatthī añcita kaṇṇaḥ
translated: When did you attain this knowledge?” “Sixty years ago, friend.”🔽“Venerable sir, you have a very keen concentration of mind.🔽” “No, friend, it is not difficult for one who is free from the Depravities.” “Well then, venerable sir, make a single elephant appear.”

original: pasāritanaṅguṭṭho soṇḍaṃ mukhe pakkhipitvā bheravaṃ koñcanādaṃ karonto tumhākaṃ abhimukho🔽āgacchati, tathā naṃ karothāti. Thero tathā katvā vegena āgacchato hatthissa bheravaṃ
analyzed: pasārita naṅguṭṭhaḥ soṇḍam mukhe pakkhipitvā bheravam koñca nādam karonto tumhākam abhimukhaḥ  āgacchati tathā nam karotha ati theraḥ tathā katvā vegena āgacchataḥ hatthissa bheravam
translated: The Elder made a white elephant appear. “Now, venerable sir, make the elephant come toward us with its ears pricked, its trunk extended, trumpeting fiercely.”

original: ākāraṃ disvā uṭṭhāya palāyituṃ āraddho. Tamenaṃ khīṇāsavatthero hatthaṃ pasāretvā
analyzed: ākāram disvā uṭṭhāya palāyitum āraddhaḥ tam enam khīṇāsava theraḥ hattham pasāretvā
translated: The Elder did so. When the king saw the fierce appearance of the elephant coming on with speed, he got up to flee.

original: cīvarakaṇṇe gahetvā “bhante, khīṇāsavassa sārajjaṃ nāma hotī”ti āha.
analyzed: cīvara kaṇṇe gahetvā bhante khīṇāsavassa sārajjam nāma hoti iti āha
translated: The Elder who was a perfected being extended his hand, seized the corner of the Elder’s robe, and said, “Venerable sir, one who is free from the Depravities is not afraid.”

original: So tamhi kāle attano puthujjanabhāvaṃ ñatvā “avassayo me, āvuso, dhammadinna hohī”ti
analyzed: saḥ tamhi kāle attanaḥ puthujjana bhāvam ñatvā avassayaḥ me āvuso dhammadinna hohi iti
translated: At that moment he realized that he was still an ordinary man. He said: “Friend Dhammadinna, be my refuge.”

original: vatvā pādamūle ukkuṭikaṃ nisīdi. “Bhante, tumhākaṃ avassayo bhavissāmiccevāhaṃ āgato,
analyzed: vatvā pāda mūle ukkuṭikam nisīdi bhante tumhākam avassayaḥ bhavissāmi icca iva aham āgataḥ
translated: He sat down at the elder’s feet and said: “Venerable sir, I have come to you to be your pupil.

original: mā cintayitthā”ti kammaṭṭhānaṃ kathesi. Thero kammaṭṭhānaṃ gahetvā caṅkamaṃ āruyha
analyzed: mā cintayittha ati kammaṭṭhānam kathesi thero kammaṭṭhānam gahetvā caṅkamaṃ āruyha
translated: Do not worry about me.” The elder taught him a meditation subject. The elder took up the meditation subject and went to the walk.

original: tatiye padavāre aggaphalaṃ arahattaṃ pāpuṇi. Thero kira dosacarito ahosi. Evarūpā
analyzed: tatiye pada vāre agga phalam arahattam pāpuṇi theraḥ kira dosa caritaḥ ahosi evarūpā
translated: In the third watch of the night he reached Arahantship, the supreme fruit. The elder was of a bilious temperament.

original: bhikkhū obhāse kampanti.
analyzed: bhikkhū obhāse kampanti
translated: Monks of this kind tremble in the radiance.

original: 734. Ñāṇanti vipassanāñāṇaṃ. Tassa kira rūpārūpadhamme tulayantassa tīrentassa vissaṭṭhaindavajiramiva avihatavegaṃ tikhiṇaṃ sūraṃ ativisadaṃ ñāṇaṃ uppajjati.
analyzed: ñāṇanti vipassanā ñāṇam tassa kira rūpa arūpa dhamme tulayantassa tīrentassa vissaṭṭha aindava jiram iva avihata vegam tikhiṇam sūram ati visadam ñāṇam uppajjati
translated: Knowledge: insight knowledge. It is said of him that when he was weighing and testing material and immaterial states, his knowledge arose as keen, sharp, and clear as a polished razor-blade, with irresistible force.

original: Pītīti vipassanāpīti. Tassa kira tasmiṃ samaye khuddakāpīti, khaṇikāpīti, okkantikāpīti, ubbegāpīti, pharaṇāpītīti ayaṃ pañcavidhā pīti sakalasarīraṃ pūrayamānā uppajjati.
analyzed: pīti iti vipassanā api iti tassa kira tasmin samaye khuddakā api iti khaṇikā api iti okkantikā api iti ubbegā api iti pharaṇā api iti iti ayam pañcavidhā pīti sakala sarīram pūrayamānā uppajjati
translated: Rapture: insight rapture. It is said of him that at that time the fivefold rapture, namely, minor, momentary, showering, uplifting, and pervading rapture, arose in him filling his whole body.

original: Passaddhīti vipassanāpassaddhi. Tassa kira tasmiṃ samaye rattiṭṭhāne vā divāṭṭhāne
analyzed: passaddhi iti vipassanā passaddhi tassa kira tasmin samaye ratti ṭṭhāne vā divāṭṭhāne
translated: Tranquillity is insight-tranquillity. It seems that when he is sitting in his night quarters or day quarters,

original: vā nisinnassa kāyacittānaṃ neva daratho, na gāravaṃ, na kakkhaḷatā, na akammaññatā,🔽na gelaññaṃ, na vaṅkatā hoti, atha kho panassa kāyacittāni passaddhāni lahūni mudūni
analyzed: vā nisinnassa kāya cittānam na iva darathaḥ na gāravam na kakkhaḷa tā na akammañña tā  na gelaññam na vaṅka tā hoti atha kho panassa kāya cittāni passaddhāni lahūni mudūni
translated: his body and mind are not sluggish, heavy, unwieldy, or disinclined to function,🔽but rather his body is tranquil, light, wieldy, and unwearied, and his mind is tranquil, clear, and inclined to function.

original: kammaññāni suvisadāni ujukāniyeva honti. So imehi passaddhādīhi anuggahitakāyacitto
analyzed: kammaññāni su visadāni ujukāniyā iva honti saḥ imehi passaddha ādīhi an uggahita kāya citto
translated: When his body and mind are assisted by this tranquillity,

original: tasmiṃ samaye amānusiṃ nāma ratiṃ anubhavati. Yaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ –
analyzed: tasmin samaye amānusim nāma ratim anubhavati yam sandhāya vuttam
translated: he experiences a kind of happiness on that occasion which is called “divine” . It is said of him:

original: “Suññāgāraṃ paviṭṭhassa, santacittassa bhikkhuno;
analyzed: suññāgāram paviṭṭhassa santa cittassa bhikkhuno
translated: “When a bhikkhu enters his empty house,

original: Amānusī rati hoti, sammā dhammaṃ vipassato.
analyzed: amānusī rati hoti sammā dhammam vipassato
translated: And his mind is peaceful as he contemplates the Dhamma,🔽Then he finds delight in that attainment,🔽And he knows that to be deathless.

original: “Yato yato sammasati, khandhānaṃ udayabbayaṃ;
analyzed: yatas yatas sammasati khandhānam udaya bbayam
translated: “Wherever he sees the arising and falling🔽Of the aggregates, he finds joy and happiness,

original: Labhatī pītipāmojjaṃ, amataṃ taṃ vijānata”nti. ;
analyzed: labhatī pīti pāmojjam amatam tam
translated: And he knows that to be deathless” .

original: Evamassa imaṃ amānusiṃ ratiṃ sādhayamānā lahutādisampayuttā passaddhi uppajjati.
analyzed: evam assa imam amānusim ratim sādhayamānā lahu tā ādi sampayuttā passaddhi uppajjati
translated: Thus tranquillity arises in him associated with lightness, etc., and it accomplishes this kind of divine happiness.

original: Sukhanti vipassanāsukhaṃ. Tassa kira tasmiṃ samaye sakalasarīraṃ abhisandayamānaṃ atipaṇītaṃ sukhaṃ uppajjati.🔽Adhimokkhoti saddhā. Vipassanāsampayuttāyeva hissa cittacetasikānaṃ atisayapasādabhūtā balavatī saddhā uppajjati.
analyzed: sukhanti vipassanā sukham tassa kira tasmin samaye sakala sarīram abhisandayamānam atipaṇītam sukham uppajjati  adhimokkhaḥ ti saddhā vipassanā sampayuttāya eva hi ssa citta cetasikānam atisaya pasāda bhūtā balavatī saddhā uppajjati
translated: “Bliss” is the bliss of insight. At that time, it seems, very refined bliss arises pervading the whole body.🔽“Resolution” is faith. For at that time strong faith arises in him, which is the supreme confidence of consciousness and its concomitants, and it is associated with insight.

original: Paggahoti vīriyaṃ. Vipassanāsampayuttameva hissa asithilaṃ anaccāraddhaṃ supaggahitaṃ vīriyaṃ uppajjati.🔽Upaṭṭhānanti sati. Vipassanāsampayuttāyeva hissa supaṭṭhitā supatiṭṭhitā nikhātā🔽acalā pabbatarājasadisā sati uppajjati. So yaṃ yaṃ ṭhānaṃ āvajjati samannāharati
analyzed: paggaho ti vīriyam vipassanā sampayuttam eva hissa asithilam anacca āraddham su paggahitam vīriyam uppajjati  upaṭṭhānam ti sati vipassanā sampayuttāya eva hi ssa su paṭṭhitā su patiṭṭhitā nikhātā  acalā pabbatarāja sadisā sati uppajjati saḥ yam yam ṭhānam āvajjati samannāharati
translated: “Striving” is energy. At that time energy arises in him, which is neither over-exerted nor under-exerted, but well poised, moderate, and sustained, and it is associated with insight.🔽“Uprightness” is mindfulness. At that time mindfulness arises in him that is well established, well augmented, well attended, well developed, and it is associated with insight.

original: manasikaroti paccavekkhati, taṃ taṃ ṭhānamassa okkhanditvā pakkhanditvā dibbacakkhuno🔽paraloko viya satiyā upaṭṭhāti.
analyzed: manasikaroti paccavekkhati tam tam ṭhānam assa okkhanditvā pakkhanditvā dibba cakkhunaḥ  para lokaḥ viya satiyā upaṭṭhāti
translated: Whatever object he adverts, gives attention to, brings to mind, or focuses on, that object comes into focus for him as soon as he adverts it, as if it were in the range of the divine eye.

original: Upekkhāti vipassanupekkhā ceva āvajjanupekkhā ca. Tasmiṃ hissa samaye sabbasaṅkhāresu
analyzed: upekkhā ati vipassanā upekkhā ca iva āvajjanā upekkhā ca tasmin hissa samaye sabba saṅkhāresu
translated: “Equanimity” is both insight equanimity and adverting equanimity. For at that time equanimity towards all formations arises in him,

original: majjhattabhūtā vipassanupekkhāpi balavatī uppajjati. Manodvāre āvajjanupekkhāpi.
analyzed: majjhatta bhūtā vipassanā upekkhā api balavatī uppajjati manaḥ dvāre āvajjanupekkhā api
translated: And the equanimity of insight is strong. And the equanimity of adverting in the mind door is strong.

original: Sā hissa taṃ taṃ ṭhānaṃ āvajjantassa vissaṭṭhaindavajiramiva pattapuṭe pakkhitta
analyzed: sā hi ssa tam tam ṭhānam āvajjantassa vissaṭṭha aindava jiram iva patta puṭe pakkhitta
translated: For that is strong and sharp in him as he adverts to this or that place, like a fine needle of diamond in a sheath of diamond,

original: tattanārāco viya ca sūrā tikhiṇā hutvā vahati.
analyzed: ca sūrā tikhiṇā hutvā vahati
translated: like a red-hot iron in a bag of wet hide.

original: Nikantīti vipassanānikanti. Evaṃ obhāsādipaṭimaṇḍitāya hissa vipassanāya ālayaṃ kurumānā sukhumā santākārā nikanti uppajjati. Yā nikanti kilesoti pariggahetumpi na sakkā hoti.🔽Yathā ca obhāse, evaṃ etesupi aññatarasmiṃ uppanne yogāvacaro “na vata me ito pubbe
analyzed: nikanti iti vipassanā nikanti evam obhāsa ādi paṭimaṇḍitāya hi ssa vipassanāya ālayam kurumānā sukhumā santa ākārā nikanti uppajjati yā nikanti kileso ti pariggahetum pi na sakkā hoti  yathā ca obhāse evam etesu pi aññatarasmin uppanne yogāvacaraḥ na vata me itas pubbe
translated: Attachment: attachment to insight. For when insight is adorned with illumination, etc., attachment arises in him subtle and peaceful in aspect, making its abode in that insight, which cannot be discerned as a defilement,

original: evarūpaṃ ñāṇaṃ uppannapubbaṃ, evarūpā pīti, passaddhi, sukhaṃ, adhimokkho, paggaho,
analyzed: evarūpam ñāṇam uppanna pubbam evarūpā pīti passaddhi sukham adhimokkhaḥ paggahaḥ
translated: And when any one of these things arises, the meditator thinks, “Never before have I experienced such knowledge, such happiness, such peace, such clarity of mind.

original: upaṭṭhānaṃ, upekkhā, nikanti uppannapubbā, addhā maggappattosmi phalappattosmī”ti
analyzed: upaṭṭhānam upekkhā nikanti uppanna pubbā addhā magga ppattaḥ asmi phala ppattaḥ asmi iti
translated: Surely I must have attained the path or fruit.”

original: amaggameva “maggo”ti aphalameva ca “phala”nti gaṇhāti. Tassa amaggaṃ “maggo”ti aphalaṃ
analyzed: amaggam eva maggoti aphalam eva ca phalanti gaṇhāti tassa amaggam maggoti aphalam
translated: He takes what is not the path to be the path and what is not fruition to be fruition.

original: “phala”nti gaṇhato vipassanāvīthi ukkantā nāma hoti. So attano mūlakammaṭṭhānaṃ vissajjetvā
analyzed: phalanti gaṇhataḥ vipassanā vīthi ukkantā nāma hoti so attanaḥ mūlakammaṭṭhānam vissajjetvā
translated: When he does this, his insight is said to be “strayed from the course.” He abandons his basic meditation subject

original: nikantimeva assādento nisīdatīti.
analyzed: nikantim eva assādentaḥ nisīdati iti
translated: and sits just enjoying the light.

original: 735. Ettha ca obhāsādayo upakkilesavatthutāya upakkilesāti vuttā, na akusalattā.
analyzed: ettha ca obhāsa ādayo upakkilesa vatthu tāya upakkilesā ati vuttā na akusala ttā
translated: Herein, the illumination, etc., are called defilements because they are the basis for defilements, not because they are themselves unwholesome.

original: Nikanti pana upakkileso ceva upakkilesavatthu ca. Vatthuvaseneva cete dasa. Gāhavasena
analyzed: nikanti pana upakkileso ca iva upakkilesa vatthu ca vatthu vasena iva ca ite dasa gāha vasena
translated: But attachment is both a defilement and the basis for defilements. They are ten in number only as bases.

original: pana samatiṃsa honti. Kathaṃ? “Mama obhāso uppanno”ti gaṇhato hi diṭṭhigāho hoti,
analyzed: pana samatiṃsa honti katham mama obhāsaḥ uppannaḥ ti gaṇhataḥ hi diṭṭhi gāho hoti
translated: But as regards taking up, there are thirty. How? For when he thinks “Illumination has arisen in me,” there is the taking up of a view;

original: “manāpo vata obhāso uppanno”ti gaṇhato mānagāho, obhāsaṃ assādayato taṇhāgāho, iti
analyzed: manāpaḥ vata obhāsaḥ uppannaḥ ti gaṇhataḥ māna gāhaḥ obhāsam assādayataḥ taṇhā gāhaḥ iti
translated: when he thinks “How pleasant is the illumination that has arisen in me,” there is the taking up of conceit; when he enjoys the illumination, there is the taking up of craving.

original: obhāse diṭṭhimānataṇhāvasena tayo gāhā. Tathā sesesupīti evaṃ gāhavasena samatiṃsa
analyzed: obhāse diṭṭhi māna taṇhā vasena tayaḥ gāhā tathā sesesu pi iti evam gāha vasena samatiṃsa
translated: So there are three kinds of taking up in the case of illumination, that is to say, by way of view, conceit, and craving. And so in the case of the rest. Thus there are thirty kinds of taking up.

original: upakkilesā honti. Tesaṃ vasena akusalo abyatto yogāvacaro obhāsādīsu kampati vikkhipati.
analyzed: upakkilesāḥ honti tesam vasena akusalaḥ abyattaḥ yogāvacaraḥ obhāsa ādīsu kampati vikkhipati
translated: They are defilements. The unskillful, unwise, unalert meditator is shaken by the light, etc., and his mind is distracted.

original: Obhāsādīsu ekekaṃ “etaṃ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attā”ti samanupassati. Tenāhu porāṇā –
analyzed: etam mama esaḥ aham asmi esaḥ me attā iti samanupassati tena āhu porāṇāḥ
translated: He regards each of the light, etc., as “This is mine, this is my self, this is my world.” Hence the Ancients said:

original: “Obhāse ceva ñāṇe ca, pītiyā ca vikampati;🔽Passaddhiyā sukhe ceva, yehi cittaṃ pavedhati.
analyzed: obhāse ca iva ñāṇe ca pītiyā ca vikampati  passaddhiyā sukhe ca iva yehi cittam pavedhati
translated: “He is shaken by light and knowledge,🔽By bliss, by serenity, and by ease,🔽By which his mind is carried away.

original: “Adhimokkhe ca paggāhe, upaṭṭhāne ca kampati;
analyzed: adhimokkhe ca paggāhe upaṭṭhāne ca kampati
translated: He is shaken by resolution and exertion,

original: Upekkhāvajjanāyañca, upekkhāya nikantiyā”ti. ;
analyzed: upekkhāvat janāyan ca upekkhāya nikantiyā ati
translated: By appearance, by equanimity, and by attachment to equanimity.”

original: Maggāmaggavavatthānakathā🔽736. Kusalo pana paṇḍito byatto buddhisampanno yogāvacaro obhāsādīsu uppannesu “ayaṃ🔽kho me obhāso uppanno, so kho panāyaṃ anicco saṅkhato paṭiccasamuppanno khayadhammo
analyzed: magga amagga vavatthāna kathā  kusalaḥ pana paṇḍitaḥ byattaḥ buddhi sampannaḥ yoga avacaraḥ obhāsa ādīsu uppannesu ayaṃ  kho me obhāsaḥ uppanno saḥ kho pana ayam aniccaḥ saṅkhataḥ paṭiccasamuppanno khaya dhammo
translated: The Discussion of the Definition of the Path and the Unpath

original: vayadhammo virāgadhammo nirodhadhammo”ti iti vā taṃ paññāya paricchindati upaparikkhati.
analyzed: vaya dhammo virāga dhammo nirodha dhammo ti iti vā tam paññāya paricchindati upaparikkhati
translated: But the skillful, wise, alert meditator, when the light, etc., arise, defines and examines them with wisdom in this way: “This light has arisen. But that is impermanent, formed, dependently arisen, subject to destruction, subject to fall, subject to fading away, subject to cessation.”

original: Atha vā panassa evaṃ hoti, “sace obhāso attā bhaveyya, ‘attā’ti gahetuṃ vaṭṭeyya.
analyzed: atha vā panassa evam hoti sace obhāsaḥ attā bhaveyya attā ati gahetum vaṭṭeyya
translated: Or else he thinks thus: “If light were self, it would be right to take it as self.

original: Anattā ca panāyaṃ ‘attā’ti gahito. Tasmā so avasavattanaṭṭhena anattā, hutvā abhāvaṭṭhena
analyzed: anattā ca pana ayam attā ati gahito tasmā saḥ a vasavattana ṭṭhena anattā hutvā abhāva ṭṭhena
translated: But this is not self, though it is taken as self. Therefore it is not self because it is not one’s own,🔽because it is subject to destruction, because it is subject to change, because it is impermanent, because it is painful, because it is subject to cankers, because it is formed, because it is diverse, because it is not subject to one’s own will, because it is not kept in being by one’s own effort.

original: anicco, uppādavayapaṭipīḷanaṭṭhena dukkho”ti sabbaṃ arūpasattake vuttanayena vitthāretabbaṃ.
analyzed: aniccaḥ uppāda vaya paṭipīḷana ṭṭhena dukkhaḥ ti sabbam arūpa sattake vutta nayena vitthāretabbam
translated: And all the rest should be elaborated in the way already described under the immaterial septad.

original: Yathā ca obhāse, evaṃ sesesupi.
analyzed: yathā ca o bhāse evam sesa supi
translated: And as with light, so with the rest.

original: So evaṃ upaparikkhitvā obhāsaṃ “netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā”ti samanupassati.
analyzed: saḥ evam upaparikkhitvā obhāsam na itam mama na isī aham asmi na mā isī attā iti samanupassati
translated: When he has investigated in this way, he sees light as “not mine, not I, not my self.”

original: Ñāṇaṃ…pe… nikantiṃ “netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā”ti samanupassati. Evaṃ
analyzed: nikantim na itam mama na mā iso attā ati samanupassati evam
translated: He sees knowledge … and desire as “not mine, not I, not my self.”

original: samanupassanto obhāsādīsu na kampati na vedhati. Tenāhu porāṇā –
analyzed: samanupassantaḥ obhāsa ādīsu na kampati na vedhati tena āhu porāṇā
translated: Seeing thus, he is not agitated about light, etc., or elated. Hence the ancients said:

original: “Imāni dasa ṭhānāni, paññāyassa pariccitā;
analyzed: imāni dasa ṭhānāni pariccitā
translated: “These ten things that are well known,🔽The wise man does not vacillate,

original: Dhammuddhaccakusalo hoti, na ca vikkhepaṃ gacchatī”ti. ;
analyzed: dhamma uddhacca kusalaḥ hoti na ca vikkhepam gacchati iti
translated: He is skilled in avoiding false views.”

original: So evaṃ vikkhepaṃ agacchanto taṃ samatiṃsavidhaṃ upakkilesajaṭaṃ vijaṭetvā obhāsādayo
analyzed: evam vikkhepam a gacchantaḥ tam sama tiṃsavidham upakkilesa jaṭam vijaṭetvā
translated: He thus goes on to disentangle the thirty-two-fold tangle of defilements and to discern the light, etc.,

original: dhammā na maggo. Upakkilesavimuttaṃ pana vīthipaṭipannaṃ vipassanāñāṇaṃ maggoti maggañca🔽amaggañca vavatthapeti. Tassevaṃ “ayaṃ maggo, ayaṃ na maggo”ti maggañca amaggañca
analyzed: dhammā na maggaḥ upakkilesa vimuttam pana vīthi paṭipannam vipassanā ñāṇam maggo ti maggañca  amaggañca vavatthapeti tassa ivam ayam maggaḥ ayam na maggo ti maggañca amaggañca
translated: The light, etc., are not the path. But the insight knowledge that has reached the path and is free from the defilements is the path.🔽So he defines what is the path and what is not the path.

original: ñatvā ṭhitaṃ ñāṇaṃ maggāmaggañāṇadassanavisuddhīti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: ñatvā ṭhitam ñāṇam magga amagga ñāṇa dassana visuddhi iti veditabbam
translated: When he has stood defining what is the path and what is not the path in this way, his knowledge is called “purification by knowledge and vision of what is the path and what is not the path.”

original: Ettāvatā ca pana tena tiṇṇaṃ saccānaṃ vavatthānaṃ kataṃ hoti. Kathaṃ? Diṭṭhivisuddhiyaṃ
analyzed: ettāvatā ca pana tena tiṇṇam saccānam vavatthānam katam hoti katham diṭṭhi visuddhiyam
translated: And at this point the defining of three truths is accomplished by him. How?

original: tāva nāmarūpassa vavatthāpanena dukkhasaccassa vavatthānaṃ kataṃ. Kaṅkhāvitaraṇavisuddhiyaṃ
analyzed: tāva nāma rūpassa vavatthāpanena dukkha saccassa vavatthānam katam kaṅkhā vitaraṇa visuddhiyam
translated: In purification by knowledge of the way, by defining mentality-materiality, he defines the truth of suffering.🔽In purification by overcoming doubt, by discerning conditions, he defines the truth of origin.

original: paccayapariggahaṇena samudayasaccassa vavatthānaṃ. Imissaṃ maggāmaggañāṇadassanavisuddhiyaṃ
analyzed: paccaya pariggahaṇena samudaya saccassa vavatthānam imissam magga amagga ñāṇa dassana visuddhiyam
translated: In this purification by knowledge and vision of what is the path and what is not the path,

original: sammāmaggassa avadhāraṇena maggasaccassa vavatthānaṃ katanti, evaṃ lokiyeneva tāva
analyzed: sammāmaggassa avadhāraṇena magga saccassa vavatthānam evam lokiyena iva tāva
translated: by determining the right path, he defines the truth of the path. So firstly he accomplishes the defining of three truths by means of the mundane path alone.

original: ñāṇena tiṇṇaṃ saccānaṃ vavatthānaṃ kataṃ hoti.
analyzed: ñāṇena tiṇṇam saccānam vavatthānam katam hoti
translated: and by knowledge the three truths are defined.🔽Thus in the Path of Purification

original: Iti sādhujanapāmojjatthāya kate visuddhimagge
analyzed: iti sādhu jana pāmojjatthāya kate visuddhi magge
translated: composed for the purpose of gladdening good people,

original: Paññābhāvanādhikāre
analyzed: paññā bhāvanā adhikāre
translated: in the chapter on the development of understanding,

original: Maggāmaggañāṇadassanavisuddhiniddeso nāma
analyzed: maggāmaggañāṇadassanavisuddhiniddesaḥ nāma
translated: called “The Description of Purification by Knowledge and Vision of What Is the Path and What Is Not the Path,”

original: Vīsatimo paricchedo.
analyzed: vīsatimaḥ paricchedo
translated: the twentieth chapter.

original: 21. Paṭipadāñāṇadassanavisuddhiniddeso
translated: The Description of Purification by Knowledge and Vision of the Way

original: Upakkilesavimuttaudayabbayañāṇakathā🔽737. Aṭṭhannaṃ pana ñāṇānaṃ vasena sikhāppattā vipassanā, navamañca saccānulomikañāṇanti
analyzed: aṭṭhannam pana ñāṇānam vasena sikhāppattā vipassanā navamañca sacca ānulomika ñāṇanti
translated: The explanation of the knowledge of rise and fall free from defilements🔽The insight that has reached its culmination through the eight kinds of knowledge and the knowledge of conformity to truth is called “purification by knowledge and vision of the way.”

original: ayaṃ paṭipadāñāṇadassanavisuddhi nāma. Aṭṭhannanti cettha upakkilesavimuttaṃ vīthipaṭipannavipassanāsaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: ayam paṭipadā ñāṇadassanavisuddhi nāma ca ittha upakkilesa vimuttam vīthi paṭipanna vipassanā saṅkhātam
translated: Herein, the knowledge of rise and fall that is free from defilements and is called “insight that has reached the paths” is eightfold, that is to say:

original: udayabbayānupassanāñāṇaṃ, bhaṅgānupassanāñāṇaṃ, bhayatupaṭṭhānañāṇaṃ, ādīnavānupassanāñāṇaṃ,
analyzed: udaya bbaya anupassanā ñāṇam bhaṅga anupassanā ñāṇam bhaya tu paṭṭhāna ñāṇam ādīnava anupassanā ñāṇam
translated: the knowledge of contemplation of rise and fall, the knowledge of contemplation of dissolution, the knowledge of appearance as terror, the knowledge of contemplation of danger,

original: nibbidānupassanāñāṇaṃ, muñcitukamyatāñāṇaṃ, paṭisaṅkhānupassanāñāṇaṃ, saṅkhārupekkhāñāṇanti
analyzed: nibbidā anupassanā ñāṇam muñcitu kamya tā ñāṇam paṭisaṅkhā anupassanā ñāṇam saṅkhāra upekkhā ñāṇam
translated: the knowledge of contemplation of dispassion, the knowledge of desire for deliverance, the knowledge of contemplation of reflection, and the knowledge of equanimity about formations.

original: imāni aṭṭha ñāṇāni veditabbāni. Navamaṃ saccānulomikañāṇanti anulomassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ.
analyzed: imāni aṭṭha ñāṇāni veditabbāni navamam sacca ānulomika ñāṇam ti anulomassa etam adhivacanam
translated: These are the eight kinds of knowledge to be understood. The ninth is called knowledge in conformity with the truths.

original: Tasmā taṃ sampādetukāmena upakkilesavimuttaṃ udayabbayañāṇaṃ ādiṃ katvā etesu ñāṇesu yogo karaṇīyo.
analyzed: tasmā tam sampādetu kāmena upakkilesa vimuttam udaya bbaya ñāṇam ādim katvā etesu ñāṇesu yogaḥ karaṇīyaḥ
translated: So one who wants to perfect it should undertake the practice of these kinds of knowledge beginning with the knowledge of rise and fall free from defilements.

original: 738. Puna udayabbayañāṇe yogo kimatthiyoti ce? Lakkhaṇasallakkhaṇattho. Udayabbayañāṇaṃ
analyzed: puna udaya bbaya ñāṇe yogaḥ kimatthiyo ti ce udaya bbaya ñāṇam
translated: Again, why should one undertake the practice of the knowledge of rise and fall? For the purpose of discerning the characteristics.

original: hi heṭṭhā dasahi upakkilesehi upakkiliṭṭhaṃ hutvā yāthāvasarasato tilakkhaṇaṃ sallakkhetuṃ
analyzed: hi heṭṭhā dasahi upakkilesehi upakkiliṭṭham hutvā yāthāvasa rasataḥ ti lakkhaṇam sallakkhetum
translated: For the knowledge of rise and fall, being defiled by the ten defilements mentioned below, was unable to discern the three characteristics as they are in reality.

original: nāsakkhi. Upakkilesavimuttaṃ pana sakkoti. Tasmā lakkhaṇasallakkhaṇatthamettha puna yogo karaṇīyo.
analyzed: na asakkhi upakkilesa vimuttam pana sakkoti tasmā lakkhaṇa sat lakkhaṇa attham ettha puna yogo karaṇīyo
translated: But when it is free from defilements it is able to do so. That is why the practice should be undertaken again for the purpose of discerning the characteristics.

original: 739. Lakkhaṇāni pana kissa amanasikārā kena paṭicchannattā na upaṭṭhahanti? Aniccalakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: lakkhaṇāni pana kissa amanasikārā kena paṭicchanna ttā na upaṭṭhahanti anicca lakkhaṇam
translated: But why do the characteristics not appear when they are not given attention and when they are obscured?🔽The characteristic of impermanence does not appear because of the non-attention given to rise and fall and because of the obscuring of continuity.

original: tāva udayabbayānaṃ amanasikārā santatiyā paṭicchannattā na upaṭṭhāti. Dukkhalakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: tāva udayabbayānam amanasikārā santatiyā paṭicchanna ttā na upaṭṭhāti dukkha lakkhaṇam
translated: The characteristic of pain

original: abhiṇhasampaṭipīḷanassa amanasikārā iriyāpathehi paṭicchannattā na upaṭṭhāti. Anattalakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: abhiṇha sampaṭipīḍanassa a manasikārā iriyāpathehi paṭicchanna ttā na upaṭṭhāti anatta lakkhaṇam
translated: and because of the non-attention given to the frequent oppression, it does not appear owing to its being concealed by the postures. The characteristic of not-self

original: nānādhātuvinibbhogassa amanasikārā ghanena paṭicchannattā na upaṭṭhāti. Udayabbayampana🔽pariggahetvā santatiyā vikopitāya aniccalakkhaṇaṃ yāthāvasarasato upaṭṭhāti. Abhiṇhasampaṭipīḷanaṃ
analyzed: nānā dhātu vinibbhogassa a manasikārā ghanena paṭicchanna ttā na upaṭṭhāti udaya bbayampana  pariggahetvā santatiyā vikopitāya anicca lakkhaṇam yāthāvasa rasataḥ upaṭṭhāti abhiṇha sampaṭipīḷanam
translated: does not appear owing to its being concealed by compactness because of the non-attention given to the analysis of the various elements. But the characteristic of impermanence🔽appears as it actually is when the continuity is disturbed by discerning rise and fall. The characteristic of pain

original: manasikatvā iriyāpathe ugghāṭite dukkhalakkhaṇaṃ yāthāvasarasato upaṭṭhāti. Nānādhātuyo
analyzed: manasikatvā iriyāpathe ugghāṭite dukkha lakkhaṇam yāthāvasarasataḥ upaṭṭhāti nānā dhātuyo
translated: appears as it actually is when the non-attention given to the frequent oppression is discarded by the postures. The characteristic of not-self

original: vinibbhujitvā ghanavinibbhoge kate anattalakkhaṇaṃ yāthāvasarasato upaṭṭhāti.🔽740. Ettha ca aniccaṃ, aniccalakkhaṇaṃ, dukkhaṃ, dukkhalakkhaṇaṃ, anattā, anattalakkhaṇanti
analyzed: vinibbhujitvā ghana vinibbhoge kate anatta lakkhaṇam yāthāvasarasataḥ upaṭṭhāti  ettha ca aniccam anicca lakkhaṇam dukkham dukkha lakkhaṇam anattā anatta lakkhaṇanti
translated: appears as it actually is when the analysis of the various elements is effected and the compactness is broken up.🔽And here the exposition should be understood as follows: impermanent, characteristic of impermanence, painful, characteristic of pain, not-self, characteristic of not-self.

original: ayaṃ vibhāgo veditabbo. Tattha aniccanti khandhapañcakaṃ. Kasmā? Uppādavayaññathattabhāvā,
analyzed: ayam vibhāgaḥ veditabbo tattha aniccanti khandha pañcakam kasmā
translated: Herein, the five aggregates are impermanent. Why? Because of rise and fall, change, and separation.

original: hutvā abhāvato vā. Uppādavayaññathattaṃ aniccalakkhaṇaṃ hutvā abhāvasaṅkhāto vā ākāravikāro.
analyzed: hutvā abhāvataḥ vā uppāda vayaññathattam anicca lakkhaṇam hutvā abhāva saṅkhātaḥ vā ākāra vikāro
translated: or as non-existence after having been. The mode of appearance as the alteration called “non-existence after having been” is the characteristic of impermanence.

original: “Yadaniccaṃ taṃ dukkha”nti vacanato pana tadeva khandhapañcakaṃ dukkhaṃ. Kasmā? Abhiṇhapaṭipīḷanā, abhiṇhapaṭipīḷanākāro dukkhalakkhaṇaṃ.
analyzed: yat aniccam tam dukkham ti vacanato pana tat eva khandha pañcakam dukkham kasmai abhiṇha paṭipīḷanā abhiṇha paṭipīḷanā ākāraḥ dukkha lakkhaṇam
translated: But because of the words, “What is impermanent is painful” , that same pentad of aggregates is painful. Why? Because of frequent oppression, the mode of appearance as frequent oppression is the characteristic of pain.

original: “Yaṃ dukkhaṃ tadanattā”ti pana vacanato tadeva khandhapañcakaṃ anattā. Kasmā? Avasavattanato, avasavattanākāro anattalakkhaṇaṃ.
analyzed: yat dukkham tat anattā ati pana vacanato tat eva khandha pañcakam anattā kasmai avasavattanataḥ avasavattana ākāraḥ anatta lakkhaṇam
translated: But because of the words, “What is painful is not-self” , that same pentad of aggregates is not-self. Why? Because of non-mastery, the mode of appearance as non-mastery is the characteristic of not-self.

original: Tayidaṃ sabbampi ayaṃ yogāvacaro upakkilesavimuttena vīthipaṭipannavipassanāsaṅkhātena udayabbayānupassanāñāṇena yāthāvasarasato sallakkheti.
analyzed: tayidam sabbam pi ayam yogāvacaraḥ upakkilesa vimuttena vīthi paṭipanna vipassanā saṅkhātena udaya bbaya anupassanā ñāṇena yāthāvasa rasataḥ sallakkheti
translated: And this meditator considers all that by means of the knowledge of contemplation of rise and fall, which is called insight and is on the way to deliverance from defilements.

original: Upakkilesavimuttaudayabbayañāṇaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ.
translated: Knowledge of rise and fall delivered from defilements is ended.

original: Bhaṅgānupassanāñāṇakathā
analyzed: bhaṅga anupassanā ñāṇa kathā
translated: Knowledge of contemplation of dissolution

original: 741. Tassevaṃ sallakkhetvā punappunaṃ “aniccaṃ dukkhamanattā”ti rūpārūpadhamme tulayato
analyzed: tassa ivam sat lakkhetvā punappunam aniccam dukkham anattā ati rūpa arūpa dhamme tulayato
translated: When he has thus considered, he weighs material and immaterial states again and again as impermanent, painful, not-self.

original: tīrayato taṃ ñāṇaṃ tikkhaṃ hutvā vahati, saṅkhārā lahuṃ upaṭṭhahanti, ñāṇe tikkhe
analyzed: tīrayataḥ tam ñāṇam tikkham hutvā vahati saṅkhārāḥ lahum upaṭṭhahanti ñāṇe tikkhe
translated: When he crosses over thus, his knowledge proceeds keenly, formations appear lightly, and the sign of arising, sign of presence, and sign of dissolution become evident to him.

original: vahante saṅkhāresu lahuṃ upaṭṭhahantesu uppādaṃ vā ṭhitiṃ vā pavattaṃ vā nimittaṃ🔽vā na sampāpuṇāti. Khayavayabhedanirodheyeva sati santiṭṭhati. Tassa “evaṃ uppajjitvā🔽evaṃ nāma saṅkhāragataṃ nirujjhatī”ti passato etasmiṃ ṭhāne bhaṅgānupassanaṃ nāma
analyzed: vahante saṅkhāresu lahum upaṭṭhahantesu uppādam vā ṭhitim vā pavattam vā nimittam  vā na sampāpuṇāti khaya vaya bheda nirodheya iva sati santiṭṭhati tassa evam uppajjitvā  evam nāma saṅkhāra gatam nirujjhati iti passato etasmin ṭhāne bhaṅga anupassanam nāma
translated: When his knowledge proceeds keenly and formations appear lightly, then the sign of arising, sign of presence, and sign of dissolution become evident to him.🔽When he sees thus “having arisen in such a way, this has ceased in such a way,” then at that time insight-knowledge called “contemplation of dissolution” arises in him.

original: vipassanāñāṇaṃ uppajjati. Yaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ –🔽“Kathaṃ ārammaṇapaṭisaṅkhā bhaṅgānupassane paññā vipassane ñāṇaṃ? Rūpārammaṇatā cittaṃ
analyzed: vipassanā ñāṇam uppajjati yam sandhāya vuttam  katham ārammaṇa paṭisaṅkhā bhaṅga anupassane paññā vipassane ñāṇam rūpa ārammaṇa tā cittam
translated: With reference to this it is said:

original: uppajjitvā bhijjati, taṃ ārammaṇaṃ paṭisaṅkhā tassa cittassa bhaṅgaṃ anupassati.
analyzed: uppajjitvā bhijjati tam ārammaṇam paṭisaṅkhā tassa cittassa bhaṅgam anupassati
translated: “How is it that knowledge of insight is insight into contemplation of dissolution through reviewing the object? The consciousness that has arisen with materiality as its object dissolves. Reviewing that object, he contemplates the dissolution of that consciousness.

original: Anupassatīti kathaṃ anupassati? Aniccato anupassati no niccato, dukkhato anupassati
analyzed: anupassati iti katham anupassati aniccataḥ anupassati no niccatas dukkhataḥ anupassati
translated: “Contemplates”: how does he contemplate? He contemplates as impermanent, not as permanent;

original: no sukhato, anattato anupassati no attato, nibbindati no nandati, virajjati no rajjati,
analyzed: no sukhataḥ anattataḥ anupassati no attataḥ nibbindati no nandati virajjati no rajjati
translated: He contemplates as not self, not as self. He becomes dispassionate, not passionate. He is not greedy, not greedy.

original: nirodheti no samudeti, paṭinissajjati no ādiyati.
analyzed: nirodheti no samudeti paṭinissajjati no ādiyati
translated: He stops, not producing. He relinquishes, not taking.

original: “Aniccato anupassanto niccasaññaṃ pajahati. Dukkhato anupassanto sukhasaññaṃ, anattato🔽anupassanto attasaññaṃ, nibbindanto nandiṃ, virajjanto rāgaṃ, nirodhento samudayaṃ🔽paṭinissajjanto ādānaṃ pajahati.🔽“Vedanārammaṇatā…pe… saññārammaṇatā… saṅkhārārammaṇatā… viññāṇārammaṇatā… cakkhārammaṇatā…pe… jarāmaraṇārammaṇatā cittaṃ uppajjitvā bhijjati…pe… paṭinissajjanto ādānaṃ pajahati.🔽“Vatthusaṅkamanā ceva, paññāya ca vivaṭṭanā;
analyzed: aniccataḥ anupassanto nicca saññam pajahati dukkhataḥ anupassanto sukha saññam anattato  anupassantaḥ atta saññam nibbindantaḥ nandim virajjantaḥ rāgam nirodhentaḥ samudayam  paṭinissajjantaḥ ādānam pajahati  vedanā ārammaṇa tā āpe saññā ārammaṇa tā saṅkhāra ārammaṇa tā viññāṇa ārammaṇa tā cakkhu ārammaṇa tā āpe jarā maraṇa ārammaṇa tā cittam uppajjitvā bhijjati pe paṭinissajjantaḥ ādānam pajahati  vatthu saṅkamanā ca iva paññāya ca vivaṭṭanā
translated: “Contemplating as impermanent, he abandons the perception of permanence. Contemplating as painful, he abandons the perception of pleasure. Contemplating as not self, he abandons the perception of self.

original: Āvajjanābalañceva, paṭisaṅkhāvipassanā.🔽“Ārammaṇaanvayena, ubho ekavavatthanā;🔽Nirodhe adhimuttatā, vayalakkhaṇavipassanā.
analyzed: āvajjanā balam ca iva paṭisaṅkhā vipassanā 🔽ārammaṇa anvayena ubho eka vavatthanā 🔽nirodhe adhimutta tā vaya lakkhaṇa vipassanā
