original: “Ārammaṇañca paṭisaṅkhā, bhaṅgañca anupassati;🔽Suññato ca upaṭṭhānaṃ, adhipaññāvipassanā.
analyzed: ārammaṇañca paṭisaṅkhā bhaṅgañca anupassati  suññatas ca upaṭṭhānam adhi paññā vipassanā
translated: “Contemplation of the object, and contemplation of dissolution,🔽And the signless way of appearance:

original: “Kusalo tīsu anupassanāsu, catasso ca vipassanāsu;
analyzed: kusalaḥ tīsu anupassanāsu catasso ca vipassanāsu
translated: “Skilled in three contemplations, and in four kinds of insight,

original: Tayo upaṭṭhāne kusalatā, nānādiṭṭhīsu na kampatī”ti.
analyzed: tayo upaṭṭhāne kusala tā nānā diṭṭhīsu na kampati iti
translated: Skilled in three ways of appearance, he does not waver in his several views” .

original: “Taṃ ñātaṭṭhena ñāṇaṃ, pajānanaṭṭhena paññā, tena vuccati ‘ārammaṇapaṭisaṅkhā bhaṅgānupassane paññā vipassane ñāṇa”’nti.
analyzed: tam ñāta ṭṭhena ñāṇam pajānana ṭṭhena paññā tena vuccati ārammaṇa paṭisaṅkhā bhaṅga anupassane paññā vipassane ñāṇam ti
translated: “It is knowledge in the sense of knowing, and it is understanding in the sense of the act of understanding, that is why ‘Understanding of contemplation of an object and of contemplation of dissolution is knowledge of insight’ is said” .

original: 742. Tattha ārammaṇapaṭisaṅkhāti yaṃkiñci ārammaṇaṃ paṭisaṅkhāya jānitvā, khayato🔽vayato disvāti attho. Bhaṅgānupassane paññāti tassa, ārammaṇaṃ khayato vayato paṭisaṅkhāya
analyzed: tattha ārammaṇa paṭisaṅkhāti yaṃ kiñci ārammaṇam paṭisaṅkhāya jānitvā khayato  vayataḥ disvā ti atthaḥ bhaṅga anupassane paññā ti tassa ārammaṇam khayataḥ vayataḥ paṭisaṅkhāya
translated: Herein, contemplation of the object is the knowing of any object by reviewing it, seeing it as destruction and

original: uppannassa ñāṇassa bhaṅgaṃ anupassane yā paññā, idaṃ vipassane ñāṇanti vuttaṃ. Taṃ
analyzed: uppannassa ñāṇassa bhaṅgam anupassane yā paññā idam vipassane ñāṇan ti vuttam tam
translated: as fall. Contemplation of dissolution is the understanding that is the contemplation of the dissolution of the knowledge that has arisen by reviewing that object as destruction and as fall. This is called “knowledge of insight.”

original: kathaṃ hotīti ayaṃ tāva kathetukamyatāpucchāya attho. Tato yathā taṃ hoti, taṃ dassetuṃ
analyzed: katham hoti iti ayam tāva kathā itu kamyatā pucchāya attho tatas yathā tam hoti tam dassetum
translated: This is the meaning of the question asked out of desire to explain. Then, in order to show how it is, it is said:

original: “rūpārammaṇatā”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: rūpa ārammaṇa tā tiādi vuttam
translated: “The appearance of an object” and so on.

original: Tattha rūpārammaṇatā cittaṃ uppajjitvā bhijjatīti rūpārammaṇaṃ cittaṃ uppajjitvā
analyzed: tattha rūpa ārammaṇa tā cittam uppajjitvā bhijjati iti rūpa ārammaṇam cittam uppajjitvā
translated: Herein, the consciousness that has materiality as its object arises and dissolves.🔽🔽The consciousness that has materiality as its object arises and

original: bhijjati. Atha vā rūpārammaṇabhāve cittaṃ uppajjitvā bhijjatīti attho. Taṃ ārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: bhijjati atha vā rūpa ārammaṇa bhāve cittam uppajjitvā bhijjati iti attho tam ārammaṇam
translated: Herein, the meaning of “arising and dissolution in materiality as a mental datum” is this. The consciousness that arises and dissolves in taking materiality as its object arises and dissolves in taking materiality as its object. Or the meaning is that it arises and dissolves in the state of being the object of consciousness as materiality.

original: paṭisaṅkhāti taṃ rūpārammaṇaṃ paṭisaṅkhāya jānitvā, khayato vayato disvāti attho.🔽Tassa cittassa bhaṅgaṃ anupassatīti yena cittena taṃ rūpārammaṇaṃ khayato vayato
analyzed: tam rūpa ārammaṇam paṭisaṅkhāya jānitvā khayataḥ vayataḥ disvā ti attho  tassa cittassa bhaṅgam anupassati iti yena cittena tam rūpa ārammaṇam khayataḥ vayataḥ
translated: He contemplates the dissolution of that consciousness: the meaning is that he sees the fall of the consciousness by which that materiality as object was seen as destruction and fall.

original: diṭṭhaṃ, tassa cittassa aparena cittena bhaṅgaṃ anupassatīti attho. Tenāhu porāṇā
analyzed: diṭṭham tassa cittassa aparena cittena bhaṅgam anupassati iti tena āhu porāṇā
translated: He contemplates the dissolution of that consciousness: the meaning is that he sees the fall of the consciousness by which that materiality as object was seen as destruction and fall. Hence the Ancients said:

original: “ñātañca ñāṇañca ubhopi vipassatī”ti.
analyzed: ubho pi vipassati iti
translated: “He contemplates with insight both what is known And what is knowing, thus he sees.

original: Ettha ca anupassatīti anu anu passati, anekehi ākārehi punappunaṃ passatīti attho. Tenāha – “anupassatīti kathaṃ anupassati. Aniccato anupassatī”tiādi.
analyzed: ettha ca anupassati iti anu anu passati anekehi ākārehi punappunam passati iti attho tena āha anupassati iti katham anupassati aniccataḥ anupassati itiādi
translated: ” Herein, he contemplates is he sees again and again in various ways. Hence it is said: “How does he contemplate? He contemplates as impermanent” , and so on.

original: Tattha yasmā bhaṅgo nāma aniccatāya paramā koṭi, tasmā so bhaṅgānupassako yogāvacaro
analyzed: tattha yasmā bhaṅgaḥ nāma aniccatāya paramā koṭi tasmā so bhaṅga anupassakaḥ yoga avacaro
translated: And here, since dissolution is the ultimate of impermanence, the meditator who sees dissolution

original: sabbaṃ saṅkhāragataṃ aniccato anupassati, no niccato. Tato aniccassa dukkhattā, dukkhassa
analyzed: sabbam saṅkhāra gatam aniccataḥ anupassati no niccataḥ tatas aniccassa dukkha ttā dukkhassa
translated: he contemplates as impermanent all that belongs to the category of determinations, not as permanent. Because of the suffering in what is impermanent, he contemplates as suffering🔽

original: ca anattattā tadeva dukkhato anupassati, no sukhato. Anattato anupassati no attato.
analyzed: ca anatta ttā tat eva dukkhataḥ anupassati no sukhataḥ anattataḥ anupassati no attataḥ
translated: He contemplates all formations as impermanent, not as permanent. Then, because of the suffering inherent in the impermanent, and because of the non-self nature of suffering, he contemplates that same formation as suffering, not as pleasant. He contemplates it as non-self, not as self.🔽But because whatever is impermanent, suffering, and non-self is not to be relished,

original: Yasmā pana yaṃ aniccaṃ dukkhamanattā, na taṃ abhinanditabbaṃ. Yañca anabhinanditabbaṃ,
analyzed: yasmai pana yam aniccam dukkham anattā na tam abhinanditabbam yat ca an abhinanditabbam
translated: and whatever is not to be relished is not to be delighted in,

original: na tattha rajjitabbaṃ. Tasmā etasmiṃ bhaṅgānupassanānusārena “aniccaṃ dukkhamanattā”ti
analyzed: na tattha rajjitabbam tasmai etasmim bhaṅga anupassanā anusārena aniccam dukkham anattā ti
translated: therefore, in conformity with the contemplation of dissolution, he sees formations as impermanent, suffering, and non-self.

original: diṭṭhe saṅkhāragate nibbindati, no nandati. Virajjati, no rajjati. So evaṃ arajjanto
analyzed: diṭṭhe saṅkhāra gate nibbindati no nandati virajjati no rajjati saḥ evam a rajjantaḥ
translated: He becomes dispassionate towards them, not passionate; he does not delight in them, but abandons them, relinquishes them, lets them go, and does not grasp at them.

original: lokikeneva tāva ñāṇena rāgaṃ nirodheti, no samudeti. Samudayaṃ na karotīti attho.
analyzed: lokikena iva tāva ñāṇena rāgam nirodheti no samudeti samudayam na karoti iti attho
translated: As he does not delight in them, he suppresses craving with mundane knowledge, he does not generate it. The meaning is that he does not bring it into existence.

original: Atha vā so evaṃ viratto yathā diṭṭhaṃ saṅkhāragataṃ, tathā adiṭṭhampi anvayañāṇavasena
analyzed: atha vā saḥ evam virattaḥ yathā diṭṭham saṅkhāra gatam tathā adiṭṭham pi anvaya ñāṇa vasena
translated: Or else, as he becomes dispassionate, he suppresses craving with the knowledge of conformity, not generating it. The meaning is that he does not bring it into existence, but suppresses it, in regard to formations not yet seen as they really are, in the same way as he has seen those already seen.

original: nirodheti, no samudeti. Nirodhatova manasikaroti. Nirodhamevassa passati, no samudayanti attho.
analyzed: nirodheti no samudeti nirodhataḥ uva manasikaroti nirodham eva assa passati no samudayanti attho
translated: He gives attention only to their cessation, he sees only their cessation, not their origination.

original: So evaṃ paṭipanno paṭinissajjati, no ādiyati. Kiṃ vuttaṃ hoti? Ayampi aniccādianupassanā
analyzed: saḥ evam paṭipannaḥ paṭinissajjati no ādiyati kim vuttam hoti ayam pi anicca ādi anupassanā
translated: He who has entered upon this practice abandons and does not grasp. What is meant?

original: tadaṅgavasena saddhiṃ khandhābhisaṅkhārehi kilesānaṃ pariccajanato, saṅkhatadosadassanena
analyzed: tad aṅga vasena saddhim khandha abhisaṅkhārehi kilesānam pariccajanataḥ saṅkhata dosa dassanena
translated: This contemplation of impermanence, etc., is called “abandoning by relinquishing” and “abandoning by entering into” because it relinquishes defilements together with the aggregates produced by kamma by the method of taking them as its object,

original: ca tabbiparīte nibbāne tanninnatāya pakkhandanato pariccāgapaṭinissaggo ceva pakkhandanapaṭinissaggo
analyzed: ca tad biparīte nibbāne tad ninna tāya pakkhandanato pariccāga paṭinissaggo ca iva pakkhandana paṭinissaggo
translated: and because it enters into Nibbāna, which is the opposite of the formed, by seeing the danger in the formed.

original: cāti vuccati. Tasmā tāya samannāgato bhikkhu yathāvuttena nayena kilese pariccajati,
analyzed: ca ati vuccati tasmā tāya samannāgataḥ bhikkhu yathā vuttena nayena kilese pariccajati
translated: Therefore the bhikkhu who possesses this contemplation abandons defilements and enters into Nibbāna in the way already stated.

original: nibbāne ca pakkhandati. Nāpi nibbattanavasena kilese ādiyati, na adosadassitāvasena
analyzed: nibbāne ca pakkhandati na api nibbattana vasena kilese ādiyati na adosa dassi tā vasena
translated: And he does not grasp defilements by taking them as a basis for rebirth, nor does he take the formed as an object by seeing it as free from danger.

original: saṅkhatārammaṇaṃ. Tena vuccati “paṭinissajjati no ādiyatī”ti.🔽743. Idānissa tehi ñāṇehi yesaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānaṃ hoti, taṃ dassetuṃ “aniccato anupassanto
analyzed: saṅkhata ārammaṇam tena vuccati paṭinissajjati no ādiyati iti  idāni sa tehi ñāṇehi yesam dhammānam pahānam hoti tam dassetum aniccataḥ anupassanto
translated: Hence it is said, “He abandons and does not grasp.”

original: niccasaññaṃ pajahatī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha nandinti sappītikaṃ taṇhaṃ. Sesaṃ vuttanayameva.
analyzed: nicca saññam pajahati itiādi vuttam tattha nandin ti sappītikam taṇham sesam vutta nayam eva
translated: Now, in order to show the states that are abandoned by means of these kinds of knowledge, it is said: “Contemplating as impermanent, he abandons perception of permanence” , and so on. Herein, delight is craving accompanied by joy. The rest is as already stated.

original: 744. Gāthāsu pana vatthusaṅkamanāti rūpassa bhaṅgaṃ disvā puna yena cittena bhaṅgo🔽diṭṭho, tassāpi bhaṅgadassanavasena purimavatthuto aññavatthusaṅkamanā. Paññāya ca
analyzed: gāthāsu pana rūpassa bhaṅgam disvā puna yena cittena bhaṅgaḥ  tassa api bhaṅga dassana vasena purima vatthutaḥ añña vatthu saṅkamanā paññāya ca
translated: But in the stanzas, “The change-of-object” is the change of object from the first object by seeing the dissolution of materiality and then by seeing the dissolution of the consciousness that saw the dissolution of materiality.

original: vivaṭṭanāti udayaṃ pahāya vaye santiṭṭhanā. Āvajjanābalañcevāti rūpassa bhaṅgaṃ disvā🔽puna bhaṅgārammaṇassa cittassa bhaṅgadassanatthaṃ anantarameva āvajjanasamatthatā.
analyzed: vivaṭṭanā ati udayam pahāya vaye santiṭṭhanā āvajjanā balañca iva ati rūpassa bhaṅgam disvā  puna bhaṅga ārammaṇassa cittassa bhaṅga dassana attham anantaram eva āvajjana samattha tā
translated: In the stanzas, “The change of the object” is the change of the object from the previous one to another by seeing the dissolution of materiality and then by seeing the dissolution of the consciousness that saw the dissolution of materiality. “The turning back of understanding” is the stopping of the process of arising and occurring and the occurrence of the process of dissolution. “The power of adverting” is the ability to advert immediately to the dissolution of the object of consciousness that saw the dissolution of materiality in order to see the dissolution of that consciousness.

original: Paṭisaṅkhāvipassanāti esā ārammaṇapaṭisaṅkhābhaṅgānupassanā nāma.🔽745. Ārammaṇaanvayena ubho ekavavatthanāti paccakkhato diṭṭhassa ārammaṇassa anvayena🔽anugamanena yathā idaṃ, tathā atītepi saṅkhāragataṃ bhijjittha, anāgatepi bhijjissatīti
analyzed: paṭisaṅkhā vipassanā ti esā ārammaṇa paṭisaṅkhā bhaṅga anupassanā nāma  ārammaṇa anvayena ubho eka vavatthanā ti paccakkhataḥ diṭṭhassa ārammaṇassa anvayena  anugamanena yathā idam tathā atīte api saṅkhāra gatam bhijjittha anāgate api bhijjissati iti
translated: “Contemplation of fall” is the contemplation of dissolution by defining the object.

original: evaṃ ubhinnaṃ ekasabhāveneva vavatthāpananti attho.
analyzed: evam ubhinnam eka sabhāvena iva vavatthāpanam iti attho
translated: “The defining of both as of one nature by following the object” is the meaning. It is the defining of both the past and the future as of one nature with the present by following the object that is actually seen. The meaning is that it is the defining of both the past and the future as of one nature with the present by following the object that is actually seen. The meaning is that it is the defining of both the past and the future as of one nature with the present thus, “As this occurs at present after arising, so also in the past formations dissolved after arising, and in the future they will dissolve after arising.”

original: Vuttampi cetaṃ porāṇehi –
analyzed: vuttam pi ca itam porāṇehi
translated: And this is said by the Ancients:

original: “Saṃvijjamānamhi visuddhadassano,
analyzed: saṃvijjamānamhi visuddha dassano
translated: “The one with purified vision, seeing the present,

original: Tadanvayaṃ neti atītanāgate;
analyzed: tad anvayam na iti atīta nāgate
translated: And so it is with past and future.

original: Sabbepi saṅkhāragatā palokino,
analyzed: sabbe pi saṅkhāra gatāḥ palokinaḥ

original: Ussāvabindū sūriyeva uggate”ti.

original: Nirodhe adhimuttatāti evaṃ ubhinnaṃ bhaṅgavasena ekavavatthānaṃ katvā tasmiññeva
analyzed: nirodhe adhimutta tā ati evam ubhinnam bhaṅga vasena eka vavatthānam katvā tasmin ñeva
translated: “Are intent on cessation”: having thus defined both in terms of dissolution,

original: bhaṅgasaṅkhāte nirodhe adhimuttatā taggarutā tanninnatā tappoṇatā tappabbhāratāti
analyzed: bhaṅga saṅkhāte nirodhe adhimutta tā tad garu tā tad ninna tā tad poṇa tā tad pabbhāra tā ati

original: attho. Vayalakkhaṇavipassanāti esā vayalakkhaṇavipassanā nāmāti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: atthaḥ vaya lakkhaṇa vipassanā ti esā vaya lakkhaṇa vipassanā nāma ati vuttam hoti
translated: “Contemplation of the characteristic of fall”: what is meant is that this is called “contemplation of the characteristic of fall.”

original: 746. Ārammaṇañca paṭisaṅkhāti purimañca rūpādiārammaṇaṃ jānitvā. Bhaṅgañca anupassatīti
analyzed: ārammaṇam ca paṭisaṅkhāti purimam ca rūpa ādi ārammaṇam jānitvā bhaṅgañca anupassati iti

original: tassārammaṇassa bhaṅgaṃ disvā tadārammaṇassa cittassa bhaṅgaṃ anupassati. Suññato
analyzed: tassa ārammaṇassa bhaṅgam disvā tad ārammaṇassa cittassa bhaṅgam anupassati suññataḥ

original: ca upaṭṭhānanti tassevaṃ bhaṅgaṃ anupassato “saṅkhārāva bhijjanti, tesaṃ bhedo maraṇaṃ,

translated: “Emptiness appears to him”: when he contemplates fall in this way, formations appear to him as void thus: “Only formations break up; their breaking up is death;

analyzed: na aññaḥ koci atthi iti suññatas upaṭṭhānam ijjhati

original: Tenāhu porāṇā –

translated: Hence the Ancients said:

original: Tesaṃ khayaṃ passati appamatto,

translated: The diligent one sees their destruction,

original: Maṇiṃva vijjhaṃ vajirena yoniso”ti.

original: Adhipaññāvipassanāti yā ca ārammaṇapaṭisaṅkhā yā ca bhaṅgānupassanā yañca suññato upaṭṭhānaṃ, ayaṃ adhipaññāvipassanā nāmāti vuttaṃ hoti.

translated: “Insight with higher understanding”: the reflection on the object, the contemplation of dissolution, and the appearance of voidness are called “insight with higher understanding.”

original: 747. Kusalo tīsu anupassanāsūti aniccānupassanādīsu tīsu cheko bhikkhu. Catasso ca
analyzed: kusalaḥ tīsu anupassanāsu ti anicca anupassanā ādīsu tīsu chekaḥ bhikkhu catasso ca

original: vipassanāsūti nibbidādīsu ca catūsu vipassanāsu. Tayo upaṭṭhāne kusalatāti khayato🔽vayato suññatoti imasmiñca tividhe upaṭṭhāne kusalatāya. Nānādiṭṭhīsu na kampatīti
analyzed: vipassanāsu iti nibbida ādīsu ca catūsu vipassanāsu tayo upaṭṭhāne kusala tā ti khayato  vayato suññato ti imasmin ca tividhe upaṭṭhāne kusala tāya nānā diṭṭhīsu na kampati iti
translated: “And in the four kinds of insight”: and in the four kinds of insight beginning with disenchantment.🔽“Skilled in the three appearances”: and skilled in the three appearances as destruction, as separation, and as voidness.

original: sassatadiṭṭhiādīsu nānappakārāsu diṭṭhīsu na vedhati.
analyzed: sassata diṭṭhi ādīsu nānappakārāsu diṭṭhīsu na vedhati

original: dubbalabhājanassa viya bhijjamānassa, sukhumarajasseva vippakiriyamānassa, tilānaṃ

analyzed: tasmā yathā nāma cakkhumā purisaḥ nagara dvāre tissaḥ aṅgārakāsuyaḥ olokayamāno sayam
translated: So just as a man with eyes standing at the city gate watching three charcoal pits would not himself go into them,

original: na bhāyati, kevalaṃ hissa “ye ye ettha nipatissanti, sabbe anappakaṃ dukkhamanubhavissantī”ti
analyzed: na bhāyati kevalam hi ssa ye ye ettha nipatissanti sabbe anappakam dukkham anubhavissanti iti
translated: He is not afraid. He simply thinks, “Whoever falls here will experience no little pain.”

original: tīraṇamattameva hoti. Yathā vā pana cakkhumā puriso khadirasūlaṃ ayosūlaṃ suvaṇṇasūlanti🔽paṭipāṭiyā ṭhapitaṃ sūlattayaṃ olokayamāno sayaṃ na bhāyati, kevalaṃ hissa “ye ye
analyzed: tīraṇam attam eva hoti yathā vā pana cakkhumā puriso khadira sūlam ayaḥ sūlam suvaṇṇa sūlanti  paṭipāṭiyā ṭhapitam sūlattayam olokayamāno sayam na bhāyati kevalam hissa ye ye
translated: He is simply observing. Or just as a man with eyes can look at a triple set of stakes, namely, a khadira stake, an iron stake, and a gold stake,

original: imesu sūlesu nipatissanti, sabbe anappakaṃ dukkhamanubhavissantī”ti tīraṇamattameva🔽hoti, evameva bhayatupaṭṭhānañāṇaṃ sayaṃ na bhāyati, kevalaṃ hissa aṅgārakāsuttayasadisesu,
analyzed: imesu sūlesu nipatissanti sabbe anappakam dukkham anubhavissanti iti tīraṇa mattam eva  hoti evam eva bhaya tu paṭṭhāna ñāṇam sayam na bhāyati kevalam hissa aṅgārakā suttaya sadisesu
translated: and is not himself afraid, he simply thinks “Whoever falls on these stakes will experience no little pain,”

original: sūlattayasadisesu ca tīsu bhavesu “atītā saṅkhārā niruddhā, paccuppannā nirujjhanti,
analyzed: ca tīsu bhavesu atītā saṅkhārāḥ niruddhā paccuppannāḥ nirujjhanti
translated: and he is simply observing, so too, knowledge of appearance as terror is not itself afraid. He simply thinks “In the three kinds of becoming, which resemble the three stakes, past formations have ceased, present ones are ceasing,🔽and future ones will cease,” and he is simply observing.

original: anāgatā nirujjhissantī”ti tīraṇamattameva hoti. Yasmā panassa kevalaṃ sabbabhavayonigatiṭhitinivāsagatā
analyzed: anāgatāḥ nirujjhissanti iti tīraṇa mattam eva hoti yasmā pana assa kevalam sabba bhava yoni gati ṭhiti nivāsa gatā
translated: But because he observes all kinds of becoming, generation, destiny, station, and abode,

original: saṅkhārā byasanāpannā sappaṭibhayā hutvā bhayato upaṭṭhahanti, tasmā bhayatupaṭṭhānanti vuccati.
analyzed: saṅkhārāḥ byasana āpannā sa paṭibhayāḥ hutvā bhayataḥ upaṭṭhahanti tasmā bhayatupaṭṭhānam ti vuccati
translated: Formations appear as a danger because they are subject to misfortune and have fearfulness. That is why it is called appearance as danger.

original: Evaṃ bhayato upaṭṭhāne panassa ayaṃ pāḷi –🔽“Aniccato manasikaroto kiṃ bhayato upaṭṭhāti? Dukkhato. Anattato manasikaroto kiṃ
analyzed: evam bhayataḥ upaṭṭhāne panassa ayam pāḷi  aniccataḥ manasikarotaḥ kim bhayataḥ upaṭṭhāti dukkhataḥ anattataḥ manasikarotaḥ kim
translated: The text is as follows:

original: bhayato upaṭṭhātīti? Aniccato manasikaroto nimittaṃ bhayato upaṭṭhāti. Dukkhato manasikaroto
analyzed: bhayataḥ upaṭṭhāti iti aniccataḥ manasikarotaḥ nimittam bhayataḥ upaṭṭhāti dukkhataḥ manasikarotaḥ
translated: “When he brings formations to mind as impermanent, what appears as a danger? When he brings them to mind as painful, what appears as a danger? When he brings them to mind as not-self, what appears as a danger?

original: pavattaṃ bhayato upaṭṭhāti. Anattato manasikaroto nimittañca pavattañca bhayato upaṭṭhātī”ti.
analyzed: pavattam bhayataḥ upaṭṭhāti anattataḥ manasikarotaḥ nimittam ca pavattam ca bhayataḥ upaṭṭhāti iti
translated: When he brings formations to mind as impermanent, the sign appears as a danger. When he brings them to mind as painful, occurrence appears as a danger. When he brings them to mind as not-self, the sign and occurrence appear as a danger” .

original: Tattha nimittanti saṅkhāranimittaṃ. Atītānāgatapaccuppannānaṃ saṅkhārānamevetaṃ adhivacanaṃ.
analyzed: tattha nimittam ti saṅkhāra nimittam atīta anāgata paccuppannānam adhivacanam
translated: Herein, the sign is the sign of formations. It is a term for formations of the past, future and present.

original: Aniccato manasikaronto hi saṅkhārānaṃ maraṇameva passati, tenassa nimittaṃ bhayato
analyzed: aniccataḥ manasikarontaḥ hi saṅkhārānam maraṇam eva passati tena assa nimittam bhayato
translated: For when he brings formations to mind as impermanent, he sees only their death, and so the sign appears as a danger to him.🔽Occurrence is the occurrence of material and immaterial becoming.

original: upaṭṭhāti. Pavattanti rūpārūpabhavapavatti. Dukkhato manasikaronto hi sukhasammatāyapi
analyzed: upaṭṭhāti pavattanti rūpa arūpa bhava pavatti dukkhataḥ manasikarontaḥ hi
translated: For when he brings formations to mind as painful, he sees only the occurrence of what is called “pleasant” as a danger.

original: pavattiyā abhiṇhapaṭipīḷanabhāvameva passati, tenassa pavattaṃ bhayato upaṭṭhāti.🔽Anattato manasikaronto pana ubhayampetaṃ suññagāmaṃ viya marīcigandhabbanagarādīni🔽viya ca rittaṃ tucchaṃ suññaṃ assāmikaṃ apariṇāyakaṃ passati. Tenassa nimittañca
analyzed: pavattiyāḥ abhiṇha paṭipīḍana bhāvam eva passati tena assa pavattam bhayataḥ upaṭṭhāti  anattataḥ manasikarontaḥ pana ubhayampetam suñña gāmam viya marīci gandhabba nagara ādīni  viya ca rittam tuccham suññam a ssāmikam a pariṇāyakam passati tenassa nimittam ca
translated: He sees only the state of being constantly oppressed in occurrence, and so occurrence appears to him as fear.

original: pavattañca ubhayaṃ bhayato upaṭṭhātīti.
analyzed: pavattam ca ubhayam bhayataḥ upaṭṭhāti iti
translated: But when he gives his attention to it as not-self, he sees both of them as void, as a void village, as a mirage, as a phantom city, as insubstantial, hollow, void, ownerless, and not to be used as one likes. So both the sign and the occurrence appear to him as fear.

original: Bhayatupaṭṭhānañāṇaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: bhaya tupaṭṭhāna ñāṇam niṭṭhitam
translated: Knowledge of appearance as fear is ended.

original: Ādīnavānupassanāñāṇakathā🔽752. Tassa taṃ bhayatupaṭṭhānañāṇaṃ āsevantassa bhāventassa bahulīkarontassa sabbabhavayonigatiṭhitisattāvāsesu
analyzed: ādīnava anupassanā ñāṇa kathā  tassa tam bhaya tu paṭṭhāna ñāṇam āsevantassa bhāventassa bahulīkarontassa sabba bhava yoni gati ṭhiti sattā vāsesu
translated: Knowledge of contemplation of danger

original: neva tāṇaṃ, na leṇaṃ, na gati, nappaṭisaraṇaṃ paññāyati. Sabbabhavayonigatiṭhitinivāsagatesu
analyzed: na iva tāṇam na leṇam na gati na paṭisaraṇam paññāyati sabba bhava yoni gati ṭhiti nivāsa gatesu
translated: As he cultivates, develops and repeatedly practices that knowledge of appearance as fear, no refuge, no haven, no place to go to, no resort is seen by him in any kind of becoming, destiny, station of consciousness, or abode of beings.

original: saṅkhāresu ekasaṅkhārepi patthanā vā parāmāso vā na hoti. Tayo bhavā vītaccikaṅgārapuṇṇaaṅgārakāsuyo
analyzed: saṅkhāresu eka saṅkhāre pi patthanā vā parāmāsaḥ vā na hoti tayaḥ bhavāḥ
translated: In formations in the three kinds of becoming, in the nine abodes of beings, in the four primary elements, and in the five aggregates as objects of clinging, he has no wish or aspiration for even one single formation. The three kinds of becoming are like a charcoal pit filled with live coals.

original: viya, cattāro mahābhūtā ghoravisaāsīvisā viya, pañcakkhandhā ukkhittāsikavadhakā
analyzed: viya cattāro mahābhūtāḥ ghora visa āsīvisāḥ viya pañca kkhandhāḥ ukkhitta āsika vadhakā
translated: the four great entities are like terrible poisonous snakes, the five aggregates are like murderers with upraised swords,

original: viya, cha ajjhattikāyatanāni suññagāmo viya, cha bāhirāyatanāni gāmaghātakacorā viya,
analyzed: viya cha ajjhattika āyatanāni suñña gāmaḥ viya cha bāhira āyatanāni gāma ghātaka corā viya
translated: the six internal sense spheres are like an empty village, the six external sense spheres are like burglars,

original: satta viññāṇaṭṭhitiyo, nava ca sattāvāsā ekādasahi aggīhi ādittā sampajjalitā sajotibhūtā🔽viya ca, sabbe saṅkhārā gaṇḍabhūtā rogabhūtā sallabhūtā aghabhūtā ābādhabhūtā viya
analyzed: satta viññāṇa ṭṭhitiyaḥ nava ca sattāvāsāḥ ekādasahi aggīhi ādittā sampajjalitā sajoti bhūtā  viya ca sabbe saṅkhārāḥ gaṇḍa bhūtāḥ roga bhūtā salla bhūtāḥ agha bhūtāḥ ābādha bhūtāḥ viya
translated: the seven stations of consciousness and the nine abodes of beings are like a house on fire,

original: ca nirassādā nirasā mahāādīnavarāsibhūtā hutvā upaṭṭhahanti.🔽Kathaṃ? Sukhena jīvitukāmassa bhīrukapurisassa ramaṇīyākārasaṇṭhitampi savāḷakamiva
analyzed: ca nirassādāḥ nirasāḥ mahā ādīnava rāsi bhūtāḥ hutvā upaṭṭhahanti  katham sukhena jīvitu kāmassa bhīruka purisassa ramaṇīya ākāra saṇṭhitam pi sa vāḷakam iva
translated: and all formations are like a boil, a tumour, a dart, a sickness, an abscess, and are without essence, without substance, and are a great mass of suffering.

original: vanagahanaṃ, sasaddūlā viya guhā, sagāharakkhasaṃ viya udakaṃ, samussitakhaggā viya
analyzed: vana gahanam sa saddūlā viya guhā sa gāha rakkhasam viya udakam samussita khaggā viya
translated: How? To a timid man who wants to live happily, a forest thicket, though it has a pleasant appearance, is like a forest fire; a cave, though it is quiet, is like a lion; water, though it is refreshing, is like a nāga-haunted lake;

original: paccatthikā, savisaṃ viya bhojanaṃ, sacoro viya maggo, ādittamiva agāraṃ, uyyuttasenā
analyzed: paccatthikā sa visam viya bhojanam sa coraḥ viya maggaḥ ādittam iva agāram uyyutta senā
translated: enemies, though they are weak, are like murderers with upraised swords; food, though it is delicious, is like poisoned food; a road, though it is level, is like a road beset by robbers; a house, though it is well-built, is like a house on fire; an army, though it is well-arrayed, is like a routed army;

original: viya raṇabhūmi. Yathā hi so puriso etāni savāḷakavanagahanādīni āgamma bhīto saṃviggo🔽lomahaṭṭhajāto samantato ādīnavameva passati, evamevāyaṃ yogāvacaro bhaṅgānupassanāvasena
analyzed: raṇa bhūmi yathā hi saḥ purisaḥ etāni sa vāḷaka vana gahana ādīni āgamma bhītaḥ saṃviggo  loma haṭṭha jātaḥ samantataḥ ādīnavam eva passati evam eva ayam yogāvacaraḥ bhaṅga anupassanā vasena
translated: as a battlefield. For just as that man, having come to the forest with its trees, creepers, thickets, and grass, is frightened, alarmed,🔽and his hair stands on end, and he sees only danger everywhere, so too this meditator, when he sees all formations as fearful through the contemplation of dissolution,

original: sabbasaṅkhāresu bhayato upaṭṭhitesu samantato nirasaṃ nirassādaṃ ādīnavameva passati.
analyzed: sabba saṅkhāresu bhayataḥ upaṭṭhitesu samantataḥ nirasam nirassādam ādīnavam eva passati
translated: sees only lack of enjoyment, lack of satisfaction, and danger everywhere.

original: Tassevaṃ passato ādīnavañāṇaṃ nāma uppannaṃ hoti. Yaṃ sandhāya idaṃ vuttaṃ –

original: “Kathaṃ bhayatupaṭṭhāne paññā ādīnave ñāṇaṃ? Uppādo bhayanti bhayatupaṭṭhāne paññā🔽ādīnave ñāṇaṃ. Pavattaṃ bhayanti… nimittaṃ bhayanti… āyūhanā bhayanti… paṭisandhi🔽bhayanti… gati bhayanti… nibbatti bhayanti… upapatti bhayanti… jāti bhayanti… jarā

translated: “How is it that knowledge of danger is in regard to what is seen as fear? Knowledge of danger is in regard to what is seen as fear in rise.

original: bhayanti bhayatupaṭṭhāne paññā ādīnave ñāṇaṃ. Anuppādo khemanti santipade ñāṇaṃ.🔽Appavattaṃ…pe… anupāyāso khemanti santipade ñāṇaṃ. Uppādo bhayaṃ, anuppādo khemanti🔽santipade ñāṇaṃ. translated: “Danger” is understanding of appearance as terror, knowledge of danger. “Safety” is knowledge of the state of peace.

analyzed: anupāyāsaḥ sukhanti santi pade ñāṇam uppādaḥ dukkham anuppādaḥ sukhanti santi pade ñāṇam 🔽upāyāsaḥ dukkham an upāyāsaḥ sukhanti santi pade ñāṇam 🔽uppādaḥ sāmisanti bhaya tupaṭṭhāne paññā ādīnave ñāṇam pavattaṃpe upāyāsaḥ sāmisanti

translated: In five instances of peace, One understands ten kinds of knowledge.

original: Dvinnaṃ ñāṇānaṃ kusalatā, nānādiṭṭhīsu na kampatī”ti.
analyzed: dvinnam ñāṇānam kusala tā nānā diṭṭhīsu na kampati iti
translated: Skilled in two kinds of knowledge, One does not waver in the various views.”

original: “Taṃ ñātaṭṭhena ñāṇaṃ. Pajānanaṭṭhena paññā. Tena vuccati “bhayatupaṭṭhāne paññā ādīnave ñāṇa”nti.🔽753. Tattha uppādoti purimakammapaccayā idha uppatti. Pavattanti tathā uppannassa🔽pavatti. Nimittanti sabbampi saṅkhāranimittaṃ. Āyūhanāti āyatiṃ paṭisandhihetubhūtaṃ🔽kammaṃ. Paṭisandhīti āyatiṃ uppatti. Gatīti yāya gatiyā sā paṭisandhi hoti. Nibbattīti
analyzed: tam ñāta ṭṭhena ñāṇam pajānana ṭṭhena paññā tena vuccati bhaya tu paṭṭhāne paññā ādīnave ñāṇam ti  tattha uppādo ti purima kamma paccayā idha uppatti pavattanti tathā uppannassa  pavatti nimittanti sabbam pi saṅkhāra nimittam āyūhanā ati āyatim paṭisandhi hetu bhūtam  kammam paṭisandhi iti āyatim uppatti gatī iti yāya gatiyā sā paṭisandhi hoti nibbatti iti
translated: “That is knowledge in the sense of known, and it is understanding in the sense of that which has understood. Hence ‘Understanding of appearance as terror is knowledge of danger.’

original: khandhānaṃ nibbattanaṃ. Upapattīti “samāpannassa vā upapannassa vā”ti evaṃ vuttā
analyzed: khandhānam nibbattanam upapatti iti samāpannassa vā upapannassa vā ti evam vuttā
translated: Herein, arising is the occurrence here of what has not previously occurred through the condition of previous kamma. Occurrence is the occurrence of what has already arisen in that way. Sign is the sign of all formations. Accumulation is kamma that is a cause for rebirth-linking in the future. Rebirth-linking is the future occurrence. Destiny is the destiny by means of which there is that rebirth-linking. Generation is the generation of the aggregates. Re-arising is what is called “in one who has attained or in one who has been reborn” .

original: vipākappavatti. Jātīti jarādīnaṃ paccayabhūtā bhavapaccayā jāti. Jarāmaraṇādayo pākaṭā
analyzed: vipāka ppavatti jāti iti jarā ādīnam paccaya bhūtā bhava paccayā jarā maraṇa ādayo pākaṭā
translated: and the process of result. Birth is the birth that is a condition for aging, etc., and is itself a condition for the kamma-result. Aging, death, etc., are obvious.

original: eva. Ettha ca uppādādayo pañceva ādīnavañāṇassa vatthuvasena vuttā. Sesā tesaṃ vevacanavasena.🔽Nibbatti jātīti idañhi dvayaṃ uppādassa ceva paṭisandhiyā ca vevacanaṃ. Gati upapattīti
analyzed: eva ettha ca uppāda ādayo pañca iva ādīnava ñāṇassa vatthu vasena vuttā sesā tesam vevacana vasena  nibbatti jāti iti idam hi dvayam uppādassa ca iva paṭisandhiyā ca vevacanam gati upapatti iti
translated: Herein, the five, namely, arising, etc., are stated as the basis for the knowledge of danger. The rest are synonyms for them.🔽“Birth is the descent into the womb” and “appearance in a womb” are synonyms for arising and rebirth-linking.

original: idaṃ dvayaṃ pavattassa. Jarādayo nimittassāti. Tenāha –
analyzed: idam dvayam jarā ādayaḥ nimittassa ati tena āha
translated: “The destiny” and “the rebirth” are synonyms for the process of occurrence. Aging, etc., are synonyms for the sign.🔽Hence it is said:

original: “Uppādañca pavattañca, nimittaṃ dukkhanti passati;
analyzed: uppādam ca pavattam ca nimittam dukkhanti passati
translated: “Arising and occurrence, he sees as danger,🔽The sign, and the result of storing up, rebirth-linking,

original: Āyūhanaṃ paṭisandhiṃ, ñāṇaṃ ādīnave ida”nti ca.
analyzed: āyūhanam paṭisandhim ñāṇam ādīnave ca
translated: This knowledge of danger.”🔽And:

original: “Idaṃ ādīnave ñāṇaṃ, pañcaṭhānesu jāyatī”ti ca.
analyzed: idam ādīnave ñāṇam pañca ṭhānesu jāyati iti ca
translated: “This knowledge of danger arises in five ways.”

original: Anuppādo khemanti santipade ñāṇantiādi pana ādīnavañāṇassa paṭipakkhañāṇadassanatthaṃ
analyzed: anuppādaḥ khemanti santi pade ñāṇa nti ādi pana ādīnava ñāṇassa paṭipakkha ñāṇa dassana ttham
translated: But the passage beginning, “Non-arising is safety” is said for the purpose of showing the knowledge that is the opposite of the knowledge of danger.

original: vuttaṃ. Bhayatupaṭṭhānena vā ādīnavaṃ disvā ubbiggahadayānaṃ abhayampi atthi khemaṃ
analyzed: vuttam bhaya tupaṭṭhānena vā ādīnavam disvā abhayam pi atthi khemam
translated: Or alternatively, having seen danger through the appearance of fear, for the purpose of showing the safety that is the opposite of danger it is said:🔽“There is safety, there is no fear.”

original: nirādīnavanti assāsajananatthampi etaṃ vuttaṃ. Yasmā vā panassa uppādādayo bhayato🔽sūpaṭṭhitā honti, tassa tappaṭipakkhaninnaṃ cittaṃ hoti, tasmā bhayatupaṭṭhānavasena
analyzed: nirādīnavanti assāsa janana attham pi etam vuttam yasmā vā pana assa uppāda ādayaḥ bhayataḥ  su upaṭṭhitāḥ honti tassa tad paṭipakkha ninnam cittam hoti tasmā bhaya tu aṭṭhāna vasena
translated: “No danger” is said for the purpose of arousing confidence. Or alternatively, since the arising, etc., of formations are evident to him as fearful,

original: siddhassa ādīnavañāṇassa ānisaṃsadassanatthampetaṃ vuttanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: siddhassa ādīnava ñāṇassa ānisaṃsa dassana ttham petam vuttan ti veditabbam
translated: his mind is inclined to their opposite, and so this is said for the purpose of showing the benefit of the knowledge of danger, which is established by way of the appearance of fear.

original: Ettha ca yaṃ bhayaṃ, taṃ yasmā niyamato dukkhaṃ. Taṃ vaṭṭāmisalokāmisakilesāmisehi🔽avippamuttattā sāmisameva. Yañca sāmisaṃ, taṃ saṅkhāramattameva. Tasmā “uppādo dukkhanti🔽bhayatupaṭṭhāne paññā ādīnave ñāṇa”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Evaṃ santepi bhayākārena dukkhākārena
analyzed: ettha ca yam bhayam tam yasmai niyamataḥ dukkham tam vaṭṭa amisa loka āmisa kilesa āmisehi  a vippamutta ttā sa āmisam eva yat ca sa āmisam tam saṅkhāra mattam eva tasmai uppādaḥ dukkhanti  bhaya tupaṭṭhāne paññā ādīnave ñāṇa ntiādi vuttam evam sante pi bhaya ākārena dukkha ākārena
translated: And here the fear is suffering since it is invariably associated with suffering. And since it is not dissociated from the suffering of the round, the suffering of the world, and the suffering of defilements,🔽it is “with a residue of clinging.” And since it is with a residue of clinging, it is mere formations. Therefore it is said: “Understanding of the appearance of fear in the clause ‘Arising is suffering’ is knowledge of danger” , and so on.

original: sāmisākārenāti evaṃ ākāranānattato pavattivasenevettha nānattaṃ veditabbaṃ.🔽Dasañāṇe pajānātīti ādīnavañāṇaṃ pajānanto uppādādivatthukāni pañca, anuppādādivatthukāni
analyzed: sāmi sākārena ati evam ākāra nānattataḥ pavatti vasena iva ittha nānattam veditabbam 🔽dasa ñāṇe pajānāti iti ādīnava ñāṇam pajānantaḥ uppāda ādi vatthukāni pañca anuppāda ādi vatthukāni
translated: But even so, the difference here should be understood as due only to the difference in the mode of occurrence, that is, as the appearance of fear, as the appearance of suffering,🔽and as the appearance of what is with a residue of clinging.

original: pañcāti dasa ñāṇāni pajānāti paṭivijjhati sacchikaroti. Dvinnaṃ ñāṇānaṃ kusalatāti
analyzed: pañca ati dasa ñāṇāni pajānāti paṭivijjhati sacchikaroti dvinnam ñāṇānam kusala tā ati
translated: He knows, penetrates, realizes, ten kinds of knowledge:

original: ādīnavañāṇassa ceva santipadañāṇassa cāti imesaṃ dvinnaṃ kusalatāya. Nānādiṭṭhīsu
analyzed: ādīnava ñāṇassa ca iva santipada ñāṇassa ca ati imesam dvinnam kusala tāya nānā diṭṭhīsu
translated: He is skilled in two kinds of knowledge,🔽in the knowledge of danger and in the knowledge of the state of peace. He does not waver in his various views.

original: na kampatīti paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānādivasena pavattāsu diṭṭhīsu na vedhati. Sesamettha uttānamevāti.
analyzed: na kampati iti parama diṭṭha dhamma nibbāna ādi vasena pavattāsu diṭṭhīsu na vedhati sesam ettha uttānam eva ati
translated: The rest is clear.

original: Ādīnavānupassanāñāṇaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: ādīnava anupassanā ñāṇam niṭṭhitam
translated: Knowledge of contemplation of danger is ended.

original: Nibbidānupassanāñāṇakathā
analyzed: nibbida anupassanā ñāṇa kathā
translated: Knowledge of contemplation of dispassion

original: 754. So evaṃ sabbasaṅkhāre ādīnavato passanto sabbabhavayonigativiññāṇaṭṭhitisattāvāsagate sabhedake saṅkhāragate nibbindati ukkaṇṭhati nābhiramati.
analyzed: so evam sabba saṅkhāre ādīnavataḥ passantaḥ sabba bhava yoni gati viññāṇa ṭṭhiti sattā vāsa gate sa bhedake saṅkhāra gate nibbindati ukkaṇṭhati na abhiramati
translated: As he sees all formations as danger in this way, he becomes dispassionate towards all the kinds of becoming, destiny, station of consciousness, and abode of beings, which are classed as formations, and he turns away from them, he does not delight in them.

original: Seyyathāpi nāma, cittakūṭapabbatapādābhirato suvaṇṇarājahaṃso asucimhi caṇḍālagāmadvāraāvāṭe
analyzed: seyyathā api nāma cittakūṭa pabbata pāda abhirato suvaṇṇa rājahaṃsaḥ asucimhi caṇḍāla gāma dvāra āvāṭe
translated: Just as a royal swan that delights in the foothills of Citta Peak does not delight in a cesspit by the roadside in a village of outcasts,

original: nābhiramati, sattasu mahāsaresuyeva abhiramati, evameva ayampi yogīrājahaṃso suparidiṭṭhādīnave
analyzed: na abhiramati sattasu abhiramati evam eva ayam pi yogī rājahaṃsaḥ su paridiṭṭha ādīnave
translated: but delights only in the seven great lakes, so too this meditator, the royal swan, who delights in the danger that he has well seen,

original: sabhedake saṅkhāragate nābhiramati. Bhāvanārāmatāya pana bhāvanāratiyā samannāgatattā
analyzed: sa bhedake saṅkhāra gate na abhiramati bhāvanā rāmatāya pana bhāvanā ratiyā samannāgata ttā
translated: He does not delight in the formed element of existence, which is subject to destruction. But because he delights in development, because he is endowed with delight in development,

original: sattasu anupassanāsuyeva ramati.🔽Yathā ca suvaṇṇapañjare pakkhitto sīho migarājā nābhiramati, tiyojanasahassavitthate
analyzed: sattasu anupassanāsuyā iva ramati  yathā ca suvaṇṇa pañjare pakkhittaḥ sīhaḥ miga rājā na abhiramati ti yojana sahassa vitthate
translated: he delights only in the seven contemplations.🔽And just as a lion, king of beasts, shut up in a golden cage does not delight in it,

original: pana himavanteyeva ramati, evamayaṃ yogīsīho tividhe sugatibhavepi nābhiramati, tīsu
analyzed: ramati evam ayam tividhe sugati bhave pi nā abhiramati tīsu
translated: but delights only in the Himalayas extending for three thousand leagues, so this meditator-lion does not delight in the three kinds of existence in the three planes,

original: pana anupassanāsuyeva ramati.
analyzed: pana anupassanāsuyā iva ramati
translated: but delights only in the three contemplations.

original: Yathā ca sabbaseto sattapatiṭṭho iddhimā vehāsaṅgamo chaddanto nāgarājā nagaramajjhe🔽nābhiramati, himavati chaddantadahagahaneyeva abhiramati, evamayaṃ yogīvaravāraṇo🔽sabbasmimpi saṅkhāragate nābhiramati, anuppādo khemantiādinā nayena diṭṭhe santipadeyeva
analyzed: yathā ca sabbasetaḥ satta patiṭṭhaḥ iddhimā vehāsaṅgamaḥ chaddantaḥ nāga rājā nagara majjhe  na abhiramati himavati abhiramati evam ayam yogī vara vāraṇaḥ  sabbasmim pi saṅkhāra gate na abhiramati anuppādaḥ khemanti ādinā nayena diṭṭhe
translated: And just as the elephant king, white all over, with sevenfold stance, possessing supernormal power, who moves through the air, six-tusked, does not delight in the middle of a town,🔽but delights only in the Himalayas in the forest grove of the six-tusked one, so this meditator-elephant does not delight in any formed element of existence,

original: abhiramati, tanninnatappoṇatappabbhāramānaso hotīti.
analyzed: abhiramati tat ninna tad poṇa tad pabbhāra mānasaḥ hoti iti
translated: but delights only in the state of peace seen in the way beginning “Non-arising is safety,” and his mind is bent, inclined, and resolved upon that.

original: Nibbidānupassanāñāṇaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: nibbidā anupassanā ñāṇam niṭṭhitam
translated: Knowledge of contemplation of dispassion is ended.

original: 755. Taṃ panetaṃ purimena ñāṇadvayena atthato ekaṃ. Tenāhu porāṇā –
analyzed: tam pana itam purimena ñāṇa dvayena atthataḥ ekam tena āhu porāṇā
translated: But in meaning this is the same as the preceding pair of kinds of knowledge. Hence the Ancients said:

original: “Bhayatupaṭṭhānaṃ ekameva tīṇi nāmāni labhati, sabbasaṅkhāre bhayato addasāti bhayatupaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: bhaya tupaṭṭhānam ekam eva tīṇi nāmāni labhati sabba saṅkhāre bhayataḥ addasāti bhaya tupaṭṭhānam
translated: “The appearance of danger is given three names: ‘knowledge of the appearance of danger’ arises when he sees all formations as danger;

original: nāma jātaṃ. Tesuyeva saṅkhāresu ādīnavaṃ uppādetīti ādīnavānupassanā nāma jātaṃ.
analyzed: nāma jātam tesu yeva saṅkhāresu ādīnavam uppādeti iti ādīnava anupassanā nāma jātam
translated: ‘contemplation of danger’ arises when he generates danger in those same formations;

original: Tesuyeva saṅkhāresu nibbindamānaṃ uppannanti nibbidānupassanā nāma jāta”nti.
analyzed: tesu yeva saṅkhāresu nibbindamānam uppannanti nibbidā anupassanā nāma jātanti
translated: ‘contemplation of dispassion’ arises when he generates dispassion in those same formations.”

original: Pāḷiyampi vuttaṃ – “yā ca bhayatupaṭṭhāne paññā, yañca ādīnave ñāṇaṃ, yā ca nibbidā, ime dhammā ekatthā, byañjanameva nāna”nti.
analyzed: pāḷiyam pi vuttam yā ca bhaya tu paṭṭhāne paññā yat ca ādīnave ñāṇam yā ca nibbidā ime dhammā ekatthāḥ byañjanam eva nānanti
translated: And it is said in the texts: “The understanding of the appearance of danger, the knowledge of danger, and dispassion: these things are identical in meaning, only the letter is different” .

original: Muñcitukamyatāñāṇakathā🔽756. Iminā pana nibbidāñāṇena imassa kulaputtassa nibbindantassa ukkaṇṭhantassa anabhiramantassa
analyzed: muñcitu kamya tā ñāṇa kathā  iminā pana nibbidā ñāṇena imassa kula puttassa nibbindantassa ukkaṇṭhantassa an abhiramantassa
translated: The explanation of the knowledge of desire for deliverance

original: sabbabhavayonigativiññāṇaṭṭhitisattāvāsagatesu sabhedakesu saṅkhāresu ekasaṅkhārepi
analyzed: sabba bhava yoni gati viññāṇa ṭṭhiti sattā vāsa gatesu sa bhedakesu saṅkhāresu eka saṅkhāre pi
translated: When this clansman has thus become dispassionate towards all kinds of becoming, generation, destiny, station of consciousness, substratum of perception, and sphere, towards all kinds of formations, even towards a single formation,

original: cittaṃ na sajjati, na laggati, na bajjhati, sabbasmā saṅkhāragatā muccitukāmaṃ nissaritukāmaṃ🔽hoti. Yathā kiṃ? Yathā nāma jālabbhantaragato maccho, sappamukhagato maṇḍūko, pañjarapakkhitto🔽vanakukkuṭo, daḷhapāsavasagato migo, ahituṇḍikahatthagato sappo, mahāpaṅkapakkhando
analyzed: cittam na sajjati na laggati na bajjhati sabbasmā saṅkhāra gatā muccitu kāmam nissaritu kāmam  hoti yathā kim yathā nāma jāla bbhantara gataḥ macchaḥ sappa mukha gataḥ maṇḍūko pañjara pakkhitto  vana kukkuṭaḥ daḷha pāsava sagataḥ migaḥ ahituṇḍika hattha gataḥ sappaḥ mahā paṅka pakkhandaḥ
translated: His cognizance does not stick, does not adhere, does not get caught up, in any formation. He is desirous of being delivered from all, desirous of escaping from all.

original: kuñjaro, supaṇṇamukhagato nāgarājā, rāhumukhappaviṭṭho cando, sapattaparivārito purisoti🔽evamādayo tato tato muccitukāmā nissaritukāmāva honti, evaṃ tassa yogino cittaṃ sabbasmā
analyzed: kuñjaraḥ supaṇṇa mukha gataḥ nāga rājā rāhu mukha ppaviṭṭhaḥ cando sa patta parivārito puriso ti  evamādayo tatas tatas muccitu kāmāḥ nissaritu kāmāḥ ava honti evam tassa yogino cittam sabbasmā
translated: What is he like? He is like a fish caught on a hook, a frog caught in a snake’s mouth, a cock caught in a hawk’s mouth, a deer caught in a trap, a snake caught in a bird’s beak, an elephant caught in a deep bog, a king of nāgas caught in the jaws of a Supaṇṇa, the moon caught by Rāhu, a man surrounded by enemies.

original: saṅkhāragatā muccitukāmaṃ nissaritukāmaṃ hoti. Athassa evaṃ sabbasaṅkhāresu vigatālayassa
analyzed: saṅkhāra gatā muccitu kāmam nissaritu kāmam hoti athassa evam sabba saṅkhāresu vigata ālayassa
translated: Just as these are desirous of being delivered from, desirous of escaping from, each of these things, so too his cognizance is desirous of being delivered from all, desirous of escaping from all formations. Then, when he has no more concern for any formation,

original: sabbasmā saṅkhāragatā muccitukāmassa uppajjati muñcitukamyatā ñāṇanti.
analyzed: sabbasmā saṅkhāra gatā muccitu kāmassa uppajjati muñcitu kamya tā
translated: he is desirous of being delivered from all, desirous of escaping from all. Knowledge of desire for deliverance arises in him.

original: Muñcitukamyatāñāṇaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: muñcitu kamya tā ñāṇam niṭṭhitam
translated: Knowledge of desire for deliverance is ended.

original: Paṭisaṅkhānupassanāñāṇakathā
analyzed: paṭisaṅkhā anupassanā ñāṇa kathā
translated: The explanation of the knowledge of contemplation of reflexion

original: 757. So evaṃ sabbabhavayonigatiṭṭhitinivāsagatehi sabhedakehi saṅkhārehi muccitukāmo🔽sabbasmā saṅkhāragatā muccituṃ puna te evaṃ saṅkhāre paṭisaṅkhānupassanāñāṇena tilakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: saḥ evam sabba bhava yoni gati ṭṭhiti nivāsa gatehi sa bhedakehi saṅkhārehi muccitu kāmaḥ  sabbasmā saṅkhāra gatāḥ muccitum puna te evam saṅkhāre paṭisaṅkhā anupassanā ñāṇena ti lakkhaṇam
translated: He who wishes thus to be released from all formations classed according to the kinds of becoming, destinies, stations of consciousness, and abodes of beings,

original: āropetvā pariggaṇhāti.
analyzed: āropetvā pariggaṇhāti
translated: and to be released from all the kinds of becoming, should again discern those same formations by means of the knowledge of contemplation of reflection, imputing the three characteristics to them in this way.

original: So sabbasaṅkhāre anaccantikato, tāvakālikato, uppādavayaparicchinnato, palokato,🔽calato, pabhaṅguto, addhuvato, vipariṇāmadhammato, assārakato, vibhavato, saṅkhatato,
analyzed: so sabba saṅkhāre anaccantikato tāvakālikato uppāda vaya paricchinnato palokato  calataḥ pabhaṅgutaḥ addhuvataḥ vipariṇāma dhammataḥ assārakataḥ vibhavataḥ saṅkhatataḥ
translated: He sees all formations as impermanent because they are not lasting, because they are for a season, because they are limited by rise and fall, because they are subject to change,🔽because they are fickle, because they are perishable, because they are not conducive to enjoyment, because they are subject to the perishing of death,

original: maraṇadhammatotiādīhi kāraṇehi aniccāti passati.
analyzed: maraṇa dhammato ti ādīhi kāraṇehi aniccā ati passati
translated: because they are not profitable, because they are subject to destruction, because they are formed, because they are subject to death.

original: Abhiṇhapaṭipīḷanato, dukkhamato, dukkhavatthuto, rogato, gaṇḍato, sallato, aghato,
analyzed: abhiṇha paṭipīḷanataḥ dukkhamataḥ dukkha vatthutaḥ rogataḥ gaṇḍataḥ sallataḥ aghataḥ
translated: He sees them as painful because they are continuously afflicted, because they are the footing for pain, because they are subject to pain, because they are a disease, because they are a tumour, because they are a dart, because they are a calamity,

original: ābādhato, ītito, upaddavato, bhayato, upasaggato, atāṇato, aleṇato, asaraṇato, ādīnavato,
analyzed: ābādhataḥ ītitaḥ upaddavataḥ bhayataḥ upasaggataḥ a tāṇataḥ a leṇataḥ a saraṇataḥ ādīnavataḥ
translated: because they are an affliction, because they are alien, because they are a plague, because they are a calamity, because they are a terror, because they are a menace, because they are no protection, because they are no refuge, because they are no support, because they are a danger,

original: aghamūlato, vadhakato, sāsavato, mārāmisato, jātidhammato, jarādhammato, byādhidhammato,
analyzed: agha mūlataḥ vadhakataḥ sāsavataḥ māra āmisataḥ jāti dhammataḥ jarā dhammataḥ byādhi dhammataḥ
translated: because they are the root of danger, because they are subject to death, because they are subject to birth, because they are subject to ageing, because they are subject to sickness,

original: sokadhammato, paridevadhammato, upāyāsadhammato, saṃkilesikadhammatotiādīhi kāraṇehi dukkhāti passati.🔽Ajaññato, duggandhato, jegucchato, paṭikkūlato, amaṇḍanārahato, virūpato, bībhacchatotiādīhi kāraṇehi dukkhalakkhaṇassa parivārabhūtato asubhato passati.
analyzed: soka dhammato parideva dhammato upāyāsa dhammato saṃkilesika dhammato ti ādīhi kāraṇehi dukkhā ati passati  a jaññataḥ duggandhataḥ jegucchataḥ paṭikkūlataḥ a maṇḍana arahataḥ virūpataḥ bībhacchataḥ ti ādīhi kāraṇehi dukkha lakkhaṇassa parivāra bhūtataḥ asubhataḥ passati
translated: He sees them as suffering because of the state of being subject to birth, and so on, in the way beginning, “Because of the state of being subject to birth there is this suffering, this ageing, this illness, this death, this sorrow, lamentation, pain, grief and despair” .🔽He sees them as foul because of the state of being a condition for the characteristic of foulness, which is the surrounding of the characteristic of suffering, in the way beginning, “Because of the state of being unknown, because of the state of being stinking, because of the state of being disgusting, because of the state of being repulsive, because of the state of being unadorned, because of the state of being misshapen, because of the state of being a source of fear” .

original: Parato, rittato, tucchato, suññato, assāmikato, anissarato, avasavattitotiādīhi kāraṇehi anattato passati.
analyzed: paratas rittataḥ tucchataḥ suññataḥ a sāmikataḥ a nissarataḥ a vasavattito ti ādīhi kāraṇehi anattataḥ passati
translated: He sees them as not-self because of the state of being other, in the way beginning, “Because of the state of being void, because of the state of being empty, because of the state of being vain, because of the state of being non-existent, because of the state of being ownerless, because of the state of being subject to destruction, because of the state of being subject to change” .

original: 758. Evañhi passatānena tilakkhaṇaṃ āropetvā saṅkhārā pariggahitā nāma honti. Kasmā panāyamete evaṃ pariggaṇhātīti? Muñcanassa upāyasampādanatthaṃ.
analyzed: evam hi passatā anena ti lakkhaṇam āropetvā saṅkhārāḥ pariggahitāḥ nāma honti kasmā pana ayam ete evam pariggaṇhāti iti muñcanassa upāya sampādana attham
translated: When he sees them thus, then formations are said to be discerned by him after the three characteristics have been imposed on them. But why does he discern them in this way? In order to perfect the means to deliverance.🔽Here is a simile. A man, it seems, went to a lake to catch fish. He took a net,

original: Tatrāyaṃ upamā – eko kira puriso “macche gahessāmī”ti macchakhippaṃ gahetvā udake🔽oḍḍāpesi so khippamukhena hatthaṃ otāretvā antoudake sappaṃ gīvāya gahetvā “maccho
analyzed: tatra ayam upamā ekaḥ kira purisaḥ macche gahessāmi iti maccha khippam gahetvā udake 🔽oḍḍāpesi saḥ khippa mukhena hattham otāretvā antoudake sappam gīvāya gahetvā macchaḥ
translated: and having spread it on the water, he drew it in. In the net there was a snake. He seized it by the neck, thinking it was a fish.

original: me gahito”ti attamano ahosi. So “mahā vata mayā maccho laddho”ti ukkhipitvā passanto
analyzed: me gahitaḥ iti atta manaḥ ahosi saḥ mahā vata mayā macchaḥ laddho ti ukkhipitvā passantaḥ
translated: and he was pleased. He thought: “What a big fish I have caught!” He lifted it up and saw

original: sovatthikattayadassanena sappoti sañjānitvā bhīto ādīnavaṃ disvā gahaṇe nibbinno
analyzed: sovatthika ttaya dassanena sappo ti sañjānitvā bhītaḥ ādīnavam disvā gahaṇe nibbinnaḥ
translated: that it was a snake. He was frightened, saw the danger, and was disgusted with his capture.

original: muñcitukāmo hutvā muñcanassa upāyaṃ karonto agganaṅguṭṭhato paṭṭhāya hatthaṃ nibbeṭhetvā
analyzed: muñcitu kāmaḥ hutvā muñcanassa upāyam karontaḥ agga naṅguṭṭhataḥ paṭṭhāya hattham nibbeṭhetvā
translated: He wanted to let it go. He made a way to let it go. He took his hand from the tip of the tail.

original: bāhuṃ ukkhipitvā uparisīse dve tayo vāre āvijjhitvā sappaṃ dubbalaṃ katvā “gaccha🔽duṭṭha sappā”ti nissajjitvā vegena taḷākapāḷiṃ āruyha “mahantassa vata bho sappassa
analyzed: bāhum ukkhipitvā upari sīse dve tayaḥ vāre āvijjhitvā sappam dubbalam katvā gaccha  duṭṭha sappa ati nissajjitvā vegena taḷāka pāḷim āruyha mahantassa vata bho sappassa
translated: He lifted his arm, shook his head two or three times, and weakened the snake. He said: “Go away,

original: mukhato muttomhī”ti āgatamaggaṃ olokayamāno aṭṭhāsi.🔽Tattha tassa purisassa “maccho”ti sappaṃ gīvāya gahetvā tuṭṭhakālo viya imassāpi
analyzed: mukhataḥ muttaḥ aham iti āgata maggam olokayamāno aṭṭhāsi  tattha tassa purisassa maccho ti sappam gīvāya gahetvā tuṭṭha kālaḥ imassa api
translated: wicked snake!” He let it go. He quickly climbed the bank of the pond. He stood looking at the way he had come, thinking: “I have escaped from the mouth of a big snake.

original: yogino āditova attabhāvaṃ paṭilabhitvā tuṭṭhakālo, tassa khippamukhato sīsaṃ nīharitvā
analyzed: yogino āditas va atta bhāvam paṭilabhitvā tuṭṭha kālo tassa khippa mukhataḥ sīsam nīharitvā
translated: Herein, just as that man was pleased when he seized the snake by the neck, thinking: “It’s a fish,” so this meditator is pleased when he first obtains a personality, thinking: “I have a personality.” He takes the head out of the mouth of the swift one,🔽that is to say, he takes the head of the personality out of the mouth of the swift one, that is, of the swift process of the round of rebirths.

original: sovatthikattayadassanaṃ viya imassa ghanavinibbhogaṃ katvā saṅkhāresu tilakkhaṇadassanaṃ,
analyzed: sovatthika ttaya dassanam viya imassa ghana vinibbhogam katvā saṅkhāresu ti lakkhaṇa dassanam
translated: The seeing of the three characteristics in formations by way of the resolution of the compact is like the seeing of the three bones.

original: tassa bhītakālo viya imassa bhayatupaṭṭhānañāṇaṃ. Tato ādīnavadassanaṃ viya ādīnavānupassanāñāṇaṃ,🔽gahaṇe nibbindanaṃ viya nibbidānupassanāñāṇaṃ. Sappaṃ muñcitukāmatā viya muñcitukamyatāñāṇaṃ,
analyzed: tassa bhīta kālaḥ viya imassa bhaya tu paṭṭhāna ñāṇam tatas ādīnava dassanam viya ādīnava anupassanā ñāṇam  gahaṇe nibbindanam viya nibbida anupassanā ñāṇam sappam muñcitu kāma tā viya muñcitu kamya tā ñāṇam
translated: The knowledge of appearance as terror is like the time of fear. The knowledge of contemplation of danger is like the seeing of the danger.🔽The knowledge of contemplation of dispassion is like the dispassion in the seizing. The knowledge of desire for deliverance is like the desire to be delivered from the snake.

original: muñcanassa upāyakaraṇaṃ viya paṭisaṅkhānupassanāñāṇena saṅkhāresu tilakkhaṇāropanaṃ.
analyzed: muñcanassa upāya karaṇam viya paṭisaṅkhā anupassanā ñāṇena saṅkhāresu ti lakkhaṇa āropanam
translated: The knowledge of contemplation of reflection is like the making of a means of deliverance.

original: Yathā hi so puriso sappaṃ āvijjhitvā dubbalaṃ katvā nivattetvā ḍaṃsituṃ asamatthabhāvaṃ
analyzed: yathā hi saḥ purisaḥ sappam āvijjhitvā dubbalam katvā nivattetvā ḍaṃsitum a samattha bhāvam
translated: For just as that man, having struck the snake and weakened it, turned it back and brought it to the state of being unable to bite, and then delivered it well,

original: pāpetvā sumuttaṃ muñcati, evamayaṃ yogāvacaro tilakkhaṇāropanena saṅkhāre āvijjhitvā
analyzed: pāpetvā su muttam muñcati evam ayam yogāvacaraḥ ti lakkhaṇa āropanena saṅkhāre āvijjhitvā
translated: so too this meditator, having struck formations with the three characteristics,

original: dubbale katvā puna niccasukhasubhaattākārena upaṭṭhātuṃ asamatthataṃ pāpetvā sumuttaṃ
analyzed: dubbale katvā puna nicca sukha subha atta ākārena upaṭṭhātum pāpetvā su muttam
translated: having weakened them, having brought them to the state of being unable to appear again with the mode of appearance as permanent, blissful, and self, then delivers them well,

original: muñcati. Tena vuttaṃ “muñcanassa upāyasampādanatthaṃ evaṃ pariggaṇhātī”ti.
analyzed: muñcati tena vuttam muñcanassa upāya sampādana attham evam pariggaṇhāti iti
translated: He lets go. Hence it was said: “He discerns thus for the purpose of perfecting the letting go” .

original: 759. Ettāvatā tassa uppannaṃ hoti paṭisaṅkhāñāṇaṃ. Yaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ –🔽“Aniccato manasikaroto kiṃ paṭisaṅkhā ñāṇaṃ uppajjati? Dukkhato. Anattato manasikaroto
analyzed: ettāvatā tassa uppannam hoti paṭisaṅkhā ñāṇam yam sandhāya vuttam  aniccataḥ manasikarotaḥ kim paṭisaṅkhā ñāṇam uppajjati dukkhataḥ anattataḥ manasikarotaḥ
translated: At this point the knowledge of contemplation of reflection has arisen in him. It is with reference to this that it is said:

original: kiṃ paṭisaṅkhā ñāṇaṃ uppajjati? Aniccato manasikaroto nimittaṃ paṭisaṅkhā ñāṇaṃ uppajjati.
analyzed: kim paṭisaṅkhā ñāṇam uppajjati aniccataḥ manasikarotaḥ nimittam paṭisaṅkhā ñāṇam uppajjati
translated: “When he brings to mind as impermanent, what knowledge arises in him through contemplation of reflection? When he brings to mind as painful, what knowledge arises in him through contemplation of reflection? When he brings to mind as not-self, what knowledge arises in him through contemplation of reflection?🔽When he brings to mind as impermanent, knowledge of contemplation of reflection on the sign arises in him.

original: Dukkhato manasikaroto pavattaṃ paṭisaṅkhā ñāṇaṃ uppajjati. Anattato manasikaroto
analyzed: dukkhataḥ manasikarotaḥ pavattam paṭisaṅkhā ñāṇam uppajjati anattataḥ manasikarotaḥ
translated: When he brings to mind as painful, knowledge of contemplation of reflection on occurrence arises in him. When he brings to mind as not-self,

original: nimittañca pavattañca paṭisaṅkhā ñāṇaṃ uppajjatī”ti.
analyzed: nimittam ca pavattam ca paṭisaṅkhā ñāṇam uppajjati iti
translated: knowledge of contemplation of reflection on the sign and on occurrence arises in him” .

original: Ettha ca nimittaṃ paṭisaṅkhāti saṅkhāranimittaṃ “addhuvaṃ tāvakālika”nti aniccalakkhaṇavasena
analyzed: ettha ca nimittam paṭisaṅkhāti saṅkhāra nimittam addhuvam tāvakālikam ti anicca lakkhaṇa vasena
translated: Herein, “knowledge of contemplation of reflection on the sign” is the knowledge that arises when he has discerned the sign of formations thus “Impermanent, just suffering, not-self” by means of the characteristic of impermanence.

original: jānitvā. Kāmañca na paṭhamaṃ jānitvā pacchā ñāṇaṃ uppajjati, vohāravasena pana “manañca
analyzed: jānitvā kāmañca na paṭhamam jānitvā pacchā ñāṇam uppajjati vohāra vasena pana manaṃ ca
translated: And although the knowledge does not arise first and the discernment afterwards, still it is expressed in this way by conventional usage as “mind and mental factors” .

original: paṭicca dhamme ca uppajjati manoviññāṇa”ntiādīni viya evaṃ vuccati. Ekattanayena🔽vā purimañca pacchimañca ekaṃ katvā evaṃ vuttanti veditabbaṃ. Iminā nayena itarasmimpi
analyzed: paṭicca dhamme ca uppajjati manaḥ viññāṇa nti ādīni viya evam vuccati ekatta nayena  vā purimam ca pacchimam ca ekam katvā evam vuttan ti veditabbam iminā nayena itarasmim pi
translated: and mind-consciousness arises in dependence on the mind-object and mind.🔽Or else it can be understood that the two terms are taken together as one and so it is said.

original: padadvaye attho veditabboti.
analyzed: pada dvaye atthaḥ veditabbo ti
translated: The meaning should be understood in the same way in the other two cases.

original: Paṭisaṅkhānupassanāñāṇaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: paṭisaṅkhā anupassanā ñāṇam niṭṭhitam
translated: Knowledge of contemplation of reflection is ended.

original: Saṅkhārupekkhāñāṇakathā🔽760. So evaṃ paṭisaṅkhānupassanāñāṇena “sabbe saṅkhārā suññā”ti pariggahetvā puna
analyzed: saṅkhāra upekkhā ñāṇa kathā  saḥ evam paṭisaṅkhā anupassanā ñāṇena sabbe saṅkhārā suññā ti pariggahetvā puna
translated: Knowledge of equanimity about formations🔽Having discerned thus with knowledge of contemplation of reflection that “all formations are void,” he next discerns voidness in two ways,

original: “suññamidaṃ attena vā attaniyena vā”ti dvikoṭikaṃ suññataṃ pariggaṇhāti. So evaṃ
analyzed: suññam idam attena vā attaniyena vā ti dvi koṭikam suññatam pariggaṇhāti saḥ evam
translated: as “void of self or of the properties of a self.”

original: neva attānaṃ, na paraṃ kiñci attano parikkhārabhāve ṭhitaṃ disvā puna “nāhaṃ kvacani,
analyzed: na iva attānam na param kiñci attano parikkhāra bhāve ṭhitam disvā puna na aham kvacani
translated: Having seen thus that there is no self or anything pertaining to a self, he next discerns the voidness stated in four ways as follows:

original: kassaci kiñcanatasmiṃ, na ca mama kvacani, kismiñci kiñcanatatthī”ti yā ettha catukoṭikā🔽suññatā kathitā, taṃ pariggaṇhāti.
analyzed: kassaci kiñcana tasmin na ca mama kvacani kismiñci kiñcana tatthi iti yā ettha catu koṭikā 🔽suññatā kathitā tam pariggaṇhāti
translated: “I am nowhere the owner of anything, nor is there anything anywhere that is mine.”

original: Kathaṃ? Ayañhi nāhaṃ kvacanīti kvaci attānaṃ na passati. Kassaci kiñcanatasminti
analyzed: katham ayan hi na aham kvacani iti kvaci attānam na passati kassaci kiñcana tasmin ti
translated: How? He does not see himself anywhere as “I am this” .

analyzed: attanaḥ attānam kassaci parassa kiñcana bhāve upanetabbam na passati  bhātaram sahāya ṭṭhāne vā sahāyam parikkhāra ṭṭhāne vā parikkhāram maññitvā upanetabbam  na passati iti atthaḥ na ca mama kvacani iti ettha mama saddam tāva ṭhapetvā na ca kvacani iti
translated: He does not see himself as belonging to anyone else in any respect.

analyzed: parassa ca attānam kvaci na passati iti ayam atthaḥ idāni mama saddam āharitvā mama kismiñci

original: kiñcanatatthīti so parassa attā mama kismiñci kiñcanabhāve atthīti na passatīti.
analyzed: so parassa attā mama kismiñci kiñcana bhāve atthi iti na passati iti
translated: He does not see himself as belonging to anyone else in any respect.

original: Attano bhātiṭṭhāne vā bhātaraṃ, sahāyaṭṭhāne vā sahāyaṃ parikkhāraṭṭhāne vā parikkhāranti
analyzed: attanaḥ bhāti ṭṭhāne vā bhātaram sahāya ṭṭhāne vā sahāyam parikkhāra ṭṭhāne vā parikkhāranti
translated: He does not see himself as belonging to anyone else in any respect, thinking: “I am his brother in the place of a brother, or his friend in the place of a friend, or his relative in the place of a relative, or his servant in the place of a servant.”

analyzed: kismiñci ṭhāne parassa attānam iminā kiñcana bhāvena upanetabbam na passati iti attho
translated: He does not see himself as belonging to anyone else in any respect.

analyzed: evam ayam yasmā na iva katthaci attānam passati na tam parassa kiñcana bhāve upanetabbam

analyzed: upekkhā vā pāṭikulyatā vā saṇṭhāti  seyyathā api nāma paduma palāse īsaka poṇe udaka phusitāni patilīyanti patikuṭanti pativattanti
