As it is said:🔽“Three doors to freedom are proclaimed by the Lord, the Well-Farer, the Knower of the worlds, the Chief of men to be taught to the world with its gods, that is to say, the emptiness door to freedom, the desireless door to freedom, and the undirected door to freedom” .

original: samanupassanatāya, animittāya ca dhātuyā cittasampakkhandanatāya, sabbasaṅkhāresu🔽manosamuttejanatāya, appaṇihitāya ca dhātuyā cittasampakkhandanatāya, sabbadhamme
analyzed: samanupassana tāya animittāya ca dhātuyā citta sampakkhandana tāya sabba saṅkhāresu 🔽manaḥ samuttejana tāya appaṇihitāya ca dhātuyā citta sampakkhandana tāya sabba dhamme
translated: For the three contemplations are called the three doors to freedom in the sense of being the three doors to the escape from the world. As it is said:🔽“Three doors to freedom are proclaimed by the Lord, the Well-Farer, the Knower of the worlds, the Chief of men to be taught to the world with its gods, that is to say, the emptiness door to freedom, the desireless door to freedom, and the undirected door to freedom” .

original: parato samanupassanatāya, suññatāya ca dhātuyā cittasampakkhandanatāya, imāni tīṇi
analyzed: paratas samanupassana tāya suñña tāya ca dhātuyā citta sampakkhandana tāya imāni tīṇi
translated: and by looking on as alien, and by inclining the mind to voidness, these three

original: vimokkhamukhāni lokaniyyānāya saṃvattantī”ti.
analyzed: vimokkha mukhāni loka niyyānāya saṃvattanti iti
translated: openings of deliverance lead to the escape from the world.

original: Tattha paricchedaparivaṭumatoti udayabbayavasena paricchedato ceva parivaṭumato ca.
analyzed: tattha udaya bbaya vasena paricchedato ca iva parivaṭumato ca
translated: Herein, as to “by delimitation and by reversal”: as to delimitation and reversal by rise and fall.

original: Aniccānupassanaṃ hi “udayato pubbe saṅkhārā natthī”ti paricchinditvā tesaṃ gatiṃ
analyzed: anicca anupassanam hi udayataḥ pubbe saṅkhārāḥ na atthi iti paricchinditvā tesam gatim
translated: For when he contemplates impermanence he delimits formations thus: “Before their rise they were non-existent,”

original: samannesamānaṃ “vayato paraṃ na gacchanti, ettheva antaradhāyantī”ti parivaṭumato
analyzed: samannesamānam vayataḥ param na gacchanti etthā iva antaradhāyanti iti parivaṭumataḥ
translated: and when he seeks their going he sees that they do not go elsewhere but that they “disappear right here” .

original: samanupassati. Manosamuttejanatāyāti cittasaṃvejanatāya. Dukkhānupassanena hi saṅkhāresu
analyzed: samanupassati manaḥ samuttejana tāya ati citta saṃvejana tāya dukkha anupassanena hi saṅkhāresu
translated: As to “by arousing a sense of urgency”: as to arousing urgency in the mind. For by contemplating pain he arouses urgency in the mind about formations thus:

original: cittaṃ saṃvejeti. Parato samanupassanatāyāti “nāhaṃ, na mamā”ti evaṃ anattato samanupassanatāya.
analyzed: cittam saṃvejeti paratas samanupassana tāya ati na aham na mama ati evam anattataḥ samanupassana tāya
translated: “They are a thorn to me.” As to “by looking on as alien”: as to looking on as not self by way of “This is not mine, this I am not, this is not my self.”

original: Iti imāni tīṇi padāni aniccānupassanādīnaṃ vasena vuttānīti veditabbāni. Teneva tadanantare
analyzed: iti imāni tīṇi padāni anicca anupassanā ādīnam vasena vuttāni iti veditabbāni tena iva tad anantare
translated: So these three terms should be understood to be stated according to the contemplations of impermanence, and so on. That is why,🔽immediately after that, the following is said:

original: pañhavissajjane vuttaṃ – “aniccato manasikaroto khayato saṅkhārā upaṭṭhahanti. Dukkhato
analyzed: pañha vissajjane vuttam aniccataḥ manasikarotaḥ khayataḥ saṅkhārāḥ upaṭṭhahanti dukkhataḥ
translated: In the answer to the question, “When he brings formations to mind as impermanent, do they appear as impermanent or not?🔽As painful …

original: manasikaroto bhayato saṅkhārā upaṭṭhahanti. Anattato manasikaroto suññato saṅkhārā upaṭṭhahantī”ti.
analyzed: manasikarotaḥ bhayataḥ saṅkhārāḥ upaṭṭhahanti anattataḥ manasikarotaḥ suññataḥ saṅkhārāḥ upaṭṭhahanti iti
translated: In the answer to the question, “When he brings formations to mind as impermanent, do they appear as void? ” it is said: “When he brings formations to mind as impermanent, they appear as destroyed. When he brings them to mind as painful, they appear as a terror. When he brings them to mind as not-self, they appear as void” .

original: 769. Katame pana te vimokkhā, yesaṃ imāni anupassanāni mukhānīti? Animitto, appaṇihito,
analyzed: katame pana te vimokkhāḥ yesam imāni anupassanāni mukhāni iti animittaḥ appaṇihitaḥ
translated: But what are these emancipations of which these contemplations are the doors?🔽They are the three, namely, the signless, the desireless, and the void.

original: suññatoti ete tayo. Vuttaṃ hetaṃ “aniccato manasikaronto adhimokkhabahulo animittaṃ
analyzed: suññato ti ete tayaḥ vuttam ha etam aniccataḥ manasikarontaḥ adhimokkha bahulaḥ animittam
translated: For this is said: “When he brings formations to mind as impermanent, being abundant in resolution he obtains the signless emancipation.

original: vimokkhaṃ paṭilabhati. Dukkhato manasikaronto passaddhibahulo appaṇihitaṃ vimokkhaṃ
analyzed: vimokkham paṭilabhati dukkhataḥ manasikaronto passaddhi bahulaḥ appaṇihitam vimokkham
translated: When he brings them to mind as painful, being abundant in tranquillity he obtains the desireless emancipation.

original: paṭilabhati. Anattato manasikaronto vedabahulo suññatavimokkhaṃ paṭilabhatī”ti.🔽Ettha ca animitto vimokkhoti animittākārena nibbānaṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā pavatto ariyamaggo.
analyzed: paṭilabhati an attataḥ manasikarontaḥ veda bahulaḥ suññata vimokkham paṭilabhati iti  ettha ca animittaḥ vimokkhaḥ ti animitta ākārena nibbānam ārammaṇam katvā pavattaḥ ariya maggo
translated: When he brings them to mind as not-self, being abundant in knowledge he obtains the void emancipation” .🔽And here the noble path that occurs with the signless as its object is called “the signless emancipation” .

original: So hi animittāya dhātuyā uppannattā animitto. Kilesehi ca vimuttattā vimokkho. Eteneva
analyzed: saḥ hi animittāya dhātuyāḥ uppanna ttā animittaḥ kilesehi ca vimutta ttā vimokkhaḥ etena iva
translated: For that is “signless” because it arises in the signless element, and it is an “emancipation” because of emancipation from defilements.

original: nayena appaṇihitākārena nibbānaṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā pavatto appaṇihito. Suññatākārena
analyzed: nayena appaṇihita ākārena nibbānam ārammaṇam katvā pavattaḥ appaṇihitaḥ suññatā ākārena
translated: The void one is that which occurs making Nibbāna its object by way of the void aspect.🔽The desireless one is that which occurs making Nibbāna its object by way of the desireless aspect.🔽The signless one is that which occurs making Nibbāna its object by way of the signless aspect.

original: nibbānaṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā pavatto suññatoti veditabbo.🔽770. Yaṃ pana abhidhamme “yasmiṃ samaye lokuttaraṃ jhānaṃ bhāveti niyyānikaṃ apacayagāmiṃ🔽diṭṭhigatānaṃ pahānāya paṭhamāya bhūmiyā pattiyā vivicceva kāmehi paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ
analyzed: nibbānam ārammaṇam katvā pavatto suññato ti veditabbo  yam pana abhidhamme yasmin samaye lokuttaram jhānam bhāveti niyyānikam apacaya gāmiṃ  diṭṭhi gatānam pahānāya paṭhamāya bhūmiyā pattiyā vivicca iva kāmehi paṭhamam jhānam
translated: But in the Abhidhamma only the two liberations are mentioned thus:

original: upasampajja viharati appaṇihitaṃ suññata”nti evaṃ vimokkhadvayameva vuttaṃ, taṃ nippariyāyato
analyzed: upasampajja viharati appaṇihitam suññatam ti evam vimokkha dvayam eva vuttam tam nippariyāyato
translated: “When he develops the supramundane jhāna, which leads out of the various kinds of becoming, leads out of the various kinds of generation, leads out of the various kinds of destiny, leads out of the various kinds of rebirth, leads out of saṃsāra, is unadulterated with the heretical way, issues in the voidness of utter passing, and has the destruction of suffering as its goal, then, quite secluded from sense desires, secluded from unprofitable things, he enters upon and dwells in the first jhāna, which is desireless and void” .🔽This is said according to the arrival at insight knowledge.

original: vipassanāgamanaṃ sandhāya. Vipassanāñāṇaṃ hi kiñcāpi paṭisambhidāmagge –🔽“Aniccānupassanāñāṇaṃ niccato abhinivesaṃ muñcatīti suññato vimokkho. Dukkhānupassanāñāṇaṃ
analyzed: vipassanā gamanam sandhāya vipassanā ñāṇam hi kiñcā api paṭisambhidā magge  anicca anupassanā ñāṇam niccatas abhinivesam muñcati iti suññatas vimokkhaḥ dukkha anupassanā ñāṇam
translated: For insight knowledge is called “liberation” in the Paṭisambhidā:

original: sukhato abhinivesaṃ. Anattānupassanāñāṇaṃ attato abhinivesaṃ muñcatīti suññato vimokkho”ti
analyzed: sukhataḥ abhinivesam anatta anupassanā ñāṇam attataḥ abhinivesam muñcati iti suññataḥ vimokkhaḥ ti
translated: “Knowledge of contemplation of impermanence liberates by relinquishing the perversion of perceiving permanence. Knowledge of contemplation of pain liberates by relinquishing the perversion of perceiving pleasure. Knowledge of contemplation of not-self liberates by relinquishing the perversion of perceiving self” .

original: evaṃ abhinivesaṃ muñcanavasena suññato vimokkhoti ca,🔽“Aniccānupassanāñāṇaṃ niccato nimittaṃ muñcatīti animitto vimokkho. Dukkhānupassanāñāṇaṃ
analyzed: evam abhinivesam muñcana vasena ca  anicca anupassanā ñāṇam niccatas nimittam muñcati iti animittaḥ vimokkhaḥ dukkha anupassanā ñāṇam
translated: And it is the outlet by voidness in the sense of the outlet by relinquishing of misinterpreting in this way.🔽“Knowledge of contemplation of impermanence relinquishes misinterpreting as permanence;

original: sukhato nimittaṃ, anattānupassanāñāṇaṃ attato nimittaṃ muñcatīti animitto vimokkho”ti
analyzed: sukhataḥ nimittam anatta anupassanā ñāṇam attataḥ nimittam muñcati iti animittaḥ vimokkhaḥ ti
translated: knowledge of contemplation of pain relinquishes misinterpreting as pleasure; and knowledge of contemplation of not-self relinquishes misinterpreting as self. So it is the outlet by the signless in the sense of the outlet by relinquishing of the sign. ”

original: evaṃ nimittaṃ muñcanavasena animitto vimokkhoti ca,🔽“Aniccānupassanāñāṇaṃ niccato paṇidhiṃ muñcatīti appaṇihito vimokkho. Dukkhānupassanāñāṇaṃ
analyzed: evam nimittam muñcana vasena animittaḥ vimokkhaḥ ti ca  anicca anupassanā ñāṇam niccatas paṇidhim muñcati iti appaṇihitaḥ vimokkhaḥ dukkha anupassanā ñāṇam
translated: And it is the outlet by the signless in the sense of the outlet by relinquishing of the sign in this way.🔽“Knowledge of contemplation of impermanence relinquishes the wish for permanence;

original: sukhato paṇidhiṃ. Anattānupassanāñāṇaṃ attato paṇidhiṃ muñcatīti appaṇihito vimokkho”ti
analyzed: sukhataḥ paṇidhim anatta anupassanā ñāṇam attataḥ paṇidhim muñcati iti appaṇihitaḥ vimokkho ti
translated: knowledge of contemplation of pain relinquishes the wish for pleasure; and knowledge of contemplation of not-self relinquishes the wish for self. So it is the outlet by the desireless in the sense of the outlet by relinquishing of the wish. ”

original: evaṃ paṇidhiṃ muñcanavasena appaṇihito vimokkhoti ca –
analyzed: evam paṇidhim muñcana vasena appaṇihitaḥ vimokkho ti ca
translated: And it is the outlet by the desireless in the sense of the outlet by relinquishing of the wish in this way.🔽This is said.

original: Vuttaṃ. Tathāpi taṃ saṅkhāranimittassa avijahanato na nippariyāyena animittaṃ. Nippariyāyena
analyzed: vuttam tathā api tam saṅkhāra nimittassa a vijahanataḥ na nippariyāyena animittam nippariyāyena
translated: But it is not the signless in the absolute sense because it does not avoid the sign of formations.🔽However, it is voidness and desirelessness in the absolute sense.

original: pana suññatañceva appaṇihitañca. Tassa ca āgamanavasena ariyamaggakkhaṇe vimokkho
analyzed: pana suññatam ca iva appaṇihitam ca tassa ca āgamana vasena ariya magga kkhaṇe vimokkho
translated: And it is the outlet in the sense of the outlet by arrival at the moment of the noble path.

original: uddhaṭo. Tasmā appaṇihitaṃ suññatanti vimokkhadvayameva vuttanti veditabbaṃ. Ayaṃ
analyzed: tasmai appaṇihitam suññatam ti vimokkha dvayam eva vuttan ti veditabbam ayam
translated: So it should be understood that only the two liberations, namely, the void and the desireless, are referred to here.

original: tāvettha vimokkhakathā.
analyzed: vimokkha kathā
translated: This, in the first place, is the explanation of the liberations.

original: 771. Yaṃ pana vuttaṃ “sattaariyapuggalavibhāgāya paccayo hotī”ti, tattha saddhānusārī,
analyzed: yam pana vuttam satta ariya puggala vibhāgāya paccayaḥ hoti iti tattha saddhā anusārī
translated: But it was said above “it is a condition for the division of the ariyan into seven kinds” . Herein, the seven ariyan persons are the faith devotee,

original: saddhāvimutto, kāyasakkhi, ubhatobhāgavimutto, dhammānusārī, diṭṭhippatto, paññāvimuttoti
analyzed: saddhā vimutto kāya sakkhi ubhatobhāga vimutto dhamma anusārī diṭṭhi ppatto paññā vimutto ti
translated: the faith devotee liberated by wisdom, the body witness, the one attained to vision, the one liberated by faith, the one liberated by understanding, and the one attained to the vision of and the trend to penetration.

original: ime tāva satta ariyapuggalā, tesaṃ vibhāgāya idaṃ saṅkhārupekkhāñāṇaṃ paccayo hoti.
analyzed: ime tāva satta ariya puggalā tesam vibhāgāya idam saṅkhāra upekkhā ñāṇam paccayaḥ hoti
translated: This knowledge of equanimity about formations is a condition for the division of these seven ariyan persons.

original: 772. Yo hi aniccato manasikaronto adhimokkhabahulo saddhindriyaṃ paṭilabhati, so sotāpattimaggakkhaṇe saddhānusārī hoti. Sesesu sattasu ṭhānesu saddhāvimutto.
analyzed: yaḥ hi aniccataḥ manasikarontaḥ adhimokkha bahulaḥ saddhā indriyam paṭilabhati saḥ sotāpatti magga kkhaṇe saddhā anusārī hoti sesesu sattasu ṭhānesu saddhā vimuttaḥ
translated: For the faith devotee is one who, when he gives attention to the perception of impermanence, acquires the faith faculty in abundance, and he is a faith devotee at the moment of the stream-entry path. He is a faith devotee liberated by faith in the remaining seven instances.

original: 773. Yo pana dukkhato manasikaronto passaddhibahulo samādhindriyaṃ paṭilabhati, so
analyzed: yaḥ pana dukkhataḥ manasikarontaḥ passaddhi bahulaḥ samādhi indriyam paṭilabhati so
translated: But the one liberated by understanding is one who, when he gives attention to the perception of pain, acquires the concentration faculty in abundance,

original: sabbattha kāyasakkhi nāma hoti. Arūpajjhānaṃ pana patvā aggaphalappatto ubhatobhāgavimutto nāma hoti.
analyzed: sabbattha kāyasakkhi nāma hoti arūpa jjhānam pana patvā agga phala ppatto ubhatobhāgavimutto nāma hoti
translated: He is called a body witness everywhere. But when he has reached the jhāna of the formless world and the highest fruit, he is called one “liberated in both ways.”

original: 774. Yo pana anattato manasikaronto vedabahulo paññindriyaṃ paṭilabhati, so sotāpattimaggakkhaṇe dhammānusārī hoti. Chasu ṭhānesu diṭṭhippatto aggaphale paññāvimuttoti.
analyzed: yaḥ pana anattataḥ manasikarontaḥ veda bahulaḥ paññindriyam paṭilabhati so sotāpatti magga kkhaṇe dhamma anusārī hoti chasu ṭhānesu diṭṭhi patto agga phale paññā vimutto ti
translated: But one who, while giving attention to the contemplation of not-self, acquires the faculty of understanding in excess, is a Dhamma-follower at the moment of the path of stream-entry. He is one who has reached view at the six successive levels. He is one “liberated by understanding” at the highest fruit.

original: 775. Vuttaṃ hetaṃ –
analyzed: vuttam ha itam
translated: For this is said:🔽“When he gives attention to contemplation of impermanence, the faith faculty is outstanding in him. Because the faith faculty is outstanding, he acquires the path of stream-entry. He is called a faith- devotee” .

original: “Aniccato manasikaroto saddhindriyaṃ adhimattaṃ hoti. Saddhindriyassa adhimattattā sotāpattimaggaṃ paṭilabhati, tena vuccati saddhānusārī”ti.🔽Tathā “aniccato manasikaroto saddhindriyaṃ adhimattaṃ hoti, saddhindriyassa adhimattattā sotāpattiphalaṃ sacchikataṃ hoti, tena vuccati saddhāvimutto”tiādi.
analyzed: aniccataḥ manasikaroto saddhā indriyam adhimattam hoti saddhā indriyassa adhimatta ttā sotāpatti maggam paṭilabhati tena vuccati saddhā anusārī iti  tathā aniccataḥ manasikaroto saddhā indriyam adhimattam hoti saddhā indriyassa adhimatta ttā sotāpatti phalam sacchikatam hoti tena vuccati saddhā vimutta itiādi
translated: And similarly: “When he gives attention to contemplation of impermanence, the faith faculty is outstanding in him. Because the faith faculty is outstanding, he realizes the fruit of stream-entry. He is called one ‘liberated by faith’” .

original: 776. Aparampi vuttaṃ –
analyzed: aparam pi vuttam
translated: And this is also said:
