original: Tathā paññāsaṅkhātaṃ dhammaṃ anusarati, dhammena vā anusaratīti dhammānusārī. Arūpajjhānena
analyzed: tathā paññā saṅkhātam dhammam anusarati dhammena vā anusarati iti dhamma anusārī arūpa jhānena
translated: “One who follows the Dhamma” : one who follows the Dhamma called wisdom, or one who goes by the Dhamma.

original: ceva ariyamaggena cāti ubhatobhāgena vimuttoti ubhatobhāgavimutto. Pajānanto vimuttoti
analyzed: ca iva ariya maggena ca ati ubhatobhāgena vimutto ti ubhatobhāga vimuttaḥ pajānantaḥ vimutto iti
translated: “One liberated in both ways” : one liberated by both the formless jhānas and the noble path.🔽“One liberated by wisdom” : one liberated by the wisdom of the path of arahantship.

original: paññāvimuttoti evaṃ vacanattho veditabboti.
analyzed: paññā vimutto ti evam vacana attho veditabbaḥ ti
translated: This is how the meaning of the terms should be understood.

original: Saṅkhārupekkhāñāṇaṃ.
analyzed: saṅkhāra upekkhā ñāṇam
translated: Knowledge of equanimity about formations.🔽But this knowledge is the same in meaning as the preceding two knowledges. Hence the ancients said:

original: 778. Taṃ panetaṃ purimena ñāṇadvayena atthato ekaṃ. Tenāhu porāṇā – “idaṃ saṅkhārupekkhāñāṇaṃ
analyzed: tam pana itam purimena ñāṇa dvayena atthataḥ ekam tena āhu porāṇāḥ idam saṅkhāra upekkhā ñāṇam
translated: “This knowledge of equanimity about formations

original: ekameva tīṇi nāmāni labhati, heṭṭhā muñcitukamyatāñāṇaṃ nāma jātaṃ, majjhe paṭisaṅkhānupassanāñāṇaṃ
analyzed: ekam eva tīṇi nāmāni labhati heṭṭhā muñcitu kamya tā ñāṇam nāma jātam majjhe paṭisaṅkhā anupassanā ñāṇam
translated: It has only one name, namely, knowledge of equanimity about formations.🔽But it has three names according to position, namely, knowledge of desire for deliverance below, knowledge of contemplation of reflection in the middle,

original: nāma, ante ca sikhāppattaṃ saṅkhārupekkhāñāṇaṃ nāma”.
analyzed: nāma ante ca sikhāppattam saṅkhārupekkhāñāṇam nāma
translated: and knowledge of equanimity about formations that has reached the peak above.

original: 779. Pāḷiyampi vuttaṃ –🔽“Kathaṃ muñcitukamyatā-paṭisaṅkhā-santiṭṭhanā paññā saṅkhārupekkhāsu ñāṇaṃ? Uppādaṃ🔽muñcitukamyatā-paṭisaṅkhā-santiṭṭhanā paññā saṅkhārupekkhāsu ñāṇaṃ. Pavattaṃ…pe…🔽nimittaṃ…pe… upāyāsaṃ muñcitukamyatāpaṭisaṅkhā-santiṭṭhanā paññā saṅkhārupekkhāsu🔽ñāṇaṃ. Uppādo dukkhanti…pe… bhayanti…pe… sāmisanti…pe… uppādo saṅkhārāti…pe… upāyāso
analyzed: pāḷiyam pi vuttam  katham muñcitu kamya tā paṭisaṅkhā santiṭṭhanā paññā saṅkhāra upekkhāsu ñāṇam uppādam  muñcitu kamya tā paṭisaṅkhā santiṭṭhanā paññā saṅkhāra upekkhāsu ñāṇam pavattam pe  upāyāsam muñcitu kamya tā paṭisaṅkhā santiṭṭhanā paññā saṅkhāra upekkhāsu  ñāṇam uppādaḥ dukkha antipe bhaya ntipe sa āmisa antipe uppādaḥ saṅkhāra atipe upāyāsaḥ
translated: And this is said in the text:

original: saṅkhārāti muñcitukamyatā-paṭisaṅkhā-santiṭṭhanā paññā saṅkhārupekkhāsu ñāṇa”nti.🔽780. Tattha muñcitukamyatā ca sā paṭisaṅkhā ca santiṭṭhanā cāti muñcitukamyatā-paṭisaṅkhā-santiṭṭhanā.
analyzed: saṅkhārā ati muñcitu kamya tā paṭisaṅkhā santiṭṭhanā paññā saṅkhāra upekkhāsu ñāṇam ti 🔽tattha muñcitu kamya tā ca sā paṭisaṅkhā ca santiṭṭhanā ca ati muñcitu kamya tā paṭisaṅkhā santiṭṭhanā
translated: “How is it that understanding of desire for deliverance, of reflection, and of steadiness is knowledge of equanimity about formations? Understanding of desire for deliverance, of reflection, and of steadiness in regard to arising is knowledge of equanimity about formations. Understanding of desire for deliverance, of reflection, and of steadiness in regard to occurrence … in regard to appearance … in regard to signs … in regard to intentions … in regard to manifestation … in regard to clinging … in regard to development … in regard to change … in regard to conditions … in regard to birth … in regard to ageing … in regard to sickness … in regard to death … in regard to sorrow … in regard to lamentation … in regard to despair … in regard to suffering … in regard to stress … in regard to agitation … in regard to defilement is knowledge of equanimity about formations. Understanding of desire for deliverance, of reflection, and of steadiness in regard to arising as painful … as a danger … as a dart … in regard to arising as formed … as a disease … as a boil … as a dart … as a calamity … as an affliction … as alien … as disintegrating … as a plague … as a bondage … as a bondage of craving … as a bondage of views … as a bondage of doubt … as a bondage of conceit … as a bondage of greed … as a bondage of hatred … as a bondage of delusion … in regard to arising as subject to cankers … as the world … as a mere heap … as subject to destruction … as subject to vanishing … as subject to arising … as subject to disappearance … as subject to change is knowledge of equanimity about formations. Understanding of desire for deliverance, of reflection, and of steadiness in regard to birth as a dart … in regard to ageing as a dart … in regard to sickness as a dart … in regard to death as a dart … in regard to sorrow as a dart … in regard to lamentation as a dart … in regard to despair as a dart … in regard to suffering as a dart … in regard to stress as a dart … in regard to agitation as a dart … in regard to defilement as a dart is knowledge of equanimity about

original: Iti pubbabhāge nibbidāñāṇena nibbinnassa uppādādīni pariccajitukāmatā muñcitukāmatā.
analyzed: iti pubba bhāge nibbidā ñāṇena nibbinnassa uppāda ādīni pariccajitu kāma tā muñcitu kāma tā
translated: So in the earlier stage, when he is dispassionate through the knowledge of dispassion, his desire to abandon and his desire to be delivered are due to his wanting to abandon and to be delivered from the arising, etc., of formations.🔽In the middle stage, the investigation is the means for his delivery.

original: Muñcanassa upāyakaraṇatthaṃ majjhe paṭisaṅkhānaṃ paṭisaṅkhā. Muñcitvā avasāne ajjhupekkhanaṃ
analyzed: muñcanassa upāya karaṇa attham majjhe paṭisaṅkhānam paṭisaṅkhāḥ muñcitvā avasāne ajjhupekkhanam
translated: In the later stage, when he has been delivered, his equanimity is the establishment.

original: santiṭṭhanā. Yaṃ sandhāya “uppādo saṅkhārā, te saṅkhāre ajjhupekkhatīti saṅkhārupekkhā”tiādi
analyzed: santiṭṭhanā yam sandhāya uppādaḥ saṅkhārā te saṅkhāre ajjhupekkhati iti saṅkhārupekkhā atiādi
translated: It is with reference to this that it is said: “The arising of formations is formations; he looks on at formations with equanimity. Thus it is insight with regard to formations” .

original: vuttaṃ. Evaṃ ekamevidaṃ ñāṇaṃ.🔽781. Apica imāyapi pāḷiyā idaṃ ekamevāti veditabbaṃ. Vuttaṃ hetaṃ – “yā ca muñcitukamyatā,
analyzed: vuttam evam ekam eva idam ñāṇam  apica imāya api pāḷiyāḥ idam ekam eva ati veditabbam vuttam ha itam yā ca muñcitu kamya tā
translated: So this is a single kind of knowledge.

original: yā ca paṭisaṅkhānupassanā, yā ca saṅkhārupekkhā, ime dhammā ekatthā, byañjanameva nāna”nti.
analyzed: yā ca paṭisaṅkhā anupassanā yā ca saṅkhāra upekkhā ime dhammā ekatthāḥ byañjanam eva nānanti
translated: Besides, it should be understood that it is a single kind of knowledge also according to this text: “The desire to be delivered, the investigation of deliverance, and the equanimity about formations—these things are one in meaning and only the letter is different” .

original: 782. Evaṃ adhigatasaṅkhārupekkhassa pana imassa kulaputtassa vipassanā sikhāppattā
analyzed: evam adhigata saṅkhāra upekkhassa pana imassa kula puttassa vipassanā sikhā appattā
translated: But when this clansman has thus acquired equanimity about formations, his insight has reached the culmination of clear vision

original: vuṭṭhānagāminī hoti. Sikhāppattā vipassanāti vā vuṭṭhānagāminīti vā saṅkhārupekkhādiñāṇattayasseva
analyzed: vuṭṭhāna gāminī hoti sikhāppattā vipassanā ati vā vuṭṭhāna gāminī iti vā saṅkhāra upekkhā ādi ñāṇa ttayassa eva
translated: and it is on the way to emergence.

original: etaṃ nāmaṃ. Sā hi sikhaṃ uttamabhāvaṃ pattattā sikhāppattā. Vuṭṭhānaṃ gacchatīti🔽vuṭṭhānagāminī. Vuṭṭhānaṃ vuccati bahiddhānimittabhūtato abhiniviṭṭhavatthuto ceva
analyzed: etam nāmam sā hi sikham uttama bhāvam pattattā sikhā appattā vuṭṭhānam gacchati iti  vuṭṭhāna gāminī vuṭṭhānam vuccati bahiddhā nimitta bhūtataḥ abhiniviṭṭha vatthutaḥ ca iva
translated: This is the name. It has reached the crest, has become the best, thus it is reached the crest . It goes to emergence,

original: ajjhattapavattato ca vuṭṭhahanato maggo, taṃ gacchatīti vuṭṭhānagāminī, maggena saddhiṃ ghaṭiyatīti attho.
analyzed: ajjhatta pavattataḥ ca vuṭṭhahanataḥ maggo tam gacchati iti vuṭṭhāna gāminī maggena saddhim
translated: thus it is emergence-going . The path is called emergence because it emerges from the internal, and because it emerges from the objective field that has become the external, and because it emerges from the state of being occupied with that. It goes to that, thus it is emergence-going. The meaning is that it is associated with the path.

original: 783. Tatrāyaṃ abhinivesavuṭṭhānānaṃ āvibhāvatthāya mātikā – ajjhattaṃ abhinivisitvā
analyzed: tatra ayam abhinivesa vuṭṭhānānam āvi bhāva tthāya mātikā ajjhattam abhinivisitvā
translated: Here is a schedule for the purpose of clarifying the emergence from the state of being occupied with that:

original: ajjhattā vuṭṭhāti, ajjhattaṃ abhinivisitvā bahiddhā vuṭṭhāti, bahiddhā abhinivisitvā
analyzed: ajjhattā vuṭṭhāti ajjhattam abhinivisitvā bahiddhā vuṭṭhāti bahiddhā abhinivisitvā
translated: having been occupied with the internal, he emerges from the internal; having been occupied with the internal, he emerges from the external; having been occupied with the external,

original: bahiddhā vuṭṭhāti, bahiddhā abhinivisitvā ajjhattā vuṭṭhāti, rūpe abhinivisitvā rūpā
analyzed: bahiddhā vuṭṭhāti bahiddhā abhinivisitvā ajjhattā vuṭṭhāti rūpe abhinivisitvā
translated: he emerges from the external; having been occupied with the external, he emerges from the internal; having been occupied with materiality, he emerges from materiality;

original: vuṭṭhāti, rūpe abhinivisitvā arūpā vuṭṭhāti, arūpe abhinivisitvā arūpā vuṭṭhāti,
analyzed: vuṭṭhāti rūpe abhinivisitvā arūpā vuṭṭhāti arūpe abhinivisitvā arūpā vuṭṭhāti
translated: having been occupied with materiality, he emerges from the immaterial; having been occupied with the immaterial, he emerges from the immaterial;

original: arūpe abhinivisitvā rūpā vuṭṭhāti, ekappahārena pañcahi khandhehi vuṭṭhāti, aniccato
analyzed: arūpe abhinivisitvā rūpā vuṭṭhāti eka ppahārena pañcahi khandhehi vuṭṭhāti aniccato
translated: having been occupied with the immaterial, he emerges from materiality; he emerges from the five aggregates by a single act of contemplation; he emerges from impermanence,

original: abhinivisitvā aniccato vuṭṭhāti, aniccato abhinivisitvā dukkhato, anattato vuṭṭhāti,🔽dukkhato abhinivisitvā dukkhato, aniccato, anattato vuṭṭhāti, anattato abhinivisitvā
analyzed: abhinivisitvā aniccataḥ vuṭṭhāti aniccataḥ abhinivisitvā dukkhataḥ anattataḥ vuṭṭhāti  dukkhataḥ abhinivisitvā dukkhataḥ aniccataḥ anattataḥ vuṭṭhāti anattataḥ abhinivisitvā
translated: When he emerges from insight into impermanence, he emerges from insight into suffering and nonself.🔽When he emerges from insight into suffering, he emerges from insight into suffering, impermanence, and nonself.

original: anattato, aniccato, dukkhato vuṭṭhāti.
analyzed: anattataḥ aniccataḥ dukkhataḥ vuṭṭhāti
translated: When he emerges from insight into nonself, he emerges from insight into nonself, impermanence, and suffering.

original: 784. Kathaṃ? Idhekacco āditova ajjhattasaṅkhāresu abhinivisati, abhinivisitvā te
analyzed: katham idha ekaccaḥ āditas va ajjhatta saṅkhāresu abhinivisati abhinivisitvā te
translated: How? Here someone first of all adverts to internal formations. Having adverted, he sees them as impermanent, painful, and not-self.

original: passati. Yasmā pana na suddhaajjhattadassanamatteneva maggavuṭṭhānaṃ hoti, bahiddhāpi
analyzed: passati yasmā pana na suddha ajjhatta dassana mattena iva magga vuṭṭhānam hoti bahiddhā api
translated: But insight does not emerge through mere seeing of internal formations;

original: daṭṭhabbameva, tasmā parassa khandhepi anupādiṇṇasaṅkhārepi aniccaṃ dukkhamanattāti
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam eva tasmā parassa khandhe pi an upādiṇṇa saṅkhāre pi aniccam dukkham anattā ti
translated: he must also see external formations as impermanent, painful, and not-self.🔽So he comprehends his own aggregates as impermanent, painful, and not-self, and he also comprehends another’s aggregates and formations not conjoined with himself as impermanent, painful, and not-self.

original: passati. So kālena ajjhattaṃ sammasati, kālena bahiddhā. Tassevaṃ sammasato ajjhattaṃ
analyzed: passati saḥ kālena ajjhattam sammasati kālena bahiddhā tassa ivam sammasataḥ ajjhattam
translated: As he comprehends thus, sometimes he comprehends internally and sometimes externally.

original: sammasanakāle vipassanā maggena saddhiṃ ghaṭiyati. Ayaṃ ajjhattaṃ abhinivisitvā ajjhattā vuṭṭhāti nāma.
analyzed: sammasana kāle vipassanā maggena saddhim ghaṭiyati ayam ajjhattam abhinivisitvā ajjhattā vuṭṭhāti nāma
translated: When he comprehends internally, insight comes to culmination together with the path. This is called “emerging from insight by way of internal adverting.”

original: Sace panassa bahiddhā sammasanakāle vipassanā maggena saddhiṃ ghaṭiyati, ayaṃ ajjhattaṃ
analyzed: sace pana assa bahiddhā sammasana kāle vipassanā maggena saddhim ghaṭiyati ayam ajjhattam
translated: But if insight coincides with the path at the time of the external survey, then the external survey is the survey of the path.

original: abhinivisitvā bahiddhā vuṭṭhāti nāma. Esa nayo bahiddhā abhinivisitvā bahiddhā ca
analyzed: abhinivisitvā bahiddhā vuṭṭhāti nāma esa nayaḥ bahiddhā abhinivisitvā bahiddhā ca
translated: But if insight comes to culmination together with the path while he is comprehending externally, then this is called “emerging after resolving upon the internal and emerging externally.”

original: ajjhattā ca vuṭṭhānepi.
analyzed: ajjhattā ca vuṭṭhāne pi
translated: The same method applies to resolving upon the external and emerging externally and internally.

original: 785. Aparo āditova rūpe abhinivisati, abhinivisitvā bhūtarūpañca upādārūpañca rāsiṃ
analyzed: aparaḥ rūpe abhinivisati abhinivisitvā bhūta rūpam ca upādā rūpam ca
translated: Another, from the beginning, resolves upon materiality, and after resolving he sees materiality as a mass by including both primary and secondary matter.

original: katvā passati. Yasmā pana na suddharūpadassanamatteneva vuṭṭhānaṃ hoti, arūpampi
analyzed: katvā passati yasmā pana na suddha rūpa dassana mattena iva vuṭṭhānam hoti arūpam pi
translated: But since emergence does not come about merely by seeing materiality, he must also see the immaterial.

original: daṭṭhabbameva. Tasmā taṃ rūpaṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā uppannaṃ vedanaṃ saññaṃ saṅkhāre viññāṇañca
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam eva tasmai tam rūpam ārammaṇam katvā uppannam vedanam saññam saṅkhāre viññāṇam ca
translated: So he sees the feeling, perception, formations and consciousness that have arisen making that materiality their object thus, “This is immaterial.”

original: “idaṃ arūpa”nti arūpaṃ passati. So kālena rūpaṃ sammasati, kālena arūpaṃ. Tassevaṃ
analyzed: idam arūpanti arūpam passati so kālena rūpam sammasati kālena arūpam tassa evam
translated: He comprehends materiality sometimes and the immaterial sometimes.

original: sammasato rūpasammasanakāle vipassanā maggena saddhiṃ ghaṭiyati, ayaṃ rūpe abhinivisitvā rūpā vuṭṭhāti nāma.
analyzed: sammasataḥ rūpa sammasana kāle vipassanā maggena saddhim ghaṭiyati ayam rūpe abhinivisitvā rūpā vuṭṭhāti nāma
translated: As he comprehends them thus, insight comes to culmination together with the path while he is comprehending materiality, and this is called “emerging after resolving upon materiality and emerging from materiality.”

original: Sace panassa arūpasammasanakāle vipassanā maggena saddhiṃ ghaṭiyati, ayaṃ arūpe abhinivisitvā arūpā vuṭṭhāti nāma. Esa nayo arūpe abhinivisitvā arūpā ca rūpā ca vuṭṭhānepi.
analyzed: sace pana assa arūpa sammasana kāle vipassanā maggena saddhim ghaṭiyati ayaṃ arūpe abhinivisitvā arūpā vuṭṭhāti nāma esa nayaḥ arūpe abhinivisitvā arūpā ca rūpā ca vuṭṭhāne pi
translated: But if insight comes to culmination together with the path at the time of the contemplation of the immaterial states, then he emerges from the immaterial states by penetrating them. The same method applies to the emergence by penetrating the immaterial states and the material states.

original: 786. “Yaṃkiñci samudayadhammaṃ, sabbaṃ taṃ nirodhadhamma”nti evaṃ abhinivisitvā evameva vuṭṭhānakāle pana ekappahārena pañcahi khandhehi vuṭṭhāti nāma.
analyzed: yaṃ kiñci samudaya dhammam sabbam tat nirodha dhamman ti evam abhinivisitvā evam eva vuṭṭhāna kāle pana eka ppahārena pañcahi khandhehi vuṭṭhāti nāma
translated: But when he emerges by penetrating thus, “Whatever is dependently arisen is of the nature to cease,” then he emerges all at once from the five aggregates subject to clinging.

original: 787. Eko āditova aniccato saṅkhāre sammasati. Yasmā pana na aniccato sammasanamatteneva
analyzed: ekaḥ āditas va aniccataḥ saṅkhāre sammasati yasmā pana na aniccataḥ sammasana mattena iva
translated: One who does so from the beginning contemplates formations as impermanent. But emergence does not come about merely by contemplating in this way.

original: vuṭṭhānaṃ hoti, dukkhatopi anattatopi sammasitabbameva, tasmā dukkhatopi anattatopi🔽sammasati. Tassevaṃ paṭipannassa aniccato sammasanakāle vuṭṭhānaṃ hoti, ayaṃ aniccato
analyzed: vuṭṭhānam hoti dukkhataḥ pi anattataḥ pi sammasitabbam eva tasmā dukkhataḥ pi anattataḥ pi  sammasati tassa ivam paṭipannassa aniccato sammasana kāle vuṭṭhānam hoti ayam aniccato
translated: Therefore he must also contemplate them as painful and not-self.

original: abhinivisitvā aniccato vuṭṭhāti nāma.
analyzed: abhinivisitvā aniccataḥ vuṭṭhāti nāma
translated: When he does so, emergence comes about at the time of the contemplation of impermanence. This is called “emergence by penetrating impermanence.”

original: Sace panassa dukkhato anattato sammasanakāle vuṭṭhānaṃ hoti, ayaṃ aniccato abhinivisitvā🔽dukkhato, anattato vuṭṭhāti nāma. Esa nayo dukkhato anattato abhinivisitvā sesavuṭṭhānesupi.
analyzed: sace panassa dukkhataḥ anattataḥ sammasana kāle vuṭṭhānam hoti ayam aniccataḥ abhinivisitvā  dukkhataḥ anattataḥ vuṭṭhāti nāma esa nayaḥ dukkhataḥ anattataḥ abhinivisitvā sesa vuṭṭhānesu pi
translated: But if he emerges from the contemplation of pain and of not-self, then he is said to emerge from the contemplation of impermanence,🔽having penetrated to the three characteristics. The same method applies in the case of the emergence from the contemplation of pain and of not-self.

original: 788. Ettha ca yopi aniccato abhiniviṭṭho, yopi dukkhato, yopi anattato, vuṭṭhānakāle🔽ca aniccato vuṭṭhānaṃ hoti. Tayopi janā adhimokkhabahulā honti, saddhindriyaṃ paṭilabhanti,
analyzed: ettha ca yaḥ api aniccataḥ abhiniviṭṭhaḥ yaḥ api dukkhataḥ yaḥ api anattataḥ vuṭṭhāna kāle  ca aniccataḥ vuṭṭhānam hoti janāḥ adhimokkha bahulāḥ honti saddhi indriyam paṭilabhanti
translated: And here, when any one of the three who has penetrated to the three characteristics emerges from the contemplation of impermanence,

original: animittavimokkhena vimuccanti, paṭhamamaggakkhaṇe saddhānusārino honti, sattasu ṭhānesu🔽saddhāvimuttā. Sace pana dukkhato vuṭṭhānaṃ hoti, tayopi janā passaddhibahulā honti,
analyzed: animitta vimokkhena vimuccanti paṭhama magga kkhaṇe saddhā anusārinaḥ honti sattasu ṭhānesu  saddhā vimuttā sace pana dukkhataḥ vuṭṭhānam hoti tayo api janā passaddhi bahulāḥ honti
translated: all three are abundant in resolution and they acquire the faith faculty. They are liberated by the signless liberation. At the moment of the first path they are faith devotees. In the seven stations they are liberated by faith.

original: samādhindriyaṃ paṭilabhanti, appaṇihitavimokkhena vimuccanti, sabbattha kāyasakkhino
analyzed: samādhi indriyam paṭilabhanti appaṇihita vimokkhena vimuccanti sabbattha kāya sakkhino
translated: But if he emerges from the contemplation of pain, all three are abundant in tranquillity and they acquire the concentration faculty. They are liberated by the desireless liberation. They are bodily witnesses.

original: honti. Yassa panettha arūpajjhānaṃ pādakaṃ, so aggaphale ubhatobhāgavimutto hoti.
analyzed: honti yassa pana ittha arūpa jhānam pādakam so agga phale ubhatobhāga vimuttaḥ hoti
translated: But if he has the immaterial jhāna as the basis for his insight, then he is one “liberated in both ways” in the case of the highest fruition.

original: Atha nesaṃ anattato vuṭṭhānaṃ hoti, tayopi janā vedabahulā honti, paññindriyaṃ paṭilabhanti,
analyzed: atha nesam anattataḥ vuṭṭhānam hoti janāḥ veda bahulāḥ honti paññindriyam paṭilabhanti
translated: Then their emergence from not-self occurs. All three persons have much knowledge. They acquire the faculty of understanding.

original: suññatavimokkhena vimuccanti, paṭhamamaggakkhaṇe dhammānusārino honti, chasu ṭhānesu
analyzed: suññata vimokkhena vimuccanti paṭhama magga kkhaṇe dhamma anusārinaḥ honti chasu ṭhānesu
translated: They are liberated by the void liberation. At the moment of the first path they are “followers of the Dhamma.” In the six ways they are

original: diṭṭhippattā aggaphale paññāvimuttāti.
analyzed: diṭṭhi ppattā agga phale paññā vimuttā ti
translated: “perfected in view.” In the supreme fruit they are “understanding-liberated.”

original: 789. Idāni saddhiṃ purimapacchimañāṇehi imissā vuṭṭhānagāminiyā vipassanāya āvibhāvatthaṃ dvādasa upamā veditabbā. Tāsaṃ idaṃ uddānaṃ –
analyzed: idāni saddhim purima pacchima ñāṇehi imissā vuṭṭhāna gāminiyā vipassanāya āvi bhāva attham dvādasa upamā veditabbā tāsam idam uddānam
translated: Now, in order to elucidate this emergence-by-understanding, together with the preceding and the subsequent kinds of knowledge, twelve similes should be known. Here is the summary for the similes:

original: “Vaggulī kaṇhasappo ca, gharaṃ go yakkhi dārako;
analyzed: vaggulī kaṇhasappaḥ ca gharam go yakkhi dārako
translated: The basket, the black snake, The house, the cow, the ghost, the child,

original: Khuddaṃ pipāsaṃ sītuṇhaṃ, andhakāraṃ visena cā”ti.
analyzed: khuddam pipāsam sītuṇham andhakāram visena ca ati
translated: Hunger, thirst, cold, heat, Darkness, and with poison.

original: Imā ca upamā bhayatupaṭṭhānato pabhuti yattha katthaci ñāṇe ṭhatvā āharituṃ vaṭṭeyyuṃ.
analyzed: imāḥ ca upamāḥ yattha katthaci ñāṇe ṭhatvā āharitum vaṭṭeyyuṃ
translated: These similes can be brought in anywhere, beginning with the appearance of fear, and they can be brought in in any one of the kinds of knowledge.

original: Imasmiṃ pana ṭhāne āhariyamānāsu bhayatupaṭṭhānato yāva phalañāṇaṃ sabbaṃ pākaṭaṃ
analyzed: imasmim pana ṭhāne āhariyamānāsu bhaya tu paṭṭhānato yāva phala ñāṇam sabbam pākaṭam
translated: But when they are brought in here, then all the rest, beginning with the appearance of fear and ending with the knowledge of the fruit, is evident.

original: hoti, tasmā idheva āharitabbāti vuttā.
analyzed: hoti tasmai idha iva āharitabbā ati vuttā
translated: So they are said to be brought in here.

original: 790. Vaggulīti ekā kira vaggulī “ettha pupphaṃ vā phalaṃ vā labhissāmī”ti pañcasākhe
analyzed: vaggulī iti ekā kira vaggulī ettha puppham vā phalam vā labhissāmi iti pañcasākhe
translated: A vaggulī is a kind of bee. It is said that one of these, thinking “Here I shall get flowers or fruits,”

original: madhukarukkhe nilīyitvā ekaṃ sākhaṃ parāmasitvā na tattha kiñci pupphaṃ phalaṃ vā
analyzed: madhuka rukkhe nilīyitvā ekam sākham parāmasitvā na tattha kiñci puppham phalam vā
translated: climbed a five-branched tree for honey and, after seizing one branch, did not see any flowers or fruits there.

original: gayhupagaṃ addasa. Yathā ca ekaṃ, evaṃ dutiyaṃ, tatiyaṃ, catutthaṃ. Pañcamampi sākhaṃ
analyzed: yathā ca ekam evam dutiyam tatiyam catuttham pañcamam pi
translated: And just as with one, so with the second, the third, the fourth, and the fifth branch.

original: parāmasitvā nāddasa. Sā “aphalo vatāyaṃ rukkho, natthettha kiñci gayhupaga”nti tasmiṃ
analyzed: parāmasitvā na addasa sā aphalaḥ vata ayam rukkho nattha ittha kiñci tasmiṃ
translated: And after seizing the fifth branch, she did not see any. Then she thought, “This tree is fruitless; there is nothing to be got here,”

original: rukkhe ālayaṃ vissajjetvā ujukāya sākhāya āruyha viṭapantarena sīsaṃ nīharitvā uddhaṃ
analyzed: rukkhe ālayam vissajjetvā ujukāya sākhāyaḥ āruyha viṭa pantarena sīsam nīharitvā uddhaṃ
translated: and after giving up her hold on the tree, she climbed up a straight branch, thrust her head through the middle of the foliage,

original: ulloketvā ākāse uppatitvā aññasmiṃ phalarukkhe nilīyati.🔽Tattha vagguli viya yogāvacaro daṭṭhabbo, pañcasākho madhukarukkho viya pañcupādānakkhandhā,
analyzed: ulloketvā ākāse uppatitvā aññasmin phala rukkhe nilīyati  tattha vagguli viya yoga avacaraḥ daṭṭhabbo pañca sākhaḥ madhuka rukkhaḥ viya pañca upādānakkhandhā
translated: and after looking up into the sky, she flew up into the air and settled in another fruit tree.🔽Herein, the meditator is like the vaggulī, the five aggregates as objects of clinging are like the five-branched tree for honey,

original: tattha vagguliyā nilīyanaṃ viya yogino khandhapañcake abhiniveso, tassā ekekaṃ sākhaṃ
analyzed: tattha vagguliyāḥ nilīyanam viya yogino khandha pañcake abhiniveso tassāḥ ekekam
translated: and the meditator’s misinterpreting the five aggregates as objects of clinging is like the vaggulī’s climbing the tree.

original: parāmasitvā kiñci gayhupagaṃ adisvā avasesasākhāparāmasanaṃ viya yogino rūpakkhandhaṃ🔽sammasitvā tattha kiñci gayhupagaṃ adisvā avasesakkhandhasammasanaṃ, tassā “aphalo
analyzed: parāmasitvā kiñci a disvā avasesa sākhā parāmasanam viya yoginaḥ rūpa kkhandham  sammasitvā tattha kiñci a disvā avasesa khandha sammasanam tassāḥ aphalo
translated: Just as the man, after grasping the tree, not seeing anything worth having in it, lets go of the branches he has grasped and grasps other branches, so the meditator,🔽after comprehending the material form aggregate, not seeing anything worth having in it, lets go of it and comprehises the other aggregates.

original: vatāyaṃ rukkho”ti rukkhe ālayavissajjanaṃ viya yogino pañcasupi khandhesu aniccalakkhaṇādidassanavasena🔽nibbinnassa muñcitukamyatādiñāṇattayaṃ, tassā ujukāya sākhāya upari ārohanaṃ viya
analyzed: vata ayam rukkho ti rukkhe ālaya vissajjanam viya yogino pañcasu pi khandhesu anicca lakkhaṇa ādi dassana vasena  nibbinnassa tassa ujukāya sākhāya upari ārohanam viya
translated: Just as the man, thinking “This tree is fruitless,” lets go of the tree and turns away from it, so the meditator, becoming dispassionate towards the five aggregates by seeing the characteristic of impermanence, etc.,🔽knows the three kinds of knowledge beginning with the desire to be delivered.🔽Just as the man climbs up the straight trunk of the tree, so the meditator develops conformity.

original: yogino anulomaṃ, sīsaṃ nīharitvā uddhaṃ ullokanaṃ viya gotrabhuñāṇaṃ, ākāse uppatanaṃ
analyzed: yoginaḥ anulomam sīsam nīharitvā uddham ullokanam viya gotra bhuñāṇam ākāse uppatanam
translated: Just as the man, after raising his head, looks up, so knowledge of the change-of-lineage.🔽Just as the man flies up into the air, so path knowledge.

original: viya maggañāṇaṃ, aññasmiṃ phalarukkhe nilīyanaṃ viya phalañāṇaṃ.🔽791. Kaṇhasappupamā paṭisaṅkhāñāṇe vuttāva. Upamāsaṃsandane panettha sappavissajjanaṃ
analyzed: viya magga ñāṇam aññasmin phala rukkhe nilīyanam viya phala ñāṇam  kaṇha sappupamā paṭisaṅkhā ñāṇe upamā saṃsandane pana ittha sa pavissajjanam
translated: Just as the man alights in another fruit tree, so fruition knowledge.🔽The simile of the black snake is given in the Paṭisambhidā under the knowledge of contemplation of danger .

original: viya gotrabhuñāṇaṃ, muñcitvā āgatamaggaṃ olokentassa ṭhānaṃ viya maggañāṇaṃ, gantvā
analyzed: viya gotra bhuñāṇam muñcitvā āgata maggam olokentassa ṭhānam viya magga ñāṇam gantvā
translated: But in the application of the similes here, knowledge of change-of-lineage is like the man’s letting go of the snake; path knowledge is like the man’s looking back at the path he has come by after he has let go of the snake; fruition knowledge is like the man’s going on to the next tree and sitting down.

original: abhayaṭṭhāne ṭhānaṃ viya phalañāṇanti ayaṃ viseso.🔽792. Gharanti gharasāmike kira sāyaṃ bhuñjitvā sayanaṃ āruyha niddaṃ okkante gharaṃ🔽ādittaṃ, so pabujjhitvā aggiṃ disvā “bhīto sādhu vatassa sace aḍayhamāno nikkhameyya”nti
analyzed: abhaya ṭṭhāne ṭhānam viya phala ñāṇam ti ayam viseso  gharanti ghara sāmike kira sāyam bhuñjitvā sayanam āruyha niddam okkante gharaṃ  ādittam saḥ pabujjhitvā aggim disvā bhītaḥ sādhu vatassa sace a ḍayhamānaḥ nikkhameyyanti
translated: The difference is that the knowledge of fruition is like the place of safety.🔽“House”: it seems that the owner of the house had gone up to bed after eating in the evening and fallen asleep. The house🔽caught fire. He woke up and saw the fire. He was frightened. “It would be good if I could get out without being burnt.”🔽

original: olokayamāno maggaṃ disvā nikkhamitvā vegena khemaṭṭhānaṃ gantvā ṭhito. Tattha gharasāmikassa🔽bhuñjitvā sayanaṃ āruyha niddokkamanaṃ viya bālaputhujjanassa khandhapañcake “ahaṃ🔽mamā”ti gahaṇaṃ. Pabujjhitvā aggiṃ disvā bhītakālo viya sammāpaṭipadaṃ paṭipajjitvā🔽lakkhaṇaṃ disvā bhayatupaṭṭhānañāṇaṃ, nikkhamanamaggaṃ olokanaṃ viya muñcitukamyatāñāṇaṃ,🔽maggadassanaṃ viya anulomaṃ, nikkhamanaṃ viya gotrabhuñāṇaṃ, vegena gamanaṃ viya🔽maggañāṇaṃ, khemaṭṭhāne ṭhānaṃ viya phalañāṇaṃ.
analyzed: olokayamānaḥ maggam disvā nikkhamitvā vegena khemaṭṭhānam gantvā ṭhitaḥ tattha ghara sāmikassa 🔽bhuñjitvā sayanam āruyha niddokkamanam viya bāla puthujjanassa khandha pañcake aham 🔽mama ati gahaṇam pabujjhitvā aggim disvā bhīta kālaḥ viya sammā paṭipadam paṭipajjitvā 🔽lakkhaṇam disvā bhaya tu paṭṭhāna ñāṇam nikkhamana maggam olokanam viya muñcitu kamya tā ñāṇam 🔽magga dassanam viya anulomam nikkhamanam viya gotra bhuñāṇam vegena gamanam viya 🔽magga ñāṇam khema ṭṭhāne ṭhānam viya phala ñāṇam
translated: The difference is that the knowledge of fruition is like the safe place.

original: 793. Goti ekassa kira kassakassa rattibhāge niddaṃ okkantassa vajaṃ bhinditvā goṇā🔽palātā, so paccūsasamaye tattha gantvā olokento tesaṃ palātabhāvaṃ ñatvā anupadaṃ
analyzed: ekassa kira kassakassa ratti bhāge niddam okkantassa vajam bhinditvā goṇā  so paccūsa samaye tattha gantvā olokento tesam palāta bhāvam ñatvā anupadam
translated: A certain farmer, it seems, had gone to bed at night after unyoking his oxen.🔽The oxen broke their halters and ran away.

original: gantvā rañño goṇe addasa. Te “mayhaṃ goṇā”ti sallakkhetvā āharanto pabhātakāle “na
analyzed: gantvā raññaḥ goṇe addasa te mayham goṇa ati sallakkhetvā āharantaḥ pabhāta kāle na
translated: The farmer got up at dawn, went there, and saw that they had run away. He followed their tracks and saw the king’s oxen.

original: ime mayhaṃ goṇā, rañño goṇā”ti sañjānitvā “yāva maṃ ‘coro aya’nti gahetvā rājapurisā🔽na anayabyasanaṃ pāpenti, tāvadeva palāyissāmī”ti bhīto goṇe pahāya vegena palāyitvā
analyzed: ime mayham goṇāḥ raññaḥ goṇā ati sañjānitvā yāva mama coraḥ ayanti gahetvā rāja purisā  na anaya byasanam tāvat eva palāyissāmi iti bhītaḥ goṇe pahāya vegena palāyitvā
translated: He thought, “These are my oxen,” and he drove them home. At daybreak he recognized them as the king’s oxen.🔽He was frightened, thinking, “Before the king’s men seize me as a thief and lead me off to inflict punishment and torture on me, I shall run away.” He abandoned the oxen and fled quickly.

original: nibbhayaṭṭhāne aṭṭhāsi. Tattha “mayhaṃ goṇā”ti rājagoṇānaṃ gahaṇaṃ viya bālaputhujjanassa
analyzed: nibbhaya ṭṭhāne aṭṭhāsi tattha mayham goṇā ti rāja goṇānam gahaṇam viya bāla puthujjanassa
translated: He stopped when he was out of danger.

original: “ahaṃ mamā”ti khandhānaṃ gahaṇaṃ, pabhāte “rājagoṇā”ti sañjānanaṃ viya yogino tilakkhaṇavasena
analyzed: aham mama ati khandhānam gahaṇam pabhāte rājagoṇā ati sañjānanam viya yogino ti lakkhaṇa vasena
translated: Herein, the fool’s taking the aggregates as “I” and “mine” is like the man’s taking the king’s oxen as his own.🔽The meditator’s recognition of the aggregates as impermanent, painful, and non-self by means of the three characteristics is like the man’s recognition of the oxen as the king’s at daybreak.

original: khandhānaṃ “aniccā dukkhā anattā”ti sañjānanaṃ, bhītakālo viya bhayatupaṭṭhānañāṇaṃ,
analyzed: khandhānam aniccā dukkhā anattā ti sañjānanam bhīta kālaḥ viya bhaya tu paṭṭhāna ñāṇam
translated: The knowledge of appearance as terror is like the time of fear.

original: vissajjitvā gantukāmatā viya muñcitukamyatā, vissajjanaṃ viya gotrabhu, palāyanaṃ
analyzed: vissajjitvā gantu kāma tā viya muñcitu kamya tā vissajjanam viya gotra bhu palāyanam
translated: The desire to be delivered is like the desire to go after giving up. The state of change-of-lineage is like the giving up. The path is like the running away.

original: viya maggo, palāyitvā abhayadese ṭhānaṃ viya phalaṃ.
analyzed: viya maggo palāyitvā abhaya dese ṭhānam viya phalam
translated: The wish to be free is like the man’s wish to escape. The state of change-of-lineage is like the escape. The path is like the running away. The fruition is like the man’s standing in a place of safety after he has escaped.

original: 794. Yakkhīti eko kira puriso yakkhiniyā saddhiṃ saṃvāsaṃ kappesi, sā rattibhāge
analyzed: yakkhī iti ekaḥ kira purisaḥ yakkhiniyā saddhim saṃvāsam kappesi sā ratti bhāge
translated: The she-devil: a certain man, it seems, lived with a she-devil. At night

original: “sutto aya”nti mantvā āmakasusānaṃ gantvā manussamaṃsaṃ khādati. So “kuhiṃ esā gacchatī”ti🔽anubandhitvā manussamaṃsaṃ khādamānaṃ disvā tassā amanussibhāvaṃ ñatvā “yāva maṃ
analyzed: suttaḥ ayanti mantvā āmaka susānam gantvā manussa maṃsam khādati so kuhim esā gacchati iti  anubandhitvā manussa maṃsam khādamānam disvā tassāḥ amanussi bhāvam ñatvā yāva mama
translated: she would think “He is asleep” and go to a charnel ground and eat human flesh. He followed her, thinking “Where does she go?”

original: na khādati, tāva palāyissāmī”ti bhīto vegena palāyitvā khemaṭṭhāne aṭṭhāsi. Tattha🔽yakkhiniyā saddhiṃ saṃvāso viya khandhānaṃ “ahaṃ mamā”ti gahaṇaṃ, susāne manussamaṃsaṃ
analyzed: na khādati tāva palāyissāmi iti bhītaḥ vegena palāyitvā khema ṭṭhāne aṭṭhāsi tattha  yakkhiniyā saddhim saṃvāsaḥ viya khandhānam aham mama ati gahaṇam susāne manussa maṃsaṃ
translated: and saw her eating human flesh. He understood that she was a non-human being. He thought “As long as she does not eat me, I shall escape,” and in his fear he ran away quickly and stood in a place of safety.

original: khādamānaṃ disvā “yakkhinī aya”nti jānanaṃ viya khandhānaṃ tilakkhaṇaṃ disvā aniccādibhāvajānanaṃ,
analyzed: khādamānam disvā yakkhinī ayanti jānanam viya khandhānam tilakkhaṇam disvā anicca ādi bhāva jānanam
translated: Herein, the apprehending of the aggregates as “I” and “mine” is like the man’s living with the she-devil. The understanding of the aggregates’ impermanence, etc., by seeing their three characteristics is like the man’s understanding that she was a she-devil when he saw her eating human flesh in the charnel ground.

original: bhītakālo viya bhayatupaṭṭhānaṃ, palāyitukāmatā viya muñcitukamyatā, susānavijahanaṃ
analyzed: bhīta kālaḥ viya bhaya tu paṭṭhānam palāyitu kāma tā viya muñcitu kamya tā su sāna vijahanam
translated: The appearance of fear is like the time of fear; the desire to escape is like the desire to be delivered; the leaving of the charnel ground is like the abandoning of the defilements.

original: viya gotrabhu, vegena palāyanaṃ viya maggo, abhayadese ṭhānaṃ viya phalaṃ.
analyzed: viya gotrabhu vegena palāyanam viya maggaḥ abhaya dese ṭhānam viya phalam
translated: The appearance of fear is like the time of fear; the desire to escape is like the desire for deliverance; the leaving of the charnel ground is like the origin of the path; the swift running away is like the path; the standing in the place of safety is like the fruition.

original: 795. Dārakoti ekā kira puttagiddhinī itthī, sā uparipāsāde nisinnāva antaravīthiyaṃ
analyzed: ekā kira putta giddhinī itthī sā upari pāsāde nisinnā ava antara vīthiyam
translated: The child: it seems that a certain woman who was fond of her child was sitting in the upper storey of a house.

original: dārakasaddaṃ sutvā “putto nu kho me kenaci viheṭhiyatī”ti vegasā gantvā “attano putto”ti
analyzed: dāraka saddam sutvā puttaḥ nu kho me kenacid viheṭhiyati iti vegasā gantvā
translated: Hearing the sound of a child in the street below, she thought, “Someone is hurting my child,” and she ran down,

original: saññāya paraputtaṃ aggahesi. Sā “paraputto aya”nti sañjānitvā ottappamānā ito cito
analyzed: saññāya para puttam aggahesi sā para puttaḥ ayanti sañjānitvā ottappamānā itas citas
translated: thinking “It is my child” and seized another’s child. When she found out that it was another’s child, she was ashamed.

original: ca oloketvā “mā heva maṃ koci ‘dārakacorī aya’nti vadeyyā”ti dārakaṃ tattheva oropetvā🔽puna vegasā pāsādaṃ āruyha nisīdi. Tattha attano puttasaññāya paraputtassa gahaṇaṃ
analyzed: ca oloketvā mā ha iva mama koci dāraka corī ayanti vadeyyāti dārakam tattha iva oropetvā  puna vegasā pāsādaṃ āruyha nisīdi tattha attano putta saññāya para puttassa gahaṇaṃ
translated: Looking this way and that, she thought, “Let no one say, ‘That is a child-stealing witch,’ ” and she put the child down right there.🔽Then she ran back up to the house and sat down. Herein, the seizing of another’s child thinking it was one’s own child is like the seizing of the five aggregates as “I” and “mine” through not knowing the three characteristics.

original: viya “ahaṃ mamā”ti pañcakkhandhagahaṇaṃ, “paraputto aya”nti sañjānanaṃ viya tilakkhaṇavasena
analyzed: viya aham mama ati pañca kkhandha gahaṇam para puttaḥ ayanti sañjānanam viya tilakkhaṇa vasena
translated: The recognition that it was another’s child is like the recognition of the three characteristics.

original: “nāhaṃ, na mamā”ti sañjānanaṃ, ottappanaṃ viya bhayatupaṭṭhānaṃ, ito cito ca olokanaṃ
analyzed: na aham na mama ati sañjānanam ottappanam viya bhaya tupaṭṭhānam itas ca itas ca olokanam
translated: “It is not mine, it is not I, it is not my self” is like the appearance of fear.🔽The knowledge of desire for deliverance is like looking here and there.

original: viya muñcitukamyatāñāṇaṃ, tattheva dārakassa oropanaṃ viya anulomaṃ, oropetvā antaravīthiyaṃ
analyzed: viya muñcitu kamya tā ñāṇam tattha iva dārakassa oropanam viya anulomam oropetvā antara vīthiyam
translated: The conformity knowledge is like putting the child down there.🔽The change-of-lineage knowledge is like the time when, after putting him down, he stands in the middle of the road.🔽The path is like climbing the palace stairs.

original: ṭhitakālo viya gotrabhu, pāsādārūhanaṃ viya maggo, āruyha nisīdanaṃ viya phalaṃ.🔽796. Khuddaṃ pipāsaṃ sītuṇhaṃ, andhakāraṃ visena cāti imā pana cha upamā vuṭṭhānagāminiyā
analyzed: ṭhita kālaḥ viya gotrabhu pāsāda ārūhanam viya maggaḥ āruyha nisīdanam viya phalam  khuddam pipāsam sītuṇham andhakāram visena ca ati imā pana cha upamā vuṭṭhāna gāminiyā
translated: The fruition is like sitting down on the couch after climbing up.

original: vipassanāya ṭhitassa lokuttaradhammābhimukhaninnapoṇapabbhārabhāvadassanatthaṃ vuttā.🔽Yathā hi khuddāya abhibhūto sujighacchito puriso sādurasaṃ bhojanaṃ pattheti, evamevāyaṃ
analyzed: vipassanāya ṭhitassa lokuttara dhamma abhimukha ninna poṇa pabbhāra bhāva dassana attham vuttā  yathā hi khuddāya abhibhūtaḥ su jighacchitaḥ purisaḥ sādurasam bhojanam pattheti evam eva ayam
translated: “Thirst, hunger, cold, heat, darkness, and poison” are the six similes given for the purpose of showing that one who is established in insight leading to emergence is intent upon, inclined to, and bent upon the supramundane state.

original: saṃsāravaṭṭajighacchāya phuṭṭho yogāvacaro amatarasaṃ kāyagatāsatibhojanaṃ pattheti.
analyzed: saṃsāra vaṭṭa jighacchāya phuṭṭhaḥ yogāvacaraḥ amata rasam kāya gata asati bhojanam pattheti
translated: For just as a man who is overcome by hunger and is very hungry seeks delicious food, so too this meditator, who is afflicted by the hunger of the round of rebirths, seeks the delicious nutriment of mindfulness occupied with the body.

original: Yathā ca pipāsito puriso parisussamānakaṇṭhamukho anekaṅgasambhāraṃ pānakaṃ pattheti, evamevāyaṃ saṃsāravaṭṭapipāsāya phuṭṭho yogāvacaro ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikamaggapānakaṃ pattheti.
analyzed: yathā ca pipāsitaḥ purisaḥ parisussamāna kaṇṭha mukhaḥ aneka aṅga sambhāram pānakam pattheti evam eva ayam saṃsāra vaṭṭa pipāsāya phuṭṭhaḥ yogāvacaraḥ ariyam aṭṭhaṅgika magga pānakam pattheti
translated: Just as a thirsty man would long for a drink consisting of a mixture of various ingredients, so this meditator who is touched by the thirst of the round of rebirths longs for the drink of the noble path consisting of the eight factors.

original: Yathā pana sītasamphuṭṭho puriso uṇhaṃ pattheti, evamevāyaṃ saṃsāravaṭṭe taṇhāsinehasītena phuṭṭho yogāvacaro kilesasantāpakaṃ maggatejaṃ pattheti.
analyzed: yathā pana sīta samphuṭṭhaḥ purisaḥ uṇham pattheti evam eva ayam saṃsāra vaṭṭe taṇhā sineha sītena phuṭṭhaḥ yogāvacaraḥ kilesa santāpakam magga tejam pattheti
translated: Just as a man who is cold longs for heat, so this meditator who is touched by the cold of craving’s moisture in the round of rebirths longs for the heat of the fire of the path that burns up defilements.

original: Yathā ca uṇhasamphuṭṭho puriso sītaṃ pattheti, evamevāyaṃ saṃsāravaṭṭe ekādasaggisantāpasantatto yogāvacaro ekādasaggivūpasamaṃ nibbānaṃ pattheti.
analyzed: yathā ca uṇha samphuṭṭhaḥ purisaḥ sītam pattheti evam eva ayam saṃsāra vaṭṭe ekādasa aggi santāpa santattaḥ yogāvacaraḥ ekādasa aggi vūpasamam nibbānam pattheti
translated: Just as a man who is hot longs for cold, so this meditator who is heated by the eleven fires in the round of rebirths longs for the cold of Nibbāna, which is the quenching of the eleven fires.

original: Yathā pana andhakārapareto puriso ālokaṃ pattheti, evamevāyaṃ avijjandhakārena onaddhapariyonaddho yogāvacaro ñāṇālokaṃ maggabhāvanaṃ pattheti.
analyzed: yathā pana andhakāra paretaḥ purisaḥ ālokam pattheti evam eva ayam avijja andhakārena onaddha pariyonaddhaḥ yogāvacaraḥ ñāṇa ālokam magga bhāvanam pattheti
translated: Just as a man enveloped in darkness longs for light, so this meditator who is enveloped and blanketed by the darkness of ignorance longs for the light of knowledge, which is the development of the path.

original: Yathā ca visasamphuṭṭho puriso visaghātanaṃ bhesajjaṃ pattheti, evamevāyaṃ kilesavisasamphuṭṭho
analyzed: yathā ca visa samphuṭṭhaḥ purisaḥ visa ghātanam bhesajjam pattheti evam eva ayam kilesa visa samphuṭṭhaḥ
translated: And just as a man bitten by a poisonous snake seeks an antidote to the poison, so this meditator, bitten by the poisonous snake of defilements,

original: yogāvacaro kilesavisanimmathanaṃ amatosadhaṃ nibbānaṃ pattheti. Tena vuttaṃ – “tassevaṃ🔽jānato evaṃ passato tīsu bhavesu…pe… navasu sattāvāsesu cittaṃ patilīyati patikuṭati
analyzed: yogāvacaraḥ kilesa visa nimmathanam amatosadham nibbānam pattheti tena vuttam tassa evam  jānataḥ evam passataḥ tīsu navasu sattāvāsesu cittam patilīyati patikuṭati
translated: seeks Nibbāna, the deathless medicine that destroys the poison of the defilements. Hence it is said:🔽“As he understands and sees thus, his mind retreats … from the three kinds of becoming … from the nine abodes of beings, recedes, draws back, and does not go further. Equanimity or revulsion becomes settled in him. Just as a ripe palm fruit in its husk, in its shell, might fall from the tree and might not even be noticed by anyone,

original: pativattati na sampasāriyati. Upekkhā vā pāṭikulyatā vā saṇṭhāti. Seyyathāpi nāma🔽padumapalāse īsakapoṇe”ti sabbaṃ pubbe vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: pativattati na sampasāriyati upekkhā vā pāṭikulyatā vā saṇṭhāti sā iyyathā api nāma  paduma palāse īsaka poṇā iti sabbam pubbe vutta nayena iva veditabbam
translated: so too, with the subsiding of thought and examination, … his mind enters and settles in the second jhāna … in the third jhāna … in the fourth jhāna.

original: 797. Ettāvatā ca panesa patilīnacaro nāma hoti, yaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ –
analyzed: ettāvatā ca pana esa patilīna caraḥ nāma hoti yam sandhāya vuttam
translated: “At this point the meditator is called one who has entered upon the way in regard to the higher profit, that is to say, the deathless Nibbāna.

original: “Patilīnacarassa bhikkhuno,
analyzed: patilīna carassa bhikkhuno
translated: “At this point his mind has retreated, drawn back, and does not go further,

original: Bhajamānassa vivittamāsanaṃ;
analyzed: bhajamānassa vivittam āsanam
translated: and it is said of him that he has entered upon the way in regard to the higher profit, that is to say, the deathless Nibbāna.🔽“When he brings to mind thus ‘The seen is to be regarded as the seen,’ his mind enters into concentration, becomes unified, and is well composed.

original: Sāmaggiyamāhu tassa taṃ,
analyzed: sāmaggiyam āhu tassa tam
translated: “When he brings to mind thus ‘The heard is to be regarded as the heard’ …

original: Yo attānaṃ bhavane na dassaye”ti. ;
analyzed: yaḥ attānam bhavane na dassayeti
translated: “When he brings to mind thus ‘The sensed is to be regarded as the sensed’ …🔽“When he brings to mind thus ‘The cognized is to be regarded as the cognized,’ his mind enters into concentration, becomes unified, and is well composed.

original: Evamidaṃ saṅkhārupekkhāñāṇaṃ yogino patilīnacarabhāvaṃ niyametvā uttari ariyamaggassāpi
analyzed: evam idam saṅkhāra upekkhā ñāṇam yogino pati līna cara bhāvam niyametvā uttari ariya maggassa api
translated: “When his mind has entered into concentration, becomes unified, and is well composed, he regards that mental state with perfect equanimity.🔽“When he brings to mind thus ‘The seen is to be regarded as the seen,’ his mind enters into concentration, becomes unified, and is well composed.🔽“When his mind has entered into concentration, becomes unified, and is well composed, he regards that mental state with perfect equanimity.🔽“When he brings to mind thus ‘The heard is to be regarded as the heard’ …🔽“When he brings to mind thus ‘The sensed is to be regarded as the sensed’ …🔽“When he brings to mind thus ‘The

original: bojjhaṅgamaggaṅgajhānaṅgapaṭipadāvimokkhavisesaṃ niyameti. Keci hi therā bojjhaṅgamaggaṅgajhānaṅgānaṃ
analyzed: bojjhaṅga magga aṅga jhāna aṅga paṭipadā vimokkha visesam niyameti keci hi therāḥ bojjhaṅga magga aṅga jhāna aṅgānaṃ
translated: and the distinction of the enlightenment factors, path factors, jhāna factors, and the kinds of progress and emancipation.

original: visesaṃ pādakajjhānaṃ niyametīti vadanti. Keci vipassanāya ārammaṇabhūtā khandhā
analyzed: visesam pādakajjhānam niyameti iti vadanti keci vipassanāya ārammaṇa bhūtā khandhā
translated: Some elders say that the distinction of the enlightenment factors, path factors, and jhāna factors is determined by the basic jhāna.🔽Some say that it is determined by the aggregates that are the object of insight.

original: niyamentīti vadanti. Keci puggalajjhāsayo niyametīti vadanti. Tesampi vādesu ayaṃ
analyzed: niyamenti iti vadanti keci puggala jjhāsayaḥ niyameti iti vadanti tesam pi vādesu ayaṃ
translated: Some say that it is determined by the temperament of the individual.

original: pubbabhāgavuṭṭhānagāminivipassanāva niyametīti veditabbā.
analyzed: pubba bhāga vuṭṭhāna gāmini vipassanā va niyameti iti veditabbā
translated: In all these opinions, however, it should be understood that it is determined by the insight that ends in the emergence from the prior stage.

original: 798. Tatrāyaṃ anupubbikathā – vipassanāniyamena hi sukkhavipassakassa uppannamaggopi,🔽samāpattilābhino jhānaṃ pādakaṃ akatvā uppannamaggopi, paṭhamajjhānaṃ pādakaṃ katvā🔽pakiṇṇakasaṅkhāre sammasitvā uppāditamaggopi paṭhamajjhānikāva honti. Sabbesu satta
analyzed: tatra ayam anupubbi kathā vipassanā niyamena hi sukkha vipassakassa uppanna maggaḥ api  samāpatti lābhinaḥ jhānam pādakam a katvā uppanna maggaḥ api paṭhamajjhānam pādakam katvā  pakiṇṇaka saṅkhāre sammasitvā uppādita maggaḥ pi paṭhama jhānikāḥ va honti sabbesu satta
translated: Here is the explanation in order: for the bare-insight worker, the path arisen by the determination of insight,🔽and for one who has obtained jhāna, the path arisen without making jhāna its basis, and the path made to arise by discerning the diverse aspects of the formations after making the first jhāna its basis, are all of the first jhāna. In all of them there are seven enlightenment factors, eight path factors, and five jhāna factors.

original: bojjhaṅgāni aṭṭha maggaṅgāni pañca jhānaṅgāni honti. Tesaṃ hi pubbabhāgavipassanā
analyzed: bojjhaṅgāni aṭṭha maggaṅgāni pañca jhāna aṅgāni honti tesam hi pubba bhāga vipassanā
translated: For their insight in the prior stage

original: somanassasahagatāpi upekkhāsahagatāpi hutvā vuṭṭhānakāle saṅkhārupekkhābhāvaṃ patvā
analyzed: somanassa sahagatā api upekkhā sahagatā api hutvā vuṭṭhāna kāle saṅkhāra upekkhā bhāvam patvā
translated: and when emerging from it, it becomes accompanied by joy.

original: somanassasahagatā hoti. Pañcakanaye dutiyatatiyacatutthajjhānāni pādakāni katvā uppāditamaggesu
analyzed: somanassa sahagatā hoti pañcaka naye dutiya tatiya catuttha jjhānāni pādakāni katvā uppādita maggesu
translated: In the fivefold method, when the path is produced by making the second, third, and fourth jhānas the basis for insight,

original: yathākkameneva jhānaṃ caturaṅgikaṃ tivaṅgikaṃ duvaṅgikañca hoti. Sabbesu pana satta🔽maggaṅgāni honti. Catutthe cha bojjhaṅgāni. Ayaṃ viseso pādakajjhānaniyamena ceva
analyzed: yathākkamena iva jhānam caturaṅgikam tivaṅgikam duvaṅgikam ca hoti sabbesu pana satta  maggaṅgāni honti catutthe cha bojjhaṅgāni ayam visesaḥ pādaka jjhāna niyamena ca iva
translated: the jhāna has four factors, three factors, and two factors respectively. But in all of them there are seven path factors.🔽In the fourth there are six enlightenment factors. This distinction is due to the restriction of the basic jhāna and to the restriction of insight,

original: vipassanāniyamena ca hoti. Tesampi hi pubbabhāgavipassanā somanassasahagatāpi upekkhāsahagatāpi🔽hoti. Vuṭṭhānagāminī somanassasahagatāva. Pañcamajjhānaṃ pādakaṃ katvā nibbattitamagge
analyzed: vipassanā niyamena ca hoti tesam pi hi pubbabhāga vipassanā somanassa sahagatā api upekkhā sahagatā api  hoti vuṭṭhāna gāminī somanassa sahagatā ava pañcama jhānam pādakam katvā nibbattita magge
translated: for the insight in the earlier stage is accompanied by joy and by equanimity,🔽but that which leads to emergence is accompanied by joy only.🔽But in the path produced by making the fifth jhāna the basis, there are two jhāna factors, namely, equanimity and unification of mind,

original: pana upekkhācittekaggatāvasena dve jhānaṅgāni bojjhaṅgamaggaṅgāni cha satta ceva.
analyzed: pana upekkhā citta ekagga tā vasena dve jhāna aṅgāni bojjhaṅga maggaṅgāni cha satta ca iva
translated: and six path factors and seven enlightenment factors.

original: Ayampi viseso ubhayaniyamavasena hoti. Imasmiṃ hi naye pubbabhāgavipassanā somanassasahagatā🔽vā upekkhāsahagatā vā hoti. Vuṭṭhānagāminī upekkhāsahagatāva. Arūpajjhānāni pādakaṃ🔽katvā uppāditamaggepi eseva nayo. Evaṃ pādakajjhānato vuṭṭhāya yekeci saṅkhāre sammasitvā
analyzed: ayam pi visesaḥ ubhaya niyama vasena hoti imasmin hi naye pubbabhāga vipassanā somanassa sahagatā  vā upekkhā sahagatā vā hoti vuṭṭhāna gāminī upekkhā sahagatā vā arūpa jhānāni pādakam  katvā uppādita magge api esā iva nayaḥ evam pādakajjhānataḥ vuṭṭhāya saṅkhāre sammasitvā
translated: This difference is due to the restriction of both. For in this method the insight in the prior stage is accompanied by joy or by equanimity,🔽but that in the path is accompanied by equanimity. And the same applies to the path produced by making the immaterial jhānas the basis for insight.

original: nibbattitamaggassa āsannapadese vuṭṭhitasamāpatti attano sadisabhāvaṃ karoti bhūmivaṇṇo viya godhāvaṇṇassa.🔽799. Dutiyattheravāde pana yato yato samāpattito vuṭṭhāya ye ye samāpattidhamme sammasitvā
analyzed: nibbattita maggassa āsanna padese vuṭṭhita samāpatti attanaḥ sadisa bhāvam karoti bhūmi vaṇṇaḥ viya godhā vaṇṇassa  dutiya thera vāde pana yatas yatas samāpattitaḥ vuṭṭhāya ye ye samāpatti dhamme sammasitvā
translated: So when the path is produced by comprehending formations after emerging from a jhāna as the basis, the attainment that emerges in a place near to it makes itself like it, as the colour of the soil does the colour of a lizard.

original: maggo nibbattito hoti, taṃtaṃsamāpattisadisova hoti. Tatrāpi ca vipassanāniyamo vuttanayeneva veditabbo.
analyzed: maggaḥ nibbattitaḥ hoti tad tad samāpatti sadisaḥ va hoti tatra api ca vipassanā niyamaḥ vutta nayena iva veditabbaḥ
translated: But in the second method, when the path is produced by comprehending the states of the attainment from which he has emerged, then it is like that attainment. And here too the restriction of insight should be understood in the way already described.

original: 800. Tatiyattheravāde attano attano ajjhāsayānurūpena yaṃ yaṃ jhānaṃ pādakaṃ katvā
analyzed: tatiya thera vāde attanaḥ attanaḥ ajjhāsayā anurūpena yam yam jhānam pādakam katvā
translated: But in the third method, when the path is produced by making whichever jhāna is the proximate cause the basis for insight,

original: ye ye jhānadhamme sammasitvā maggo nibbattito, taṃtaṃjhānasadisova hoti. Pādakajjhānaṃ
analyzed: ye ye jhāna dhamme sammasitvā maggaḥ nibbattitaḥ taṃ taṃ jhāna sadisaḥ va hoti pādakajjhānam
translated: and the path is generated in conformity with whichever jhāna he has verified.

original: pana sammasitajjhānaṃ vā vinā ajjhāsayamatteneva taṃ na ijjhati. Svāyamattho nandakovādasuttena🔽dīpetabbo. Etthāpi ca vipassanāniyamo vuttanayeneva veditabbo. Evaṃ tāva saṅkhārupekkhā
analyzed: pana sammasita jjhānam vā vinā tam na ijjhati nandaka uvāda suttena  dīpetabbaḥ ettha api ca vipassanā niyamaḥ vutta nayena iva veditabbaḥ evam tāva saṅkhāra upekkhā
translated: But it does not succeed without the basic jhāna or the verified jhāna, only with the mere wish. This matter can be illustrated by the Nandakovāda Sutta.

original: bojjhaṅgamaggaṅgajhānaṅgāni niyametīti veditabbā.
analyzed: bojjhaṅga maggaṅga jhānaṅgāni niyameti iti veditabbā
translated: And here too the rule for insight should be understood in the way already described. This, firstly, is how equanimity about formations controls the path factors, jhāna factors, and enlightenment factors.

original: 801. Sace panāyaṃ ādito kilese vikkhambhayamānā dukkhena sappayogena sasaṅkhārena
analyzed: sace pana ayam āditas kilese vikkhambhayamānā dukkhena sa ppayogena sa saṅkhārena
translated: But if this equanimity about formations is unable to suppress the defilements at the beginning with difficulty, with effort, and with prompting,

original: vikkhambhetuṃ asakkhi, dukkhāpaṭipadā nāma hoti. Vipariyāyena sukhāpaṭipadā. Kilese🔽pana vikkhambhetvā vipassanāparivāsaṃ maggapātubhāvaṃ saṇikaṃ kurumānā dandhābhiññā
analyzed: vikkhambhetum asakkhi dukkha apaṭipadā nāma hoti vipariyāyena sukha apaṭipadā kilese  pana vikkhambhetvā vipassanā parivāsam magga pātubhāvam saṇikam kurumānā dandha abhiññā
translated: it is called the difficult way. The opposite kind is the easy way.🔽But when it suppresses the defilements and then makes the appearance of the path and the other things delay, it is called the way of slow direct-knowledge. The opposite kind is the way of quick direct-knowledge.

original: nāma hoti. Vipariyāyena khippābhiññā. Iti ayaṃ saṅkhārupekkhā āgamanīyaṭṭhāne ṭhatvā
analyzed: nāma hoti vipariyāyena khippa abhiññā iti ayam saṅkhāra upekkhā āgamanīya ṭhāne ṭhatvā
translated: So this equanimity about formations stands in the place of coming,

original: attano attano maggassa nāmaṃ deti. Tena maggo cattāri nāmāni labhati.
analyzed: attanaḥ attanaḥ maggassa nāmam deti tena maggo cattāri nāmāni labhati
translated: He gives each path its own name. So the path gets four names.

original: Sā panāyaṃ paṭipadā kassaci bhikkhuno nānā hoti, kassaci catūsupi maggesu ekāva.
analyzed: sā pana ayam paṭipadā kassaci bhikkhuno nānā hoti kassaci catūsu pi maggesu ekā ava
translated: But this practice is different for some bhikkhus and the same for others in the case of all four paths.

original: Buddhānaṃ pana cattāropi maggā sukhāpaṭipadā khippābhiññāva ahesuṃ. Tathā dhammasenāpatissa.
analyzed: buddhānam pana cattāro api maggā sukhā paṭipadā khippa abhiññā ava ahesum tathā dhammasenāpatissa
translated: But the four paths of the Buddhas and of the General of the Dhamma were the easy way with swift development,

original: Mahāmoggallānattherassa pana paṭhamamaggo sukhāpaṭipado khippābhiñño ahosi. Upari
analyzed: mahāmoggallāna therassa pana paṭhama maggo sukhā paṭipadaḥ khippa abhiñño ahosi upari
translated: and the Elder Mahā Moggallāna’s first path was the easy way with swift development,🔽but the other three were the difficult way with sluggish development.

original: tayo dukkhāpaṭipadā dandhābhiññā. Yathā ca paṭipadā, evaṃ adhipatayopi kassaci bhikkhuno
analyzed: tayaḥ dukkha apaṭipadāḥ dandha abhiññāḥ yathā ca paṭipadā evam adhipatayaḥ api kassaci bhikkhuno
translated: And just as the practice is different for some bhikkhus and the same for others,🔽so also the predominance is different for some bhikkhus and the same for others in the case of all four paths.

original: catūsu maggesu nānā honti. Kassaci catūsupi ekāva. Evaṃ saṅkhārupekkhā paṭipadāvisesaṃ
analyzed: catūsu maggesu nānā honti kassaci catūsu pi evam saṅkhāra upekkhā paṭipadā visesam
translated: So equanimity about formations determines the difference in the practice,

original: niyameti. Yathā pana vimokkhavisesaṃ niyameti, taṃ pubbe vuttameva.
analyzed: niyameti yathā pana vimokkha visesam niyameti tat pubbe vuttam eva
translated: but how it determines the difference in the liberation has already been told.

original: 802. Apica maggo nāma pañcahi kāraṇehi nāmaṃ labhati sarasena vā paccanīkena vā saguṇena
analyzed: apica maggaḥ nāma pañcahi kāraṇehi nāmam labhati sa rasena vā paccanīkena vā sa guṇena
translated: Besides, a path gets its name for five reasons: because of its own nature, because of its opposite, because of its special quality,

original: vā ārammaṇena vā āgamanena vā. Sace hi saṅkhārupekkhā aniccato saṅkhāre sammasitvā
analyzed: vā ārammaṇena vā āgamanena vā sace hi saṅkhāra upekkhā aniccataḥ saṅkhāre sammasitvā
translated: Or it is so called because of the object, or because of the arrival. For if equanimity about formations emerges after he has comprehended formations as impermanent,

original: vuṭṭhāti, animittavimokkhena vimuccati. Sace dukkhato sammasitvā vuṭṭhāti, appaṇihitavimokkhena
analyzed: vuṭṭhāti animitta vimokkhena vimuccati sace dukkhataḥ sammasitvā vuṭṭhāti appaṇihita vimokkhena
translated: he is liberated by the signless liberation. If he emerges after he has comprehended them as painful, he is liberated by the desireless liberation.

original: vimuccati. Sace anattato sammasitvā vuṭṭhāti, suññatavimokkhena vimuccati. Idaṃ sarasato nāmaṃ nāma.
analyzed: vimuccati sace anattataḥ sammasitvā vuṭṭhāti suññata vimokkhena vimuccati idam sarasataḥ nāmam nāma
translated: If he emerges after he has comprehended them as not-self, he is liberated by the void liberation. This is the name according to the individual essence.

original: Yasmā panesa aniccānupassanāya saṅkhārānaṃ ghanavinibbhogaṃ katvā niccanimittadhuvanimittasassatanimittāni🔽pajahanto āgato, tasmā animitto. Dukkhānupassanāya pana sukhasaññaṃ pahāya paṇidhiṃ
analyzed: yasmai pana esa anicca anupassanāya saṅkhārānam ghana vinibbhogam katvā nicca nimitta dhuva nimitta sassata nimittāni  pajahantaḥ āgataḥ tasmai animitto dukkha anupassanāya pana sukha saññam pahāya paṇidhim
translated: But because he has arrived by abandoning the sign of permanence, the sign of lastingness, the sign of weal, by dissolving the compactness of formations through contemplation of impermanence,🔽it is called the signless. But because he has arrived by abandoning perception of pleasure, by drying up longing and wish, through contemplation of pain,

original: patthanaṃ sukkhāpetvā āgatattā appaṇihito. Anattānupassanāya attasattapuggalasaññaṃ
analyzed: patthanam sukkhāpetvā āgata ttā appaṇihitaḥ anatta anupassanāya atta satta puggala saññam
translated: it is called desireless. And because he has arrived by abandoning perception of self, of a living being, of a person, by seeing formations as void of self,

original: pahāya saṅkhārānaṃ suññato diṭṭhattā suññatoti idaṃ paccanīkato nāmaṃ nāma.
analyzed: pahāya saṅkhārānam suññatas diṭṭha ttā suññatas ti idam paccanīkato nāmam nāma
translated: it is called void. This is the name according to the opposite.

original: Rāgādīhi panesa suññattā suññato, rūpanimittādīnaṃ rāganimittādīnaññeva vā abhāvena animitto, rāgapaṇidhiādīnaṃ abhāvato appaṇihitoti idamassa saguṇato nāmaṃ.
analyzed: rāga ādīhi pana esa suññattā suññataḥ rūpa nimitta ādīnam vā abhāvena animittaḥ rāga paṇidhi ādīnam abhāvataḥ appaṇihitaḥ ti idam assa saguṇataḥ nāmam
translated: It is void since it is void of greed, etc., or since it is void of the sign of form, etc., or of the sign of greed, etc.; it is desireless since it is devoid of desire for greed, resolve, etc. This is its name according to its special qualities.

original: Svāyaṃ suññaṃ animittaṃ appaṇihitañca nibbānaṃ ārammaṇaṃ karotītipi suññato animitto appaṇihitoti vuccati. Idamassa ārammaṇato nāmaṃ.
analyzed: svāyam suññam animittam appaṇihitam ca nibbānam ārammaṇam karoti iti pi suññataḥ animittaḥ appaṇihitaḥ ti vuccati idam assa ārammaṇato nāmam
translated: And again, it is called void, desireless, and signless because it makes void, desireless, and signless Nibbāna its object. This is its name according to its object.

original: 803. Āgamanaṃ pana duvidhaṃ vipassanāgamanaṃ maggāgamanañca. Tattha magge vipassanāgamanaṃ
analyzed: āgamanam pana duvidham vipassanā āgamanam magga āgamanam ca tattha magge vipassanā āgamanam
translated: Its arrival is twofold as arrival by insight and as arrival by the path. Herein, the arrival by insight is in the path,

original: labhati, phale maggāgamanaṃ. Anattānupassanā hi suññatā nāma, suññatavipassanāya
analyzed: labhati phale magga āgamanam anatta anupassanā hi suññatā nāma suññata vipassanāya
translated: and the arrival by the path is in the fruition. For the contemplation of not-self is called void,

original: maggo suññato, aniccānupassanā animittā nāma, animittavipassanāya maggo animitto.
analyzed: maggo suññatas anicca anupassanā animittā nāma animitta vipassanāya maggaḥ animittaḥ
translated: and the path is void since it is arrived at by void insight. The contemplation of impermanence is called signless, and the path is signless since it is arrived at by signless insight.

original: Idaṃ pana nāmaṃ na abhidhammapariyāyena labbhati, suttantapariyāyena labbhati. Tatra
analyzed: idam pana nāmam na abhidhamma pariyāyena labbhati suttanta pariyāyena labbhati tatra
translated: But this name is not found in the Abhidhamma as a term for the path, it is found in the Suttanta.

original: hi gotrabhuñāṇaṃ animittaṃ nibbānaṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā animittanāmakaṃ hutvā sayaṃ āgamanīyaṭṭhāne
analyzed: hi gotrabhuñāṇam animittam nibbānam ārammaṇam katvā animitta nāmakam hutvā sayam āgamanīya ṭhāne
translated: The knowledge of the path of stream-entry is called “signless” because it has as its object Nibbāna, which is signless, and because it is itself called “signless” since it is the path of stream-entry that is to be reached by itself.

original: ṭhatvā maggassa nāmaṃ detīti vadanti. Tena maggo animittoti vutto. Maggāgamanena
analyzed: ṭhatvā maggassa nāmam deti iti vadanti tena maggaḥ animittaḥ iti vuttaḥ magga āgamanena
translated: It is called “signless” because it is the path.🔽But it is proper to call the fruition “signless” because it is reached by the path.

original: pana phalaṃ animittanti yujjatiyeva. Dukkhānupassanā saṅkhāresu paṇidhiṃ sukkhāpetvā🔽āgatattā appaṇihitā nāma, appaṇihitavipassanāya maggo appaṇihito, appaṇihitamaggassa
analyzed: pana phalam animittan ti yujjati yā iva dukkha anupassanā saṅkhāresu paṇidhim sukkhāpetvā  āgata ttā appaṇihitā nāma appaṇihita vipassanāya maggaḥ appaṇihitaḥ appaṇihita maggassa
translated: The insight that is the contemplation of pain in formations is called “desireless” because it dries up desire for formations.🔽The path is called “desireless” because it is reached by the insight that is desireless.🔽The fruition is called “desireless” because it is reached by the desireless path.

original: phalaṃ appaṇihitaṃ. Evaṃ vipassanā attano nāmaṃ maggassa deti, maggo phalassāti idaṃ
analyzed: phalam appaṇihitam evam vipassanā attanaḥ nāmam maggassa deti maggo phalassa ati idam
translated: Thus insight gives its own name to the path, and the path gives its name to the fruition.

original: āgamanato nāmaṃ. Evamayaṃ saṅkhārupekkhā vimokkhavisesaṃ niyametīti.
analyzed: āgamanataḥ nāma evam ayam saṅkhāra upekkhā vimokkha visesam niyameti iti
translated: This is how the knowledge of equanimity about formations determines the distinction of the outlet of the jhāna.

original: Saṅkhārupekkhāñāṇaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: saṅkhāra upekkhā ñāṇam niṭṭhitam
translated: The knowledge of equanimity about formations is ended.

original: Anulomañāṇakathā
analyzed: anuloma ñāṇa kathā
translated: The explanation of conformity knowledge

original: 804. Tassa taṃ saṅkhārupekkhāñāṇaṃ āsevantassa bhāventassa bahulīkarontassa adhimokkhasaddhā
analyzed: tassa tam saṅkhāra upekkhā ñāṇam āsevantassa bhāventassa bahulīkarontassa adhimokkha saddhā
translated: As he cultivates, develops, and repeats this knowledge of equanimity about formations, his faith, which is now called “resolution,”

original: balavatarā nibbattati, vīriyaṃ supaggahitaṃ hoti, sati sūpaṭṭhitā, cittaṃ susamāhitaṃ,
analyzed: balavatarā nibbattati vīriyam su paggahitam hoti sati su upaṭṭhitā cittam su samāhitam
translated: and his energy is well exerted, his mindfulness well established, his mind well concentrated,

original: tikkhatarā saṅkhārupekkhā uppajjati. Tassa “dāni maggo uppajjissatī”ti saṅkhārupekkhā
analyzed: tikkhatarā saṅkhāra upekkhā uppajjati tassa dāni maggaḥ uppajjissati iti saṅkhāra upekkhā
translated: and his equanimity about formations has arisen more rapidly. He thinks, “Now the path will arise.” Equanimity about formations

original: saṅkhāre aniccāti vā dukkhāti vā anattāti vā sammasitvā bhavaṅgaṃ otarati. Bhavaṅgānantaraṃ
analyzed: saṅkhāre aniccā ati vā dukkhā ati vā anattā ati vā sammasitvā bhavaṅgam otarati bhavaṅga anantaram
translated: is applied to formations as impermanent or as painful or as not-self. After that he enters upon the process of reviewing.

original: saṅkhārupekkhāya katanayeneva saṅkhāre aniccāti vā dukkhāti vā anattāti vā ārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: saṅkhāra upekkhāya ka tanayena iva saṅkhāre aniccā ati vā dukkhā ati vā anattā ati vā ārammaṇam
translated: After the life-continuum, equanimity about formations is applied to formations as impermanent or as painful or as not-self in the way already described.

original: kurumānaṃ uppajjati manodvārāvajjanaṃ. Tato bhavaṅgaṃ āvaṭṭetvā uppannassa tassa🔽kiriyacittassānantaraṃ avīcikaṃ cittasantatiṃ anuppabandhamānaṃ tatheva saṅkhāre🔽ārammaṇaṃ katvā uppajjati paṭhamaṃ javanacittaṃ, yaṃ parikammanti vuccati. Tadanantaraṃ
analyzed: kurumānam uppajjati manaḥ dvāra āvajjanam tatas bhavaṅgam āvaṭṭetvā uppannassa tassa  kiriya cittassa anantaram avīcikam citta santatim an uppabandhamānam tathā iva saṅkhāre  ārammaṇam katvā uppajjati paṭhamam javana cittam yam parikamman ti vuccati tad anantaram
translated: The mind-door adverting that occurs making formations its object arises. After that,🔽without interrupting the continuity of the life-continuum, the first javana consciousness arises making formations its object in the same way. It is called the “preliminary work.” Next to that,

original: tatheva saṅkhāre ārammaṇaṃ katvā uppajjati dutiyaṃ javanacittaṃ, yaṃ upacāranti vuccati.
analyzed: tathā iva saṅkhāre ārammaṇam katvā uppajjati dutiyam javana cittam yam vuccati
translated: without interrupting the continuity of the life-continuum, the second javana consciousness arises making formations its object in the same way. It is called the “access.”

original: Tadanantarampi tatheva saṅkhāre ārammaṇaṃ katvā uppajjati tatiyaṃ javanacittaṃ, yaṃ
analyzed: tad anantaram pi tathā iva saṅkhāre ārammaṇam katvā uppajjati tatiyam javana cittam yam
translated: The second impulsion consciousness arises next in the same way with formations as its object.

original: anulomanti vuccati. Idaṃ nesaṃ pāṭiyekkaṃ nāmaṃ.🔽Avisesena pana tividhampetaṃ āsevanantipi parikammantipi upacārantipi anulomantipi
analyzed: anulomanti vuccati idam nesam pāṭiyekkam nāmaṃ  avisesena pana tividham etam āsevanantipi parikammantipi upacārantipi anulomantipi
translated: This is called the conformity knowledge. This is their individual name.🔽But in general all three are called “development,” “readiness,” “access,” and “conformity.”

original: vattuṃ vaṭṭati. Kissānulomaṃ? Purimabhāgapacchimabhāgānaṃ. Tañhi purimānaṃ aṭṭhannaṃ🔽vipassanāñāṇānaṃ tathakiccatāya ca anulometi, upari ca sattatiṃsāya bodhipakkhiyadhammānaṃ.🔽Tañhi aniccalakkhaṇādivasena saṅkhāre ārabbha pavattattā, “udayabbayavantānaṃyeva🔽vata dhammānaṃ udayabbayañāṇaṃ uppādavaye addasā”ti ca, “bhaṅgavantānaṃyeva vata
analyzed: vattum vaṭṭati kissa anulomam purima bhāga pacchima bhāgānam tat hi purimānam aṭṭhannam  vipassanā ñāṇānam tathakiccatāya ca anulomā iti upari ca sattatiṃsāya bodhi pakkhiya dhammānam  tat hi anicca lakkhaṇa ādi vasena saṅkhāre ārabbha pavatta ttā  vata dhammānam udaya bbaya ñāṇam uppāda vaye addasāti ca vata
translated: Why is it conformity? Because it conforms to the prior and subsequent parts. For it conforms to the eight kinds of insight knowledge that precede it by having the same object, and it conforms to the thirty-seven states partaking of enlightenment that follow it.

original: bhaṅgānupassanaṃ bhaṅgaṃ addasā”ti ca, “sabhayaṃyeva vata bhayatupaṭṭhānassa bhayato
analyzed: bhaṅga anupassanam bhaṅgam addasāti ca sa bhayaṃya iva vata bhaya tupaṭṭhānassa bhayato
translated: For it occurs with formations as its object by means of the characteristic of impermanence, etc., and it is said: “The knowledge of arising and falling away is the seeing of arising and falling away of only those states that are subject to arising and falling away” , and “The contemplation of dissolution is the seeing of dissolution of only those states that are subject to dissolution” , and “The appearance of danger is the seeing of danger in only what is fearful” , and “The contemplation of destruction is the seeing of destruction of only what is subject to destruction” , and “The contemplation of fall is the seeing of fall of only what is subject to fall” , and “The contemplation of change is the seeing of change in only what is subject to change” , and “The contemplation of the signless is the seeing of the signless in only what is signless” , and “The contemplation of the desireless is the seeing of the desireless in only what is desireless” , and “The contemplation of the void is the seeing of the void in only what is void” , and “The contemplation of the inconstant is the seeing of the inconstant in only what is inconstant” , and “The contemplation of the non-self is the seeing of the non-self in only what is non-self” .

original: upaṭṭhita”nti ca, “sādīnaveyeva vata ādīnavānupassanaṃ ādīnavaṃ addasā”ti ca, “nibbinditabbeyeva🔽vata nibbidāñāṇaṃ nibbinna”nti ca, “muñcitabbamhiyeva vata muñcitukamyatāñāṇaṃ muñcitukāmaṃ🔽jāta”nti ca, “paṭisaṅkhātabbaṃyeva vata paṭisaṅkhāñāṇena paṭisaṅkhāta”nti ca, “upekkhitabbaṃyeva🔽vata saṅkhārupekkhāya upekkhita”nti ca atthato vadamānaṃ viya imesañca aṭṭhannaṃ
analyzed: upaṭṭhitanti ca sa ādīnavā iya iva vata ādīnava anupassanam ādīnavam addasā ati ca nibbinditabbā iya iva  vata nibbidā ñāṇam nibbinnanti ca vata muñcitu kamyatā ñāṇam muñcitu kāmam  jātanti ca paṭisaṅkhātabbam yeva vata paṭisaṅkhā ñāṇena paṭisaṅkhātanti ca upekkhitabbaṃ yeva  vata saṅkhāra upekkhāya upekkhitanti ca atthataḥ vadamānam viya imesam ca aṭṭhannam
translated: and “in what is to be seen as danger he saw only danger,” and “in what is to be felt dispassion for he felt only dispassion,” and “in what is to be freed from he felt only a desire to be freed from,” and “in what is to be contemplated he contemplated only,” and “in what is to be looked on with equanimity he looked on with equanimity only,”🔽he seems to be saying: “In what is to be seen as danger he saw only danger,” and so on.🔽
