original: uparibhāgaṃ patto taṃ muñcitvā vedhamāno paratīre patitvā saṇikaṃ patiṭṭhāti, evamevāyaṃ🔽yogāvacaropi bhavayonigatiṭṭhitinivāsānaṃ paratīrabhūte nibbāne patiṭṭhātukāmo udayabbayānupassanādinā🔽vegena dhāvitvā attabhāvarukkhasākhāya bandhitvā olambitaṃ rūparajjuṃ vā vedanādīsu🔽aññataradaṇḍaṃ vā aniccanti vā dukkhanti vā anattāti vāti anulomāvajjanena gahetvā
analyzed: upari bhāgam pattaḥ tam muñcitvā vedhamānaḥ para tīre patitvā saṇikam patiṭṭhāti evam eva ayam 🔽yogāvacaraḥ api bhava yoni gati ṭṭhiti nivāsānam para tīra bhūte nibbāne patiṭṭhātu kāmaḥ udaya bbaya anupassana ādinā 🔽vegena dhāvitvā atta bhāva rukkha sākhāya bandhitvā olambitam rūpa rajjum vā vedanā ādīsu 🔽aññatara daṇḍam vā aniccanti vā dukkhanti vā anattāti vā ati anuloma āvajjanena gahetvā
translated: Here is a simile to illustrate how the supramundane jhāna, which occurs in a single cognitive series with the conformity knowledge, has different objects, though it arises in a single impulsion. Suppose a man wanted to cross a great desert. He would have to go very fast. So he would run with all his might, and he would take a rope or a stick and fasten it to a tree on the near side and stretch it out and hold on to it. Then he would run, holding on to the rope or stick, and he would arrive at the far side of the desert. Then he would let go of the rope or stick and fall on the far side. In the same way, the meditator who wants to arrive at Nibbāna, which is the far side of the desert of becoming with its wombs and planes of existence, runs with all his might by means of the insight that discerns rise and fall, etc., and he takes the rope of materiality or the stick consisting of any of the others beginning with feeling, and he holds on to it by means of conformity knowledge with the thought, “Materiality is impermanent, painful, not-self,” or with the thought, “Feeling … … consciousness is impermanent, painful, not-self.”

original: taṃ amuñcamānova paṭhamena anulomacittena ullaṅghitvā dutiyena paratīraninnapoṇapabbhārakāyo
analyzed: tam a muñcamānaḥ iva paṭhamena anuloma cittena ullaṅghitvā dutiyena para tīra ninna poṇa pabbhāra kāyaḥ
translated: He does not let go of it but, after surmounting it with the first conformity knowledge, he directs his mind to the further shore, which is the signless void, and he does so with the second conformity knowledge as with a body that has crossed over and is leaning on the further shore.

original: viya nibbānaninnapoṇapabbhāramānaso hutvā tatiyena paratīrassa uparibhāgaṃ patto🔽viya idāni pattabbassa nibbānassa āsanno hutvā tassa cittassa nirodhena taṃ saṅkhārārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: viya nibbāna ninna poṇa pabbhāra mānasaḥ hutvā tatiyena para tīrassa upari bhāgam pattaḥ  viya idāni pattabbassa nibbānassa āsannaḥ hutvā tassa cittassa nirodhena tam saṅkhāra ārammaṇam
translated: Then, with the third conformity knowledge, he reaches the upper part of the further shore,

original: muñcitvā gotrabhucittena visaṅkhāre paratīrabhūte nibbāne patati. Ekārammaṇe pana
analyzed: muñcitvā gotrabhu cittena visaṅkhāre para tīra bhūte nibbāne patati eka ārammaṇe pana
translated: and he is near to the extinction that is to be reached. He lets go of the sign of formations as object by stopping that consciousness, and he falls on the extinction that is without formations, which is the further shore, with the change-of-lineage consciousness.

original: aladdhāsevanatāya vedhamāno so puriso viya na tāva suppatiṭṭhito hoti, tato maggañāṇena patiṭṭhātīti.
analyzed: a laddha āsevana tāya vedhamāno saḥ purisaḥ viya na tāva su patiṭṭhitaḥ hoti tatas magga ñāṇena patiṭṭhāti iti
translated: But he is not well steadied, like the man who is wounded by the arrow, because he has not yet obtained practice in the single object. Then he steadies himself with path knowledge.

original: 808. Tattha anulomaṃ saccapaṭicchādakaṃ kilesatamaṃ vinodetuṃ sakkoti, na nibbānamārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: tattha anulomam sacca paṭicchādakam kilesatamam vinodetum sakkoti na nibbānam ārammaṇam
translated: Herein, conformity knowledge is able to dispel the darkness of defilements that conceals the truths, but it is not able to make extinction the object.

original: kātuṃ. Gotrabhu nibbānameva ārammaṇaṃ kātuṃ sakkoti, na saccapaṭicchādakaṃ tamaṃ
analyzed: kātum gotrabhu nibbānam eva ārammaṇam kātum sakkoti na sacca paṭicchādakam tamaṃ
translated: Change-of-lineage is able to make extinction the object, but it is not able to dispel the darkness that conceals the truths.

original: vinodetuṃ. Tatrāyaṃ upamā – eko kira cakkhumā puriso “nakkhattayogaṃ jānissāmī”ti
analyzed: vinodetum tatra ayam upamā ekaḥ kira cakkhumā purisaḥ nakkhatta yogam jānissāmi iti
translated: He should dispel them. Here is a simile. A man with eyes, it seems,

original: rattibhāge nikkhamitvā candaṃ passituṃ uddhaṃ ullokesi, tassa valāhakehi paṭicchannattā
analyzed: ratti bhāge nikkhamitvā candam passitum uddham ullokesi tassa valāhakehi paṭicchanna ttā
translated: went out at night to see the moon. He looked up to see the moon,

original: cando na paññāyittha. Atheko vāto uṭṭhahitvā thūlathūle valāhake viddhaṃseti. Aparo
analyzed: candaḥ na paññāyittha atha ekaḥ vātaḥ uṭṭhahitvā thūla thūle valāhake aparaḥ
translated: but it was not visible because it was obscured by clouds. Then a wind arose and scattered the thick clouds. Another

original: majjhime, aparo sukhumeti. Tato so puriso vigatavalāhake nabhe candaṃ disvā nakkhattayogaṃ aññāsi.
analyzed: majjhime aparaḥ sukhuma iti tatas so purisaḥ vigata valāhake nabhe candam disvā nakkhatta yogam aññāsi
translated: scattered the medium-sized ones, and another the fine ones. Then the man saw the moon in the cloudless sky and he knew the conjunction of the stars.

original: Tattha tayo valāhakā viya saccapaṭicchādakathūlamajjhimasukhumaṃ kilesandhakāraṃ,
analyzed: tattha tayaḥ valāhakāḥ sacca paṭicchādaka thūla majjhima sukhumam kilesa andhakāram
translated: Herein, the three kinds of clouds are like the gross, medium, and fine darkness of defilements that obscures the truths.

original: tayo vātā viya tīṇi anulomacittāni, cakkhumā puriso viya gotrabhuñāṇaṃ, cando viya🔽nibbānaṃ, ekekassa vātassa yathākkamena valāhakaviddhaṃsanaṃ viya ekekassa anulomacittassa
analyzed: tayaḥ vātāḥ viya tīṇi anuloma cittāni cakkhumā purisaḥ viya gotra bhuñāṇam candaḥ viya  nibbānam ekekassa vātassa yathākkamena valāhaka viddhaṃsanam viya ekekassa anuloma cittassa
translated: The three winds are like the three kinds of conformity knowledge. The man with eyes is like change-of-lineage knowledge.

original: saccapaṭicchādakatamavinodanaṃ, vigatavalāhake nabhe tassa purisassa visuddhacandadassanaṃ
analyzed: sacca paṭicchādakatama vinodanam vigata valāhake nabhe tassa purisassa visuddha canda dassanam
translated: The moon is like Nibbāna. The scattering of the clouds by each of the winds is like the removal of the obscurations of the truths by each of the kinds of conformity knowledge. The man’s seeing of the clear moon in the cloudless sky is like the seeing of Nibbāna.

original: viya vigate saccapaṭicchādake tame gotrabhuñāṇassa visuddhanibbānadassanaṃ.
analyzed: viya vigate sacca paṭicchādake tame gotra bhuñāṇassa visuddha nibbāna dassanam
translated: and when the darkness of the deceptions has been dispelled, it sees Nibbāna, which is the purification of knowledge, as the man sees the moon.

original: Yatheva hi tayo vātā candapaṭicchādake valāhakeyeva viddhaṃsetuṃ sakkonti, na candaṃ
analyzed: yathā iva hi tayaḥ vātā canda paṭicchādake valāhakeya iva viddhaṃsetum sakkonti na candam
translated: For just as the three winds are able to dispel the cloud, which is the veil of the moon, but are not able to see the moon,

original: daṭṭhuṃ, evaṃ anulomāni saccapaṭicchādakaṃ tamaññeva vinodetuṃ sakkonti, na nibbānaṃ
analyzed: daṭṭhum evam anulomāni sacca paṭicchādakam tam aññā iva vinodetum sakkonti na nibbānam
translated: so too, the conformity knowledge is able to remove the darkness of the deceptions, but it is not able to see Nibbāna.

original: daṭṭhuṃ. Yathā so puriso candameva daṭṭhuṃ sakkoti, na valāhake viddhaṃsetuṃ, evaṃ🔽gotrabhuñāṇaṃ nibbānameva daṭṭhuṃ sakkoti, na kilesatamaṃ vinodetuṃ. Teneva cetaṃ🔽maggassa āvajjananti vuccati. Tañhi anāvajjanampi samānaṃ āvajjanaṭṭhāne ṭhatvā “evaṃ🔽nibbattāhī”ti maggassa saññaṃ datvā viya nirujjhati. Maggopi tena dinnasaññaṃ amuñcitvāva
analyzed: daṭṭhum yathā saḥ puriso candam eva daṭṭhum sakkoti na valāhake viddhaṃsetum evam  gotra bhuñāṇam nibbānam eva daṭṭhum sakkoti na kilesatamam vinodetum tena iva ca itaṃ  maggassa āvajjananti vuccati tat hi anāvajjanam pi samānam āvajjana ṭhāne ṭhatvā evam  nibbattāhi iti maggassa saññam da tvā viya nirujjhati maggaḥ api tena dinna saññam a muñcitvā ava
translated: And just as the man is able to see the moon but is not able to dispel the cloud,🔽so too, the knowledge of change-of-lineage is able to see Nibbāna but is not able to remove the darkness of defilements. That is why it is called “the adverting of the path.” For it ceases as if giving a sign to the path, thinking “It should arise thus,” though it does not actually advert.

original: avīcisantativasena taṃ ñāṇaṃ anuppabandhamāno anibbiddhapubbaṃ apadālitapubbaṃ lobhakkhandhaṃ
analyzed: avīci santati vasena tam ñāṇam an uppabandhamānaḥ a nibbiddha pubbam a padālita pubbam lobha kkhandham
translated: And the path, as if not letting go of the sign given by it, arises next to that knowledge in uninterrupted succession, as if following it, and it penetrates and bursts the mass of greed that has not been penetrated and burst before.

original: dosakkhandhaṃ mohakkhandhaṃ nibbijjhamānova padālayamānova nibbattati.
analyzed: dosa kkhandham moha kkhandham nibbijjhamānaḥ iva padālayamānaḥ iva nibbattati
translated: and the aggregates of greed, delusion, etc., are broken up and destroyed.

original: 809. Tatrāyaṃ upamā – eko kira issāso aṭṭhausabhamatte padese phalakasataṃ ṭhapāpetvā
analyzed: tatra ayam upamā ekaḥ kira issāsaḥ aṭṭhausabha matte padese phalaka satam
translated: Here is a simile. A man, it seems, had a hundred arrows shot into a space the size of a bull’s hide spread out for him.

original: vatthena mukhaṃ veṭhetvā saraṃ sannahitvā cakkayante aṭṭhāsi. Añño puriso cakkayantaṃ🔽āvijjhitvā yadā issāsassa phalakaṃ abhimukhaṃ hoti, tadā tattha daṇḍakena saññaṃ🔽deti. Issāso daṇḍakasaññaṃ amuñcitvāva saraṃ khipitvā phalakasataṃ nibbijjhati. Tattha
analyzed: vatthena mukham veṭhetvā saram sannahitvā cakkayante aṭṭhāsi añño puriso cakkayantam  āvijjhitvā yadā issāsassa phalakam abhimukham hoti tadā tattha daṇḍakena saññam  deti issāsaḥ daṇḍaka saññam a muñcitvā ava saram khipitvā phalaka satam nibbijjhati tattha
translated: He stood in a chariot and covered his face with a cloth. Another man stood in the chariot and gave him a signal with a stick🔽whenever an arrow was coming towards him. The man, without paying any attention to the signal with the stick, shot the hundred arrows and broke the bull’s hide.

original: daṇḍakasaññaṃ viya gotrabhuñāṇaṃ, issāso viya maggañāṇaṃ. Issāsassa daṇḍakasaññaṃ
analyzed: daṇḍaka saññam viya gotrabhu ñāṇam issāsaḥ viya magga ñāṇam issāsassa daṇḍaka saññam
translated: Herein, the knowledge of change-of-lineage is like the signal with the stick, and the path knowledge is like the man. Just as the man, without paying any attention to the signal with the stick, shot the hundred arrows and broke the bull’s hide,

original: amuñcitvāva phalakasatanibbijjhanaṃ viya maggañāṇassa gotrabhuñāṇena dinnasaññaṃ🔽amuñcitvāva nibbānaṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā anibbiddhapubbānaṃ apadālitapubbānaṃ lobhadosamohakkhandhānaṃ
analyzed: a muñcitvā ava phalaka sata nibbijjhanam viya magga ñāṇassa gotra bhuñāṇena dinna saññam  a muñcitvā ava nibbānam ārammaṇam katvā a nibbiddha pubbānam a padālita pubbānam lobha dosa moha kkhandhānam
translated: so too the path knowledge, without paying any attention to the signal given by the knowledge of change-of-lineage,

original: nibbijjhanapadālanaṃ.
analyzed: nibbijjhana padālanam
translated: breaks up and destroys the aggregates of greed, delusion, etc., which have not been broken up and destroyed before, by making Nibbāna its object.

original: 810. Na kevalañcesa maggo lobhakkhandhādīnaṃ nibbijjhanameva karoti, apica kho anamataggasaṃsāravaṭṭadukkhasamuddaṃ
analyzed: na kevalam ca isa maggaḥ lobha kkhandha ādīnam nibbijjhanam eva karoti api ca kho anamatagga saṃsāra vaṭṭa dukkha samuddam
translated: cools the suffering of the round of rebirths with its beginning un- known,🔽it closes all the doors to the states of loss,

original: soseti, sabbaapāyadvārāni pidahati, sattannaṃ ariyadhanānaṃ sammukhībhāvaṃ karoti,
analyzed: soseti sabba apāya dvārāni pidahati sattannam ariya dhanānam sammukhībhāvam karoti
translated: it brings the seven kinds of noble riches into being,🔽it abandons the eightfold wrong path, it allays all fear and trembling,

original: aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ micchāmaggaṃ pajahati, sabbaverabhayāni vūpasameti, sammāsambuddhassa
analyzed: aṭṭhaṅgikam micchāmaggam pajahati sabba vera bhayāni vūpasameti sammāsambuddhassa
translated: it makes him a son of the Perfectly Enlightened One,

original: orasaputtabhāvaṃ upaneti, aññesañca anekasatānaṃ ānisaṃsānaṃ paṭilābhāya saṃvattatīti
analyzed: orasa putta bhāvam upaneti aññesam ca aneka satānam ānisaṃsānam paṭilābhāya saṃvattati iti
translated: and it leads to the acquisition of many other benefits as well.

original: evaṃ anekānisaṃsadāyakena sotāpattimaggena sampayuttaṃ ñāṇaṃ sotāpattimagge ñāṇanti.
analyzed: evam aneka anisaṃsa dāyakena sotāpatti maggena sampayuttam ñāṇam sotāpatti magge ñāṇam ti
translated: So the knowledge associated with the path of stream-entry, which gives such great benefits, is “knowledge of the path of stream-entry.”

original: Paṭhamamaggañāṇaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: paṭhama magga ñāṇam niṭṭhitam
translated: Knowledge of the first path is ended

original: Sotāpannapuggalakathā
analyzed: sotāpanna puggala kathā
translated: The person who is a stream-enterer

original: 811. Imassa pana ñāṇassa anantaraṃ tasseva vipākabhūtāni dve tīṇi vā phalacittāni
analyzed: imassa pana ñāṇassa anantaram tassa iva vipāka bhūtāni dve tīṇi vā phala cittāni
translated: Next to this knowledge, two or three fruition consciousnesses arise, which are its result.

original: uppajjanti. Anantaravipākattāyeva hi lokuttarakusalānaṃ “samādhimānantarikaññamāhū”ti
analyzed: uppajjanti anantara vipāka ttāya iva hi lokuttara kusalānam samādhim ānantarika
translated: For it is said, “The supramundane profitable is called ‘concentration with immediate result’ because it has fruition immediately next to it” .

original: ca “dandhaṃ ānantarikaṃ pāpuṇāti āsavānaṃ khayāyā”ti ca ādi vuttaṃ. Keci pana ekaṃ
analyzed: ca dandham ānantarikam pāpuṇāti āsavānam khayāya iti ca ādi vuttam keci pana ekam
translated: and “he reaches the supramundane path slowly, and he reaches the destruction of the taints slowly” .

original: dve tīṇi cattāri vā phalacittānīti vadanti, taṃ na gahetabbaṃ.🔽Anulomassa hi āsevanante gotrabhuñāṇaṃ uppajjati. Tasmā sabbantimena paricchedena
analyzed: dve tīṇi cattāri vā phala cittāni iti vadanti tam na gahetabbam  anulomassa hi āsevana nte gotra bhuñāṇam uppajjati tasmā sabba antimena paricchedena
translated: But some say that there are one, two, three, or four path consciousnesses. That should not be accepted.🔽For when the conformity has been given attention as “to be comprehended,” knowledge of change-of-lineage arises. So there must be two conformity consciousnesses within the scope of that.

original: dvīhi anulomacittehi bhavitabbaṃ. Na hi ekaṃ āsevanapaccayaṃ labhati, sattacittaparamā
analyzed: dvīhi anuloma cittehi bhavitabbam na hi ekam āsevana paccayam labhati satta citta paramā
translated: For one does not get the condition of “given attention as ‘to be comprehended’” with one, and there are seven consciousnesses at the most in a single cognitive series.

original: ca ekāvajjanavīthi. Tasmā yassa dve anulomāni, tassa tatiyaṃ gotrabhu catutthaṃ maggacittaṃ
analyzed: ca ekāvajjanavīthi tasmai yassa dve anulomāni tassa tatiyam gotrabhu catuttham magga cittaṃ
translated: So if there are two conformities, the third is knowledge of change-of-lineage and the fourth is path consciousness.

original: tīṇi phalacittāni honti. Yassa tīṇi anulomāni, tassa catutthaṃ gotrabhu pañcamaṃ
analyzed: tīṇi phala cittāni honti yassa tīṇi anulomāni tassa catuttham gotra bhu pañcamam
translated: If there are three conformities, the fourth is knowledge of change-of-lineage and the fifth is path consciousness.

original: maggacittaṃ dve phalacittāni honti. Tena vuttaṃ “dve tīṇi vā phalacittāni uppajjantī”ti.
analyzed: magga cittam dve phala cittāni honti tena vuttam dve tīṇi vā phala cittāni uppajjanti iti
translated: There are two fruition consciousnesses. That is why it was said above “two or three fruition consciousnesses arise.”

original: Keci pana yassa cattāri anulomāni, tassa pañcamaṃ gotrabhu chaṭṭhaṃ maggacittaṃ ekaṃ
analyzed: keci pana yassa cattāri anulomāni tassa pañcamam gotrabhu chaṭṭham magga cittam ekam
translated: But some say that if there are four conformities, the fifth is knowledge of change-of-lineage and the sixth is path consciousness.

original: phalacittanti vadanti, taṃ pana yasmā catutthaṃ pañcamaṃ vā appeti, na tato paraṃ
analyzed: phalacittanti vadanti tam pana yasmā catuttham pañcamam vā appeti na tatas param
translated: They say that it is the fruition consciousness, but that is rejected because it is next to the life-continuum and because it is not the fourth or fifth consciousness after the path consciousness.

original: āsannabhavaṅgattāti paṭikkhittaṃ. Tasmā na sārato paccetabbaṃ.
analyzed: āsanna bhavaṅga ttā ti paṭikkhittam tasmā na sārataḥ paccetabbam
translated: So it should not be accepted as correct.

original: 812. Ettāvatā ca panesa sotāpanno nāma dutiyo ariyapuggalo hoti. Bhusaṃ pamattopi
analyzed: ettāvatā ca pana esa sotāpannaḥ nāma dutiyaḥ ariya puggalo hoti bhusam pamattaḥ api
translated: At this point he is the second noble person called “stream-enterer.”🔽Even if he is negligent, he is incapable of dying in a state of deprivation and of going to hell.

original: hutvā sattakkhattuṃ devesu ca manussesu ca sandhāvitvā saṃsaritvā dukkhassantassa🔽karaṇasamattho hoti. Phalapariyosāne panassa cittaṃ bhavaṅgaṃ otarati, tato bhavaṅgaṃ
analyzed: hutvā sattakkhattum devesu ca manussesu ca sandhāvitvā saṃsaritvā dukkhassantassa  karaṇa samatthaḥ hoti phala pariyosāne pana assa cittam bhavaṅgam otarati tatas bhavaṅgam
translated: Having transmigrated and wandered through seven existences among gods and humans, he is capable of making an end of suffering.

original: upacchinditvā maggapaccavekkhaṇatthāya uppajjati manodvārāvajjanaṃ, tasmiṃ niruddhe🔽paṭipāṭiyā satta maggapaccavekkhaṇajavanānīti. Puna bhavaṅgaṃ otaritvā teneva nayena
analyzed: upacchinditvā magga paccavekkhaṇa tthāya uppajjati manaḥ dvāra āvajjanam tasmin niruddhe  paṭipāṭiyā satta magga paccavekkhaṇa javanāni iti puna bhavaṅgam otaritvā tena iva nayena
translated: But at the end of the fruition his consciousness enters the life-continuum. Then, interrupting the life-continuum, mind-door adverting arises in order to review the path. When that has ceased,🔽there arise in succession seven impulsions reviewing the path.🔽Then his consciousness again enters the life-continuum. In the same way, adverting, etc., arise in order to review the fruition, and so on.

original: phalādīnaṃ paccavekkhaṇatthāya āvajjanādīni uppajjanti. Yesaṃ uppattiyā esa maggaṃ
analyzed: phala ādīnam paccavekkhaṇa atthāya āvajjana ādīni uppajjanti yesam uppattiyā maggam
translated: With the arising of these, he reviews the path,

original: paccavekkhati, phalaṃ paccavekkhati, pahīnakilese paccavekkhati, avasiṭṭhakilese
analyzed: paccavekkhati phalam paccavekkhati pahīna kilese paccavekkhati avasiṭṭha kilese
translated: he reviews the path, he reviews the fruition, he reviews the defilements abandoned,

original: paccavekkhati, nibbānaṃ paccavekkhati.🔽So hi “iminā vatāhaṃ maggena āgato”ti maggaṃ paccavekkhati, tato “ayaṃ me ānisaṃso
analyzed: paccavekkhati nibbānam paccavekkhati  so hi iminā vata aham maggena āgataḥ ti maggam paccavekkhati tatas ayam me ānisaṃso
translated: he reviews the defilements still remaining, he reviews Nibbāna.

original: laddho”ti phalaṃ paccavekkhati. Tato “ime nāma me kilesā pahīnā”ti pahīnakilese paccavekkhati.
analyzed: laddhaḥ ti phalam paccavekkhati tatas ime nāma me kilesāḥ pahīnā ati pahīna kilese paccavekkhati
translated: For he reviews the path, thinking, “It was by this path that I came”; next he reviews the fruition, thinking, “This is the benefit obtained by me”; next he reviews the defilements abandoned, thinking, “These are the defilements abandoned by me”;

original: Tato “ime nāma me kilesā avasiṭṭhā”ti uparimaggattayavajjhe kilese paccavekkhati.
analyzed: tatas ime nāma me kilesāḥ upari magga ttaya vajjhe kilese paccavekkhati
translated: next he reviews the defilements still remaining, thinking, “These are the defilements still remaining in me,” namely, the defilements in the three higher paths.

original: Avasāne ca “ayaṃ me dhammo ārammaṇato paṭividdho”ti amataṃ nibbānaṃ paccavekkhati.
analyzed: avasāne ca ayam me dhammaḥ ārammaṇataḥ paṭividdhaḥ ti amatam nibbānam paccavekkhati
translated: And finally he reviews the deathless Nibbāna, thinking, “This is the state of Nibbāna that I have realized by making it my object.”🔽So the noble disciple who is a stream-enterer has five things to review.

original: Iti sotāpannassa ariyasāvakassa pañca paccavekkhaṇāni honti. Yathā ca sotāpannassa,
analyzed: iti sotāpannassa ariyasāvakassa pañca paccavekkhaṇāni honti yathā ca sotāpannassa
translated: And just as in the case of the stream-enterer,

original: evaṃ sakadāgāmianāgāmīnampi. Arahato pana avasiṭṭhakilesapaccavekkhaṇaṃ nāma natthīti.
analyzed: evam sakadāgāmi anāgāmīnam pi arahataḥ pana avasiṭṭha kilesa paccavekkhaṇam nāma natthi iti
translated: so also in the case of the once-returner and the non-returner. But in the case of the Arahant there is no reviewing of defilements still remaining.

original: Evaṃ sabbānipi ekūnavīsati paccavekkhaṇāni nāma.
analyzed: evam sabbāni api ekūnavīsati paccavekkhaṇāni nāma
translated: So there are altogether nineteen things to review.

original: Ukkaṭṭhaparicchedoyeva ceso. Pahīnāvasiṭṭhakilesapaccavekkhaṇañhi sekkhānampi hoti
analyzed: ukkaṭṭha paricchedaḥ yā iva ca iso pahīna avasiṭṭha kilesa paccavekkhaṇam hi sekkhānam pi hoti
translated: For the reviewing of defilements abandoned and not abandoned is found in the trainers,

original: vā na vā. Tassa hi paccavekkhaṇassa abhāveneva mahānāmo bhagavantaṃ pucchi “kosu
analyzed: vā na vā tassa hi paccavekkhaṇassa abhāvena iva mahānāmaḥ bhagavantam pucchi kosu
translated: but not in the non-trainers. It was because he had no such reviewing that Mahānāma asked the Blessed One,

original: nāma me dhammo ajjhattaṃ appahīno, yena me ekadā lobhadhammāpi cittaṃ pariyādāya
analyzed: nāma me dhammaḥ ajjhattam appahīnaḥ yena me ekadā lobha dhammā api cittam pariyādāya
translated: “Venerable sir, what is that thing owing to which lust invades the mind and persists there,

original: tiṭṭhantī”ti sabbaṃ vitthārato veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: tiṭṭhanti iti sabbam vitthārataḥ veditabbam
translated: and owing to which the mind becomes excited and distracted?” All this should be understood in detail.

original: Dutiyamaggañāṇakathā
analyzed: dutiya magga ñāṇa kathā
translated: The second path knowledge

original: 813. Evaṃ paccavekkhitvā pana so sotāpanno ariyasāvako tasmiññeva vā āsane nisinno,
analyzed: evam paccavekkhitvā pana so sotāpannaḥ ariya sāvako tasmin ñeva vā āsane nisinno
translated: When he has reviewed thus, the stream-enterer, the noble disciple, either on that same occasion or on some subsequent occasion,

original: aparena vā samayena kāmarāgabyāpādānaṃ tanubhāvāya dutiyāya bhūmiyā pattiyā yogaṃ
analyzed: aparena vā samayena kāma rāga byāpādānam tanu bhāvāya dutiyāya bhūmiyā pattiyā yogam
translated: by making the second kind of aspiration, which is for the purpose of attaining the second plane, for the purpose of weakening lust, hate and delusion,

original: karoti. So indriyabalabojjhaṅgāni samodhānetvā tadeva rūpavedanāsaññāsaṅkhāraviññāṇabhedaṃ
analyzed: karoti saḥ indriya bala bojjhaṅgāni samodhānetvā tat eva rūpa vedanā saññā saṅkhāra viññāṇa bhedam
translated: he crushes that same type of formations classed as materiality, feeling, perception, mental formations and consciousness,

original: saṅkhāragataṃ aniccaṃ dukkhamanattāti ñāṇena parimaddati, parivatteti, vipassanāvīthiṃ
analyzed: saṅkhāra gatam aniccam dukkham anattā ati ñāṇena parimaddati parivatteti vipassanā vīthiṃ
translated: with the knowledge that they are impermanent, painful, not-self; he turns it over and over,

original: ogāhati. Tassevaṃ paṭipannassa vuttanayeneva saṅkhārupekkhāvasāne ekāvajjanena anulomagotrabhuñāṇesu
analyzed: ogāhati tassa ivam paṭipannassa vutta nayena iva saṅkhāra upekkhā avasāne eka āvajjanena anuloma gotra bhuñāṇesu
translated: and enters upon it. When he has thus entered upon it, the path knowledge and fruition knowledge arise in him in the way already described.

original: uppannesu gotrabhuanantaraṃ sakadāgāmimaggo uppajjati. Tena sampayuttaṃ ñāṇaṃ sakadāgāmimagge ñāṇanti.
analyzed: uppannesu gotra bhu anantaram sakadāgāmi maggaḥ uppajjati tena sampayuttam ñāṇam sakadāgāmi magge ñāṇam ti
translated: And next to the change-of-lineage knowledge the path of once-return arises. The knowledge associated with that is “knowledge of the path of once-return.”

original: Dutiyañāṇaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: dutiya ñāṇam niṭṭhitam
translated: The second kind of knowledge is ended.

original: Tatiyamaggañāṇakathā
analyzed: tatiya magga ñāṇa kathā
translated: Knowledge of the third path

original: 814. Imassāpi ñāṇassa anantaraṃ vuttanayeneva phalacittāni veditabbāni. Ettāvatā
analyzed: imassa api ñāṇassa anantaram vutta nayena iva phala cittāni veditabbāni ettāvatā
translated: . The fruition consciousnesses should be understood in the way already described immediately following upon this knowledge.

original: cesa sakadāgāmī nāma catuttho ariyapuggalo hoti sakiṃdeva imaṃ lokaṃ āgantvā dukkhassantakaraṇasamattho.
analyzed: sakadāgāmī nāma catutthaḥ ariya puggalo hoti sakiṃdevaḥ imaṃ lokaṃ āgantvā
translated: At this point he is called a “once-returner” and is the fourth noble person. He is able to put an end to suffering after returning once to this world.

original: Tato paraṃ paccavekkhaṇaṃ vuttanayameva.🔽Evaṃ paccavekkhitvā ca so sakadāgāmī ariyasāvako tasmiññeva vā āsane nisinno aparena
analyzed: tatas param paccavekkhaṇam vutta nayam eva  evam paccavekkhitvā ca so sakadāgāmī ariya sāvako tasmin ñā eva vā āsane nisinnaḥ aparena
translated: The reviewing of the path, fruition, etc., is in the way already described.

original: vā samayena kāmarāgabyāpādānaṃ anavasesappahānāya tatiyāya bhūmiyā pattiyā yogaṃ
analyzed: vā samayena kāma rāga byāpādānam anavasesa pahānāya tatiyāya bhūmiyā pattiyā yogam
translated: And when he has reviewed in this way, that noble disciple who is a once-returner either on that same seat or on another occasion attains to the third path, the non-return path, for the purpose of realizing the fruit of non-return by abandoning the defilements that remain, that is to say,🔽the five kinds of lower fetter.

original: karoti, so indriyabalabojjhaṅgāni samodhānetvā tadeva saṅkhāragataṃ aniccaṃ dukkhamanattāti
analyzed: karoti saḥ indriya bala bojjhaṅgāni samodhānetvā tat eva saṅkhāra gatam aniccam dukkham anattā ati
translated: He brings the faculties, powers, and enlightenment factors into focus, and he pounds and turns over and over that same field of formations with the knowledge that they are impermanent, painful, and not-self.

original: ñāṇena parimaddati, parivatteti, vipassanāvīthiṃ ogāhati. Tassevaṃ paṭipannassa vuttanayeneva
analyzed: ñāṇena parimaddati parivatteti vipassanā vīthim ogāhati tassa ivam paṭipannassa vutta nayena iva
translated: He enters upon the course of insight. As he continues to develop this meditation subject in this way,

original: saṅkhārupekkhāvasāne ekāvajjanena anulomagotrabhuñāṇesu uppannesu gotrabhuanantaraṃ
analyzed: saṅkhāra upekkhā avasāne eka āvajjanena anuloma gotra bhuñāṇesu uppannesu gotra bhu anantaram
translated: at the end of equanimity about formations, after the four kinds of refinement, the path arises in him at the end of the conformity knowledge.

original: anāgāmimaggo uppajjati, tena sampayuttaṃ ñāṇaṃ anāgāmimagge ñāṇanti.
analyzed: anāgāmi maggaḥ uppajjati tena sampayuttam ñāṇam anāgāmi magge ñāṇam ti
translated: The knowledge associated with that path is “knowledge of the path of non-return.”

original: Tatiyañāṇaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: tatiya ñāṇam niṭṭhitam
translated: Knowledge of the third path is ended.

original: Catutthamaggañāṇakathā
analyzed: catuttha magga ñāṇa kathā
translated: Knowledge of the fourth path

original: 815. Imassapi ñāṇassa anantaraṃ vuttanayeneva phalacittāni veditabbāni. Ettāvatā🔽cesa anāgāmī nāma chaṭṭho ariyapuggalo hoti opapātiko tatthaparinibbāyī anāvattidhammo
analyzed: imassa api ñāṇassa anantaram vutta nayena iva phala cittāni veditabbāni ettāvatā  anāgāmī nāma chaṭṭhaḥ ariya puggalo hoti opapātikaḥ tattha parinibbāyī an āvatti dhammo
translated: . The fruition consciousnesses should be understood in the way already described immediately after this knowledge.

original: paṭisandhivasena imaṃ lokaṃ puna anāgantā. Tato paraṃ paccavekkhaṇaṃ vuttanayameva.
analyzed: paṭisandhi vasena imam lokam puna anāgantā tatas param paccavekkhaṇam vutta nayam eva
translated: At this point he is a non-returner, the sixth noble person, one who is bound for the pure abodes, one due to appear only in the Brahma-world, one who will not be reborn in this world again. After that, the survey is as already described.

original: Evaṃ paccavekkhitvā ca so anāgāmī ariyasāvako tasmiññeva vā āsane nisinno, aparena🔽vā samayena rūpārūparāgamānauddhaccaavijjānaṃ anavasesappahānāya catutthāya bhūmiyā🔽pattiyā yogaṃ karoti, so indriyabalabojjhaṅgāni samodhānetvā tadeva saṅkhāragataṃ
analyzed: evam paccavekkhitvā ca so anāgāmī ariya sāvako tasmin ñā eva vā āsane nisinnaḥ aparena  vā samayena rūpa arūpa rāga māna auddhacca avijjānam anavasesa ppahānāya catutthāya bhūmiyā  pattiyā yogam karoti saḥ indriya bala bojjhaṅgāni samodhānetvā tat eva saṅkhāra gatam
translated: And after reviewing thus, that noble disciple either while sitting in that same seat or else on another occasion🔽makes it his task to attain the fourth plane, which is the abandoning without remainder of lust, hate, and delusion.

original: aniccaṃ dukkhamanattāti ñāṇena parimaddati, parivatteti, vipassanāvīthiṃ ogāhati.🔽Tassevaṃ paṭipannassa vuttanayeneva saṅkhārupekkhāvasāne ekāvajjanena anulomagotrabhuñāṇesu
analyzed: aniccam dukkham anattā ti ñāṇena parimaddati parivattā iti vipassanā vīthim ogāhati  tassa ivam paṭipannassa vutta nayena iva saṅkhāra upekkhā avasāne eka āvajjanena anuloma gotra bhuñāṇesu
translated: He combines the faculties, powers, and enlightenment factors, and he resolves that same field of formations into impermanence, suffering, and non-self by means of the knowledge of fall, and he plunges into the stream of insight.🔽When he has thus entered upon the way, the conformity knowledge and the path knowledge arise in him in one moment with just one revolution of the cognitive series,

original: uppannesu gotrabhuanantaraṃ arahattamaggo uppajjati, tena sampayuttaṃ ñāṇaṃ arahattamagge ñāṇanti.
analyzed: uppannesu gotra bhu anantaram arahatta maggaḥ uppajjati tena sampayuttam ñāṇam arahatta magge
translated: as was the case with the path of non-return. The knowledge associated with the path of Arahantship is the knowledge of the path of Arahantship.

original: Catutthañāṇaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: catuttha ñāṇam niṭṭhitam
translated: The fourth kind of knowledge is ended.

original: Arahantapuggalakathā
analyzed: arahanta puggala kathā
translated: The explanation of the person who is an Arahant

original: 816. Imassapi ñāṇassa anantaraṃ vuttanayeneva phalacittāni veditabbāni. Ettāvatā
analyzed: imassa api ñāṇassa anantaram vutta nayena iva phala cittāni veditabbāni ettāvatā
translated: . The fruition consciousnesses should be understood to follow upon this knowledge in the way already described.

original: cesa arahā nāma aṭṭhamo ariyapuggalo hoti mahākhīṇāsavo antimadehadhārī ohitabhāro
analyzed: arahā nāma aṭṭhamaḥ ariya puggalo hoti mahā khīṇāsavaḥ antima deha dhārī ohita bhāro
translated: He is called a “worthy one,” the eighth person of the noble group, a great one with cankers destroyed, a bearer of his last body, one who has laid down the burden,

original: anuppattasadattho parikkhīṇabhavasaṃyojano sammādaññā vimutto sadevakassa lokassa aggadakkhiṇeyyoti.
analyzed: an uppatta sat atthaḥ parikkhīṇa bhava saṃyojano sammā daññā vimutto sa devakassa lokassa agga dakkhiṇeyyaḥ ti
translated: attained his goal, destroyed the fetter of becoming, and is released through right knowledge, one worthy to receive gifts from both gods and men.

original: Iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ “sotāpattimaggo sakadāgāmimaggo anāgāmimaggo arahattamaggoti imesu
analyzed: iti yam tam vuttam sotāpatti maggo sakadāgāmi maggaḥ anāgāmi maggaḥ arahatta maggo iti imesu
translated: So it was said: “The path of stream-entry, the path of once-return, the path of non-return, the path of arahatship—

original: pana catūsu maggesu ñāṇaṃ ñāṇadassanavisuddhi nāmā”ti, taṃ imāni iminā anukkamena
analyzed: pana catūsu maggesu ñāṇam ñāṇa dassana visuddhi nāma ati tam imāni iminā anukkamena
translated: the knowledge in these four paths is called purification by knowledge and vision” .

original: pattabbāni cattāri ñāṇāni sandhāya vuttaṃ.
analyzed: pattabbāni cattāri ñāṇāni sandhāya vuttam
translated: This was said with reference to the four kinds of knowledge to be attained in the following order.

original: Bodhipakkhiyakathā
analyzed: bodhipakkhiya kathā
translated: The exposition of the factors of enlightenment.

original: 817. Idāni imissāyeva catuñāṇāya ñāṇadassanavisuddhiyā ānubhāvavijānanatthaṃ –
analyzed: idāni imissāya eva catu ñāṇāya ñāṇa dassana visuddhiyā ānubhāva vijānana attham
translated: Now, in order to show the power of this purification by knowledge and vision consisting of the four kinds of knowledge, it was said:

original: Paripuṇṇabodhipakkhiya, bhāvo vuṭṭhānabalasamāyogo;
analyzed: bhāvaḥ vuṭṭhāna bala samāyogaḥ
translated: The factors of enlightenment complete, the state of footing, the power of emergence,

original: Ye yena pahātabbā, dhammā tesaṃ pahānañca.
analyzed: ye yena pahātabbāḥ dhammāḥ tesam pahānañca
translated: The states to be abandoned by each, and their abandoning,

original: Kiccāni pariññādīni, yāni vuttāni abhisamayakāle;
analyzed: kiccāni pariññā ādīni yāni vuttāni abhisamaya kāle
translated: The functions of full understanding, etc., stated at the time of penetration,

original: Tāni ca yathāsabhāvena, jānitabbāni sabbānīti.
analyzed: tāni ca yathā sabhāvena jānitabbāni sabbāni iti
translated: And all of them should be known according to their individual characteristics.

original: 818. Tattha paripuṇṇabodhipakkhiya, bhāvoti bodhipakkhiyānaṃ paripuṇṇabhāvo. Cattāro🔽satipaṭṭhānā, cattāro sammappadhānā, cattāro iddhipādā, pañcindriyāni, pañca balāni,🔽satta bojjhaṅgā, ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggoti hi ime sattatiṃsa dhammā bujjhanaṭṭhena
analyzed: tattha bhāvo ti bodhi pakkhiyānam paripuṇṇa bhāvo cattāro  sati paṭṭhānā cattāro sammappadhānā cattāro iddhipādā pañca indriyāni pañca balāni  satta bojjhaṅgāḥ ariyaḥ aṭṭhaṅgikaḥ maggo ti hi ime sattatiṃsa dhammā bujjhan aṭṭhena
translated: Herein, the state of being fulfilled in the enlightenment factors is the fulfilled state of the enlightenment factors.🔽The thirty-seven states are called enlightenment factors because they exist in the side of the noble path that has been given the name “enlightenment” in the sense of enlightening.

original: bodhoti laddhanāmassa ariyamaggassa pakkhe bhavattā bodhipakkhiyā nāma. Pakkhe bhavattāti🔽upakārabhāve ṭhitattā.
analyzed: bodho ti laddha nāmassa ariya maggassa pakkhe bhavattā bodhi pakkhiyā nāma pakkhe bhavattā ati  upakāra bhāve ṭhita t tā
translated: They exist in the side of it: they exist in the state of being its helpers.🔽They are foundations of mindfulness because they occur by repeatedly approaching and attending to their respective objects.

original: 819. Tesu tesu ārammaṇesu okkhanditvā pakkhanditvā upaṭṭhānato paṭṭhānaṃ. Satiyeva🔽paṭṭhānaṃ satipaṭṭhānaṃ. Kāyavedanācittadhammesu panassā asubha-dukkha-anicca-anattākāragahaṇavasena
analyzed: tesu tesu ārammaṇesu okkhanditvā pakkhanditvā upaṭṭhānataḥ paṭṭhānam satiyā iva  paṭṭhānam sati paṭṭhānam kāya vedanā citta dhammesu pana assā asubha dukkha anicca anatta ākāra gahaṇa vasena
translated: Mindfulness itself is the foundation: the meaning is that they are foundations of mindfulness in the sense of states that cause mindfulness to be established.

original: subha-sukha-nicca-atta-saññāpahānakiccasādhanavasena ca pavattito catudhā bhedo hoti.
analyzed: ca pavattito catudhā bhedaḥ hoti
translated: But they are classified into four kinds according to their function in abandoning perception of beauty, pleasure, permanence, and self, and in accomplishing the function of realizing the signless, desireless, and void, respectively, in regard to the body, feelings, cognizance, and mental objects.

original: Tasmā cattāro satipaṭṭhānāti vuccanti.
analyzed: tasmā cattāro sati paṭṭhānā ti vuccanti
translated: So they are called the four foundations of mindfulness.

original: 820. Padahanti etenāti padhānaṃ. Sobhanaṃ padhānaṃ sammappadhānaṃ. Sammā vā padahanti🔽etenāti sammappadhānaṃ. Sobhanaṃ vā taṃ kilesavirūpattavirahato padhānañca hitasukhanipphādakattena
analyzed: padahanti etena ati padhānam sobhanam padhānam sammappadhānam sammā vā padahanti  etena ati sammappadhānam sobhanam vā tam padhānam ca hita sukha nipphādaka ttena
translated: “Striving” is padhāna . Right striving is sammappadhāna . Or it is sammappadhāna in the sense of “they strive rightly” with it .🔽Or it is sammappadhāna in the sense of “it is a good striving” because it is free from the disfigurement of defilements and because it produces welfare and pleasure.

original: seṭṭhabhāvāvahanato padhānabhāvakāraṇato cāti sammappadhānaṃ. Vīriyassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ.🔽Tayidaṃ uppannānuppannānaṃ akusalānaṃ pahānānuppattikiccaṃ anuppannuppannānañca kusalānaṃ
analyzed: seṭṭha bhāva āvahanato padhāna bhāva kāraṇato ca ati sammappadhānam vīriyassa etam adhivacanaṃ  tayā idam uppanna anuppannānam akusalānam pahāna anuppatti kiccam anuppanna uppannānam ca kusalānam
translated: “Striving” is padhāna . Right striving is sammāpadhāna . Or alternatively, they rightly strive with this, thus it is right striving . Or it is beautiful striving , and it is striving because it is the means to the state of being a noble one , since it is the cause of the state of being a noble one by being the cause of the state of being a noble one through the beauty of the absence of the ugliness of defilement. It is a term for energy.

original: uppattiṭṭhitikiccaṃ sādhayatīti catubbidhaṃ hoti, tasmā cattāro sammappadhānāti vuccanti.🔽821. Pubbe vuttena ijjhanaṭṭhena iddhi. Tassā sampayuttāya pubbaṅgamaṭṭhena phalabhūtāya
analyzed: uppatti ṭṭhiti kiccam sādhayati iti catubbidham hoti tasmā cattāro sammappadhānā ti vuccanti  pubbe vuttena ijjhan aṭṭhena tassā sampayuttāya pubbaṅgama ṭṭhena phala bhūtāya
translated: This is fourfold as the function of abandoning arisen and of preventing the arising of unarisen unprofitable things, and as the function of causing the arising of unarisen and of maintaining the continuity of arisen profitable things. So it is called the four right strivings.

original: pubbabhāgakāraṇaṭṭhena ca iddhiyā pādoti iddhipādo. So chandādivasena catubbidho
analyzed: pubbabhāga kāraṇa ṭṭhena ca iddhiyā pādo ti iddhipādaḥ so chanda ādi vasena catubbidhaḥ
translated: “Success” is iddhi in the sense of succeeding, as already stated. The basis of that is iddhipāda in the sense of being the forerunner of what is associated with it, in the sense of being its fruit, and in the sense of being the cause of its prior part. It is fourfold as will, etc.,

original: hoti, tasmā cattāro iddhipādāti vuccanti. Yathāha – “cattāro iddhipādā chandiddhipādo🔽cittiddhipādo vīriyiddhipādo vīmaṃsiddhipādo”ti. Ime lokuttarāva. Lokiyā pana “chandañce🔽bhikkhu adhipatiṃ karitvā labhati samādhiṃ, labhati cittassa ekaggataṃ. Ayaṃ vuccati🔽chandasamādhī”tiādivacanato chandādiadhipativasena paṭiladdhadhammāpi honti.
analyzed: hoti tasmā cattāro iddhipādā ti vuccanti yathā āha cattāro iddhipādā chandī ddhipādaḥ  citta iddhipādaḥ vīriya iddhipādaḥ vīmaṃsiddhipādaḥ iti ime lokuttarā ava lokiyā pana  bhikkhu adhipatim karitvā labhati samādhim labhati cittassa ekagga tam ayam vuccati  chanda samādhi iti ādi vacanataḥ chanda ādi adhipati vasena paṭiladdha dhammā api honti
translated: They are called “bases of success” because they are the bases for the success of the kinds of direct knowledge, etc., that are successful by the success of the kinds of direct knowledge, etc., that are successful by the success of the four roads to power. As it is said: “The four bases of success are the base for success consisting in desire, the base for success consisting in persistence, the base for success consisting in consciousness, the base for success consisting in inquiry” . These are only supramundane. But those that are acquired by the predominance of desire, etc., are also mundane states, according to the text: “If a bhikkhu, by making desire the predominant factor, obtains concentration of mind and gains knowledge and vision , this is called concentration due to desire” .🔽🔽

original: 822. Assaddhiyakosajjapamādavikkhepasammohānaṃ abhibhavanato abhibhavanasaṅkhātena
analyzed: assaddhiya kosajja pamāda vikkhepa sammohānam abhibhavanataḥ abhibhavana saṅkhātena
translated: They are called “bases of success” because they are the bases for the success of the kinds of direct knowledge consisting in the various kinds of psychic power, etc., and because they are the bases for the success of the kinds of direct knowledge consisting in the realization of the supramundane states. As it is said: “The four bases of success are the base for success consisting in psychic power, the base for success consisting in the knowledge of the divine ear, the base for success consisting in the knowledge of penetration of minds, the base for success consisting in the knowledge of recollection of past lives, the base for success consisting in the knowledge of the passing away and reappearance of beings, the base for success consisting in the knowledge of the destruction of the taints” . These are only supramundane. But in the case of the mundane kinds, the states that are obtained by the predominance of zeal, etc., are also called “bases of success” in the sense of being the bases for the success of the kinds of direct knowledge consisting in the realization of the jhānas, etc., according to the text: “If a bhikkhu obtains concentration, obtains unification of mind by making zeal predominant, this is called concentration due to zeal” , and so on.

original: adhipatiyaṭṭhena indriyaṃ. Assaddhiyādīhi ca anabhibhavanīyato akampiyaṭṭhena balaṃ.
analyzed: adhipatiya ṭṭhena indriyam ca an abhibhavanīyataḥ akampiya ṭṭhena balam
translated: They are faculties in the sense of predominance through the predominance of overcoming, since they overcome non-faith, idleness, negligence, distraction, and confusion. They are powers in the sense of non-submergence, since they are unmoved by their opposites, non-faith, and so on.

original: Tadubhayampi saddhādivasena pañcavidhaṃ hoti, tasmā pañcindriyāni pañca balānīti vuccanti.
analyzed: tat ubhayam pi saddhā ādi vasena pañcavidham tasmā pañca indriyāni pañca balāni iti vuccanti
translated: And both of them are of five kinds as faith, etc., thus they are called the five faculties and the five powers.

original: 823. Bujjhanakasattassa pana aṅgabhāvena satiādayo satta bojjhaṅgā. Niyyānikaṭṭhena
analyzed: bujjhanaka sattassa pana aṅga bhāvena sati ādayo satta bojjhaṅgāḥ niyyānika ṭṭhena
translated: The seven enlightenment factors are enlightenment factors in the sense of a factor of a discoverer of what was not discovered before, that is to say, of a buddha.

original: ca sammādiṭṭhiādayo aṭṭha maggaṅgā honti. Tena vuttaṃ “satta bojjhaṅgā ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo”ti.
analyzed: ca sammādiṭṭhi ādayaḥ aṭṭha maggaṅgāḥ honti tena vuttam satta bojjhaṅgāḥ ariyaḥ aṭṭhaṅgikaḥ maggo ti
translated: and the eight path factors beginning with right view. Hence it was said above: “The seven enlightenment factors are the Noble Eightfold Path.”

original: 824. Iti ime sattatiṃsa bodhipakkhiyadhammā pubbabhāge lokiyavipassanāya vattamānāya
analyzed: iti ime sattatiṃsa bodhi pakkhiya dhammā pubbabhāge lokiya vipassanāya vattamānāya
translated: So these thirty-seven states partaking of enlightenment are the thirty-seven aids to enlightenment.🔽When insight is occurring in the earlier stage with the world as its object,

original: cuddasavidhena kāyaṃ pariggaṇhato ca kāyānupassanāsatipaṭṭhānaṃ, navavidhena vedanaṃ🔽pariggaṇhato ca vedanānupassanāsatipaṭṭhānaṃ, soḷasavidhena cittaṃ pariggaṇhato ca
analyzed: cuddasavidhena kāyam pariggaṇhato ca kāya anupassanā sati paṭṭhānam navavidhena vedanam  pariggaṇhato ca vedanā anupassanā sati paṭṭhānam soḷasavidhena cittam pariggaṇhato ca
translated: and when he discerns feeling in nine ways,🔽and when he discerns the mind in sixteen ways,

original: cittānupassanāsatipaṭṭhānaṃ, pañcavidhena dhamme pariggaṇhato ca dhammānupassanāsatipaṭṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: citta anupassanā sati paṭṭhānam pañcavidhena dhamme pariggaṇhato ca dhamma anupassanā sati paṭṭhānam
translated: and when he discerns mental data in five ways,

original: Imasmiṃ attabhāve anuppannapubbaṃ parassa uppannaṃ akusalaṃ disvā “yathā paṭipannassetaṃ
analyzed: imasmin attabhāve an uppanna pubbam parassa uppannam akusalam disvā yathā paṭipannassa etam
translated: and when he sees unprofitable things arisen in another’s mental continuity that have not arisen in his own, and he makes an effort for their non-arising in this way:

original: uppannaṃ, na tathā paṭipajjissāmi evaṃ me etaṃ nuppajjissatī”ti, tassa anuppādāya
analyzed: uppannam na tathā paṭipajjissāmi evam me etam na uppajjissati iti tassa an uppādāya
translated: “I shall conduct myself and maintain the practice in such a way that those unprofitable things that have arisen in another’s mental continuity will not arise in my mental continuity,”

original: vāyamanakāle paṭhamaṃ sammappadhānaṃ. Attano samudācārappattaṃ akusalaṃ disvā tassa
analyzed: vāyamana kāle paṭhamam sammappadhānam attano samudācāra ppattam akusalam disvā tassa
translated: then at the time of making the effort this is the first right endeavour.

original: pahānāya vāyamanakāle dutiyaṃ. Imasmiṃ attabhāve anuppannapubbaṃ jhānaṃ vā vipassanaṃ🔽vā uppādetuṃ vāyamantassa tatiyaṃ. Uppannaṃ yathā na parihāyati, evaṃ punappunaṃ🔽uppādentassa catutthaṃ sammappadhānaṃ. Chandaṃ dhuraṃ katvā kusaluppādanakāle chandiddhipādo.🔽Micchāvācāya viramaṇakāle sammāvācāti evaṃ nānācittesu labbhanti. Imesaṃ pana catunnaṃ
analyzed: pahānāya vā āyamana kāle dutiyam imasmin atta bhāve an uppanna pubbam jhānam vā vipassanam  vā uppādetum vāyamantassa tatiyam uppannam yathā na parihāyati evam punappunam  uppādentassa catuttham sammappadhānam chandam dhuram katvā kusala uppādana kāle chandiddhipādo  micchāvācāya viramaṇa kāle sammāvācā ati evam nānā cittesu labbhanti imesam pana catunnam
translated: At the time of striving for the abandoning of the hindrances, the second right endeavour. At the time of striving to arouse jhāna or insight that has not arisen, or to develop further that which has arisen, the third right endeavour. At the time of striving to arouse again and again that which has arisen so that it does not lapse, the fourth right endeavour. At the time of arousing profitable states by making desire the van, the basis of success consisting of desire. At the time of refraining from wrong speech, right speech. So they are found in the various kinds of consciousness.

original: ñāṇānaṃ uppattikāle ekacitte labbhanti. Phalakkhaṇe ṭhapetvā cattāro sammappadhāne🔽avasesā tettiṃsa labbhanti.🔽825. Evaṃ ekacitte labbhamānesu cetesu ekāva nibbānārammaṇā sati kāyādīsu subhasaññādippahānakiccasādhanavasena
analyzed: ñāṇānaṃ uppatti kāle eka citte labbhanti phala kkhaṇe ṭhapetvā cattāro sammappadhāne  avasesā tettiṃsa labbhanti  evam eka citte labbhamānesu cetesu ekā ava nibbāna ārammaṇā sati kāya ādīsu subha saññā ādi pahāna kicca sādhana vasena
translated: The second when he is making an effort to abandon them. The third when he is making an effort to arouse jhāna or insight that has not already arisen in that existence. The fourth when he is arousing it again and again in order that what has arisen may continue. The four bases for success are the footing for will in the sense of predominance, in the case of one who is making an effort to arouse profitable states. Right speech is the footing for energy in the sense of predominance, in the case of one who is refraining from wrong speech. So they are found in various consciousnesses. But they are found in a single consciousness at the moment of the arising of these four kinds of knowledge. At the moment of the fruition attainment, the four right efforts are found, and the remaining thirty-three are found.

original: cattāro satipaṭṭhānāti vuccati. Ekameva ca vīriyaṃ anuppannānaṃ anuppādādikiccasādhanavasena
analyzed: cattāro sati paṭṭhānā ti vuccati ekam eva ca vīriyam anuppannānam anuppāda ādi kicca sādhana vasena
translated: So when they are found in a single consciousness, the single mindfulness that has Nibbāna as its object is called the four foundations of mindfulness since it accomplishes the function of abandoning the perception of beauty, and so on, in the case of the body, and so on. And the single energy is called the four right efforts since it accomplishes the function of preventing the arising of unprofitable states that have not arisen, and so on.

original: cattāro sammappadhānāti vuccati. Sesesu pana hāpanavaḍḍhanaṃ natthi.
analyzed: cattāro sammappadhānā ti vuccati sesesu pana hāpana vaḍḍhanam natthi
translated: “Four right efforts” is said. But there is no subtraction and addition in the rest.

original: 826. Apica tesu –
analyzed: api ca tesu
translated: Moreover, as regards these:🔽Nine are singlefold, one twofold,

original: Nava ekavidhā eko, dvedhātha catu pañcadhā;
analyzed: nava ekavidhāḥ ekaḥ dvedhā atha catu pañcadhā
translated: Then one fourfold, one fivefold,🔽One eightfold, one ninefold:

original: Aṭṭhadhā navadhā ceva, iti chaddhā bhavanti te.🔽Nava ekavidhāti chando, cittaṃ, pīti, passaddhi, upekkhā, saṅkappo, vācā, kammanto,
analyzed: aṭṭhadhā navadhā ca iva iti chaddhā bhavanti te  nava ekavidhā iti chando cittam pīti passaddhi upekkhā saṅkappaḥ vācā kammanto
translated: Thus they are sixfold.

original: ājīvoti ime nava chandiddhipādādivasena ekavidhāva honti, na aññaṃ koṭṭhāsaṃ bhajanti.🔽Eko dvedhāti saddhā indriya, balavasena dvedhā ṭhitā. Atha catu pañcadhāti athañño🔽eko catudhā, añño pañcadhā ṭhitoti attho. Tattha samādhi eko indriya, bala, bojjhaṅga,
analyzed: ājīvo ti ime nava chandiddhipāda ādi vasena ekavidhā ava honti na aññam koṭṭhāsam bhajanti  ekaḥ dvedhā iti saddhā indriya balavasena dvedhā ṭhitā atha catu pañcadhā ati  ekaḥ catudhā añño pañcadhā ṭhito ti attho tattha samādhi eko indriya bala bojjhaṅga
translated: Nine are singlefold: zeal, consciousness, happiness, tranquillity, equanimity, thinking, speech, action, and livelihood. These nine are singlefold only as the basis for success in zeal, etc., and they do not belong to any other section.🔽One is twofold: faith, as a faculty and as a power.🔽Then one fourfold, one fivefold: then another one is fourfold, another one is fivefold, is the meaning. Herein, concentration is fourfold as a faculty, a power, an enlightenment factor, and a path factor.

original: maggaṅgavasena catudhā ṭhito. Paññā tesañca catunnaṃ iddhipādakoṭṭhāsassa ca vasena
analyzed: maggaṅga vasena catudhā ṭhitaḥ paññā tesam ca catunnam iddhipāda koṭṭhāsassa ca vasena
translated: Understanding is fivefold as those four and as a basis for success in zeal.

original: pañcadhā. Aṭṭhadhā navadhā cevāti aparo eko aṭṭhadhā, eko navadhā ṭhitoti attho.
analyzed: pañcadhā aṭṭhadhā navadhā ca iva ati aparaḥ ekaḥ aṭṭhadhā ekaḥ navadhā ṭhito ti attho
translated: One eightfold, one ninefold: one other is eightfold, one other is ninefold, is the meaning.

original: Catusatipaṭṭhāna, indriya, bala, bojjhaṅga, maggaṅgavasena sati aṭṭhadhā ṭhitā. Catusammappadhāna,
analyzed: indriya bala bojjhaṅga maggaṅga vasena sati aṭṭhadhā ṭhitā
translated: And it is established in eight ways as mindfulness of the four foundations of mindfulness, of the faculties, powers, enlightenment factors, and path factors.🔽And it is established in four ways as the four right endeavours,

original: iddhipāda, indriya, bala, bojjhaṅga, maggaṅgavasena vīriyaṃ navadhāti. Evaṃ –
analyzed: iddhipāda indriya bala bojjhaṅga maggaṅga vasena vīriyam navadhā ati evam
translated: Mindfulness is established in eight ways as the four foundations of mindfulness, the faculties, the powers, the factors of enlightenment, and the path factors. Energy is ninefold as the four right endeavours, the bases of success, the faculties, the powers, the factors of enlightenment, and the path factors. So:

original: Cuddaseva asambhinnā, hontete bodhipakkhiyā;🔽Koṭṭhāsato sattavidhā, sattatiṃsappabhedato.
analyzed: cuddasā iva asambhinnāḥ honta ete bodhi pakkhiyā  koṭṭhāsato sattavidhā sattatiṃsa ppabhedato
translated: The thirty-seven ideas that lead to enlightenment Are thus unmixed in fourteen ways,🔽In seven ways by position, and in thirty-seven ways By division.

original: Sakiccanipphādanato, sarūpena ca vuttito;
analyzed: sa kicca nipphādanato sarūpena ca vuttitaḥ
translated: They are all produced by their own function, And they occur according to their individual nature.

original: Sabbeva ariyamaggassa, sambhave sambhavanti teti.
analyzed: sabbe iva ariya maggassa sambhave sambhavanti te ti
translated: They all come into existence when the noble path comes into existence.

original: Evaṃ tāvettha paripuṇṇabodhipakkhiyabhāvo jānitabbo.
analyzed: evam tāva ettha paripuṇṇa bodhi pakkhiya bhāvaḥ jānitabbo
translated: This, firstly, is how the fulfilled nature of the enlightenment factors should be understood.🔽The Path of Purification🔽The Path of Purification composed for the purpose of gladdening good people.🔽The section for recitation on the powers and faculties is finished.

original: Vuṭṭhānabalasamāyogakathā🔽827. Vuṭṭhānabalasamāyogoti vuṭṭhānañceva balasamāyogo ca. Lokiyavipassanā hi nimittārammaṇattā🔽ceva pavattikāraṇassa ca samudayassa asamucchindanato neva nimittā na pavattā vuṭṭhāti.
analyzed: vuṭṭhāna bala samāyoga kathā  vuṭṭhāna bala samāyogo ti vuṭṭhānam ca iva bala samāyogo ca lokiya vipassanā hi nimitta ārammaṇa ttā  ca iva pavatti kāraṇassa ca samudayassa a samucchindanataḥ na iva nimittā na pavattā vuṭṭhāti
translated: The section on the powers and faculties🔽The “combination of the power of emergence and the faculty of final knowledge” is the combination of the power of emergence and the faculty of final knowledge. For mundane insight does not emerge from its object, the sign, and it does not emerge from the cause of its occurrence, the arising of the sign, since it has the sign as its object and since it does not sever the cause of the occurrence of the sign.🔽Knowledge of change-of-lineage does not emerge from the cause of its occurrence, the arising of the sign, since it does not sever the cause of the occurrence of the sign.

original: Gotrabhuñāṇaṃ samudayassa asamucchindanato pavattā na vuṭṭhāti. Nibbānārammaṇato
analyzed: gotra bhuñāṇam samudayassa a samucchindanataḥ pavattā na vuṭṭhāti nibbāna ārammaṇato
translated: But it does emerge from its object, the sign, since it has Nibbāna as its object.

original: pana nimittā vuṭṭhātīti ekato vuṭṭhānaṃ hoti. Tenāha “bahiddhāvuṭṭhānavivaṭṭane paññā🔽gotrabhuñāṇa”nti. Tathā “uppādā vivaṭṭitvā anuppādaṃ pakkhandatīti gotrabhu, pavattā🔽vivaṭṭitvā”ti sabbaṃ veditabbaṃ. Imāni pana cattāripi ñāṇāni animittārammaṇattā nimittato
analyzed: pana nimittā vuṭṭhāti iti ekatas vuṭṭhānam hoti tena āha bahiddhā vuṭṭhāna vivaṭṭane paññā  tathā uppādāḥ vivaṭṭitvā anuppādam pakkhandati iti gotrabhu pavattā  vivaṭṭitvā iti sabbam veditabbam imāni pana cattāri pi ñāṇāni animitta ārammaṇa ttā nimittato
translated: but he emerges from the sign. So there is emergence from one. Hence it is said, “Understanding of emergence and turning away in external things is the knowledge of change-of-lineage” . Likewise, “Having turned away from arising, it enters into non- arising” , and so on. All this should be understood. But these four kinds of knowledge have the signless as their object, and so they are called “knowledge of the signless” .🔽

original: vuṭṭhahanti, samudayassa samucchindanato pavattā vuṭṭhahantīti dubhato vuṭṭhānāni honti.
analyzed: vuṭṭhahanti samudayassa samucchindanataḥ pavattā vuṭṭhahanti iti dubhataḥ vuṭṭhānāni honti
translated: but it emerges from the sign. So there is emergence from one. Hence it is said: “Understanding of emergence and turning away in regard to what is external is knowledge of the state of change-of-lineage” . Likewise: “It emerges from arising and plunges into non- arising” , and so on. All this should be understood. But these four kinds of knowledge emerge from the sign because they have the signless as their object, and they emerge from occurrence because they sever the origin. So they are “emergence from both” .

original: Tena vuttaṃ –
analyzed: tena vuttam
translated: Hence it is said:

original: “Kathaṃ dubhato vuṭṭhānavivaṭṭane paññā magge ñāṇaṃ?🔽“Sotāpattimaggakkhaṇe dassanaṭṭhena sammādiṭṭhi micchādiṭṭhiyā vuṭṭhāti, tadanuvattakakilesehi🔽ca khandhehi ca vuṭṭhāti, bahiddhā ca sabbanimittehi vuṭṭhāti. Tena vuccati dubhato
analyzed: katham dubhataḥ vuṭṭhāna vivaṭṭane paññā magge ñāṇam  sotāpatti magga kkhaṇe dassana ṭṭhena sammādiṭṭhi micchādiṭṭhiyā vuṭṭhāti tad anuvattaka kilesehi  ca khandhehi ca vuṭṭhāti bahiddhā ca sabba nimittehi vuṭṭhāti tena vuccati dubhataḥ
translated: “How is it that understanding of emergence and turning away in regard to both is knowledge of the path?

original: vuṭṭhānavivaṭṭane paññā magge ñāṇaṃ. Abhiniropanaṭṭhena sammāsaṅkappo micchāsaṅkappā…pe…
analyzed: vuṭṭhāna vivaṭṭane paññā magge ñāṇam abhiniropana ṭṭhena sammāsaṅkappo micchāsaṅkappa ape
translated: “At the moment of the stream-entry path, right view emerges from wrong view in the sense of seeing, and it emerges from the defilements and from the aggregates that occur consequent upon the wrong view, and it emerges from all the signs externally. Hence it is said that understanding of emergence and turning away in regard to both is knowledge of the path. Right thought emerges from wrong thought in the sense of adverting …

original: pariggahaṭṭhena sammāvācā micchāvācāya. Samuṭṭhānaṭṭhena sammākammanto. Vodānaṭṭhena🔽sammāājīvo. Paggahaṭṭhena sammāvāyāmo. Upaṭṭhānaṭṭhena sammāsati. Avikkhepaṭṭhena
analyzed: pariggaha aṭṭhena sammāvācā micchāvācāya samuṭṭhāna ṭṭhena sammākammantaḥ vodāna ṭṭhena  sammāājīvaḥ paggaha ṭṭhena sammāvāyāmaḥ upaṭṭhāna ṭṭhena sammāsati avikkhepa ṭṭhena
translated: Right speech is the escape from wrong speech in the sense of embracing. Right action is the escape from wrong action in the sense of origination.🔽Right livelihood is the escape from wrong livelihood in the sense of cleansing.

original: sammāsamādhi micchāsamādhito vuṭṭhāti, tadanuvattakakilesehi ca khandhehi ca vuṭṭhāti,
analyzed: sammāsamādhi micchāsamādhitaḥ vuṭṭhāti tad anuvattaka kilesehi ca khandhehi ca vuṭṭhāti
translated: Right effort is the escape from wrong effort in the sense of exerting. Right mindfulness is the escape from wrong mindfulness in the sense of establishing. Right concentration is the escape from wrong concentration in the sense of non-distraction. It is the escape from the defilements associated with wrong concentration, and from the aggregates, etc., associated with it.

original: bahiddhā ca sabbanimittehi vuṭṭhāti. Tena vuccati ‘dubhato vuṭṭhānavivaṭṭane paññā magge ñāṇa’nti.
analyzed: bahiddhā ca sabba nimittehi vuṭṭhāti tena vuccati dubhataḥ vuṭṭhāna vivaṭṭane paññā magge ñāṇam ti
translated: And it is the escape from all external signs. Hence ‘Understanding of the act of abandoning and of the escape in the case of the path is knowledge of the path’ is said.🔽‘At the moment of the path of once-returner-ship, right view … right concentration are the escape from the gross fetters of sense desire and resistance, from the gross inherent tendencies to them, and from the gross unprofitable things associated with them. …’

original: “Sakadāgāmimaggakkhaṇe dassanaṭṭhena sammādiṭṭhi…pe… avikkhepaṭṭhena sammāsamādhi oḷārikā kāmarāgasaṃyojanā paṭighasaṃyojanā oḷārikā kāmarāgānusayā paṭighānusayā vuṭṭhāti…pe….
analyzed: sakadāgāmi magga khaṇe dassana ṭhena sammādiṭṭhi pe avikkhepa ṭṭhena sammāsamādhi oḷārikā kāma rāga saṃyojanā paṭigha saṃyojanā oḷārikā kāma rāga anusayā paṭigha anusayā vuṭṭhā atipe
translated: ‘At the moment of the path of non-returner-ship, right view … right concentration are the escape from the subtle fetters of sense desire and resistance, from the subtle inherent tendencies to them, and from the subtle unprofitable things associated with them. …’

original: “Anāgāmimaggakkhaṇe dassanaṭṭhena sammādiṭṭhi…pe… avikkhepaṭṭhena sammāsamādhi anusahagatā kāmarāgasaṃyojanā paṭighasaṃyojanā anusahagatā kāmarāgānusayā paṭighānusayā vuṭṭhāti…pe….🔽“Arahattamaggakkhaṇe dassanaṭṭhena sammādiṭṭhi…pe… avikkhepaṭṭhena sammāsamādhi rūparāgā
analyzed: anāgāmi magga kkhaṇe dassana ṭhena sammādiṭṭhi pe avikkhepa ṭṭhena sammāsamādhi anu sahagatā kāma rāga saṃyojanā paṭigha saṃyojanā anu sahagatā kāma rāga anusayā paṭigha anusayā vuṭṭhā ātipe  arahatta magga kkhaṇe dassana ṭhena sammādiṭṭhi pe avikkhepa ṭṭhena sammāsamādhi rūpa rāgā
translated: “At the moment of the path of non-return, right view, right thinking, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right concentration in the sense of seeing, etc., and in the sense of non-distraction, emerge from the fetter of lust for sensual pleasures, from the fetter of resentment, from the underlying tendency to lust for sensual pleasures, and from the underlying tendency to resentment. …

original: arūparāgā mānā uddhaccā avijjāya mānānusayā bhavarāgānusayā avijjānusayā vuṭṭhāti,
analyzed: arūpa rāgāḥ mānāḥ uddhaccāḥ avijjāya māna anusayāḥ bhava rāga anusayāḥ avijja anusayāḥ vuṭṭhāti
translated: “At the moment of the path of Arahantship, right view, right thinking, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right concentration in the sense of seeing, etc., and in the sense of non-distraction, emerge from lust for the fine-material and immaterial, from conceit , from agitation, from ignorance, from the underlying tendency to conceit, from the underlying tendency to lust for existence, and from the underlying tendency to ignorance.

original: tadanuvattakakilesehi ca khandhehi ca vuṭṭhāti, bahiddhā ca sabbanimittehi vuṭṭhāti.
analyzed: tad anuvattaka kilesehi ca khandhehi ca vuṭṭhāti bahiddhā ca sabba nimittehi vuṭṭhāti
translated: They emerge from the defilements and from the aggregates that accompany the defilements, and they emerge from all external signs.

original: Tena vuccati ‘dubhato vuṭṭhānavivaṭṭane paññā magge ñāṇa”’nti.
analyzed: tena vuccati dubhataḥ vuṭṭhāna vivaṭṭane paññā magge ñāṇam ti
translated: Hence it is said: ‘Understanding of emergence and of non-recurrence in the case of the path is knowledge of the path’” .

original: 828. Lokiyānañca aṭṭhannaṃ samāpattīnaṃ bhāvanākāle samathabalaṃ adhikaṃ hoti. Aniccānupassanādīnaṃ
analyzed: lokiyānam ca aṭṭhannam samāpattīnam bhāvanā kāle samatha balam adhikam hoti anicca anupassanā ādīnam
translated: At the time of developing the eight mundane attainments, the power of serenity is predominant. At the time of developing the contemplations of impermanence, etc.,

original: bhāvanākāle vipassanābalaṃ. Ariyamaggakkhaṇe pana yuganaddhā te dhammā pavattanti
analyzed: bhāvanā kāle vipassanā balam ariya magga kkhaṇe pana yuga naddhā te dhammā pavattanti
translated: the power of insight is predominant. But at the moment of the noble path the two are yoked together.

original: aññamaññaṃ anativattanaṭṭhena. Tasmā imesu catūsupi ñāṇesu ubhayabalasamāyogo hoti. Yathāha –
analyzed: aññam aññam an ativattana ṭṭhena tasmai imesu catūsu pi ñāṇesu ubhaya bala samāyogaḥ hoti yathā āha
translated: and in the sense of not overstepping each other. So there is a combination of both powers in these four kinds of knowledge. As it is said:

original: “Uddhaccasahagatakilesehi ca khandhehi ca vuṭṭhahato cittassa ekaggatā avikkhepo🔽samādhi nirodhagocaro, avijjāsahagatakilesehi ca khandhehi ca vuṭṭhahato anupassanaṭṭhena🔽vipassanā nirodhagocarā. Iti vuṭṭhānaṭṭhena samathavipassanā ekarasā honti, yuganaddhā
analyzed: uddhacca sahagata kilesehi ca khandhehi ca vuṭṭhahato cittassa ekagga tā avikkhepo  samādhi nirodha gocaraḥ avijjā sahagata kilesehi ca khandhehi ca vuṭṭhahataḥ anupassana ṭṭhena  vipassanā nirodha gocarā iti vuṭṭhāna ṭṭhena samatha vipassanā ekarasāḥ honti yuga naddhā
translated: “The unification of cognizance and non-distraction due to the fading away of lust is concentration.🔽The contemplation as suffering due to the fading away of ignorance is insight. So in the sense of fading away serenity and insight have a single function, they are yoked evenly, they do not overstep each other.

original: honti, aññamaññaṃ nātivattantīti. Tena vuccati vuṭṭhānaṭṭhena samathavipassanaṃ yuganaddhaṃ bhāvetī”ti.
analyzed: honti aññam aññam na ativattanti iti tena vuccati vuṭṭhāna aṭṭhena samatha vipassanam yuga naddham bhāveti iti
translated: That is why it is said that he develops serenity and insight in union by making them even in the sense of fading away” .

original: Evamettha vuṭṭhānabalasamāyogo veditabbo.
analyzed: evam ettha vuṭṭhāna bala samāyogaḥ veditabbo
translated: So the combination of powers in the sense of fading away should be understood here in this way.

original: Pahātabbadhammapahānakathā🔽829. Ye yena pahātabbā dhammā, tesaṃ pahānañcāti imesu pana catūsu ñāṇesu ye dhammā
analyzed: pahātabba dhamma pahāna kathā  ye yena pahātabbāḥ dhammāḥ tesam pahānam ca ati imesu pana catūsu ñāṇesu ye dhammā
translated: Abandonment of what is to be abandoned

original: yena ñāṇena pahātabbā, tesaṃ pahānañca jānitabbaṃ. Etāni hi yathāyogaṃ
analyzed: yena ñāṇena pahātabbā tesam pahānañca jānitabbam etāni hi yathāyogam
translated: As to the states that are to be abandoned by means of these four kinds of knowledge and the abandoning of them: in these four kinds of knowledge the states that are to be abandoned by each kind of knowledge and the abandoning of them should be understood. For these four kinds of knowledge are respectively

original: saṃyojanakilesamicchattalokadhammamacchariyavipallāsaganthaagatiāsavaoghayoganīvaraṇaparāmāsaupādānaanusayamalaakusalakammapathacittuppādasaṅkhātānaṃ🔽dhammānaṃ pahānakarāni.🔽Tattha saṃyojanānīti khandhehi khandhānaṃ phalena kammassa dukkhena vā sattānaṃ saṃyojakattā
analyzed: saṃyojana kilesa micchatta loka dhamma macchariya vipallāsa gantha agati āsava ogha yoga nīvaraṇa parāmāsa upādāna anusaya mala a kusala kamma patha cittuppāda saṅkhātānam  dhammānam pahāna karāni  tattha saṃyojanāni iti khandhehi khandhānam phalena kammassa dukkhena vā sattānam saṃyojaka ttā
translated: They are the abandoners of states called fetters, defilements, perversions, mundane states, envy, perversions, ties, bad ways, taints, floods, bonds, hindrances, adherences, attachments, inherent tendencies, stains, and unprofitable courses of action.🔽Herein, the fetters are ten states called “lust for fine-material existence,” etc., which are so called because they fetter the aggregates to the aggregates by means of the fruit of kamma, or because they fetter beings to suffering.

original: rūparāgādayo dasa dhammā vuccanti. Yāvañhi te, tāva etesaṃ anuparamoti. Tatrāpi rūparāgo🔽arūparāgo māno uddhaccaṃ avijjāti ime pañca uddhaṃnibbattanakakhandhādisaṃyojakattā🔽uddhaṃbhāgiyasaṃyojanāni nāma. Sakkāyadiṭṭhi vicikicchā sīlabbataparāmāso kāmarāgo
analyzed: rūpa rāga ādayaḥ dasa dhammāḥ vuccanti yāvat hi te tāva etesam tatra api rūpa rāgaḥ  arūpa rāgaḥ mānaḥ uddhaccam avijjāti ime pañca uddham nibbattanaka khandha ādi saṃyojaka ttā  uddhaṃbhāgiya saṃyojanāni nāma sakkāya diṭṭhi vicikicchā sīlabbata parāmāsaḥ kāma rāgo
translated: For as long as they exist, so long do these not cease. And here, lust for the fine-material,🔽lust for the immaterial, conceit, agitation, and ignorance are called “fetters pertaining to the higher,” because they fetter the aggregates that will be reborn in the future.

original: paṭighoti ime pañca adhonibbattanakakhandhādisaṃyojakattā adhobhāgiyasaṃyojanāni nāma.
analyzed: paṭighaḥ ti ime pañca adhas nibbattanaka khandha ādi saṃyojaka ttā adhobhāgiya saṃyojanāni nāma
translated: And personality view, uncertainty, adherence to rules and vows, lust for sensual desires, and resentment are called “fetters pertaining to the lower,” because they fetter the aggregates that will be reborn in the future.

original: Kilesāti sayaṃ saṃkiliṭṭhattā sampayuttadhammānañca saṃkilesikattā lobho doso moho māno diṭṭhi vicikicchā thinaṃ uddhaccaṃ ahirikaṃ anottappanti ime dasa dhammā.🔽Micchattāti micchāpavattanato micchādiṭṭhi micchāsaṅkappo micchāvācā micchākammanto
analyzed: kilesā ati sayam saṃkiliṭṭha ttā sampayutta dhammānam ca saṃkilesika ttā lobhaḥ dosaḥ mohaḥ mānaḥ diṭṭhi vicikicchā thinam uddhaccam ahirikam anottappanti ime dasa dhammā  micchattā ati micchā apavattanataḥ micchā diṭṭhi micchā saṅkappaḥ micchā vācā micchā kammanto
translated: “Defilements” are the ten states consisting of greed, hate, delusion, conceit, false view, uncertainty, stiffness, agitation, consciencelessness, and shamelessness.

original: micchāājīvo micchāvāyāmo micchāsati micchāsamādhīti ime aṭṭha dhammā. Micchāvimuttimicchāñāṇehi vā saddhiṃ dasa.🔽Lokadhammāti lokappavattiyā sati anuparamadhammakattā lābho alābho yaso ayaso sukhaṃ🔽dukkhaṃ nindā pasaṃsāti ime aṭṭha. Idha pana kāraṇopacārena lābhādivatthukassa anunayassa
analyzed: micchāājīvaḥ micchāvāyāmaḥ micchā sati micchā samādhi iti ime aṭṭha dhammā micchā vimutti micchā ñāṇehi vā saddhim dasa  loka dhammā ti loka ppavattiyā sati anuparama dhammaka ttā lābhaḥ alābhaḥ yasaḥ ayasaḥ sukham  dukkham nindā pasaṃsā ati ime aṭṭha idha pana kāraṇa upacārena lābha ādi vatthukassa anunayassa
translated: “Wrongnesses” are the eight states consisting of wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, and wrong concentration, or the ten states together with wrong deliverance and wrong knowledge.

original: alābhādivatthukassa paṭighassa cetaṃ lokadhammaggahaṇena gahaṇaṃ katanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: alābha ādi vatthukassa paṭighassa ca itam loka dhamma ggahaṇena gahaṇam katan ti veditabbam
translated: “Worldly states” are the eight states consisting of gain, loss, fame, disgrace, pleasure, pain, blame, and praise. But here the taking of these should be understood as the taking of the underlying tendency to lust that has gain, etc., as its object and the underlying tendency to aversion that has loss, etc., as its object by figurative application of the cause by the effect.

original: Macchariyānīti āvāsamacchariyaṃ kulamacchariyaṃ lābhamacchariyaṃ dhammamacchariyaṃ
analyzed: macchariyāni iti āvāsa macchariyam kulam acchariyam lābham acchariyam dhamma macchariyam
translated: “Stinginess” is stinginess about dwellings, families, gains, and the True Dhamma.

original: vaṇṇamacchariyanti imāsu āvāsādīsu aññesaṃ sādhāraṇabhāvaṃ asahanākārena pavattāni pañca macchariyāni.
analyzed: imāsu āvāsa ādīsu aññesam sādhāraṇa bhāvam asahanā ākārena pavattāni pañca macchariyāni
translated: The five kinds of stinginess are stinginess about dwelling, about families, about gains, about Dhamma, and about one’s own self.

original: Vipallāsāti aniccadukkhaanattaasubhesuyeva vatthūsu “niccaṃ sukhaṃ attā subha”nti evaṃ pavatto saññāvipallāso cittavipallāso diṭṭhivipallāsoti ime tayo.🔽Ganthāti nāmakāyassa ceva rūpakāyassa ca ganthanato abhijjhādayo cattāro. Tathā hi🔽te abhijjhā kāyagantho, byāpādo kāyagantho, sīlabbataparāmāso kāyagantho, idaṃsaccābhiniveso
analyzed: vipallāsā ti anicca dukkha anatta asubhesu yeva vatthūsu niccam sukham attā subham ti evam pavatto saññā vipallāso citta vipallāso diṭṭhi vipallāso ti ime tayo  ganthā ti nāmakāyassa ca iva rūpakāyassa ca ganthanataḥ abhijjhā ādayo cattāro tathā hi  te abhijjhā kāya ganthaḥ byāpādaḥ kāya ganthaḥ sīlabbata parāmāsaḥ kāya ganthaḥ idaṃsacca abhinivesaḥ
translated: The three perversions are the perversion of perception, the perversion of cognizance, and the perversion of view, which occur only in the case of impermanence, pain, foulness, and not-self.

original: kāyagantho icceva vuttā.
analyzed: kāyagantho iccā iva vuttā
translated: The four ties are covetousness, ill will, adherence to rules and vows, and assertion of a personal entity. For these are called respectively the bodily tie of covetousness, the bodily tie of ill will, the bodily tie of adherence to rules and vows, and the bodily tie of assertion of a personal entity.🔽  The four floods are the flood of sensuality, the flood of becoming, the flood of view, and the flood of ignorance.

original: Agatīti chandadosamohabhayehi akattabbakaraṇassa, kattabbākaraṇassa ca adhivacanaṃ. Tañhi ariyehi agantabbattā agatīti vuccati.
analyzed: agati iti chanda dosa moha bhayehi akattabba karaṇassa kattabba akaraṇassa ca adhivacanam tat hi ariyehi a gantabba ttā agati iti vuccati
translated: The four bonds are the bond of sensuality, the bond of becoming, the bond of view, and the bond of ignorance.

original: Āsavāti ārammaṇavasena āgotrabhuto, ābhavaggato ca savanā, asaṃvutehi vā dvārehi🔽ghaṭachiddehi udakaṃ viya savanato niccapaggharaṇaṭṭhena saṃsāradukkhassa vā savanato🔽kāmarāgabhavarāgamicchādiṭṭhiavijjānametaṃ adhivacanaṃ.🔽Bhavasāgare ākaḍḍhanaṭṭhena duruttaraṇaṭṭhena ca oghātipi, ārammaṇaviyogassa ceva dukkhaviyogassa ca appadānato yogātipi tesaññeva adhivacanaṃ.🔽Nīvaraṇānīti cittassa āvaraṇanīvaraṇapaṭicchādanaṭṭhena kāmacchandādayo pañca.🔽Parāmāsoti tassa tassa dhammassa sabhāvaṃ atikkamma parato abhūtaṃ sabhāvaṃ āmasanākārena pavattanato micchādiṭṭhiyā etaṃ adhivacanaṃ.
analyzed: āsavā ti ārammaṇa vasena ca savanā asaṃvutehi vā dvārehi  ghaṭa chiddehi udakam viya savanataḥ nicca paggharaṇa aṭṭhena saṃsāra dukkhassa vā savanataḥ  adhivacanam  bhava sāgare ākaḍḍhana ṭhena duruttaraṇa ṭhena ca ogha atipi ārammaṇa viyogassa ca iva dukkha viyogassa ca appadānataḥ yoga atipi tesaññeva adhivacanaṃ  nīvaraṇāni iti cittassa āvaraṇa nīvaraṇa paṭicchādana ṭṭhena kāmacchanda ādayo pañca  parāmāsaḥ ti tassa tassa dhammassa sabhāvam atikkamma paratas abhūtam sabhāvam āmasana ākārena pavattanataḥ micchādiṭṭhiyāḥ etam adhivacanam
translated: “Defilements” : they are called “defilements” because they are the cause of the arising of the unwholesome, because they are the cause of the arising of the defilements, because they are the cause of the arising of the kamma-resultants, and because they are the cause of the arising of the inconstant world.🔽“Cankers” : they are called “cancers” because they are the cause of the arising of the unwholesome, because they are the cause of the arising of the defilements, because they are the cause of the arising of the kamma-resultants, and because they are the cause of the arising of the inconstant world.🔽“Floods” : they are called “floods” because they cause beings to be swept away and submerged in the ocean of existence.🔽“Bonds” : they are called “bonds” because they bind beings to the suffering of the round.🔽“Hindrances” : they are called “hindrances” because they hinder and obstruct the mind.🔽“Misapprehensions” : they are called “misapprehensions” because they occur in the mode of misapprehending the individual essence of their object by overrunning it.

original: Upādānānīti sabbākārena paṭiccasamuppādaniddese vuttāni kāmupādānādīni cattāri.
analyzed: upādānāni iti sabba ākārena paṭiccasamuppāda niddese vuttāni kāma upādāna ādīni cattāri
translated: “Defilements” : they are called “defilements” because they are the cause of the arising of the defilements, because they are the cause of the arising of the defilements, because they are
