analyzed: saṅkhārānam paṭippassaddhiyā soḷasahi ñāṇa cariyāhi navahi samādhi cariyāhi vasībhāva tā  paññā nirodha samāpattiyāḥ ñāṇan ti hi vuttam ayam ca sampadā ṭhapetvā aṭṭha samāpatti lābhino
translated: and in nine ways of concentration,🔽his wisdom is knowledge of the attainment of cessation” .🔽And this accomplishment is not found in anyone else except non-returners and arahants who have attained the eight attainments.

original: anāgāmikhīṇāsave aññesaṃ natthi. Tasmā teyeva samāpajjanti, na aññe.
analyzed: anāgāmi khīṇāsave aññesam na atthi tasmā te yeva samāpajjanti na aññe
translated: That is why only they enter it, not others.

original: 869. Katamāni panettha dve balāni…pe… katamā vasībhāvatāti? Na ettha kiñci amhehi vattabbaṃ atthi. Sabbamidaṃ etassa uddesassa niddese vuttameva. Yathāha –
analyzed: katamāni pana ittha dve balānipe katamā vasībhāva tā iti na ettha kiñci amhehi vattabbam atthi sabbam idam etassa uddesassa niddese vuttam eva yathā āha
translated: But what are the two powers here? … What is mastery? There is nothing here for us to say. All this has already been said in the description of the heading. As it is said:

original: “Dvīhi balehīti dve balāni samathabalaṃ vipassanābalaṃ. Katamaṃ samathabalaṃ? Nekkhammavasena
analyzed: dvīhi balehi iti dve balāni samatha balam vipassanā balam katamam samatha balam nekkhamma vasena
translated: “Because he possesses two powers”: there are two powers, the power of concentration and the power of wisdom. What is the power of concentration?

original: cittassa ekaggatā avikkhepo samathabalaṃ. Abyāpādavasena… ālokasaññāvasena… avikkhepavasena…pe…
analyzed: cittassa ekagga tā avikkhepaḥ samatha balam abyāpāda vasena āloka saññā vasena avikkhepa vasena pe
translated: Through non-ill-will… through the perception of light… through non-distraction…

original: paṭinissaggānupassiassāsavasena… paṭinissaggānupassipassāsavasena cittassa ekaggatā
analyzed: paṭinissagga anupassi assāsa vasena paṭinissagga anupassi passāsa vasena cittassa ekagga tā
translated: through in-breaths and out-breaths contemplating relinquishment, one-pointedness of mind,🔽non-distraction is the strength of concentration.

original: avikkhepo samathabalanti. Kenaṭṭhena samathabalaṃ? Paṭhamajjhānena nīvaraṇe na kampatīti
analyzed: avikkhepaḥ samatha balan ti kenaṭṭhena samatha balam paṭhama jhānena nīvaraṇe na kampati iti
translated: In what sense is it the strength of concentration? It does not waver in the first jhāna because of the hindrances,

original: samathabalaṃ. Dutiyajjhānena vitakkavicāre…pe… nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasamāpattiyā🔽ākiñcaññāyatanasaññāya na kampatīti samathabalaṃ. Uddhacce ca uddhaccasahagatakilese
analyzed: samatha balam dutiya jhānena vitakka vicārepe na ivasaññā nāsañña āyatana samāpattiyā  ākiñcaññāyatana saññāya na kampati iti samatha balam uddhacce ca uddhacca sahagata kilese
translated: so it is the strength of concentration. It does not waver in the second jhāna because of applied and sustained thought, …

original: ca khandhe ca na kampati na calati na vedhatīti samathabalaṃ. Idaṃ samathabalaṃ.
analyzed: ca khandhe ca na kampati na calati na vedhati iti samatha balam idam samatha balam
translated: in the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception because of the perception of the base consisting of nothingness, so it is the strength of concentration. It does not waver in restlessness and anxiety, in the defilements and in the aggregates, so it is the strength of concentration. This is the strength of concentration.

original: “Katamaṃ vipassanābalaṃ? Aniccānupassanā vipassanābalaṃ. Dukkhānupassanā… anattānupassanā…
analyzed: katamam vipassanā balam anicca anupassanā vipassanā balam dukkha anupassanā anatta anupassanā
translated: “What is the strength of insight? Contemplation of impermanence is the strength of insight. Contemplation of pain … contemplation of not-self …

original: nibbidānupassanā… virāgānupassanā… nirodhānupassanā… paṭinissaggānupassanā vipassanābalaṃ.
analyzed: nibbida anupassanā virāga anupassanā nirodha anupassanā paṭinissagga anupassanā vipassanā balam
translated: contemplation of dispassion … contemplation of fading away … contemplation of cessation … contemplation of relinquishment is the strength of insight.

original: Rūpe aniccānupassanā…pe… rūpe paṭinissaggānupassanā vipassanābalaṃ. Vedanāya… saññāya…
analyzed: rūpe anicca anupassanā āpe rūpe paṭinissagga anupassanā vipassanā balam vedanāya saññāya
translated: Contemplation of impermanence in materiality… Contemplation of relinquishment in materiality is the strength of insight. Contemplation of impermanence in feeling … in perception …

original: saṅkhāresu… viññāṇe… cakkhusmiṃ…pe… jarāmaraṇe aniccānupassanā. Jarāmaraṇe paṭinissaggānupassanā
analyzed: saṅkhāresu viññāṇe cakkhusmiṃpe jarā maraṇe anicca anupassanā jarā maraṇe paṭinissagga anupassanā
translated: in formations … in consciousness … in the eye … in ageing-and-death … Contemplation of relinquishment in ageing-and-death is the strength of insight.

original: vipassanābalanti. Kenaṭṭhena vipassanābalaṃ? Aniccānupassanāya niccasaññāya na kampatīti🔽vipassanābalaṃ. Dukkhānupassanāya sukhasaññāya na kampatīti… anattānupassanāya attasaññāya
analyzed: vipassanā balanti kenaṭṭhena vipassanā balam anicca anupassanāya nicca saññāya na kampati iti  vipassanā balam dukkha anupassanāya sukha saññāya na kampati iti anatta anupassanāya atta saññāya
translated: In what sense is the strength of insight? Contemplation of impermanence does not waver with the perception of permanence,

original: na kampatīti… nibbidānupassanāya nandiyā na kampatīti… virāgānupassanāya rāge na🔽kampatīti… nirodhānupassanāya samudaye na kampatīti… paṭinissaggānupassanāya ādāne
analyzed: na kampati iti nibbida anupassanāya nandiyā na kampati iti virāga anupassanāya rāge na  kampati iti nirodha anupassanāya samudaye na kampati iti paṭinissagga anupassanāya ādāne
translated: so it is the strength of insight. Contemplation of pain does not waver with the perception of pleasure … Contemplation of not-self does not waver with the perception of self … Contemplation of dispassion does not waver with delight … Contemplation of fading away does not waver with greed …

original: na kampatīti vipassanābalaṃ. Avijjāya ca avijjāsahagatakilese ca khandhe ca na kampati
analyzed: na kampati iti vipassanā balam avijjāya ca avijjā sahagata kilese ca khandhe ca na kampati
translated: Contemplation of cessation does not waver with arising … Contemplation of relinquishment does not waver with grasping, so it is the strength of insight. Contemplation of impermanence does not waver with ignorance and with the defilements and with the aggregates that are associated with ignorance …🔽Contemplation of relinquishment does not waver with ignorance and with the defilements and with the aggregates that are associated with ignorance, so it is the strength of insight.

original: na calati na vedhatīti vipassanābalaṃ. Idaṃ vipassanābalaṃ.
analyzed: na calati na vedhati iti vipassanā balam idam vipassanā balam
translated: This is the strength of insight.

original: “Tayo ca saṅkhārānaṃ paṭippassaddhiyāti katamesaṃ tiṇṇannaṃ saṅkhārānaṃ paṭippassaddhiyā?
analyzed: tayo ca saṅkhārānam paṭippassaddhiyā ati katamesam tiṇṇannam saṅkhārānam paṭippassaddhiyā
translated: “And the stilling of the three types of volitional formations: the stilling of which three types of volitional formations?

original: Dutiyajjhānaṃ samāpannassa vitakkavicārā vacīsaṅkhārā paṭippassaddhā honti. Catutthaṃ🔽jhānaṃ samāpannassa assāsapassāsā kāyasaṅkhārā paṭippassaddhā honti. Saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ
analyzed: dutiya jhānam samāpannassa vitakka vicārāḥ vacī saṅkhārāḥ paṭippassaddhāḥ honti catuttham  jhānam samāpannassa assāsa passāsā kāya saṅkhārā paṭippassaddhāḥ honti saññā vedayita nirodham
translated: When one has attained the second jhana, the volitional formations accompanied by applied and sustained thought have stilled in one.🔽When one has attained the fourth jhana, the volitional formations accompanied by in-breath and out-breath have stilled in one.🔽When one has attained the cessation of perception and feeling, the volitional formations of perception and feeling have stilled in one.

original: samāpannassa saññā ca vedanā ca cittasaṅkhārā paṭippassaddhā honti. Imesaṃ tiṇṇannaṃ🔽saṅkhārānaṃ paṭippassaddhiyā.
analyzed: samāpannassa saññā ca vedanā ca citta saṅkhārā paṭippassaddhāḥ honti imesam tiṇṇannam  saṅkhārānam paṭippassaddhiyā
translated: This is the stilling of these three types of volitional formations.🔽“And the sixteen bases of the awareness-release: what are the sixteen bases of the awareness-release?

original: “Soḷasahi ñāṇacariyāhīti katamāhi soḷasahi ñāṇacariyāhi? Aniccānupassanā ñāṇacariyā.
analyzed: soḷasahi ñāṇa cariyāhi iti katamāhi soḷasahi ñāṇa cariyāhi anicca anupassanā ñāṇa cariyā
translated: The contemplation of impermanence is a base of the awareness-release.

original: Dukkhā… anattā… nibbidā… virāgā… nirodhā… paṭinissaggā… vivaṭṭānupassanā ñāṇacariyā.🔽Sotāpattimaggo ñāṇacariyā. Sotāpattiphalasamāpatti ñāṇacariyā. Sakadāgāmimaggo…pe…
analyzed: dukkhāḥ anattā nibbidāḥ virāgāḥ nirodhāḥ paṭinissaggāḥ vivaṭṭā anupassanāḥ ñāṇa cariyā  sotāpatti maggaḥ ñāṇa cariyā sotāpatti phala samāpatti ñāṇa cariyā sakadāgāmi magga upe
translated: The contemplation of dispassion… the contemplation of fading away… the contemplation of cessation… the contemplation of relinquishment… the contemplation of turning away is a base of the awareness-release.

original: arahattaphalasamāpatti ñāṇacariyā. Imāhi soḷasahi ñāṇacariyāhi.
analyzed: arahatta phala samāpatti ñāṇa cariyā imāhi soḷasahi ñāṇa cariyāhi
translated: The stream-entry path is a base of the awareness-release. The attainment of the fruit of stream-entry is a base of the awareness-release. The once-return path… the attainment of the fruit of once-return… the non-return path… the attainment of the fruit of non-return… the arahant path… the attainment of the fruit of arahantship is a base of the awareness-release.🔽These are the sixteen bases of the awareness-release.

original: “Navahi samādhicariyāhīti katamāhi navahi samādhicariyāhi? Paṭhamajjhānaṃ samādhicariyā.
analyzed: navahi samādhi cariyāhi iti katamāhi navahi samādhi cariyāhi paṭhamajjhānam samādhi cariyā
translated: “Nine kinds of practice in concentration”: what are the nine kinds of practice in concentration? The first jhana is a kind of practice in concentration.

original: Dutiyajjhānaṃ…pe… nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasamāpatti samādhicariyā. Paṭhamajjhānapaṭilābhatthāya🔽vitakko ca vicāro ca pīti ca sukhañca cittekaggatā ca…pe… nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasamāpattiṃ
analyzed: dutiya jhāna pe nevasaññānāsaññāyatana samāpatti samādhi cariyā paṭhama jhāna paṭilābha tthāya  vitakko ca vicāro ca pīti ca sukham ca citta ekagga tā na ivasaññā nāsañña āyatana samāpattim
translated: The second jhana … the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception is a kind of practice in concentration. The first jhana is a kind of practice in concentration for obtaining the first jhana.🔽Thinking and exploring are applied thought and sustained thought. The first jhana is a kind of practice in concentration for obtaining the first jhana.

original: paṭilābhatthāya vitakko ca vicāro ca pīti ca sukhañca cittekaggatā ca. Imāhi navahi samādhicariyāhi.
analyzed: paṭilābha atthāya vitakko ca vicāro ca pīti ca sukham ca citta ekagga tā ca imāhi navahi samādhi cariyāhi
translated: The second jhana … the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception is a kind of practice in concentration for obtaining the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception. Thinking and exploring are applied thought and sustained thought. The base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception is a kind of practice in concentration for obtaining the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception. These are the nine kinds of practice in concentration.

original: “Vasīti pañca vasiyo – āvajjanavasī, samāpajjanavasī, adhiṭṭhānavasī, vuṭṭhānavasī,🔽paccavekkhaṇavasī. Paṭhamajjhānaṃ yatthicchakaṃ yadicchakaṃ yāvaticchakaṃ āvajjati,
analyzed: vasī iti pañca vasiyaḥ āvajjana vasī samāpajjana vasī adhiṭṭhāna vasī vuṭṭhāna vasī  paccavekkhaṇa vasī paṭhama jhānam yatthicchakam yadicchakam yāvaticchakam āvajjati
translated: “Mastery”: there are five kinds of mastery: mastery in adverting, mastery in attaining, mastery in resolving, mastery in emerging,🔽and mastery in reviewing. One adverts to the first jhana as much as one wants, as little as one wants, and however one wants.

original: āvajjanāya dandhāyitattaṃ natthīti āvajjanavasī. Paṭhamajjhānaṃ yatthicchakaṃ yadicchakaṃ
analyzed: āvajjanāya natthi iti āvajjana vasī paṭhama jhānam yatthicchakam yadicchakam
translated: There is no sluggishness in adverting. This is mastery in adverting. One attains the first jhana as much as one wants, as little as one wants, and however one wants.

original: yāvaticchakaṃ samāpajjati, samāpajjanāya dandhāyitattaṃ natthīti samāpajjanavasī…pe…
analyzed: yāvaticchakam samāpajjati samāpajjanāya na atthi iti samāpajjana vasīpe
translated: He attains whenever he wants, without trouble, without difficulty. He has mastery in attaining. …🔽He resolves, and his resolve succeeds. …

original: adhiṭṭhāti adhiṭṭhāne…pe… vuṭṭhāti vuṭṭhāne…pe… paccavekkhati paccavekkhaṇāya dandhāyitattaṃ🔽natthīti paccavekkhaṇavasī. Dutiyaṃ…pe… nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasamāpattiṃ yatthicchakaṃ🔽yadicchakaṃ yāvaticchakaṃ āvajjati …pe… paccavekkhati. Paccavekkhaṇāya dandhāyitattaṃ
analyzed: adhiṭṭhāti adhiṭṭhāna īpe vuṭṭhāti vuṭṭhāna īpe paccavekkhati paccavekkhaṇāya dandhāyi tattam  natthi iti paccavekkhaṇa vasī dutiyam pe nevasaññānāsaññāyatana samāpattim yatthicchakam  yadicchakam yāvaticchakam āvajjati pe paccavekkhati paccavekkhaṇāya dandhāyitattam
translated: He emerges whenever he wants, without trouble, without difficulty. He has mastery in emerging. …

original: natthīti paccavekkhaṇavasī. Imā pañca vasiyo”ti.
analyzed: natthi iti paccavekkhaṇa vasī imā pañca vasiyaḥ ti
translated: He reviews, and his review succeeds. He has mastery in reviewing. These are the five masteries.

original: 870. Ettha ca “soḷasahi ñāṇacariyāhī”ti ukkaṭṭhaniddeso esa. Anāgāmino pana cuddasahi
analyzed: ettha ca soḷasahi ñāṇa cariyāhi iti ukkaṭṭha niddeso esa anāgāminaḥ pana cuddasahi
translated: And here the words ‘in sixteen ways’ is a maximum statement. But a non-returner has mastery

original: ñāṇacariyāhi hoti. Yadi evaṃ sakadāgāmino dvādasahi sotāpannassa ca dasahi kiṃ na
analyzed: ñāṇa cariyāhi hoti yadi evam sakadāgāminaḥ dvādasahi sotāpannassa ca dasahi kim na
translated: in fourteen ways. If that is so, why is it not said of a once-returner in twelve ways and of a stream-enterer in ten ways?

original: hotīti? Na hoti, samādhipāribandhikassa pañca kāmaguṇikarāgassa appahīnattā. Tesaṃ
analyzed: hoti iti na hoti samādhi pāribandhikassa pañca kāmaguṇika rāgassa appahīna ttā tesam
translated: It is not said because the five lusts that are obstacles to concentration have not been abandoned by them.

original: hi so appahīno. Tasmā samathabalaṃ na paripuṇṇaṃ hoti, tasmiṃ aparipūre dvīhi balehi
analyzed: hi saḥ appahīnaḥ tasmā samatha balam na paripuṇṇam hoti tasmin a paripūre dvīhi balehi
translated: because it is not abandoned. Therefore the strength of serenity is not fulfilled. When that is unfulfilled, the two strengths of🔽

original: samāpajjitabbaṃ nirodhasamāpattiṃ balavekallena samāpajjituṃ na sakkonti. Anāgāmissa
analyzed: samāpajjitabbam nirodha samāpattim bala vekallena samāpajjitum na sakkonti anāgāmissa
translated: for that has not been abandoned by him. Therefore the power of serenity is not fulfilled in him. When that is unfulfilled, he is unable to attain the attainment of cessation, which should be attained by means of the two powers, because of deficiency in power. But it has been abandoned by the non-returner,

original: pana so pahīno, tasmā esa paripuṇṇabalo hoti. Paripuṇṇabalattā sakkoti. Tenāha bhagavā
analyzed: pana so pahīno tasmai esa paripuṇṇa balaḥ hoti paripuṇṇa bala ttā sakkoti tena āha bhagavā
translated: and therefore he has fulfilled power. And because he has fulfilled power he is able to attain it. That is why the Exalted One said:

original: – “nirodhā vuṭṭhahantassa nevasaññānāsaññāyatanakusalaṃ phalasamāpattiyā anantarapaccayena
analyzed: nirodhā vuṭṭhahantassa nevasaññānāsaññāyatana kusalam phala samāpattiyāḥ anantara paccayena
translated: “When he emerges from cessation, the profitable of the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception is a condition, as proximity condition, for the attainment of fruition” .

original: paccayo”ti. Idañhi paṭṭhāne mahāpakaraṇe anāgāminova nirodhā vuṭṭhānaṃ sandhāya vuttanti.
analyzed: paccayaḥ ti idam hi paṭṭhāne mahāpakaraṇe anāgāmino eva nirodhā vuṭṭhānam sandhāya vuttan ti
translated: For this is said in the Great Book of the Paṭṭhāna with reference to the non-returner’s emergence from cessation.

original: 871. Kattha samāpajjantīti pañcavokārabhave. Kasmā? Anupubbasamāpattisabbhāvato.
analyzed: kattha samāpajjanti iti pañcavokāra bhave kasmai anupubba samāpatti sabbhāvato
translated: Where do they attain it? In the five-constituent kind of becoming. Why? Because of the absence of the successive attainments.

original: Catuvokārabhave pana paṭhamajjhānādīnaṃ uppatti natthi. Tasmā na sakkā tattha samāpajjitunti.
analyzed: catu vokāra bhave pana paṭhamajjhāna ādīnam uppatti natthi tasmā na sakkā tattha samāpajjitun ti
translated: But in the four-constituent kind of becoming there is no arising of the first jhāna, and so on. Therefore it is impossible to attain it there.

original: Keci pana “vatthussa abhāvā”ti vadanti.
analyzed: keci pana vatthussa abhāvā ti vadanti
translated: But some say that it is because of the absence of a physical basis .

original: 872. Kasmā samāpajjantīti saṅkhārānaṃ pavattibhede ukkaṇṭhitvā diṭṭheva dhamme acittakā hutvā “nirodhaṃ nibbānaṃ patvā sukhaṃ viharissāmā”ti samāpajjanti.
analyzed: kasmā samāpajjanti iti saṅkhārānam pavatti bhede ukkaṇṭhitvā diṭṭhe iva dhamme acittakāḥ hutvā nirodham nibbānam patvā sukham viharissāma ati samāpajjanti
translated: Why do they attain it? They attain it thinking, “We shall dwell happily by attaining cessation, the unformed element, after becoming free from the occurrence of formations and after becoming free from consciousness in this very life.”

original: 873. Kathañcassā samāpajjanaṃ hotīti samathavipassanāvasena ussakkitvā katapubbakiccassa🔽nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ nirodhayato, evamassa samāpajjanaṃ hoti. Yo hi samathavaseneva
analyzed: katham ca assā samāpajjanam hoti iti samatha vipassanā vasena ussakkitvā kata pubba kiccassa  nevasaññānāsaññāyatanam nirodhayataḥ evam assa samāpajjanam hoti yaḥ hi samatha vasena iva
translated: How is its attainment? It is attained by one who has made the preliminary work his own by exerting himself in both serenity and insight.

original: ussakkati, so nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasamāpattiṃ patvā tiṭṭhati. Yo pana vipassanāvaseneva🔽ussakkati, so phalasamāpattiṃ patvā tiṭṭhati. Yo pana ubhayavaseneva ussakkitvā pubbakiccaṃ
analyzed: ussakkati so nevasaññānāsaññāyatana samāpattim patvā tiṭṭhati yaḥ pana vipassanā vasena iva  ussakkati so phala samāpattim patvā tiṭṭhati yaḥ pana ubhaya vasena iva ussakkitvā pubba kiccam
translated: For when one who has made the preliminary work his own and who exerts himself in serenity alone reaches the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception, he stops there.🔽But when one who exerts himself in insight alone reaches the fruition attainment, he stops there.

original: katvā nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ nirodheti, so taṃ samāpajjatīti ayamettha saṅkhepo.
analyzed: katvā nevasaññānāsaññāyatanam nirodheti saḥ tam samāpajjati iti ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ
translated: But when one who exerts himself in both and has made the preliminary work his own stops the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception, then he attains cessation. This is the brief treatment here.

original: 874. Ayaṃ pana vitthāro – idha bhikkhu nirodhaṃ samāpajjitukāmo katabhattakicco sudhotahatthapādo
analyzed: ayam pana vitthāraḥ idha bhikkhu nirodham samāpajjitu kāmo kata bhatta kicco su dhota hatthapādaḥ
translated: But the detailed explanation is this. Here a bhikkhu who wants to attain cessation makes his living quarters suitable, and he arranges his requisites in the way already described.🔽Then, after going to the place where he is going to attain it, he should eat only a little at the last meal of the day.

original: vivitte okāse supaññattamhi āsane nisīdati pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya🔽parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā, so paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhāya tattha saṅkhāre
analyzed: vivitte okāse su paññattamhi āsane nisīdati pallaṅkam ābhujitvā ujum kāyam paṇidhāya  parimukham satim upaṭṭhapetvā so paṭhamam jhānam samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhāya tattha saṅkhāre
translated: He sits down in a secluded place in the well-prepared seat, folds his legs crosswise, sets his body erect, and establishes mindfulness in front of him.

original: aniccato dukkhato anattato vipassati.🔽Vipassanā panesā tividhā hoti – saṅkhāraparigaṇhanakavipassanā, phalasamāpattivipassanā,
analyzed: aniccataḥ dukkhataḥ anattataḥ vipassati  vipassanā pana esā tividhā hoti saṅkhāra parigaṇhanaka vipassanā phala samāpatti vipassanā
translated: After that, he attains the first jhāna and emerges from it. Then he comprehends the formations in the first jhāna as impermanent, painful, and not-self.

original: nirodhasamāpattivipassanāti. Tattha saṅkhāraparigaṇhanakavipassanā mandā vā hotu🔽tikkhā vā, maggassa padaṭṭhānaṃ hotiyeva. Phalasamāpattivipassanā tikkhāva vaṭṭati
analyzed: nirodha samāpatti vipassanā ti tattha saṅkhāra parigaṇhanaka vipassanā mandā vā hotu  tikkhā vā maggassa padaṭṭhānam hotiyā iva phala samāpatti vipassanā tikkhā ava vaṭṭati
translated: This insight is of three kinds: insight that investigates formations, insight that attains fruition attainment, and insight that attains cessation attainment. Herein, insight that investigates formations may be either sluggish or keen.

original: maggabhāvanāsadisā. Nirodhasamāpattivipassanā pana nātimandanātitikkhā vaṭṭati. Tasmā
analyzed: magga bhāvanā sadisā nirodha samāpatti vipassanā pana na ati mandana atitikkhā vaṭṭati tasmā
translated: But insight that attains fruition attainment must be keen only, like the development of the path. And insight that attains cessation attainment must be neither sluggish nor keen.

original: esa nātimandāya nātitikkhāya vipassanāya te saṅkhāre vipassati.
analyzed: esa na ati mandāya na ati tikkhāya vipassanāya te saṅkhāre vipassati
translated: Therefore he comprehends those formations with neither sluggish nor keen insight.

original: Tato dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhāya tattha saṅkhāre tatheva vipassati. Tato
analyzed: tatas dutiyam jhānam samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhāya tattha saṅkhāre tathā iva vipassati tatas
translated: After that he attains the second jhāna and emerges from it. Then he comprehends the formations in the second jhāna as impermanent, painful, and not-self.

original: tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ…pe… tato viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhāya tattha saṅkhāre tatheva
analyzed: tatiyam jhānaṃpe tatas viññāṇañcāyatanam samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhāya tattha saṅkhāre tathā iva
translated: and the third jhana … and he emerges from the base consisting of boundless consciousness, and he sees formations there in that way.

original: vipassati. Tathā ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhāya catubbidhaṃ pubbakiccaṃ karoti
analyzed: vipassati tathā ākiñcaññāyatanam samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhāya catubbidham pubba kiccam karoti
translated: Similarly, after he has attained the base consisting of nothingness and emerged from it, he performs the fourfold preparatory task:🔽he resolves that what is not bound up with his own person shall not be disturbed;🔽he resolves that the Community shall be satisfied with the alms food;🔽he resolves that the Teacher shall be informed;

original: – nānābaddhaavikopanaṃ, saṅghapaṭimānanaṃ, satthupakkosanaṃ, addhānaparicchedanti.🔽875. Tattha nānābaddhaavikopananti yaṃ iminā bhikkhunā saddhiṃ ekābaddhaṃ na hoti,
analyzed: nānā baddha a vikopanam saṅgha paṭimānanam satthu pakkosanam addhāna paricchedam ti  tattha nānābaddha avikopanam ti yam iminā bhikkhunā saddhim ekābaddham na hoti
translated: he resolves that the boundary shall be delimited.

original: nānābaddhaṃ hutvā ṭhitaṃ pattacīvaraṃ vā mañcapīṭhaṃ vā nivāsagehaṃ vā aññaṃ vā pana🔽kiñci parikkhārajātaṃ, taṃ yathā na vikuppati, aggiudakavātacoraundūrādīnaṃ vasena
analyzed: nānābaddham hutvā ṭhitam patta cīvaram vā mañca pīṭham vā nivāsa geham vā aññam vā pana  kiñci parikkhāra jātam tam yathā na vikuppati aggi udaka vāta cora aundūra ādīnam vasena
translated: Herein, what is not bound up with his own person means his robe and bowl, his bed, chair, and dwelling, or any other requisite that is not bound up with his own person but is kept by him as stored.

original: na vinassati, evaṃ adhiṭṭhātabbaṃ.
analyzed: na vinassati evam adhiṭṭhātabbam
translated: He should resolve that it shall not be disturbed by fire, water, kings, thieves, and so on, that it shall not be lost.

original: Tatridaṃ adhiṭṭhānavidhānaṃ “idañca idañca imasmiṃ sattāhabbhantare mā agginā jhāyatu,
analyzed: tatra idam adhiṭṭhāna vidhānam idam ca idam ca imasmin satta ahar bhantare mā agginā jhāyatu
translated: Here is the method for the resolution: “Let this and this not be burnt by fire during this coming week,

original: mā udakena vuyhatu, mā vātena viddhaṃsatu, mā corehi hariyatu, mā undūrādīhi khajjatū”ti.
analyzed: mā udakena vuyhatu mā vātena mā corehi hariyatu mā undūra ādīhi khajjatu iti
translated: Let it not be carried away by water, let it not be destroyed by wind, let it not be stolen by thieves, let it not be eaten by rats and so on.’

original: Evaṃ adhiṭṭhite taṃ sattāhaṃ tassa na koci parissayo hoti.
analyzed: evam adhiṭṭhite tam sattāham tassa na koci parissayaḥ hoti
translated: When it is determined in this way, no harm befalls it for those seven days.

original: Anadhiṭṭhahato pana aggiādīhi vinassati mahānāgattherassa viya. Thero kira mātuupāsikāya
analyzed: an adhiṭṭhahataḥ pana aggi ādīhi vinassati mahānāga therassa viya thero kira mātu upāsikāya
translated: But if it is not determined, it is destroyed by fire, etc., as in the case of the Elder Mahānāga.

original: gāmaṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi. Upāsikā yāguṃ datvā āsanasālāya nisīdāpesi. Thero nirodhaṃ
analyzed: gāmam piṇḍāya upāsikā yāgum da tvā āsana sālāya theraḥ nirodham
translated: The elder, it seems, entered a village for alms. A lay devotee gave him rice gruel and had him sit down in the assembly hall. The elder sat down and entered into cessation.

original: samāpajjitvā nisīdi. Tasmiṃ nisinne āsanasālāya agginā gahitāya sesabhikkhū attano
analyzed: samāpajjitvā nisīdi tasmin nisinne āsana sālāya agginā gahitāya sesa bhikkhū attano
translated: While he was sitting there, the assembly hall caught fire. The other bhikkhus each took their own seats and fled.

original: attano nisinnāsanaṃ gahetvā palāyiṃsu. Gāmavāsikā sannipatitvā theraṃ disvā “alasasamaṇo”ti
analyzed: attanaḥ nisinnāsanam gahetvā palāyiṃsu gāmavāsikā sannipatitvā theram disvā alasa samaṇa iti
translated: The villagers gathered and said, “He is a lazy recluse.”

original: āhaṃsu. Aggi tiṇaveṇukaṭṭhāni jhāpetvā theraṃ parikkhipitvā aṭṭhāsi. Manussā ghaṭehi
analyzed: āhaṃsu aggi tiṇa veṇuka ṭṭhāni jhāpetvā theram parikkhipitvā aṭṭhāsi manussāḥ ghaṭehi
translated: The fire burned up the grass, sticks, timber, etc., and then stood still surrounding the elder. The people brought water in pots

original: udakaṃ āharitvā nibbāpetvā chārikaṃ apanetvā paribhaṇḍaṃ katvā pupphāni vikiritvā
analyzed: udakam āharitvā nibbāpetvā chārikam apanetvā paribhaṇḍam katvā pupphāni vikiritvā
translated: and extinguished the fire. They removed the ashes, made a shrine, scattered flowers,

original: namassamānā aṭṭhaṃsu. Thero paricchinnakālavasena vuṭṭhāya te disvā “pākaṭomhi jāto”ti
analyzed: namassamānāḥ aṭṭhaṃsu thero paricchinna kāla vasena vuṭṭhāya te disvā pākaṭaḥ amhi jātaḥ iti
translated: and they stood there worshipping him. When the elder had risen at the end of the period of his resolve, he saw them and thought, “I am discovered.”

original: vehāsaṃ uppatitvā piyaṅgudīpaṃ agamāsi. Idaṃ nānābaddhaavikopanaṃ nāma.
analyzed: vehāsam uppatitvā piyaṅgu dīpam agamāsi idam nānābaddhaavikopanam nāma
translated: So he rose up in the air and went to Piyaṅgu Island. This is called “non-conflicting with the various” .

original: Yaṃ ekābaddhaṃ hoti nivāsanapāvuraṇaṃ vā nisinnāsanaṃ vā, tattha visuṃ adhiṭṭhānakiccaṃ🔽natthi. Samāpattivaseneva naṃ rakkhati āyasmato sañjīvassa viya. Vuttampi cetaṃ “āyasmato
analyzed: yam eka ābaddham hoti nivāsana pāvuraṇam vā nisinna āsanam vā tattha visum adhiṭṭhāna kiccam  natthi samāpatti vasena iva nam rakkhati āyasmato sañjīvassa viya vuttam pi ca itam āyasmato
translated: When the under and upper robes are worn together or when a seat is sat upon, there is no need for a separate resolve

original: sañjīvassa samādhivipphārā iddhi, āyasmato sāriputtassa samādhivipphārā iddhī”ti.🔽876. Saṅghapaṭimānananti saṅghassa paṭimānanaṃ udikkhanaṃ. Yāva eso bhikkhu āgacchati,
analyzed: sañjīvassa samādhi vipphārāḥ iddhi āyasmataḥ sāriputtassa samādhi vipphārāḥ iddhi iti  saṅgha paṭimānanam ti saṅghassa paṭimānanam udikkhanam yāva esaḥ bhikkhu āgacchati
translated: in that case. He guards it by means of attainment, like the venerable Sañjīva. And this is said: “The venerable Sañjīva’s supernormal power is due to the change-of-lineage consciousness, the venerable Sāriputta’s is due to the path” .

original: tāva saṅghakammassa akaraṇanti attho. Ettha ca na paṭimānanaṃ etassa pubbakiccaṃ,
analyzed: tāva saṅgha kammassa akaraṇanti atthaḥ ettha ca na paṭimānanam etassa pubba kiccam
translated: The Community’s permission: the Community’s permission is the Community’s announcement. The meaning is that the Community transaction is not to be done until this bhikkhu comes. And here the permission is not the prior duty;

original: paṭimānanāvajjanaṃ pana pubbakiccaṃ. Tasmā evaṃ āvajjitabbaṃ “sace mayi sattāhaṃ
analyzed: paṭimānana āvajjanam pana pubba kiccam tasmai evam āvajjitabbam sace mayi sattāham
translated: but the adverting to the permission is the prior duty. So it should be adverted to in this way: “If I can get permission for seven days,

original: nirodhaṃ samāpajjitvā nisinne saṅgho uttikammādīsu kiñcideva kammaṃ kattukāmo hoti,
analyzed: nirodham samāpajjitvā nisinne saṅghaḥ utti kamma ādīsu kiñcid eva kammam kattu kāmo hoti
translated: If the Sangha wants to do a legal procedure such as the rehabilitation of a monk,

original: yāva maṃ koci bhikkhu āgantvā na pakkosati, tāvadeva vuṭṭhahissāmī”ti. Evaṃ katvā
analyzed: yāva mam koci bhikkhu āgantvā na pakkosati tāvat eva vuṭṭhahissāmi iti evam katvā
translated: he thinks, ‘As long as no one comes and calls me, I’ll stay in attainment.’

original: samāpanno hi tasmiṃ samaye vuṭṭhātiyeva.
analyzed: samāpannaḥ hi tasmin samaye vuṭṭhātiyā iva
translated: He then enters the attainment.

original: Yo pana evaṃ na karoti, saṅgho ca sannipatitvā taṃ apassanto “asuko bhikkhu kuhi”nti🔽“nirodhasamāpanno”ti vutte saṅgho kañci bhikkhuṃ peseti “gaccha naṃ saṅghassa vacanena🔽pakkosāhī”ti. Athassa tena bhikkhunā savanūpacāre ṭhatvā “saṅgho taṃ āvuso paṭimānetī”ti
analyzed: yaḥ pana evam na karoti saṅghaḥ ca sannipatitvā tam a passantaḥ asukaḥ bhikkhu kuhinti  nirodha samāpannaḥ ti vutte saṅghaḥ kañci bhikkhum peseti gaccha nam saṅghassa vacanena  pakkosāhi iti athassa tena bhikkhunā savana upacāre ṭhatvā saṅghaḥ tam āvuso paṭimāneti iti
translated: But if he doesn’t do this, and the Sangha gathers and doesn’t see him, they ask,🔽‘Where’s monk so-and-so?’🔽‘He’s in attainment.’ The Sangha then sends a monk, saying,🔽‘Go and call him on behalf of the Sangha.’ As soon as that monk stands within hearing and says,

original: vuttamatteva vuṭṭhānaṃ hoti. Evaṃ garukā hi saṅghassa āṇā nāma. Tasmā taṃ āvajjitvā
analyzed: vutta mattā iva vuṭṭhānam hoti evam garukā hi saṅghassa āṇā nāma tasmā tam āvajjitvā
translated: ‘Venerable, the Sangha is summoning you,’ he comes out of attainment. The command of the Sangha is weighty. Therefore he should direct his mind to that and

original: yathā sayameva vuṭṭhāti, evaṃ samāpajjitabbaṃ.
analyzed: yathā sayam eva vuṭṭhāti evam samāpajjitabbam
translated: enter the attainment in such a way that he comes out by himself.

original: 877. Satthupakkosananti idhāpi satthupakkosanāvajjanameva imassa kiccaṃ. Tasmā tampi
analyzed: satthu pakkosanan ti idha api satthu pakkosana āvajjanam eva imassa kiccam tasmā tam pi
translated: ‘Being called by the Teacher’: here too the purpose is to direct his mind to being called by the Teacher. Therefore he should

original: evaṃ āvajjitabbaṃ “sace mayi sattāhaṃ nirodhaṃ samāpajjitvā nisinne satthā otiṇṇavatthusmiṃ🔽sikkhāpadaṃ vā paññapeti, tathārūpāya vā atthuppattiyā dhammaṃ deseti, yāva maṃ koci
analyzed: evam āvajjitabbam sace mayi sattāham nirodham samāpajjitvā nisinne satthā otiṇṇa vatthusmin  sikkhāpadam vā paññapeti tathārūpāya vā atthuppattiyā dhammaṃ deseti yāva mam koci
translated: He should advert thus: “If the Teacher should pass away while I am sitting here for seven days in attainment of cessation,🔽then the Teacher will either lay down a training rule or give a Dhamma talk on some other matter, and I will not hear it.🔽

original: āgantvā na pakkosati, tāvadeva vuṭṭhahissāmī”ti. Evaṃ katvā nisinno hi tasmiṃ samaye vuṭṭhātiyeva.🔽Yo pana evaṃ na karoti, satthā ca saṅghe sannipatite taṃ apassanto “asuko bhikkhu🔽kuhi”nti “nirodhasamāpanno”ti vutte kañci bhikkhuṃ peseti “gaccha naṃ mama vacanena🔽pakkosā”ti. Athassa tena bhikkhunā savanūpacāre ṭhatvā “satthā āyasmantaṃ āmantetī”ti
analyzed: āgantvā na pakkosati tāvat eva vuṭṭhahissāmi iti evam katvā nisinnaḥ hi tasmin samaye vuṭṭhātiyā iva  yaḥ pana evam na karoti satthā ca saṅghe sannipatite tam a passantaḥ asukaḥ bhikkhu  kuhin ti nirodha samāpannaḥ ti vutte kañci bhikkhum peseti gaccha nam mama vacanena  pakkosa ati athassa tena bhikkhunā savana upacāre ṭhatvā satthā āyasmantam āmanteti iti
translated: He should advert thus: “If the Teacher, after I have been sitting in cessation for seven days, should lay down a training precept or give a Dhamma talk on some such matter as that on which I have had insight, then I shall emerge just as soon as anyone comes to tell me. But if not, I shall emerge at the end of the seven days.” For if he sits thus, he emerges at the end of the seven days.

original: vuttamatteva vuṭṭhānaṃ hoti. Evaṃ garukaṃ hi satthupakkosanaṃ, tasmā taṃ āvajjitvā🔽yathā sayameva vuṭṭhāti, evaṃ samāpajjitabbaṃ.
analyzed: vutta mattā iva vuṭṭhānam hoti evam garukam hi satthu pakkosanam tasmā tam āvajjitvā 🔽yathā sayam eva vuṭṭhāti evam samāpajjitabbam
translated: But if he does not do so, then when the Teacher, after assembling the community of bhikkhus, does not see that bhikkhu and asks, “Where is so and so?” and is told, “He has entered upon cessation,” he sends a bhikkhu, telling him, “Go and tell him that I want him to emerge.” Then his emergence takes place the moment he hears the sound of the message being brought to him while he is still in cessation. So weighty is the Teacher’s summons. That is why he should attain in such a way that he emerges by himself.

original: 878. Addhānaparicchedoti jīvitaddhānassa paricchedo. Iminā bhikkhunā addhānaparicchede
analyzed: addhāna paricchedo ti jīvita ddhānassa paricchedaḥ iminā bhikkhunā addhāna paricchede
translated: The delimitation of the life span: the delimitation of the life span is the delimitation of the life faculty.🔽This bhikkhu should be very skilled in the delimitation of the life span.

original: sukusalena bhavitabbaṃ. Attano “āyusaṅkhārā sattāhaṃ pavattissanti na pavattissantī”ti🔽āvajjitvāva samāpajjitabbaṃ. Sace hi sattāhabbhantare nirujjhanake āyusaṅkhāre anāvajjitvāva🔽samāpajjati, nāssa nirodhasamāpatti maraṇaṃ paṭibāhituṃ sakkoti. Antonirodhe maraṇassa
analyzed: su kusalena bhavitabbam attanaḥ āyu saṅkhārā sattāham pavattissanti na pavattissanti iti  āvajjitvā ava samāpajjitabbam sace hi satta ahabbhantare nirujjhanake āyu saṅkhāre an āvajjitvā ava  samāpajjati na assa nirodha samāpatti maraṇam paṭibāhitum sakkoti antar nirodhe maraṇassa
translated: He should advert to his own life formation thus, “Will it continue for seven days or not?”🔽and then attain Nibbāna. For if he attains Nibbāna without adverting to the life formation that will cease within seven days, he is unable to prevent his attainment of Nibbāna from being death.🔽Because there is no death in the actual Nibbāna, he emerges from the attainment and then attains it again.

original: natthitāya antarāva samāpattito vuṭṭhāti. Tasmā etaṃ āvajjitvāva samāpajjitabbaṃ.
analyzed: na atthitāya antarā ava samāpattitaḥ vuṭṭhāti tasmai etam āvajjitvā ava samāpajjitabbam
translated: That is why it is said that he should advert to it and then attain Nibbāna.

original: Avasesaṃ hi anāvajjitumpi vaṭṭati. Idaṃ pana āvajjitabbamevāti vuttaṃ.🔽879. So evaṃ ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhāya imaṃ pubbakiccaṃ katvā nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ
analyzed: avasesam hi an āvajjitum pi vaṭṭati idam pana āvajjitabbam eva ati vuttam  saḥ evam ākiñcaññāyatanam samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhāya imam pubba kiccam katvā nevasaññānāsaññāyatanam
translated: For the rest it is allowable not to advert, but this is said to be what should be adverted to.🔽Having thus attained the base consisting of nothingness and emerged from it, he performs the preliminary work and then attains the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception.

original: samāpajjati. Athekaṃ vā dve vā cittavāre atikkamitvā acittako hoti, nirodhaṃ phusati.
analyzed: samāpajjati atha ekam vā dve vā citta vāre atikkamitvā acittakaḥ hoti nirodham phusati
translated: After traversing one or two consciousnesses he becomes without consciousness and contacts cessation.

original: Kasmā panassa dvinnaṃ cittānaṃ uparicittāni na pavattantīti? Nirodhassa payogattā.
analyzed: kasmā pana assa dvinnam cittānam upari cittāni na pavattanti iti nirodhassa payoga ttā
translated: But why do no other consciousnesses occur after the two? Because it is the means to cessation.

original: Idañhi imassa bhikkhuno dve samathavipassanādhamme yuganaddhe katvā aṭṭha samāpattiārohanaṃ
analyzed: idam hi imassa bhikkhuno dve samatha vipassanā dhamme yuga naddhe katvā aṭṭha samāpatti ārohanaṃ
translated: For this bhikkhu’s ascending the eight attainments by yoking the two things, serenity and insight, together is a means to successive cessation,

original: anupubbanirodhassa payogo, na nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasamāpattiyāti nirodhassa payogattā
analyzed: anupubba nirodhassa payogaḥ na na ivasaññānāsaññāyatana samāpattiyā ati nirodhassa payoga ttā
translated: not to the attainment of the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception. So because it is the means to cessation,

original: dvinnaṃ cittānaṃ upari na pavattanti.
analyzed: dvinnam cittānam upari na pavattanti
translated: no other consciousnesses occur after the two.

original: Yo pana bhikkhu ākiñcaññāyatanato vuṭṭhāya idaṃ pubbakiccaṃ akatvā nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ🔽samāpajjati, so parato acittako bhavituṃ na sakkoti, paṭinivattitvā puna ākiñcaññāyataneyeva
analyzed: yaḥ pana bhikkhu ākiñcaññāyatanataḥ vuṭṭhāya idam pubba kiccam a katvā nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ  samāpajjati saḥ paratas acittakaḥ bhavitum na sakkoti paṭinivattitvā punar ākiñcaññāyataneya iva
translated: But if a bhikkhu emerges from the base consisting of nothingness and enters upon the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception without doing this preliminary work,

original: patiṭṭhāti. Maggaṃ agatapubbapurisūpamā cettha vattabbā –
analyzed: patiṭṭhāti maggam a gata pubba purisa upamā ca ittha vattabbā
translated: he is unable to be without consciousness beyond that. He turns back and establishes himself in the base consisting of nothingness again. The simile here is that of the man who has not travelled a road before.

original: Eko kira puriso ekaṃ maggaṃ agatapubbo antarā udakakandaraṃ vā gambhīraṃ udakacikkhallaṃ
analyzed: ekaḥ kira purisaḥ ekam maggam a gata pubbaḥ antarā udaka kandaram vā gambhīram udaka cikkhallam
translated: It is said that a man who had not travelled a certain road before came to a deep pool of water with no ford.

original: atikkamitvā ṭhapitaṃ caṇḍātapasantattapāsāṇaṃ vā āgamma taṃ nivāsanapāvuraṇaṃ asaṇṭhapetvāva🔽kandaraṃ orūḷho parikkhāratemanabhayena punadeva tīre patiṭṭhāti. Pāsāṇaṃ akkamitvāpi🔽santattapādo punadeva orabhāge patiṭṭhāti. Tattha yathā so puriso asaṇṭhapitanivāsanapāvuraṇattā

translated: and he climbs down the cliff without putting on his under robe and upper robe,

original: karitvā parato gacchati, evamevaṃ katapubbakicco bhikkhu nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ
analyzed: karitvā paratas gacchati evam evam kata pubba kiccaḥ bhikkhu nevasaññānāsaññāyatanam
translated: and having done so, he goes away. So too, a bhikkhu who has done his task enters upon and dwells in the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.

original: samāpajjitvāva parato acittako hutvā nirodhaṃ phusitvā viharati.
analyzed: samāpajjitvā ava paratas acittakaḥ hutvā nirodham phusitvā viharati
translated: Just as the man who has gone to the other side of the river and is standing there does not go there again, so too, when the bhikkhu has attained the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception and has emerged from it, his consciousness does not incline to that attainment, does not lean on that, does not adhere to it.

original: 880. Kathaṃ ṭhānanti evaṃ samāpannāya panassā kālaparicchedavasena ceva antarāāyukkhayasaṅghapaṭimānanasatthupakkosanābhāvena ca ṭhānaṃ hoti.
analyzed: katham ṭhānam ti evam samāpannāya panassā kāla pariccheda vasena ca iva ca ṭhānam hoti
translated: . How does he maintain it? When he has attained it in this way, his maintenance of it is by delimiting the duration of the attainment and by not allowing the life span to end through forgetting the motion and through not honouring the Teacher’s dwelling.

original: 881. Kathaṃ vuṭṭhānanti anāgāmissa anāgāmiphaluppattiyā, arahato arahattaphaluppattiyāti evaṃ dvedhā vuṭṭhānaṃ hoti.🔽882. Vuṭṭhitassa kiṃninnaṃ cittaṃ hotīti nibbānaninnaṃ. Vuttaṃ hetaṃ “saññāvedayitanirodhasamāpattiyā
analyzed: katham vuṭṭhānam ti anāgāmissa anāgāmi phala uppattiyā arahataḥ arahatta phala uppattiyā ati evam dvedhā vuṭṭhānam hoti  vuṭṭhitassa kiṃninnam cittam hoti iti nibbāna ninnam vuttam ha etam saññā vedayita nirodha samāpattiyā
translated: . How does he emerge? When he has attained it, he emerges in two ways: by attaining the fruition of non-return and by attaining the fruition of Arahantship.

original: vuṭṭhitassa kho, āvuso visākha, bhikkhuno vivekaninnaṃ cittaṃ hoti vivekapoṇaṃ vivekapabbhāra”nti.
analyzed: vuṭṭhitassa kho āvuso visākha bhikkhuno viveka ninnam cittam hoti viveka poṇam viveka pabbhāram ti
translated: . To what does his mind tend? It tends to Nibbāna, for this is said: “When a bhikkhu emerges from cessation, friends, his mind tends to seclusion, inclines to seclusion, is bent on seclusion” .

original: 883. Matassa ca samāpannassa ca ko visesoti ayampi attho sutte vuttoyeva. Yathāha
analyzed: matassa ca samāpannassa ca kaḥ visesaḥ ti ayam pi atthaḥ sutte vuttaḥ yā iva yathā āha
translated: . What is the difference between one who has attained and one who is dead? This too is stated in the texts. For it is said:

original: – “yvāyaṃ, āvuso, mato kālaṅkato, tassa kāyasaṅkhārā niruddhā paṭippassaddhā, vacīsaṅkhārā…
analyzed: yvā ayam āvuso mataḥ kālaṅkato tassa kāya saṅkhārāḥ niruddhā paṭippassaddhāḥ vacī saṅkhārā
translated: “The bodily formations of the one who has died and passed away have ceased and are calmed down. The verbal formations …

original: cittasaṅkhārā niruddhā paṭippassaddhā, āyu parikkhīṇo, usmā vūpasantā, indriyāni🔽paribhinnāni. Yo cāyaṃ bhikkhu saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpanno, tassapi kāyasaṅkhārā🔽niruddhā paṭippassaddhā, vacīsaṅkhārā… cittasaṅkhārā niruddhā paṭippassaddhā, āyu
analyzed: citta saṅkhārāḥ niruddhā paṭippassaddhā āyu parikkhīṇaḥ usmā vūpasantā indriyāni  paribhinnāni yaḥ ca ayam bhikkhu saññā vedayita nirodham samāpannaḥ tassa api kāya saṅkhārā  niruddhā paṭippassaddhā vacī saṅkhārā citta saṅkhārā niruddhā paṭippassaddhā āyu
translated: “The bodily processes, friend, of the one who has died and passed away have ceased and subsided, the verbal processes … the mental processes have ceased and subsided, his life is ended, his heat has subsided, and his faculties are broken up and changed.

original: aparikkhīṇo, usmā avūpasantā, indriyāni aparibhinnānī”ti.
analyzed: a parikkhīṇaḥ usmā a vūpasantā indriyāni a paribhinnāni iti
translated: But in the case of the bhikkhu attained to the cessation of perception and feeling, his bodily processes … his verbal processes … his mental processes have ceased and subsided, but his life is not ended, his heat has not subsided, and his faculties are not broken up and changed.”

original: 884. Nirodhasamāpatti saṅkhatātiādipucchāyaṃ pana saṅkhatātipi asaṅkhatātipi lokiyātipi🔽lokuttarātipi na vattabbā. Kasmā? Sabhāvato natthitāya. Yasmā panassā samāpajjantassa
analyzed: nirodha samāpatti pana  na vattabbā kasmā sabhāvataḥ na thitāya yasmā pana assā samāpajjantassa
translated: As regards the question, “Is the attainment of cessation formed or unformed, mundane or supramundane? “ it should be said that it is not formed or unformed, not mundane or supramundane.

original: vasena samāpannā nāma hoti, tasmā nipphannāti vattuṃ vaṭṭati, no anipphannā.
analyzed: vasena samāpannā nāma hoti tasmā nipphannā ati vattum vaṭṭati no a nipphannā
translated: Why? Because it does not exist in actuality. But since it is attained by one who is entering upon it, it is proper to say that it is “produced,” not that it is “unproduced.”

original: Iti santaṃ samāpattiṃ, imaṃ ariyanisevitaṃ;
analyzed: iti santam samāpattim imam ariya nisevitam
translated: So this attainment, which is peaceful, And frequented by noble ones,

original: Diṭṭheva dhamme nibbānamitisaṅkhaṃ upāgataṃ;
analyzed: diṭṭhe iva dhamme nibbānam iti saṅkham upāgatam
translated: And in this very life he has attained extinction, so called.

original: Bhāvetvā ariyaṃ paññaṃ, samāpajjanti paṇḍitā.
analyzed: bhāvetvā ariyam paññam samāpajjanti paṇḍitā
translated: The wise attain it by developing noble understanding.

original: Yasmā tasmā imissāpi, samāpattisamatthatā;
analyzed: yasmai tasmai imissā api samāpatti samattha tā
translated: Therefore this ability to attain the attainment

original: Ariyamaggesu paññāya, ānisaṃsoti vuccatīti.
analyzed: ariya maggesu paññāya ānisaṃso ti vuccati iti
translated: Is said to be the benefit of understanding in the noble paths.

original: Āhuneyyabhāvādisiddhikathā
analyzed: āhuneyī abhāva ādi siddhi kathā
translated: The discussion of the benefits of being an object of offerings, etc.

original: 885. Āhuneyyabhāvādisiddhīti na kevalañca nirodhasamāpattiyā samāpajjanasamatthatāva,
analyzed: āhuneyya bhāva ādi siddhi iti na kevalam ca nirodha samāpattiyā
translated: And not only the ability to attain the attainment of cessation is a benefit of this development of supramundane understanding;

original: ayaṃ pana āhuneyyabhāvādisiddhipi imissā lokuttarapaññābhāvanāya ānisaṃsoti veditabbo.
analyzed: ayam pana imissā lokuttara paññā bhāvanāya ānisaṃso ti veditabbo
translated: but also the benefits consisting in being an object of offerings, etc., should be understood as a benefit of this development of supramundane understanding.

original: Avisesena hi catubbidhāyapi etissā bhāvitattā bhāvitapañño puggalo sadevakassa lokassa
analyzed: avisesena hi etissā bhāvita ttā bhāvita pañño puggalo sa devakassa lokassa
translated: For when anyone has developed this understanding of four kinds without distinction, he is a person of developed understanding.🔽He is an object of offerings, etc., in the world with its deities,

original: āhuneyyo hoti pāhuneyyo dakkhiṇeyyo añjalīkaraṇīyo anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassa.
analyzed: āhuneyyaḥ hoti pāhuneyyaḥ dakkhiṇeyyaḥ añjalīkaraṇīyaḥ anuttaram puññakkhettam lokassa
translated: he is the world’s most worthy recipient.

original: 886. Visesato panettha paṭhamamaggapaññaṃ tāva bhāvetvā mandāya vipassanāya āgato
analyzed: visesataḥ pana ittha paṭhama magga paññam tāva bhāvetvā mandāya vipassanāya āgataḥ
translated: But in particular, firstly, when he has developed the understanding that is the path of stream-entry,

original: mudindriyopi sattakkhattuparamo nāma hoti, sattasugatibhave saṃsaritvā dukkhassantaṃ🔽karoti. Majjhimāya vipassanāya āgato majjhimindriyo kolaṃkolo nāma hoti, dve vā tīṇi🔽vā kulāni sandhāvitvā saṃsaritvā dukkhassantaṃ karoti. Tikkhāya vipassanāya āgato
analyzed: mud indriyaḥ api sattakkhattuparamaḥ nāma hoti satta sugati bhave saṃsaritvā  karoti majjhimāya vipassanāya āgataḥ majjhima indriyaḥ kolaṃkolaḥ nāma hoti dve vā tīṇi  vā kulāni sandhāvitvā saṃsaritvā dukkhassantam karoti tikkhāya vipassanāya āgataḥ
translated: and he is called “one who has seven rebirths at most,” who, after wandering among deities and human beings for seven times,🔽makes an end of suffering. One who has come by means of medium insight is of medium faculties and is called “one who goes from family to family.” He makes an end of suffering after wandering among deities and human beings for two or three times. One who has come by means of keen insight is of keen faculties and is called “one who attains Nibbāna in the interval.” He makes an end of suffering in that very life.

original: tikkhindriyo ekabījī nāma hoti, ekaññeva mānusakaṃ bhavaṃ nibbattetvā dukkhassantaṃ karoti.
analyzed: tikkha indriyaḥ ekabījī nāma hoti ekaññā iva mānusakam bhavam nibbattetvā dukkhassa antam karoti
translated: One of medium faculties who has reached insight by the medium way is called a “one who goes from family to family.” He transmigrates among two or three families and makes an end of suffering. One of keen faculties who has reached insight by the keen way is called a “one who attains final knowledge after one birth.” He is reborn only once more in the human world and makes an end of suffering.

original: 887. Dutiyamaggapaññaṃ bhāvetvā sakadāgāmī nāma hoti, sakideva imaṃ lokaṃ āgantvā dukkhassantaṃ karoti.🔽888. Tatiyamaggapaññaṃ bhāvetvā anāgāmī nāma hoti. So indriyavemattatāvasena antarāparinibbāyī,
analyzed: dutiya magga paññam bhāvetvā sakadāgāmī nāma hoti sakideva imam lokam āgantvā dukkhassantam karoti  tatiya magga paññam bhāvetvā anāgāmī nāma hoti saḥ indriya vematta tā vasena antarā parinibbāyī
translated: One who develops the path knowledge of the second path is called a “once-returner.” He returns to this world only one more time and makes an end of suffering.

original: upahaccaparinibbāyī, asaṅkhāraparinibbāyī, sasaṅkhāraparinibbāyī, uddhaṃsoto akaniṭṭhagāmīti
analyzed: upahacca parinibbāyī asaṅkhāra parinibbāyī sa saṅkhāra parinibbāyī uddhaṃsotaḥ akaniṭṭha gāmī iti
translated: One who develops the path knowledge of the third path is called a “non-returner.” According to the difference in his faculties, he is of six kinds: one who attains final knowledge early in this life, one who attains final knowledge late in this life, one who attains final knowledge by striving, one who attains final knowledge without striving, one who goes upstream to the Pure Abodes, and one who goes upstream to the highest gods.

original: pañcadhā. Idha vihāyaniṭṭho hoti. Tattha antarāparinibbāyīti yattha katthaci suddhāvāsabhave🔽upapajjitvā āyuvemajjhaṃ appatvāva parinibbāyati. Upahaccaparinibbāyīti āyuvemajjhaṃ
analyzed: pañcadhā idha hoti tattha antarā parinibbāyī iti yattha katthaci suddhāvāsa bhave  upapajjitvā āyu vemajjham ap patvā ava parinibbāyati upahacca parinibbāyī iti āyu vemajjham
translated: It is fivefold. One who is intent on the here and now is one who attains Nibbāna in the intermediate state, wherever he is reborn in the Pure Abodes.

original: atikkamitvā parinibbāyati. Asaṅkhāraparinibbāyīti asaṅkhārena appayogena uparimaggaṃ🔽nibbatteti. Sasaṅkhāraparinibbāyīti sasaṅkhārena sappayogena uparimaggaṃ nibbatteti.🔽Uddhaṃsoto akaniṭṭhagāmīti yatthupapanno, tato uddhaṃ yāva akaniṭṭhabhavā āruyha
analyzed: atikkamitvā parinibbāyati a saṅkhāra parinibbāyī iti asaṅkhārena appayogena upari maggam  nibbattā iti sa saṅkhāra parinibbāyī iti sa saṅkhārena sa payogena upari maggam nibbattā iti  uddhaṃsotaḥ akaniṭṭha gāmī iti tatas uddham yāva akaniṭṭha bhavāḥ āruyha
translated: One who attains Nibbāna without exertion is one who attains Nibbāna without exertion after passing beyond the middle of his life span. One who attains Nibbāna with exertion is one who attains Nibbāna with exertion after passing beyond the middle of his life span.🔽One who goes upstream is one who, after being reborn in the highest Pure Abodes, attains Nibbāna there.

original: tattha parinibbāyati.🔽889. Catutthamaggapaññaṃ bhāvetvā koci saddhāvimutto hoti, koci paññāvimutto hoti,
analyzed: tattha parinibbāyati  catuttha magga paññam bhāvetvā koci saddhā vimuttaḥ hoti koci paññā vimuttaḥ hoti
translated: One who is liberated by faith is one who, after developing understanding, becomes a faith-liberated one. One who is liberated by understanding is one who, after developing concentration, becomes a Dhamma-follower.

original: koci ubhatobhāgavimutto hoti, koci tevijjo, koci chaḷabhiñño, koci paṭisambhidappabhedappatto
analyzed: koci ubhatobhāga vimuttaḥ hoti koci tevijjaḥ koci chaḍabhiñño koci paṭisambhida pabheda ppatto
translated: One who is both-ways liberated is one who, after developing understanding, becomes a Dhamma-follower. One who has the threefold knowledge is one who, after developing concentration, becomes a body-witness. One who has the six kinds of direct-knowledge is one who, after developing understanding, becomes a Dhamma-follower.

original: mahākhīṇāsavo. Yaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ “maggakkhaṇe panesa taṃ jaṭaṃ vijaṭeti nāma. Phalakkhaṇe
analyzed: mahā khīṇāsavaḥ yam sandhāya vuttam magga kkhaṇe pana esa tam jaṭam vijaṭā iti nāma phala kkhaṇe
translated: He is a great destroyer of cankers. It is of him that it is said: “At the moment of the path he disentangles the tangle.

original: vijaṭitajaṭo sadevakassa lokassa aggadakkhiṇeyyo hotī”ti.
analyzed: vijaṭita jaṭaḥ sa devakassa lokassa aggadakkhiṇeyyaḥ hoti iti
translated: At the moment of fruition he is one who has disentangled the tangle and is worthy of the highest offerings in the world with its deities” .

original: Evaṃ anekānisaṃsā, ariyapaññāya bhāvanā;
analyzed: evam aneka anisaṃsā ariya paññāya bhāvanā
translated: So, with many benefits, Ariyan understanding’s kept in being;

original: Yasmā tasmā kareyyātha, ratiṃ tattha vicakkhaṇo.
analyzed: yasmai tasmai kareyyātha ratim tattha vicakkhaṇo
translated: Therefore, with insight, you should take delight In keeping it in being.

original: 890. Ettāvatā ca –
analyzed: ettāvatā ca
translated: And in so far as this is so,

original: Sīle patiṭṭhāya naro sapañño, cittaṃ paññañca bhāvayaṃ;
analyzed: sīle patiṭṭhāya naro sa pañño cittam paññam ca bhāvayaṃ
translated: The man of wit who on virtue stands fast, Develops consciousness and understanding,

original: Ātāpī nipako bhikkhu, so imaṃ vijaṭaye jaṭanti. –
analyzed: ātāpī nipakaḥ bhikkhu saḥ imam vijaṭaye jaṭanti
translated: The ardent watchful bhikkhu, he will disentangle This tangle hard to disentangle.

original: Imissā gāthāya sīlasamādhipaññāmukhena desite visuddhimagge sānisaṃsā paññābhāvanā paridīpitā hotīti.
analyzed: imissā gāthāya sīla samādhi paññā mukhena desite visuddhi magge sa anisaṃsā paññā bhāvanā paridīpitā hoti iti
translated: So in this stanza the development of understanding with its benefits is demonstrated in the Path of Purification taught under the headings of virtue, concentration, and understanding.🔽In the Path of Purification

original: Iti sādhujanapāmojjatthāya kate visuddhimagge🔽Paññābhāvanādhikāre
analyzed: iti sādhu jana pāmojjatthāya kate visuddhi magge  paññā bhāvanā adhikāre
translated: Compiled for the purpose of gladdening good people🔽In the chapter on the development of understanding

original: Paññābhāvanānisaṃsaniddeso nāma
translated: Called the demonstration of the benefits of the development of understanding

original: Tevīsatimo paricchedo.
analyzed: tevīsatimaḥ paricchedaḥ
translated: The twenty-third chapter

original: Nigamanakathā
analyzed: nigamana kathā
translated: The summing-up

original: 891. Ettāvatā ca –
analyzed: ettāvatā ca
translated: And in so far as this is so,

original: “Sīle patiṭṭhāya naro sapañño, cittaṃ paññañca bhāvayaṃ;
analyzed: sīle patiṭṭhāya naro sa pañño cittam paññam ca bhāvayaṃ
translated: The man of wit who on virtue stands fast, Develops consciousness and understanding,

original: Ātāpī nipako bhikkhu, so imaṃ vijaṭaye jaṭa”nti. –
analyzed: ātāpī nipakaḥ bhikkhu saḥ imam vijaṭaye jaṭanti
translated: A bhikkhu ardent and sagacious Can disentangle this tangle.”

original: Imaṃ gāthaṃ nikkhipitvā yadavocumha –
analyzed: imam gātham nikkhipitvā yat avocumha
translated: When we said “Having uttered this stanza,”

original: “Imissā dāni gāthāya, kathitāya mahesinā;
analyzed: imissā dāni gāthāya kathitāya mahesinā
translated: “Now when this stanza was uttered By the Great Sage,

original: Vaṇṇayanto yathābhūtaṃ, atthaṃ sīlādibhedanaṃ.
analyzed: vaṇṇayantaḥ yathābhūtam attham sīla ādi bhedanam
translated: Expounding the meaning of virtue, etc., in accordance with truth,

original: “Sudullabhaṃ labhitvāna, pabbajjaṃ jinasāsane;
analyzed: su dullabham labhitvāna pabbajjam jina sāsane
translated: “Having obtained the going forth In the Dispensation of the Conqueror, so hard to obtain,

original: Sīlādisaṅgahaṃ khemaṃ, ujuṃ maggaṃ visuddhiyā.
analyzed: sīla ādi saṅgaham khemam ujum maggam visuddhiyā
translated: The virtue, etc., that is the safeguard, The straight path to purification,

original: “Yathābhūtaṃ ajānantā, suddhikāmāpi ye idha;
analyzed: yathābhūtam a jānantā suddhi kāmā api ye
translated: “Those who do not know the truth, Though they desire purification here,

original: Visuddhiṃ nādhigacchanti, vāyamantāpi yogino.
analyzed: visuddhim na adhigacchanti yoginaḥ
translated: Do not attain purification, Though they strive, the yogis do.

original: “Tesaṃ pāmojjakaraṇaṃ, suvisuddhavinicchayaṃ;🔽Mahāvihāravāsīnaṃ, desanānayanissitaṃ.🔽“Visuddhimaggaṃ bhāsissaṃ, taṃ me sakkacca bhāsato;
analyzed: tesam pāmojja karaṇam su visuddha vinicchayam  mahā vihāra vāsīnam desanā naya nissitam  visuddhi maggam bhāsissam tam me sakkacca bhāsataḥ
translated: “To give them delight, and because The true interpretation is well purified,🔽I will expound the Path of Purification, Which is based on the Teacher’s Dispensation,

original: Visuddhikāmā sabbepi, nisāmayatha sādhavo”ti.
analyzed: visuddhi kāmā sabbe pi nisāmayatha sādhavaḥ ti
translated: “I will expound the Path of Purification, So listen with undivided attention, All you who long for purity.”

original: Svāyaṃ bhāsito hoti.
analyzed: svāyam bhāsitaḥ ha iti
translated: This has been expounded.

original: 892. Tattha ca –
analyzed: tattha ca
translated: And here

original: Tesaṃ sīlādibhedānaṃ, atthānaṃ yo vinicchayo;
analyzed: tesam sīla ādi bhedānam atthānam yaḥ vinicchayaḥ
translated: The interpretation of the meaning Of virtue, etc., in its several aspects

original: Pañcannampi nikāyānaṃ, vutto aṭṭhakathānaye.
analyzed: pañcannam pi nikāyānam vuttaḥ aṭṭhakathā naye
translated: Is given in the commentaries On all the five Nikāyas.

original: Samāharitvā taṃ sabbaṃ, yebhuyyena sanicchayo;
analyzed: samāharitvā tam sabbam yebhuyyena
translated: Having collected all that, he has mostly arranged it,

original: Sabbasaṅkaradosehi, mutto yasmā pakāsito.
analyzed: sabba saṅkara dosehi muttaḥ yasmā pakāsito
translated: Since he has been released from all the faults of confusion, he has been revealed.

original: Tasmā visuddhikāmehi, suddhapaññehi yogihi;
analyzed: tasmai visuddhi kāmehi suddha paññehi yogihi
translated: Therefore, those who desire purity, those who are pure in wisdom,

original: Visuddhimagge etasmiṃ, karaṇīyova ādaroti.🔽Vibhajjavādiseṭṭhānaṃ, theriyānaṃ yasassinaṃ;
analyzed: visuddhi magge etasmin karaṇīyaḥ uva ādaroti  theriyānam yasassinam
translated: In this Path of Purification, they should make an effort.🔽The most excellent of the Vibhajjavādins, the famous Elders,

original: Mahāvihāravāsīnaṃ, vaṃsajassa vibhāvino.
analyzed: mahā vihāra vāsīnam vaṃsajassa vibhāvino
translated: The residents of the Great Monastery, the expounders of the lineage,

original: Bhadantasaṅghapālassa, sucisallekhavuttino;
analyzed: bhadanta saṅghapālassa suci sallekha vuttino
translated: The venerable Saṅghapāla, who lived with pure and excellent conduct,

original: Vinayācārayuttassa, yuttassa paṭipattiyaṃ.
analyzed: vinaya ācāra yuttassa yuttassa paṭipattiyam
translated: Who was skilled in the Vinaya, who was skilled in practice,

original: Khantisoraccamettādi-guṇabhūsitacetaso;
analyzed: khanti soracca mettā ādi guṇa bhūsita cetasaḥ
translated: Whose mind was adorned with the qualities of patience, gentleness, loving kindness, and so on,

original: Ajjhesanaṃ gahetvāna, karontena imaṃ mayā.🔽Saddhammaṭṭhitikāmena, yo patto puññasañcayo;
analyzed: ajjhesanam gahetvāna karontena imam mayā  saddhamma ṭṭhiti kāmena yaḥ patto puñña sañcayaḥ
translated: Having accepted the request, this was composed by me.🔽By the power of the accumulation of merit that has been obtained by one who desires the establishment of the true Dhamma,

original: Tassa tejena sabbepi, sukhamedhantu pāṇino.
analyzed: tassa tejena sabbe api sukham edhantu pāṇinaḥ
translated: May all living beings be happy.

original: Visuddhimaggo eso ca, antarāyaṃ vinā idha;
analyzed: visuddhi maggo esaḥ ca antarāyam vinā idha
translated: And this Path of Purification, without hindrance here,

original: Niṭṭhito aṭṭhapaññāsa-bhāṇavārāya pāḷiyā.
analyzed: niṭṭhitaḥ aṭṭha paññāsa bhāṇa vārāya pāḷiyā
translated: Has been completed in the text of eighty-five recitation sections.

original: Yathā tatheva lokassa, sabbe kalyāṇanissitā;
analyzed: yathā tathā iva lokassa sabbe kalyāṇa nissitā
translated: Just as it is, may all the good things in the world

original: Anantarāyā ijjhantu, sīghaṃ sīghaṃ manorathāti.
analyzed: anantarāyāḥ sīgham sīgham
translated: May they be quickly fulfilled, quickly, quickly, as I wish.

original: 895. Parama visuddha saddhā buddhi vīriya paṭimaṇḍitena sīlācārajjava maddavādiguṇasamudayasamuditena
analyzed: parama visuddha saddhā buddhi vīriya paṭimaṇḍitena
translated: By one who is adorned with the most pure faith, understanding, and energy, who is endowed with the aggregate of virtues such as virtue, conduct, swiftness, gentleness, etc.,

original: sakasamaya samayantaragahanajjhogāhaṇasamatthena paññāveyyattiyasamannāgatena tipiṭakapariyattibhede
analyzed: saka samaya samaya antara gahana ajjhogāhaṇa samatthena paññā veyyattiya samannāgatena ti piṭaka pariyatti bhede
translated: who is capable of penetrating the depths of his own and others’ doctrines, who is endowed with the fullness of understanding, who is unhindered in the knowledge of the nine-factored Tipiṭaka,

original: sāṭṭhakathe satthusāsane appaṭihatañāṇappabhāvena mahāveyyākaraṇena karaṇasampattijanitasukhaviniggatamadhurodāravacanalāvaṇṇayuttena
analyzed: sa aṭṭhakathe satthu sāsane appaṭihata ñāṇa ppabhāvena mahā veyyākaraṇena karaṇa sampatti janita sukha viniggata madhura udāra vacana lāvaṇṇa yuttena
translated: which is the doctrine of the Master, who is a great expounder, who is endowed with a voice that is sweet and sonorous, being free from the suffering born of the imperfection of speech,

original: yuttamuttavādinā vādīvarena mahākavinā chaḷabhiññāpaṭisambhidādi bhedaguṇapaṭimaṇḍite
analyzed: yutta mutta vādinā vādīvarena mahā kavinā chaṣ abhiññā paṭisambhidā ādi bheda guṇa paṭimaṇḍite
translated: who is a great poet, a master of speech, who is adorned with the special qualities such as the six kinds of direct knowledge, the discriminations, etc.,

original: uttarimanussadhamme appaṭihatabuddhīnaṃ theravaṃsappadīpānaṃ therānaṃ mahāvihāravāsīnaṃ🔽vaṃsālaṅkārabhūtena vipulavisuddhabuddhinā buddhaghosoti garūhi gahitanāmadheyyena
analyzed: uttari manussa dhamme appaṭihata buddhīnam thera vaṃsa ppadīpānam therānam mahāvihāra vāsīnam  vaṃsa alaṅkāra bhūtena vipula visuddha buddhinā buddha ghosaḥ iti garūhi gahita nāmadheyyena
translated: who is unhindered in the knowledge of the supramundane states, who is a light unto the lineage of elders, who is a resident of the Great Monastery,🔽who is an ornament of the lineage, who is of pure and vast understanding, who is called by the name Buddhaghosa,

original: therena mudantakhedakavattabbena kato visuddhimaggo nāma.
analyzed: therena mudantakhedaka vattabbena kataḥ visuddhimaggaḥ nāma
translated: who is a joyous worker, by the elder Buddhaghosa was composed this work called The Path of Purification.

original: Tāva tiṭṭhatu lokasmiṃ, lokanittharaṇesinaṃ;
analyzed: tāva tiṭṭhatu lokasmim loka nittharaṇa īsinam
translated: Let it remain in the world as long as the world endures,

original: Dassento kulaputtānaṃ, nayaṃ sīlādisuddhiyā.
analyzed: dassento kula puttānam nayam sīla ādi suddhiyā
translated: Showing the way to purity in virtue and the rest to those who are well-born.

original: Yāva buddhoti nāmampi, suddhacittassa tādino;
analyzed: yāva buddhaḥ ti nāmam pi suddhacittassa tādinaḥ
translated: And let the name “Buddha” also remain as long as the world endures,

original: Lokamhi lokajeṭṭhassa, pavattati mahesinoti.
analyzed: lokamhi loka jeṭṭhassa pavattati mahesino ti
translated: For the world’s chief, the Great Seer, who is pure in heart.

original: Iti sādhujanapāmojjatthāya katā visuddhimaggakathā,
analyzed: iti katā visuddhi magga kathā
translated: Thus this commentary on the Path of Purification, which was composed for the purpose of gladdening the heart of good people,

original: Pāḷigaṇanāya pana sā aṭṭhapaññāsabhāṇavārā hotīti.
analyzed: pāḷi gaṇanāya pana sā aṭṭha paññāsa bhāṇavārā hoti iti
translated: Consists of fifty-eight chapters in the enumeration of the text.

original: Visuddhimaggapakaraṇaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: visuddhi magga pakaraṇam niṭṭhitam
translated: The treatise called The Path of Purification is finished.
